text: I've wanted to use a camera slider for a while now, but the price tends to be quite high for these.A slider allows you to mount your camera onto a "track" and do nice panning shots while remaining steady. You've probably seen plenty of these shots on TV, Movies and Music Videos.This particular slider comes in at just under 3 1/2 feet. Due to the placement of the camera mount, there is about 3 feet of usable space on the slider.Included with the slider is the track (39.5"), 2 feet with adjustable sides to help level it, 1 "slider" with a 3/8" or 1/4" camera mount (to mount either your camera directly or another ballhead/mount) and a padded carrying bag.I was expecting some assembly, but the entire thing goes together in about 1 minute. The slider locks into place on the track and has an adjustable "lock" mechanism to tighten or loosen it (to get the right amount of movement). The slider itself also has a bubble level to help make sure it's flat.The feet attach with 1 thumbscrew each (no tools needed), and it can be taken apart in about 30 seconds which was great.The one I received is actually a light blue color, not the red shown in the photo. I think the shiny blue still looks nice, but might not fit for everyones style. The majority of the product is black, the slider track is marked with white numbers for distance.Product works nice -- I would recommend some sort of panning head to attach your camera to on top of the slider for more control.Directly under the center of the slider is a tripod mount, to attach it to a tripod instead of the feet for a higher shot. The left/right (where the feet connect) also have 1/4" threading to attach to tripods or lightstands. I haven't tried the center threading (I imagine with a heavier camera, it may be side-heavy), attaching lightstands or tripods to the left/right will probably provide the most sturdy platform.Overall, great price for this item. They do make different lengths (for about the same price) so make sure you find the length you need more. The 39.5" one is a nice size that isn't too big.Note: I received this item at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

Picked this up expecting a full-head mask (front + back), unfortunately despite the description it's only a half-mask (front only, with an elastic strap). Wish I had known as I might have gotten something else.Quality is otherwise good. The hair is much nicer in person than the photo (it's much more full). Looks much more like a  "Planet of the apes" mask in person (due to the hair) than the preview photo.. I was actually hoping it wouldn't look like a planet of the apes mask and more of a generic monkey mask.

I'll start off by saying HDMI cables are essentially all the same. It's a digital signal, so as long as the signal gets across, it won't degrade. On the other hand, there are different versions (1.1, 1.4, etc..) which each have additional features. TV control over HDMI, Ethernet, 3D or more. From what I can tell, these cables are the latest version of the standard.The difference in quality is really just the shielding, and the one on this one is pretty nice! It's a thick cable housing with a nice appearance (black/gray) whereas most I've seen like this have a bright color like Red or Blue.The downside of these thicker cables are that they're often very stiff and hard to move around when trying to plug into the back of a TV (the cheaper cables are actually nice as they're very flexible). Fortunately, a right-angle adapter is included, allowing you to get into hard to reach spots on the TV or Home Theater accessories.With all this said.. I'm a bit hesitant to continue using it due to the other reviews. Several reviews are reporting that the connector simply broke off, getting lodged into their TV. Not a good thing! I'll see how it holds up and update this if I have any issues. For now, it's fine.Note that this product was received at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

I'll start off by saying that Tomb Raider being a temporary-exclusive for the XBox one is what sold me on the console. Loving the first game, I didn't want to wait a year to play the sequal on the PS4.To rate the game fairly, I did complete it prior to this review (not 100%, but story mode). Completed the game with 61%. Accoring to Xbox, I played 10 hours. 523 enemies killed, 22 achievements earned, 3,226,728 Distance Travelled (feet??)While almost all of the reviews here focused on the positives, I wanted to point out my complaints with the game and why I didn't find it to live up to the hype. I did still enjoy the game, but I know that because this is not rated 5-stars, I will be down-voted.Graphics.. great. Really nice throughout with only a random texture here and there that looks a bit low-res. The rest is nice and polished.Being a big fan of the first Tomb Raider game, I was really looking forward to this one. Unfortunately, it just didn't do it for me the same way the first did.My disappointment comes down to a mix of storyline (it was a bit too "Fantasy" for my style. Trying to mix modern day "bad guys" alongside Magical baddies). I will say I'm not a fan of the "Fantasy" style in movies/games, so it was a bit of a turnoff. I didn't notice this at all in the first game, and to be honest, the story in this one reminded too much of a Resident Evil game for some reason.Characters: Same problem.. just didn't care for them. Might just be me, but I found myself a bit bored with them (and the story), but again "YMMV" as I'm just not into the fantasy genre much.Moves: Lara has a bunch of neat moves, weapons and they're upgraded throughout the story. While I did not see a New Game + mode, I did like the fact you can free-roam to complete the other side-quests after you finish the story line (and going through the game, I didn't have some of the stuff I needed to access these side-quests at the time, so it's perfect).Micro-transactions: The game has a Season Pass (30 bucks) and I have no problem with that. It also has "Card Packs" you can purchase for real money which I believe unlock additional items (costumes, skills, upgrades) which I'm not a fan at all of. While not necessary to enjoy the game, I much would have preferred these be included in the game itself, the season pass, or separately without playing a game of chance with the cards.Variety: It felt like there were really 3 locations in the game to me. A snowy/icy area, a fantasy village/town and a modern day/dry area. While going through the locations, it kept feeling to me like I was just going from one of these cities to the next, then repeating. They are nice, don't get me wrong, but it didn't feel like the variety the first game had.Gameplay: And here's where I had a bit more of a problem. You learn "moves" (climbs, swinging, jumping, rope sliding) and then find yourself repeating these over and over. Every location has the same textures (white "skidmarks" indicating a spot you can run up.. white railing indicating an area you can climb, bumpy wall indicating you can climb it or wood indicating you can shoot arrows at it). This is true regardless of where you are -- modern city, icy area or fancy village all have the same looking textures, and you perform the same moves to complete it. In the end, you probably do this several hundred times and it feels a bit old like they're having you do it just to do it. While fun at first, I found it got old a bit quick. Same applies to fights. Fight 3-guys, 5-guys, then a whole group of them (with one who is heavily armored), repeat. Lastly, collecting items along the way became a constant thing. Everywhere I go, I'd scan the area for anything I can use, collect them all, and then head to the next area -- I found I was still constantly running out of weapons in battle, despite collecting every item I could find.Puzzles: I found the puzzles to be interesting. I did find some to be a bit challenging (or not as obvious as I would have expected) but I was able to get through them all.In the end, I'm happy I got it. I won't be playing the story again (while my first thought when finishing the last tomb raider was "I need to play that again!") but I will continue to complete the side-quests.I didn't find it to be the great exclusive I was expecting years after the first game.. but it was a fun 10'ish hours. I don't recommend it, I just would have preferred a bit more variety to it and maybe a story that didn't involve so much "fantasy". If you're into that though, you might appreciate it more than I did!

Having bought a TV for a second room, I needed a stand and wanted to go for a rolling one to get the most flexibility out of it (rolling it when needed to make more space).I liked the look of the Vivo and the price was one of the best I've seen. Most rolling TV stands cost more than the TV itself.Opening the box.. it's intimidating. Hundreds of screws, bolts, washers, metal beams, tools and more. Fortunately, I found out at the end that most of these are extra parts that will vary depending on the TV you're installing. In total, I would say there are about 30 bolts that need to be attached.Setup time took about an hour. Included are 4 tools to assemble.. the only other tool I needed (not included) was a phillips head screwdriver to attach the tray. One very big issue I encountered was that one of the holes on the legs (to attach to the base) was not aligned properly and wouldn't fit (triple checked to make sure I was doing it right). Fortunately, swapping legs, the matching hole on the opposite side was also slightly offset just enough to let me attach it. If this weren't the case, I wouldn't be able to assemble it (and drilling a bigger hole is tough considering the strengthened material).Design is nice. I particularly like the "short" legs in the back, which make it possibly to put into a corner of a room. The 2 beams are a neat idea also (most seem to use 1 beam).When setup, the wheels will help move it around the room and the TV can tilt forwards and backwards.Overall feel when assembled was very secure. Used it with a 40" TV and had no worries about it falling over. Make sure you use all of the necessary bolts and tighten them.With that said.. some issues:Cable management.. is terrible. The expectation is that you'll run your cables from the ground, up the ~5 1/2 feet tube, out the top, pull it back down and attach it to the TV. To do this, you'll need about a 12 foot cord and most power cables included with TVs are maybe 3-4 feet. There is no "exit hole" on the front, only on the very top and very bottom of each pole.This also means that using the optional tray, the wires will can't enter the cable management tube. I found both of these issues better addressed by simply using velcro cable wraps an securing them to the outside of the tubes.Problem #2: The tray. There are about half a dozen positions heights you can put the tray at, and the highest is maybe 2.5-3 feet. The pegs are only on the bottom of the pole. This might be fine for a 65" TV, but anything smaller, the tray seems a bit too low and out of place at even the highest setting.In the end, price was great, cable management and tray aren't a dealbreaker and this thing is tough. Recommended if you need one!

Having never tried an LED bulb, I was curious how well they would work. Picked this one up and was immediately surprised by the size (about 2x the size of a CFL). Plugged it in and immediately saw a huge difference in brightness. Lit up the entire room! Very nice, will definitely look into purchasing more of these.Note that due to the size, if using in a standing lamp or light-socket, it may be too large to fit (or will stick out more than a typical bulb will). I was fine with this sacrifice for the increased brightness.Note: I received this bulb at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

Purchased these as I needed a few extra HDMI cables - compared to the big box stores, 2 of these come to half the price of 1 of their cheapest cable.Fortunately, being a digital cable, there isn't much difference between a low-end and a pricier one.. the cables to feel well worth the price (not too thin) and gave me no issues. Tried with 1080p and it worked great.  Would purchase these again if the price is right.. better than most "cheap" ones I've tried.Note: I received these cables at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

I'll start off by saying I really wanted to like this. I was hoping for a compact replacement for my other bluetooth car receiver, but in the end it's become a "backup" instead.I own the Flexsmart x2 receiver, so some comparisons will be related to that.. and then I'll state why I found this one to be inferior.Design: I found the design to be both "nice" and a bit troublesome. It's very compact but has a very "cheap" plastic feel to it. There are a total of 3 buttons on it: CH+, CH- and the orange button. The orange button is used to answer calls and I believe also play/pause music. On the left are 2 red LED-lit charging ports (USB cable not included) and to the right a display stating the station you're "broadcasting" to.Design Problems: I didn't think of it at first, but when plugged in, it sits about 1-2 inches in front of your cigarette lighter. This means that to answer calls or play/pause, you typically need to lean down pretty low to reach it (depending where your cigarette lighter port is at). The bright orange button also turns to a solid black at night time, so it's not as noticeable as you would expect. Not a huge deal.Because the adapter sits so far back into the car (opposed to a "gooseneck" adapter like the Flexsmart) I found that anything in the cup-holders will block access to the adapter.Ports/Power/Usability: I found the power to come on quickly, it fortunately has 2 USB charging ports and they're lit to find easily in the dark.It's pretty easy to use -- turn it on, set a station, connect to it and tune to that station on your car.Problems with ports/power/usability:There are no ports -- my other adapter has a 3.5mm input to connect to a non-bluetooth device. No deduction in score, because this one doesn't advertise this.THE POWER IS ALWAYS ON - This is my biggest problem. Even with the car off, the device stays on and provides power. This may be car-specific, but doing this will cause your battery to drain overnight or when not in use. This is a problem as if you don't see the adapter (for instance, it's behind a cup), it will create problems. It's also a downside to not be able to leave it plugged in at all times. The flexsmart has a power on/off button to turn it on.. the power off on this only turns off the LCD screen but leaves the power coming through (and LEDs on)There is no volume button (not a negative, just point this out as the flexsmart does have one, it's sometimes useful but not needed).I found that sometimes my phone would not connect to it automatically and had to turn bluetooth off and then back onIn the end... it works. If you have a car that will cut power to the auxillary port when turned off, it's not so bad. For me, I just can't recommend it. Wanted to love it, I'll keep it still, but it's just not what I was hoping for. Check your car first to see if it will work better - if your aux port is in a better spot than mine, it might be a better buy.Note that this item was received at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

Purchased this as it seemed like a neat idea -- small, portable christmas lights powered by 3 AA batteries.Product includes battery box (clear) with attach string of lights and a screw.Battery box has an On/Off switch (solid only, no flickering or chasing). I found the on/off switch to not work too well. When On, it was loose and kept flickering because it was moving between on/off very easily (even when left alone).The light strand is thin and very flexible (not like normal xmas lights). The battery box takes 3 AA batteries, so it gets to be a bit bulky. There is no clip on it to attach to a belt, for instance, it must be held in place or put in a pocket if used on a person/costume.The battery box was difficult to open -- it has a screw that needs to be removed each time (if you choose to use it) and while the battery door was easy to take off, it was a bit tricky to put back on.I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

Purchased this mask for a Hotline Miami costume. A lot of the masks you see online don't actually appear the same way in person -- either quality has gone down significantly, the mask is extra floppy or has other issues. This mask was surprising in that it seemed very well made and painted, the eye holes were hidden well and it worked perfectly.The only issue is with the red part at the top of the head, it constantly fell over to one side -- this was fixed by adding a small piece of cardboard to keep it stiff.I didn't have any issues with the hair shedding and it looked nice when it arrived (didn't need to be brushed).Attached image is one we used this mask for -

Purchased this 2-pack of bottles as it was available at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review, and I had a use for some pump-bottles.Included are 2 amber colored bottles, 2 black pump-tops and 2 pieces of twine and nametags.The nametags and twine didn't do much for me -- they definitely give it an 'artsy' sort of look and mix well with the product but I was more interested due to the tinted color.The 2 I received came white and rectangular nametags (apparently they use a variety of them in different shapes, so you may receive some mismatched ones).The bottles themselves are pretty solid. They're not a very soft-plastic, which is nice, and the pump has a wide tube so they work well. I found the bottles themselves to be a bit nicer than the multi-pack clear colored ones that tend to be sold in a pack for a lower cost.In the end, the bottles worked fine. I think the asking price is a bit much -- it's not so much that the product feels cheap, but rather that the price much be too much for this type of item in general. The only real thing I found that it has going for it which differentiates it from the others are the color and the included twine + nametag. If that's exactly what you're looking for though, you may find the item more useful.I didn't find anything particularly wrong with it, rather I just didn't find anything too special about it to justify the higher asking price.

The Fifth Element was one of the earlier Blu-Rays (2006) and had its share of problems. In 2007 it was released as a Remastered disc which improved on many of those issues.In 2015, it was released under sony's new "Remastered in 4K" series in 2 different formats: A Blu-Ray only version and a "Supreme Cinema" series which includes a book. Both versions include the SAME disc.. the supreme cinema series only includes a book alongside it.Owning several versions of The Fifth Element on VHS, DVD, Superbit DVD, UMD, Digital download and all 3 Blu-Rays.. I definitely prefer the current Blu-Ray.Video-wise, I found it to be a slight upgrade over the earlier blu-rays (it's a bit more vibrant, but other than that it's not too noticeable)Audio-wise, it not includes a 7.1 Dolby Atmos soundtrack which was amazing (and sounded like an upgrade even on a non-atmos setup compared to the 2011 release)Extras-wise, it includes all of the features available from the DVD that never made it to blu-ray (on the downside, they're not in HD).In the end, is it worth it?I hear the Supreme Cinema book has its issues, but the standalone release comes in a nice slipcover and normal blu-ray case, looks better, sounds better, has a bunch of extras and is definitely affordable.You won't see the same upgrade as in other titles like Leon (regular blu ray vs. re-release) but for a fan, I'm not disappointed. I find it to be the best version of the film so far.

Surprisingly cheap for such nice quality (and quantity!)Stickers are a bright red/orange with black text. I found these to be nicely printed (a lot of the "Biohazard" stuff has been very faded, for some reason) -- purchased these more as a novelty, but would work fine as an actual usable product.Roll is decent sized and contains 500 (!) stickers. Sticker quality is nice, easy to peel and stays on and easily visible. good size (2") -- recommended!Only problem will likely be using all 500 of these. Even if used for a party, you'll end with hundreds left over. At the already low price, I can't see the price going down any even if offered in a set of 50 or 100.

Purchased these for use with alcohol-activated paints.Note that these are "detail brushes" and are very thin and narrow to get small, precise lines. If you're looking for more of a general brush, you'll want to look elsewhere.(Note that I'm holding these to a higher standard as they're considered to be AIT ART's "Premium" line -- they also sell standard brushes at about half the price (same price for double the brushes))Having used a variety of brushes ranging from the throwaway-type (dollar-store quality) to higher-end and special FX brushes, I'd say these are somewhere inbetween. You definitely notice a difference when using higher end brushes, but these are almost much nicer than the standard discount variety brushes.The brushes come packaged in a protective  (light cardboard) box that can be re-used for storage if needed. I wouldn't call it a "nice" box by any means, but this set is also not advertising it as a storage box (like some of their other products include), so this is just information-only.The brushes all came with individual plastic sleeves to protect them during shipment, and the included details note a 1-year satisfaction guarantee if you have any trouble with them.I used each of the brushes multiple times and compared with others (such as the bdellium brushes) and found the results to be generally good. Some of the brushes did seem to be a bit sparse on fibers and one in particular didn't work well at all with painting (the largest bristled brush). Purchasing these for details, I was more concerned with the smaller brushes and they seemed to work generally well.For cleaning, I used the strongest cleaner I had: Cinema Secrets Brush Cleaner which cleaned the brushes quickly and none of the fibers were released (some of the lesser-prices brushes will lose hairs or loosen up in this cleaner).Design-wise, I think they look nicer in the photos. I found them to look a little "cheap" in person compared to the photos which show a nice shiny chrome look, but it doesn't affect the quality and the brushes still look "OK" -- again, I'd say it's inbetween the cheap brushes and the nicer ones (a bit closer to the "nice" side than the "cheap" side).After purchasing, I received an email from AIT offering a discount on future brushes. To be honest, I don't feel like I'll be using this discount on another set (this was the only "premium" brush set I found from AIT, and I'm not sure if I'd like to see what their standard brushes are like).I purchased these brushes at a discount in exchange for an honest review. I'll be keeping the brushes and continuing to use them, I just don't know if I would consider them to be the "premium" they're being advertised as.

May have just received a "bad batch" but the stickers I received were all very difficult to remove. The cuts to separate them seemed to dig too deep into the backing, so trying to peel a sticker resulted in peeling the paper up. Took maybe 3-4 tries to actually get the sticker to remove (each time).With that said, the price was great, size was good (about 3/4" -- good for single use item, but doesn't draw a lot of attention, can be easily overlooked) and you get a good amount of stickers.Ended up ordering a 2nd set.

Purchased these as a decoration/prop so I'm not too upset with how they turned out, but for anyone purchasing them based on the photo, the ones I received were different looking.Item comes on a roll (bags are torn off)Red with black letteringPrint is on one-side only (not both)Print is very light, almost like it's been worn off or printed with "Low Ink" even when first opened.No "Biohazard" text, only says "INFECTIOUS WASTE" and has the logo.  The ones I received had the logo/text repeated twice on the one side and blank on the other.Bags were small -- would not fit my 3 gallon cansThey should work fine, but for anyone wanting it as displayed, it doesn't show up this way

I've been looking for some bright markers besides the paint-pens sold at craft stores. Came across these and decided to give them a shot -- includes 8 pens in a nice set of colors (including white), all showed up very vibrantly and run out of "ink" while writing (problem with others I've tried)Works on a nice variety of materials -- can't comment on the longevity of them yet, but really enjoying them so far. Would buy another set for sure.(Note: This product was received at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review)

I'll start off by saying I have a big selection of "good" cameras (ranging from mirrorless to DSLRs) but there's something neat about an instant film camera. Being able to take pictures and have no clue if they'll turn out (and each one costing you money) is a bit scary to jump into, and there will definitely be shots you don't like.. but that randomness is one of the more enjoyable parts to it.I originally purchased the Mini 8 camera and the 210 "Wide" camera. I immediately loved the Mini8, but the 210 Wide seemed much less user friendly (huge, lots of settings that aren't very clear, different focus distances to set), but I bought it for the "wide" prints (as big as 2 Mini prints).Unfortunately, the 210 Wide camera just gave terrible results. Some parts overexposed, some underexposed, while the same shots with the Mini8 were beautiful. The 210 also required a bit more (twice the batteries, larger film, a "closeup" adapter (that arrived broken). In the end, I sent the 210 back and kept the Mini 8.The Mini 8 is actually a nice size. It's a bit bulky, but nothing too bad at all. It's very easy to use (open the lens, it will tell you which setting to pick (a LED will light up), select it and press the shutter button. There are "settings" for indoors, outdoors, High-Key, etc..  and with the light up LED it's very easy to tell which you need to use.The viewfinder is relatively close to the lens, giving a "pretty accurate" representation of what the shot will look like. The viewfinder on the 210 was a bit too far from the lens and always gave me odd framing.The Mini8 uses the Instax Mini prints -- they come in packs of 10 (usually in 2-packs -- 20 shots). The camera will hold 10 at a time, so one thing to keep in mind with the size is that unless you want only 10 shots per outing, you'll need to bring extra packs and that's where the cost (and extra bulk) come from.I like the way the prints look. They're definitely a vintage/washed out/overexposed look most of the time, but it's neat to have! I would say it would be fine for kids to use, except they may be a little trigger-happy with the shutter button (and 10 shots = about 10 bucks).Overall, I really like it. I wasn't expecting to (I was expecting more from the 210 wide instax to be honest) but it impressed me so much, I ordered 8 extra boxed of film for it.

I originally picked up an Instax Mini 8 and loved it. It was a nice, convenient way to get portable prints. Only problem was that the prints were really small. About the size of a credit card (and thats including the border -- the actual print was much smaller than that).I saw a lot of mixed reviews on the 210 (and 300) "Wide" cameras, but decided to chance it.Right off the bat, the thing is huge (talking bigger than a high-end DSLR huge) and feels very plastic'y. I'm fine with both of these, I use DSLRs and plastic works as long as it works. Problem is, pieces arrived snapped off (like the closeup filter), there are a number of settings (0.9-3 meters, 3 meters to infinity, self-explanatory), Normal/Dark/Light (adjusts the brightness of the image), and most of them aren't very clear. I found I would have to take a shot, wait, adjust from there and hope the 2nd one turns out better.The lens-placement (vs viewfinder) is quite a bit off, often resulting in shots (at least portrait-style) being oddly placed in the frame, but my biggest gripe was that the quality just wasn't comparable to the instax. I'm not sure if it's the lens, the flash, but I found many images coming out both overexposed and underexposed (due to the flash, I believe). Taking the same shot on the Instax Mini 8 resulted in a nice looking image (albeit half the size)I was really wanting to like the 210.. the fact that the prints are twice as big at the same cost ha me very interested.. but after using it (or at least trying to -- the closeup filter was broken) I'll be returning it.I don't really know what they can fix to make it better.. it sounds like the 300 is more or less the same camera.. but whatever they're doing on the Mini 8.. it's working!

A month ago, I've never heard of "Pro Aiir" -- I picked up a bottle at a local event to try out (previously I've used EBA's VIBE (water-based), Endura (Alcohol based), Ben-Nye Magicolor (water-based), Skin Illustrator (Alcohol) and Mehron liquid facepaint).The EBA lines were nice color with a great fragrance, but expensive (sold in 1 oz bottles for about the price of this stuff in a 2 oz. bottle). The Alcohol ones also tended to clog my airbrushes a bit (since so much of it settles in the bottle, even a lot of shaking it will leave clogs).Ben Nye and Meh-Ron were both nice, but only water-based. Skin Illustrator seemed very overpriced for "watered-down" looking colors.Pro-Aiir comes in a few sizes.. I think they sell as low as 0.5 oz. samples.. the common sizes are the 2.1 and 4.2 ounce sizes (they sell 8/16/64 ounce ones, but there doesn't really seem to be any discount on them other than maybe a couple bucks).I picked up half a dozen colors and have had good luck.The liquid works straight out of the bottle (no need to water it down or mix with other stuff), and goes on smooth at a low PSI. I like the way the colors look, they last long (I still can't tell what they mean by "Hybrid" as, as far as I can tell, it's all alcohol-based). The paint is very watery which is nice (Endura tends to be very thick out of the bottle).Some colors seem to have a nice fragrance, others have models complaining (black, for example -- I noticed the "Smells like mildew" comment from someone, which might be a problem with some colors). I've also heard that some colors (like white) need to be worked differently (higher PSI, layered more) to get the same coverage, which can be a challenge if going between lots of colors.One small gripe is that the labeling is very inconsistent. I purchased 6 different ones, and received 3 different types of labels. Not a big deal, but it's nice to have some consistency among bottles.In the end, worked great.. happy with it.. I'll buy more!

Originally picked up one of these from another brand and really liked it. Saw this 2-pack available at a discounted rate and decided to go for it also.Product seems to be identical to the other Silicone Ice Cube Trays (a good thing), has minimal branding on it (not a big deal, but some have a large company name or bright blue color tray opposed to the black of these trays.Makes 2x2" cubes, easy to remove due to the silicone tray (no more "cracking" the ice cubes out).My only complaint is that the trays appear to be made to "stack" (they have a slight groove on them to lay on top), however putting 3 trays in the freezer for 15 hours, only the top one was solid ice (the bottom 2 had a frozen exterior and mostly water inside -- not good for ice cubes). If stacking, a much longer time is required for them all to freeze.Disclaimer: I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

The Skin Illustrator palette's are great.. I saw this liquid being advertised as both a Palette refill and an Airbrush liquid. Seemed like a nice multi-use product and the bottle was decently sized.Unfortunately, with use I just wasn't happy with the value for the price.To me, it seemed way too watered-down with Alcohol (I bought 4 different colors, so it's not just a one-off). They were very thin which made using it with an airbrush very easy, but it was translucent that it was pretty unusable.As a palette refill, it worked better. You squeeze some into your Skin Illustrator palette, mix it in with a brush and then heat it with a hair dryer until it hardens. Nice for that (since until recently, they didn't sell refills), however since it's so watered down, even though you have a 2 oz. bottle it doesn't fill up much of a palette. At the price (about 1/3 the price of a palette) you're better off buying a new palette and getting 10 colors instead of these.

Picked up a few low-lying fog machines and 4 different types of Froggys Fog to try out with them.Went with the Freezin Fog Juice, Velocity, QuikBlast and their un-named generic fog.The Freezin fog is designed for use in a chiller -- the fog will stay low to the ground, but you need to cool it down first. Some fog machine have an ice-basket built in which will help, but once it heats up it will begin to raise.The biggest difference I noticed with the Freezin fog is just how thick it is. I ran it through 400w machines and it went through very smoothe, producing a very thick white smoke/fog -- the most dense I've seen of any fog juices I've tried.. it came out solid white in a way that it can't be seen through.The branding implies it's for use outdoors, and I can definitely see why. Within 30 seconds it can fill a small room with a thick white layer that will keep you from seeing more than a few inches in front of you. The smoke was probably twice as full as their generic fog fluid, and about 5-6 times the Quikblast/Velocity fogs.With that, the "hang time" was very high - it lasted a LONG time indoors, which is why its probably recommended for outdoors (most will dissipate very quickly outdoors). If you're looking for an indoor "haze", this may be too much depending on the size of the room. In a larger area it should work, but in a house it will likely turn into much more than a haze (and look like smoke)Very good at what it does, I was very surprised. Just remember you'll need a "chiller" if you intend to keep it low to the ground. If you're looking for fog that's got a good thickness, is cheap but not as overwhelming as this (for indoors, something that will leave a light haze), look into the generic Froggys Fog bottles. For something that will disappear completely within about 45 seconds (no haze) the Velocity juice is great. For something that will be gone in 20-25 seconds, look into Quikblast.

Normally a big fan of Pee Wee content, I was looking forward to seeing this.I remember seeing the 1981 special about 10 years ago and enjoyed it, I've always liked the movies and TV show.. I figured this would be a great watch. And for the most part, I did enjoy it.The Blu-Ray clocks in at 89 minutes (including a short intro and credits) and I felt that the show may have run a bit better at an hour long.The set design was perfect -- looked straight out of the 80's show. Almost like the entire set was put into storage and cleaned off, looking good as new. Everything seemed to be in place, the props were all there.. great job and probably one of the best things to see in the special.Camera work was also good - lots of moving around, different camera angles and cameras setup for specific shots.. they did a nice job filming it!Video was also good - while only 1080i, I didn't notice the issues some have (with motion). Audio was in english and english closed captions were also included - I didn't see any other issues. Blu-Ray is listed for Regions A, B, C but one of the reviews states it ONLY works in Region A players.The show plays out as an hour and a half long stage show and they do keep a pretty good flow throughout. My issue with the show is that so much of it was re-used from the 1981 special (Live at the Roxy - available on DVD). What I mean by this are that not only are jokes similar or references to the earlier show, but the same lines are used (almost throughout the special) nearly word-for-word.The new content making current references (such as 4square and twitter) also came off a bit odd - I was almost expecting to hear "Myspace" references in it!The show is still entertaining (though I did feel it went a bit long), but it would have been nice to see more than the same jokes. Even the "Mr. Bungle" short film makes an appearance in this one, while characters from the original show (Captain Carl/Phil Hartman) are missing (for obvious reasons), having some of their jokes/references moved to other characters.The only extra is an audio commentary (which is a nice bonus). I would really have loved some behind the scenes features such as bringing the playhouse back and making it look so authentic 30 years later.I was really looking forward to this, but seeing it was almost a word-for-word remake in parts, it left me a bit disappointed.

Recently purchased "QuickBlast" (or "QuikBlast") from Froggys Fog - it's meant to be a very fast dissipating fog (gives smoke/fog effect but then disappears completely within about 10-15 seconds). QuickBlast is made mostly for up-shot foggers like a Chauvet (fog shoots up, quickly disappears) and did a good job at that.Velocity is very similar except it has a longer hangtime of closer to 45 seconds. I found this to be a good time if not using an up-shot fogger. It will give you the fog you want but then quickly disappear completely. When I say "Disappear Completely", I mean that it won't leave a trace of haze.One of the big problems of using fog machines indoors are that most fogs leave a haze in the air after the fog goes away.. and this can last quite a while or require you to open windows, doors and turn on fans. Velocity and Quickblast are nice in that they give you the smokey fog effect then disappear.Note, if you want to keep the haze around (for effect, ambient or to use with lazers/lights, etc..) you won't want to use this fog.

I've used a variety of different fog liquids in the past - some will come out as a thick white smoke, others a very mild "hazy" look, some will hang in the air as a haze for 20-30+ minutes.. I wanted something that will give a nice smoke effect but then disappear quickly after.QuikBlast did a nice job at this. It seems to be made for "quick blasts" of smoke (such as an air cannon or a Chauvet Geyser that fires upwards), but it did work fine in both a regular and low-lying fog machine.The liquid is odorless and the 1 gallon size will go a long way. The smoke came out as a nice thick smoke and began to fade very quickly afterwards. The biggest difference is the lack of a constant haze after using it. Most liquids when used indoors will keep a layer in the air until completely aired out, this one tends to disappear within about 30 seconds (for the most part) and should be totally cleared within a minute.Froggys makes several different liquids in this type (QuikBlast, Velocity, Fast Dissipating Fog) and I wish there was a better description of each, since they sound similar.If you're using a geyser machine, this is the fog you want. If you're using it for stage/effects and want something that will give the effect but not linger on for more than a minute, this stuff works nice!

Picked this up to replace another air-vent mount that uses a push-to-close method of gripping, which stopped working as well.This one uses a "Pull to open" method instead, providing a constant grip on the phone which is much better.Product quality is good, the grip is tight and it's compact. A ballhead allows rotation as needed to get the right angle.Unfortunately, the large clip makes it difficult to attach to some vents. My prior mount used a slim spring grip (and had a support mount to keep the vents from drooping down) while this one uses 2 different grip mounts. I found the grip was too large in size, no matter how I used it. I was able to get it to fit, but in doing so it puts pressure and stretches the air vents out.The weight of the product also causes the vent to droop (most other air vent mounts I've used have had the optional support brace to prevent this.Nice product, I love the size and the grip, but the other issues prevent me from giving it 5 stars.Note: This product was received at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review

Many people enjoyed Windows 8 (and 8.1), but many also didn't. Windows 10 seems to try to satisfy both sides and does a good job at it.Included in this package is a USB drive for installing Windows 10 (a change from the DVDs used in past versions, but a necessary one seeing that many newer devices no longer have a CD/DVD Drive). Note that if you download Windows 10, you can create a bootable USB copy within windows.NOTE: Windows 10 is also available FREE to those currently running Windows 7, Windows 8 or Windows 8.1 -- if you own these, you DO NOT need to purchase this. If you're running Windows XP, Vista or no copy of windows at all (building your own PC) this is the product you want.I've been running windows 10 on 3 different systems: Tablet (Surface Pro), Desktop and Desktop (with multi-touch).Installing: None had any issues, all drivers & programs worked right off the bat, including multiple monitors, hard drives and input devices (including wireless mice, keyboards, Wacom tablets)Windows now uses a combination of the Windows 7 start menu and Windows 8 "start screen" -- the start menu is back, but now includes a small section for pinning apps to (similar to windows 8). You can re-arrange, resize and remove these as needed. Modern apps (form the Windows App Store) still feature live tiles, so if you pin a Weather app and Email app, you'll see how many unread emails you have and a brief overview of the weather.You can bring back the Windows 8/8.1 start screen in the options if you prefer it (such as using a tablet)Opening any apps are now standalone and resize-able. In windows 8 and 8.1, these ran full screen and could be cut down to half-screen. In Windows 10 you can resize them and move them around like any other program. This is nice since some applications are useful to have (such as an Instagram client, which doesn't have a native Windows application) without forcing it full-screen. New apps can be downloaded from the Windows Store. Apps can be stretched to "full screen" like in Windows 8/8.1, but are not required.There is now a Notifications center. Get a twitter message, 4 emails and 2 instagram likes? you can see these instantly in the Notifications Center (similar to that on a smartphone)Also new is "Cortana", the virtual assistant. Cortana is similar to Siri on an iphone (and Cortana has been available on Windows Phones for a while). It docks near the start button and allows you to either talk to it ("What time is it in New York?", "What it 50 x 143?", "Remind me to buy eggs tomorrow") or type in the search box.  This is nice as it scans your email and includes information - I placed an order on eBay and got a shipping email and Cortana offered to track it and provide updates for me. I know some won't like Cortana, but if you use it a few times you'll find it useful.Icons have been updated - they look much more basic than the Windows 8/8.1 icons -- not a huge fan of these (everything in the file viewer seems to be made to look too clean/basic) but I'm also not annoyed by them. Everything does seem to be a bit smaller (such as the taskbar buttons for applications).Virtual Desktops are new, allowing you to create a 2nd or 3rd desktop and quickly switch between them. This is useful if you want to have one setup for art (Photoshop, Illustrator) and another for web browsing, without being overhwelmed with open applications at the same time. Click to Desktop 1 and you'll only see the photoshop/illustrator programs, click Desktop 2 and you'll only see the browser. Even nicer, the "Task View" button on the taskbar will give a quick overview of all open windows: If you have 5 browsers open, this will show a live preview of each and let you quickly locate the one you're looking for.Classic applications all work - I did an in-place upgrade from Windows 8.1 on 3 computers and had NO incompatible hardware or software.The "Favorites" option in the file viewer has been replaced with a Quick Access option that provides similar functionality.Windows Snap is back - drag a window to the left or right side and it will snap to that half of the screen. This includes a new 1/4 snap feature if you drag it to a corner (it will snap to that corner, taking up 25% of the screen and allowing you to snap more windows)Xbox is now built into Windows 10.. sorta?Xbox allows you to stream games from your Xbox One to your Windows 10 PC. This is done over the network and seems to work well. I would recommend a wired network for both the Xbox and PC, but it works fine on wireless if not needed for super-quick movements. NOTE: You'll need to plug your Xbox One controller into your PC (you can't use it while connected to your XBox One, from what I can tell). There will apparently be a wireless adapter coming later this year.Speed: Speed was about similar, possibly a bit faster for me than Windows 8 and 8.1. The earlier version was already very quick and Windows 10 seems to improve on that.The Charms menus (holding your mouse in the corner) from Windows 8/8.1 have been removed, and replaced with a much easier to use (in my opinion) set of options in the Notifications Center.I've been really enjoying Windows 10, especially since it is offered as a free-upgrade to earlier OS owners. If buying a new OS (none installed, or using something before Windows 7) this is a nice upgrade since it has the best of both worlds.If upgrading, you will have a very easy option to "roll back" to windows 8 or 8.1, but this option is only available for 30 days after upgrading to Windows 10.If I did have a complaint, it's that the OS doesn't seem like a large upgrade over 8.1. In fact, I could have seen them releasing this as 8.2 (or 8.5) since most of the features people will use are added on. Additionally, some stuff appears to be heavily updated and running in a newer, more modern view while other programs are running in a dated-looking classic view. An example is the Settings menu which provides a very visual and large modern experience to change settings, while the Control Panel looks the same as it did 10 years ago. My Computer looks the same as Windows 7 while other parts seem brand new.  Lastly, some user interface elements seem a bit dated - the start menu (if removing the recently used items) has a large blank space that you can't add on to. This seems like a big oversight.I feel a bit odd giving this a 5 star rating, but I honestly feel Microsoft did a good job at this. I upgraded all 3 of my workstations and have been using Windows 10 for a while without issues (it was previously in a pre-release state for the public to install). No blue-screens, everything worked (applications & hardware) and seems to be improved.Recommended!

Picked this up because it was cheap.. really cheap! About 20 bucks for the machine.Item itself is fairly small/compact and the handle is really nice. Doesn't hold much fog juice, but also doesn't need to (it goes a long ways)Cap in back of machine unscrews to let you fill it with fog -- the fog container is not removable (like some machines) so if you want to change fog liquid you'll need to pour out the old fluid.Machine warms up in about 3 minutes and runs for about a minute before needing to heat up again (about 1 minute). Light on remote turns green when ready, hold to release fog (NOTE: You need to HOLD the button - some machines have an "On" button to keep constant fog, this doesn't)Output is good with the cheaper fog liquids, but the higher-end ones (like Froggys) seemed to be too much for it.Had mine for a few months, used maybe 20 times (about 15 minutes at a time) and it just stopped one day. Pump works, but a burning smell comes out (and leaks brown liquid.. probably not good).Contacted the company, apparently it only had a 30 day limited warranty (???), I guess for the price it's expected.Fog output was decent while it lasted. I'd probably buy another one if it was a bit more reliable (if  you need it and it just "doesnt wanna work" any more, you're kind of out of luck)With that said, if you only need it for halloween, it's not a bad machine. Keep in mind you need to hold the button on the remote to fire it.I'd honestly look into the 1byone machines on Amazon if you want a cheap fog machine. Not much more and seems to be better quality.

This is a nice "Good" fog at a low price. I used this with a Low-Lying Fog Machine (400w) and had no problems running it through the 400w machine. Compared to the halloween fogs sold in stores, the price is better and quality is higher.It's hard to see, but this is "Froggys Fog" which is a maker of some of the best fog liquids out there. It's also the smallest size they offer (from what I can tell). Unfortunately, I can't tell which version of Froggys it is.I will say, this product is for the 32oz size -- you can get a 1 gallon size (about 4x the size) for about twice the price. Keep this in mind if buying for longer-term use.The fog comes in a nice, re-sealable bottle and is odor-free.The fog came out white and a good thickness -- some lower-end fogs will come out as more of a fog, I would say this is more of a thick smoke and if used in a small area will make it very difficult to see through at first.The fog is not fast-dissipating (meaning it WILL hang in the air as a light haze). Some people like this (good for clubs) but can create problems if using it indoors (it will stay looking "hazy" for a good while until aired out). If using outdoors, will work very well.If looking for something that won't hang in the air as long, check out Froggy's version of Velocity or Fast Dissipating Fluid -- these will give the initial smoke/fog but then quickly disappear and not leave a trace.

This fog machine was purchased to replace a much smaller fog machine of the same power (400 watts) - I bought it both as a replacement as well as for the "low lying fog" effect.PRICE: Price was good! I purchased the version with Wireless remote control. There was no remote control in the box. There weren't even instructions in the box. There also wasn't a "Plastic Water Bag" in the box.QUALITY: It works! But see above. Lots of missing accessories.Additionally, the exterior seems fine but once you start using it, it feels very "cheap". The chiller tray i lined with a very thin aluminum and plain styrofoam. The tubes are very light-weight also, something that could present a problem later on.FEATURES: Wireless remote control! (Well, I paid for it but it wasn't in the box. So forget about that). Apparently the wired remote control is the receiver for the wireless one, so if you plan to operate wirelessly you STILL need to plug the bulky wired control in.Wired remote control has a very thick wire, feels good quality but is a basic fog remote (light turns on when ready) but the nice thing is that this is a physical switch to turn the fog on or off. Turn it on and it will continuously output fog whenever ready -- a nice change from the "Hold to shoot fog" that most fog machines use, so I'll give it credit for that.BUILD: Lots of removable pieces.The fog tank is a removable bottle (which is nice - I prefer this over the fog machines that you fill directly into the machine).The cap for it has a hose that goes into the bottle to pull the fluid. Since the hose isn't "locked" in place, you need to make sure it reaches the bottom of the bottle to pull the fog juice out.There is a little white hose coming out the back to drain water (more on that later..) - It's supposed to hook up to a plastic water bag of some sort, but there was none in my box.The front half of the fog machine opens with a latch and a thumb-screw-lid to exposure a compartment to add ice to (more on that below also..)FUNCTION: So it's pretty straightforward. Fill the bottle with fog juice, turn the machine on (and optionally add ice to the chiller box in front), wait for it to warm up and hit the remote control.WARM UP TIME: I found this to be at least twice as long as my other machines (same wattage). It took about 5 minutes to warm up (there was a slight burning smell at that point -- doesn't bother me, but I know it bothers some, so I wanted to mention it). At that point it will fire for approximately 30 seconds of fog. When you first hit the button you'll hear the pump (load) but after a couple seconds that noise goes away.Most fog machines shoot outwards once heated, this one (being a 'low lying' fog machine) has an additional box on the front.. the fog fires into this box, hits an aluminum wall and then moves upwards (this is where ice would be if you add it) and continuing out to the front of the machine.If you fill the box with ice, this will chill the fog and send out a "cooler" fog that will stay low to the ground (most fogs will rise because of the heat). A few issues here are:* The box holds very little ice. I see some of these that hold pounds of ice, I'd be surprised if this even held a full icecube tray worth of ice.* The ice doesn't last long. Within about 15-20 minutes, it was gone)* The ice turns to water and goes out the little white tube in the back. This is supposed to connect to the water bag - if you don't use something to catch it, it will go straight to the floor.If you don't use ice, the machine will work similar to a fog machine (the "wall" might slow down the output, however). It's also recommended to buy "Low Lying Fog" such as something from Froggys Fog and not the cheap stuff.BONUS: If you leave the "ice tray" open, fog will go straight-up (not like a burst, more of an upward-pointed fog machine) which is a nice benefit if you have a use for it.So whats the verdict?Price was cheap, quality seemed cheap (but it works!), lots of missing pieces inside. Warm up time about 2x longer than similar machines and the burst-times were low (30 seconds at a time before needing a minute to get ready for more?), cheap/bargain fog machines are usually better than that. The tubes also seem fragile if you plan to travel with it at all.SIZE: A big surprise was the size -- this thing was pretty big. The ice compartment takes up about half the size of the machine.

Product is  of high quality - a soft foam interior with a soft exterior case (waterproof). There are 2 pieces (a larger one and smaller one) attached by a flexible connector to fit most uses. The smaller piece has 2 suction cups (one on each side), the larger has 5 (2 left, 2 right, 1 center). The suction cups do hold well in place (meaning they won't fall off on their own), however they do slide when coming into contact with water (which is what it's made for) - only mentioning this since it's listed as "Non Slip".Received notice of lifetime guarantee from Gorilla Grip, which was very nice. Product seems of high quality and is priced well.Note, I received this product at a reduced price in return for an honest review.

Having not seen this show since it aired on TV, I wasn't sure how well it would hold up over the years (a lot of shows don't). I decided to take a chance and pick  up the box set, hoping for the best but not having the highest expectations.Shout Factory, the company releasing this product, has had some problems over the years with their releases - even some of their bigger titles haven't had the greatest video presentation. For them to release a full 5 seasons of a show from the 80's,  I was expecting it to be a release to get the content out and not much else.Fortunately, I was wrong -- they did a great job on this release!The set comes in a very sturdy matte-box package (much sturdier than other releases I own which use a flimsy box). This is both nice (sturdy!) but also a bit of an issue as the cases are very hard to remove since it's such a tight-fit. Inside the box are 2 large blu-ray cases (each holding 4 discs -- seasons 1 & 2 on the first case, seasons 3, 4, 5 on the second case, a total of 8 discs)The discs are listed as Region A onlyYou can get  a full listing of whats on each  disc by looking behind the discs inside the case (the case is a transparent blue, so you can view the disc listing). I would have liked a paper insert with this content, but this still works fine!Content: The content holds up surprisingly well. I know a lot of kids' shows don't hold up over the years, but this one is still entertaining today. It definitely requires you to be able to stand the randomness, but if you do you'll love it. Included are 45 episodes, including the Christmas SpecialVideo: This is where my big concern was going to be. This show started in 1986 and was a TV show. Fortunately, it was shot on film and was kept safe over the years..Shout Factory did a complete restoration, scanning and cleaning up the original film content. I believe it was mentioned that while the show was shot on film, it was finalized in Standard Definition with the completed effects. Shout Factory went in and re-created some of these (such as the word of the day) to present the entire show in High Definition. They did a very faithful job on this, and I don't think anyone will be upset. It's presented in 1080i (despite what the box says, its not 1080p), 4:3 ratio (meaning black bars on the left/right)The detail is incredible -- you can see strings on the puppets and the detail on pee-wee's jacket (it's actual a striped black/white very close together, not a solid grey). There is a noticeable grain, and it appears to be sharpened, but the detail seen is well worth it (especially when you compare it to the way it originally looked). Colors are bright and vibrant.Audio: I'm listening on a soundbar and didn't notice any issues. Box stated it's in Stereo/Mono english. English subtitles are included.Extras: The set has a nice set of extras! The Christmas Special includes an audio commentary.  There are a number of (newly produced) extras, including interviews and featurettes. Very interesting to watch now, 30 years later!Overall, highly recommended. The price is a bit high, but considering the content I'm completely satisfied with it. Great job on this release!

I've been a big fan of Robot Chicken since the beginning. Having not seen the new series on TV, I was looking forward to this release.The biggest disappointment, right off the bat, is that there is NO Blu-Ray release this time around. This is weird because not only is it 2015, but seasons 5 and 6 were on Blu-Ray (along with some of the special episodes like DC and Star Wars)The other kind of weird thing is that it comes in a regular (white) Blu-Ray case without a slipcover. Kind of a bummer since the earlier releases had really digipack cases.. this one is kinda plain. Included inside are 2 discs and an episode guide (which is nice to have!)Each disc has about 10 episodes and in total runs 220 minutes. Episodes are uncensored and each has an optional commentary.Content: I still like the show, but I didn't find this series as good as the previous ones. It has its moments for sure and I don't regret picking it up!Video: Unfortunately, it's DVD only. Quality is not up to the standard of the recent blu-rays at all. The disc is anamorphic widescreen ("no black bars") and generally "Good quality" but its "DVD Good Quality", and will be a letdown if you're used to Blu-Rays (including the previous seasons of this). Lots of aliasing, blurriness and compression was visible to me.Audio: I didn't notice any issues, but I was listening on a 2.1 soundbar.Extras: As mentioned above, plenty of commenties but also a 'christmas special' and some behind the scenes features.Overall, a nice package still - I'd give it about a 3.5 (and the earlier sets a higher score).

Came across this while looking for Region Free 3D titles not released in the US.This disc comes region-free (will work in US players). I didn't notice a 2D option on the menu, but I assume it plays in 2D on a non-3D TV/Player. This is real "3D" and not the red/blue glasses type.The disc runs about an hour and 20 minutes, divided into 12 segments.The content seems to be filmed exclusively for the disc. Most is set against a solid black backdrop with a stage in front (not the most interesting) - the part that makes it interesting are the effects used (fog, lighting, projection mapping, reflection), but there are also some CG effects and camera techniques to make it look a little too artsy (routines where the camera angle is is focused only on the shoes/feet for the entire length, and that image duplicated on screen several times). It seems like they tried a little too hard to make parts artsy and it just came off as annoying/boring.The 3D is decent. It's not terribly impressive since most of the girls are on the same plane without much separation (in front or behind) to give depth. There are angles where it works better, but never saw anything impressive with the 3D.Most of the 3D seems to be depth (going further into the TV) opposed to pop out (coming towards you) with a few exceptions. Didn't notice ghosting.A lot of the content seems repetitive ("Didn't I already see this 5 minutes ago??"), is split up with interviews with someone between sets, and seems to be a little long (even at 80 minutes)The disc is dubbed into Russian and has no english subtitles. I imagine I'm not missing much with the dialog between sets, but it's a bit annoying as it was clearly in another language (heard in the background) and has a russian dub playing over it).In the end, it had some neat moments. The fog, lighting and reflections effects were good, the 3D was neat at times, but it just seemed a little too long and a little underwhelming with the 3D. The disc was cheap enough to not be disappointed in it -- another region free option is available with an english dub (for about 10 bucks more), but it honestly wouldn't have been worth the extra money for it.

I use paper seamless in the studio but wanted a more portable option for on-locationshoots.The Impact backdrop comes in a zippered bag about 2 feet in diameter. I'll start off by saying the bag has a really nice loop handle on it (good for attaching to a bag) that will hold up to wear. Using cheap reflectors int he past, these handles always tore off in a matter of a few uses, this one's holding up.The bag is a solid black with the Impact logo on the front  (would've preferred a solid black without branding), theres about a 1x1 foot "window" cut on the front, allowing you see what's inside (helpful if you have a black/white backdrop in one and a blue/green in another)The product unfolds easily (folding it back is a bit trickier, but after a few times you would be used to it)It unfolds to about 5 feet x 7 feet -- it's BLACK on one side and WHITE on the other. Neither side is completely solid (if theres strong backlighting, it ill shine through). It appears to be 2 layers of fabric (one for each color) which gives a nicer feel than the single-piece double-colored ones. It's a nice cloth fabric and not the typical nylon materia I'm used to with reflectors.The backdrop unfolds to a pretty flat shape -- it's also got straps on all sides to attach it to lightstands, backdrop stands, etc.. (I use a "Background disc holder" which attaches to the top of a lightstand and clips the top of this -- seems to be easier with 1 stand, but if you have 2+ stands the velcro may be more stable)You can have someone hold it behind a model, set it against a wall, etc..I've had very good luck shooting with it. It doesn't come out perfectly smooth (the folding will create wrinkles) but it hasn't been a problem for me to easily fix in post.My main use was to isolate subjects instead of using available backdrops in locations that may be too busy to mask out later. Works very well for that.. just keep in mind that there is no "bottom" to this - you won't get a seamless look because it ends at the floor, while traditional backdrops continue underneath the model. Would have been nice if there was an included few-feet of extra material for the subject to stand on to create a seamless experience, but this otherwise works great for anything above the feet.7 feet tall is a great height, it can also be used horiontally if needed for a wider size than 5 feet.Overall, really enjoying it. Much higher quality than some of the other 3rd-party vendors. Paid extra and didn't mind it in this case. Recommended!

Picked this up to hold the Impact 5x7 foot backdrop.For that, it actually works well. Has a decent amount of opening to grip the backdrop (should have no problems with reflectors since most are smaller). Attached to the top of a lightstand (note: there is no 1/4" or 3/8" screw, so it won't work on a tripod).Does NOT swivel (meant to hold it with the opening on the bottom, so you can't angle a reflector), not a problem for me.I found it works best/easiest to attach the clip to the reflector/backdrop FIRST and then attach it to the lightstand.Quality is a bit iffy. Uses a firm plastic for the top piece, metal barrel for to attach to the lightstand and has a metal screw with a plastic handle.First issue, is you need to almost ENTIRELY unscrew the handle to attach it to a lightstand. Every time,  the screw fell to the ground. If on location, you can easily lose the screw. Other issue (based on experience with these same screws on other photo equipment) is that once you reach a certain point, the metal screw will actually tear through the plastic handle. Don't over-tighten  as it can destroy the screw handle also making it useless.With that said, it works and it works alright.Keep in mind this only grips the TOP of the reflector/backdrop. If wind hits it, it will still swing around (I recommend sandbagging a lightstad and possibly also have someone stand behind it to stabilize the backdrop/reflector to keep it from swaying.Overall, happy with it but not perfect

I'll start off by saying that this review is based on a frequent "sale" price of about 25 bucks. Some sellers are offering this fan at 3x that price -- at 2x I'd still recommend it, but more than 40-50 is a bit too much.I own a large number of fans ranging from the cheap plastic table fans to large floor freestanding fans, and these. The reason for buying these were partly the low price, partly the style (which is a nice retro look) and partly because it's easy to clean (the others I own have no easy access to clean them)The fan is built very solid and has a nice metal finish. It comes in either Copper, Stainless steel and Gunmetal black. I would up with the Copper model due to it being the only one on sale and like the look (I was expecting it to look more "copper" than it actually is -- I prefer the color it actually is)It's got a sturdy base, blows a lot of air and has an oscillating mode along with 3 speeds (via turn-knob). I wasn't able to get the up-down swivel to work right, but haven't messed with it much since it's at a good position right now. Cord could be a little longer (I think it's maybe 5-6 feet?) which makes it a little short to put higher up.Quality of it overall is very high -- style is nice (I have a modern looking setup and was wondering how well a "retro" fan would work, but it looks surprisingly nice), air output is very good. Noise is perfectly fine for me (on high) but I know some people have a much lower tolerance for noise.I do wish it had a remote control like my other fans (might ruin the retro look of it though!). There's also no sleep timer option.Liked it enough, bought 2 more!

I tend to use Eneloop batteries and have had very good luck with them over the years -- I've tried the Energizer and Duracell rechargables which just didn't last nearly as long (despite being a "Low Discharge" battery like these) and have had the Energizer, Duracell and AmazonBasics (standard rechargables, not these) go "bad" on me and refuse to charge after about 6-12 months.These batteries are the newest "High Capacity" version of the low-self discharge batteries. Rechargables tend to come in either high capacity (but will drain fast when not in use) or low self discharge (lower capacity, but will last for years of non-use).These batteries try to mix the best of both worlds. You get a higher capacity (2400-2500mAH opposed to 1900-2000 mAH) while still having a long shelf-life of non-use (but not quite as long as the regular low-self-discharge, low capacity batteries).This is for those who tend to change batteries frequently -- an example is photographers changing batteries in flash units. For that, these are great.They're comparable to the "Eneloop XX" or "Eneloop Pro" batteries but at a fraction of the price. Using approximately 12 sets (48 AA) of these batteries, none have yet to show up as damaged (refusing to charge). Price is definitely a nice bonus (you can get 8 of these for what 4 of the Eneloop Pro's would cost), the downside is that the price is still more than any regular (1900-2000 mAH) rechargables would cost.If you need the extra power, these are great! Replaced my old eneloops with these.

Sprained my ankle about a month ago and tried to just manage. Did the rest, ice, compression and elevate, but it was still uncomfortable to walk. It began to get a little easier after a week and a half, but going up stairs or walking for periods of time still hurt. Planning to originally just "sit it out", I then gave in and bought this boot.I picked up a large for a size 11 shoe and it was perfect  (I'd say it would fit up to a size 12). Included are the soft inner liner, the hard plastic boot with velcro straps and some soft insert pads.Putting it together was very easy (it's all held together with velcro), the soft inserts (though small) really do make a difference for comfort.I use this boot part-time (take it off at home and for driving, wear it when I plan to walk around more than just in the house), so I use put it on and take it off once a day. The strength of the straps has held up for sure (even walking for 12+ hours a day) but some of the velcro (on the hard plastic boot) is attached with an adhesive which became a big mess after about a week (it still works, but the entire side of the boot is covered with this adhesive material.There is a blue "pump" button at the top to add air, which is nice, but I tend to not use it much anymore. If you want a more compressed feeling, it does do a good job though!The rubber bottom of the boot holds up very well, despite walking around for long periods of time on various environments.Most importantly, I can easily walk with this for hours. Upstairs, downstairs, etc..Stuff that would normally be hurting without the boot.. it made a huge difference. I don't feel any discomfort from it, and for that it was well worth the price paid. Highly recommended

I purchased this after getting the Ez-Pro 60" Softbox -- the quality was very impressive and ease of use was a huge seller for me. Looking for something of similar quality, I picked up the 12x56 softbox and eggcrate grid.The "EZ PRO" is the important part to look for in their products as they assemble very easily, much like an umbrella. The ribs are very sturdy (fiberglass), much stronger than any umbrella I've ever used. I wouldn't recommend tossing it around, but I don't see it breaking as easy as an umbrella would.The mount is easily swapped out with a screwdriver - great if you own multiple types of lights (AlienBee and Bowens, for example)I'm using this with a speedlight and a Bowens adapter with great results.The stripbox unfolds in a matter of seconds, from there you attach 2 diffusion covers (the inner one can be left attached even when disassembled and in a big), the outer cover attaches very quickly via velcro and makes a nice tight fit (some softboxes have an issue of a 'drooping' cover). There's also a silver dish that connects to spread the light out across the long length of the box.The size is a bit odd (12x56) but that's the point of a stripbox. I would have liked to see the 12x80 inch offered in the NON ez-pro line, but this is as big as I've found.The light folds down and fits into an included bag (the bag is admittedly low quality, but it works). The item, in the bag, dos take up quite a bit of room (much moreso than a simple umbrella), though not as much as the 60" EZ-ProQuality is high -- fiberglass and metal with a good fabric. However, the quality doesn't seem to match up to the 60" octabox (and I'm not sure why, really). For the price, I was expecting a bit more value.One thing to note is that the eggcrate grid is NOT included and is very costly by itself. I purchased the grid and while it is very fragile (be VERY careful when removing it or it will tear), it does work great. Definitely not up to the quality of the softbox, but a useful accessory if you use grids - check the item page for that for my review.Overall, I do highly recommend it and I'm already eye'ing a 2nd one.

I've used plenty of lighting solutions over the years and have always been looking for "the next best thing"Starting with Umbrellas (white shoot-thru and black/silver reflective), I was never totally happy with the light. It worked in a pinch, it was inexpensive, but never gave me anything special in terms of lighting. I quickly moved to the Phottix Softlighter II and loved it -- this was a reflective umbrella with a softbox cover on it. It gave a nice, large light source but the downfalls were the setup process (having to attach the cover to each spoke of the light) and the fragile nature of the umbrella. One fall and the umbrella was toast (which didn't take long)Seeing the Fotodiox lights, I was interested. The "EZ PRO" is the important part to look for in their products as they assemble very easily, much like an umbrella. The ribs are very sturdy (fiberglass), much stronger than any umbrella I've ever used. I wouldn't recommend tossing it around, but I don't see it breaking as easy as an umbrella would.The mount is easily swapped out with a screwdriver - great if you own multiple types of lights (AlienBee and Bowens, for example)I'm using this with a speedlight and a Bowens adapter with great results.The softbox unfolds in a matter of seconds, from there you attach 2 diffusion covers (the inner one can be left attached even when disassembled and in a big), the outer cover attaches very quickly via velcro and makes a nice tight fit (some softboxes have an issue of a 'drooping' cover)The size is VERY large -- I bought the 60" one (upgrading from a 46" Softlighter) and the difference is noticeable. With that said, no regrets at all. I love this light.The light folds down and fits into an included bag (the bag is admittedly low quality, but it works). The item, in the bag, dos take up quite a bit of room (much moreso than a simple umbrella), this is closer to a golf-bag size.Quality is high -- fiberglass and metal with a good fabric.One thing to note is that the eggcrate grid is NOT included and is very costly by itself. I purchased the grid and while it is very fragile (be VERY careful when removing it or it will tear), it does work great. Definitely not up to the quality of the softbox, but a useful accessory if you use grids - check the item page for that for my review.Overall, highly recommended - already looking into buying a 2nd!

This is basically an 8.8 LB brick with a Superclamp attached to it. It's a nice alternative to sandbags and works great on lightstands and boom arms.The package arrives un-assembled and without directions (the orange brick, a spring, a washer and the handle) - the handle/screw/washer all screw into the weight easy and without the need for any tools.The item works fairly simple -- loosen the arm to widen the clamp, attach to a boom arm and tighten down. The big benefits here are the size (fairly small for the weight it has -- something that would likely take a much larger sandbag), the solid shape and the ability to superclamp it onto your boom arm and adjust the positioning (higher or lower on the arm).The downside compared to a sandbag is that you're stuck at 8.8 LBs. With a (non-sealed) sandbag you can easily adjust the weight as needed, with this you're stuck at a solid weight (which may be more than you need). Manfrotto makes these in 3lb, 10lb and 15lb, however the price of this 8.8lb calumet one is less than the Manfrotto 3lb. would cost (and still a high quality).A really nice benefit is the ability to clamp it onto a lightstand -- if you've used a lightstand with an umbrella, you know they can fall over very easily in the wind. Attaching some of these weights to the lightstand (either to the legs directly or to the center column) can hold it down and prevent the stand from tipping in the wind and possibly damaging your light. I've used 2 of these to hold down a 60" umbrella in the wind without problems. With that said, if the wind is blowing hard enough, this may keep the stand from tipping but a weaker umbrella may snap from the force of the wind.

This review is mostly to respond to some of the previous reviews/comments made on the product. This was purchased in June 2015 (in case they have made any changes since the earlier production)Right off the bat, this thing IS overpriced. It's almost the same price as the softbox itself and the softbox is MUCH higher quality.Essentially you get a foldable eggcrate/grid for the 12x56 softbox made of poor materials. The eggcrate comes in a very portable (nice!) bag measuring about 1 foot by about 5 inches.. it folds up very compact and travels in this pouch easily.To attach it, simply remove it form the bag and unfold it to display the giant rectangle shape.. it attaches to the 12x56 softbox with a small strip of velcro. It attaches to the "end" part of the softbox (those saying it's too big or too small may be attaching it to the wrong part.. mine did indeed fit perfectly without any extra room and without any sagging from too much room).As mentioned, the quality is poor. It's essentially a strip of velcro (1 for each side) and the grid itself is made of a somewhat thin vinyl material (think a throwaway tablecloth from a picnic. It's better than paper, but not by much)If used indoors, it should last. The most likely ways it will break are: using it outdoors in heavy wind (the material is so thin, I can see the wind tearing it if it catches it) and removing it. The problem is instead of one long rectangle shape of velcro, it's 4 straight-pieces of velcro (one for each side) all attached by the thin vinyl material. This means if you try to pull it off all at once you'll stretch the vinyl and tear it. The natural instinct is to pull the velcro off completely in one-go, but with this you need to remove each piece one at a time. Doing this will likely make the product last.Overall, it's overpriced. The quality is bad.. but there are no other options and it works. For that, I have to give it 4 stars for those that need it. If there were another option, I would say go with that, but there isn't.

This is actually a pretty nice flash bounce.
