I've made these out of craft foam before and they work good in situations where you need a bright, spread out fill light in a specific direction and don't have much to bounce off of.. but don't have time to set up a separate lightstand.There are essentially 2 pieces: The diffuser/reflector and the strap.Right off the bat, the strap is pretty much garbage. It's too small and too fragile. If you use it (and can get it to fit your flash) the odds are high that you'll find that the diffuser is missing not too much later. If at all possible, I recommend not using it.Fortunately, it is easy to fix. I use 2x velcro cable ties (they usually sell for a few bucks as a 50- or 100- pack), doing this gives extra room and a higher amount of velcro to grip onto.Another option is to line the inside of the diffuser with Velcro and attach the opposite side onto the flash itself OR use a separate accessory like a 'Honl Speedstrap" which wraps around the flash and easily removes. Both will give a much more secure fit (the speedstrap will prevent you from needing to put velcro on the flash itself.The diffuser itself is "OK" in terms of quality. It feels like a cardboard wrapped in a vinyl type of finish. I was expecting a bit more, but overall I think it will be fine.. especially for the price.The diffuser folds flat and locks together using 2 buttons on the back.The way the diffuser works is that the flash fires upwards into the diffuser to light up the inside of it, and "scoop" that larger light source towards your subject providing a (slightly better) light - both in terms of size and diffusion. Larger light = softer (and more background fill).The suggested way of attaching it is not my preference -- I prefer to turn the flash head sideways and attach this item to one of the short ends (still facing forward) which will give extra flexibility (turning the head) in portrait mode so that the flash is always at the top. See photo attached as example.NOTE: The reflector is not transparent at all -- flash will not bounce through it. The full power will go up and forward (the angle of the "scoop"). By unbuttoning the flash, and the card being used flat (no "scoop") you can use it as a fill flash  + bounce (flash will go upwards to bounce off a ceiling, and forward towards your subject.

When using studio lights raised higher-up (and in close) you can sometimes have issues with the lower half of people (feet/legs) being darker on full-length portraits. In most areas you can move your lights, but in a small studio it can be a problem.I picked up this box to help fix that problem.. and it worked surprisingly well!There are NO INSTRUCTIONS and there appear to be missing pieces at first.. be sure to look at the product photos on here to see how it goes together. The item ships with a bunch of metal bars and the "softbox" folded into a small reflector-style circle case. Very compact!The metal bars assemble to form an "H" shape and have plastic clips on the 2 top and 2 bottom bars to hold the softbox open.Remove the softbox from the case and use the "H" to prop it open.It has a bar to attach a studio strobe.. but if you're using speedlights it will work also (but you'll need to find your own mount. I use a Manfrotto 026) The bottom of the inside is coated in silver, so pointing the flash down will reflect it upwards through the transparent diffuser sheet.It's very easy to use, just place in front of your model and adjust the light as needed. Getting inside to the flash is easy (and it closes with a pull-string) and setup/teardown takes less than 15-20 seconds.It holds its shape very well and seems to be made with high quality (especially for the price). I haven't seen any others like this, especially in this price, so it's a nice little purchase.One thing I will mention is to keep an eye on your models' face in photos -- if the power of this is up too high, it will create a weird "lighting from below" where the bottom of their face has spillage from this light which looks weird. In most cases it's not a problem, but keep an eye out for it if you're upping the power.

I read the reviews before ordering this. I don't think anyone praised it for being high-quality (or even "decent quality") but still wanted to give it a chance because I was wanting a grid for the 60" Ez-Pro Octabox.Due to the shape and size of the Octabox, I haven't found any other compatible grids. That means you're stuck with this one (or nothing)The grid comes in a small carrying pouch (which was unexpected and a nice touch). Immediately when opening it, you can tell the grid is fairly flimsy. A lot of people say it feels like paper, and they're not wrong about that. It's not actually paper, it seems like a very, very thin layer of vinyl but it will definitely rip/tear without much effort so be careful. For the price, you definitely expect more (especially considering the value that the Ez-Pro softbox itself is)There are essentially 8 "sides" (flat strips around the edges) with a gap separating them.. this allows you to attach each to one side of the softbox. It actually works really well, but the downside is when removing the grid it's VERY EASY to tear the grid. The key is to remove each strip one at a time and not "pull" it at all like you would be inclined to.The grid connects to the softbox with velcro - the strips are about 1 1/2 - 2 inches wide but the velcro part is very small (maybe 1/4 - 1/2 inches).So why 4 stars? It works, it's the only option out there and once in place the quality is better. What I mean by that is that the grid makes a very nice fit.. a lot of 3rd party manufacturers of photo equipment (looking at you Cowboy Studios and ePhotoinc!)  don't have the best fit. A cover might be too oversized and droop, or too tight to attach without fighting it.. this one went on easy and was the perfect fit. I was kind of surprised with it after the initial impressions. There was no sagging and it functioned just as well as I would have liked (and better than expected). It's unfortunate that the quality is so low as I would otherwise highly recommend them. As-is, I don't know if i'd trust it outdoors and even indoors you need to be really careful with it.

EDIT: This review is written on the original price of about 120 bucks (sold by amazon) -- 3rd party sellers are selling this lens for much more, and at that price it becomes similar in price to the Canon version of the lens.(I own and use a wide range of lenses, mostly faster primes (f1.4), some "L" lenses and some zooms ranging from the entry-level to the mid-range)I've been using Yongnuo products for a few years and have been generally happy with them.. They've been making speedlights for several years and started off a bit iffy but quickly brought up the quality. With the YN35mm f2 being their 2nd lens, I was honestly not expecting much.Tried this one on both a full-frame and crop-sensor camera for the results below.* BUILD QUALITY * : The lens is mostly plastic but has a metal mount. It feels a bit higher quality than the canon 50mm 1.8 but not by much. The lens does not have the distance marker scale that the Canon 35mm f2 has, but otherwise I'm not very familiar with that lens.* ACCESSORIES / BUTTONS * The lens does include a front and rear cap (the lens cap being a nice E-52II comparable cap). Uses 52mm threading for filters.The side has an AF/MF switch for going between modesFrom what I can tell, there is no attachment for a lens-hood. You'll need to buy a threaded (52mm) hood if you want to attach one to this lens. The lens does extend while focusing but the barrel does not rotate.IMPORTANT: For some reason, yongnuo puts a protective cover over the front and rear elements glass of the lens -- be sure to remove these stickers before use.* FOCUSING/NOISE * : The lens does make a loud mechanical noise while zooming, almost identical to the 50mm 1.8 Canon lens. If you're shooting video, you will hear it (noise is fairly loud in both autofocus and manual)The focusing works if you don't need super fast focusing (spots). It doesn't seem to hunt, it's just slow.Focusing is accurate, though, and taking 15 test shots (setting lens to infinity each time and focusing at different distances from minimum (.25m/.8ft) to maximum), all 15 were accurate* COMPATABILITY * : The lens works on both APS (full-frame) and APS-C (1.6x crop) sensors with an EF or EF-S mount.* EXIF DATA * : Lens displays as "35mm F2" (no maker) in EXIF data.. Serial # shows as 00000000.  Other data is shown (such as aperture -- some 3rd party lenses will not display this, or will display the lens as a "50mm" with no additional data regardless of focal length and aperture). I've heard that some peoples' YN35's will display as a Sigma 24-xx zoom lens, so they may have changed this since the first batch.* CLARITY/SHARPNESS * : Surprisingly.. the lens is sharp!I originally tested at F2, expecting some issues, and it performed very well. Clarity was there (even at 100% crop), colors were nice, sharpness was high and the out of focus elements were really nice and smooth looking (some lenses product an ugly out of focus/bokeh area).Moving up to f/2.8 the lens got quite a bit sharper. I would consider it very usable at even f2, but will probably keep it at f2.8 for portraits and to ensure sharp focus.Color fringing was noticeable on a few shots with a high contrast but wasn't bad (lightroom fixed it up quickly), and nowhere near as bad as something like the Canon 85mm 1.8.* PROBLEMS * : For some reason, the lens would not focus properly in live view. I don't know why this is -- it will "hunt" for focus, it will lock in but every time it was very obviously out of focus. I don't know if this is an issue with the camera itself or this particular lens (all other lenses tested had no issues focusing in live-view)Unfortunately I don't have a Canon 35mm f2 to compare it to, but I'm more than happy with this one and would buy another Yongnuo lens without hesitation assuming this one holds up over time.* OVERALL * : Highly recommended, especially if you're wanting a lens a bit wider and faster than the 40mm 2.8 or something to go alongside a 50mm 1.4/1.8

I've used several of the higher-priced airbrush makeups (EBA Vibe, Ben Nye) and was surprised that this one was so cheap for such a large size. Having not used Mehron much in the past, I was a bit hesitant.Fortunately, it did work.. and surprisingly well. I didn't try using it straight from the bottle, I did a mix of about 75% paint + 25% Ben Nye Final Seal to water it down.. Sprayed fine, went on smooth and stayed well (no issues with it flaking off, but as with any water-based paint it will come off with sweat).Ended up buying a couple more.

I've been using the Spyder Express for a few years and have generally been dissatisfied with it. After dealing with odd issues with earlier versions (only designed for 32-bit OS's, crashing profiles, single-monitor calibration, etc..) I wanted something a bit more advanced.During a recent sale I picked up the i1Display Pro 3 (EODIS3).The box includes the USB device, a CD-Rom with the software (download it directly from X-Rite instead.. they have the most up to date version) and a quick-install manual.The USB device has a very plastic'y feel, the dust-cover doesn't seem like something that would protect it too much and the USB cable is very thin (a bit worrying since you hang this on your monitor by the USB cable)Software install is very basic (only 1 install, not multiple like some other calibration tools). It's a bit odd in that it only launches in "DEMO" mode until you plug the i1Display into it (then it unlocks the full version)My uses were to calibrate 3 monitors (LED) for photo editing. I rarely print, so webviewing was my main goal here.There are 2 modes: Basic and Advanced, and they're pretty much what they sound like. Unfortunately, even Basic was a bit "advanced" if you don't know the luminance, color temperature, etc.. that you want (the standard seems to be 120cd/m2 and D65, so I went with those). Without any real instruction, it will easily confuse some users (and keep in mind, this is the basic mode)From there, you go into calibration mode/measuring mode. Place the device on your monitor (you need to tilt your monitor back so the device sits flush on it.. all 3 of my monitors do not tilt backwards, so I actually had to prop them up with something underneath the front.From there, it will either auto-adjust your contrast/brightness (if it has ADC built in) or ask you to do so. What was nice is that it tells you where it's at. EX: 140 (and you want 120). As you adjust it, it tells you how close you are and will eventually give you a green check-mark when everything is good. After that it will flash through a series of colors (approx 2 minutes on basic mode) and then ask to save your profile.In advanced mode, there are many additional options (including an extended large-pallette of colors which takes about 7 minutes to calibrate). You can also view just how close it is (EX you want 6500k and it measured as 6,548k.. you wanted 120cd/m2, it measured 119cdm/2) which is nice.I found my current calibration was already very close, but the brightness was up way too high (around 180, opposed to 120) on all 3 displays. The other changes made by the software seemed to be very minimal, but it did quickly calibrate all 3 monitors.My only complaints:I had this crash my Surface Pro when trying to calibrate with ADC turned on (crashed every time.. worked fine with it off)Crashed an nvidia app (PC) the first time running it.. worked fine after that thoughDefault profile was a v4 profile (which messed up colors in non-supported apps, such as windows photo viewer.. had to re-calibrate with a v2 profile)USB cable seems a bit weak, item is very plastic'y (despite high cost)Other than that, it ran fast and looks good so far. Glad I got it just for the peace of mind (knowing how accurate my monitor was)

I just upgraded from a 7-port USB 2.0 hub to this 3.0 one. Looking around, almost all 3.0 hubs seemed to have issues, this one seemed to "last" a bit higher than the AmazonBasics model and was the same price.The hub has a decent sized (3 foot?) USB cable along with a port cable (it uses the standard sized plug with a "brick" in the middle of the plug, opposed to a brick on the power-plug end (which can sometimes  limit the amount of AC outputs you can use - a nice touch here)The hub itself is a decent size and weight. My original concern was with all USB ports next to eachother (this sometimes causes the larger USB devices like thumb drives to not fit side-by-side.. I had no issues with mine, connecting USB hard drives, thumb drives and more devices.Device was plug and play (as expected) within Windows 8 - all devices were instantly recognized.Each device has a blue LED next to the input, however not all worked. I plugged hard drives into 4 of them and 2 lights lit up. Not sure what that means.It looks like 2 inputs (the far left and right) are a constantly--powered one, so you can plug an iPad, Phone or other USB device in to charge them while the computer is off (un-tested)Unfortunately, on arrival 1 port was only recognized as USB 2.0. I tried 3 drives and 2 cables, all only showed as USB 2.0 connections. All others were USB 3.0..I emailed the manufacturer (when you buy from Plugable/fulfilled by Amazon they send you an email after purchase with contact info), and they offered to send a replacement free of charge (without sending mine back first) which was nice. Most companies require you to send the item back and wait for it to be repaired.. that didn't seem to be the case here. The products seem to havea 1-year warranty which isn't much, but the price of the item itself also isn't much.For the price, I'd probably buy again.

Bio-Dome's been a long time favorite of mine.. had to get the Blu-Ray.The disc contains only the movie (no special features) - the video is pretty good (the first 5-minutes look awful, but once the movie actually starts it's better than I expected. Seems to be a bit over-saturated but that could be how it always looked). A good amount of grain, but the picture is sharp.Audio, on the other hand, is only in DTS 2.0 (the DVD from 13 years ago even had a 5.1 track)This could be forgiven, but the high price on this release makes it a bit iffy -- the movie looks great, sounds "good" for most of it (the beginning was really bad - sounded much better on the DVD).If you're a fan of the movie, it's an upgrade (visually) over the DVD

I'll start off by saying I own a lot of the pricier modifiers -- westcott, lastolite, phottix, etc..I've tried some of the 3rd party stuff and have generally been disappointed ("saggy" diffusers, poor quality product, etc..)After receiving this Neewer 28x28" softbox, I immediately ordered a 2nd one.With that said, there are a few issues.Setup time is super-quick. Literally 30 seconds from bag to set up is possible. The main part of the softbox is an umbrella (no weird metal frames to assemble) and once it's setup you attach it to a lightstand (zipper hole on the bottom) and throw the velcro diffuser on it. Love it.Diffuser quality is nice -- a double-diffusion would have been nice, but the quality is definitely there. Umbrella also seems to be strongly re-inforced.The bottom has a double-zipper for the lightstand to go through. You'll need an umbrella swivel for your lightstand to hold this -- I recommend the "Full aluminum OM-18 Pro" which has become a favorite over even the Manfrotto swivel.The 2 problems here are: There isn't much working room. You want to aim the flash at the back of the umbrella for it to light evenly. Unless you keep it angled, it's somewhat too small to fit in there (even without a hotshoe receiver) unless you stand it up straight and point it towards the back. I prefer to adjust the actual flash to fire right into the back, not at an angle.Another issue is if you're using a manual-powered speedlight, it's a bit tricky to get inside the diffuser to adjust it (fortunately the velcro helps). I recommend flashes which can be controlled wirelessly from the camera (like a Yongnuo YN560III/IV)Lastly, it's not the best for angles. You can only tilt it so much before it gets stuck. There just isn't as much flexibility because the lightstand has to go through the bottom of it. The only solution I found was to put a swivel umbrella on the lightstand, put a short lightstand extension stick on that, put another swivel on the extension and put the softbox through there. Not an ideal (or cheap solution). As long as you're not trying to point the softbox down (without a boom arm) you'll be fine.. but don't expect the flexibility of an umbrella.

I'm relatively new to airbrushes, so I'm not terribly familiar with the different hose sizes, types and materials -- I've been using the 6-foot hose included with the Paasche Talon airbrush and it's been working fine.. until I snapped it.Needing a replacement, and the 10-foot hose of the same type being only about a buck more, I went for this one.Right off the bat, the hose LOOKS the same - it's a high quality braided air hose. Connectors are the same (it will fit the Talon airbrush - not sure about others). Like the 6-foot hose, I did need an adapter to plug it into the air compressor I use (TC-20T air compressor -- if you did not need one with the 6-foot hose, you won't need one for this. I imagine it's more that my compressor has a non-standard sized outlet -- no deduction, just a heads-up!)The hose length is nice -- 10 feet is a nice improvement over the 6 foot version if you need a little more space. I didn't have any leaks in mine (something a few reviews have noted, so do check yours if you order one!)I did notice that the side that connects to the air compressor IS different than the one on the 6-foot hose. The 6-foot one seems to have some better sealing/rubber O-Rings, while the 10-foot version seems to rely more on friction and holding it against the compressor. I had no leaks when tightened, so it does seem to work, but just another change that could cause some issues down the road.In the end, it's a nice size and works nicely!

I found this product a few years back at a photo expo.. tried it.. and loved it!It's a full replacement eyecup. You start by removing the original eyepiece on the camera (in this case, the 6D -- very easy to do), replace the eyepiece with this and you're done. Snaps in place, no tools/disassembly required.The eyepiece itself is a circle and has this rubber eyecup going around it (since it's a circle, the rubber piece moves anywhere you want it to be (left side, right side, point up) which is very nice. The biggest benefit is that it blocks out stray light so youre ONLY seeing the viewfinder. I heard it won't work with the overly large glasses, but it's worked on every pair I've owned (enough to buy 4 of these!)Now, the downsides:It's rubber. Rubber doesn't last forever. I've had about 3 or 4 of these tear on me (and once it tears, it's pretty much done for). This does seem to have been fixed (or improved) though.. I havent had any tear in about 3 years now.It's bulky. It will prevent you from setting the camera down on the back (unless you fold the eyecup into itself)It's big. This will block the (top) of the LCD. I havent found it to be too big of a problem, but it will get in the way (especially if you're trying to use liveview or show people pictures on the screen. It folds up easily enough, but it is a bit of an oddity you dont always think of.

A few years ago, Delkin Devices released a product called the ImageRouter - it was one long strip with 4 CF readers built in.. the idea is after a long day of shooting (multiple cards or multiple cameras) you can go home and download everything at once.It's a great idea, and with Delkin discontinuing the ImageRouter (and the switch most manufacturers made to SD) I've been wanting something like it.I think they did some things right, but others I just have to ask "why?" to.Here's how the system works:You buy the HR1 (the base), buy the modules you want (CF, SD, etc..) and then just plug them into the base. The base holds up to 4 of these readers.Easy enough? I like the idea that you can mix & match.. 2 SD, 2 CF, etc..Unfortunately, and this is where my problems begin, the HR1 base is expensive! 50 to 75 bucks.. for the cardreader holder alone. No card-readers included (the picture is a bit misleading)Each CF/SD reader ranges from about 25 to 35 bucks (so do the math on the base + 4 readers.. it adds up!)I made the leap, and here are my thoughts:First, it's a luxory item. You don't NEED 4 CF readers.. but it's nice to have!You can also buy 4 cheaper readers and use those just fine.. this just looks nicer.1 reader per module. Problem here is, you can buy a good USB 3.0 reader that will read all the card types for pretty cheap, and about the same size as each module. Considering how bulky these are, they could've added more to each module (especially the ones like the SD reader)The base is pretty heavy, but I can almost guarantee its fake weight (unnecessary weight to give it a stronger and heavier feel). I'm sure the readers are also quite empty.. which begs the question, why so big? At about 6x5x5 inches, it's pretty bulky. I don't mind this as much as I have the space, but others can have issues with it.Next up, there is a constant bright blue LED on it -- each reader has its own LED, but the base also has one.The lights on the individual readers light up when in use, but the main base is always lit.SIDENOTE: I do like that the individual drives light up when in use (it lets you know when it's ready (solid), in use (blinking) and acts as a reminder that "Your memory card is still in here.. you might wanna take it with you")Another complaint: It requires power!Each reader can work by itself with just a USB cable.. but to use the base you need to plug in an AC power cable.  The power plug is also very bulky (a "wall wart") which can be trouble finding space for.A nice feature: You can always mix & match the trays. Shooting mostly SD cards? load it up with SD trays. Shooting CF? load it up with CF trays. Both? do half and half. Of course, each does have a cost attached to it.The included USB cable is a decent length, but not really long enough for my liking (I'd say maybe 3 feet?), meaning if you plan to have your computer on the ground and the card reader on the opposite side of the desk, you're out of luck without buying an extension.The readers have a USB 3.0 port on the back (thats it) and the base has a male USB connector -- the base basically works as a hub for these, so you'll get the same results out of just plugging 4 of these into a computer.The nice thing is each reader can be used standalone: Take it on the go, with your laptop, etc.. and no issues. Note that the individual readers do not require power (only when in the base)The readers attach firmly -- I'm able to insert/remove CF cards (which are normally a tight fit) without it pulling the trays out.Each tray also has a cover to protect it from dust when not in use.Overall: Works nice, I like it! But just so many issues.. it just seems like they're trying to get your money in as many ways as they can from it, not really doing you any favors.

I'll start off by saying until now, I've only purchased the official CANON battery grips for every DSLR I had (3 prior to the 6D). With the cost of these being 5x what the 3rd party ones sell for, I decided to chance it.I was very pleased in how nice the grip feels. I can't compare it to the official Canon version, but it seems to work just as well (and feel nice) like my XTi/40D/7D canon grips.The benefit of the battery grip is:* Holds 2x batteries (lets you shoot twice as long!)* Includes 6x AA tray (so if you run out of batteries you can run the DSLR on AA batteries (only recommended if absolutely no other option)* Gives shutter controls (dial, shutter button, AF point button, etc..) in vertical mode (much more comfortable!)* Adds a nice rubber grip to the DSLR for vertical shooting* Adds size to the DSLR (for those that like it)The battery grip connects into the battery slot -- remove the battery cover (it stores in the grip so if you choose to go back, you still have it).The screw-in connector works, but is a bit loose (won't undo itself, but has a bit of play -- this is the same as on Canons battery grips)The rubber grip is slightly different than the grip on the 6D itself (a bit smoother, not as rough). Both work fine for me (no preference)Overall.. very nice grip, 1/5 the cost.. works great!

I bought this to replace my OLD Sigma 30mm f/1.4 EX DG Lens Hood (first one was damaged).While the product page SHOWS that original item, this is actually the "new" version (sigma originally released the lens with a somewhat matte finish, then re-released it later on as a plastic version that looks something like their Art line.If you have the Matte version, this hood will not match. It fits, but rather than the nice texture (and bumpy interior), this new version is a solid piece of plastic. It doesn't feel quite as nice as the original hood but the shape does match.. there are a few small details different (like a textured ring around the bottom of the hood). It stays in place but there is a bit of "play" in it.. and it does not match the lens (the original lens is more of a matte grey, this is a solid black).In the end.. it works, it's the same shape.. just not the same material.

Coldshoe's have always been a big iffy to me -- most of them use 2 pieces of metal to grip onto the side of the flash foot, tighten down and hold it in place with friction. They seem to work, but it's a lot of weight/pressure to put on a flash foot and any sudden movement (moving the lightstand or lowering it quickly) could cause it to fall off.. and flashes aren't cheap.Because of this, I've always been hesitant of using them. The Frio changed that with its design -The frio is a thick plastic and has several pieces in place to hold the flash and not put too much pressure on it. There's a special slot that it locks into (designed to encase the flash foot) to prevent it from falling out.. it has a "protector" bump right behind the flash foot to prevent it from sliding out and it has a locking pin hole so you can tighten the flash into it.NOTE: Some flashes like the Canon 580EXII have a rubber-sealed locking mechanism.. I don't know if these will work on the frio.The overall feel is much nicer than something like the stroboframe and I haven't had issues with it. The bottom has a 3/8" and 1/4" metal mount to attach to a tripod or lightstand.The downsides of it:It's only available in this weird blue color. I don't know why they couldn't make it black.. but it's a small gripe.The flash can be somewhat tricky to put on (and take off) due to the rear-bumper (you need to press it down to get the flash in or out). I've tried putting the flash on, thought it was on and almost let go.They sell these in a few packs -- 1 pack, 3 pack, 5 pack.. each one gives a better discount, so if you need these look into the different pack sizes.

I've been a longtime DSLR user (CompactFlash), so going from the high-speed cards (100+mb/sec) to the somewhat slower cards has been a big change. With the prices dramatically jumping (from 40mb/sec to 60mb/sec to 80-90mb/sec), I purchased a few of each.The 60MB/Sec card seems to be a good speed -- it definitely feels faster than the 40MB/sec card (about 50% faster) but noticeably slower than the 80-90MB/sec cards.You probably won't notice much of a difference when shooting (most cameras wont write to the card at this full speed) but you will notice it when downloading pictures to your computer. If you shoot only a couple GB at a time, I wouldn't spend too much more for the faster speeds but if you're shooting 10+ GB you'll want the faster speed.The price jump from the 60MB/sec to the 80-90-95 MB/sec cards is quite a bit, so I can't really recommend that.. but the jump from the 40MB/sec cards to the 60MB/sec cards is only a few bucks and you'll appreciate it. I regret buying some of my 40MB/sec cards.

I've been a big fan of the ThinkTank "holders" -- the DSLR battery holder (this), the AA holder, the CF/SD holders and the Gel holders..The problem with the DSLR batter holder (available in a 2x or 4x size) is that it's not specific. It's more of a "One size fits.. Most?" design. I say this because some batteries fit great some fit very loose, some fit 2x in each side and some don't fit at all.If you're using one of the somewhat big batteries (Canon 7D, 5D, 40D) it should fit fine.. If you have a smaller battery (Rebel XTi) it'll fit, but be a bit loose in the holder. If you're using a small battery (EOS-M/Mirrorless) it will fit 2 in each side. If you're using a big battery, however, it may not fit at all.For me, mine did fit so I give it 5 stars. For others, it may be a problem.The pouch doesn't add much bulk, keeps the batteries protected (it has a flap w/ velcro to seal it). I typically put my batteries in "contact-side down" to indicate NEW and "contact-side-up" to indicate used.I like the 4x battery pack if using multiple cameras, but the 2x is also nice for short trips.I do wish it had one of the safety-straps like their other holder/wallets do (to clip it into a bag and not have it come out on you)

Let me start off by saying I love Eneloop Batteries. I've been using them for about 5 years now (since the earlier models), mostly for photography (flashes) but also for other items (Xbox controller, wireless transmitters, etc..)The big feature of Eneloop are that they hold the charge - some batteries, you charge them, let them sit for a couple months and they're totally dead when you go to use it (this also applies to putting them into devices, like a flash or remote control -- after a couple months, they're dead.With Eneloop, it holds the charge -- and for quite a while! (years). The downside is that you get a lower capacity (you can get a 2700 mAH battery that will last 2 months or a 2000 mAH battery that will last over 5 years without needing a recharge).If you plan to use these in high-drain devices where you use the entire battery in one day, you probably won't notice the full benefits of these batteries.Eneloop released their Eneloop XX line a couple years ago (now knows as Eneloop Pro). They have a higher capacity (about 25% more) with the slow-discharge rate (but faster than regular eneloops). These for are when you want "the best of both worlds".. higher capacity AND longer lasting.The differences:Eneloop (white): 1900-2000 mAH, can be recharged 2100 times. About 10 bucks for a 4-packEneloop Pro (black): 2450-2550 mAH, can be recharged up to 500 times. About 20 bucks for a 4-pack (Look for sales! I got mine for about 13 bucks on Amazon)The white ones will hold 70% of the charge after 5 years. The Pro's hold up to 85% after 1 year (so not quite as good).The 500 recharges vs 2100 recharges doesn't do much for me.. In the 5 years I've had the eneloops, I'd be surprised if I recharged each set more than 100 times (and thats using them regularly)The more important thing is the extra power.. is 25% power worth an almost 100% premium in price (non-sale?) And that all depends on the person.For me, in a day of photography I would go through a full set of Eneloop (regular) and finish up with a 2nd set.. that 25% extra capacity would normally save me from needing the 2nd set.. but everyone is different. If you need more than that extra 25%, you're probably better off getting 2 sets of the regular eneloops' since you'll be changing them anyways.I had some problems with the earlier Eneloop XX, but those seem to be resolved with the new Eneloop Pro's (so I'm glad I gave them a 2nd chance). I have tried the AmazonBasics batteries and they just didn't seem to work as well as the Eneloops. I also picked up several Duracell and Energizer AA batteries and both encountered charging errors just a few months after owning.In the end, for me it comes down to the price.. a 25-50% premium (for 25% extra power) is worth it for me.. but if it were to be the typical 100% premium price for that 25% extra power, I would have passed.

I picked up this wallet a couple years ago when it was released, and still use it.Just about everything about it is perfect for me.. but make sure your gels will fit before buying!It will fit the Rosco sample gels, the Strobist gels and other similar shaped gels.. Any of the larger ones (such as the ROGUEGELS) may not fit. If your gel is more than about 1/2" wider than a typical speedlight head (580EX size), it probably won't fit.The wallet closes with velcro and has a spot for a business card (so your name is on it) to sit in a clear window.It unfolds into 6 section (5 usable) and each will hold quite a few gels.I used a label-maker to label them by color:RED, GREEN/BLUE-GREEN, BLUE/PURPLE, PINK/PURPLE and YELLOW/ORANGEit's a nice material, folds up compact and protects your gels. I stuck a bunch of gaffers tape strips on the outside to be able to use it to attach the gels to speedlights (without carrying a roll of tape around)It also includes a removable strap (maybe 10"?) for hooking it to something, to prevent from losing it.The style matches the Pixel Rocket wallets and other Thinktank battery wallets

I'l start off by saying I've been using the Manfrotto Tilt-Swivel for a few years and love it.. everything about it is great, except the price. As of this review, the price has gone up about 33% (3x the price of this item), and needing 3 more of these I didn't want to spend that much.I've start off by saying I have used several other tilt-swivels with mixed results. I've never been totally happy with them.. the closest one has been the Calumet swivel (about 2/3 the price of the Manfrotto)Let me also say to just avoid the plastic ones.. I've tried 3 over the years and all have been bad.On to this product:Off the bat, it's solid. Seems to be mostly metal (the screw knobs seem to be plastic)You get a total of 4 pieces:* The swivel itself* a Coldshoe (metal)* A Male-Male spigot (1/4" - 3/8")* A female-female spigot (1/4" - 3/8")This combination lets you attach to either a lightstand or tripod, and mount a flash, camera or other accesory on top.There are 3 sections to the swivel (black/white/black) which is different from the usual 2 that these have.. the benefit is that you can attach the bottom end to a lightstand, tilt the middle section (umbrella holder) to the desired angle) and then with a flash on the top piece, tilt it to point directly into the umbrella (a big problem with other ones are that the flash sits way too high, so it's hard to fill the umbrella.. you get hot spots on the top and darker on the bottom).. This is actually a really cool design!There are 5 knobs on the swivel:2 metal (to lock the spigot/lightstand), 2 plastic (to adjust the angle) and 1 small metal (to hold the umbrella in place.Unfortunately, these were a little too close together for me.. you can even see it in the picture but some of them are REALLY close together and can be a bit difficult to tighten/loosen, but overall I was able to do it fine.. just felt a little "tight"The spigots seem fine, but not the same quality as the brass ones Manfrotto sells (I dont expect any problems)The coldshoe seems fine, but I use a Frio v2 Coldshoe instead (which works great!)Lastly, the 2 swiveling sections have "teeth" on each end to lock tightly in place. This is great since others that use friction to hold together do tend to droop down under weight. The teeth will hold it firmly in place.Overall.. the price I paid (1/3 of a manfrotto swivel), it works great. I love the 3rd section. No regrets on buying this over the Manfrotto.As of this review (3 days after ordering), the price has gone up to about 1/2 of the Manfrotto swivel

I'll start off by saying I've owned 10+ R-Straps.. Several RS-4's, an RS-5, 2 RS Dual-Straps and now 2 Cross Shots.One of my biggest gripes with the RS4 and RS-5 are that they could slip. I constantly found my shoulder strap "slipping" forward with use, and it got pretty annoying. Seeing the rubber grip on the Cross Shot had me give it a chance.My initial concern: Ugly orange! (the Cross Shot was originally only sold in Orange.. it's not in black, thanksfull!), next up: It's the cheapest R-Strap and has extra features.. whats wrong with it? And finally, the quick release clip on the back.Fortunately, none of these were a problem!The Cross Shot uses a molded rubber grip over the strap (in place of the previous fabric shoulder pieces). I was expecting a solid fabric strap with a sliding rubber sheath over it, but it's actually molded on top of the strap. I do wonder how long it will hold up for with repeated use, but so far no issues.The rubber works! It gives a nice grip on your shoulder so as not to slide around.The Cross Shot includes a free Lockstar connector (an added safety feature, usually sold separately)The cross shot folds up nice and compact (unfortunately, unlike my other straps they did not include a pouch for this one)Finally, my concern about the quick release -- the back of the strap features a quick-release buckle.. these scare me when you're talking about the buckle holding (sometimes) thousands of dollars of equipment. What if it snags and gets undone? what if someone comes up behind you and clicks the buckle?Some of my other R-Straps (the dual strap) include these buckles, and the thought has always freaked me out. I purchased the "R-Strap Buck" which is basically a safety clip for the buckle to prevent it from unbuckling (it locks the buckle together, so it cant be used unless you remove the buck (which wont happen accidentally)), for me the piece of mind was worth losing the quick release feature.I was glad to see that BlackRapid has improved the buckle though.. now in addition to the 2 side clips, it has a 3rd button that needs to be pressed (at the same time as the other 2) for it to actually release. This safety feature makes me feel a lot better about it.. but I still bought a Buck to keep it permanently locked.In the end.. I really like this strap. It's very compact, it's got a nice grip, it has the newer FastenR3 connector and a free Lockstar.. note that the rubber grip (instead of the previous fabric one) means you lose the extra pockets that those had (nice for batteries and whatnot)

I've gone through quite a few lens caps -- the original canon caps (with sides on the tabs), 3rd party caps (with the center squeeze like this) and others with a lens-leash.I wasn't expecting it, but this lens cap is a serious improvement. A couple advantages are:Thicker/taller - Compared to 3rd party caps, this one stands a bit taller, making it easier to grip from the sides (you can squeeze the edges or the center to release it)Center-squeeze - One of the nicest benefits is that this makes it easy to attach/detach from a lens when using a lens hood. With the previous style, you wouldn't be able to have a lens hood attached and still be able to remove or attach the hood.Quality - I've used Sigma, Rocketfish and other 3rd-party branded lens caps with a similar look, and the quality here (albeit a weird thing to say about a lens cap) is noticeable. I've had cheaper ones break on me, be hard to release/put on, be loose or just have other issues.The only other difference I've noticed between these and the 3rd party ones are that some of the 3rd party ones allow for a "lens leash" to be attached (to keep the cap hanging from the lens so as not to lose it), but I'm more than happy to lose this benefit in place of the others gained.

I picked up about 8 of these for the Canon EOS-M and EOS-M2 (along with several CANON LP-E12 and several WASABI POWER LP-E12)All were fully charged using the Canon charger, all were new and showed full power in the EOS-M/M2 and were used in the same environments (with regular lenses, with IS lenses and with the same LCD screen settings (Screen off after 15 seconds, camera off after 5 minutes, AF Illumination light off, Touch focus off and On-Shot auto-focus on). Using several of each battery, all lasted roughly the same amount of time (~200-250 pictures).Seeing that the Opteka is rated at 2,000 mAH and the Canon is rated at 875mAH (I believe the Wasabi is 1100), I unfortunately did not notice any difference. The change may be apparent on other cameras that use the battery (the M/M2 are a mirrorless which use the LCD screen as a viewfinder), but I didn't notice that.With that said.. I can get 9 of these for the price of a Canon one, and they worked just as well.

This item is a very small softbox -- about 9"I wouldn't use it as a main softbox (unless I absolutely had to) but it makes a nice one for a hair light, side light, etc..I purchased a few of these years ago and loved them. They fold flat, setup easily and have a little storage bag.. plus it's cheap!Fast forward to now, I purchased 2 more from Amazon and the item's changed.The softbox unfolds to the square shape and has 2 layers of diffusion (an inner layer and the main outer diffuser). Previously, both attached via Velcro and I had no issues. Easy to setup, easy to put away.The newer model uses clips on the inside which are very tough to attach/detach -- I actually kept mine attached due to the trouble in constantly putting it together and taking it apart, but when folder it feels like it's going to snap any moment. It hasn't yet, but I won't be surprised when it finally does, and it's not a good feeling.The outer layer still attaches with Velcro, but it's now a bit oversized. Previously, the outer diffuser was a nice fit, now it's a bit large. It doesn't affect the quality but makes it look a bit "off".In the end.. it's still a nice softbox if you need a small one, but the changes (for the worse) have been disappointing since I'd previously have given it a 5-star review.

I'll start off by saying I love the OP/TECH USA Lens Mount Cap. It's a heavy duty (very strong/protective) rear-lens cap for your lenses, with a rubber sealing on it to keep moisture out. I bought one for each of my lenses and loved them.When I saw this, I was interested -- I've always used my Canon original body cap (without issues) but wanted to give this a try.Note: The BODY CAP PROTECTIVE COVER (this item) goes onto the DSLR body when not using a lens.First issue was that it's not entirely clear on attaching it -- the Canon cap goes on easily, Lenses have a Red or White dot to line up with the mount, but this item has a slight raised area (easy to miss) that needs to be lined up with the lens mount to attach properly.Once attached, it's a very firm fit -- which can be good or bad. It's a bit scary when locking it since it feels like it could damage the body itself with how tight it is.The tightness is apparently a good thing as the inside of the mount included a rubber weather sealing.The big selling point for this is that it (can) protect  your camera a bit more than the plain Canon body cap that comes with the camera especially in dusty or wet environments where these can enter the DSLR housing. How common is this? I really couldn't tell you. I will say I'd feel better walking around somewhere like Burning Man or in a rainy area with this body cap attached than the default cap, but most likely I'd just have a lens attached.If you travel to any of those types of environments, check this item out. It's very strong, protective (?) and feels nicer than the original cap (it matches the feel of the higher end Canon bodies). If you're just looking at is as a replacement cap, it's probably not worth it (due to the somewhat hassle in attaching it, and the scary feeling of over tightening it)

I've used plenty of coldshoes for Speedlights -- between the plastic "feet" included with many, to the stroboframe, to those included on radio receivers (RF-602) to those included on light modifier brackets.So far, the frio has felt the most secure to use, and best designed, despite a couple small gripes.First, some positives: Very compact, very sturdy, plenty of locking mechanisms (the "snap-in", the lock down feature with the flashes pin and the plastic covering the top portion of the flash hotshoe). Metal 1/4" and 3/8" threading on the bottom.Overall, very good -- the only couple gripes: Price -- it's expensive for what it is, especially when you see how basic it seems (adds up if buying multiple). The color: It's only available in this weird blue color.. why not black? Lastly, I hear some of the Canon flashes that use rubber weather sealing around the connector won't fit (those speedlights that use the twist-down locking mechanism will work)Comparing to some others:Stroboframe was the scariest I used -- a very small piece of metal that holds the speedlight only by the metal shoe -- it always seemed way off balance and like it was just going to snap the flash if I made any sudden movements with it. Price was also high."Feet" included with speedlights - Prior to these, the feet were my favorite. They're cheap (usually included free), have a lock-down mechanism and are very compact (plus they can sit on the floor without the need for a stand). These were a bit hit or miss as some used plastic threading and some used metal. Never had an issue though.Radio receivers - These are nice in that they're multi-function.. they'll typically work as a radio receiver, a flash mount and "feet" if needing to stand a flash on the ground. These are typically not much more than the frio, but a bit overkill if only using it for a flash coldshoe.Coldshoes included with modifiers -- Some modifiers, such as the EzyBox softbox, include a special coldshoe required to mount the speedlight. These, I'm not a fan of due to them trying to accomodate all flashes and typically not working great with any -- these use friction to hold the flash in but I've had a flash drop out of these before.Overall, it's a bit pricey, it's not the nicest looking, but in the end.. it's worked the best and I'd buy a few more.

I've been using Yongnuo flashes for years and love them -- the YN560's are a great manual-flash, and the new YN560III pairs beautiful with the new YN560TX!The YN560III has a built in RF-602/RF-603 receiver, meaning you don't need a separate receiver. You can purchase a RF-602 TX or RF-603TX and trigger the flashes wirelessly.. until now, this has been a nice little bonus but with the YN560TX, it adds the ability to remotely change the power levels of the flashes from the camera itself (opposed to just sending a trigger signal). This is a great feature, one usually reserved for higher-cost ETTL models.A few nice features on it:* The YN560TX can pair up to 6 groups. You can have an A, B, C, D, E, F group and adjust each light separately.. If you assign 2 flashes to an "A" group, changing that setting on the YN560TX will change it on all "A" group flashes.* You can set the YN560TX to either RF602 or RF603 and 16 different channels each -- if you have an older flash (like a YN560II) you will need a RF602 or RF603 receiver to trigger the flash (Note: the wireless control will not work on YN560 or YN560II -- you need the 560III or newer). It will only trigger a RF602/603.* If you change the power with the YN560TX, you can also trigger those flashes with a RF602/RF603 transmitter set to the same channel (EX: Using 2 cameras one with a YN560TX and one with a RF602/RF603)On to the product -- it's a nice design - it looks like someone cut a YN560 in half and took off the flash head -- even down to the red front cover (which appears to be functionless/decoration-only?)Construction is solid, buttons are good and it has a good viewing angle/backlight (green)Setup is a bit tricky as there are 4 buttons, a TEST light, up/down/left/right/center and an on-off switch.. this means lots of holding multiple buttons at once to set features. For example, hold MODE+HZ/FN to change from RF602 to RF603.. A lot of these aren't very clear, and if in the field and needing to "fix" something, can be quite a challenge (even with the instruction manual, due to the way it's written). A nicer method would have been to have a "Settings" menu to change these rather than button presses (pressing 1 button, holding the same button, and holding the same button + another button all product different features).The hotshoe is metal ad has a locking/twist mechanism which is nice. The item's lightweight, even with batteries.. but it's pretty bulky (not deducting points for, since a lot of that is due to the screen size and buttons), but it's worth noting.Unfortunately, where I started to discover some problems were with it being somewhat unreliable when using multiple -- I picked up 3 of these to use with 3 different cameras. You CAN use multiple together, but settings don't always send the way you'd like them to. For example I'll call these 560TX-A and 560TX-BIf 560TX-A is set to 1/1 power on channel A and 560TX-B is set to 1/4 power on channel A, the one which was set LAST takes priority. If you want the 2nd transmitters' settings to send, you need to use the "Group" button to highlight the channel (EX: "A") for about 2 seconds for it to send that signal. If using 1 channel, it's not bad.. if using 3, 4, 5 or 6 it's kind of annoying. I bought this thinking it sent the "power level" signal when it transmitted the "Flash" signal, which is not the case.My other gripe was that it was hit or miss, even at close distances (~5 feet). With fresh batteries in a brand new YN560III and in the YN560TX, I would have some flashes failing to "flash" every few shots.. Trying with a RF602 transmitter, the problem went away. I don't know why it does this, and it would alternate between flashes that wouldn't fire (the flashes were recharged, on a lower level (not overheating) and tried with multiple sets of new batteries in each and different YN560TX's). Outdoors seemed to work better, however

I recently picked up 2 Canon EOS-M cameras and the lens adapter was a big selling point for me on the camera. I bought 2 of these "White Box" models and they do appear to be official Canon adapters.White Box is exactly what it sounds like -- it comes in a white box with no other documentation (instructions, warranty card, etc..)I have heard that "White Box" is typically the designation given to canon  products that were split from larger bundles (EX: Canon EOS-M + Adapter set, or a Canon 5D + 24-105mm lens), splitting it apart and selling the included item separately.The mount does have a serial # included on it, but again no warranty card (which may or may not be an issue if you need warranty service. With that said, the price of the White Box model is very inexpensive and probably cheaper to replace than repair)Included with it are 2 caps: Front cap (Canon EF Body cap) and rear cap (EF-M Rear lens cap). There is also a 1/4" 20 threading on the bottom of the mount (good if you plan to mount a larger lens so you're not applying all the weight onto the tiny EOSM body from a larger lens).There is no glass in the adapter. It appears to be a Metal material (or at least a VERY sturdy plastic).It has contacts to enable Autofocus, Aperture adjustments, Lens data information transfer/EXIF, Image stabilization or any other settings from lenses (some cheaper ones do not allow these).It works with Canon EF and EF-S lenses as well as 3rd party EF/EF-S lenses.It has a locking mechanism on the lens, with a release switch (similar to the one on the body) to keep it from accidentally releasing the lens.Overall great value.. adds a LOT to the Canon EOSM camera!

I've been using DSLR's for almost 8 years now and have avoided the EOS M for the longest time -- I prefer the large size of a heavy DSLR with battery grip, so the benefits of a "small camera" never did much for me.. especially if making compromises.I have 3 DSLRs (xD and xxD and xxxD series canon) and honestly bought this because it was cheap (I typically use multiple bodies to be able to have multiple lenses ready at all times, opposed to changing). With some of my older bodies showing age (10 megapixel, older sensor) the price of about 300 bucks for the EOS M, the 22mm f2 and the EF adapter (with a couple spare batteries) was about half of what a new Canon Rebel would have cost. I didn't buy this to replace a camera, or as a first camera, but to compliment my existing ones.The EOSM is VERY small and light.. this works both for and against you. The small size will make it easier to shoot in public without the visibility of holding a large pro camera (it looks closer to a point & shoot than a DSLR, with the 22mm f2 lens).. but if doing a photoshoot with it, people will take you less seriously (it looks like you're doing a 'professional' shoot with a point & shoot).. Doesn't affect the quality whatsoever, but it is something to keep in mind.The camera itself is nice -- most of the functions are done on the touchscreen (such as focus points) which are nicer than some of the DSLRs and using the dial to select a focus point), but changing the ISO, Aperture, Shutter, etc.. are also via touchscreen. It would have been nice to have taken the actual controls for the Canon G-Series point & shoots instead of going all touch. On the same note, they seem to have taken the Rebels' minimized ISO settings (100, 200, 400, 800, etc...) opposed to the 100, 125, 160, 200, 250, 320, 400, etc.. of the higher end models.No wifi or GPS built in (I believe they added them in the M2).. these would be nice, but not necessary. A tilting screen would have been much nicer (since there is no viewfinder)Camera uses a SD slot, shoots RAW or JPEG. It has a weird (and somewhat questionable) camera strap.. nice that it comes off/attached easily but kind of scary with how easy it can be removed. I'll be using an R-Strap with it. No handstrap option or battery grip options available.The camera has a normal 1/4" 20 tripod threading on the bottom (lined with the center of lens). If you buy the EF Adapter, it also included a tripod threading on the collar (great for heavier lenses). The hotshoe on top is a real, standard hot shoe and works fine with hotshoe accessories, flashes and wireless transmitters.Photo quality is VERY nice.. same as from a nice DSLR (use good glass/lenses with it!). Autofocus is a bit slow, but really it works fine for me.. the thing to keep in mind is if you're having someone pose for a photo, you're fine. Modeling, it's fine. Group shots, fine. Landscapes, fine. Only problem is if you're shooting sports.. I wouldn't use this for any fast movements as it probably won't focus quick enough.I highly recommend the 22mm f2 lens (even if you have good EF lenses -- the 22mm is a really nice lens) and recommend the EF adapter (theyre now under 50 bucks for a canon-branded one). The EF adapter lets you use canon EF and EFS lenses, including aperture/autofocus and image stabilizer.Overall, I'm really enjoying it and considering buying a 2nd one to carry with a different lens. The price (late 2014) is great.. at its full price I would have passed. With it having not taken off, and the M2 only releasing in Japan, chances of an M3 are very low.EDIT: Just about a week after buying this, I picked up a 2nd one. For the price, it can't be beat and I wanted to grab a 2nd (for when I don't want to bring multiple DSLR's along) before they're gone entirely.

Picked up some of this after I was noticing my airbrush getting 'dry tip' quite a bit with alcohol-based paints.. cleaning it helped, but it became pretty frequent (even on a freshly cleaned airbrush/needle). Picked this up and.. it works! The 2 Oz. side is plenty (in fact, I think even .5 oz would be enough). What I do is open the cap, stick the needle into the opening and lift it out, letting any excess oil run off of it before putting it into the airbrush. It keeps the alcohol-based paints from drying on the needle (at least for a while!), providing a much easier airbrushing experience

I mainly picked this up to clean my airbrush -- most of the pieces can be cleaned by hand using a variety of tools (brushes cleaner liquids, airbrush pipe cleaners, etc..) but they're both a time-consuming process and don't get everything -- especially the needle tips and heads, they tend to keep paint stuck on (or more likely, inside) them. Over time these not only make the airbrush look heavily used, but begin to clog quicker. Even using the items above, a few places couldnt be easily cleaned (the insides of the small needle tips and threaded parts of the airbrush, for example).Picking this up, I was able to disassemble and clean an airbrush gun within 10 minutes (with only about 1 minute of that being actual effort/work).The item itself is pretty straight-forward.. it's a large dish with a lid, and 2 buttons: On and Off. No timers, no settings, no countdown on the top.The inside is lined in metal and includes a small plastic basket for tiny pieces, and a plastic stand for watches.Fill the thing with your cleaner of choice (I usually fill with water and a couple cap-fulls of the included liquid -- I hear people use dish soap or windex with good results), hit the ON button and wait for it to turn off (it auto-shuts-off after 3 minutes).I tend to do 2 run-throughs with a cleaning fluid (6 minutes total) and then 1 final one with just clean water to get any chemicals off, then let it dry.Tried a pair of glasses and it also worked very nice - got any small bits of dirt that are normally not accessible due to the tight spots they're in.I haven't used this as a full replacement for cleaning, I typically clean out the airbrush briefly and then put it in the ultrasonic cleaner when it needs a more thorough cleaning.The only downsides I see are.. it's small. Real small. I was expecting it to be bigger.. this thing is maybe 6.5" long by 4" wide on the inside, and it's oval shapes, so those are the widest dimensions. Once you put the plastic liner in, it's even smaller. This is kind of nice if you need to clean small items, but it may require multiple "fills" of items depending how much you need to clean. I've seen some where people will put 3-4 airbrushes in at once without any problem.. this one fills easily with just 1.The unit also has a permanent blue LED shining into the tank (even when off) which may be an issue for those wanting to keep it plugged in.It also doesn't have settings for time -- just on/off (3 minutes at a time) and also no countdown timer. For me, thats not a problem but it may be for some.

I've owned quite a few of the yongnuo flashes, from the earlier YN460/N460-II/YN465 to the YN560, YN560II and now the YN560IIIThe YN560III, being nearly the same price as the YN560 and YN560II is the best yet -First off -- Biggest feature is that these now include a built-in receiver (letting you use an existing RF-602, RF-603 or the new YN560TX). I had plenty of RF-602s and now the YN560TX and both work perfect, but they're a little awkward/confusing to set up (more on that later)In terms of looks, it's almost identical to the YN560II - a couple differences are:* Backlight is now a yellowish tint, was previously an orange* The buttons have been revised to allow more featuresI put new batteries in the YN560I, II and III and fired them all simulataneously at full power and all seemed to recycle about the same speed (no improvements here)The YN560III includes a soft pouch to carry it and a plastic coldshoe stand (Yongnuo seems to have stopped including the Stofen-like diffuser in their new flashes)The YN560III still has the high-voltage battery socket on the side (a nice feature, since they've dropped it on their higher end flashes) and runs of 4x AA batteries (Tip: Get Eneloops!)The reason for buying these was the compatibility with the YN560TX.. This replaces the RF602/RF603 and sits on your camera but lets you set the flash power wirelessly.. You can set up to 6 groups of flashes and change the power levels from the camera itself. I use multiple cameras and was able to put a YN560TX on each camera, set to different settings, and trigger it that way -- it did seem to get a little confused, but overall did work nice (much better than changing the settings on the flashes each time)So now the problem.. The YN560III has the same amount of buttons as the earlier models, but has a LOT more features built in. This means you need to learn odd button combinations (on the YN560II, each button was a dedicated function, on the III, if you press a button you get one feature, Hold it you'll get a different feature and hold 2 buttons you'll get another feature). They're not entirely clear on how to do certain things (like changing from the default RF603 to the RF602) and even the manual doesn't expain this. Overall though.. it works, and it works nice so I do recommend the upgrade. If you're fine with the existing YN560/YN560III and don't need the wireless control, you can pass on these.The RF602/RF603 can be set to (I believe) 16 channels each, and can be triggered with either the 602/603 or the YN560TX transmitter.. You can also use the YN560TX transmitter to fire other flashes on a RF602/RF603 receiver (if you have ones like the YN560/YN560II, or other models)The big downside is the lack of ETTL -- I personally don't use it, but that's something Yongnuo reserves for the higher end models. For the price, I love these things.

I've been using Final Seal for a while now and have loved it -- works great on effects makeups/powders and with airbrushes.. while providing a nice fragrance!It comes in a number of sizes from a small bottle to this extra large "jug" -- if you plan to use it for a single event, a small bottle will do just fine. The larger size is for someone who wants to use it for quite a few different coverages (a makeup artist, cosplayer, etc..). The cost of the larger size isn't very much compared to the small size, but keep in mind it comes in a large container with no easy applicator. I picked up one of these and it easily lasted about 30-40 large applications (face/arms/legs), I imagine most will get even most uses out of it.I recommend getting a small spray bottle (very inexpensive) if going for one of these larger (16 oz) bottles.. the cost savings are quite a bit over the smaller bottles.The seal goes on with a nice minty fragrance (kind of like a mouthwash) which people seem to like -- it won't dry liquids (such as fake bloods) but will do a nice job with keeping most others from smearing.It also works very nice with the Ben Nye Magicolor when using an airbrush (by itself, the magicolor is a bit too thick to properly spray). They suggest using a small amount, but about 50/50 (magicolor + final seal) seems to work really nice for me.Overall, nice product, not too bad in price if buying in bulk (16 oz). Recommended!

The EW-73C is a nice lens hood for the Canon 10-18mm  lens --I typically shoot at night and dont notice much of a problem with flare on this, but bought the hood for protection - being an ultra-wide, you tend to get closer to the subjects and it's a safe way to keep your lens from being damaged (either too close to the ground or a wall, or anything else). The hood is a nice size and provides protection for the lens (especially if not using a UV filter) which is really nice -- I imagine it also cuts down quite a bit on lens flare. Would be nice if Canon packaged these with their non-L lenses or at least sold them for a bit lower in price.. otherwise a very nice item!

I truly enjoyed reading this book. Ultimately, the life of William Haines is about two things - one is a story of enduring love, and the other is a man who stood on principle and lived his life as he believed he should. His life is also a story of reinvention, of being open and prepared to change course at any time. Today you're a box office movie star, but tomorrow you just might be the ticket-taker or the usher.The only time I found myself skimming entire passages was during some of the author's flowing descriptions about interior decoration. A little bit was fascinating, but some of these details were a little bit over the top. At some points in the narration, I really wanted to yell at the author: "Dude, calm the **** down." I'm also not sure that it was completely necessary to track down the young boy who had once accused William Haines' partner of molesting him, to get his side of the story, sixty years later. No criminal charges were ever filed and recreating the gory details only added an ick factor to an otherwise flawless story. Other than these few mentions, this is a book well worth reading for anyone who has an interest in the history of Hollywood and the early decades of the film industry.

This is my second purchase of this product. I liked the first one so much, I bought another. I have the first shelf underneath my computer table - my cable modem and wifi router are on the top shelf and I have my four external hard drives on the lower shelf.
This Belkin CAT6 network cable worked perfectly and lays flat - it doesn't kink up like cheaper generic cables. This was a good buy for my recent remodeling project.
The construction of these headphones was extremely flimsy and highly disappointing. The ear hooks broke almost right away. I do not recommend this product at all.
I liked the feeling of this lotion on my skin. The scent is light and pleasant and the lotion left my skin with a good feeling.

I love this tablet and have been using it to binge-watch my favorite TV shows with Amazon Prime Video. This is the first Amazon Kindle, Fire or tablet I've owned which has an option for an external memory card. I bought the one recommended by Amazon, which was guaranteed to work with this model of Fire tablet.

I have a very low-profile case for my iPhone, and have never had any problems charging the phone in other chargers, with the phone remaining inside my Otterbox case. This charger wouldn't work with my phone inside the case, and when I removed the case and charged my phone without it, another problem occurred. This charger does not offer a very stable or secure hold for a charging phone and it seemed very easy to knock my phone out of the charger base. So I am not going to use this charger. I'll probably just throw it into a recycling bin and consider it money lost. I've already thrown away the box and packaging, and it's just not worth the hassle of starting a product return with Amazon.
Nicely (and individually) wrapped, these chocolate bars would make good holiday basket gifts. I ate one candy bar, just for review purposes, of course. Absolutely delicious.
I found the taste of these vitamins to be bland and inoffensive, which is a positive feature in a prenatal vitamin.

This story has everything - murder, passion, betrayal, and a surprise ending. If this book was fiction, the plot might have been unbelievable, but "Tinseltown" is a true story. The author's physical description of 1920's Hollywood is vivid and poignant, and he manages to bring a cast of fascinating characters to life for the reader. The other interesting thing to read about was how, back in the days before internet and social media, it was possible to shed one's identity and create an entirely new persona, complete with a different birth year.

This is how much I liked this "standing case" for my new Amazon Fire tablet. I threw it into the trash already. There's no support - if you move the tablet even slightly with this case attached, the folded base of the case collapses. At this price, it wasn't worth the hassle for me to bother trying to package it up and send it back to Amazon.

The boyfriend said this would be a great gift for a teenager or young adult male. He liked the products, and would consider buying them again in larger sizes. Also, in a situation where you need a generic gift for a man, such as when his sister brings her new boyfriend home to meet the family, at least there's a polite gift that he can unwrap when everyone else unwraps their presents on Christmas Day.
Very pretty colors. Reasonably durable fabric and construction for the price.
This Avery product worked perfectly with my new HP deskjet printer.

I took one bite of the beef flavored stick, and immediately spit it into the trash can. This is the absolute worst tasting beef stick I've ever tried in my entire life. The texture was gross and it felt as if I was chomping on a dog chew toy.

All these speakers do is "hum." One minute everything was fine, and the next, poof! Turns out there's something wrong with the bass unit (the biggest speaker in the set), which of course, is the center of the entire system. I tried other speakers and got the same results - nothing but a "hum." I'll follow up with Logitech and see if I get any kind of a customer service response.Updated review: I have not  heard any response at all from Logitech. Guess I'll just toss this broken stuff into my recycling bin.
I am using these bags to sort and organize computer parts and cables, and I have found them to be extremely useful for this purpose.

This cat tree is much smaller than it appears in the product photos, and the hiding place is far too small for my cats, none of whom are particularly large. This cat tree would be good for a kitten, but then again, why invest in a cat tree that's only going to be usable for a year or two? I'd much rather spend more money (probably buying local so I could see the item in person before I bought it) on a cat tree that would last for the lifetime of my cats. Whoever designed the swingy parts of this cat tree has clearly never lived with an indoor cat. Cats like stability and aren't likely to bond well with anything that swings at them. Also, the ladder was of no use (or interest) to my cats.

I set this up as a repeater, but when I tested it one room away from the router, the download speed was so ridiculously slow that the website I was downloading from ended up "timing out" and couldn't complete the download. Then I tested the speed, downloading the same exact music files, using my regular Wi-Fi connection, and it was lightning fast.So this works fine as a repeater if all you want to do is read email, but if you're looking for a reasonably fast download speed, there are existing products which work much better. Also, WTF is the deal with the obnoxious flashing blue light? I ended up unplugging this router from the wall so I could get some sleep.

This laptop is sweet. Powers up and loads Windows within a few seconds. The screen image is so sharp and the colors are rich and bright. I will update this review later on to reflect my long-term experience using this laptop.

Given the low price, this is a surprisingly high-quality men's t-shirt. I chose it for the boyfriend, but then I tried it on first, and I ended up keeping it for myself. One specific detail makes this product stand out - the store/manufacturer hang tag was fastened to the inside the neck of the shirt with a small safety pin. Instead of being attached with a ridiculously tight plastic tie that leaves a big hole in some part of the shirt after you remove it. This bit with the safety pin is classy. Also, the boyfriend, after examining the shirt more closely, believes it is a house brand (generic label) of some way more expensive designer product clothing line, and I would tend to agree. This is the kind of men's t-shirt you'd find (in the good old days) in a high-end department store, even if it wasn't terribly expensive. Even the fabric feels expensive.  I'm going to place an order for more shirts because the boyfriend really wants one of his own.
The boyfriend really likes this cologne. He says at this price, however it's a special occasion scent and not one he would wear every day.

I recently updated all of my network cables to be 5e or 6, and there is a noticeable improvement in the quality and speed of my internet connection. I also got rid of every generic no-name network cable in my house and replaced them with Belkin brand cables.
These are attractive dish towels which are also thick and absorbent. The fabric and materials look and feel far more expensive than the low price would suggest.

After wasting time and money buying online and searching local shops for a back support pillow, all I found were junk pillows that were soft and offered absolutely no support at all. So I took a chance buying this back rest pillow, and it was exactly the product I was looking for.
These vitamins were easy to swallow and have an inoffensive taste. It's difficult to objectively test and review a product such as vitamins.

I bought my HP Stream used from a seller named "Burnt Circuit." Everything worked fine. However, I really think Microsoft's offer of a free upgrade to Windows 10 is a bad idea - I know technology and I can tell you there's no way Windows 10 can possibly work right on this device. I'd just leave well enough alone and be happy that this tablet came with a robust version of Windows 8.1 that works just fine.

I love these lights so much that I just bought three more packages. They are far better quality than I expected for this low of a price. The light is strong and bright and stays on for about 30 seconds after being activated, if no further motion is detected.I ended up moving these lights up higher because at first, I'd set them down so low (near the baseboards) that every time a cat walked past, my bedroom lit up like a prison cell inside a North Korean prison camp. The boyfriend thought it was hilarious.
I'm usually not satisfied with the quality of trash bags that are described as being made out of recycled materials, but these bags are as high quality as the regular Hefty brand trash bags.

Here's what you should know about me first as a consumer. I am a furniture snob. I hate particle board. Everything inside my house is real wood, the kind of furniture my kids call "grandma furniture." If a piece of furniture doesn't require the help of four grown men to move it, usually I don't want it. But I absolutely love this table. Yes, it's made out of plastic, but it looks really nice inside my house. I wanted a specific height and style of table to use in a bedroom, underneath a window to hide the tech clutter that has invaded our lives. To be clear, this is not a storage ottoman with a lid - it's 100% a table, but there's enough room underneath it to put away the laptop when it's time to sleep. It also slides easily and can be moved without difficulty.Although it's not the same quality, the table complements this wicker chair that I've owned for a few years, and at a casual glance, you wouldn't know that the ottoman is plastic and the chair is made out of a high-quality wicker weave.  Strathwood Hayden All-Weather Wicker Bistro Chair (Discontinued by Manufacturer)
This is the Moen towel ring I bought to go with the other Moen bathroom hardware products I purchased at the same time. After nearly a year of constant use, the towel ring still looks brand new.

This Moen toilet paper holder was definitely worth buying - the installer I hired did have to drill a new set of holes because the toilet paper holder he removed was the more standard square bracket design with a plastic toilet paper insert roll. If you're a renter in need of a quick cover up for drilled holes left behind after installing this toilet paper holder and removing the old one, take a look at this product. Prime-Line Products KD 16083 Self Adhesive Smooth Plastic Screw Hole Covers (Pack of 53), Maple.  I bought mine on eBay because none of the sellers on Amazon (at that time) had a close enough color to match what I needed.

I bought an entire set of these Moen products, including a hand towel ring, larger towel rack and a toilet paper roll holder and had the pieces installed by a professional - located directly behind our bathroom and kitchen walls are a complex set of pipes and heating elements. Almost a year later, the hardware still looks as good as new and I am very pleased with my selection.

I figured out the key secret to make this daddy work. Let's just say you live across the street from Starbucks, which offers free Wi-Fi to its customers. It would be nice to have access to that open and unsecured (no password required) free Wi-Fi network, just in case the home internet connection that you pay for suddenly quits working. But maybe that Starbucks Wi-Fi signal is just a little bit too weak and you can't connect up with it reliably from your penthouse apartment. With this Amped Wireless router, now you can.You set this device up in repeater mode, then do a search for nearby 2.4ghz  and 5ghz Wi-Fi networks. It's a tad annoying that you have to choose both, but what you're really interested in at this point are the open 2.4ghz Wi-Fi networks, because 5ghz WI-Fi is still not commonly available for free.Then you are going to clone the Starbucks Wi-Fi and whatever 5 ghz network you chose -  If the 5 ghz Wi-Fi network is your own, make sure you put a password on that puppy. Now back to Starbucks.At first when I made this magic happen, I was high-fiving myself and walking through my neighborhood, checking out the Wi-Fi signal I had created. It goes for blocks. Then I realized this was a problem. The network you create with this repeater device has a name that looks something like this: Starbucks Customer WIFI_RE. The RE is you, short for "repeater." The reason this is a problem? I live in the OG hood with a lot of neighbors who are on parole. (Don't ask me how I know this to be true. I just do.) So I really don't want to share my poached Wi-Fi network with all of these people, some of whom are card-carrying parolees registered as Friends of Meagan.
