But I found out that I could not pour either too quickly or too slowly.  Now, with the correct amount of finesse in wrist action, I can neatly filled my French press without dripping on the counter.  But this kettle's spout could have been made easier to pour from if it was shaped more like a spout.  This spout is okay for pouring your boiled water into the wide opening of a French press.  But if you try to pour a precise amount of boiled water into a small teacup or try to pour into the narrow opening of a Thermos bottle, good luck! Fuzzy Wuzzy's Conclusion:Overall, this is a great kettle that I rate as 4 stars!  I would have gave it a 5-star rating if it did not have the following 4 issues that bug me:1) The kettle could have been constructed using far less plastic by using a lid that was entirely stainless steel (but then again, I could find NO other electric kettle that was plastic-free, and this kettle comes closest to being a plastic-free design, especially when I cover its top with my glass saucepan).2) The auto-shutoff is not totally reliable (but then again, I have read these complaints on other makes and models of electric kettles too, and I fixed my kettle's auto-shutoff by replacing its lid with a saucepan cover).3) If this was truly entirely stainless steel on this kettle's interior, it would not develop rust spots around the inside of its base.4) The kettle's pour spout needs to be shaped more like a spout.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies (but buy the MX922 instead if you find it at a great discounted price) Positives: The quality of text and graphics on Word/Excel printouts is excellent. The quality of photo prints are good when compared to most all-in-one multi-function printers. This printer has a multitude of flexible connection options: USB 2.0, Wireless Wi-Fi LAN, Wired Ethernet LAN, Wireless PictBridge connection to Canon cameras, Bluetooth from a mobile phone (using an optional Bluetooth adapter), AirPrint printing from iPad/iPhone/iOS devices, Google Cloud Print from Gmail/GoogleDocs/GoogleChrome. The two black/color ink cartridges can be conveniently replaced from a front-facing panel, instead of having to lift up the entire scanner lid to access them. The printer can print in full duplex mode, automatically printing to both sides of the paper. Negatives: Print speed is a bit on the slow side compared to many other multi-function printers, but its print quality is better than most. While this is an excellent printer for home or home office use, its slower speed and limited 100-sheet paper capacity would not be a good choice for a busy small office. The single color ink cartridge contains all three cyan/magenta/yellow colors, so each color cannot be separately replaced.This Canon MX522 is a multi-function printer that can print and fax from a PC, wirelessly print via AirPrint from iPad/iPhone/iOS devices, print from a Web service such as Google Cloud Print, and it can also work as a standalone color copier and fax machine.  Its multi-functional appeal is not just limited to its outputs, but it is likewise very flexible with its connection inputs.Setup was easy and quick.  The print speed of this MX522 is its main weakness.  Whether printing Word documents, Excel spreadsheets, or photos, it prints about %40 to %60 slower than a comparably priced Epson WorkForce multi-function printer.  However, the quality of the print from this MX522 on Word documents and Excel spreadsheets is better than the Epson.  Upon close examination, the text and graphics on my Word and Excel printouts have an excellent, clear, crisp look to them, better than the Epson.  So perhaps this Canon takes it time printing so that it emphasizes quality over quantity.  Fair enough...  While the print quality of text on documents is noticeably better on this MX522 when compared to a similar Epson WorkForce printer, the print quality of photos was fairly average, i.e. not good, not bad, and either comparable to, or slightly better than, other multi-function printers.This printer uses two ink cartridges, a black cartridge (PG-240, PG-240XL, PG-240XXL) and a cyan/magenta/yellow three-color cartridge (CL-241, CL-241XL).  Depending upon their pricing, the larger "XL" cartridges are often a better deal than the non-XL cartridges.  While replacing a single three-color ink cartridge is more convenient than replacing three separately-colored ink cartridges, I really would have preferred that this printer used three separate cyan, magenta, and yellow ink cartridges in addition to the black color.  Regardless of whether I am printing photos or documents containing graphics, the colors are never used up at the same rate.  So if I have used up all of the cyan color, I have to replace the color cartridge even though the magenta and yellow inks are likely not empty and still usable.  By comparison, Epson's WorkForce printers do use four separate cyan/magenta/yellow/black ink cartridges.  But as with "razor blade marketing", I think that all inkjet printer manufacturers earn the bulk of their printer hardware profits from the ink cartridges.  Compared to many multi-function printers where you have to lift up a bulky scanner lid in order to access and replace the ink cartridges, the two ink cartridges in this MX522 are easily replaced by accessing a small door located at the front right corner of this printer.Some all-in-one printers do not offer automatic duplexer.  But this MX522 has full duplex capability so I can automatically print to both sides of a sheet without needing to manually insert a printed page back into the printer to print the other side.  On printers that have a duplexer, I use this feature a lot since it also saves on paper, especially if I am printing a 70-page document.This printer includes "My Image Garden" software that lets you manage, organize, and edit your photos.  Its photo editing and image enhancement functions are weak and limited when compared to Photoshop Elements or PaintShop Pro, but it is very easy to use for the photo-editing novice, and it can do some pretty nifty things such as capture frames from a MOV/MP4 video, or create cards or calendars to print out.One nitpick that I have is that even though you can connect this printer using its USB 2.0 port, a USB cable is not provided in the box.  So if you want to connect this printer using USB, you have to provide your own cable.  But the wireless Wi-Fi printing works so well that you should choose this as the main connection. Fuzzy Wuzzy's Conclusion:This MX522 printer is the middle model of Canon's line of three MX scanner/copier/fax multi-function printers.  At the time of this review's writing, the better Canon PIXMA MX922 Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner, Copier and Fax MX922 printer is only selling for $15 to $20 more than this MX522.  Amazon prices may fluctuate daily, but the $15 to $20 price difference has been going on for a long time now.  If you can get a great price deal on the MX922 printer, I would definitely recommend the MX922 printer instead because its print speed is about twice as fast as this MX522, its photo/graphics/text print quality is better, it uses separate color ink cartridges instead of this MX522's wasteful approach of combining all colors into a single cartridge, and it has far better paper handling capabilities.  So while I rate this MX522 4 stars, I would rate the MX922 5 stars.  If you also want a multi-function printer to print the bulk of your photos at home, instead of using a separate high-quality dedicated photo printer to print photos at home or using a commercial service to print your photos, the MX922's photo print quality is better than this MX522, and it prints photos better than most multi-function printers in general.  If the price difference between this MX522 and the better MX922 was $50, then you may have to consider the extra cost.  But if you can get the MX922 for just $15 or $20 more, definitely get the MX922 instead of this MX522 because you get a lot more features for a little extra cost.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies (4.5-star rating overall; 5 stars for the tripod, 4 stars for the ball head). Positives: The tripod has a high build quality and low weight, while still retaining high strength. The GH-300T pistol grip ball head's built-in shutter release trigger is quite unique. The tripod supports up to 18 pounds of maximum load capacity. The center column can be pivoted to any angle while still holding a large camera and lens at very unconventional angles. The legs can adjust to 25, 50, and 80 degree angles and the tripod can be configured from a maximum height of 67.5" all the way down to about 7.0" from the ground, which is great for low-angle and macro photography applications. Negatives: The tension control knob to adjust the ball head's resistance is hard to adjust to get a good balance between having enough friction to hold the camera at any angle and not having too much resistance in the pistol grip itself. Only two shutter cables are included, TC2 Canon type-2 and TN2 Nikon type-2, for lower-end Canon and Nikon cameras.  TC1 and TN1 cables for higher-end and full-frame Canons and Nikons are not included. The "User Manual" for the 'GH-300T' ball head is very sparse with its wording and descriptions.What is in the box package? Vanguard 283AGH tripod with Vanguard GH-300T pistol grip ball head Vanguard QS-60 "Quick Shoe" quick release plate Wrench and hex wrench for adjusting tripod and ball head 42-page 15-language 'Abeo Pro Series' "User Manual" 40-page 15-language 'GH-300T' ball head "User Manual" 15-language "Limited Lifetime Warranty" foldout sheet TC2 Canon type-2 and TN2 Nikon type-2 shutter release cables for lower-end Canon and Nikon cameras Nylon tripod bag with drawstring closurePrior to using this highly versatile tripod, I have used other Vanguard tripods that were more conventional along with Vanguard's SBH-30, SBH-50, and SBH-100 magnesium alloy ball heads, and I have been uniformly pleased with their performance.The tripod itself is a uniquely flexible contortionist that uses what Vanguard calls a "Multi-Angle Central Column" that can tilt, pivot, slide, and swivel into just about any angle.  When this contortionist center column is adjusted in combination with the three legs that can each pivot out to 80-degree angles, this gives the 283AGH excellent chameleon-like flexibility for converting from a tall upright tripod to a really short tripod (either by lowering the tripod and/or pivoting the camera downward to a very low height) for various tabletop, product, macro, and low-angle photography applications.  It can be fun to shoot photos or videos of a scene using a very short height to get a "bug's eye" view from way down low, providing a composition based on a very unique angle of view.  You can use low-angle photography for everything from portraits to landscapes.  Because the camera will be so low to the ground, you will usually have to use your LCD monitor to compose the shot, instead of looking into the viewfinder, and if your camera has an LCD screen that flips out and pivots, that makes it even easier.This tripod's three legs are equipped with three-way all-terrain feet encompassing anti-slip rubber feet, spikes, and snow/sand shoes.  While rubber feet and spikes are common on tripods, the snow/sand shoes are unique and interesting... and they actually work quite well.  When the tripod wears the snow/sand shoes, it reminds me of photos showing the Apollo Lunar Module when it landed on the Moon's surface.  Each leg telescopes using three sections and two flip locks.  Each upper leg section is wrapped with an all-weather foam grip that feels comfortable yet durable, and lets me get a secure grip of the tripod even when it is wet from rain.  I sometimes carry this tripod, with its legs fully extended, over my shoulder while moving around outside, and placing this foam grip section on my shoulder also adds to both comfort and traction while the tripod rests on my shoulder.Vanguard uses flip locks on the legs of their aluminum alloy tripods and twist locks on the legs of their carbon fiber tripods, and I think that this is a very smart manufacturing decision.  Although some tripod manufacturers use flip locks on carbon fiber tripods, carbon fiber has less flex and "give" than metals like aluminum and using twist locks on carbon fiber tripods apply less pressure on the tubes than flip locks.  Overall, I greatly prefer flip locks over twist locks because I think that well-designed flip-lock legs, such as those used on this 283AGH tripod, can be both loosened/extended and retracted/tightened quicker than twist-lock legs.  Flip locks are especially quicker for me when I am wearing ski gloves while adjusting a tripod high up in the mountains during winter.  I can also easily glance at flip locks to see that all of them are tightened whereas twist locks provide no visual cue that they are all tightened before I mount my camera onto the tripod head.  With tripods that use twist locks, I habitually press down on my twist-lock tripods first to see if the twist-lock legs will shift any before I mount my camera onto the tripod.Although this tripod is quite sturdy and stable when used indoors, it can be made even sturdier if I hang a counterweight such as my camera bag, backpack, or a water bottle from the accessory hook that is located at the bottom of the center column.  This hook is especially useful for weighing down the tripod if using it on uneven ground or on windy days outdoors.  Vanguard makes a nice useful Vanguard SB-100 Stone Bag that you can attach to any tripod's legs to weigh it down more.  But since this tripod's center column already includes a hook, I often hang either a camera holster, camera bag, backpack, or my Nalgene water bottle on the center column hook to help anchor the tripod and I find that is sufficient.  Sometimes, I just pull out a spare plastic grocery bag, load it up with some rocks, and hang it from the tripod's center column hook to get a rock-solid anchoring of the tripod.  To be prepared for photo outings that require more tripod stability, you may want to either always hang your camera bag onto this tripod's hook, use Vanguard's SB-100 Stone Bag, or just carry some spare grocery bags with you and you can create an improvised heavy counterweight to hang from the hook.The 283AGH has a nice orange-colored anti-shock elastomer rubber ring positioned underneath the pan head that is on top of the center column.  If you accidentally lower the center column too quickly, this anti-shock ring helps to cushion the impact of your equipment as the center column slides down onto the tripod collar.  The top pan head on the tripod can be configured for both 1/4-inch and 3/8-inch threaded head mounts using the included hex wrench to unscrew the adapter on the center column.The GH-300T pistol grip ball head that is mounted on this tripod is a really unique ball head.  I personally prefer ball heads on my tripods, and this design, with its built-in shutter release trigger, is ideally suited for action/sports/wildlife photographers and for shooting video.  If you are a landscape, wedding, or portrait photographer who likes the creative flexibility offered by this tripod's "Multi-Angle Central Column", you can save a lot of money by getting another Vanguard tripod that uses this same feature, but with a more conventional, and far less fussy, ball head instead.  The GH-300T has dual pan heads for smooth panning and accurately aligned panorama shots.  The top pan head, located under the quick release plate, has 72 click points for panning at precise intervals, while the bottom pan head does not click into grooves, allowing for smooth movements.If you have never used a pistol grip head before, it may feel a little weird with how you control the tension of the head by squeezing the pistol grip itself.  A knob behind the grip lets you control how much tension you need to squeeze the grip along with how much tension the grip head needs to hold the camera stationary.  But this adjustment is not precise and it is not easy to find a good balance between how much weight the tripod head will hold versus how much effort you need to squeeze the grip.  I have fairly strong hands and fingers, but I can see how this pistol grip can be hard to use for someone with weak hands.  I always seem to be fussing with the tension adjustment while trying to find the right amount of friction that is sufficient to hold the camera in place and does not require way too much force to squeeze.  I do not know how this design can be improved, but this is the sole reason why I rate this GH-300T 4 stars while the tripod gets a 5-star rating.As with the contortionist tripod, the pistol grip on the GH-300T can be rotated to eight different angles relative to the panning base.  This can be useful if the center column has been pivoted so it is no longer vertical.When the shutter release cable is connected from the pistol grip to the camera, the round orange button becomes the shutter button.  The button can also be half-pressed to initiate auto-focus, and the trigger can be slid upward to lock the shutter open when shooting in "Bulb" mode.  The tripod package includes only two shutter cables, a TC2 Canon type-2 cable and TN2 Nikon type-2 cable, for lower-end Canon and Nikon cameras.  TC1 and TN1 cables for higher-end and full-frame Canons and Nikons are not included.  The TC1 Canon cable is compatible with Canon 1D, 5D, 7D, 60D/50D/40D/30D/20D/10D cameras.  The TN1 Nikon cable works with Nikon D1, D3, D700/D300/D200 cameras.  It seems to me that someone who uses a high-end tripod like this would also be using a high-end camera, so Vanguard should have included the TC1/TN1 cables instead of the TC2/TN2 cables for lower-end cameras.  The TC1, TN1, and TS1 (for Sony cameras) cables can be purchased separately.Because there have been customer complaints regarding problems with the shutter release cable used on the VANGUARD GH-300T Pistol Grip Ball Head (Black), and Vanguard said that they were working to resolve the issue, I phoned Vanguard to ask about the shutter release cable connection problems.  Vanguard mailed me a free package containing updated cables, not just for the original TC2 and TN2 cables, but the package contained all five TC1, TC2, TN1, TN2, TS1 cables for high-end Canons, low-end Canons, high-end Nikons, low-end Nikons, and Sony cameras, respectively!  Considering the high price of this 283AGH tripod, I think that Vanguard should have included all five cables to begin with.  The updated TC2/TN2 cables look very similar to the original TC2/TN2 cables, but each one has a small silver-colored triangle discretely printed on the connector housing that plugs into the pistol grip.The included tripod bag securely holds this tripod, but it would have been nice if the bag also included a zippered pouch to store the wrench, hex wrench, and shutter cables while carrying this tripod around.Overall, this is an excellent tripod and pistol grip ball head.  The tension control knob to adjust the friction is the one main weak link in the total design.  But the build quality of the tripod and the thoughtful attention to detail in the other areas of this tripod are superb.

Rating: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies! Packaging, Style, Appearance:  Excellent 5-fuzzies rating Construction & Build Quality:  Excellent 5-fuzzies rating Design & Features:  Excellent 5-fuzzies rating Ergonomics, Usability & Ease of Use:  Excellent 5-fuzzies rating Performance, Durability, Reliability:  Excellent 5-fuzzies rating Competitive Pricing & Value:  Average not-good not-bad 3-fuzzies rating Positives: This backpack can hold 2 DSLRs (or video cameras), 6-8 lenses (up to 300mm f2.8), monopod, shotgun microphones, various other camera and video gear, and a separate laptop sleeve can hold up to a 17" laptop. This backpack has excellent no-compromise professional-grade build quality with a weather-proof coated 1680D ballistic nylon exterior, ripstop nylon interior, heavily-reinforced stitching, and high-quality YKK self-healing zippers. The four main compartments all use lockable zippers for added security, and each compartment can be separately unlocked and opened without totally exposing all of the camera gear and laptop to nearby strangers. The 14 adjustable Velcro-attached dividers allow for many different storage configurations. A removable "WeatherWrap" rain cover is included. The shoulder harness, waist belt, and ventilated back panels are all thickly padded. The bottom panel is waterproof so you can set the backpack onto a wet ground or sidewalk. This backpack's 14"W-x-20"H-x-9"D exterior dimensions meet airline carry-on sizing regulations. Negatives: There is no easy and secure way to carry a tripod on this nearly-perfect backpack.  Tripod attachment straps/clips/loops were not a part of this backpack's design. All zippers have 4-inch long pull cords that are excessively long as they dangle, can be a nuisance, and the pull cords can get caught on something.My first impression of this Tenba Roadie II HD-SLR/video backpack was that it is definitely professional-grade in terms of its large size, design, and build quality.  Before loading any gear into it, it already weighs 5.6 pounds empty.  This is a large backpack, and if you fully load up all the storage compartments with a laptop, cameras, lenses, microphones, and other camera/video gear, the 14"W-x-20"H-x-9"D exterior dimensions (43 linear inches) can expand out to a size of about 16"W-x-20"H-x-11"D (47 linear inches), and the total weight could reach 30 or 40 pounds; you would essentially have a carry-on luggage strapped to your back.  While this backpack will fit into the overhead bins of most airlines, it will not fit underneath the seats.  Most airlines allow a carry-on to be of a size up to 45 or 46 linear inches.  A few airlines allow a carry-on to be as large as 50 or 52 linear inches.  So this Tenba Roadie II should not present a problem as a carry-on aboard most airlines, and I could even fit this backpack into the overhead compartment of some smaller turboprop short-hop commuter planes.  If you fully load up this backpack, however, it may be difficult to squeeze it into the overhead compartment of small turboprop planes.This backpack is still very comfortable to wear even when it is bulky and heavy from being fully loaded with gear.  The panel that faces your back, the contoured shoulder harness, and the waist belt are all thickly padded.  The back panel also has a T-shaped ventilated air channel to keep your back cooler while you are lugging your gear around.  If you have to wear this fully-loaded backpack for long durations, the thickly and firmly padded waist belt, usually found on larger backcountry backpacks, will be a welcome feature.  But if you have a weak or bad back, I would not recommend fully loading up this backpack and then walking around for long periods with this strapped to your back.  All of the padding uses a high-density foam that does not compress and wear out over time with repeated use and heavy loads.  Both sides of the padded waist belt each have a zippered pocket, with the zippered pocket on the right side also containing an innovative water bottle holder so you can have a beverage container strapped to the right side of your waist while you are carrying this backpack.  The top of this backpack has a padded grab handle if you want to carry this backpack like luggage.My second impression of this backpack was that it has a lot of long zipper pull cords dangling all over it.  This backpack has a total of 21 4-inch long zipper pull cords with 12 dangling on the outside and 9 dangling on the inside.  These pull cords loop through each zipper handle and are twisted around themselves.  This may look stylish, but over time, I expected them to untwist and just become loops.  With the backpack zipped up, there are five pairs of these long zipper pull cords dangling around the outside of the backpack's compartments, looking like Rastafarian dreadlocks ponytails.  Both sides of the padded waist belt, which are connected together using heavy-duty Duraflex buckle clips, also each have a 4-inch zipper pull cord dangling from them.  When the rear-facing main camera compartment is opened up, four of the plastic pouches that line the inside of the ventilated back panel also sport 4-inch pull cords.  And the rear-facing accessory compartment has five 4-inch pull cords dangling from its five zippered interior pouches.  These pull cords are excessively and unnecessarily long, and the pull cords actually can be a nuisance and get in the way, getting caught on something else.  I sometimes loosely tie each pair of pull cords together if I do not expect to be opening up a compartment soon.  And if you have cats at home, all of these dangling pull cords make great cat toys, so you should keep this backpack away from your cats :-)  So I really wish that this backpack's 14 zipper pull cords were just 1.5 or 2.0 inches long, instead of 4 inches long.  There is absolutely no advantage to having long zipper pull cords that are 4 inches in length, and I have sometimes even had the pull cord from one zipper get caught in the zipper of another compartment that I was in the process of zipping up.The main camera compartment faces the rear (your back) while the laptop compartment and another accessory compartment face outward toward the front.  This configuration can offer added security if you are carrying a fully loaded backpack in a crowded busy market filled with strangers or you are standing on a crowded train or bus.  Pickpockets cannot surreptitiously remove camera gear from the exposed front side while your backpack is carried on your back.  If you are carrying a laptop computer on the front/outward-facing laptop sleeve, that compartment is exposed to pickpockets.  But trying to secretly pull a laptop out of this sleeve would be far more difficult than trying to remove a camera or lens from the camera's main compartment.  When all your gear is zipped up and concealed inside this backpack, it has a subdued appearance that looks more like a small piece of luggage.  Some camera backpacks have too much of a high-tech or hip and trendy appearance that screams: "Look at me! I am carrying thousands of dollars worth of expensive camera gear!"The laptop sleeve has interior dimensions of 10.6"W-x-18"H-x-1"D.  This can hold a 17-inch laptop unless that 17-inch laptop is larger than normal or has a 9-cell battery.  One of my 17-inch laptops cannot fit in this compartment due to its 9-cell battery sticking out too much.  All 15-inch laptops can easily fit in this compartment.  On the outside of the laptop compartment is another accessory compartment with five zippered pouches, two open pouches, and a business card slot on the inside.  This accessory compartment, measuring about 9" wide and 12" high, is large enough to hold a small ultrabook or netbook.Two flaps on the top of this backpack unzip and open outward away from each other to reveal a top compartment where more gear and accessories can be stored.  The floor of this top compartment is actually another Velcro-attached divider, and if you remove this divider, it allows you to access the main camera compartment just by unzipping these top two flaps so you can access camera gear that is stored in the main camera compartment through this smaller top opening instead of fully opening up the main compartment and revealing to strangers all of the expensive camera gear that you have stored inside.  You can also adjust the size of this top compartment so that you can quickly access frequently used lenses just by pulling open this top compartment instead of having to unzip the main camera compartment.The main rear-facing camera compartment, the laptop compartment, the accessory compartment, and the two flaps that open up the top compartment are all equipped with lockable zippers for better security.  Obviously, if this entire backpack is actually stolen with all your gear inside, then using locking zippers makes no difference in adding security.  But there are various situations, both with studio photography and on-location shooting, where I trust that no one will steal my entire backpack of equipment, but I also do not want someone borrowing or removing equipment from my backpack.  So with these lockable zippers, I can lock up all four compartments using luggage locks.Both sides of this backpack are identical in that they both have 14-inch high zippered pockets that are great for holding longer shotgun microphones or monopods.  Near the top of each zippered pocket is a accessory loop that lets you hang additional lens cases, pouches, and carabiners from both sides of the backpack.  And on the outside of this long zippered pocket is a roomy Velcro-secured pocket for storing other gear.  With all of this storage flexibility, the one glaring omission in this backpack's design is an easy and secure way to carry a tripod.  For video work, I prefer a tripod that is equipped with a joystick/pistol-grip ball head for better pan/tilt action.  Some of these tripods are large enough to require that they be carried separately in their own bag with a sling strap.  But many video tripods can still be easily carried on a backpack that is equipped with cinch straps and buckles to firmly hold the tripod.  By leaving the Velcro-secured pocket on either side of this backpack open, I can insert three legs of a smaller tripod or two legs of a larger tripod into the bottom pocket, thereby converting that pocket into a tripod foot pouch, and I can loop a Velcro strap through the accessory loop that is sewn into the 14-inch zippered pocket to tie the middle of my tripod to the side of the backpack, but it does not firmly hold the tripod in place and the tripod can wobble around too much during transport.  This backpack could have perfectly held a larger tripod if Tenba had sewn two cinch-strap buckles along one side of the backpack to cinch the tripod along two points in addition to having two or three of the tripod's feet inserted into the bottom pocket.Because I wish that this backpack had a good way to carry a tripod, I would actually rate this Tenba Roadie II backpack 4.5 stars instead of a full 5-star rating.  But this may not been an issue for you, or you may prefer to carry a tripod in its own separate pouch and sling it over your shoulder.  Overall, this is a professional-grade camera backpack with a matching professional-grade list price of $299.  If you are more of an amateur/casual photo/video enthusiast, unless you can get this backpack at a good discount, you may consider less expensive (but still very good) camera backpacks made by Lowepro or Think Tank.  With the large size and weight of this backpack, its storage space may be more than what most people need unless you are a professional photographer/videographer.July 6, 2015 Update: There is an updated version of this Tenba Roadie II HDSLR/Video Backpack. The Tenba Roadie II HDSLR/Video Backpack model 638-333 that I reviewed here on May 15 2013 was introduced in May 2012. The updated Tenba Roadie backpack model 638-319 Tenba 638-319 HDSLR/Video Backpack (Black) was introduced in September 2014, and the updated backpack now lets you strap a tripod to the backpack and it holds the tripod feet in a pouch. Unless you can get this older 638-333 model backpack at a good price and carrying a tripod is not important to you, I would consider the newer 638-319 instead of this older model.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!I have previously read several "Inside Out" books from Microsoft Press and they have all been uniformly excellent, thorough, detailed, and evenly balanced in their coverage of a wide array of topics.  This new book on Windows 8 likewise does not disappoint and offers the right amount of detail to satisfy both average users of Windows and expert power users.  This book is not a "Windows 8 for Dummies" style of book, however, and its reference book layout and organization assumes at least an intermediate level of proficiency in using previous versions of Windows.  As with most intermediate-to-expert level technical books, this book has an underlying assumption that you know about some of the general Windows concepts that it talks about.  The first 195 pages of this book, encompassing eight chapters, are in a section called "Getting Started".  But even this section assumes that you are fairly comfortable with using a previous version of Windows, and there are no beginner-level tutorials.  After this "Getting Started" section, there is a "File Management" section (Chapters 9-13), "Music, Videos, TV, and Movies" section (Chapters 14-27), "Security and Privacy" (Chapters 18-20), "Networking" (Chapters 21-24), and "Maintaining, Tuning, and Troubleshooting" (Chapters 25-57).  Although all of this information would also be very helpful in a business office environment (e.g. a whole Chapter 20 is devoted to using the "Hyper-V" virtual machine functionality), this book is more oriented towards individuals and home users.  If you are looking to set up Windows Server 2012 (Windows 8 Server), the Windows Server 2012 Inside Out book is great for that.With this book being organized like a reference guide, you do not need to read every page sequentially from start to finish.  The first 195 pages in the "Getting Started" section should be read through, but then you can hop around in different chapters depending upon your needs and questions.  I installed my first Windows 8 Pro from a DVD last November.  Prior to doing that, I had already read through a large amount of Windows 8 "survival guides" and "transition guides" that were posted on various Web sites; reading these online guides helped me immensely even before I purchased the Windows 8 Pro DVD.My one small quibble with this book is that the much-despised Start screen of Windows 8 is not addressed until Chapter 5, while a discussion about Windows 8 apps is discussed early on in Chapter 2.  For someone who is upgrading/transitioning to Windows 8, having to deal with the Start screen could be a more urgent and immediate issue than managing Windows 8 apps.  For example, after I installed Windows 8 Pro last year, one of my immediate questions was: "How do I shutdown, reboot, and logoff in Windows 8?", since those functions were previously tied to the old Start menu on the desktop.  Luckily, this is covered on page 113; you create two shortcut tiles to reboot or shutdown Windows.  But instruction is not given on how to create a similar tile to logoff from Windows, even though you can adapt the page-113 instructions to use the 'shutdown /l' or 'logoff' Windows command to create a shortcut tile that logs you off.  Microsoft also offers on their Web site a more complicated way to create shutdown/restart/logoff tiles on the Start screen using a bundled PowerShell script that you can download (I include the download link in the 'Comments' section of my review).  I am still puzzled as to why Microsoft did not just include these three shortcut tiles by default in a new installation of Windows 8.  If you hanker for the old Start menu that had been yanked out of Windows 8, page 119 talks about third-party apps that you can install to get the old Start menu back, and how to automatically begin at the desktop instead of landing in the Windows 8 tiled Start screen whenever you initially login to Windows 8.  For many users who are accustomed to their old Windows Start menu and desktop, all this useful information should have been moved up earlier in the book, and the Chapter 2 discussion about Windows 8 apps could have been postponed to be the next chapter after Chapter 5.  This book's Chapter 5 is called "Personalizing Windows 8", but much of it could be called "Transitioning to the Windows 8 User Interface".As useful as this book is with its thorough coverage of Windows 8, a HUGE bonus is that with the purchase of this book, you also get an access code that allows you to download a free eBook PDF copy of this book!  The book also describes how to access 50 how-to videos totaling several hours of instructions that are narrated and demonstrated by the author himself.  Each of these short how-to videos are a few minutes in length, and they can provide even better instructions than what was written in the book, especially for people who like to learn by seeing instead of just reading.  You can bookmark the Web page link containing the how-to videos to access them while you are reading the printed book.  If you are reading the eBook, it conveniently contains a listing of links for all the videos so you can just click a link within the eBook to access one of the videos.  All of the printed book's images are in black-and-white, but the eBook's images are in full color.  So along with being far more useful than the printed book since I can quickly search within the eBook for keywords, the eBook looks nicer with its color images.  And if I am already carrying a laptop/ultrabook/netbook anyway, I do not have to lug this heavy printed book around with me.  I really wish that all technical books offered a free eBook accompaniment like this since it is so convenient to always have with my computer, I can quickly search through the content, and I can copy-and-paste programming code and computer commands directly from an eBook instead of having to type out what was written in a printed book.I highly recommend this great book if you are either an average/intermediate or advanced/expert user of Windows!  If you are a hardcore power user of Windows or if you are a system administrator who is responsible for maintaining Windows 8 in an office environment, this book is not a totally all-encompassing tome describing all the various aspects of Windows 8 internals or the use of Windows 8 in a corporate environment.  So I hesitate to call this book the "ultimate, in-depth reference", which is the wording written on this book's cover.  But then again, for most technical topics such as operating systems, programming languages, and software technologies, I often end up buying more than one book on the topic because each book has different strengths and weaknesses.  But this book nicely balances the "what you need to know" information with lots of useful tips, and because it covers a lot of ground within its 700+ pages, it may be the only Windows 8 book that many people need.  If you are a novice at using Windows, however, this should not be your first Windows 8 book, even though this can be the second or third Windows 8 book that you read.Note: As with many technical books, this book has a few errors within it.  At the time of this review's writing, there are 9 errors verified by the author and 3 unconfirmed errors in this book's content.  In the 'Comments' section of my review, I list the link to the O'Reilly Web site where the errata for this book are listed and described.  The O'Reilly Web site is also where you would go to enter the access code for downloading the eBook PDF version of this book.  The errors were all reported several months ago or during last year.  I can understand that it takes time to update the printed version of this book with the corrections to the errors, but these errors were still in the eBook PDF that I downloaded last month.  It would be nice if the eBook PDF file could be updated quicker.  I could then re-download an updated version of the eBook that had the the errors corrected.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies. Positives: This is a small compact very-portable hard drive considering that it houses 1-TB of storage space, a Wi-Fi access point, and a rechargeable battery. The internal rechargeable battery can provide about 10 hours of juice.  But if you are streaming large HD videos all the time, the battery life will be much shorter. Negatives: The "Seagate Media" mobile app only supports a limited number of digital video formats (M4V/MP4/MOV/AVI). Along with the included AC adapter wall charger, this package should also include a car charger too. Since this hard drive is designed with portability in mind, I wish that it came with a carrying case.What is in the box package? 1-TB hard drive USB-to-DC cable with AC adapter charger USB 3.0 adapter with detachable USB 3.0 cable "Quick Start Guide" foldout leaflet 24-page 24-language 3-Year Limited Warranty bookletIn this age of BYOD and multi-device multi-media interoperability, this Seagate Wireless Plus is a really great idea!  I used to copy videos and photos to my iPad and copy music, videos, and photos to my netbook/ultrabook, which can be tedious to do on a weekly basis.  But with a hard drive like this, I can now wirelessly share all files with up to eight mobile devices.  This little hard drive is amazingly compact considering that it is a 1-TB drive combined with the electronics to make it a Wi-Fi access point and it includes an internal rechargeable battery that keeps the media streaming for about ten hours.Set up was pretty easy.  However, this is NOT a plug-and-play device, and the included printed "Quick Start Guide" is VERY sparse, even when compared to the "Quick Start Guide" included with other electronics.  In the 'Comment' section of my review, I include a link to Seagate's Web site where you can download a "User Guide" PDF file that is far more useful than the printed "Quick Start Guide" that is included in this package.  By default, the Wi-Fi network is not password-protected, so anyone within the area can conveniently access your files.  So after you download the "Seagate Media" app, you should set a password, which turns on WPA-level wireless security to ensure the privacy of your files or data.Streaming of movies was flawless and free of glitches, lags, and stutters.  The downloadable "User Guide" states that the wireless range is "close to 150 feet", with the usual caveat that walls and obstructions will interfere with the strength of the signal.  Being 60 to 70 feet away with an unobstructed line of sight, the signal is very strong.  When I start having walls or different floors of the house get in the way, the signal proportionally degrades and I get stuttering.Overall, this is a great little device.  I rate this 4-stars instead of 5-stars, however, mainly because it could be improved to have more flexibility in streaming more of the popular varieties of digital video formats.  And for the price, it would have been nice if the package included a waterproof carrying case that could store the hard drive along with its USB adapter and cables.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies. Positives: Feature-rich powerful route and trip planning, with expanded points of interests. This software is ideally suited for use on my older Dell Mini 10 netbook (or a compact ultrabook), which is then paired with my Garmin GPS. Negatives: The user interface and general usability have not been much improved since "Microsoft Streets and Trips 2007". In some areas, the address search and map data is not as accurate and up-to-date as my Garmin GPS.Prior to this 2013 version, I have used the 2007 and 2011 versions of S&T.  The update in going from 2007 to 2011 was far greater than updating 2011 to this 2013 version.  The product description's "System Requirements" for this software does not include Windows 8, but it runs fine on my little Dell Mini 10 netbook running Windows 8.  For actual trip and route planning, using S&T is far better and easier than trying to do everything on my Garmin GPS.  However, for bigger trips involving many hours of driving, I still use a combination of this S&T software, Google Maps, several Web sites that specialize in road trip planning, and lots of Internet searching/researching to map out my routes and plans.  S&T can output a .gpx file that I can then import into my Garmin Nuvi GPS for the actual in-car driving directions.While there have been some incremental improvements to this 2013 version, the user interface and general usability feel somewhat outdated.  As mentioned, even this software's "System Requirements" only list "Platform: Windows 7/Vista/XP" ad omit any mention of Windows 8, as if the internal user interface code has not  changed much since 2007 when I was running S&T on Windows Vista.If you already have "Microsoft Streets and Trips 2011" or the 2012 version, there is really not enough reason to upgrade to this 2013 version.  However, if your current version is 2007, this does make a pretty good upgrade.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!I previously added two of these 5400-RPM Western Digital Scorpio Blue drives in the 1-TB size on a laptop that is often used for the editing of photos, images, and very large video files.  I liked them so much that I added this 750-GB to a four-year old Windows laptop.  My older laptop has a weaker battery and 90-watt AC adapter, so I choose this Scorpio Blue instead of the Scorpio Black because I do not need maximum performance, and I prefer the lower-power, cooler, and quieter operation of this hard drive.The 9.5mm-height form factor of this drive means that it can fit inside most laptops.  There are four threaded inserts on the two longer sides of the drive for use with standard mounting screws; no mounting screws or hard drive bracket/caddy are provided with this hard drive.  This drive is rated at a very quiet 22 dBA sound level when idle, and 25 dBA when the drive is seeking/reading/writing.  With this drive installed inside my laptop, I can only barely hear the drive's operations in a very quiet room when my ears are about one to two feet away from the drive's location inside the laptop and the drive is actively reading/writing.  When the laptop is idle, I do not hear the drive at all.  And even if this hard drive is actively seeking/reading/writing, its tiny sound is masked by my laptop's fan noise even if the fan starts running from its slowest speed.When tested using the "HD Tune" hard drive performance benchmarking tool, it turns out that this 5400-RPM Scorpio Blue drive compares favorably to the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drives, even though the faster Black drives also have a 16-MB cache compared to the smaller 8-MB cache on the Blue drives.  On my installed 750-GB drive, HD Tune reported a minimum/maximum/average read speed of 53, 110, and 85 MB/sec, and a minimum/maximum/average write speed of 40, 108, and 84 MB/sec.  This is only about 15% to 18% slower than the performance of the 750-GB 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drive, which runs faster and hotter, and uses more power.  This 5400-RPM drive is slightly faster than Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drive, and it even compares favorably to Seagate's Momentus XT Hybrid Drive.  This drive's random access read and write times are also comparable to both the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black and Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drives.  If you are trying to decide between the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drive (or some other faster 7200-RPM mobile-form-factor drive), the Black drive will be about 15% to 18% faster than this drive.  However, this 750-GB drive is slightly slower than the WD Blue 1 TB Mobile Hard Drive: 2.5 Inch, 5400 RPM, SATA II, 8 MB Cache - WD10JPVT.  So if you can spend about $20 more for 250-GB of extra space on the 1-TB version of this drive, you get a slightly faster read/write speed compared to this 750-GB drive.Western Digital offers an "Acronis TrueImage" that can be downloaded from their Web site to let you copy all your data from an old drive to a new drive so you do not have to reinstall your operating system to get all the benefits of a new drive.  If you do replace your main system drive, you can either use cloning software such as "Acronis True Image" to mirror all your system files and applications back onto the new drive, or you can perform a fresh OS install and reinstall all applications that you were using.  The advantage of cloning your system files and applications is that it is much faster to put everything back onto the new drive.  The advantage of performing fresh installs of the OS and applications is that it can often declutter your files and free up hundreds of megabytes of space (which is like totally cleaning out a basement that has accumulated years of stuff).If you are trying to decide between the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drive (or some other faster 7200-RPM mobile-form-factor drive), the "Black" drive will be about 10% to 15% faster than this "Blue" drive.  This drive has pretty good performance for a 5400-RPM drive and it does not use as much energy or generate as much heat as a 7200-RPM drive.  If you frequently use your laptop unplugged and you want to maximize the number of hours that you can run on battery power, 5400-RPM drives drain the battery less than 7200-RPM drives.  The Scorpio Black drives already use less power than many 7200-RPM laptop drives.  But these Scorpio Blue drives use 20% less power when reading/writing and 25% less power when idling than the Scorpio Black drives.  I can dream about the day that it becomes affordable to equip a laptop with two 1-TB SSD drives, but for now, this 5400-RPM drive is really not that much slower compared to most 7200-RPM drives.I rely both on my own research and the opinions of others to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope that this review helped you to be a wise shopper! :)

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!I have two of these 1-TB drives installed in a laptop that is often used for the editing of photos, images, and very large video files.  I had originally considered getting two of the faster 7200-RPM "Scorpio Black" series drives.  But the largest "Black" drive is 750 GB, and for my purposes of needing storage space more than speed, the 2 TB of disk space from having two of these 1-TB drives installed in my laptop is significantly more important than having 500-GB less space by installing two of the faster 7200-RPM 750-GB "Black" drives.The 9.5mm-height form factor of this drive means that it can fit inside most laptops.  There are four threaded inserts on the two longer sides of the drive for use with standard mounting screws; no mounting screws or hard drive bracket/caddy are provided with this hard drive.  This drive is rated at a very quiet 22 dBA sound level when idle, and 25 dBA when the drive is seeking/reading/writing.  With two of these drives installed inside my laptop, I can only barely hear the drives' operations in a quiet room when my ears are about one to two feet away from the drives' location inside the laptop and the drives are actively reading/writing.  When the laptop is idle, I do not hear the drives at all.  And even if this hard drive is actively seeking/reading/writing, its tiny sound is masked by my laptop's fan noise even if the fan starts running from its slowest speed.When tested using the "HD Tune" hard drive performance benchmarking tool, it turns out that this 5400-RPM Scorpio Blue drive compares favorably to the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drives, even though the faster Black drives also have a 16-MB cache compared to the smaller 8-MB cache on the Blue drives.  On my installed 1-TB drives, HD Tune reported a minimum/maximum/average read speed of 56, 115, and 89 MB/sec, and a minimum/maximum/average write speed of 42, 113, and 88 MB/sec.  This is only about 10% to 15% slower than the performance of the largest-capacity 750-GB Scorpio Black drive.  This 5400-RPM drive is slightly faster than Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drive, and it even compares favorably to Seagate's Momentus XT Hybrid Drive.  This drive's random access read and write times are also comparable to both the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black and Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drives.Western Digital offers an "Acronis TrueImage" that can be downloaded from their Web site to let you copy all your data from an old drive to a new drive so you do not have to reinstall your operating system to get all the benefits of a new drive.  If you do replace your main system drive, you can either use cloning software such as "Acronis True Image" to mirror all your system files and applications back onto the new drive, or you can perform a fresh OS install and reinstall all applications that you were using.  The advantage of cloning your system files and applications is that it is much faster to put everything back onto the new drive.  The advantage of performing fresh installs of the OS and applications is that it can often declutter your files and free up hundreds of megabytes of space (which is like totally cleaning out a basement that has accumulated years of stuff).If you are trying to decide between the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drive (or some other faster 7200-RPM mobile-form-factor drive), the "Black" drive will be about 10% to 15% faster than this "Blue" drive.  Although I am using two of these drives for photo/video editing and two 7200-RPM 750-MB Scorpio Black drives would have performed faster when editing very large HD video files, this drive has pretty good performance and two of these drives do not use as much energy or generate as much heat as two 7200-RPM drives.  If you frequently use your laptop unplugged and you want to maximize the number of hours that you can run on battery power, two 5400-RPM drives drain the battery less than two 7200-RPM drives.  The Scorpio Black drives already use less power than many 7200-RPM laptop drives.  But these Scorpio Blue drives use 20% less power when reading/writing and 25% less power when idling than the Scorpio Black drives.  I love that I can pack 2-TB of reliable, quiet, inexpensive, and take-it-with-me portable storage into my laptop without needing to bring along external hard drives.  I can dream about the day that it becomes affordable to equip a laptop with two 1-TB SSD drives, but for now, this 5400-RPM drive is really not that much slower compared to most 7200-RPM drives.I rely both on my own research and the opinions of others to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope that this review helped you to be a wise shopper! :)
