This is only about 10% to 15% slower than the performance of the largest-capacity 750-GB Scorpio Black drive.  This 5400-RPM drive is slightly faster than Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drive, and it even compares favorably to Seagate's Momentus XT Hybrid Drive.  This drive's random access read and write times are also comparable to both the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black and Seagate's 7200-RPM Momentus drives.Western Digital offers an "Acronis TrueImage" that can be downloaded from their Web site to let you copy all your data from an old drive to a new drive so you do not have to reinstall your operating system to get all the benefits of a new drive.  If you do replace your main system drive, you can either use cloning software such as "Acronis True Image" to mirror all your system files and applications back onto the new drive, or you can perform a fresh OS install and reinstall all applications that you were using.  The advantage of cloning your system files and applications is that it is much faster to put everything back onto the new drive.  The advantage of performing fresh installs of the OS and applications is that it can often declutter your files and free up hundreds of megabytes of space (which is like totally cleaning out a basement that has accumulated years of stuff).If you are trying to decide between the 7200-RPM Scorpio Black drive (or some other faster 7200-RPM mobile-form-factor drive), the "Black" drive will be about 10% to 15% faster than this "Blue" drive.  Although I am using two of these drives for photo/video editing and two 7200-RPM 750-MB Scorpio Black drives would have performed faster when editing very large HD video files, this drive has pretty good performance and two of these drives do not use as much energy or generate as much heat as two 7200-RPM drives.  If you frequently use your laptop unplugged and you want to maximize the number of hours that you can run on battery power, two 5400-RPM drives drain the battery less than two 7200-RPM drives.  The Scorpio Black drives already use less power than many 7200-RPM laptop drives.  But these Scorpio Blue drives use 20% less power when reading/writing and 25% less power when idling than the Scorpio Black drives.  I love that I can pack 2-TB of reliable, quiet, inexpensive, and take-it-with-me portable storage into my laptop without needing to bring along external hard drives.  I can dream about the day that it becomes affordable to equip a laptop with two 1-TB SSD drives, but for now, this 5400-RPM drive is really not that much slower compared to most 7200-RPM drives.I rely both on my own research and the opinions of others to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope that this review helped you to be a wise shopper! :)

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!I first heard about Coenzyme Q10 in 2007 after reading Dr. Andrew Weil's book "Healthy Aging" and it really piqued my curiosity since CoQ10 has the unique ability to increase oxygen utilization in our cells.  Many people still have not heard about Coenzyme Q10 since it is far less publicized than the usual vitamins and minerals.  But in 1978, Peter Mitchell was awarded the Nobel Prize in chemistry and part of the reason for the award was his discovery of how CoQ10 helps the mitochondria in our cells turn oxygen into energy.These soft-gel capsules are quite large in size, but I found them easy to swallow when washed down with a big gulp of water.  I have not felt any side effects from taking this supplement.  This is a very valuable supplement to take, especially as you age into your 40s, 50s, and beyond.  I highly recommend this supplement!

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!Since the best sources of B-12 come from animal products, vegans and vegetarians can be at risk for B-12 deficiencies.  Previous studies have shown that, in some areas, more than 90% of vegans had B-12 deficiencies in their diet.  For more than three decades now, I have been on a vegetarian diet that includes dairy and egg.  And for vegetarians like me, two-thirds of vegetarians can also be susceptible to B-12 deficiencies.  I must admit that I do not notice the advertised benefit of "promotes better sleep" after taking this for several weeks... but I also never have sleep problems anyway.  And I did not notice any difference in energy level or healthier nerve/brain tissue.  A large part of the problem with trying to self-analyze myself after taking supplements like this is that it can be extremely difficult to subjectively judge without being mentally tripped up by possible placebo effects.  I would say the same thing about trying to judge the efficacy of taking vitamin C, D, or other B-complex vitamins.  But these chewable vitamin lozenges have a nice tasty cherry flavor to them, and they do not upset my stomach.  B-12 is a water-soluble vitamin, so unlike the fat-soluble vitamins A/D/E/K, this can be taken without being accompanied by food.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies.Over the years, I have used a variety of TASCAM pro studio gear, including their recorders and mixers, and I have been uniformly pleased with their performance.  The sound of these headphones is very good, especially when you consider the low price of these headphones.  The treble high frequencies are nicely balanced, without being too muted or too sizzling hot, and it never sounds too strident even when played loud.  The midrange and vocals are smooth.  The bass is taut, but I would have preferred a deeper bass response from the 50mm drivers used in these headphones.  Although everyone's head is sized and shaped a bit differently, I have a large head that sometimes cannot fit into some baseball caps even when the baseball caps are adjusted to maximum looseness.  And for me, these headphones clamp onto my ears a bit too tight.  Luckily, the ear cups feel comfortably padded around my ears so the discomfort is not too great.  The ear cup cavities are a bit on the small side, which is not a problem for me, but can be uncomfortable for people with big ears.  The headphone cable is generously long, almost 10 feet in length, which is great for both DJ and studio work.  Overall, the build quality is pretty good, again taking into account the value pricing of these headphones.  These headphones are not premium-grade, but they are also not premium-priced.  They are a great value for the price, as long as your head is not too big like mine and you are not expecting very deep bass output.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies.Inside this concise easy-to-read book are 39 rules for delivering great customer service.  Each numbered rule is explained within four to seven pages, with lots of anecdotes from the author's personal experiences.  To me, most of these rules amount to empathizing with the customers and treating them the way that you would want to be treated as a customer, regardless of the business or industry that you are involved in.  A few of the rules, such as "Rule #29: Have a Geek on Your Team" (so that you can keep up with, and take advantage of, the latest technologies), are not so much about customer service, but more about having good business acumen.  The 39 rules that are presented here are definitely not the ultimate, most comprehensive, collection of customer service advice.  But as a book that you can share with your co-workers, managers and non-managers alike, this book is useful for reminding us of some good core business practices, and this book can be completely read within a single day.

Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary: Recommended with warm fuzzies.Nutrition Information:Serving Size: 1 bar (40g)Servings Per Container: 12Amount Per Serving, % DVCalories:  170.00Calories from Fat:  50.00Total Fat:  6.00g,  9%Saturated Fat:  4.50g,  23%Trans Fat:  0.00Cholesterol:  10.00mg,  3%Sodium:  130.00mg, 5%Potassium:  120.00mg, 3%Total Carbohydrate: 19.00g,  6%Dietary Fiber:  0.00g,  0%Sugars:  14.00gProtein:  10.00g,  20%Iron:  6%Calcium:  20%Vitamin A:  25%Thiamin:  25%Niacin:  25%Folate:  25%Biotin:  25%Riboflavin:  25%Vitamin B6:  25%Vitamin B12:  25%Pantothenic Acid:  25%Vitamin C:  25%Vitamin D:  8%Vitamin E:  25%** Daily Value (DV) not establishedPercent Daily Values are based on a 2000 calorie diet.  Your daily values may behigher or lower depending on your calorie needs:Calories:  2000,  2500Total Fat: Less than  65g,  80gSat. Fat: Less than  20g,  25gCholesterol: Less than  300 mg,  300 mgSodium: Less than  2400 mg,  2400 mgTotal Carbohydrate:  300g,  375gDietary Fiber:  25g,  30gProtein:  50g,  65gCalories per gram:Fat: 9Carbohydrate: 4Protein: 4Other Ingredients:  Designer Whey Protein Blend (Soy Protein Isolate, Milk Protein Concentrate, Whey Protein Concentrate), Peanut Butter Flavored Coating, Honey, Brown Rice Syrup, Dried Cane Juice, Tapioca Syrup, Water, Fractionated Palm Kernel Oil, Rice Flour, Partially Defatted Peanut Flour, Sugar, Calcium Pantothenate, Vitamin A Palmitate, Pyridoxine Hydrochloride, Riboflavin, Thiamine Mononitrate, Folic Acid, Biotin, Cyanocobalamin, Cholecalciferol, Nonfat Milk, Natural Flavor, Glycerine, Tapioca Starch, Salt, Butter, High Oleic Sunflower Oil, Cocoa (Processed with Alkali), Soy Lecithin, sunflower lecithin, Sodium Caseinate, Sodium Citrate, Carrageenan, MaltodextrinWarning:  Contains Milk, Soy and Peanuts.Produced on equipment that also processes tree nuts, egg, wheat and sesame.Overall, I like this protein bar.  Although I would prefer a bit more of a peanut flavor to the taste, it is pretty good.  This protein bar has a bit of a mealy grainy texture to it.  The outside is drizzled with a little chocolate with some crunchy bits.  I like its texture and I prefer a snack bar texture that is less sticky and gooey since most gooey snack bars are loaded with corn syrup.  Each one-bar serving has a good coverage of the most common essential vitamins: Vitamins A, C, E, Thiamine, Riboflavin, Niacin, B6, Folate, B12, Biotin, and Pantothenic Acid are all at 25% RDA.Because this vegetarian-friendly protein bar contains whey protein, milk protein, and soy protein, if you are allergic to either soy or dairy products, you should probably avoid this protein bar.  Whey protein may cause gas, bloating, cramps, fatigue, and headaches in some people.  Whey protein is derived from dairy sources, and if you have lactose intolerance, you may be more susceptible to these side effects from consuming whey protein.  And since this protein bar contains whey and milk protein, it is suitable for vegetarians like me, but not suitable for people on a vegan diet.Many people, like me, eat a protein bar like this, instead of eating a regular candy bar, because they are physically active, like to stay fit, and tend to eat a healthy diet.  The reason that I rate this protein bar 4 stars instead of 5 stars is because the 5 grams of fat (8% RDA, including 3.5 grams of saturated fat (18% RDA)), 14 grams of sugar, and 190 milligrams of sodium (8% RDA) are a bit high compared to some other healthy snack bars.  Although everyone's palate differs, I think that these protein bars would taste even better with less sodium added to each bar.  But then again, I also think that many restaurants add too much salt to their dishes too.

Belkin has a good reputation for cell-phone products, at least, as far as I can tell by reading Amazon reviews. They make different types of chargers, adapters, USB cables, and so forth. And their products come in pretty colors, which is an important factor for someone like me, who hates the traditional black cables! So when I had the chance to get this USB/Lightning cable, I decided to go ahead and give it a try.It's very short, just six inches, which makes it ideal for charging your phone while you're driving---provided you don't actually need to use the phone while it's charging. If the phone is just going to sit in your center console, it's perfect. It would also work for syncing your phone with your laptop. One end is a standard USB plug, while the other end is a Lightning plug, which works with the latest generation of iPhones, iPads, and iPods. I have an iPhone 6, so it's exactly what I needed.Also, it's a lovely shade of purple. Sometimes you order a "purple" USB cable and it ends up being pink, or lavender, or magenta, or any color except purple, which can be frustrating. I like my cables and chargers to be color-coded, so I can easily tell them apart from my husband's. And I really love purple, so that's my color of choice. The last time I bought a purple charging cable, it was bright magenta, which was disappointing. But this one is exactly as advertised, a lovely shade of purple.I'm not really tech savvy, so I can't offer specs or compare it with similar models. But I can tell you that it works, which is the most important thing, right? I used it to charge my phone while out and about town, and it performed quite well. I'll give it four stars and recommend it to anyone who needs a very short, purple, Lightning to USB charging cable.

I was disappointed with this book. It bills itself as a guide for fashion designers, but I can't see how it would actually help anyone who's interested in fashion design. It's really just a catalog for the author's artwork. It's beautifully rendered, with pages that look like aged parchment, and intricate borders around the edges. Very pretty! However, it seems like English isn't the author's native language. The grammar is poor, sentences are phrased awkwardly, and so forth. I wouldn't call the errors typos, it's more like the author just isn't familiar with English.Also, the entire Kindle book has no text---it's a series of images, scans of the original book's pages. This means it takes several seconds to turn each page, because the image has to load. So if you want to flip back and forth to compare drawings, or search through the book for a specific page, it'll take forever. Several times, my Kindle Fire actually crashed, because it couldn't handle loading the graphics! This is not acceptable in a Kindle book.Aside from that, there's very little instruction for drawing your own sketches. It includes templates that you can use, but they're very stylized---so much so, that the models look like anorexic aliens, with huge heads, tiny necks, and extremely long, bony legs. I know fashion models are meant to be tall and thin, but this is absurd. The normal human being is 7 1/2 to 8 heads tall, while fashion sketches are generally 8 1/2 to 9 heads tall. The author's sketches are even taller and skinnier, with at least one having no less than 10 heads! It looks ridiculous.As a point in the author's favor, her fabrics are rendered beautifully. Very lush and detailed, which I know can be difficult to achieve. I just wish she'd explained how she'd drawn them. As another negative, there's a large section of "historical costumes," but as a historical costumer myself, I can testify that most of these are anything but accurate. Granted, the medieval period isn't my personal specialty, but the "medieval tavern wench" and "medieval costume" don't resemble anything I've seen from the medieval period. Some of the later costumes have accurate details, but the silhouettes are all wrong. The key to making a historical fashion sketch look right is the shape of the garment. With many of these dresses, the skirts are limp, as if they have no petticoats underneath. Also, they have very modern bust shapes, as if the model is wearing a modern bra, instead of the appropriate underpinnings. If these were supposed to be "historically inspired" modern garments, it wouldn't be a problem, but that isn't the case.I'll give this book two stars, because the sketches are pretty. But as far as being a help or inspiration for fashion designers? I shouldn't think so.

I enjoyed this YA book, even though it had a few flaws. The story will definitely mean more if you're familiar with "Les Miserables," either the musical, any of the movies, or the original classic book. If you have no idea what "Les Mis" is about, who the characters are, and what happens, you may find yourself feeling a bit lost. Events happen that parallel the original story, but they aren't always explained in detail, so you may be left wondering if you've missed something.The story is told in first-person, from the point of view of Eponine, a pivotal character in "Les Mis," even though the original story isn't about her. Briefly put, "Les Mis" is about a man, Jean Valjean, who is unjustly imprisoned and then struggles to make a better life for himself once being released. It takes place in early 19th century Paris (post-Napoleon), which is a political powder-keg waiting to explode. Jean Valjean ends up being responsible for a woman being turned away from her job, and when the woman dies on the streets, he swears he'll find her young daughter and raise her as his own child. He rescues the daughter, Cosette, who was basically enslaved by Eponine's parents, and takes her to Paris, where she grows up with moderate wealth and happiness. Fast forward a few years, and Cosette falls in love with a young gentleman, Marius, who is working to start a revolution in Paris. He and his friends succeed in starting their revolt, but it's short-lived, with tragic results. Marius survives, thanks to both Eponine and Jean Valjean, and he and Cosette live happily ever after.How does Eponine fit into all of this? She's also in love with Marius. Realizing he won't ever love her, she helps him woo Cosette, and even saves his life at one point during the revolt. The only backstory Eponine gets (at least in the musical), is that she grew up with Cosette. As children, Eponine was well-off, while Cosette wore rags and worked herself ragged. When they meet again, their positions are reversed---now Eponine is living in poverty, while Cosette has a happy life. You don't learn much about Eponine, but in this book, "A Little in Love," you finally get a glimpse into her unhappy childhood. As a young girl, Eponine desperately wants to be a good person, to be honest, and kind to others, but the only way she can earn her mother's affection is to present her with stolen goods, or to be cruel to others--especially to Cosette. A part of her withers with every coin she steals and every harsh word she utters, but eventually, she has the chance to live her own life. She wants to be a person worthy of Marius's love, but to her dismay, Cosette has already stolen his heart.This is a tragic story, filled with suffering and misery. But it also shows how the goodness of a person's heart can see them through the hard times.It's well-written, with a fast pace. In fact, I read the whole novel in just a few hours, so it's a good book if you're looking for something that won't take forever to finish. It reads a bit too easily at times---it's definitely YA, not adult---but the author has an excellent voice, and she's a great storyteller. Many scenes were vivid and detailed, with descriptions that pull you right into the story. The downside is, the book doesn't have nearly as much content as it could have. It skips over long periods of time, jumping forward, instead of fleshing things out. There was so much potential, events that could have happened, scenes that could have had MORE. I felt like perhaps the author didn't want the story to get too dark, so she glossed over things that would, most likely, have happened to Eponine in Paris. I think the author should have embraced the darkness, instead of fighting it, since "Les Miserables" is, by its very nature, a dark story.There were also a few scenes where I was strongly reminded of the recent movie/musical. A couple of sections contained word-for-word quotes, which is definitely something you want to avoid when writing a book based off a famous movie or play. It's simply too distracting, not to mention the potential for copyright infringement! But these were few and far-between, so I can forgive them. Mostly.I'll give this book four stars, because it was an entertaining way to spend the evening. However, I'll only recommend it if you're a fan of "Les Mis" and want to know more of Eponine's personal backstory. If you haven't read the book, or seen the musical, or any of the movies, you'll probably want to skip it.

I've been wanting to try a rotary cutter for some time now, but it's always intimidated me. I'm rather clumsy at times and I was scared I'd slip while cutting and slice my hand. Enter the Ruler Handle, a small handle that attaches to your ruler via suction cups! It elevates your hand, so there's less risk of you getting hurt while rotary cutting. It also gives you an easier way of holding your ruler straight while cutting.The suction cups on mine are clear, not black as shown in the description photo. But that's even better!The only problem I've found is that the suction cups will not stick to a ruler that has tiny holes in it. Apparently, the suction cups can't fully adhere if the surface isn't solid. Unfortunately, many quilting rulers have small holes running down the middle. My new ruler has holes running along its entire length, but my older ruler only has holes across half of it, which means I can use the older ruler, so long as I'm careful where I place the handle. This is annoying, because it's an old ruler, faded and worn out. I was planning to retire it, but now I have to keep it around for use with my rotary cutter. But I suppose this isn't the product's fault. It's just how suction cups work.All in all, I'm pleased with this product. I used a rotary cutter for the first time the other day and the handle worked quite well. I'll give it four stars and recommend it to anyone who sews, quilts, or crafts, and needs to keep their ruler steady while measuring or drawing lines.

This is a pack of 100 white magazine-size comic boards. Most people use them as a backing for comic books in protective sleeves, to prevent the comic from getting bent. They're very stiff, but not too thick, so I can see how they would work great for that purpose. Personally, I ordered them because I'd read a blog post about using them to wrap fabric around, to help organize your sewing room. I haven't quite mastered the art of wrapping fabric around these boards, but they do seem sturdy enough to support a yard of lightweight to medium-weight fabric.My only complaint is that these boards don't come in a box. You get a giant stack of them, but they're shrink-wrapped, which means once you tear the plastic off, you have a hundred loose boards, with nothing to keep them contained. If you aren't planning to use all of them right away, it could be a problem. Also, because of the lack of a protective box, the top board had a damaged edge.In general, I'm happy with this purchase. Not sure if I'd buy again---I guess it depends on whether I can master the art of fabric-wrapping. But my husband collects comics, so if I can't use all of them, I'm sure he'd be happy to take them off my hands!

This is a transparent ruler, perfect for anyone who sews, quilts, or crafts. It's printed with a 1/8-inch grid, so you can measure both width and length, which is fantastic. (I have another transparent ruler that does not have a grid, and it's so much harder to measure seam allowances with.)I ordered this to replace my old ruler, which is getting pretty dinged up and faded. What I received must be an upgraded version, because it's different from my old ruler---in a good way! The grid and numbers are a darker shade of blue, which makes them a lot easier to see. The numbers along one edge are much larger, which makes them easier to see. No more squinting at the ruler, trying to read the tiny, faded numbers! Also, there are small holes running down the entire length of the ruler, which allows you to use it to draw circles. Just place a pin in one of the holes---whichever one is at the measurement equal to the radius of the circle you want to draw---and then place your pencil at the short edge, and pivot the ruler, drawing your circle.The drawback is, the small holes make it impossible to use a suction-cup handle with this ruler. When you're cutting with a rotary cutter, you need a sturdy ruler that you can anchor in place with a suction-cup handle. (The handle raises your hand above the ruler, so you won't slice your fingers if you accidentally slip with the rotary cutter. They're VERY sharp!) Well, unfortunately, the small holes prevent the suction cup from adhering to the ruler. So it won't work for cutting bias strips with a rotary cutter. But that's a minor inconvenience, unless you were hoping to get away with only having one all-purpose ruler.I also appreciate that the new ruler has numbers oriented in both directions, so you don't have to turn the ruler the other way just to read the numbers. (Unless it's upside-down, in which case, the numbers will be backwards and yes, you'll have to turn it over.) But with my old ruler, I was always having to rotate it the other way, just so I could read the numbers. No more! And, as a bonus, the new ruler has a hole at one end, which allows you to hang it from a hook.In short, I'm extremely pleased with this ruler! It's so much easier to use than my old one. I'll give it five stars and heartily recommend it to anyone who sews, quilts, or crafts. It's great for measuring fabric, drafting patterns, and so forth.P.S. For a comparison of the old version with the new one, see the attached photo.

This is plain black ink---the large tank, which I believe it uses for printing text. Our printer has a second black ink, which is narrow, like the colored inks. Its code number is #226, so double-check before you order, just to be sure you're replacing the correct ink tank.This ink is pretty good. I mean, I can't really use any other type of ink in our printer, so it's hard to compare it with other brands. But it does a fair enough job. And by that I mean the text it prints is black, like it should be. It's easy to install, although if you've never done it before, it might take you a minute to figure it out. You have to peel off a bit of shrink-wrapping, then twist this orange thing off the top of the ink, while being careful not to accidentally block this tiny hole with your fingers. After that, you just open your printer and pull out the old, used ink, and pop the new one in. It's pretty straightforward.I have no complaints, except for the fact that our printer guzzles this stuff like mad. But I think that's the printer's fault, not the ink's. I tend to print in spurts, I'll have several things to print one day, then I'll go a week or two without printing anything. Be warned---if you go more than a week without printing, the ink can dry up and clog, which ruins the ink tank. This has happened to us more than once. So try to print something every week, even if you don't really need to, just to keep the ink flowing.Four stars, good product. Recommended to anyone with a printer that takes this type of ink, especially if you print a lot of word documents.

I'm not really tech savvy, so I can't quote statistics at you, or compare this cable with others that are out there. What I CAN tell you is that this is a perfectly serviceable USB cable with a Lightning tip. It can be used to charge your iPhone (5 and 6 only, I believe), as well as newer iPads, and any other devices that use a Lightning connector. It's pretty long, so it'll reach places that the shorter cables won't. And it allows for a swift charge, so I'm happy.Oh, and it's purple! What's not to love? The only thing is, the cable I received is not lavender, as pictured. It's a much darker pinkish-purple. That's fine---I didn't necessarily need lavender, I just wanted something in the purple color family. But if you're expecting a pastel lavender, as shown, you might be disappointed.Other than that, I have no complaints. At home, I keep it plugged into a USB charging port on my nightstand, so I can plug my iPhone in whenever I need to charge it. I've used it daily for several months now, and it's never failed me. I also take it with me when I travel, so I can charge my iPhone in the car or at the hotel. I'll subtract a star because the color was so far off from what I was expecting, but since it's otherwise an excellent USB cable, I'll give it four stars in all. Recommended for anyone who needs a long USB/Lightning cable.

This device is very interesting! I saw it advertised on "Shark Tank," a TV show that features people who've come up with a unique product they want to sell. If one of the investors likes the product and thinks the person is capable of selling it globally, they'll sponsor them, giving them funding in exchange for a percentage of their company. Needless to say, this product won a sponsor. But what is it, exactly? It's tool that allows you to apply pressure to spots on your back or neck, without contorting yourself in an effort to reach them.Aha! Genius. Pure genius!I have both fibromyalgia and myofascial pain syndrome, along with other medical conditions. As a result, I often get pinched nerves from spasming muscles. It's a painful condition that's treated with heat and massage, along with applying steady pressure to the tight muscles, which tricks them into relaxing. Since the pinched nerves usually occur between my spine and shoulder blades, it's very hard to reach them on my own. But it's hard for my husband to massage the spots for me, since he doesn't know exactly where to apply pressure, or how hard to press. The best trick I've found is actually two tennis balls in a knotted sock. I lean against the wall, sandwiching the tennis balls between the wall and my back. Then I bend my knees, moving up and down, rolling the balls along my back until they reach the spot I need to apply pressure to. And if that sounds awkward . . . well, yes, it is! It's hard to maneuver the tennis balls to the right spot and then keep them there. I've also tried a massage chair, which has hard, round bumps that rotate and move up and down to "massage" your neck and back. But the amount of pressure it applies is too much for me---It helps, yes, but I find it quite painful. For years, I've longed for a better solution. And I think I've found it with the Q-Flex.Basically, this tool is a question mark-shaped stick, with a foam grip to hold onto, and a hard ball-point on the other end. You angle the curved section over your shoulder, or under your arm, applying pressure to your back or neck with the ball-point. It allows you to reach virtually any part of your neck, upper back, lower back, etc. If you're interested in official acupressure techniques, it comes with a little booklet that shows you where to apply pressure for certain results. If you're more interested in stopping pinched nerves, muscle spasms, or knotted muscles, it can do that, too. Just place the ball-point anywhere you need it, then angle the handle and pull. You control how much pressure you apply, so you can make sure it doesn't get painful. It may take a little practice to figure out exactly where to place the tip and what angle to use, but you'll figure it out quickly.I love this product, but I'm a bit confused by the fact that it claims to be a "Back and Body Massage Tool." If there's a way to use it to massage your own back, I haven't figured it out. Seems like it would be painful to rub your back with the hard ball-point. Not to mention awkward. But if you want to apply steady, direct pressure to a specific spot to relieve muscle tension and spasms, it's truly excellent!I'll give the Q-Flex four stars and recommend it to anyone who suffers from muscle spasms or pinched nerves in your neck or back. You might check with your doctor to ask about the safest way to use this device, just to be sure you aren't doing more harm than good. I'm very pleased with the Q-Flex and intend to share it with friends and family members. (But they'll have to order their own, if they like it!)* Edited to Add (10/12/15): I figured out how to use the Q-Flex for massage! You just slide it up and down your back. I thought it would be awkward, but if you're wearing a t-shirt, it slides back and forth easily. Now, it's not as good as an actual massage from a person, obviously, but it does what it claims. Therefore, I'm adjusting my rating up to 5 stars. Great product!

These are high-quality snaps. They're size 3, so they're fairly large. (At least, they seem quite large to me, since I'm used to working with doll-sized snaps!) Perfect for fastening a book cover, tote bag, purse, coat, jacket---anything that requires a large, sturdy snap. I bought them to use with crocheted neck-warmers, so they would wrap around the neck and stay in place without shifting, or having buttons pop loose. The snaps work quite well for that purpose.These happen to be black snaps, so they're good for use with dark fabrics or materials, especially if you don't want the snaps to be visible. The crocheted neck-warmer I made is dark teal, and I was afraid silver snaps would be too visible, so I opted for black.You get a pack of four snaps, with two halves each (male and female). They're sew-on snaps, which means you'll need a large needle and thread. I recommend using waxed thread, as there's less chance it'll break, or knot and snarl, while you're sewing. (To wax it, pull the thread through a cake of beeswax several times, until it feels a bit like dental floss. Fold the thread into a scrap of muslin and press with a warm iron. This melts the wax, fusing it with the thread.) Be sure to use thread that matches your fabric closely, so it won't be too visible.Very nice product! They don't pop open easily, even under strain. Indeed, it takes some effort to unsnap them. Highly recommend for anyone who needs a sturdy closure for clothing, home decor items, purses or totes, etc.

I really don't like to start a review on a negative note, however this one warrants such. Bayou Blue is sad, disturbing, and shows  what ails us as a society and nation.I saw and watched this film/documentary on another site before Amazon - I watched it out of curiosity mostly, also a young woman somewhere on the internet is searching for this- one of her relatives was a victim of serial killer Ronald Dominique who from 1997- 2006 raped and killed 23 men.I have watched Cajun Justice here on Amazon, much of that show was filmed in these small towns where most of the killings took place, in one of the episodes of Cajun Justice, a man did mention that there had been a serial killer in the area, he didn't mention a name, he looked  embarrassed.I think most people were just as shocked and surprised as anybody that such a person lived in their area and nobody had a clue what was happening or who the killer was.It's unfortunate that the only beauty or redeeming feature in this film is the natural beauty that is southeastern Louisiana.Most of the bayou's are dying and along with it a special way of life. Hurricane Katrina the BP oil spill after that, lack of other jobs in industry or otherwise, chronic poverty and lack of education- who's to blame?. There are many unanswered questions, this has the feel of a whodunit mystery,since you have to wait til half way through this film to get a brief , glance of the man who is shielded by police and shrouded in darkness, whimpering and head down. Too bad this man didn't seek mental help or have anyone to confide in, many lives would have been spared.Unfortunately this was real life, not a figment of a writers imagination and many people there in the bayous live with many real fears everyday, fear of losing their way of life and culture, fear of the erosion of the bayous, fear of corruption, fear of being forgotten and misunderstood. I think this documentary is food for thought on many levels. Persons judging or looking down on anyone in this film should take a good long look at themselves in the mirror, the persons interviewed on the film may not have cried on camera nor speak the Queens English or several other points made by some (rude and unfeeling, might I add) that were made.  However, they are the true survivors and in many ways stronger than many of us , who sit in front of our computers and write a review on these kinds of atrocities while others have to live with this misery every day. So think before you write something mean people, Karma is very real, and you may have to live the life you just made fun of on this film. If my review has helped click yes below. thank you.

This is an excellent brush for blending powder eye shadow in the crease area, but it is not perfect.  It would be perfect if the bristles were slightly firmer and the brush head had a slightly narrower shape.  Just a tad, because you don't want overly stiff bristles, nor too narrow; you can buy crease brushes that are quite narrow.The fact is, the brush is great for blending, but I could get my eye makeup done faster with the aforementioned adjustments.  As it is, it's great if you're not playing beat the clock!I've also used this as a lid, and all-over eye area brush.  If you can afford only one eye shadow brush, buy this one.Though this brush is also easy to clean, once you've used it, it will never be white again.  It absorbs pigment and becomes stained with first use.  It's stained, mind you.  It isn't holding product.  If you use a gray eye shadow one day and a brown the next, the brush won't transfer gray in with the brown.The handle is a nice length, and it's well-balanced.  I heartily recommend it.  Just know it isn't a be-all, end-all brush.

This protein bar is supposed to be chocolate, almond, and coconut flavor.  The main flavor note is chocolate; occasionally I pick up on the almond and coconut.  This was a dire disappointment to me, because I love chocolate and coconut, and if there is almond, so much the better.I only bought one box, and I did finish it.  It isn't like the flavor is awful.  They actually taste pretty good.  They just don't taste quite as I expected.  The flavor and texture are quite pleasant, and I appreciate being able to find a protein source that isn't sky high in calories.Nevertheless, I experienced some gastrointestinal distress, the details of which I'll spare you, dear reader.  Let it suffice that I personally cannot recommend these protein and fiber bars based on this experience.  Your experience may vary.

I've decided I'm never buying makeup brush sets again.  I've bought several sets, and there is always something disappointing about them.  Just as there is always a color in a palette I will never use, so are makeup brush sets.  Always, there are unnecessary or poorly designed brushes.  Even Paula's Choice brush sets include clunkers.Last year, after reading rave reviews, I purchased BEST SELLING Professional 8 Piece Makeup Brush Set with Designer Case Plus BONUS Stippling Brush. Hand-Made Powder, Foundation, Concealer, Eye Shadow Brushes and More. Professionally Endorsed.  These brushes are good quality, but I only like the powder brush and one of the eye shadow brushes.  That didn't save me any money!  Essentially, I paid over forty dollars for a powder brush and eye shadow brush.  The biggest disappointment in that set is the blush brush.  It's too small, and it isn't round.This blush brush is meant for use with powder blush.  It looks and feels like it's made of luxurious animal hair, but in fact, the bristles are synthetic.  They are made with DuPont Natrafil, developed to perform like animal hair bristles.This is the yummiest makeup brush I've ever used, period.  The bristles are very soft, but sufficiently dense.  The brush picks up powder brush with the gentlest touch against the pan.  Blush powder doesn't blow around in the air.  It stays on the brush until I apply it to my face with a few quick strokes.  It blends perfectly.I've had this brush long enough to wash it twice.  It really doesn't need cleaning as often as my other makeup brushes, because the blush picked up  is deposited almost entirely on the face.  It simply takes longer for it to get dirty.  When I clean my makeup brushes, I fill my bathroom basin with a couple inches of water, and add a generous amount of CeraVe Foaming Facial Cleanser.  I swirl the bristle ends of my brushes in that solution.  This brush gets clean faster than any other brush I own.  After washing, I refill the basin with clean water and swirl; then I repeat to make sure all the cleanser is rinsed.  I gently squeeze the bristles, and lie the brush flat on a paper towel.I've read that Natrafil brushes dry faster than brushes made from other materials.  I find this untrue.  This brush does take longer to dry than my other brushes.  But it's worth it to have the absolute perfect powder blush brush.  This brush far exceeds my expectations.  You will not be disappointed!

I always keep Fruit of the Eart Vloe Vera Gel on hand, because it's so useful.Unlike many aloe gels, this does not contain added colors, SD alcohol, menthol, or lidocaine.  SD alcohol and menthol provide a cooling sensation, but can irritate the skin.  Lidocaine is what your dentist injects into your gums to numb nerve endings for dental procedures.  I have used gels with lidocaine in the past, and it does help with the pain, but it will not help heal the burn.  Neither will SD alcohol or menthol.If you have mild sunburn, apply this frequently, stay inside, and stay cool.  Fortunately, this product can be applied as often as you please.  If your sunburn is moderate to severe, see your doctor.I use this for minor household burns.  Two days ago, I burned my forearm near my elbow while reaching into a 425 degree oven.  Right away, I ran some cool (not cold) water over the affected area, and started applying this gel every couple hours.  I also used a good moisturizer and sunscreen; more on those products later.  The burned area of skin is now brown.  There is no redness, no pain or irritation, blistering, peeling, or scabbing.  The skin is perfectly smooth and the mark will fade.It's also good for an array of minor skin irritations.  Sometimes when I'm handling plants and gardening, oils from the plant cause a bit of an allergic reaction.  I'm not talking about poison ivy types of reactions here, just itchiness with or without redness, without a rash.  It's quite soothing.  It also helps heal minor cuts and abrasions, those tiny injuries that happen while cleaning house or handling office items.I've used it in a pinch as hair gel.  It has no film formers or silicones, so it doesn't add hold or shine, but the thickeners will add some body to my hair, which is great, because my hair can use all the body I can give it.For both men and women this is possibly the best aftershave product out there.  No matter how you remove hair, you may experience skin irritation.  Depilatories, epilators, electric, and blade razors can all cause rash or razor burn.  Gentlemen, please get rid of aftershave products and use this.  Don't use aftershave products or colognes containing alcohol or menthol.  No matter what you've been told, these products are not good for your skin.  You may think the "burn" is a necessary part of a good shave, but you're wrong.  A good shave is the result of good shaving tools and techniques.  Those products burn because they irritate your skin, and the more irritation you have from shaving, the more they burn.  Otherwise, this is the first thing you should apply to your skin after shaving.Use styptic powder or pencil, or an alum block to stop bleeding if necessary.  Then, men and women both, use this gel first thing after shaving or other methods of hair removal.  Aloe contains potent anti-irritants.  It will soothe your skin, and help ease redness.  After using the aloe gel, apply a moisturizer, such as Cerave Facial Moisturizing Lotion PM, CeraVe Moisturizing Lotion, or ShiKai Lotion, Dry Skin Therapy, Gold Bond  Ultimate Restoring Lotion, With CoQ10.  You'll need sunscreen if you go outside.  I recommend Olay Professional Pro-X Age Repair Lotion With Sunscreen Broad Spectrum SPF 30, EltaMD UV Lotion Broad-Spectrum SPF 30+, Banana Boat Sunscreen Protect and Hydrate Moisturizing Broad Spectrum Sun Care Sunscreen Lotion - SPF 50, or Industrial Strength SunscreenISSC-8-30+FF SPF 30+Micro Refined Clear Zinc OxideFragrance Free.Finally, and yummiest of all, this is so marvelous for rubbing your feet.  Especially in the summer, when it's mighty cooling, sometime after you get home from school or work, get your dawgs out of your shoes and spend a few minutes massaging your feet with aloe gel.  It feels fantastic, and it isn't so messy as massage creams, lotions, or oils, or other moisturizers.  It's a dandy treat for your feet.

It's too bad the vendor doesn't let you choose a color package, but I like the colors I got.  The shirt fits as expected according to the size chart, but beware:  The arm holes are enormous!  They're cut well into the chest area, so you definitely don't want to leave the house wearing these shirts.I would hope you aren't planning to wear them outside the house, anyway.  I bought them to help keep cool on hot, humid days, and they're great for that.  And I don't have to worry about pit stains.....I actually like the fact that the armholes are so big.  Makes for a very comfortable shirt.I wash mine in cold and hang them to dry.  They're all cotton, but thin, and dry in a trice.  After several washes, one shirt started losing its hem thread.  I keep cutting it - don't pull.  It will just unravel more.They're really super to wear while doing aerobics or yoga.  I would buy again, no matter what colors I got.

The sizing is correct, and it is indeed skinny as promised.  The extra brass adds a tiny amount of bulk, but doesn't dig when you sit down.It's not built to last, but at this price, that's OK, and you can afford to buy several colors.

This tisane is quite sweet.  You won't need any sweetener.  The sweetness is tempered by the spearmint, so you have a fruity-flavored, minty beverage which is nice hot or iced.  Soothing in the throat, and very relaxing, indeed.  I would buy this again.

I recently read about marula oil, and that it contains vitamins A, C, and E, if I recall correctly.  There are lots of oils that can be used on skin or hair, but not all of them have antioxidants, so I had to try it.There is no added fragrance.  It's a plant oil with medium viscosity, and it absorbs into skin fairly well.  I personally do not like the way it feels on my face, and I can't use it on my hair, because my hair is too fine.  I use this primarily after a shower.  I towel off my torso, step out of the shower, and put four or five squirts on each arm, and five or six squirts on each leg.  Then I rapidly rub it around on my wet skin.  It's a very effective moisturizer!Though packaged with a spray pump, the oil is to thick to spray.  It works more like a lotion pump.  I like the packaging, but it could be better.  An opaque bottle and airtight seal would have behooved me to rate this five stars.  I advise you to keep it capped and in a dark place when not in use to prevent light and air from breaking down the antioxidants.  There are no preservatives, aside from the antioxidants, so when you get it, use it.  The bottle will last a surprisingly long time.It's also a good spot moisturizer for very dry areas.  It's nice on feet at night, with socks so you don't mess up your sheets.  Don't oil your feet in the daytime.  You'll be slip-sliding in your shoes all day.  It's good on cuticles and those doggone dry patches on my knuckles.  If you do put oil on your hair or scalp, this is definitely worth trying.Whatever you use it for, you could buy a similar product at a higher price that isn't any better.  Highly recommended.

Nice cords for beading or to use as a non-metallic chain for a pendant, about 2 mm by 3 mm.  The materials don't really feel like suede.  They have a very soft feel.  They do look almost like suede.  I've had no problems with pilling, stretching, or breaking.It's a nice color assortment, too, but not all the colors match my color palette, so there are some I won't use.  I do like them.

This is a comprehensive stretching program divided into three separate workouts, approximately 20 minutes each.Each body part is stretched in each workout, and if you do all of the workouts, I daresay you'll have stretched every single muscle except your tongue and scalp muscles.  The workouts build upon each other, too.  What you do in the Easy workout helps you prepare for the Moderate workout, and you need to be capable of doing both of these to do the Intense workout.Attention is paid to the neck, shoulders, arms, wrists, fingers, chest, back, groin, glutes, all four major thigh muscles, calves, ankles, feet, and toes.  In 20 minutes, no less.  Many of the stretches are active stretches.  None are held more than a few seconds.  The Intense workout has some ballistic stretches.The Intense workout is somewhat aerobic, and successful practice of some of the moves calls for considerable strength.  The Easy and Moderate workouts are easy for me, but I have some difficulty with some of the moves in the Intense workout, primarily the backbend series that begins around one hour and three minutes in the streaming version.  Something to aspire to, though.I do the Moderate followed by the Easy workout at least twice a week, after an aerobic, strength, or yoga session.  Please note, you've probably done most of these stretches in some form in P.E. classes at school.  They are not exotic moves, and easy to re-learn.I do have a couple of quibbles, though.  There is a glaring error in the instruction in the Easy workout.  Following a lift-your-toe calf stretch, one knee is forward and bent; the other leg is behind you and straight.  Kim says to stretch the "back hamstrings".  You're not stretching your hamstrings.  You're stretching your calf.  If you try to stretch your hamstrings from this position, you'll hyperextend your knee.  So, watch out for that part.The other quibble is a bit more serious.  I've had my reasons to practice flexibility all my life, and I find some of the transitions too fast for my taste.  I can do them, but my form suffers.  For the person unacquainted with flexibility exercises, they could cause loss of balance or a strain, particularly in the adductors.Otherwise, this is a fine program for overall flexibility, and I do recommend it.  Be sure to watch each workout first, and if you have difficulty with the pacing, opt for skipping a move.  And remember, if you don't use it, you lose it.

This insect killer contains effective ingredients, and is priced right.  I like Ortho products overall.  It's generally a good brand.So I expected certain qualities, which this didn't deliver for me.  For one thing, the nozzle drips, and I mean excessively.  Every pull of the trigger dispenses spray, plus a substantial dribble of product that rolls down the bottle, and doesn't land anywhere you'd want it to.I shook the product before use, on a sunny, 77-degree day with 5 mph winds.  A perfect day.  The product rolled right off the leaves of my rosebush, as if raindrops were falling.  The product didn't stick to the rosebush at all.  That means the only way it will work is if it's sprayed directly on insects.  If it doesn't stick to the plant, it can't work systemically.  Unless that's why the nozzle drips - to let it fall to earth and be absorbed into the roots.  That doesn't seem likely.  And it's supposed to work on contact and systemically, but if it's not sticking to, or getting absorbed by the plant, it sure can't work systemically.I'm sure you can find another Ortho pesticide that will work for your flowering plants.  This isn't it.

This mouse is sturdy and accurate.  It has some heft, but is not so heavy it will slow you down.  It features smooth, matte surfaces that allow good, easy gripping without slipping.The forward/backward buttons are positioned so you can use your thumb, keeping your fingers available for faster reactions.  They are not so far back they get in the way of your thumb.This mouse is sold with a free mouse pad, which I find OK.  I kind of like to play without a mouse pad, myself.  I always go over the edge at an inopportune moment.  You may or may like it; if you don't, use it as a coaster.  You gotta have some place to set your Slurpee!This mouse is not programmable, and isn't advertised or presented as programmable.  It is a basic, wired mouse that will take a pounding.  Even the USB cord is fabric-protected.The one thing I really don't care for is the scroll wheel.  It is set up to ratchet for accuracy, but it is far too tight for me.  It takes enough force to move it that it distracts me.But if you want a basic, sturdy, comfortable gaming mouse, you'll be satisfied with this one.

This oil and emulsifier based cleanser removes all traces of makeup and does not leave skin feeling stripped.  It is an impressive makeup remover.I have issues with the aesthetics, though.  The first time I used it, I kept wondering when it would start to foam because it felt like I was still rubbing oil and water on my skin.  I finally opened my eyes and glanced in the mirror to find it was indeed foaming.  I can't feel it changing on my face or with my fingertips.  I've used it a good two weeks now, and that hasn't changed.  I know that after I add water, it will start foaming, but I can't tell when that happens.  It is impossible to rinse off unless I use a washcloth.  I can see the makeup is gone, but water beads up on my face.  I appreciate the softness, but I really don't like leaving cleanser on my face, so I scrape it off with a wash cloth.Yesterday, I noticed the "Safe For" symbol on the back of the bottle.  This symbol looks like a jar, and has a number followed by the letter "M".  This symbol is not on all cosmetic and personal care consumables, but I find it more and more often.  Unfortunately, according to the "Safe For" symbol on this bottle, the cleanser is safe to use for a mere three months after opening.  I think the average consumer will wind up wasting a lot of product.  Exceptions would be multi-user households.

A dozen monkish thirty-somethings practice their disciplines in or away from their home base in Garrison Oaks.  Carolyn's practice is language.  Since her parents died, she's dedicated her life to learning languages.  Margaret's discipline is dying, Jennifer's is healing and resurrecting; Michael puts Dr. Doolittle to shame with his relationships with animals of the air, land, and sea.  David battles, and Peter studies mathematics.  Rachel predicts the future.  Almost all of their parents are dead, and they consider themselves a family because since they were orphaned, they have been under the care of and serving Father, a powerful enigma.Father becomes absent, and none of them know where to find him.  Someone has to take over and lead the family.  No one talks about it, but a power struggle and mayhem ensue.  Some of the family seem clueless.  Others, like Carolyn, are ruthless.Carolyn enlists an outsider named Steve to do her dirty work, and won't give him a break.  He winds up charged with murder, then escaping jail while being interviewed by a government agent named Erwin, who is badass defined.  What is not clear, and makes the middle of the book a compulsive read, is Carolyn's true motivation and methods.  This is one of the most creative story arcs I've read in years.  It's absolutely impossible, but completely logical.  For a fantasy.It's unfortunate that Mr. Hawkins did not maintain the urgency of the middle of the book through to the end.  I thought the story would end with a bang, but it ended in a soft, cozy thud.  Still, most of it is a very exciting read, provided you don't mind a little blood and guts.

This toothbrush has very soft bristles and is well suited to brushing sore teeth or when gums are sore.  On the reverse are rubber nibs which can be used in a pinch.  Sometimes just one bristle hitting the wrong way can send one to the ceiling.  The nibs are not as effective at cleaning, but are certainly better than nothing when one cannot bear to brush.  The nibs work like a teething ring.  The toothbrush handle holds the gel, and has a large ergonomic grip.The actives in the pain relieving gel raise the pH on the affected tooth, and fill "tubules" in dentin and cementum.  Tubules allow air and water to pass through the tooth to the nerve.  Thus, the actives effectively block air and liquid from reaching the nerve, preventing pain from occurring.I like the toothbrush and gel very much, and recommend this product particularly when one is traveling and unable to get to a dentist should sensitivity occur.  The package instructions state the entire tube should be used.  This may apply for chronically sensitive teeth, but otherwise I would not advise using the gel for extended periods.  If sensitivity lasts more than a week, especially if new, one should see one's dentist.A toothbrush you should buy just in case.

Terry Masear is a college professor teaching English as a Second Language.  When she discovers a hummingbird chick fallen from his nest, she contacts Jean Roper, hummingbird rehabilitator extraordinaire.  Jean helps her and Terry tells her to call if she needs help. Jean does, and Terry is sucked into the world of hummingbird rehabilitation.In other words, Ms. Masear didn't aspire to this calling.  She is a natural storyteller.  Her rehab memoir spans the summer of 2008, and includes lots of useful information for hobbyist hummingbirders.  She spills all the poop:  How Hollywood hummingbirds typically get hurt, hours fielding frantic phone calls, a grueling schedule of feeding the birds she's rehabbing, and cleaning up the mess.Two birds, Gabriel and Pepper, require special attention before they can be released, and you'll not want to see them go.If your mantra is "four parts water, one part sugar", this is a must read.  Two wings up!

I watered my dirt (too soon to plant!), and found this hose easy to handle.  It does not twist easily.  It's suitable for light to medium duty tasks.I hadn't thought about it, but the garden hose I have been using before I got this is 5/8" diameter.  This is 1/2" diameter.  Because of that, it does weigh less.  It also has a plastic anti-twist grip; my old hose has a stainless steel one, so that cuts down the weight, too.  But I think the plastic grip cuts the quality somewhat.For my own knowledge, I did some research and found that 1/2" hoses deliver about 9 gallons of water per minute, while 5/8" hoses deliver 17 gallons per minute.  If you're trying to limit water use, this hose will be helpful, but if you need more flow, it won't.This hose is for cold water only, so if you have a hot water pressure washer, you'll need a different hose.  This hose has very good burst strength.I find the connector dissatisying.  It is perfectly round and smooth.  My old hose is beveled, which means if it gets stuck on the spigot (yes, I've had this happen), I can use a wrench to loosen it.  That won't work with this hose.Since some hoses don't even have an anti-twist grip, and others have better grips and connectors, I'm calling this one in the middle.  I'd encourage you to think about what you really need from your garden hose(s), and try to get the best quality YOU need for the best price.

When I viewed the product page, I was intrigued by the list of ingredients.  I don't know that probiotics applied to skin are beneficial, but the other ingredients sounded great, so I bought it.The product I received did not have the same ingredients on its label, but I was still interested.  This is a rich cream with plenty of slip.  A little goes a long way, it hydrates well, and does not feel greasy.But it came with a surprise odor.  I do not want to sound mean-spirited, but it smells foul.  The best I can describe the smell of this skin cream is regurgitated wine.  It is absolutely horrible.  But I've changed diapers; I figured I could get used to any odor.  I can't.  I used it every day for three weeks and I'm throwing in the towel.  I do not like to be wasteful, but this is going in the trash.  I can't bear to apply it any longer.I don't know why it has such a foul odor.  Bad batch?  Old Product?  Could be either with the discrepant ingredient label, or it could be lack of familiarity with stinky ingredients on my part.  I can't factually state why it smells so bad, but it does.  I will not purchase this again, and I won't be trying any other Acure Organics products.  Not recommended.

This ear cuff is perfect for everyday wear.  I bought the right cuff, too.Actually, most people think I'm wearing earrings, but the silver wire that wraps around the ear catches their eye; it's different, but not gaudy.So I have a pair of cuffs I can wear on all but the most formal occasions.  They slip on and off easily, they're comfortable, attractive, and go with everything.  The pearls are tiny, but still pretty.I've had these several months.  I keep them in the pouch so they don't tarnish.I really love these, so two wings up!

This ear cuff is perfect for everyday wear.  I bought the left cuff, too.Actually, most people think I'm wearing earrings, but the silver wire that wraps around the ear catches their eye; it's different, but not gaudy.So I have a pair of cuffs I can wear on all but the most formal occasions.  They slip on and off easily, they're comfortable, attractive, and go with everything.  The pearls are tiny, but still pretty.I've had these several months.  I keep them in the pouch so they don't tarnish.I really love these, so two wings up!

It isn't hard to find a screen protector to fit a Fire HD 7" second generation.  Amazon was kind enough to put all the buttons on the back of the device, so the surface is completely flat, with no cutouts.  A screen protector need be only the correct size to fit perfectly.This overpriced product is ONE screen protector, for front and back of the device, a bottle of soap solution, and a cloth.  I did not use the portion for the back of the device, because I always put my tablets in some sort of case to protect the entire device.The soap solution is provided to facilitate the "wet" method of installing the screen protector.  I watched the youtube video as advised in instructions.  These instructions advised any small bubbles would vanish in a few days.Well, they didn't.  Ever.  The solution was way too soapy as well.  I can live with Tiny Bubbles under my screen protector.  I really can, as long as they don't interfere with the display.  But smearing is unacceptable.  The solution smeared on the back side of the screen protector, and it wouldn't go away, either.I've found with other devices I've bought I can do a wet application with my eyeglass cleaning cloth and solution that I get refilled for free at the Big W.  And there are plenty of screen protectors that cost much less money.  I could kick myself for buying this.  Actually, I did kick myself.  Then I went and got a different screen protector at a reasonable price.Novelty does not mean quality.

I remember vividly the first time I tried on a pair of Nike Air sneakers.  It was 1989, and the shoes were white leather with royal blue trim.  The price was $108.00.  I'd found a pair of Brooks I liked, but my husband kind of insisted I try these because the shoe sales person recommended them.  At first, I shook my head.  That's a lot of money for a pair of sneakers, and it was a boat load of money in 1989.  I tried them on just to get my usually cheapskate husband to shut up.He asked me how they felt.  I turned to him and said, "They feel like little tiny elves made them just especially for my feet."  We bought them, and for a while, I wouldn't buy ANY shoe but Nike Air.I had a change of heart primarily because the shoe stores that carried the full Nike Air line stopped carrying them, or went out of business.  I had to find other sneaker brands that suited me.  And I have found good sneakers, but nothing like Nike Air.This pair has fabric uppers and a minimalist build.  There are plenty of splashes of color, but no extraneous stitching.  The stitching in the upper is confined to the lace and tongue area, the strip of vinyl at the front of the toe box, which does not touch your toes if you buy the correct size, and bracing stitches at the back of the heel.The first thing I noticed when I tried these was how balanced my posture became, immediately.  I could feel my center of balance shift directly above my arches.  The air in the sole absorbs shock and provides cushion, but this is balanced against the function of the shoe.  The sole facilitates movement.  It is not minimalist thin like many running shoes on the market today, but it is not thick and clumsy.These shoes are feather-light and comfortable.  The tongue slips only occasionally.  This is a big plus if you find yourself constantly tugging at your shoe tongues because they've slipped port or starboard.  I've worn these shoes for twelve hours straight many times.  My feet may get a little tired, but the shoes don't make my feet tired.  I never feel like I must remove my shoes.The little elves are back!  Hands down, the best shoe I've ever purchased on Amazon.  Buy your true size.  I award these shoes the rare and coveted HB stamp of approval, my highest recommendation.And, if you know her shoe size, a wonderful gift.

When I selected this straightener, I didn't realize it matches my John Frieda Full Volume Hair Dryer.  Good heavens, suddenly my bathroom looks like a salon!  This straightener is really pretty, and it is with a heavy heart I give it four stars because it tends to snag my hair.  A lot of straightening irons will do that, but my Remington S8500 Shine Therapy  Moisturizing and Conditioning Digital Ceramic Hair Straightener, 1" has never snagged it.Maybe I should just be more careful.  My hair is already straight, and admittedly, I'm in a hurry to give it a finished look on shampoo mornings.  This straightener offers many heat settings, which are displayed in degrees Fahrenheit.  These temperatures are to be used as guidelines.  I set it to 310 degrees; it might actually heat to 300 or 320.  Though they aren't exact, I prefer this display over the notched displays often found on multi-temperature styling tools.  That's irrational, but I don't think I'm alone.  I like the variety of heat settings and the display.It does heat up fast!  That's a plus, even though it's only a 15 second time difference from my Remington.  The 1.5 inch plates are very nice for all but short length hair.  And then there's the snagging, which occurs just when I flip my wrist (so maybe it really is me).  The plates meet well, and so far, I've had no issues with the cord tangling.The instructions state this iron should not be used with hair products containing oils.  I don't think this is a warning to not deep fry hair.  I think it is because the straightener can be heated beyond the smoke point for most oils used in styling products.  If you use this at a lower temperature setting, and clean it between uses, you should be able to use oil-based products.This comes with a sectioning comb that is like a rat-tailed detangling comb.  It is very functional, but it is not a finishing comb.This straightener is a Conair product with the John Frieda label.  Overall, I like it.  It looks great and has great features.  I think most people would be pleased with the results - I am, despite the snags.  It makes quick work of styling.

But not definition, which should not have surprised me.  The barrel is an inch and a quarter in diameter.  I didn't expect much in the way of curl from a barrel that size.  That's just unrealistic.What it does well is build a foundation for a hair style.  I get lots of oomph, and those with curly hair can tame the mane, which I think is a better idea than trying to achieve straight hair, because natural curls reform.I don't get much beyond volume.  A little bit of wave, but it doesn't last long enough for the time required to get it.  Getting any wave at all requires painstakingly sectioning hair, and very patiently letting it sit against the rotating barrel.I like that it has a few heat settings from which to choose, and it does not tangle my hair.  I thought it might, but even when I tried to tangle my hair with it, it didn't.My hair is straight and fine, so if your hair is different, you should certainly expect different results.  Do not worry about tangles or snags.  Do expect to spend a lot more than ten minutes styling your hair with it.  It seems to me this iron would work best for those with hair of medium length and thickness.The iron comes with a cloth to protect your vanity from the hot barrel.  The cloth is kind of a joke, in my opinion.  It does not provide enough insulation to keep your vanity from being marked, just enough to keep it from catching fire.  It's also rather small.  If you do buy this, I recommend resting the iron with the brush side against the vanity, and the barrel sticking up in the air.  It will rest that way, and that's a better bet than using the cloth to protect your vanity.

Yowza, this little bit is quite the speaker!  It's lightweight with a slim profile.  The control buttons on the unit are self-explanatory icons.  It's very easy to use.  I'm sure even my dingaling sister could figure it out.The sound is crisp and clear, and yes, it WILL travel.  Please respect your neighbors, but not too much.  They might want to join you.  Up to five devices can be wirelessly connected, and if multiple devices are being used, you can set the device for two modes:  Heist, which lets users "take over" the speaker, or daisy chain.  Daisy chain (what an archaic term!) automatically passes the speaker from one device to the next.  Perfect for your pool party or barbecue.There is, thank goodness, an indoor mode.  The outdoor mode can knock you into next week.  Either way, you get great sound for a single speaker.  A great gift, no matter the listener's favorite genre.

I bought a turquoise veil, size 72" x 45."  The color is beautiful, but the veil is heavily over-dyed.I use it as a head wrap at night.  I'm new at this, but am happy with the results.  My hair is shoulder length and straight.  If I do not plan to shampoo in the morning, I pull my hair up into a loose bun on the top of my head, or for curls, set my hair with Wrap Snap N Go Hair Rollers.  Either way, the veil-as-wrap keeps my hair in place while I sleep, and I spend far less time shampooing and styling.It is habutai silk, and very fine and somewhat sheer.  Mine arrived with a tiny hole that appears to have occurred in the weaving process.  It looks like some of the threads were too short or broke on the loom.  It's small and probably was not noticed in finishing.  If I was wearing it in public, it would not be noticed.I love silk, and this is a) reasonably priced and 2) real silk.  It's hard to tell online if what is described as silk is actually silk.  This is the real deal, and I may be back for more pieces.Back to the color:  Turquoise.  It is truly turquoise, like the Caribbean.  Because I use it for my hair, I must wash it occasionally because product builds up on it.  I've washed it four times, and every single time, my vanity sink has looked like the sea.  So, a word of caution if you plan to wash this item.  Have handy an old towel or shirt to absorb excess water (and dye) after washing, and clean the sink right away so it doesn't stain.  I drape mine over a wooden clothes dryer and it dries very quickly.  Despite the loss of dye, so far the color is still vibrant, and I am very pleased with this item.

Finally, a whey powder I enjoy!  Every whey powder I've tried has been thin and watery, no matter the flavor; and none has left me feeling the slightest bit full.  This mixes easily and has good viscosity, and my stomach says, "Hey, that's food!"Texture:  As stated, this product is thicker than water.  This is because of the ground flax seeds.  I mix it with six ounces of water and toss a couple ice cubes in.  I let them partly melt, then remove them, stir again, and have a beverage with almost a pudding texture.  Still liquid, of course.  It isn't pleasant to view, I must admit.  When ground flax seeds meet water, they become mucilaginous.  So there is a trade off between visual appeal and texture, but it's worth it.Nutrition:  Flax seed is good for you.  It's a good source of dietary fiber, as is the oat fiber.  This product contains 20 grams of protein in a slim 110 calories.  It is low in fat.  Several vitamins and minerals are added.  So, there is a lot of nutrition in the drink.Other nutrition:  This product also contains coffee extract, white kidney bean extract, and raspberry ketones.  I know these ingredients have been ballyhooed for weight loss support.  I've never used any of them and have no opinion.  I am mentioning them for reviewing purposes.Flavor:  I am ambivalent.  It's pretty sweet, but does not remind me of any berry flavor.  It doesn't taste bad, but there is room for improvement.  Fortunately, one can easily dress up the flavor.  It can be mixed with milk or yogurt, and you can make smoothies with it.  A banana and/or some real berries would really knock the flavor off the chart.  Just remember, fruit has water in it, so you'll need to experiment to find your flavor/thickness balance.This is not a meal replacement, but if you add fruit to it or have some on the side, along with some grain, or perhaps some vegetables, you really can make a meal of it.

UNT Gentle Purity Makeup Removing Lotion is a true pleasure to use. Dispense some product from the re-lockable bottle and massage it gently into the skin. It feels like a rich lotion as it emulsifies makeup. Just massage it lightly, no need to pull on skin. Rinse with warm water. There may be some leftover mascara under the eyes, but otherwise, it's all gone. I love using this product. It feels fantastic on my skin. It is definitely my favorite makeup remover.This product contains some added fragrance, which may pose a problem for some. It seems to be a masking fragrance, and doesn't smell strong; the product has very little odor at all. Still, fragrance can be a problem for some. It has not irritated my skin.UNT recommends following makeup removal with their cleanser. I have not tried it. After I rinse, I gently wipe my face with a damp washcloth to dislodge makeup or makeup remover that may still be stuck to my skin. Actually, my skin feels clean. Some days I can feel a slight film. I use Cerave foaming cleanser after, to make sure all product is removed, but I wash my neck and chest anyway, so this is not an extra step.This product contains some good skin care ingredients, which don't stay on your skin, but kudos to UNT for including anti-irritants.The only issue I have with this product is its price. I had to pay more than I would like to get that luxurious feel. But it does work very well, and if your wallet can take the hit, I do recommend trying it.

I bought this brush to carry in my purse or have handy at my desk.I am pleased with the quality of the materials.  The brush, overall, is sturdy and durable.  The handle is very comfortable, and the bristles are densely packed.  It is purse size, so if you have very thick, long hair, don't expect it to perform like a full size brush; yet for its size, it smooths hair very well, and I like it a lot, especially for neatening my hair during the day.  My hair just goes where it goes.  The brush puts it back where I want it.The caveat is, the bristle ends are very sharp, and will scratch the scalp.  I have scratched my scalp with it, but it works so well otherwise, I just make sure I don't let it touch my scalp.  I have another brush at home I can use near my scalp, but it is far too large to carry around.A good brush, but I would not use it on a child's hair due to the scratch factor.

Don't you find it difficult to find a comfortable pillow?  I do.  Even if I go to the BB&B and squish them in my hands, and actually try them out lying down, I never feel certain.  Buying pillows is like rolling dice, and I hate to gamble.I prefer a big, fat, soft, king-size down pillow.  The one I use right now set me back over a hundred, and I don't regret a penny.  My head is the comfiest bowling ball on the planet.I'm also a bit on the fence when it comes to memory foam.  Sometimes it is too hard or soft, or collapses too easily.  But, enough of my Goldilocks syndrome . . .This pillow is definitely firm, and it does not feel like my head is sinking in, but it does, slowly.  And once it settles, it is settled.  No rolling around or slipping off.  This pillow is a good candidate for those who use CPAP, because the head is kept still.  You know you hate when the mask just about pulls your nose off your face if you move your head a bit!  But your head is unlikely to move if you use this pillow.  It does stay cool, too.  I'm a sweat head, but not with this pillow.The first time I tried this pillow, I just wanted some quiet time for about twenty minutes.  I woke up an hour and a half later.  I'm not a napper, but it happened, and I felt surprisingly refreshed.  This is now my travel pillow.  It's heavy compared to my down pillow, but it's not as heavy as I thought it would be.If you like a firm pillow, and want some stability, you'll like this one.

Applique does not an absorbent towel make, but these are mighty attractive towels for a guest bath or for staging one's home for sale.The towels are quite white, the appliques and trim are shades of blue and beige that speak of sea and sand but are not <shudder> beachy.  They are classic colors and easy to work into a color scheme.  The towels look lovely in a bath with an interesting but neutral shower curtain.  You don't have to create your decor exclusively from this line.The towels themselves are 100% cotton, made in Canada; the decorative touches are added in the USA.  The cotton terry is good overall.  It is neither thin nor plush.  The hand towel I received had a snag in the terry loop.  Fortunately, I found and clipped it.The bath towel should be placed in a laundry wash bag because the threading for the shell beading will likely fray eventually, causing pieces of this decorative trim to fall off the towel. A laundry bag will help protect the threading in the washing machine.  The towels should be dried on a low setting to keep the appliques from shrinking.  The bath towel and laundry bag should be removed from the dryer while still damp and hung to complete drying.  I have a lot of beaded garments I wash and wear, even though they're labeled dry clean.  The real problem with beading falling off happens because of dryer heat.These are best used as decorative towels.  They would make a lovely gift for someone's home, for Christmas, or new home owners or renters.

The nutritional profile of theSouth Beach Diet Protein Fit Bar, Dark Chocolate Coconut with Greek Yogurt Coating is similar to other brands of protein bars at the approximately 200 calorie mark.  That is, the protein and fiber are there.But there are many brands of protein bars in the 200 calorie range, and all make different flavors.  There is no problem finding a protein bar.  The problem is finding a protein bar one likes.  I've tried lots of brands, marking them good or bad in my mental list after tasting them.  There is some logic to my method, and everyone applies it to foods of comparable nutritional value.  I'm talking about things like peanut butter, cereal, bread, nut and soy milks, to name a few.This review is entirely subjective and based on my experience and opinions.
