This is the very first South Beach Diet product I have tried.  I tried it with an open mind because I do eat protein bars, and I really like coconut.  I had no bias for or against the brand, and still don't.So let's get to it.  Yes, I can taste coconut.  After I finish chewing and swallowing, I can feel the little dessicated bits of coconut in my mouth.  It's definitely there.  Yes, there is dark chocolate, though I find it a bit more subtle.  Then there is, well, the other stuff, which tastes and has the crumbly texture of stale marshmallow treats with little or no sugar.  I find the taste and texture as a whole unappealing, and that is why I rate these bars two stars.Others may find these delightful, but I don't.  They are worth trying to see if you like them yourself.  I won't be trying these again.  Maybe another flavor, but not this particular bar.

These slacks have a nice, sharp crease.  The sizing is true; the cut is a little on the slim side in the thighs.  The fabric drapes well, and the slacks are comfortable.  These are great for work if you don't have to wear suit pants, and good for date nights.  Machine wash and dry.  But for longer wear, hang from the bottom hem to dry.

Generally, I love Panasonic products. I'm sitting in front of a Panasonic plasma television right now, purchased in 2005, which performs beautifully after nine years. So I was eager to try these batteries, because I do play Wii games, often.I have a white Wii-mote and a black Wii-mote. When I received the Panasonic black Wii-mote. I have been playing ExerBeat exclusively, because I use both remotes simultaneously and equally. This facilitated a side-by-side comparison.I don't have a battery tester, but the Wii will prompts me regarding battery life of accessories. To my surprise, the white Wii-mote lost a bar, but the black Wii-mote is still full.That means the Panasonic batteries are draining faster than the Ray-O-Vacs.Panasonic markets these batteries as being great for gaming. And they perform as well as average batteries, but with a shorter life.

These shoes fit well, and they are comfortable. But they don't hold up. I bought a pair in January which I rotate between two other pairs of shoes. That means I wear them about twice a week, and I rarely wear them outside. I've worn them inside my home, primarily for training.When I'm not wearing them, I store them on a shelf in my closet. They're not abused, but they look like it. I was so pleased when I bought them, but the insole is breaking down, and the uppers are stretched way out.I hadn't tried Ryka before, but these shoes had such glowing reviews I was persuaded to purchase. My experience was not good. I wouldn't write off the brand, but I would not buy another pair of these shoes.

These slippers have a durable sole that will take you to the front porch, or inside the garage, but I wouldn't walk around outside in them. They are comfortable, but they are not the sturdiest. This type of footwear is not ideal for wear in the great outdoors, anyway. The slippers are built for comfort, not support.The packaging states these slippers are made a little wider for greater comfort. They are a little wider than Isotoner slippers I've purchased in the past, but they are not sized wide. Those who wear a wide or narrow size shoe will not be pleased.I wear a size 10 shoe, and was a little leery of a 9.5/10, but they fit me well. If you wear a 9.5, you may find them longer than you'd please.They deliver comfort with a very cushiony insole, one-piece slide, and stitching to hold that nice, soft microterry cloth in place over the cushion and bottom sole.These slippers are machine washable. Hallelujah! I hate wearing dirty slippers! So you might want two pairs. Do not put them in the dryer. They must air dry, and that takes some time, so if you have two pairs, you'll not be without the comfort.I like these very much and recommend them with absolutely no reservations. I offer only this bit of advice: Don't expect them to last for years. That nearly pillowy insole, which is why you want them, is going to break down and flatten out. This is not exclusive to Isotoner. Every pair of slippers I've owned that has a deep cushioned insole has broken down. It's the nature of the material.Unless you have narrow or wide feet, expect to truck around the neighborhood in them, or want slippers that will last until the end of time, these are for you. And they would make a nice gift for the ladies in your life who have the slipper jones!

I will say the bifurcated blue peel-away is a great idea for a screen protector.  It makes application much easier to approach, and a bit easier to handle than the conventional one-piece clear film.Mine arrived in new condition, with no dents.  I've purchased screen protectors that were DOA - dented on arrival, either damaged before or during transit.  That can happen at a brick and mortar store, too, though.  No card or cleaning cloth included, but I use my own anyway, as the cloths are always too small and a library card works better to squeegee out the bubbles.The screen protector (anti-glare) is good.  It serves its purpose and doesn't noticeably affect the touch sensitivity of the Kindle Fire.But, the product is way too expensive.  One could easily purchase ten screen protectors for the price.

Though it's a petty quibble, my speaker doesn't have a voice saying it's pairing or connecting.  It has squelch instead, but that's really all right with me.  It makes me nostalgic.  And there is a written prompt on my device that says it's pairing, so that's all good.I like this speaker a lot.  It passed the classical, Journey, and Pink tests with flying colors.  It didn't fare as well during the wailing guitar licks on Layla, though.  Those high notes are screaming, but they veer a bit toward banshee on this speaker.It took only two hours to charge through my laptop with the USB cord, and the battery life is good.  I do think it is a little bit pricey at the time I write this.  A buck and a half seems like a lot of money to me.In a small room, it performs well.  I found that in my bedroom I need to put it close to me, on the nightstand for best performance.  When I placed it in different spots on the perimeter of the room, the space and soft furnishings absorbed a lot of sound.If you're on the fence, choose this one.  You won't be disappointed.

The paper, binding, and cover are first-rate quality.  However, the pages are not die-cut, and this sketchbook is pricey.Consider whether you plan to keep your sketches, or whether you need sketch paper for homework or doodling.  There are similar products that do have die-cut pages that cost less.  This is 70 lb paper, suitable for most media, but probably will not work well for water-color.

I am never without this sunscreen.  This is how much I am never without this sunscreen:  I take it on vacation, and check my bags at the airport.  I am not leaving home without it, just in case I can't find it at my destination.This is a chemical sunscreen that offers broad spectrum protection.  No fragrance added.  It includes emollient and moisturizing ingredients, though if your skin is very dry, you'll want to apply moisturizer first.  It absorbs into the skin very well, and feels much lighter than most sunscreens, especially water-resistant ones.Speaking of water-resistant, I often find this type of sunscreen unpleasant to reapply.  They usually roll up on the skin; it feels like you're rubbing sand and lotion on your skin.  Or they feel smeary, greasy, and heavy.  This is water-resistant, but I've not had the aforementioned issues.  Reapplying this is like reapplying body lotion.It gives the skin a nice bit of glow, can be used on the face if you're not wearing makeup, and doesn't smell like an umbrella drink.  I don't know how it could get any better.  I wear this every single day of the year.  Two wings up!

I loved River God, and seriously wish that I had skipped this one. The plot is vapid, the characters are un-engaging, the writing is verbose and dull, the final undoing of the grand old enemy is simply silly, and the other 1-star reviewers are spot on.

My previous Thule 915XT Roadway 5 Bike Hitch Carrier was an amazing unit  it not only was built like a tank, but also made it possible to load my trunk even with it attached to the hitch. Unfortunately, opening the trunk only worked with the bikes unloaded.I was therefore really interested in seeing how the swing away design worked. And, Im glad to find that it was just as easy to operate as advertised.The rest is as expected from Thule  installation is simple, it is built like a tank (my 4 year old 915XT still looks as good as new); attaches to the hitch solidly; and the bike cradles hold bikes securely.My old Thule STL2 works just as well to secure this carrier.

Updated May 31:Well, I swapped out this SSD with a SanDisk Extreme Pro - and the difference was night and day. The SanDisk booted up just fine *every single* time.Updated May 30:Last weekend I tried making the SSD my boot drive, and suddenly ran into a lot of problems. I was able to successfully install Windows on it, but then found that I could boot successfully into it only once out of every 3 or so tries. I'm not sure what's going on - but it will boot like a dream once, and then on the very next restart my BIOS will claim that no bootable drive exists.This is not a loose connection as I can replicate this even if the computer is in exactly the same position - and I have seated the cable as tight as it can go.I've seen rumblings of SATA 2 / Sandforce compatibility issues - but I'm not certain if that's what's plaguing my drive.##################################I replaced the second hard drive of a 3 year old laptop, with this SSD. Overall the process was relatively easy. The drive fit nicely into my existing drive's mounting bracket, and slotted in with minimal fuss.

Connect this to a USB 3.0 port, and watch the bits fly! I was clocking at over 100MB/s, and even the transfer of a 4GB file flashed by in no time at all.This drive seems to handle itself well - the drivers were installed automatically, the drive has always been recognized in just a few seconds, and the light indicating a solid connection comes on as expected.I'm nervous with Lexar's construction, especially after a previous negative experience with Lexar media which proceeded to fall apart in very short order. But, so far, so good.

Update 05/09:Please see the first comment below to allow the running of Google Play store apps on the phone. I have not tried this myself - and it's probably too adventurous for me. Fortunately a much simpler (but limited) alternative is to use the instructions at:www<dot>cnet<dot>com<slash>how-to<slash>the-easiest-way-to-install-android-apps-on-bb10This limits you to the apps available on the Amazon app store, but I was able to get Temple Run 2 up and running without breaking a sweat :)Original review:I was very excited to get a chance to use the new Leap. As a Crackberry addict from a number of years ago, I have since found my sweet spot with Android phones, and iOS tablets. While this device does recapture some of the mojo of its storied pedigree, it unfortunately did not arouse any strong urge to chuck out my existing devices.Ergonomically++ it feels solid in my hand, and looks like it will take hard use well++ its dimpled rubberized backing feels secure even with one-handed operation++ its buttons are easy to reach and operateAudio/Video:++ its speaker sounds lively and crisp - though not quite as luxurious as the awesome HTC One.++ its 5" screen with 720p resolution is gorgeousProcessor:++ I was never hindered waiting for applications to start, or for videos to start playing on YouTube.OS:++ OS 10 is intuitive - it is swipe based (up to close an app, down to show its settings, etc.) I was never hindered trying to figure out how to do something.Camera:++ auto HDR that actually works!Battery:++ seems to last forever - with light to normal use, easily lasts me 24 hoursKeyboard:++ Keyboard mechanics work well using swipe based actions (down to display special chars, to left to delete a word); and positioning the cursor is simplicity itself (click and drag); and supports traditional Shift-drag text selection.++ word completion works well. As you type, the keyboard displays various autocomplete choices that you can drag to the edit box.Browser:++ worked well for my usual sites, and even handled Flash video on web sitesSo why not a full 5-stars?-- While the phone comes with staples such as apps for YouTube and Maps, Blackberry World lacks many apps that have become essential for me - including Netflix, Pandora, WeatherBug, Flipboard, etc. While one could argue that this is not the phone's fault, it does limit what the phone can do for you.-- The keyboard lacks visual feedback when Shift key is pressed (though the Shift Key itself does change). This is annoying, especially when you can't see what you are typing (e.g., with mixed case passwords)In conclusion, if you can live with the limited app store, then this is a very capable phone.

This polyester table cloth looked great on our dark cherry dining table - it is a bit see through and that actually made it look better than if it were fully opaque. It held up well in our washing machine the one time we washed it - but the fabric is really thin, and I'm not sure what the longevity picture will be like.

It came very well packaged - not a scratch, dent, or fold anywhere. It took about 15 minutes to put together - most of which was time spent in unwrapping the shade from its shrink wrap cocoon. The translucent base is very attractive, the base is heavy enough to resist inadvertent movement, and the overall build quality seems to be decent.~A_E~

This keyboard is an absolute joy to use. It is the most authentic that I have encountered in over two decades - no exaggeration - the key travel distance, the perfect firmness, and texture simply put my mainstay Logitech G110 to shame. I type a lot (in the order of pages each day), and this keyboard feels excellent, with hardly any fatigue.Everything about this keyboard feels like a craftsman product - it is about three times as heavy as my G110, the keys don't feel the least bit plasticky, there's a satisfying (and very audible) click on each key press, and even the cabling looks industrial grade.The backlight on this keyboard is really cool with different brightness levels and even a couple of blinking modes (though that's probably an acquired taste). There's even a unique mode that lights up subsets of keys (such as only the WASD keys).I do miss the macro keys and the volume control wheel on the G110, but the FN-based volume control works reasonably well here.Note that setup was simplicity itself - it needs two USB plugs - one for the keyboard, and the other for it to act as a USB hub; and jacks for a headphone and mic.In summary, this is my new favorite keyboard.

It came packaged very securely, looks aesthetically pleasing (unlike the blocky USB hubs of not too long ago), was easy to setup, and  worked well.Setup required plugging in power and connecting my devices. My USB 3 external hard drives very recognized and everything worked like a dream.Recommended!

I simply could not get it to work, and gave up before I hurt myself. I have used this style of stapler before, so I'm familiar with how they are loaded and used, but the unit I received seemed to not want to cooperate.~A_E~

I'm not one to be excited by kitchen hardware, but this one impressed me right out of the box. It has the heft and feel of solid steel, and it looks like it will go the distance even in our busy kitchen.Planning#######I am not a particularly handy individual, and I was very nervous about tackling this project. Nevertheless, armed with a couple of YouTube videos, and a helpful spouse, I decided to give it a shot.The project was complicated by a number of factors. We were dealing with an under-mount sink, we only had two holes cutout in the counter-top, and these holes were very closely spaced. Our solution was to do away with the base plate and mount the faucet flush to the counter, and to install the handle on the left hand side.Fortunately, the Wexford was flexible enough to meet our constraints. And, this handle position worked out great for us because we normally use our left hands to turn it, anyway.The only concession was that the Grohe brand imprint ended up on the reverse side of the faucet, and so is not visible - but that's not something I'd lose sleep over :)Installation#######After getting together a couple of adjustable wrenches, some plumber's tape, and a screwdriver set, we decided to tackle this project.About 15 minutes later, we had removed our old Kohler, which ended up looking very pitifully scrawny next to this behemoth of a faucet. Truly, its pictures do not do it justice - this faucet is a monster!Sadly, the instructions were a little unclear in places - putting us into "figure-it-out" mode every once in a while. For instance you need the provided plastic shim only if your counter-top is less than 1-3/4" thick, but the manual is very ambiguous on this point. Likewise, the fact that you need the cylindrical washer when not using the base plate, was not clear enough for the brain dead (like me). Nevertheless, none of these were show-stoppers, just annoyances - and we worked through them.We also struggled to install a loaded soap dispenser - but learned later that it would have been far easier to install it empty, and then fill it from the top. Well, we'll keep it in mind for the future.In the end, it took us about 2 hours before we were done - mostly due to both a severe lack of skills, as well as a severe lack of space (and an abundance of sharp edges) under the sink.But, luck favors the (stupid and/or) brave, and we had a bright shiny new faucet to show at the end of it all.Usage#####Once installed, the faucet is a dream to use - the handle and spout have a silky smooth action, and the faucet feels rich and luxurious. Its weighted sprayer works great and has 2 options - a solid flow and a spray. And, the soap dispenser works with a very smooth spring action.The Wexford's finish is supposed to make it very easy to wipe off limescale - which will be useful for us, as we have very hard water.I'll have to report back on how well this stands up over time, but so far this looks to be a solid product - both from a mechanical and aesthetic standpoint.~A_E~PS. This product combines German design with Chinese manufacturing.

Simply put, this monitor is a gorgeous monster:++ 27 inches of real estate are a luxury - no need to choose which windows to display!++ text is crisp and clear, and the colors are natural and vibrant.++ all of 2 million pixels ... and not a single dead or stuck one!++ anti-glare screen works great without any noticeable sacrifice of contrast/colors++ aesthetics are stellar with barely visible branding, and a nice thin bezel.Even the LED light is not directly visible - you only see its reflection in the base.And if even that bothers you, you can turn it off in the menus!++ Tilt adjustment works fine - though you have to be careful you don't tip over the whole display++ lots of adjustment potential, with menus for contrast/brightness, color temperature (presets as well as custom adjustable RGB values).++ setup is very simple - power on, connect, and it automatically the input to use.++ excellent shipping - arrived without any damage.Unfortunately, there are also some negatives.-- it sits literally about 1 1/2 inches off the table. Fortunately, a ream of printer paper cured that for me.-- its base is simply too unsteady for 27 inches of goodness. It picks up the slightest vibration - such as when I'm typing this review.-- speakers are pointless. I get better bass and volume out of my laptop's speakers. No exaggerations.-- no HDMI! seriously! And no DVI cable supplied either. I had to dig up an old DVI-HDMI cable that I had lying around.Overall, this is a 5-star display with a 3-star base giving it 4-stars at best.I wish monitor manufacturers would realize that they have currently have monstrous displays resting on plastic stalks. This is simply not workable, and requires investment in VESA-mounts for active users. I touch type, and I can see the monitor sway with every keystroke (though it is fortunately, barely perceptible.)I also almost deducted a star for the lack of HDMI - none of my machines currently have a DVI output, and I wish ViewSonic would get with the program.~A_E~

The PJD6345 is a decent projector with:++ excellent brightness and sharpness,++ low noise,++ loads of connectivity options (VGA, HDMI, and USB.)++ decent room filling mono sound from its built-in speakers (16W)++ a decent 3 year warranty (though, as expected the lamp is warrantied only for 1 year.)The weakest link on this projector is, very oddly, its power plug. I have never encountered a plug that was so easy to dislodge, thereby turning off the projector at the slightest jerk.I was also disappointed with its choppy playback of a AVCHD file from a flash drive connected to its USB port.Ergonomics were not great either - there's only one center-front height adjustment (I prefer having one on either side to allow for sloping surfaces), and adjustment is slow as it needs to be unscrewed rather than a one click release (as in many Epsons.)Note that its throw distance can be challenging especially if you need large diagonals in a confined space (e.g., 14 feet for a 100" diagonal.)Finally, its resolution is only XGA which means the picture is stellar up to until about 60" diagonal. While resolution was not a problem for standard text/graphics style presentations, no one is going to mistake this for a home movie projector.I did not have a wifi module so I was not able to verify the limitations identified by the other reviewer. However, connected via HDMI, I encountered no issues whatsoever - whether it was firing up a presentation in a conference room, or whether playing a training video. As long as I was careful about not jostling its power cable, this projector handled well, and my audience had no complaints.In short, this is a decent projector without much to rave about - hence the 3-star, It's Okay, rating.Happy Viewing!~A_E~

Last year I tried out, and returned, the HVLF60M - a strobe that overheated way too easily for my style of shooting (I tend to bounce at full power - and the 60M stopped after less than 2 dozen exposures.)I tried the Metz Mecablitz but the need for an adapter was a constant source of discomfort.Fortunately, the F43M is a much better alternative. It provides excellent exposures, and does not overheat (at full power) until about 42 exposures - which is almost enough for my demanding needs. (Turns out I've been spoiled by Canon.)It provides excellent exposures, its cobra head is the best innovation in strobes, and its TTL exposures are spot on.Obviously, this is not as powerful as the F60M, but the lower weight and smaller size are definitely welcome. This makes it particularly suitable for smaller form factor cameras - such as the NEX-6.Overall - highly recommended.~A_E~

The Asus TF103C has some very strong positives:# a stellar display - very sharp, very bright, and very colorful (despite its middle of the road pixel density)# a solid heft to it - way above its price-grade.# quiet good looks - with a brushed aluminum finish and a rubberized exterior# app performance that is zippy where I never have to wait for anything.# an awesome keyboard and touchpad.In particular, the touchpad works very well - with even scrolling and clicking support; and the keyboard is comfortable to use, with numerous hard buttons for common functions such as entering settings, and back/home navigation.Unfortunately, the docking mechanism is the TF103C's Achilles heel - and the only reason that this tablet bundle did not get a full 5 stars.First, docking is not intuitive. Even after days of near constant use, I still have to pay attention to aligning it just right - it has not become second nature.And, second, the angle of the tablet to the keyboard is about 110 degrees. This makes it hard to use when your eye line is looking down at the screen (e.g., when standing up.) This also means that the keyboard cannot be folded back to return to an impromptu tablet - say to view something in portrait mode. The only option is to undock - which means you now have to deal with an extra piece of furniture.Despite those minor quibbles, I love the TF103C - it is a joy to use, and everything works just like it is supposed to.This tablet bundle is a winner!Happy Computing!~A_E~

There's something awe inspiring about any router that has so many antennas - and the WRT1900AC did not disappoint.This router launched to very high expectations. It was to be the modern-day successor to its hall-of-fame older sibling - the WRT54GL - which I reviewed here years ago :)Coming almost a year after Belkin's purchase of the Linksys brand, there was also a lot of anticipation (mine included) as to the future of a venerable brand (remember the ill-fated merger of Chrysler and Mercedes?). After a singularly bad experience with a previous Belkin router, I had personally chosen to stay away - well, until this one.I recently had a chance to get familiar with Fluke Network's AirCheck wifi tester, which has a uniquely useful Survey feature that works great for testing routers. I used this to get a baseline from my WNDR4700, and compared it with the results after switching to the Linksys.My findings?Setup was painless - I unhooked my Netgear WNDR4700; moved its Ethernet cables over to the WRT1900AC; rebooted my cable modem; and powered up the new router. I connected via the Ethernet port to the WRT1900AC, configured my wireless networks to their original settings, and I was done. Yes - it took about 10 minutes, and most of that was spent fishing a cable that I managed to drop in the most inaccessible area behind my office desk.The WRT1900AC also provides a smashing device network map that is a spectacular improvement over the anemic options previous routers sported, and its user interface has also been greatly streamlined.It also performed far better, or even more important - more consistently, than the older WNDR4700 that it replaced - in both the 2.4 and 5-GHz bands.AirCheck's Survey mode provides heatmap-like graphical views of signal strength (dbM) and throughput (Mbps) across both frequency bands. After a long weekend where I painstakingly drew up an architectural map of two floors, I was ready to go. For both routers, I measured signal strength and throughput in common usage areas (such as my entertainment center, my favorite couch, etc.) In both bands, the Linksys comfortably bested my older WNDR4700. Visually this appears as a single tone color across most of the floor for the Linksys, whereas it is a patchwork quilt for the WNDR (I have a few known dead zones that I've patched using a wireless access point.)As for reliability, so far it has been stable and I have not had any noticeable reboots or disconnects.This router does get fairly hot - despite its well ventilated case and internal fan. But then, this router has a processor that is about as powerful as my desktop tower from the mid 90s :)Note that I do not intend to use OpenWRT/Tomato/etc. so I cannot speak to that controversy.Happy Networking!~A_E~Setup Tips:1. Use WPA2 encryption, with a password that is at least 8 characters long (12 preferred)2. Turn off UPnP and WPS unless you explicitly need them (there are security issues associated with both.)3. Change the router's admin password right away (the default is "admin")4. The DHCP server is configured to start at 192.168.1.100. I changed this to the traditional range as I have memorized the reserved addresses for a number of devices.

This is one of those rare products that not only does everything that it is supposed to, but does it with style. It had the entire family ooh-ing and ah-ing from the moment I took it out of the package (it is aesthetically very pleasing.)So what works well:1. Amazing software.A product such as this can be decimated by poor software, but Epson's team must be congratulated on releasing truly production-grade software. There are apps for every major platform out there (iOS, Android. Mac, Windows) and the versions I tested (Android, Windows 7 x64) worked flawlessly, and were absurdly easy to use. I could add borders, print photos (albeit grainy and monochrome), choose from custom graphics, edit my own text, and much more. Note that the PC software has much more functionality than the mobile apps do.2. Build Quality.While it is made of plastic, no corners were cut in its production. This is one solid product, with hard no rough edges, and even the tape door closes with a nice satisfying thunk. With proper use, I can see this lasting a very long time.3. Aesthetics and Design.Its aesthetics are stunning - looking more like a retro cassette-tape player than a label printer. And small touches abound - like the slightly inclined buttons that are easy to press from above, the windows through which you can see the currently installed tape, the attractive color scheme, and even the non-skid feet!4. Setup.On both the Android and PC, setup was easy and painless. Literally taking less than 3-5 minutes each.5. Print optionsWhile the consumables for this printer are not cheap, I was pleased to find a wide assortment of labels already available. There's tape for various widths (up to 1" wide), color combinations (incl. high contrast black on yellow), and materials (ribbons and fluorescent backgrounds.)6. Label print qualityWhile I was very impressed with its overall print quality - it was the printing on the ribbons that blew me away - producing store quality results right at home. The adhesive on the normal labels was also decently strong.7. Multiple power options (electric outlets + 6 AA batteries)I love the fact that this can be powered by batteries - adding greatly to its overall versatility.To conclude, the LW-600P does not take a wrong step. It has all its bases covered - in terms of a quality product, software, and consumables, which translates to more than just a functional product - this is a product that is actually fun to use.I found my only wish-it-would-work item when I tried connecting to the printer from my Bluetooth-enabled notebook. Unfortunately, the software insists on a USB cable connection. Hopefully this will be addressed soon.As with any product, there's a risk that this will keel over and die, right after I've finished gushing about it. But, from all that I have seen, this is going to be a fun new addition to our home, and I expect to enjoy it for a very long time.Happy Printing!~A_E~

I have been using this binder at my office for about a week now, and I simply love it. It is one of the most versatile binders I've ever used - with pockets galore, a nifty handle, and a very professional look. In fact, this new folder is so generously sized that it has replaced multiple folders that I used to carry my stuff around from one meeting to the next.My favorite feature would be its two accordion files (one outside the binder and one inside) that come complete with tabs. Another close favorite is the zipper pocket in the inside for odds and ends (including vending machine quarters, USB drives, access cards, etc.) The handle is not particularly useful, but who knows I might find that I can't live without it someday (at least once I fill it up to its rated 800+ sheet capacity.)The only reason that I docked a star is that sometimes the outside zipper sticks, and needs some TLC to loosen it.~A_E~

This made in Korea SDHC card has a unique 2-tone color scheme that sets it apart from all the other cards that I have accumulated over the years.It isn't particularly speedy - being rated at Class 6 - but it held up well with recording video and still photos using a HF-R50 camcorder. It even worked well in my DSLR in burst mode.I use SanDisk cards exclusively - as I am paranoid about the idea of losing once in a lifetime captures. As I have never used a Samsung card before, only time will tell how well this holds up over a longer period of use - but so far so good!~A_E~

This is a point and shoot with a difference. I was able to shoot a video, view it on Windows MediaPlayer, and download it using a web browser on my computer - all in minutes!Unfortunately, to do this you need a veritable degree in computer networking, and there were a number of dead ends. However, if you are patient, this camcorder will reward you with an amazing amount of functionality - as long as you acknowledge that there are a few rough edges.Let's start at the beginning.I recorded a robin catching a worm, at full zoom, and the video capture quality was unbelievable - even eliciting a wow! from my spouse. The colors were bright and the video had great contrast. In addition, the sharpness was excellent - with each blade of grass and each leaf coming through. Definitely, far better than I had expected for this price point.Of course, this was recorded at the highest quality that this camcorder supports - AVCHD 60P, which gives a paltry 30 minutes of recording time using the built-in 8GB of memory. With a Samsung 32GB SDHC memory card installed, this expanded to a decent total of about 3 hours.(Note that you can use the Relay Recording feature to seamlessly skip from the internal memory to the SD card once the internal memory fills up.)I copied the recorded video to my computer simply by connecting it via the provided USB cable. Both the internal memory as well as the SD card appeared as drives in Windows Explorer (Windows 8.1 x64), and I was able to navigate down to the folder that contained the video recordings (.MTS files.)An alternative approach to transferring files is to have the camcorder setup a private network, to which your computer connects. I was then able to use a standard web browser (Chrome) to download files from it (a 330MB 12 min video took about 2 mins to download).Interestingly, the HFR50 can even act as a DLNA media server - allowing Windows Media Player to stream media off of it. The only caveat is that your network must have the bandwidth to support full HD streaming (about 27Mbps).I was also impressed with its touch screen interface - clicking was accurate, and it even supported smooth scrolling!Note that the CameraAccess Plus app was not compatible with my Android smartphone - so I was not able to try it out. Likewise, I am leery of installing additional software on my workstations - so I did not care to install ImageBrowser EX (for handling MP4 video and pictures) or Transfer Utility LE (for transferring AVCHD video.)One annoying feature is that the lens cover does not automatically retract when it is powered on. Instead, all you get is a reminder to open it manually. Another slight downside is that its LCD is very reflective, making it hard to view in bright conditions.In conclusion - this is quite a well-featured camcorder but only as long as you are willing to invest in learning how to use its features, and as long as you are not put off by some rough edges.~A_E~

I recently had a chance to review the Midland ER300, a very capable all-in-one product (weather radio, crank AM/FM radio, flashlight, charger, dog whistle, SOS light, etc.)I was very eager to compare that Midland with this new option from Cobra, particularly because of its portability.At first glance, this is a very handsome radio - with a bright color scheme (contrasty black and yellow), a rubberized grip, a solid antenna, some weatherproofing (it survived an accidental lake dunking), and a convenient belt-clip/lanyard. Turning it on, I found the sound very audible and clear (better than the Midland.) In addition, it can charge other devices (micro USB output) and has a built-in flashlight. It has the same form factor as a regular FRS walkie-talkie, and I found it fairly comfortable to hold and use. Programming it was very straightforward as well, it took very little time to setup the SAME station for our area, and enabled alerting.I also liked the attention to detail - where the designers allowed the annoyingly loud beep on button pushes to be muted; its Tornado mode - which only goes off for tornado warnings; and its Wx Weather Alert - which lets you temporarily turn on all alerts when traveling outside your SAME areas.Unfortunately, it has two big problems, which ended up being deal breakers.1. It refused to alert even when the ER300 was blaring away. I verified that it was receiving the exact same NWS station as the Midland.2. It refuses to charge up its batteries even while placed in the cradle. Once full, the charger turns off until the battery is depleted. I leave the ER300 connected and charging at all times.Both of these should be easy to fix - and hopefully Cobra will address these in newer units. However, as it stands, I am unable to recommend this unit.~A_E~

This is a very attractive binder - one that my daughter fell in love with, the moment she saw it. The image is cheery (springtime with a bird on mine) and even the interior is filled with a fleur-de-lis style pattern. Unfortunately, the one I received came pre-installed with a couple of blemishes (almost like extra glue left over) on the cover that detracted from the image.The only other noteworthy feature is that the cover is fairly tight and is not easy to open and keep flat (hence the loss of one star.)Other than that, this is a fairly standard binder - with traditional, easy to open rings with a mechanism that uses a lever on each end of the spine. I have taken this with me to school in a backpack with other material (including another binder), and it has held up well.The added "green" credentials with using recycled material add to its attractiveness.Overall, I like this binder.~A_E~

This stylus oozes good looks - right from its unique packaging, its wood finish, its distinctive shape, to its sleek minimalistic aesthetics. Unfortunately, this beauty is only skin deep - charging it involves some level of dis-assembly, and a worry about where to place the remaining parts of the stylus while it is charging.By default, the Pencil works as a spongy-tipped capacitive stylus - in any app, across all tablets, and even without being charged (since it does not use its Bluetooth radio.) Unfortunately, it is too expensive to be used in that mode.However, its true power (no pun intended) comes from its implementation of Bluetooth Low Energy (v4.0) which allow its more advanced features to be brought online. However, this does mean that it requires iPad versions that support this specification, namely the iPad 3 and later.When powered up, the Pencil/53 can actively detect when it is pressed (using buttons at both ends) and communicate that to the the iPad. This lets you use the Pencil/53 as naturally as you might use a real pencil (write with one end, and erase using the other.)The iPad-only Paper/53 app (2012 app of the year) is designed to engage the complete feature set of the Pencil/53 - it knows the difference between the writing tip and the eraser end (erase), your finger (blend mode), and your palm (palm rejection). The app also allows easy Bluetooth connection, without going in to the iPad settings menu (by touching and holding a connection icon in the tool palette.)Personally, I found that I quite enjoyed using this stylus - connection was quick, there was no lag, and its ratio of charge to use time was very decent. I also liked its ability to stick securely to my iPad. It took me a while to get comfortable with the carpenter's pencil-styling, but I got there eventually.The nib is very soft, and moves smoothly across my screen. This is a good thing because I had to remove my screen protector to get this to work, and it would have been tragic to have my screen scratched by this stylus. However, this extra softness means that you need to bear down on the stylus a bit, so the tip can wear itself out very quickly. I used mine for about two weeks before I noticed it wearing out. Fortunately, it comes with a replacement, but I'm now even more conscious about wear and tear on the nib.The design of Paper/Pencil comes from a team with a great track record (Xbox/Kinect) and has venture funding from Horowitz/Andreesen (Interestingly, I just completed reading Ben Horowitz's book "The Hard Thing about Hard Things".)~A_E~

Each spring, the unfortunate combination of hungry mice and children who leave doors open, means that we are subjected to what seems like an invasion of rodents, leaving me scurrying for traps and peanut butter.Our last successful catch was a sticky strip that unfortunately left me having to deal with a scared, stuck mouse. After having had to physically put it out of its misery, I decided to explore additional options. (I am not particularly sentimental about mice, but it's still not something that I look forward to doing.)This one-time use, spin-based trap seemed like a great idea.I loved the ease of its setup (fill with bait, pull to prime, and place), and I liked the construction of this unit (easy to unset and reset).Unfortunately, in the weeks since I placed this trap, it has sat silent and lonely.It's hard to rate a mouse trap without a trapped mouse as proof. For now, I rated it at 3-stars (Its Okay) to reflect its ease of use, and to avoid skewing its product score. I'll update this review if the hit rate with this trap improves in the future.~A_E~

I am not a binder connoisseur by any stretch of the imagination - and my only strong emotion comes along when one falls apart earlier than I think it should.That said, I have carried this back and forth from school, in a backpack along with another binder, notebooks, and a laptop, and it has proved to be sturdy enough to survive without any visible ill-effects.This binder hosts some very nice features - plastic sleeves that are handy at holding on to extra stuff (such as index cards), outside pockets to label its contents, strong hinges, and the new one finger release (a huge ergonomic improvement).I have become very fond of that last feature ever since I encountered it on a previous binder. While I cannot remember ever having pinched my fingers within the traditional mechanism, it is still gratifying to see that inventors are still hard at work on old staples.I'll update this review if the tough hinges prove not to be as tough as they are purported to be, but for now I have no reason to suggest that the hinge material used is lacking in any way.Recommended!~A_E~

0:41 MinsThe HDR-PJ810 is a very competent video camera.Its robust specifications include 32GB internal memory, great image quality, 5.1 channel sound, extraordinary optical image stabilization, built-in projector, decent G-quality lens (12x optical zoom, fast F/1.8 lens, and 26.8mm at its widest), and wireless capabilities. Add to it the trademark super convenience of a built-in USB cable, compact form factor, and a built in projector light. This year's model also has a button that suppresses the camera user's voice.In addition, the camera is a pure joy to use. The touchscreen is generously sized, is responsive and very usable (e.g., for pulling focus.) All its hard buttons are very logically and intuitively placed. And, its weight is just right for extended periods of handheld video recording.The accompanying battery (NP-FV50) also was sufficiently capable - together with a spare I am able to cover an entire vacation day's worth of shooting.The only downsides to this camera come in comparison to its predecessor - the HDR-PJ790V, with its mind blowing capabilities (cavernous 96GB internal memory, brilliantly accurate Carl Zeiss lens, awesome microphone array, crazy good image stabilization, and built in GPS.) Of course, the HDRPJ810 is about 30% less expensive - so it is not hard to see why something had to give.Performance:#########That said - this camcorder is no slouch. As an example, see my uploaded video which was shot handheld at full zoom. This video was shot through a glass patio door - which did not throw off the camera's ability to focus on the subject. The capture quality was at the highest that the camcorder supports - [PS] @ 28 Mbps, 1920x1080 resolution, 60 frames per second, progressive. (For more details on image quality - see the "Recording modes" section below.)In particular, note that at the 11 sec point, I pulled focus using the touchscreen, and the image stabilization makes any camera shake barely noticeable.The projector image (30 sec point) shows a 48" diagonal on a white screen. Going bigger tends to have a less satisfying image.You may also notice the high level of ambient microphone noise. This is probably due to the fact that the PJ810's microphone array is built into its body, placing it very close to the camera's electronics. This noise is less noticeable when there is action going on - as is typical with automatic gain control circuitry. (Here, I was trying to stay as quiet as possible.)In conclusion, this is an awesome video camera, and should be more than sufficient for normal home video usage. At its price point, this is an excellent balance of cost and functionality.Must have accessories:###############1] If you need additional battery power, check out the NP-FV70 or NP-FV100 instead.2] BC-TRV charger - I hate to leave camcorder charging overnight so this travel charger is very handy.3] VMCUAM2 USB adapter cable - lets you back up your videos to an external hard drive without needing a computer.Recording modes:############Sony uses video quality abbreviations - PS, FX, FH, HQ, and LP - that I'm clarifying for others who may be as confused as I was:There are 4 aspects to recording video - bit rate (the number of bits captured per second, in Mbps), the number of pixels in each video frame (full HD 1920x1080, or 1440x1080), frame rate (the number of frames recorded per second), and whether these frames are interlaced or progressive (whether each frame is captured in full, or whether the odd rows and even rows are captured separately.)For highest quality capture: pick the highest bit rate, the highest number of pixels in each frame, the highest frame rate, and use progressive mode.For the HDR-PJ810 this is [PS] quality - up to 28 Mbps, 1920x1080 resolution, 60 frames per second, progressive.The downside? All those bits take up a lot of disk space, reducing available recording time. Switching to FX or below, causes more aggressive compression - that can cause compression artifacts in fast moving scenes.My advice: stay at PS. Why compromise on quality? Just pack a external drive, and clean up space as you go.On the PJ810, to pick [PS] quality, use Menu > Image Quality/Size > Frame Rate > 60p. You will be warned that you cannot record this capture to DVD, and that you cannot take still photos while capturing video. (This is not a huge problem, as you can always do this in post production.)Happy Memories!~A_E~

This is a value product that far outstrips its modest pricing. And, as long as you have modest expectations, this home theater setup is surprisingly competent. It is a very capable Bluray player, with a very well designed remote, and a decent set of speakers. Its weak spots are its receiver (which is extremely limited), and its lack of future expansion - neither of which are unexpected, given that a mid-grade receiver alone can cost more than this entire product.Setup was fairly straightforward - connect the speakers to the receiver (simply slot in the speaker wires), connect the HDMI out port to a TV, and run through simple setup steps for language selection, wired network setup, and verification of correct speaker cabling. That last one is particularly useful because it lets you get immediate confirmation of any cabling issues.The only additional setup that is necessary is to set up speaker levels - to adjust the output levels from each of the 5 speakers and the subwoofer.Once the unit was ready, I threw in a movie and was blown away by the picture quality - as good as what I get from my more expensive Bluray players. Sound quality was pretty decent, though on the bright side with strong highs but missing the mid and low frequencies. The subwoofer tended to pump out a lot of bass, but is best muted a bit as it ends up muddying the sound.In conclusion - this is a highly competent setup especially at this price point.While it will not anchor a home theater setup (a particular annoyance is its lack of wireless networking), it will serve very well as a secondary setup - for a dorm room or cabin.~A_E~

The box contained the DAP-1520, a bunch of stickers with wireless access passwords, and an anemic instruction booklet. Unfortunately, that lulled me into a false sense of security and so I was floored by how confusing the setup process turned out to be.The steps (in an ideal world) are as follows:1. Plug in the DAP-1520 into a power outlet, and wait for the lights to go from solid red to blinking amber.2. Select the wireless network created by the DAP-1520, and enter the supplied wireless passphrase.3. Click the notification message displayed by the wireless icon in the status tray.4. In the browser window that opens up, provide the default password and choose to setup the unit.5. Provide the DAP-1520 with the login passphrase for your wireless access point6. Wait for the DAP-1520 to reboot - and you're done!Unfortunately, the user manual/sheet led me astray and I spent 20 minutes trying to figure this out. The worst was that the HTTP URL used to connect to the DAP-1520 that is provided on the manual did not match the URL printed on the sticker accompanying the unit. Later when I connected to it, I received a spinning Scanning logo that did not do anything.All in all, a very confusing experience was had by me. I love networking products (I'm a sucker for punishment) - so I managed to persevere through it all.Fortunately, since it was setup it has worked like a charm - for a range extender.In my experience, the best way to improve your network range is to (a) buy a more powerful router, or (b) setup a second access point as a repeater. If neither option is palatable, consider setting up a Moca network (uses coax cabling), or a Powerline network (uses electrical wiring.) I would recommend considering a range extender only after exhausting those other options.The good thing about this particular unit is that it is dual band - so you don't have to lose half your networking bandwidth as with older technologies (it can use one band to talk to you, and the other band to talk to the router.) This last part has to do with the fact that wireless networks are half-duplex - i.e., there can only be one transmitting unit on a network at any given time.Good luck with your purchase decision, and Happy Networking!~A_E~

The package contained the N300 wireless adapter and an installation CD with a warning that the software needed to be installed before using the wireless adapter.Setup was fairly painless - it detected a newer version of the software, downloaded it from the Internet, installed it, and walked me through the network connection process (pick SSID and enter a passphrase.)Performance has been reasonable too - with a very respectable 24Mbps download speed (though the software claims it established a 300Mbps connection with full bars.)The only real downside is that this is not a dual band adapter (it is 2.4GHz only) - which is a pity considering today's uncrowded 5GHz channels.Happy Networking!~A_E~

TL;DR version:#######This is an almost-great product - a one-stop shop for a number of useful utilities that is unfortunately hobbled by an excessive pricing model, a troublesome licensing model, a sad set of functionality trade-offs, and surprisingly poor documentation.Unfortunately, given that there are such awesome free tools out there, I cannot recommend this tool set.Full review:#######This AirCheck product combines multiple networking tools into a single convenient Windows 8 style interface. In includes:1. A User Experience tool that lets you run basic tests that verify Access Point connection, DNS lookup, ping, traceroute, HTTP/FTP downloads, video/audio streaming, and simple HTTP browsing (which even tells your average download speed).2. A Survey tool that takes a custom architectural blueprint, and then lets you walk around your office space sampling throughput or signal strength. This is simply magical - and one of the must-have utilities in this tool set. I love this!3. A Device Finder that lists access points (and clients if you use the supplied adapter). A simple signal strength meter allows you to actively locate an access point.4. A Discovery feature that lists networks and lets you group them by access points or channels used.All of this is rolled into an organizational structure that is based on projects and tasks within that project.In my estimation, the Survey tool is the only must-have tool - where I do not know of a free equivalent.So what does not work well?####################1. Excessive pricing - Given that many of these tools are available for free (barring the Survey tool), I cannot see where the value proposition lies.2. Troublesome licensing model - you are tied to a single adapter (either within a laptop, or the supplied USB adapter). Any changes to the assigned adapter seems to need a valid support contract. This seems excessively restrictive.3. Sad set of functionality tradeoffs - unfortunately neither option (laptop adapter or supplied adapter) lets you access this tool's full functionality. Only the laptop adapter gives you access to the Survey tool (yeah!), whereas only the supplied adapter gives you access to the Client finder. I chose to sacrifice the Client finder, but this is a terrible choice to have to make with a product that costs this much.4. Surprisingly poor documentation - that should never have made it into a production-quality software product. For instance, it took me over an hour to figure out how to effectively use the Survey tool for a custom building plan- the documentation was completely lacking.Conclusion#######Overall, my recommendation would be to hold off until Fluke Networks has fixed some of these issues. Until then, there is a slew of free products (jPerf, inSSIDer, Wifi Analyzer, and Fing Network Tools) that should meet most needs.Happy Networking!~A_E~

I'm not a towel connoisseur by any means, but I do prefer my bath towels to be super absorbent and plush. Unfortunately, this set is not quite that. The fabric feels noticeably coarse to the touch, and in general usage falls at about the average level.I'm assuming the 700 gallons of fresh water saved by these towels, comes from what it would take to grow the recycled cotton that makes up a third of these towels - which definitely sounds like a worthwhile goal.If I were rating these towels purely on personal preference, I would have given it 3 stars - It's Okay - as they are adequate at what they do. However, the additional green credentials accompanying this merit an extra star.~A_E~

TL;DR version:This is a pretty neat keyboard: easy to setup, a very polished look and very comfortable to use. The only minor downside is that on the iPad 2, the volume and power buttons are not easy to get to (though the packaging claims that you will never need to use these buttons, which is actually correct.)Full version:Setup was a breeze - simply slot the iPad into the case (it fits very easily and very well), turn on the iPad's Bluetooth and pair with the keyboard. That's it!The keyboard was very easy to type with - the travel of each key was deep enough and soft enough that I could type this entire review on it without any issues. In addition, Fn keys exist to set volume and for common actions such as cut/copy/paste, etc. Finally, the Alt key along with the cursor keys support selecting of words; and the Command key lets you jet to the start/end of a line or page.The icing on the cake is the very decent aesthetics and ergonomics. This looks and feels like a high end product and there are lots of little touches that make it very comfortable to use  (such as soft bumpers on the edges and a finger hold to open the case.) Even the Belkin logo is tastefully discreet.The only problems I encountered with usability were the tiny Delete/Backspace key that was hard to hit consistently, and the Fn key at the far left that I kept hitting when I meant to hit the Alt key instead.While the volume buttons were not exposed easily on the iPad2, I did not feel their loss once I got used to the equivalent Fn keys on the keyboard. Likewise, while the power button is hard to access, the smart cover is very responsive and is a good alternative.Other than these minor gripes, this keyboard functions well, and is a joy to use.Happy Typing!A_E

This is a honest, from-the-gut, telling of the story of a successful sale of LoudCloud/Opsware to HP, and the many lessons derived from that experience.There isn't the dispassionate gloss that you get from typical books on management and leadership, and instead you are given the birds eye view of the messy and unpredictable process that comes from being a CEO.Happy reading!~A_E~

Typical of NatGeo's Traveler series, you will find gorgeous photographs and great writing. My favorite sections were the awesome retelling of 5000 years of India's history, and a comparative review of her religions.Unfortunately, for me, it had the exact same problems as the others in this series: a font that I found frustratingly hard to read, maps that were barely usable which required a lot of hunting to find the points of interest mentioned in the text, and tepid itineraries (ref: Charting your Trip pp8-11).A bigger problem with this particular book is that it tries to cover too much in too few pages. For instance, the section on Delhi and its surroundings gets the star treatment, and is very well detailed, but this comes at the unfortunate expense of other areas. This is unavoidable with a country of this size and with such a rich cultural heritage - but it could have been mitigated with a tighter focus on sights represented from the remainder of the country.Overall, get this book if you are focused on the Golden Triangle (Delhi, Agra, Jaipur), or if you wish to spend time in Tamil Nadu. For all other areas, supplementary sources would undoubtedly be required.Happy Travels!~A_E~

I enjoy traveling, and often prepare for years before actually visiting a country. Brazil has been on my wish list for a while now, and I found this book to be quite decent for the purpose of planning a trip there.The Discover series from Lonely Planet has been my gold standard for such research.Unfortunately, Fodor's Brazil 2014 does not rise to that level. While I found this book to be excellent as a pure travel planning guide, it is written in an efficient, dispassionate and clinical manner - and simply does not capture the magic of travel to a country with such spectacular natural bounty and biodiversity. Even its photographs are prosaic and functional.By contrast, National Geographic Traveler's Brazil is an excellently written book, but can be frustrating in its lack of easy to read maps as well as its marginal itinerary planning help.A better option might be to use Nat Geo's Brazil to get excited about your travel, and then use this guide to actually plan your visit.Happy Travels!~A_E~

I enjoy traveling, and often prepare for years before actually visiting a country. Brazil has been on my wish list for a while now, and I found this book to be quite decent for the purpose of planning a trip there.The Discover series from Lonely Planet is my gold standard for such research, and I have previously been disappointed by NatGeo's travel books. As a result, I went in with lowered expectations.Unfortunately, while this book is very well written and has the trademark stunning photographs, I was less than impressed.This series in general uses a font that is very hard on my eyes which is a problem when it comes to extended reading. In addition, the maps are very frustrating as it is often very hard to locate an area being discussed in the text on the accompanying map. In addition, the "insider tips" were mostly uninteresting; and the suggested itineraries were greatly lacking.That said, I did enjoy the read, and in particular found the treatment of Bonita (ecotourism) and Manaus (gateway to the Amazon) done very well.I also liked NatGeo's approach of placing hotel/restaurant information at the end of the book - these get out-of-date very quickly, and I usually rely on review web sites for that information anyway. Keeping these lists at the end makes it easier to get at key travel information without having to wade through this in the middle of the book.In comparison, I found Fodor's Brazil 2014 to be a much better alternative as a pure travel planning guide. Unfortunately, Fodor's guide is written in an efficient, dispassionate and clinical manner - it simply does not capture the magic of travel to a country with such spectacular natural bounty and biodiversity. Even its photographs are prosaic and functional.A better option might be to use this book to get excited about your travel, and then use the Fodor's guide to actually plan your visit.Happy Travels!~A_E~

I read this at my son's urging, and was incredibly moved.The featured review by shel99 says it all - so I'll end by saying that this is a powerful tale so be prepared for the emotions that it will wring out of you.Happy Reading!~A_E~
No issues - the cable and end points look well constructed and should last a while. Very highly recommended.~A_E~

I have previously used much stronger formulations including the nuclear strength versions of Nizoral and Head+Shoulders. Both of these have been excellent at controlling my dandruff once it had been aggravated enough from lack of attention. When I got a chance to try out the CLEAR versions (Ocean Mineral and Citrus Fresh), I decided to take a chance on a brand that I had not tried before.It is useful to note that the CLEAR brand has a decent pedigree (it's from Unilever) - since I try not to experiment with chemicals from companies that I do not trust.Unfortunately, my experiences were mixed.Both products arrived in decent packaging, and arrived safely with a little piece of cellophane tape to prevent spills. The shampoo's texture feels vaguely medicinal, but it lathered on strongly even with our hard water, and I did not feel any lingering itchy residue after it had been washed off.However, the overall strength of neither version quite worked for me. It never really cleared up my dandruff, and after a few tries, I had to retreat to my old standbys - which worked their magic, and cleared things up for me.As with any medication, I am loth to extrapolate their effectiveness from just my single experience - but for me it rated at-most an It's Okay (3-stars) because it did work reasonably as a shampoo and conditioner.(Note that I tried two versions of this shampoo - Ocean Mineral and Citrus Fresh. Other than fragrance differences, they had identical effects on my scalp.)~A_E~

I have previously used much stronger formulations including the nuclear strength scalp-searing versions of Nizoral and Head+Shoulders. Both of these have been excellent at controlling my dandruff once it had been aggravated enough from a lack of attention. When I got a chance to try out the CLEAR versions, I decided to take a chance on a brand that I had not tried before.Unfortunately, my experiences were mixed. The packaging was decent, and it arrived safely with a little piece of cellophane tape to prevent spills. Its texture feels vaguely medicinal, but it lathered on strongly, and I did not feel any lingering itchy residue. However, its overall strength left a lot to be desired. It never quite cleared up my dandruff, and after a few tries, I had to retreat to my old standbys - which worked their magic, and cleared things up for me.As with any medication, I am loth to extrapolate their effectiveness from just my single experience, and judging by the plethora of 5-stars that this product has garnered, others seem to have had much better experiences. Unfortunately, for me it rated at-most an It's Okay (3-stars) because it did work reasonably as a shampoo and conditioner.(I tried two versions of this shampoo - this Ocean Mineral and Citrus Fresh. Other than fragrance differences, they had identical effects on my scalp.)~A_E~

I enjoyed the film. Yes there were flaws, such as the need to know about the earlier films and the villains in them to understand what was going on, and the unlikelihood that the current villain is who he claims to be, and such minor points as the female character looking like a vampire when she was given blood red lipstick to wear. But, overall, I found the film to be what I wanted it to be. There was lots of action, and I like films with action. Bond was his usual cool self, and I liked that. The overall plot was new and the internal problems within the intelligence system were interesting.

My family likes all of the many Campanelli products. We found that these towels have all-around usefulness. They are very durable. They are soft, gentle, have beautiful colors, clears dirt and makeup and dust. I even use if to assure that no oil gets on my pillow; when I lay down to read a book, I place a towel under my head.

This company makes environmental friendly cleaning products.The dust cloths, sponges, hand-towels and many, many more items all can be washed with dish-washing soap and air-dried, only.They can be re-used many times. It is a pleasure to look at the bright colors and the soft feel of different materials the products are made of.My family enjoys using and cleaning with them very much! It is FUN!

I disliked this film. The story could have been good, but I couldn't watch how it was acted after 52 minutes and shut it off, never seeing the end. The acting seemed so amateurish. The timing of the fight scenes was so off that it was clear that when one man supposedly hit another, he did not do so. The shooting scenes did not seem real; it was as if people were playing at it. Our hero had two helpers against an entire army with the goal to free a kidnapped woman. One of the two helpers seemed so silly it was embarrassing to look at him.

I ordered the stamp when I received a letter from a friend who was using the stamp and I was impressed. The stamp gives the impression of a professional printing. It can be used on envelopes and to customize one's paper-goods like napkins, gift notes, gift wrappings, and gift boxes. The stamp is very easy to use. The result looks great!

This is a beautiful five-piece set that wine enthusiasts will enjoy. The five pieces will help enhance the aroma and taste of their wines.  The set is packaged in a nice looking box that owners may want to keep on their shelves to display the five items. All of the items are easy to use. The wine bottle opener, for example, works with a set of AA batteries, and all that a user needs to do is push a button.I received the box as a complementary sample for my honest review and I am very happy to have received it, and I am using it with pleasure.

This is the most beautiful wine aerator that I have seen. I like that it is made of glass, that it resembles a winged angel and an ancient vase. It looks very nice on my shelf. It looks so nice that when we had guests, we placed the aerator next to the bottle of wine and received compliments.It works. The wine moves gracefully but quickly though the aerator and enhances my wine, giving it a finer bouquet.I received the aerator as a complimentary sample for my honest feedback, and was very satisfied, as I wrote.

In this interesting book, Deborah Gatchel explores biblical events by (1) adding details unstated in the Bible that explain what the Bible teaches and (2) by introducing people not mentioned in the Bible so that readers can see a deeper meaning in the biblical tales through their eyes, and she succeeds. She describes her goal: A common thread weaves through our stories  the power of faith in God. She quotes Romans 6:23 and states that people need to have faith in Jesus and earn eternal life.Each of Gatchels fifteen stories is written in a straight-forward, simple, and warm style. In the story of Noah and the flood, for example, she tells us about the reactions of members of Noahs family who would not accompany him and be saved on the ark, as well as how other people reacted during the decades in which he built the ark. In the tale about Abrahams servant obeying Abrahams request that he secure a wife for Abrahams son Isaac, Gatchel reveals the reactions of the young Rebekah and her familys thinking about the servants entreaty that they allow Rebekah to accompany him to become Isaacs wife. In the story about Moses, she tells us about his sister Miriam faithfully guarding her brother and introduces us to a brother not mentioned in the Bible. In the account about Paul, we are told how a slave who stole items from his master was influenced to change by Paul.All in all, Christians will enjoy these stories, obtain a keener insight into them, and be inspired.

This 2014 film is one of the best westerns I saw in a long time; great acting and filled with tension. Jon and his brother, who fought for Denmark against Germany, left Denmark for the US to create a future. Seven years later, Jon sends for his wife and son. On the way to his ranch, two outlaws rape and kill his wife and son. Jon kills them. The two were part of a gang. One was the brother of the gang leader. The outlaws decide to take revenge, and the revenge is outlandish.The tension builds up very close to the beginning of the film and does not let up for a moment.

Being familiar with the Bible and knowing that the film would differ with the biblical story in a radical manner, I decided not to watch the film; but then I did. I enjoyed it and found it thought-provoking.I was right that the film has many events in it that are not in the Bible, and some are even contrary to what the Bible states. Among the many: The Bible does not state that the Israelites slaves built Egyptian palaces and enhanced the countrys glory. Moses was not an Egyptian general who led Egyptian forces against Hyksos, a better general than the future Pharaoh (son of the present Pharaoh), and saved his life during the battle. The Egyptians did not call out praises to Moses when he returned from the battle and ignored the future Pharaoh. Moses had two sons, not just one. The number of Israelite slaves in the Torah was 600,000 males, not 400,000.  Nun was not mentioned in the Bible as the man who told Moses he was an Israelite. God did not appear several times to Moses looking like a boy. There is no indication in the Torah that the plague of blood in the Egyptian waters was the result of crocodiles attacking Egyptian ships and chewing the Egyptian sailors. The Torah does not state that the plagues were designed to destroy the Egyptians economy, especially its food supply, and cause the population to call on Pharaoh to release the slaves. Moses did not train and lead a force of fighters to fight Pharaohs army. Pharaoh did not order his people to seek out and kill Moses. The Egyptian population did not shout curses at the Israelites as they left Egypt, the Bible states the opposite; they even gave gifts to the departing nation.I found the film version inspirational, as I will state more fully in a moment, I thought that Christian Bale was a better Moses than Charleston Hesston in the earlier film version. He was more human. I liked many comments in the film; for example, when Moses told the Israelites to put lamb blood on their door posts and the Israelites asked him, will it help, Moses responded: If I am right, we will bless the lambs for eternity.What I am about to say will bother some readers but it is worth thinking about. While the film version of the exodus is different than the Torah version, it may be true or at least a fair explanation of the biblical tale. The Torah itself frequently gives more than one version of a story. For example, there are two versions of the Ten Commandments, one in Exodus 20 and one in Deuteronomy 5. One version saying the son who tried to save Joseph from being killed by his brothers was Reuben, the other Judah. One says Joseph was sold to Ishmaelites, the other to Midianites. There are two different accounts (minor differences) between what occurred when Abraham sent his servant to acquire a wife for his son Isaac between the narrative and how the servant described it. There are more than a few times that the Bible tells a story which is followed by a song (such as the tale of the drowning of Egyptians at the Red Sea and Joshuas victory at Jericho), and in each instance the details in the song differ with the narrative account (for example, it is only in the song that the sun stood still). Is it possible that the story of the flood is a version of the Gilgamesh tale which was composed before the time of Moses?

Bob Steele (1907-1988) began to star in B westerns in 1927. In the 1940s, his career as a star cowboy began to fade and he accepted supporting roles for several decades. In this 1945 film, he stars as the adopted son of an Indian Agent who is killed during a robbery. He goes out to find the killer of his adopted father and to find his real father. He is able to identify his adopted father's killer by a ring and watch that the killer took from him. He can identify his natural father by means of another watch that his now dead mother had. The film has several comedy segments as was typical in the westerns of this era, as well as the ubiquitous fist fights, gun fights, and chases.

While the film is fiction, it portrays and indicts the barbaric system of divorces in Israel that are no better than how women were treated in the Middle Ages. In Israel, only rabbinical courts can issue divorces, but as shown in this film, the rabbis believe they can only issue a divorce if the husband agrees to give the divorce to his wife. A woman cannot initiate a divorce. As a result, husbands can refuse to grant wives divorces leaving them unable to marry. They are chained to their husband for life even though the husband is not living with them, supporting them, and able, under Jewish law, to marry another woman. This situation needs to be changed.In this film, we see the common occurrence. The wife Viviane Amsalem wants a divorce from her husband who is extremely controlling. There is no doubt that the marriage cannot endure, but the rabbis continually insist that Viviane return to her husband and try to work out the marriage. This goes on for about a dozen appearances before the rabbinical court of three rabbis, for over five years during which time Viviane suffers. Viewers will see how unsympathetic the rabbis are to her situation, how little they know of psychology, and how prejudiced the rabbis are in favoring the male.The film was made in Israel and the people speak in Hebrew, but there are subtitles which are easy to read.

This is a book that people, Jews and non-Jews, who believe in mysticism, will enjoy. The author tells how he is convinced that the mystical approach to life can transform and improve one's life. In sixteen chapters, Rabbi Yoel Glick describes the kabbalistic concept of God being composed of ten disjointed parts known as the ten sefirot, how humans are created in the image of God, about the tenth divine level which interacts with humans - the feminine aspect of God called Malkhut and Shekhinah, about the mystical leader of the sixteenth century Ari, how people grow and progress as human beings and how souls grow, about karma, the astral body, free will, how heaven is organized, tikun, angels, the concept of the temple, the messiah, the soul of people and of nations, and many other mystical concepts.The book is filled with charts, showing, for example, the ten sefirot, the five levels of the soul, the five bodies of the soul, the body of the earth, the seven planes of earth, and many more.

This is an excellent haunting novel by an author who died at age 36, the year that this book was published, in 1962. He wrote one book before this one The Human Season, and two were published posthumously, The Tenants of Moonbloom and The Children of the Gate. All four received positive well-deserved acclaim. Dara Horn wrote the informative Forward to this volume. The Pawnbroker is considered the best and most powerful book dealing with the trauma produced by the holocaust. The book was a National Book Award finalist. It sold 500,000 copies when it was published. It was made into a powerful film starring Rod Steiger in 1964, and Steiger won a Best Actor Oscar nomination for his performance of Sol Nazerman.Nazerman survived the World War II Nazi death camp where he lost his parents, wife, and children. The experience left him bereft of hope and deprived him of feelings for people. He is 45 years old. He lost his family fifteen years ago. He opened a pawn shop in Harlem where he deals with prostitutes, pimps, and thieves, which Wallant describes with skill and feelings. Wallant also describes other characters involved in Nazermans life with similar skill. There is his sister, her husband, and their child, an aged woman with a dying father with whom Nazerman secures sexual release. Nazerman supports all four of them. There is also a young black man who is Nazermans assistant in the shop with whom he has an ambivalent relationship. His pawnshop makes no money and Nazerman survives only because the shop is a front for gangsters who pay him a salary, a situation that bothers him.

Jews and non-Jews have recognized the practical wisdom of many of the sayings in Pirkei Avot, The Ethics of the Fathers, and many Jews can quote its teachings from memory. Jews considered the Ethics of the Fathers so significant that many excellent commentaries have been written on the Ethics and the custom arose to read one chapter a week during the summer months.But this Koren volume is unique in half a dozen ways that make it special. The Hebrew script and English translation are broken down, as is usual in Koren books, into easy to read phrases with excellent print. The translation of the six chapters by Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks is in modern English, with Rabbi Sacks sometimes paraphrasing the Hebrew text when it makes more sense to do so rather than presenting an awkward literal English translation. Rabbi Marc D. Angel has given a very learned introduction in which he points out, among much else, that Great sages in ancient civilizations have provided teachings to help guide humanity to harmonious, happy, and wise lives. Among the wisest and most influential teachers were those of ancient Israel.Rabbi Angel offers explanation of all of the wise ancient sayings, presenting both traditional commentaries as well as learned thoughts by others, Jews and non-Jews, which add depth to the teachings of the fathers. He supplements the wise lessons of the ancients with modern information such as the following. An Israeli Nobel Prize winner described the illusion of validity: people tend to think their judgments are valid even when based simply on first impressions or relatively short observations and are often badly mistaken.
