A psychiatrist wrote that We establish irrational ideals of the real man and the right kind of woman, which not only separates us more and more from our genuine potentialities, but in the long run also lead us into self-destructiveness. The philosopher of the late first and early second century CE, Epictetus, warned Know you not that a good man does nothing for appearance sake but for the sake of having done right. An American scientist observed: One human trait, urging us by our nature, is the drive to be useful.Rabbi Angel adds historical information. He describes, for instance, the period of the Great Assembly (a congress of some seventy elders), followed by the Zuggot (leadership by the pairs), followed by the governance by descendants of the family of Hillel, and gives biographical data about each man mentioned in the book. He notes that the Ethics represents different generations and historical conditions in the Land of Israel, and he explains the differences. He describes five periods. He tells how there are sayings of nineteen sages who lived prior to the destruction of the Temple in 70 CE; sixteen who flourished from 70 through the early second century when Israel was under the harsh dominion of Rome; fourteen between the early second century through the Bar Kokhba rebellion against Rome in 132-135; eleven sages following the rebellion through the late second century; and eight scholars who lived between the late second century through the early third century; sixty eight wise men in all.The book is filled with a wealth of other information, inspiring stories, and the results of psychological experiments. For example: the psychologist Erich Fromm noted that most people fail in life because they are unable to make a decision when they come to metaphorical forks in the road; people are so impressed by being watched that when a picture of two eyes is painted on an honor box to pay for beverages, people paid more than twice as much for their drinks; nations perish when its people forget where they came from.In short, while other commentaries on Pirkei Avot have much to offer, this volume will teach readers very much in an interesting, thought-provoking, and enjoyable manner.

This new translation and commentary on the biblical book of Psalms is very good for four reasons: (1) The Hebrew script and English translation are broken down, as is usual in Koren books, into easy to read phrases. (2) The translation of the Psalms by Rabbi Eli Cashdan is in modern English. For example, Psalm 23 begins:A psalm of David.The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want.He makes me lie down in green pastures;He leads me beside still watersInstead of:He maketh me to lie down in green pastures;He leadeth me beside the still waters.(3) The book contains a learned and easy to read introduction and commentary by Rabbi Dr. Tzvi Hersh Weinreb who is not only a renowned rabbi but a former practicing psychologist and able to understand the emotions underlying many of the psalms. (4) The book is filled with a wealth of information and inspiration. For example: (a) Each of the 150 psalms is preceded by a brief meditation written in the first person which captures the predominant mood of the psalm. The introduction for the first psalm, for instance, has; I face a difficult choice. Good versus evil. How can I choose? Will I regret my choice of the former, when the latter has such obvious advantages? (b) Each psalm is followed by an essay that expounds upon one or two of its central teachings. (c) It contains prayers to be recited before and after the reading of psalms. (d) It identifies nine psalms that can be recited on special occasions such as prayers for recovery from illness and prayers to be recited at a cemetery. (e) It also has two charts that people can use to study the psalm weekly or monthly.

This film has two features that raise it slightly above the usual western: race and the mistreatment of wives. It is 1861 and the civil war has just begun. Army forces in Texas leave to fight in the east leaving no soldiers to aid the settlers against the Indians. A white man and a black man grew up together and try to organize the settlers to fight the Indians, but some settlers do not want to be with the black man. Additionally, while one man's wife wants her husband to act reasonably, he hits her. The Indians attack and kidnap all the settles' wives and children. In the film we get to see the side of the Indians and get to see reasonable as well as unreasonable Indians.

This is a grade B film with a plot which has been seen in a dozen of old films, without any variation. There are no surprises. Reagan is a marshal who wants to give up his marshal practice, moves to a new location, but is pulled into saving the city.

The Mutrah bracelet is very unique and interesting in color. It is a combination of brass and cord, gold and pink. Therefore, it an be worn by all ages and by males and females. It is elegant and sporty at the same time.The perfect gift for everyone.

This is a fun version of Tarzan with what we have seen in other versions, with just a few changes, such as Tarzan having a bird that protects him. The drawings are good and it is easy to forget that we are not watching real actors. There is lots of action and much emotion. I think that both young and old will enjoy the film.

This book has much that will delight children as well as adults. However it has problems: much of the book is out of date, it having been published in 1904; the language is sometimes obscure since it is based on Scottish, and the kindle version, as noted by other reviewers is not very good. However, the rhymes, games, songs, stories for bairns and big folk has much to delight. It also has interesting information, such as the poems Little Jack Horner and Mary had a Little Lamb are based on true stories. One way to use it is for adults to choose items from the book to tell kids.

After reading half a dozen pages, Steve N. Lees action drama grabbed me. I was interested in finding out what happened. Soon I was also wondering about Tess Williams past.A beautiful young woman is seeking work, any kind of work, so that she and her mother who is dying can leave this Baltic country and travel to England where her mother, who is extremely ill, perhaps even dying, may get medical help. But her purse was stolen. She has no money. She is willing to clean houses to get money, to get out. A handsome personable man offers her a job and drives her to it. But there is no job. Instead she is beaten and raped.The girls mother is looking for her. She sees a five foot seven beautiful woman save a couple by beating up three men who threatened them. This is Tess who has a past where harm was done to her in America. She spent ten years training in hand to hand combat and breathing exercises to control herself, who is determined to take revenge for what was done to her. Until then she helps others who need help, just as she helped the couple that the mother saw. She had killed 56 people. She wears a bullet-proof vest when need as well as other protective gear, including glove with metal inside. The abducted girls mother feels certain that Tess can help her. Tess feels sorry for her and agrees to help find her daughter.The book tells of their search and the difficulties they encounter and the people Tess must fight and those she must kill. It is, as I wrote, gripping. It is also suspenseful. The figure of Tess is nicely drawn and we identify with her. There is much suspense and a lot of action.

This is an important work, with this volume being only the beginning of the half dozen books in the series. Ginzberg points out that the tales that he collected were not invented in the synagogue, but by the people who wanted to see the biblical stories in a miraculous manner. The stories show Gods involvement in human affair and magnifies the heroic efforts of biblical characters. Maimonides (1138-1204) pointed out in his work called Chelek that anyone who accepts Midrashim, legends, as being true is a fool. So too anyone who dismisses them because they are untrue is also a fool, because the rabbis used these legends in a homiletical manner to teach lessons. They used the popular tales as parables, changing them slightly to make their point.Whether one is interested in the legends to see what the ancients thought or to try to mine them for the rabbinical lesson, the legends are fascinating, just as fiction is fascinating when it is told well.

This is a very good book energetically written that will help both new and old writers improve their writing skills because it is good even for seasoned writers to be reminded to add proper details to writing, but not overdo it, and what kind of details to add, and when to do so. Kat Duncan tells what kind of details enhance a story or non-fiction writing, about action details that are best when drawn out, where to set the scene, different kinds of sensory details, when and how to insert  dialogue, mannerisms, habits, and how to use details to make the reader identify with and like the character. She spices her book with many examples that show what are good uses and bad uses of details.

This is one of the best books that I read about dinosaurs. It contains virtually everything children and adults want to know about them: the different kinds, that some are as small as a chicken, what they eat, their anatomy, their sense od smell, their diet, their eggs, how scientists are able to tell us so much about them, and much more

This prequel to the Men of Lancaster County series is a superb story of the effect upon an Amish man when his daughter and later his dog disappeared and how it affected his religious belief and how he found it again. The writing is suspenseful. The story develops slowly. We do not know at first what is happening or why, but the author grabs our interest and holds it. We identify with Joel and want to find out what is happening and why and how Joel will deal with it.

This is a fascinating children-friendly book with three enjoyable stories of a dad, mom, and three kids, two older brothers and a young sister and her teddy bear. The pictures in the book are delightful. The first story is called Fair. In it, grandma takes the kids to a fair because when she was a child, she went every year. Two hundred times, one of the kids laughed. The children needed to bring a gift to enter the fair. Ben brought a book, Zach a plastic sword, and Chelsea an old rattle. The kids saw many things and participated in them. There were rides, prizes, cotton candy, corn on the cob, cakes, fresh milk, animals in a petting zoo, and they saw piglets in a mock fight, and more. Kids reading what they saw and did will enjoy their adventures vicariously.The second tale Crepes describes how the three kids helped mom make crepes. It was a fun adventure making the crepes and setting the table. The kids promised to be good if mom makes crepes once a week.The third story Park tells the adventures of the children when they went to a picnic in the park with mom and dad. When they were playing with their Frisbee, a puppy stole the Frisbee and they chased it. Later they begged mom and dad for a puppy of their own.

I enjoyed this short story. It has all the elements that are in longer action novels, intrigue, suspense, a good development of characters, and more. The writing is clear and the story and its plot captured my interest.

Flash fiction are short stories with a beginning, middle and end as other tales, but much shorter, some as short as three dozen words of less. This one, a first attempt by an author, is seven pages long and can be read in under five minutes. It leads the reader to think what is being said is saying something, but by the end, the reader discovers the story is saying something else. It is pretty good.

Flash stories are complete novels - beginning, middle, and end - written with a few words. Some authors write such fiction with several dozen words, no more. Others shoot for a slightly larger number. This book contains flash stories of under 100 words from just under two dozen authors. Some of the stories are quite striking, memorable. Others are hard to understand - it seems that what is not stated should have been stated. Still others are in between or close to being very good, such as stories that seem to lead the reader to think that the plot is something, but he or she soon discovers it is something else. All in all, the book is worth reading because of the best tales and those almost as good.

This is a short story of a woman who has sex with a man and then discovers that he is her stepbrother because her mother just married his father. Both believe that sex with a step-sibling is wrong, but they do it anyway. The sex is described in detail. It is a kind of sadistic sex, master and subject.

This is a fun book with delightful pictures that kids will enjoy. The book has a surprise gift at the end. It is about three friends who decide to go on an adventure and sleep overnight in a tent and what happened to them during the night. The three are Alexander who is a pig, Pim who is a hedgehog, and Mycroft who is a zebra. Pim is afraid of virtually everything while Mycroft is brainy, logical, and practical. Alexander likes to sing poetic songs that he makes up and he walks in his sleep.The three set up a tent and Alexander is bit on his hooves by a lobster and his green suit is ruined. He hangs up the suit and the three go to sleep. During the night, Alexander sleep-walks and because he is walking with his eyes closed, he walks into a tree and starts screaming. Pim and Mycroft think he was pig-napped.Kids will enjoy finding out what happens next and why the three think the green suit is a monster.

Bybliotech has done a great service to readers by making the complete classical works of a large number of writers available to them for a very inexpensive price. I found the kindle version of the complete works of William Makepeace Thackeray easy to use. I could click on whatever work I wanted to read and the book, short story, or other writing would appear instantaneously. I also found that it is very easy to read and not as some other versions of older writings that were placed by others on kindle, which are filled with mistakes. This huge kindle Thackeray version contains the complete novels, novellas, short stories, satires, drama, poems, travel, nonfiction, and letters.William Makepeace Thackeray (1811 1863) was an English novelist of the nineteenth century. He is famous today for his satirical works, especially Vanity Fair, which is a panoramic portrait of English society of his day. In this masterpiece, which has become a part of university courses, and has been repeatedly adapted for the cinema and television, Thackeray shows a fondness for roguish upstart Becky Sharp while he satirizes high society, military prowess, the institution of marriage, and hypocrisy.In his own time, during the Victorian era, he was ranked second only to Charles Dickens; Anthony Trollope ranked his History of Henry Esmond as his greatest work; Charlotte Bronte considered him her favorite author. But while many enjoy all or most of his writings, he is known today almost exclusively for Vanity Fair.

This book is disturbing, humorous, serious, critical, thought-provoking, and a necessary read for people who want to understand international affairs, the situation in Israel, and how outsiders can influence events with terrible results. It was a number 1 best seller in Israel. The book is well written and gonzo journalism at its best.Gonzo journalism is a writing that does not claim to be objective. It frequently includes the author as a participant in the story. It is usually written in an energetic participatory writing style in which the author is the prime protagonist. It is generally made up of a combination of social critique and a satire of ones self, which can be biting and quite humorous. It focuses on personal experiences and emotions, in contrast to traditional journalism, which prefers a detached style and relies on facts or quotations that can be verified by third parties. Yet its goal is to reveal the truth. Catch a Jew has all of these characteristics.Tuvia Tenenbom was born in Israel to a very religious family, but gave it all up, became a secular Jew and left Israel. He speaks English, Hebrew, Arabic, and German, and is able to use these skills together with his warm and often jolly personality during a period of seven months when he interviewed all kinds of people in Israel. He was able to convince the people to whom he spoke to open up to him because he was not a Jew, but a German  who the Palestinians like  or an Arab.Most of the Israeli Jews that he interviewed are self-haters, man and women, from the street or in top governmental offices, who criticize Israel. They are people on the left who support the Palestinian causes and those on the right who feel the Israeli government is not doing all it should be doing, such as settlers. All of the Palestinians who he interviewed hate Israel and say that they feel they are living in an occupied country, even those living in Israel and not in the west bank or Gaza. They cry that they are poor and mistreated although they obtain free health care, free college, and some live in luxurious homes.What is most disturbing is that outside agencies such as the Red Cross and governments, especially Germany, not only support the Palestinians with huge gifts of money, but they encourage Palestinians to have demonstrations and riots, and they incite them to lie.

This play by the famed Greek playwright Euripides (480-406 BCE) is a supernatural tale of King Admetus who was told that he would not die if he could find another person who was willing to die for him. In his play, Euripides analyses the psychology of the king. After being rebuffed by his parents, he asks his wife to die for him. She agrees on the condition that he marries no other person after her death. She explained that she loves her two children and feared that a stepmother would not treat them well. The king agrees and she dies. Soon after her death, the king realizes two things. First, he acted dishonorably and second, he misses his wife. This is he who lives in shame because he dared not do. He never knew her worth he will know it now.Just as she is being buried, Heracles appears at the kings palace. Unasked by the king, he goes out, wrestles with death, defeats death, and brings back Alcestis to her husband alive.Interestingly, Alcestis is unable to speak when she reappears after her death. Her husband asks why this is so. Heracles explains that it is only after three days after death that one can be fully alive again. This brings to mind the story of the resurrection of Jesus after three days.

This book ends the first 22 years since John Carter arrived on Mars. It ends what might be called the first trilogy of the eleven books written by Burroughs. The first two books ended in cliffhangers. The second concluded with Carter's wife being captured. This book tells the many adventures that Carter goes through as he attempts to find and save his wife. He is not sure she is still alive. He also wants to find her father and grandfather who have been missing for a long time after they went in search for her. Carter faces problem after problem. He frequently comes very near to saving her, but something always happens to foil his attempt.

Wine is an essential part of Judaism. It is mentioned 136 times in the Hebrew Bible, sometimes to emphasize its possible harmful effects on people, as with Noah, Laban, and King Ahasuerus; sometimes as part of the sacrifice that was offered to God, as in the book of Leviticus and elsewhere; and sometimes to praise it, as in Song of Songs and Proverbs. When the wine was poured as a sacrifice on the altar, the Levites in the Temple would break into song. Wine introduces the meal of the holiest day on the Jewish calendar, the Sabbath, when before the Sabbath meal is eaten, a meal more sumptuous than meals during the rest of the week, a blessing is said before eating that meal over wine because wine taste good and enhances the meal and it is therefore a suitable introduction to the meal. The drinking of the wine at this time came to be thought of as being on a human level similar to the wine offered to God with sacrifices,  and therefore, just as only the best kind of wine was offered as a sacrifice, so too many Jews felt that only the best kind of wine should be used for this blessing, which is called kiddush, meaning sanctification, and which teaches the possibility for holiness that can exist in the Sabbath if it is properly observed.Rabbis extolled wine in the Talmud. Bava Batra 12b states: one who routinely drinks wine  even if his heart is totally stopped up  the wine will make him intelligent.  Nedarim 10b states that a Nazarite who swears off drinking wine because he wants to rectify a personal failing or to rise to a higher spiritual level through abstinence must bring a sin offering because one should not abstain from legitimate pleasures. Wine is considered so special that while the blessing over bread at the beginning of a meal covers all foods during the meal  meaning, people do not have to make additional blessings for each type of food  this rule does not apply to wine; whether drunk alone, before the meal, or during the meal, one must say the blessing thanking God for the wine.Irving Langer relates the history of the Jewish consumption of wine and tells about the different kinds of wines and how they can be enjoyed. Historians estimate that there were hundreds of wine presses scattered throughout Israel during the Roman period (63 BCE  70 CE) and the ancient Jews of the second temple period (516 BCE  70 CE) consumed about three hundred gallons of wine each year and also produced huge amounts of wine for export. Wine making flourished in Israel and came to an end with the Islamic conquest of the country in the seventh century CE. Jews outside of Israel also produced wine, but in the Middle Ages, Jews were prohibited from owning land and this put an end to this activity.When Jews settled in America, the Jewish desire for wine prompted the making of wine in New York State from Concord grapes, but the result was coarse and bitter and had to be sweetened with lots of sugar to make it palatable. Not knowing that these Manischewitz and Shapiro sweetened wines were inferior wines that needed to be adulterated, several generations of Jews began to believe that kosher wine needed to be sweet, a belief that many still have today. Twenty-five years ago, more than ninety percent of kosher wines were sweet, today, over eighty percent of kosher wines are dry, and the best of the sweet kosher wines are produced at great expense to make the very best dessert wines.The production of dry kosher wines in America began in the late 1950s. Today there are over 1500 types of kosher wines,  produced throughout virtually every wine growing area in Europe, including five different areas in Israel where world-class quality wines are produced.  Israel began to produce wine again in 1848 in the Old City of Jerusalem. By 2010, Carmel Winery, the largest winemaker in Israel, won the Decanter International Trophy in the Red Rhone varietal group, beating nearly eleven thousand wines from forty-one countries. Barkan Winery is the second largest winery in Israel, producing about seven to nine million bottles of wine a year.There are many varieties of wine, but there are six big varieties, three whites and three reds: Riesling, Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blank (all whites), and Pinot Noir, Merlot, and Cabernet Sauvignon (reds).  Irving Langer explains how professional wine critics taste in only a sip of wine earthy, bright, spicy, fruity, complex, about the various aroma qualities, taste qualities, aftertaste, color, and more. He also gives ten steps that one should take to secure the best enjoyment in drinking wine. He tells how there are two tastes that wine gives: the first when the wine is on your tongue and the second when you swallow. He explains that different wine glasses are used for different varieties, how to order wine in a restaurant, how to store wine, why wine is taken from the middle and not the top or bottom of the winery barrel, and much more.

The copyright of the Burroughs Jack Carter books have expired and therefore these excellent books are available in various formats for a very low fee, or even free from some sources. Amazon offers a set of all Edgar Rice Burroughs seven Jack Carter books about his experiences on Mars for only ninety-nine cents. However, there are a total of eleven Jack Carter Mars books. Burroughs is famous for writing the Tarzan books, but he wrote many other kinds of books. The following is some highlights about this book, but I am careful not to include a host of details that make the book interesting, clever, and suspenseful.Jack Carter of Virginia was a captain in the Confederate Army. He had served previously in various countries as a soldier of fortune and was well-adapt in military affairs and was very strong. After the Civil War, he and a fellow officer went west prospecting for gold. They found a large vein of gold, but while attempting to lay claim to the strike, his partner was killed by Indians and Carter lay wounded in a cave. He awoke naked and discovered that somehow he had been transferred to Mars. In the first book of the seven book series, Carter in involved in many adventures. Because of the lesser gravity in Mars, Carter is able to leap very high and he is stronger than the many different kinds of Martians. At the end of the book, he saves Mars from extinction, but is transported back to earth. In this volume, after an absence of some ten years on earth, Jack Carter is transported again to Mars. But he finds himself in an area and among a people very different than those he knew during his prior visit. He is now in the land that is the subject of superstition. The rest of the people on Mars believe that when they are ready to die, they go to this land where god is. The belief is that no one can come back from this land. If, as happened once, a person does come back, and that person says that the land is not a peaceful and happy place, but a land where those who come to it are treated badly, are enslaved, and when its inhabitants tire of the person, they eat them  if a person came back and said this, the people would call that person a blasphemer and kill that person.Carter needs to escape this land and find his wife. He undergoes many adventures. Among them he must save himself from being killed as a blasphemer, he meets a young person who looks like him, he discovers that his wife has been taken hostage by the people in this heaven, he leads an army to rescue her, and he meets the god.

Davey wrote this clever, fun, and poetic book for people of all ages. The illustrations in the book by Lotysh and Khalova are marvelous. Adults and children will delight in reading and seeing this book, over and over again.Billy is more fun and has more fun than most people. He has a giant black hound and the two obviously love one another. Hes soft like a child underneath. Billy loves and appreciates nature, as we all should, but dont. He loves to sleep beside roses and lilies. He likes to look at the stars and the moon. He plays music to the autumn weather.I learn a lot from this BillyAs I watch him run wild and free.Hes simple and quite a bit sillyBut he brings out the Billy in me.In short, readers of this delightful book will learn to enjoy all the beautiful things around them, as Billy does.

Nirit Litaney, author of seven other delightful books, wrote this clever and fascinating tale of a rather cute young looking alien named Zigi. Abira Das drew quite a lot of very nice drawings for the book that add much. Children will enjoy reading or hearing Zigis adventure and enjoy looking at the pictures; and they will learn a lot about chocolate.Zigi is friendly and harmless. He not an earthling and doesnt look like one. When he gets sick, he needs to eat chocolates which cure him. He also eats chocolates because he likes the taste. Since there are no chocolates on his planet, he needs to travel to earth on his spaceship from time to time, especially when he is sick, to eat chocolates. He has a bad cold now and this is why he made the trip that Nirit narrates. Zigi brought along moon stones which he leaves for people when he takes their chocolate, because Zigi is honest. Earth people like moon stones. Zigi is very careful to sneak around on earth because he does not want the earth people to see him.Nirit Litaney tells readers about a half dozen adventures that Zigi has during this trip. He goes to a coffee shop for hot chocolate, a bakery for cakes and cookies that contain chocolate, a chocolate store with many different kinds of candies, a spa where children swim in chocolate, and a birthday party where kids are given a plate full of chocolates.In short, this is a fun book and children will be thrilled with it.

This tale by the famed English satirist William Makepeace Thackeray (1811-1863), author of the highly respected Vanity Fair, is a childrens story filled with humor and sprinkled lavishly with nonsense. It is the story of a fairy, a king of two kingdoms, their offspring, and an old ugly woman. Virtually every name in the tale is funny, as is all the incidences. Children will not understand every satire, but will enjoy the tale. Adults will do both.The legitimate king and queen of both kingdoms were dethroned by people who should not have done so. The son of one kingdom is kept in the palace but receives no education and cannot even spell. The daughter of the other kingdom wandered away during the rebellion and was raised by lions. A fairy was invited to all royal births and gave magical gifts. She gave a magical ring to the mother of the uneducated boy before the rebellion, who passed it on to her son, and a feather to the son of the other kingdom after his father ceased the kingdom. Both items made the wearer appear to be the most handsome or beautiful person in the kingdom. The fairy became tired of giving magical gifts and so, at the birth of the later uneducated son and the birth of the daughter who was later raised by lions, she gave the wish that the suffer some adversities (and therein lies the moral of the tale). All of the fairies gifts, of course, came true, and therein lies the story.For example, different people secured the ring and feather at different times. Once, an ugly old lady picked up the ring and the uneducated son fell in love with her and promised to marry her, and signed a paper to that effect. But later, when she wasnt wearing the ring, he fell in love with the girl who was raised by the lions. What could he do?Beside the adventures resulting from the ring and the feather, there was the problem of how to rectify the illegal seizure of kingdoms.

I am a fan of Wilkie Collins novels. I join with others in considering his Moonstone and Woman in White as masterpieces. I have enjoyed many of his novels. But I did not like this one very much; and it seems from the works of literary critics, I am not alone in feeling this way. The problem, I think, is that the book moves somewhat slowly in the first couple of hundred pages. However, the book develops into a criminal case based on a real life situation. This part is very interesting. The following is the general plot at the outset of the book.Blind Love is the last of Wilkie Collins books. Actually, he never finished it. He published the beginning parts in serial fashion in a magazine, as was customary in the nineteenth century, but on his death bed, he gave very detailed notes to his friend Walter Besant, including lots of dialogue he planned to insert in the book.  Besant finished the book, but does not reveal where his input began.Three men love Iris. Her rich strong-willed father loves her and wants to protect her, but he insists that she marry Hugh. He tells her that if she marries Lord Harry, she will receive no money from him. He will disinherit her. Hugh loves her dearly, but Iris rejected his proposal several times. Nevertheless, he does not give up and is determined to help her in any way that he can. Hugh is a very honest Englishman. In contrast, Irish Lord Harry was disinherited by his father because, while he is exceptionally charming, he is very impetuous and has been involved in many disreputable adventures. Among others, he gambled all of his money on a horse race and lost it all. He also loves Iris, but there is also another emotion that is driving him. He wants to avenge the murder of his friend; he wants to kill the murderer. It is he that Iris loves blindly. While she knows all of Harrys faults, she overlooks them.There are three other characters that impact upon the above-mentioned four people. Dr. and Mrs. Vimpany do various things that hurt Iris. Dr. Vimpany is a drunk who is interested in obtaining money and willing to do so in a criminal manner. He is the worst villain in this novel. Mrs. Vimpany is a former actress who uses her acting skills to fool people. Iris has a maid with a strange and secret past that has had a strong effect on her life. She is filled with hatred against men and is unpredictable. She is an excellent foil against Mr. Vimpany and is the hero of this story.

Enoch is not part of the Bible. In fact, much of what is in it does not match what is in the Hebrew Bible or the New Testament. It is filled with superstitious ideas. I Enoch was composed sometime around 200 BCE.  The third century was a period of enormous distress for Jews, and the masses, unable to help themselves, sought an explanation for the evil around them and prayed for supernatural aid. Enoch was not unique in differing from mainstream Judaism. The writings of the times did not generally reflect mainstream Jewish thinking and contained many borrowed terms from non-Jewish sources.I Enoch, for example, is the first book that interprets Genesis 6 as a description of fallen angels. It describes a group of angels who descend to earth because of a sexual lust for earthly women. They defile their pure heavenly essence by joining with the women and having children who are giants. They teach their wives and children knowledge that humans should not have, such as the ability to write and the process of performing abortions. Their children befoul the earth and lead to the flood in the days of Noah.

Many individuals of all faiths use the famed biblical and talmudic French rabbi Rashi (1040-1105) to help them understand the Bible. Rashi is a master writer. His commentaries are short, to the point, clarifying, and interesting. People enjoyed his explanations so much that the first Hebrew book printed after the invention of the printing press around 1450 was Rashis Torah commentary in 1475. This book was printed before the printing of the Torah in Hebrew. But, as we will see, the love that most Jews had for Rashi was somewhat like an uneducated peasant who is in love with a princess. Users of Rashis interpretations lose much by not understanding what the authors goal is and how what he says implements his goal. In fact, unless a person understands Rashis methodology, he or she will get the wrong idea what the sage is saying and why he made his comment. There are many scholarly books that address this problem such as Sarah Kumins Rashis Exegetical Categorization: In Respect to the Distinction between Peshat and Derash, and Avraham Grossmans Rashi.Following his five volume Whats Bothering Rashi, composed in English, Rabbi Dr. Avigdor Bonchek has written a short 136 page book, Rashi: The Magic and the Mystery, that addresses what Rashi students need to know. He writes in very readable English, with many examples for everything he explains. He addresses Rashis history, his style, why his explanations are unique, his use of Midrash, what he means when he states he will only address the plain meaning of the text, why his grandson Rashbam disagreed with his methodology, how everyone should question what Rashi is saying, and much more.Bonchek points out that readers should not be fooled by the seemingly simple style of Rashis comments. Rashi was an extremely careful writer. Rashis primary goal was to address a problem he sees in the Torah text and he used a Midrash  in seventy percent of his commentaries  only when what the Midrash states fits in with what he considers the plain meaning of the text.Bonchek states that Rashi does many things. Among much else, Rashi explain difficult passages and seeming contradictions, he helps folks avoid misunderstandings, he sometimes does so by translating familiar words in ways that enhance their meaning, he selects one of the many Midrashim that he feels answers a difficulty that he sees in the text  although he does not reveal what difficulty he sees. When using a Midrash, he may select one that is commenting on another verse and may change the Midrashs wording and he may combine two separate Midrashim, if doing so helps him clarify a passage  for the goal of the Midrash is to teach a moral lesson, while Rashi uses the Midrash to explain a verse. Sometimes he even invents his own Midrash to meet his clarification goal. Sometimes Rashi has two comments one derash and the other peshat, usually because neither one by itself satisfied him in explaining the passage or word.Besides not recognizing what and why Rashi comments as he does, not knowing Rashis style could mislead users of his commentary. For example, Rashi starts every parasha (weekly Torah reading) with lead words containing the name of the parasha for no other reason than to indicate where the parasha begins.  Many do not know that he is doing so, and mistakenly seek a textual difficulty that Rashi is addressing. He also begins each of the five books of the Torah with a comment showing Gods love of Israel and their land. He apparently did so to inspire Jews and teach Torah values. Failure to recognize this, led many individuals to misread what Rashi is doing.In short, Rashi devotees miss what he is doing unless they understand that something is bothering Rashi and that Rashi does not reveal what this is, and fail to discover what that something is, and how Rashi resolves the problem he sees.This book is an excellent clear introduction to Rashis unique interpretative methodology. I had only two problems with it, one minor and one major. The minor one is that Rabbi Dr. Bonchek decided to use the current practice of calling most sages, except Rashi, using the word the, as in the Rashbam, the Ramban, etc. I found this annoying. The other issue is that he did not identify that Rashi is following the methodology of Rabbi Akiva.Two talmudic sages of the second century, Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Ishmael, disagreed on how to interpret the Bible.  Rabbi Akiva, unfortunately in my opinion, won out, and Rashi and most ancient Bible commentators as well as most Midrashim follow his view.  He felt that since the Torah is divine, and since God makes no mistakes, and is able to make an idea clear without any repetition, whenever the Bible repeats itself, the seeming repetition must be understood as Scripture making a new statement, and one needs to ask what is the Torah saying with this seeming repetition? This explains many Rashi comments. Rashi is saying that the seeming repetition or seeming unnecessary extra word, a practice that occurs very frequently in the Torah, is revealing something new. Rashi quotes many Midrashim because they are reflecting the Akiva methodology.In contrast, Rabbi Ishmael taught that the Torah [that was given to humans in a manner that they can understand and therefore] speaks in human language. The frequent repetitions or extra words are used for emphasis and to enhance the beauty of what is said, sometimes giving the statement a near poetic nuance. Maimonides accepted Rabbi Ishmaels method of understanding the Torah, as did Rashis grandson Rashbam, and as do most modern Bible commentators.

This is a funny book with funny pictures, which will cause children to laugh out loud.  It is a take-off on Old MacDonald had a Farm. The pages are filled with clever rhymes and startling colorful pictures. Ma MacDonald has a restaurant on her farm with lots and lots of delicious dishes. The animals also think so, so they get into every dish and are under-foot.  Children will delight seeing and hearing how many different kinds of animals act and the many different kinds of foods.

Children are fascinated by animals. Most of them like to have pets and to visit zoos. This is good not only because it widens the childrens understanding of the world but it also teaches them that every species of animals is different, yet all are interesting, even animals that are dangerous. This teaches kids to extend their understanding of animals to humans. Just as all animals differ, so do all humans, yet everyone should be respected.D. J. Thomas book is a perfect aid to teach children about animals. It offers information about many species and does so in an interesting manner, one that will enchant kids. It describes each breed, tells what the animal eats, what it does during the day and night, how long the animal lives, and other fascinating bits about each animal. It is jam-packed with information. It speaks about elephants, anacondas, chimpanzees, parrots, flying foxes, geckos, gorillas, iguanas, jaguars, cobras, komodo dragons, leopards, and many more.For example, Thomas tells how elephants swim using their trunks and that crocodiles swallow stones to aid them in swimming deeper. Flying foxes have a wing-span of at least six feet in length and cobras eighteen feet long. Iguanas can be seven feet long and can last under water for thirty minutes. The book also defines terms that children should know such as mammals, nocturnal, carnivores, herbivores, and omnivores, and identifies animals that eat and sleep in these ways.

This is an interesting Swedish mystery with Kurt Wallander leading a team of detectives attempting to solve two crimes. While the mood of the story is often gloomy  rain, personal worries, fear that his (Wallanders) girlfriend is seeing another man, illnesses, old age, deaths, needing to give up planned vacations, lack of sleep, Wallanders new boss being unsure of himself  this atmosphere does not detract from the story. It offers readers a more in-depth understanding of characters and the difficulties facing the police. It is true that when I watched the TV versions of several Wallander mysteries which were moody, I was somewhat turned off by the gloom, but I did not have this feeling reading this book or the several other Mankell Wallander mysteries that I read. In fact, I looked forward to reading this book and enjoyed it. It is well written and gripping. One of the mysteries, the smaller one, the one that takes up less police and story time, is the apparent suicide of a young Jamaican girl who showed up in Sweden for unknown reasons, seemed to be afraid of something, went out to a strange field, apparently simply because it was there, poured gasoline in a circle around her and on her, and when Wallander began to approach her, she ignited herself and burned to death. Wallander and his team try to find out why she apparently wanted to commit suicide and why she did it the way she did, for there is just about no more hurtful way to die than to be burned to death. This is why Joan of Arc was burned and why witched were burned, to give them as much pain as possible. The other mystery is what seem to be bizarre serial killings. We are told that the murderer identifies with Herbert Hoover of the American FBI and with the Indian Chief Geronimo, and that he paints his face when he goes out to kill. We are also told that he is seeking revenge for his sister. This is about all we know at the onset of the novel, but the police do not know this. What they do know is that the murders are carefully planned, an ax or hatchet is used, and the victims are scalped. They try to find a connection between the victims but do not find it and they try to delve into the psychology of the murderer but do not see it.

Children need to learn the value of having friends and also learn that the way to do so is to be kind to others. Brandon Cullums clever book with nice drawings and a poetic story teaches these lessons.Alfred is a mean dinosaur. He loves to sneak up on triceratops and velociraptors, other kinds of dinosaurs, and scare them by shouting, Boo! One day, as he was about to do it, his tale got caught in a tree. When he tried to pull it free, he fell and banged his head. Everything went black. Then, although Alfred did not realize it, he was transferred to the future, to a zoo. He saw skeletons of dinosaurs there, but what really bothered him was that boys saw him and laughed. Alfred never saw humans before and he was never laughed at before. Then he met Chloe and the two became friends, and Alfred learnt the value of friendship, just as children who read or hear this tale will do.

Many children worry that they are not brave enough, that others can bully and hurt them. Tammy Brown Elkeles tale about Trinidad will help them develop a sense of confidence. Children love this is kind of adventure story. It is an imaginative tale that children will enjoy for its story and the story will prompt kids to think more of their possible abilities. The pictures in her book are nice, eye catching, and funny. This is one of eight thoughtful, educational, and delightful childrens books that Tammy Brown Elkeles wrote, books that children will relate to and enjoy.This is a tale about Triceratops, dinosaurs with three horns. They are herbivores who do not eat meat. Giant carnivores hate them and have been fighting them for generations and eating them. Trinidads dad is one of the brave fighters among the herbivores. He lost one of his three horns when he fought and beat a giant carnivore. But while all the Triceratops learn to fight to protect themselves and their families, Trinidad does not want to fight. He remains silent in fighting class. His dad and classmates think he is a coward. Trinidad is hurt by what others think of him. But then one day, while the adults are out fighting carnivores, the school is attacked by a huge carnivore and all the youngsters are frightened.Children will be thrilled to hear what Trinidad did and will learn much from hearing about it.

One of the things that parents want to do  or should want to do  is to help children develop their imagination. Tammy Brown Elkeles tale about the snow globe does that. This is the kind of adventure story that children love. It is an imaginative tale that will prompt kids to think of other imaginative adventures. The pictures in her book are nice, eye catching, and funny. This is one of eight thoughtful, educational, and delightful childrens books that Tammy Brown Elkeles wrote, books that children will relate to and enjoy.In this story, two kids, Joe and Nigel are suffering from a hot day and wish they could find some way to cool off. They are also looking for something to play with. They see their dads snow glob, and with the help of their dog Luna, they open the glob and step inside. They are now very small so they can fit in the globe. The three have lots of fun in the snow glob. Among much else, they make a snow bear. Their dad comes into their room and cannot find them because they are so small and inside the globe.Children will delight hearing or reading this tale and will learn how to think.

They aren't kidding when they said 1-lb, about 45-sticks! These guys are GREAT! The bag was STUFFED, came in right at 1-lb, and it is great tasting cinnamon. I cook with cinnamon often, and it is SO MUCH MORE AFFORDABLE to grind your own when you need it, versus paying extortion for stale store-bought pre-ground powder.Can't recommend them enough - OliveNation is great product!

I use a lot of Honeyville products (I'm sure I financed some of their equipment, along the way), and most all of their products are good to excellent, anyway. The butter is great - and really can only compare to their 'powdered shortening' for cooking convenience in a pinch.I've also used their powdered milk to cook with, and to substitute for butter when out, but you can tell the taste, and it is quite-wasteful of the powdered milk.With the powdered butter, just add water to consistency-desired, and either slap it on the toast, or blend it into the recipe. I find that the powdered shortening (just put a teaspoon of it in the skillet as a powder, and fire the skillet up - it melts in the pan) works better to keep food from sticking in a cast iron skillet, but if cooking with the butter, you can't beat the taste. Most, I'd say, couldn't tell it from fresh butter - and if you are making mac-n-cheese from powder, in the field, you need a bit of this and a bit of powdered milk, to mix up your cheese sauce.To keep it fresh, everyone has their 'secret way' to do it - but the CHEAP WAY to keep it dark, fresh and ready, is to (once you open the can), break it down in 1-pint zip lock bags - half-cup to 1-cup to a bag, get the air out, then throw all your bags into the freezer. Now, it will last as long as the can's expiration date said it would - without a vacuum sealer, or other expensive contraption. Just write the date on the zip lock bags with a marker. Now they are dark, dry, air-free, and frozen to prevent bacteria growth! I do this with milk powder, too.Oh, did you know, that if you will hard-freeze (below 0-degrees) corn meal and flour in the freezer this same way, for four days when you get it in the store, it will kill all insect eggs (like weevils, etc.) as well as stop rust and bacteria from reducing it's storage life? After four days, you can take it out and store it in your cool pantry, and it will still keep for up to 2-years!
What more to say? It's a 4-ton pulley block that is well built. If you need one for a winch or come-along, you'll probably need one if you don't have one. This one works.

Great gadget. Add a faucet or a shut-off-valve when you buy it, and you create your own water storage system that can connect to any hosepipe instantly. I actually got this to create an affordable truck-bed water transfer setup, but once I had it, the wife eyed it as a friendly rainbarrel set up for her own uses. Now, there are several laying around here. Good quality, standard threading. Everything you need to put a hosepipe connector on your barrel side, except a drill and drillbit. REMEMBER THOUGH, with this, there is no valve included to shut the water off. You WILL need a valve, if you want to hold water in your tank, and access it on demand.

Well, at any form of comparable food like this, you end up with one of two choices - either Ranchers Cut Freeze-Dried Ground Beef, or Libby's Seasoned Beef Crumbles (vacuum-sealed foil pouch, ready-to-eat).The Rancher's Cut is good - but does take a bit of 'experimentation' to get the water right for the end product, and you do need to season it to taste. The Libby's Seasoned Beef Crumbles is about what you would end up with after cooking your own fresh beef in a skillet and crumbling it. It is seasoned to taste already, and no water required. It comes in a foil pouch you could tear open a bit and boil in a pot of water, if in a hurry.As for cost, The Rancher's Cut FDGB is approximately $10 per pound of ready-to-eat meat (about 10-cups of product in a can, and it takes about 2-cups to make a pound of cooked meat in the end). The Libby's is already 'wet' in the pouch, with a pouch weight of 6-oz per, then two pouches can generally replace a pound of equivalent beef (remember, cookdown on 80/20 beef will NOT leave you with 16 ounces of finished meat), then you are looking at about $5 per pound of ready-to-eat meat from the Libby's Seasoned Beef Crumbles. (I have found the Libby's pouches locally for $2 a pouch - but you may pay higher per pouch, depending on your source).While a big fan of the Honeyville brand in general, I wasn't totally impressed with this product. While good, edible food; price point is a tough one on this item, compared to the alternatives (home jerking of meat, Libby's alternative, and home canning, to name a few). The one upside to the Ranchers Cut FDGB is that it has a shelf-life of approximately 15-years (the advantage of most dried and vacuum-sealed foods), while the Libby's Seasoned Beef Crumbles only has a shelf-life of about 2 years.  Both products have great taste, but the LIbby's is ready for you now, where the Ranchers you have to season for yourself.  Both are perfect consistency to make tacos or sloppy joes or spaghetti sauce with meat, in record time.In the end, it really depends on your pantry plans. I have both, myself - but find that the Libby's is a lot easier to grab and toss in a skillet, in a pinch, than working up the Freeze-Dried stuff. Then again, the Freeze Dried stuff can last a LONG time, so buy a can, set it back, and forget it until you need it.  Overall, I gave it a 4-star rating, due to the high price being almost double of it's competitor.

First off, these are real NSN-numbered mil-spec goggles. These are the same ones I used when in the Marines. I have two of them now (one for my wife, one for me) to use outdoors (you have to live in the Desert Southwest to understand why you need these if you are out in the 'sand'.)That said, I have bought a dozen goggles - from DeWalt construction types, to RZ ATV sport goggles, and even tried dive masks. Nothing, NOTHING out performs these goggles. Here's why:These goggles are made of very soft rubber. The lenses are a polycarbonate piece that can be removed and replaced.  The box comes with the clear lens AND a sunshade lens. You change them by unsnapping two buttons and swapping them in less than a minute. The head-size is adjusted by a simple bunji-type strap (like you find on dive goggles), just put them on your head, and adjust to size. They will fit anyone from a hat-size of 6 up to 8+.As for why they are so great? They have a foam-rubber seal that circles the mask, and vent-holes to prevent fogging that still filter through the 'foam' interior strip. You might feel wind, but you don't get dust in your eyes! I've used them in 100-mph straight-line winds with sandstorms towering 2-miles above the surface - and they work. PERIOD! You can't say anything better about good gear, than it is comfortable to wear, doesn't negatively affect your eyesight range, and that THEY WORK.As for some who say 'the seal leaks', I say 'tighten the straps, you don't understand how to fit a pair of goggles correctly'. People, this isn't casual eye wear. You have to fit them properly for them to work properly. I guess it takes fitting a military gas mask to ensure a proper seal on your face, to understand how to get a seal on protective wear. You aren't slumming on the block when you wear these, you are protecting your eyes. This does NOT mean you have to cinch them down until blood stops flowing, to ensure a good seal, but you can't just throw them on 'with nary a contact point' and expect them to seal, either.As for head-and-face shape and size, related to fitting? They are highly flexible for narrow faces (like smaller people - hey, even my wife has) and for those with larger or broader faces (I wear a 7-3/4 hat size - and they fit me fine too). They are relatively flat when you get them, only a small curve - you get face-fit by fitting them to your head with the retaining strap. The thing that takes the longest to fit these initially, is getting your strap right. Once you have fitted them, you won't have to do it again, the strap is an elastic that will let you stretch it a bit, to take them off without further adjustment.I have had 6-pairs of these over the years. I have NEVER had a bad pair of them, they always fit, they always seal. The lenses are polycarbonate, and can be scratched. That said, they also come with a protective film over them. I recommend leaving it if it has no air bubbles in it. Personally, I have used a single sheet of Saran Wrap over the outer side of the lens before installing it into the rubber frame, to protect the polycarbonate (a lot cheaper to replace Saran Wrap cover, than to replace the lenses). Think of it as 'not convenient tear-offs that don't tear off'.They may look 'uncool', they may not be all chromed out or stylish, but I wouldn't take anything for my dust goggles. Then again, I'd rather use a white 3M N95 respirator mask (for $1 each) and a bandana to cover it, than to pay $20 or more for a pretty toy mask that you constantly have to replace filters on, because it's cool with its little camouflage paint job, too.In the real world, function trumps 'pretty', anyday.

When these kit-legs came out a few years ago, I bought a set. The first ones weren't so hot, the resin-plastic wasn't formulated right. I bought another set last year, and the resin is good stuff now - about like your top-end plastic resin tool boxes (sun doesn't affect it, nor does cold or age, it seems). For a fast kit if you have the wood laying around to finish it off, it is great (also makes a 'take-down-workbench' possible, that you can transport fairly easily).That said, the kit used to be about $20, and 'acceptable' compared to alternatives. Now, at $60, I have to say, it has priced itself out of the market. Consider, that all it takes to actually make a workbench is 4 legs, which can be made my cutting a 2x4 in half and miter-joining them together with some long sheetrock screws. You can make all four legs in less than an hour if your tools are handy, for about 1/6th of the price of this simple leg kit. Sorry, but I don't see the value in paying 600-percent more for these plastic legs over an all-wood table. If you got fancy, and have a table saw, you actually could even miter-cut the 2x4's for the legs, and make a frame-joint to clean it all up. Make them in 2x6's and double their strength, still for half-the-cost.Sorry, looks neat, seems awesome, but you just can't get past that price-point. If you are able to build a table from this kit, you most likely can also build the legs from wood too.  I gave this 3-stars because of the concept and decent product, but they lose 2-stars for super-over-the-top price.

Always hate those review where someone hasn't tried it yet. This isn't one of those reviews.We purchased our Texsport Camouflage Square Dome Tent (that's what they named it when we bought it) back in mid-2009, and set it up in the backyard to inspect it (before going out and getting caught off-guard with it later).  This tent is roomy for a 9x9' tent. Good head height. For me and my husband, lots of good room and space, even with out cots set up. Fly fit good, poles were the shock-rod flex poles, easy enough, and the bottom is a traditional polypropylene 'bathtub' structure, while the upper is basically a coated nylon taffeta that water-repels excellently.We took it down, packed it up, and about 2-weeks later, headed out. We took a trip to a local state park that has a significant wilderness area, and we packed in and stayed for over a week. It rained two of those nights, one significantly. Since we had packed in, we didn't have our cots - just bedrolls with polarfleece and wool blankets and this tent. All went well, the door zipper has an excellent rain fly over it,  the material kept all water out, and we found one small drip point on a seam that let in a few drops of water. No problem that a wax stick won't fix. Done.At the end of our trip, it had fared well, nothing broken, nothing damaged, and we found the one tiny leak point and waxed it.  Our next trip was about a month later, this time 'pickup truck pack-in', for a 2-week stay on a remote property we own. This time, while all went well, we did, unfortunately manage to break one of the black plastic 'snap-on' corner clips in half. It still covered well, but it flapped against the dome pole pretty bad, so we 'chip-clipped' it for the moment to stop wind noise on it. We also had heavy rain a couple of times, once with wind. On the 'wind and rain' night, it was blowing quite hard, and we managed to get a couple of gusts that lofted a little rain under one of the gazebo ends on the fly, which fell through the mesh top into the center of the tent. My guess, it was about 35-mph wind and VERY large, heavy raindrops. (about the same effect if you took a cup of water, and splashed it up under the eave aiming for the tent's roof mesh.The floor tub was excellent, no leaks, again.No troubles with the zippers, the screen mesh is excellent and holds out bugs well, even tiny no-see-ums (very important where we often go to). We do set it up on a 'floor tarp' to keep ground rocks from cutting the tent tub, of course. Inside it has an excellent 'lamp offering' up at the top, so you can hang small battery-powered tent lamps. The rain fly is simple, and quite ingenious. The only negative I could mention, is that in rainy times, it can be a mosquito habitat if you aren't careful. A quick metal chafing dish with a mosquito coil inside the tent can fix that issue, though (careful of sparks and fire, as always). It comes with everything you need but that extra ground-tarp (don't know of any tent that comes with that, though they all should).We've used our tent now for over 52 days of total camping, in all seasons. It has held up EXCELLENTLY. I've seen 'two outing' tents that don't look as good as this still does! Zippers still good, got one little wear place in the tub on a corner where a 'stake pull' is located at that I need to sew up before our next outing - haven't got to that yet, but other than the hole, it still hasn't pulled out!NOBODY makes a better tent for the money. I've seen $600 canvas tents show more damage for less wear-time. If you want a good, solid tent, that packs well (at about 12-pounds, it CAN be backpacked if in a small group), wears excellent, has good water repellency, and is VERY SOLID AND STABLE in wind and weather, choose this one.  Best of all, IT ISN'T PSYCHO-TECNO-COLORED! (I remember when tents were beige, and green, and brown and earthy tones - since when did everyone feel it necessary to make their tents look like CARNIVAL CANDY?! The color is what got me to buy it 5-years ago, the quality guaranteed I will replace it with this same model, when I replace it.

Wow, lots of goods-and-bads on this product. Rumor has it, there are refills for it. Bad news, I haven't actually seen them or been able to get ahold of them. You can of course, mold or form your own 'replacement' candle to fit it - but in the end, is it really worth it?As for repelling mosquitoes, well - it kinda does. If you are dealing with the little guys that you see in some backyards, maybe in Europe, hey, seems to work. If you think that this toy is going to repel those gigantic Philippine Tiger Stripe monsters, FORGET IT. They will land on this thing, while it is lit, freebase the fumes, and go on a snarfing munchie spree looking for the nearest vein to pop - ON YOU.This apparently does not work on the Tiger Stripes, and another reviewer has already mentioned that too. The only thing I have found that can keep them off you is actual DEET sprays or heavy lemongrass scent integrated into a citronella smoker. This citronella candle? Forget it, I can't tell if they just don't care, or if the Tiger Stripe mosquitoes are lured to it.  We have a marsh nearby our home, and after taking this out to it (while in my best head bugnet, and long-sleeve shirt and pants), tried this and a dozen other candles and wick burners. The wick burners were the only 'light it and forget it' that could even begin to get the Tiger Stripes away, and any personal spray with 50-percent or more DEET in it.Overall, I rate this 3-stars. It DOES work on little black flies, no-see-ums and regular mosquitoes. This of course, doesn't help if your bug-mix also includes the new adder to America, the Philippine Tiger Stripe mosquito. They are going to have to reformulate to repel these behemoths.

Not a 'just bought it review', I've got several of these, and have used them for years. You cannot beat these little lanterns! About 5-years ago, I saw one of these on a shelf in Wal-Mart for $9, on clearance, so I bought it on a whim. Got it home, fired it up that night, and was quite surprised at the amount of light it put out! Compared to a candle lantern, you are talking anywhere from 2-5 times the light of an average candle lantern. In a 12x12 room, or most tents, it is ample light to get around, read a book, find stuff, etc. easily. NOTE: This is NOT a 1000-lumen Coleman White Gas Lantern! You are NOT going to get 'office lighting' level of light out of this. To expect that amount of light out of 3-AA batteries and a few LED Elements is more than a 'touch' of over-expectation. Be for real, this is not a flashlight, it is a lantern with a reflector panel that can drop, or be raised, on one of it's 'triangular' plastic 3 sides. This helps to 'not blind you' when reading, or carrying it in front of you to see your way in the dark. Again, this replaces the need for candles, small oil lamps, tea candle lanterns, survival candle lanterns, etc. IT IS NOT a LARGE LANTERN REPLACEMENT. (you do not buy a half-ton pickup truck expecting to hook-up-to, and haul tractor-trailer loads, and you don't put a ton of cargo into your car. Don't expect unrealistic things from your lantern, either).As for battery life, it is so very hard to address this. The ad says 'up to 125-hours of battery life per replacement', but I killed one set of batteries by leaving the lantern on when in my backpack, once. Another time, I can only guess at how long I used it before the batteries 'got tired', but I'd guess an easy 80-90 hours of pretty-demanding use. I now use rechargeables in it (Eneloops), so with one of these lanterns, the Eneloops, a solar battery charger - hey, this thing is more 'renewable' than a candle lantern! I keep it and a 4-pack of charged Eneloops in my backpack, and never worry about 'no tent light' when camping, EVER.It works great camping (it has a fold-up hanging loop on top, great for some paracord to hang it in the top of your tent, on a tree limb nearby, or fold the loop down and just set it on your kitchen table during a power outage. Simple 'ON', 'OFF' function, no bells-and-whistles, bottom trap-door easily opens to a carrier that holds the three 'AA' batteries (make sure to align the contacts with the carrier and the lantern, when you replace batteries). I haven't had one of my lanterns fail to work yet - and combined, probably have 1100 hours of use on them all. I keep one in my backpack, one in the RV, and one in the kitchen drawer in event of power outage. Knowing where it is, enables me to turn it on, sit it on the table, and begin my hunt for other flashlights, batteries, breakers, etc.Best thing Coleman has come out with in years. It's only a shame that the other new stuff they have come out with recently doesn't measure up to this little guy.

Five years ago, my wife and I planned on taking a late-fall extended camp trip, and needed some bags that we could actually stand to be comfortable in if it got COLD. We found the Teton Sports XL bags (single size, not the Queen size) rated to -20F, and for about $85 at the time, bought two of them. We took them to the primitive cabin we were going to be staying at, and after some major problems with the wood stove that first night, found the outside thermometer at the cabin saying that the temperature on the front porch was -4F that next morning. I never woke up, I was that comfortable inside. Temp inside had to be less than 10F. That one morning sold me on Teton bags, forevermore.They are super-quilted, love that flannel lining, and the cold-collar-tube, zipper over-cover inside, and the extra collar length at the head all give you the comfort of a square bag, while sealing you up like as if you were in a mummy bag. I have really bad 'cold feet', and after tossing my Zippo hand warmer down into the feet of the bag, had no problem staying 'toasty, all over'. You'd expect to pay a lot more for Teton's quality - and most who never find them, probably do. I've seen $200 bags that can't outperform them. We went back and bought the 'queen size' bag, just for that 'comfort' perspective. The cabin has a 'rope bed frame', and after some 'deep woods engineering', figured out how to comfortably under-support the bags while they are laid on top of that rope frame bed. It's better than being at home!I can't say enough about the Teton bags - buy one, try it out, and you most certainly will be sold after that.

What a joke, 23F/-5C comfort rating? Only if you have the coat of a polar bear already on you. Seriously, a comfort rating is designed to tell you what MOST PEOPLE would find tolerable to camp in. While there is a lot of leeway in a 'comfort rating', it is understood to be what you can 'tolerate' and 'sleep through' for 6-7 hours, without chill causing you to wake, or you to lose core temperature at. Sure, some people have colder feet than others, some have poor circulation, the rating is for 'the 95th percentile', and sadly, no one enforces actual gear ratings. If they did, you'd suddenly see most of the junk like this rated much, much higher. In reality, this is a 'slumber party bag' good for 55F/13C, approximately. Think of it as a thick sheet, at best. For anyone that works for the company that makes this thing, shame on you. You should be made to strip bare, get spritzed with water mist, and made to get in this toy while it's 23F outside and forced to stay there for 7-hours. Uncomfortable? What a joke - you'd be a frozen fishstick in an hour. Don't plan on actually camping in this toy if it isn't July and south of 45-degrees north latitude below 5000 ft elevation. If you actually want a decent 'couples' sleeping bag that can actually give you comfort at 23F, look at the Teton bags. I have three of them, two of which are rated to -20F, and I have actually had a good night's sleep at 0-F in them several times. Cost is actually affordable for them, too. Expect to pay $80-$100, minimum, for a true 20F single bag, $100-$120 for a 20F couples bag. Anything less, and expect used, damaged, or lies. That's just how it works.

First off, this is a serious design copy from the MSR International model of white-gas-stoves. This is one of the first reasons I stopped and looked at it, the concept of my beloved MSR International in a gas version, neat. I picked one up for $15 after reading that it was a 'dual fuel' (butane/propane) gas stove. If it works, can't go wrong, right? Or, so I thought. Well, get it home, open it up, and find out that it is Butane-only out of the box. You have to buy the EXTRA adapter ($8 to $25, depending on mfg) to use the 16-oz propane cylinders with this stove. No free lunches, still, I guess. Maybe that should have ALSO been mentioned in the hype on the box (must have been small-print, like 'batteries not included', but I digress).Well, once I went and bought an adapter for $12 (stove price now at $27, total), I put it all together, screw on a propane tank, light it up - and find that the 'fine adjustment' is either 'overly touchy', or I am just a brute with a fuel valve. I believe the first is more true than the later, as it takes a FINE TOUCH to 'get down to a simmer' without turning it off. Oh well, maybe it behaves better on Butane than propane? Anyway - took it camping (with my MSR fully fueled and with me, as a KNOWN DEPENDABLE BACK UP). I then realized what someone else mentioned - no generator - the little tube gizmo that normally runs across the fire to warm the fuel so it doesn't spit and sputter in cold weather. Guess what: IT SPITS PRETTY BAD in cold weather, and if you aren't careful, and you cook near your tent, your gear, or your clothes, you might just end up on fire to find out first hand what benefits a generator gives you in a stove.Anyway, I packed it up, pulled out my MSR International, and was content to have safe fire without firebomb threat.  As always, you get what you pay for. If you are going to break down and chunk Butane canisters at this beast while it's 70-F outside, enjoy. I wish you luck, and speedy healing. I'll stick with my MSR International White Gas (actually, it is a real dual fuel, but who's counting, right?).I gave this 2 stars because it is actually well-built, and with a few 'polishing points', I would have thought MSR built this - the quality is quite good. That said, MSR would have added a generator, a bottle adapter, better instructions, and probably around $75 to the cost. I just couldn't take this stove to 3-stars, when it advertises butane OR propane, then doesn't give you the adapter they KNOW has to be used to use either fuel. I'd rather they charged me $27 up front, with the adapter, than $15 and leave me trying to find the adapter in the discarded packaging for 2 hours, before realizing that it wasn't there to begin with.

I have one of these Texsport cots (and a lot of other Texsport camping gear). As most Texsport stuff, it is good, as long as you don't try to compare it to the top-end mil-spec stuff. Keep in mind, the real Mil-Spec cot that's been in use for the past 40-years is rated to 1200-pounds (and new, the military paid over $250 for them, each)!As for a good, general cot to get 98-percent of all people off the ground, comfortable, with a rubber mat and sleeping bag laid out on it, you cannot beat this for $60, new. I have two old mil-spec cots (which are near-impossible to get both bars in, after years of age and shrinkage), and the tautness and stability are similar. But, when you go to pick them up, you can tell by the near-double weight, which one is which. Like looking at a half-ton pickup versus a 1-ton pickup - they kinda look alike, but there is a lot of difference in the muscle they each have.I take the mil-spec cot - and it is a head banger, since end-to-end, it's only about 75-inches long. These Texsport cots are about 10-inches longer, and you can feel that added length by not bashing your head on an end-bar. My wife, though short, loves both cots - and can sleep comfortably on both. At 6'2", I like the general feel of the Texsport better - but like the tighter feel of the mil-spec (were it not for the head-bar).Overall, I give the Texsport a 4-star rating. This is better than any other cot I have seen or used, except the mil-spec cots. Most cots, for big guys, just don't hold up past 3-4 uses. So far, I have yet to break a Texsport King Kot. The price is good for the features, and obviously, Texsport is what Coleman once was (and is no longer). That said, I'd easily recommend the Texsport cot to anyone looking to 'move up' to a tent cot, or just looking to get a good cot and can't locate a mil-spec one.

I had the unfortunate luck to have a family member buy this $180 monster and ask me to join them to test it out. That, and by accepting for me and my husband, set myself up for the following harbinger of complaints that came later (he greatly dislikes Coleman products, stating that they no longer make good camping gear, just cheap Chinese junk that is priced excessively and performs poorly). Here's how this nightmare went:We joined family on a quickly-planned camping trip. Weather was supposed to be clear that weekend, so we just grabbed essentials (folding table, two chairs, sleeping bags, a lantern and fishing gear) and were told that due to 'breaking in their new giant Coleman tent, we had all the tent we would need.' Ok, great, less to pack. Great weather ahead, remember?Well, after running late, can't find anyone selling ice, can't find our food cooler, and a mass run on gasoline for some unknown reason at the local quick store, we took off, and arrived at our family's start point - their front yard. Another two hours to help them load the truck, and now we're all starting to gripe. Another hour-and-a-half, and we are lakeside, about to get dark, and we are rushing to get the lanterns lit, tables set up, and we get the 'advertisement' perspective on the quick 1-min tent setup. Ok, doubtful, my husband jeers as it actually goes up in about 90-seconds. Ok, he's impressed enough to quit inciting family uprising for a moment. We get the bags laid out - and he's complaining about 'where's the tent fly', that's when we learn 'Coleman says this tent doesn't actually require a rain fly'. OMG, the laughter and picking starts up again. So, he quits jabbing about the tent fly, and says 'well, at least with no rain in the forecast, hopefully we won't get to test that claim'. Less than 4-hours later, around midnight, the bottom falls out.IT rained from midnight until mid-day the next day. rain isn't really the word for it, it was more like living under the sea at points. Big, slow, heavy drops - until the air was 100-percent saturated. It only took about 2-hours of high humidity, and we saw the first water pooling in the corners. We hadn't brought cots - running late, of course, so rubber mats were all that was between us and that bathtub floor. Sheer genius design - let the roof and walls be porous enough to be cotton muslin soaking water up, and make the floor waterproof bathtub. Genius. (these were my husband's first words, that very soon, we all were repeating). Water was EVERYWHERE. The inside walls were wet, the door material, the floor, the zippers were allowing soak-thru, the seams likewise. It was like the thing was made of cotton sheets - AND THE WATER WOULDN'T STOP. The absence of a rain fly doubled the misery, as the ceiling was dripping and draping down now, too.We were bailing by sunrise - the air was cold, down to about 50-F, and it was still raining on top of it all. We didn't even have a direction to go to stop the misery, except to pack all the wet up and leave. We packed in the rain, rolled the soaking mop of 200-pounds of tent into an unidentifiable ball, threw it in the truck, along with the 50-pound soaked sleeping bags, grabbed the chairs, tables, etc., and tossed them in as well, and left. We arrived home about the time the rain was letting up.Bad luck? Well, you can't guarantee weather. HOWEVER, you would have been dryer by just sitting under a juniper tree than fooling with this miserable tent failure. Whatever material they CLAIM this tent is made of, clearly WATERPROOF should NEVER enter your mind as an assumption. This thing was miserable. Even a walled canvas tent would have been a thousand times better, at least the water runs off canvas! This thing acted like a sponge, one direction for water flow, INWARDS!The insanity of a tent without water repellency is insane. No rain fly is insane. If you plan on buying and using this thing anywhere that you have 1-percent or more chance of rain, FORGET IT. This nightmare should be labeled 'FOR USE IN SAHARA DESERT, ONLY'. Paying $180 for this tent, another $40 for the rainfly, and then having to buy $40 in Scotchguard just to semi-water-proof it is beyond contemptable - it is downright PROOF that Coleman has NO IDEA what their products are supposed to be used for.Buy any other brand of tent but this one - clearly, Coleman is too busy counting your money to worry about designing your products properly.

I have two of these tarps in my camping/survival gear packs for me and my wife. Hers is still in it's wrapper, but I took mine out to inspect it when I bought it 4-years ago.
