It is on-size at 10x12, and is approx. 10-mils thick. Good Poly tarp with decent grommets. The back-side of mine is 'unprinted' olive-drab color, so a 'wind flip' won't have you staring at a 'white' or blank reverse. As with most heavier PE tarps, you can use them for ground cover under your tent, or even as an emergency tent, itself. The only reason I gave it 4-stars instead of 5 is that when I bought my first two, they were $7.99 each, now they are almost TRIPLE that. Ouch, pricey now. I was going to buy two more and put them back, but at that price, I guess I'll just hold off for now. I love the Texsport gear, and have quite a bit of it (tents, stainless cups, plates, tarps, etc.) but that is a real premium on a PE tarp, just for the sake of that camo print - forget it, I'll just buy an olive drab one.

I've used about everything known to mankind, at some point, to keep feet and hands warm. I've always been one to nearly live outdoors anyway. I've tried battery powered stuff, snap-click chemical warmers, the 'rip open' disposable iron-powder warmers, and of course, the old 'solid fuel stick' hand warmers (the red velvet ones, for those who know what I am talking about). NONE COMPARE, and I only wish I had started out using a ZIPPO hand warmer to start with - maybe I'd have learned my lesson quicker.My wife gave me my ZIPPO Hand Warmer for a gift a few years ago, when I had lost my old 'stinky' solid fuel one. I always hated it due to the atrocious smell it makes when lit, but it was fairly dependable for that 2-3 hour 'warm pocket' in even the coldest days. The problem is, well, it stunk a lot, and using it hunting probably kills your chances of not being noticed by at least 50-percent. So, I figured I'd try this warmer instead. My two greatest fears (having used zippo lighters for years) was 'chemical burn' in my pocket from the fuel, and the potential for 'smelling' the lighter fluid (since it uses the same fuel as any zippo or other fuel-type naptha lighter). Well, after a few 'tanks full' of fuel, I found nothing was further from the truth.After you get used to filling it (don't lose the little filler tank that comes with it - can't beat the little 'plastic measuring cup' function for putting just the right amount of fuel into it each time), just fill it, put the catalyst cap back on top (once you puil the two halves apart, there's a little 'button catalyst' that just pulls off, under which is a giant cotton bed for the fuel to be poured), then use a normal lighter of any kind to 'warm and light' the catalyst top, then put the two halves back together. Takes all of 30-seconds if you have your little filler tank ready to pour. I average around 4-5 hours of 'good burn' time, and while it gets toasty, it never gets so hot as to burn you or your clothes. It doesn't smell like a lighter either, once it's going, and I've never had 'naptha burn' like you can get with a lighter when it's in your pocket.Over the past few years, I've learned all sorts of tricks to use it for, too. Like when you are camping, and it's cold outside (I hunt in the winter months), you can fill it up right before bed, toss it into the toe-area of your sleeping bag, and you will have toasty feet all night long! I found out during a long camping trip, that in a 'OMG, I'm out of fuel' that Napthalene, aka Coleman Fuel, will also power this great tool - at least well enough not to hurt it, and to get you through a tough night when you need to stay warm.It is superb quality, as most all Zippo stuff is anyhow, and I wouldn't take ANYTHING for mine, period. Like a Harley, or a Jeep, you can get lots of good stuff for it too, like the metal 'emergency ration' keychain fobs for that 'last dose of fuel' moment, you can get carry cases, and of course, you can get replacement platinum Zippo Catalyst buttons too (though I have used mine a LOT, and have to say, I can't imagine the thing needing a replacement catalyst button - but I guess like Zippo lighter wicks, they must apparently burn out in time - or they wouldn't sell replacements, right?)Don't look at another handwarmer, until you buy one of these first - They really are 'an essential piece' of survival gear, right beside a good knife and stainless steel cup.

I am a real purist normally about metal fittings. Problem is, they have gotten so junky as of late, that the metal ones leak horribly too. Having worked with a lot of indoor PEX plumbing lately, I've dealt with some indoor plumbing fittings called 'Sharkbites', that are expensive, but wonderful about no-leaks, and durable. I thought, 'man, that would be great to find something like those for hosepipe'. Well, they aren't metal, but these Nelson fittings are 'sharkbites' for hosepipe. They have fingers inside that bite and grip the hose, and the clamp down is solid and secure. I have three of them in operation, one is often under pressures approaching 70-psi, and it has held up for a year with no problems and constant pressure. I am a believer! Not a single drop of water leaked since I started using them. I can't say enough good about them. Once you cut and square your old hose pipe end with a knife or cutoff tool, you don't need tools to put these on, they just press-on, and hand tighten down, right there. No clamping, no wrenches, no screwdrivers, you just tighten them and you are like new again. You can get Male, Female and hose-to-hose joints. I picked up a bunch more, once I saw how good they worked. Can't afford not to have a few in your toolbox at all times!

Normally, my wife and I buy the brass Camco water pressure regulators for our RV. If you have ever camped in an RV campsite, you know how the water pressure is - either NO pressure, or enough to carve your initials into steel plate with. Unfortunately, due to heavy salts, iron, etc. in the water at campsites, these regulators normally die after an average year of camping hard. As a result, you have to replace them. Well, this year, we thought we'd save a couple of bucks and buy the Camco plastic pressure regulators shown here. We picked up two of them, and put the first one on. Now mind you, we live in the desert, and it was probably 105-degrees F when I put this one on, in a campsite where the water pressure normally runs 70-psi, anyhow. It took less than a minute, and the blue plastic of the housing softened and the whole pressure regulator blew off the faucet! I tried it again, and within a minute, it did it again. No problem, I thought, just a bad one, let me get the other one and put it on. As soon as I swapped them and turned the water on, it leaked like a sieve. I tightened it to try and get it to stop, and when I had it down to barely a drip, THIS ONE BLEW OFF THE FAUCET, TOO. Sorry, but a pressure regulator that can't stand up to the high side pressure isn't much of a pressure regulator. As always, you get what you pay for. I searched around town, bought two brass regulators, and said forget it, I won't do the junky plastic ones again. BUYER BEWARE, they are NOT durable against any significant pressures.

I picked this up for a .22 LR rifle I have that had a broken older tasco scope on it. I've used Tasco's for years for rimfire, so I'm not a stranger on what to expect from them. This scope is very comparable to most they've ever sold, and the 3x7 variable is a nice 'add on' to the old fixed 4x scopes of past years.When it came in, before ever mounting it, I eyed through it - it is a duplex reticle (thick lines on the outside, fine wires at the cross-point). It didn't mention duplex reticle in the ad, but since most 30/30's are duplex, no big deal there. (for those that don't know, a 30/30 reticle gives you a measure of 30-inches at 100-yards when set at 4x, so you can use it to rangefind on known-distance or known-sized objects). Anyway, the reason for my 4-star instead of 5-star rating? Even though the objective and ocular lenses are round, just like in the picture in this offering, the actual reticle is TV shaped (again, another obscure feature from Tasco from back in the 1970's where the reticle isn't round, it is basically 'oval-shaped' with a 'wide-angle' field of view - something I personally don't care for). Since they didn't mention 'TV' or 'Wide Angle' as a scope feature, I kind of felt misled in the product description. I actually thought they had quit making this reticle form-factor. It seems they have not. It is a decent scope, holds a decent zero on a .22 LR, and the 30/30 feature is quite accurate. Overall, a solid 4-star scope for $20, and should work FINE on any air rifle or rimfire you have.

Love my Griffin USB micro, but I can't address the 'knock-off' complaint that several have mentioned. Mine is a true Griffin, and it works wonderfully. I can charge my Motorola phone on it, and can also use a standard mini-USB cable to power my Garmin through it, too, if I need to. It puts out 1-amp, per port, and have had it for 2+ years now without a fault. Now, keep in mind, it IS a nightmare to get out of your cigarette lighter socket, because of it's flush mount - so if you smoke, this might be an issue to you. I stopped smoking years ago, but have lots of tech gadgets that benefit from this in my car, so no loss, all good, in my book.

Don't believe the ad statement 'heavy duty cord' translates into 'heavy duty' anything, other than maybe rubber insulation. THIS IS FOR LOW-POWER ITEMS ONLY!!! It is 20-AWG wire inside, barely enough wire diameter to run a 5-watt speaker. If you think you are going to plug in a tire inflator, a 1,000,000 candle spotlight, etc., you are SADLY MISTAKEN. This is NOT, repeat NOT heavy duty. It is a crime that the wire AWG (American Wire Gauge) is not listed in the specs. Otherwise, you would know that plugging in a heavy amperage load is either going to burn this up in a split second, or turn it into a heater coil and set your car on fire when you try. If you want to charge a cell phone, an iPad, etc. on it, go ahead, no problem. But the problem is, most people buy an extension cord for a cigarette lighter to do something with a heavy amp load outside of the vehicle. This WILL NOT support a heavy amp load.

Perfect size for a half-cup or so of peppercorn. It fits in your hand nicely, and works well - but the inside finish is rather rough, rougher than I thought it would be. Still nice, but that inside finish still concerns me, don't know if bits of marble are going to come off in my pepper, or not.

The LARGE LC-1 ALICE pack is an absolutely excellent backpack system, bar none. Read the description carefully, LARGE, because the one that most troops was ever issued was MEDIUM, not LARGE. What's the difference? About DOUBLE the pack capacity on the same aluminum frame and strapping. I have loaded mine to 134-lbs before, with everything inside the nylon. The MEDIUM has three external pockets and webbing for ALICE clips to tie gear onto. The LARGE pack has three LARGE lower pockets, and three smaller TOP pockets on the outside, for a total count of six external pockets, plus lots of strapping. The main compartment is almost twice as large as the MEDIUM, too, and you still have the unvelcro top flap to put maps, the 'against-your-back' T-shirt pouch, etc. Your old 'waterproof bags' will still line this one too, but it's quite a stretch. There is NO WAY you can out-haul this bag. This thing is big, it's mean, it's Marine-Corps-built in toughness, and if you aren't careful, it will surely hurt you it can haul so much. I have two, one MEDIUM and one LARGE, so we can both go camping - and let me tell you, both packed, the MEDIUM looks like kinder-care, just based on size, when they are staged next to each other. Forget the MEDIUM's, and if you can get a LARGE for this price, and think you can hump 100+ pounds (or want to put the great dane in with your gear for fun), this is the pack you want.

For most who have bought a new Coleman lantern in the past 20 years, and it's a 'greenie', then chances are very high that you have either the model 286 or 288 (286 is one-mantle, 288 is 2-mantles). This globe fits both, legitimately (per Coleman), but when you put it onto the 288, it will seem 'a bit small, but functional'. That's because the 288's (at least mine, until I broke my globe) had about 1/8" greater globe diameter. Still works, still safe, but you'll 'notice the difference'. How do I know? Because I moved and BROKE 3 GLOBES on 3 of my lanterns (still don't know how I broke the one in it's own carry case!). Anyway, if you are like me, and broke more than one, there are deals on 'bulk globes' on Amazon too (5-packs). You can normally score these locally for $12, but if you can't, then watch the shipping fees - they are all over the board, depending on the vendor - from free to $10 per globe shipping. In the end, it is the right globe, just be careful of the pricing.

Great Lantern - if you understand the difference between White Gas and Kerosene. First off, this is a one-mantle lantern, not two, like the White Gas or Coleman Fuel models, so light is around half as bright. Secondly, the Kerosene used in this is NOT interchangeable with White Gas lanterns at all ('White Gas' or Napthalene, aka Coleman Fuel is much closer to Naptha or lighter fluid than it is Kerosene). Secondly, Kerosene lanterns require a little more post-use maintenance, as Kerosene tends to hold water in the fuel that will cause your fuel tank, tubes and generator to 'rust out' easier - gotta keep them clean to make them work right. If you are looking for a one-fuel lighting answer for a survival situation, this IS THE LANTERN you want, period. Take this, a Kerosun heater, a few hurricane indoor lamps, and you have lighting and indoor heating solved. All you need is some firewood and a 55-gallon barrel of kero to get you through it all. If you are planning for camping, fishing, etc., then you might prefer their White Gas models, or dual-fuel models. For a kero lantern, this is a good lantern, however.

I am so old, I remember when it came on TV originally. It was, at the time, an amazing show. We talked about it at work for a week afterward (gotta keep in mind, Jaws came out about 6-months earlier, and it headlined at cinemas for over 100-weeks, back then, and Star Wars hadn't been heard of yet). We were amazed that Richard Boone would do a 'creature feature' like this, it really wasn't his style overall. His acting is the powerhouse that sells this show. I went back and watched it a week ago, yes, the CGI wasn't CGI back then, it was rubber suits and Ray Harryhausen's claymation. The actors actually had to get dirty, the costumes are of the era, but the story is still complex, from a time when you actually had complex themes still in movies that the actors had to sell ALL of to make a good show. It is almost two movies in one, it is 'Armageddon' (getting to the dinoland with the Polar Explorer) and Jurrassic Park (OMG the dinos are going to kill us), put together. Yes, it would look great in today's films with CGI 'real life' dinosaurs, a $200-million budget, real-location filming, maybe some real dino-cloning to boot. Since none of that has, or is going to happen, I guess you'll have to watch this EXCELLENT old movie that set the actual genre for 'Jurassic Films' way before it's time, if you want to see a good story with 'at the time', best-resources available. Oh, and FYI, it was NOT a 'B-Movie' when it came out. Being 17 now, spoiled to 'Transformers' doesn't make this any less than the great movie it was then, it just makes it 'a period movie' that shows some of it's age.

I had this video for years in VHS format, loved it. Would dust it off and play it about once a year. Though I have lived in some really rough 'lower 48' wilderness, I was truly amazed at the resourcefulness and strength of those who were shown in this excellent documentary. Sadly, almost all shown in the video have left the 'bush' for 'civilization', except for Heimo and his wife. There is a 'VICE' documentary on YouTube done in 2011 that kinda follows up to this documentary, but shows only Heimo and his wife 15-years later. It is a real shame that ANWAR and the Dept. of the Interior won't auction the old 'homesteads' off to a new generation willing to 'walk in Heimo's shoes' - but it appears they are gong to lock up ANWAR and cold-storage it for scientists and rich expedition travelers, instead. Such a shame, and lost heritage. If you like the wild, and Alaska, if you watch nothing else but this one documentary, watch it. This is the one you will remember.

Not really sure if everyone else received junk, or if they are just China-bashing again. Oh, well. I have this saw, it stays with my backpack all the time, and has been heavily used in hunting and camping trips for several years. Yes, it is made in China. Yes, it does appear 'flimsy' (hence it being a 'light, tubular design'). The rivet by the tension handle DOES look suspect to breaking, but after cutting the equivalent of several cords of wood with it, I have not broken it. I DID buy a small machine bolt and wing nut, and zip-locked them in the bottom of my backpack, should a broken rivet ever occur - but this is more 'common sense' than equipment doubt, at this point. I have had no failures, except from those 4 American-made 21-inch bowsaw blades that aren't as 'tempered' or 'hardened' as they claimed to be. Seems that the Chinese 'junk' outlasted that 'American Junk' again. Imagine that? Seriously, for the money, this is well-worth the $15 price, and sure beats other higher-priced saws that came from the same Chinese factory, and were re-labeled once they got to America.

These are the blades I buy all the time for my backpack-camp saw. I go through at least one a year, kinda rough on them when camping. They are sharp, teeth are hardened, cut most woods very well, clean, fast cut too. Why spend $10 - $25 per blade, plus shipping, when ACE has them in stock any day of the week?

Then I took my brush and brushed it down, my hair was manageable and there was no trace from yesterday's products , it was clean and fresh.Then I added the dry conditioner and it did not smell as good as the lavender but it was still fragranced and it made my hair shiny and bouncy.These are my true and tested results in the pictures below with the Luseta bundle.I did not need to wash my hair by using these fabulous products.Of course, I will use these sparingly because I wash my hair every other day but when I feel lazy or just want to revive my hair in an instant I will use these products.The dry shampoo is a bigger can than the dry conditioner.The lavender dry shampoo is 8.45 fl oz and the dry conditioner is 4.06 fl and these products are flammable so be careful when using it, besides the instructions are on the back of the cans.But the results made my hair alive, smooth and shiny.

I have enjoyed most of the books in this series, but I found myself ready for a break from it so I hadn't read this next installment until now.  Sometimes being away from something allows us to come back to it with fresh eyes and an renewed enthusiasm.  That was certainly the case here.  Miss Julia is back to her (lovingly) interfering ways as she decides that Hazel Marie needs help with the babies and Uncle Vern who shows up on her doorstep, right at the time when James is out of commission due to a fall.  Miss Julia steps in with a plan to address her lack of cooking skills, a day at the beauty parlor for some much-needed attention, as well as hiring some help for taking care of the twins.  As is usual, Miss Julia's best intentions don't work out quite as planned but everything seems to eventually work itself out.  acThis book is a bit light on the plot and adds recipes at the end of each chapter (which some folks will view as filler), but I still enjoyed it quite a bit.  It was nice getting back to old friends and I found it was easy to settle back into a relaxing, comfortable read.I am giving this 4 stars, which might be a bit generous due to my enthusiasm for the characters after a fairly long absence.  Had I read this one immediately after the last, I think it would have been closer to 3 stars.

I have loved all three Tana French books that I have read, including this one.  Set in Dublin, Frank gets sucked back into his dysfunctional family after over 20 years away when the suitcase of a missing young woman in discovered in the walls of an abandoned home.  The owner of the suitcase was (and still is) very important to him and trying to discover what happened to her may be the only thing that would draw him back to the old neighborhood.  The novel has two main themes:  what happened to the woman (mystery), and what was the relationship between them.  As very strong sub-theme is uncovering all the crazy undercurrents, and sometimes outright crazy behavior, of Frank's family and the characters that populate the old neighborhood.An excellent mystery and an excellent look at human relations should have this novel appealing to a broad audience.  One note of warning - the language is pretty raw throughout so if that is something that would really bother you, you might want to pass.

Most people have eaten lemon curd which is easy to find in your local grocery store.  While looking at a more exotic grocery, I was wanting something a bit different to serve with scones for a small group I was hosting.  I picked up this lime curd along with another product by this same manufacturer.  It is delicious!  The entire group commented out tasty it was and how smooth the curd tasted compared to lemon curds they had eaten in the past.  This has a mellow, lime flavor rather than having a lot of "bite".  It was wonderful on plain scones and I will be looking to buy it again after the current jar is consumed.  What a delightful discovery!

I was looking for something a bit different to serve with tea for a small group book study I was hosting.  I saw these (and knowing the group usually loved to purchase scones in restaurants when available) and decided to give them a try.  I was quite pleased.  They were easy to whip up - only add water - and they baked up quickly.  I used the method of just dropping them on the cookie sheet.  I didn't butter the sheet as recommended, but used a silicone baking mat which made clean up quick.  The scones turned out beautifully and were very light.  I offered lime curd and tangerine marmalade to put on them.  They were so good, the group asked to see the bag so they could purchase it themselves.I am not a cook, nor do I have much interest in spending loads of time in the kitchen, and these were great with little effort on my part.  Will definitely be purchasing again.Note:  If you are not familiar with scones, they are not a very sweet item, so don't expect something along the lines of banana breads or blueberry muffins which are much, much sweeter.

I already own two pair of the spa slippers (thong-style) and love them.  I have been in search of something with a closed-toe style for the colder months of the years.  I have tried several more expensive manufacturers and been disappointed with the short length of time before they began falling apart.  I tried a less expensive manufacturer and loved the feel of the slipper, but they only lasted 4 months before the fabric was completely worn through and the stuffing coming out.  I had not ordered these because I was wanting a slide-in style that I didn't have to tuck my heel into.  Since I had such poor luck with other options, I went ahead and purchased these out of desperation.  I bought the black since they were significantly less expensive than the other colors but I was a bit concerned about them showing dirt, and particularly cat hair.Bottom Line, I should have ordered these from the beginning!  The black color does not show dirt at all and the cat hair isn't problem.  While it does take an extra minute to put them on, that is minor compared to the benefits.  The slipper has a strap of fabric across the top with velcro so you can adjust the tightness in the front of the slipper.  There is elastic around the top of the heel section so it is easy to get on and off plus it allows the slipper to conform to your foot, increasing the comfort.  They are well-made and still look just like they did when I took them out of the package.  There is a generous amount of support on the slipper bed so they support the foot nicely.Two things I will bring to your attention.  1) Sizing: I usually wear a size 9 shoe, and sometimes a 9.5.  I originally ordered the large but had to return them since they were too small.  I went with the extra large and they fit will, but aren't any too big.  Based upon my experience, I would assume these run on the small side.  2)  While the slipper bed is well-supported for a slipper, they do bend and flex.  This is fine with me, but if you are are looking for a stiff slipper bed, this isn't for you.Acorn is becoming a brand I trust.

There are tons of reviews out there regarding this book, so going into plot and story line (which have already been covered) won't add much.  What I would like to do is put my two-cent's worth in and state that I loved this installment in the series.  I have read them all and enjoyed each and every one.  Ms. Penny keeps things fresh and has not fallen into the trap so many authors do of sticking with a formula or putting lots of filler in as the series ages.  One of the things I like most about these books is that they aren't just mysteries;  they are just as much literature/fiction and a close look at relationships between the characters.  This one probably tilted the balance a bit more away from the mystery flavor, but it still kept me guessing throughout the novel.I love her books, I loved this installment, and I can't wait until August to read the next one.  Fabulous series!

I purchased the Amazon leather case (expensive) for my first generation Paperwhite.  While I loved it, I didn't love the price so when I was looking for a case for my second generation Paperwhite, I shopped around and found a Fintie case for it -- the brown, map design.  That has been a wonderful case and I actually like it better than the Amazon one due to being lighter weight.  When I purchased a Voyage recently, I immediately knew I was looking for a Fintie case and purchased this one.  After now using it for 6 weeks, here are my impressions:Pros:- price- weight -- very light and adds minimal weight to the device- fit - the Kindle fits securely in the case and the case adds minimal bulk- looks -- nice- auto wake feature -- has yet to fail.  Even better than the previous cover which would fail from time to time.Cons:- the front cover appears to be two separate pieces glued together.  It feels like there is a little "give" when I pull open the case.  I have concerns that it will separate at some point- the overall quality doesn't appear to be quite as highBottom Line:  Assuming the case holds up a reasonable period of time, I would still buy this case again.  With the difference in price between the Fintie case and the leather ones, I could replace this one a couple of times and still be money ahead.  With the introduction of new devices every fall, it doesn't serve me well to put too much into a case that won't likely fit the next Kindle introduced.

We are just completing a total kitchen remodel and this was the sink we chose.  I knew I didn't want a cast iron sink --- had two of those already and tired of having to work to get scratches from pots and pans removed from the surface.  I wasn't excited about a stainless steel sink as they can be touchy as well regarding water marks.  After quite a bit of research of options, we decided to give this a try.  I have used it now for several weeks and I can't tell you how pleased I am.  I love the composite granite as it always looks good with only rinsing it out from time to time.  What a difference from what I had previously!  I also love the depth of the sink as I can wash things in it without having water all over the counter and floor.  I also am in love with the 60/40 split and the low divide.  I like two sinks rather than one when hand washing items, but find I wash in the larger side and rinse in the smaller.  I also think the low divide allows the handles of larger pots to spill over into the other side of the sink without the pan resting at an odd angle.Beautiful design and beautiful material.  Would highly recommend the composite granite regardless of what sink configuration you prefer.

Liz Trenow caught my attention earlier this year when I read The Forgotten Seamstress.  If found that book to be one where I lost myself in the story and enjoyed every single page.  That experience prompted me to go in search of other works by this author and this was the only other one available for Kindle.The product description has a nice synopsis of the storyline so no need to expand on that here.  I do take a different stand on this book being compared to a Nicholas Sparks' "The Notebook".  Having read that book as well, this one seems to me to have more substance to it and less romance/lighter fare.  While there is the romantic angle, the historical time period and skill of silk weaving add some heft to keep it from being too fluffy.  One of the strongest aspects of the novel is the main character of Lily.  The development of her as the narrative progresses is excellent and the fact the author shows the reader some of her weaknesses as well as some of her failures make her a character that comes to life.  Ms Trenow has drawn a character I would enjoy meeting in real life.With all the positive aspects of this book, it still didn't grab me the way "The Forgotten Seamstress" did.  For me there were some pacing issues in the mid-section and I would have liked to have had the editor take another go at it.  Fortunately, those problems were largely contained in the middle and as I was close to the 60% mark, my interest was back and I found myself happy to be reading.  The other item I took issue with was one of the supporting characters and how he/she was utlized in the book.  I can't say much or I will be giving a spoiler, but I do wish the entire sub-plot had been handled differently.All in all, a good, solid 4-star read.  Will be looking for her other book "The Poppy Factory" to be made available on Kindle.

I have owned one Nook and many Kindles over the years and this is hands-down my favorite.  The product line just keeps getting better and better plus I appreciate Amazon listening to their customers and providing page forward and back buttons along with the touch screen.I have both Paperwhites (gen 1 and gen 2) and was debating about getting the Voyage.  A friend strongly encouraged me and I did break down and made the purchase at the end of February.  It was an excellent decision.  First off, I have come to prefer e-readers to paper books so I am generally predisposed to a favorable opinion.  I also much prefer the black and white e-readers to tablets as they most closely simulate the printed page and love the lighting option on the Paperwhites and now the Voyage.If you are a first-time buyer and will use the device primarily for reading , I would recommend you purchase the Voyage.  If you have used e-readers before and are looking to purchase a new one, this is the one I would also recommend you buy.  The pros are numerous and I have found no negatives so far.- contrast and font sharpness are superb- the touch screen is much better and much more responsive than those of the Paperwhite- the page forward and back buttons are a wonderful addition for all kinds of reasons.  Just one of the reasons is that it allows you to hold the Voyage multiples ways and still read easily.  I like the fact my hands don't have to stay in a similar position all the time which can become uncomfortable when reading for extended periods- I didn't really care much about the automatic light adjustment and thought I would most likely turn that feature off.  Instead, I have found it to be wonderful and have left it on.-  the smaller size and lighter weight is a huge plus.  For people who read a lot, every little bit helps and the Voyage is noticeably more comfortable to hold.I have kept my previous devices as back-ups in case I need them, but the Voyage is my reading device of choice.

I, like many others, first became aware of Cheryl Strayed with her book entitled "Wild" which chronicled her walk along the Pacific Coast Trail.  It was selected by Oprah and I thought it was one of her better selections.  Ms. Strayed was speaking at a local college earlier this month and I decided to go back and read her freshman effort in preparation for attending her talk.While the book is fiction, it definitely had a familiar theme and was heavily influenced by the loss of the author's mother at a relatively early age.  From both books and hearing the author speak, it appears the death of her mother was the most defining even of her life so far and the hole it left is still obvious even in the present day.The story itself revolves around a young(ish) mother who discovers she has a very aggressive cancer and only a short time to live.  How her live and death impacts her family and how they each hand their grief is the bones of the story.  Her two children are older and their reactions are very different.  One child is out on her own attending college and the other is still in school and living at home.  Her "husband" who she never legally married is the love of her life and his way of grieving is very different from what might be expected.A star rating is difficult to assign as I had some very conflicted opinions.  On one hand, the characters are incredibly well fleshed-out and I feel like I came to know them and what they were going through.  The writing is both descriptive and clear which is often times difficult for a writer to pull off.  On the other hand, the main theme is so similar to "Wild" that the two books almost merged in my mind.  I would also recommend you take a pass if you are feeling depressed or in need of a lift.  Hard to read and hard to forget.  A well-written book that isn't quite in that top group of stellar books but pretty amazing for a first novel.

I have been searching for a new slipper to where during the warmer, summer months and hadn't found anything I was willing to try until I ran across these.  I LOVE these slippers and have promptly thrown my old ones in the trash.Pros:1)  Try to size.  I wear a size 9 shoe and order the slipper in an 8-9 and they fit perfectly.2)  Contoured back means my heel doesn't slip around3)  Very comfortable, plush fabric covering the entire slipper4)  Love the rubber sole.  I have planters fasciitis and having the rubber sole gives enough support that it helps keep it under control5)  The piece that goes between the toes is very, very comfortable and non-irritating6)  Very reasonable priceCons:  None

I have noticed over the years that a singer does well on American Idol but when their CD comes out, it appears they have been "handled" and lose what made them interesting and unique.  Their look is polished up and the album seems like many other album being produced today with over-done everything.  I hate that an artist I came to love is no longer recognizable to me and has lost their "something special".Fortunately, with Candice Glover, that doesn't appear to have happened.  I do think that an entire album of love songs is a bit much and would have liked lyrics beyond "I love you and you left me", but what is here is good.  Her voice is given the opportunity to shine with simple accompaniments being the rule rather than the exception.  She is at her best when the voice is front and center and the piano/guitar/other acoustical instrument is in the background and compliments rather than overpowers. That has largely been accomplished here.Some of the tracks I like better than others which isn't unusual but there is only one track I dislike enough to punch the skip button.  Most are very, very good and I find a couple of the tracks circulating in my head throughout the day.  Track 4 is that way and I find myself hearing the song and her lovely voice even when not actually listening to the music.I would probably give the album a high 4-stars, but since she has managed to release an album that actually sounds like her, I have to give a bonus star for that alone.  I don't know how much control she had over this, but someone, somewhere (and maybe Candice herself) did something right.  Loved her from the beginning of the season and I am so very happy to be able to listen to her gorgeous voice at will.

Whether you are just starting out on your journey of de-cluttering or well down the path, this book has something to offer everyone.  The book is short and sweet at only 99 pages and covers both the "why" and the "how" of de-cluttering.For people who are just starting the journey, I am particularly enthused about the author dealing with the "why" portion of de-cluttering.  If you look at the table of contents, the first three sections are dedicated to why de-cluttering is so important.  The remaining four sections are more the "how to" instructions for the best way to tackle the project regardless of how much or little you need to do.For people who are already on the journey, it is a motivational/reinforcing book especially the early chapters.  It also gives a few different twists than I have seen previously on the implementation steps.  Very practical and useful.I would encourage you to take a look at the table of contents available via the "look inside this book" feature.  It will help you better understand the contents as it is very detailed.As far as my own journey, I have been walking this road for about fifteen years now.  I think I have things pretty well under control and then life throws a curve which creates another need for me to de-clutter.  Mostly this has been due to the constantly changing health situation of my elderly parents.  They have downsized multiple times over the past three years and I have had responsibility for keeping or getting rid of almost everything they owned.  At each step, there has been a huge influx of "stuff" that I must make decisions about and then take actionThere are two thoughts I have, one if which is a tad different from the author.  I have found it helpful to de-clutter the entire house prior to deciding on storage solutions for what remains.  If you do her steps perfectly, the storage can be determined as soon as a room is finished but I don't do the steps perfectly.  I end up moving things around the house as I realize that where I have stored things isn't necessarily the optimal location.  If I hold off purchasing storage solutions until the I am finished, I am more likely to buy the right things.The second thought is that the process takes me waaaaaaaay longer than I think it will and is very iterative.  The end results are wonderful and I get motivated by the improvement I see as I go, but this isn't something that I can do over a few weekends.  If you live alone, it might go faster but I have to work with other family members and get their buy in on de-cluttering and that can be a slow, slow process.

I am in the process of decluttering and organizing and one of the items I decided to purchase as I am doing this, is matching hangers for the master closet.  I purchased 156 of these hangers and each one arrived well-packed, undamaged, and in perfect condition.  I had purchased 10 from a local store and used them prior to making this larger commitment, and I am please with the original ten which I have been using for a while as well as the new ones.The hangers are excellent for hanging my husband's work pants and they don't fall off this hanger. (Note:  even the dry cleaners hangs them separately from the other items in their business since they must be handled carefully or they fall off.)  His long sleeve button-down work shirts fit well on the hanger and his polos and more casual shirts do too.  He also has a bad habit of pulling the shirt off the hanger and the wire hangers were bent and broken with the empty hangers at a crazy angle which looked awful.  His polo shirts also no longer have the pointy shoulder thing as the hanger is contoured correctly and the shirts lay right. I have fleece jackets, turtle-neck sweaters, t-shirts, jeans, dress pants on them and everything works beautifully.In addition, the aesthetics of the closet are wonderful.  I walk in and everything looks so much more organized even though I just changed the hangers.  When I had a mixture of wire hangers, plastic tube hangers, and clear plastic ones, everything looked messy.  As I get older, the pleasure of having things neat and orderly is becoming more important to me.  This was a relatively small investment and the pay-off is high.

Maeve Binchy is an author who has had a wide following for years, and I am one of her most loyal fans.  Every time I picked up a book by her that I had not read, I was immediately struck by what a wonderful gift she had for making the ordinary, fascinating.  I have also noticed that when talking about books with various friends over the years, everyone loves her work, even with a wide range of reading tastes among us.Ms Binchy passed away in July of 2012 and many of us who loved her work were greatly saddened by this loss.  A new book was published in November of that year which everyone was assuming would be the last.  While I enjoyed it, I didn't feel it had the polish of her previous works.  Low and behold, that novel wasn't  her final publication as her husband, Gordon Snell, collected together short stories that she had hoped would one day be a book but had never been published.  Her husband had the following to say, "Maeve wrote the stories over several decades, reflecting the city and people of the moment - always with the idea of one day making them into a collection with Chestnut Street as its centre. I am very pleased with the way her editors have now gathered them together as she intended, to make this delightful new Maeve Binchy book Chestnut Street."It was with eager anticipation and also with  dread that I opened the first pages of this collection and began reading.  What I found inside was a treasure trove of pure Binchy magic and  it is easily one of my favorite Maeve Bindhy works.  That is saying quite a lot as I am not a fan of short stories.  I prefer the novel format with its ability to develop characters and a storyline that allows me to immerse myself in another world.  Short stories usually leave me unsettled as I feel shortchanged when I come abruptly to the end of a narrative I wanted to see continued.  There are only two writers I find myself enjoying their short stories and Maeve Binchy is one of those writers.  Interestingly enough, the other writer is Patrick Taylor, who is also Irish.This collection of 36 shorts stories is like finding 36 small pearls, each one completely formed and luminescent.  She had the unique ability to draw me in with the first sentence and keep me in the palm of her hand for the duration whether it be a four hundred page novel or a two page short story.  This collection is written about a group of folks who live on a fictional street in Dublin and the characters are only loosely connected if they are connected at all.  Some of the stories are pure entertainment and some are life lessons presented as interesting stories.  There actually is a lot of great wisdom about leading a successful and fulfilled life without the reader realizing how deep some of the messages are until the story comes to a close.  I loved, loved, loved this book and am excited for others to be able to partake of the joys of an outstanding body work by this incredible author.

I had the Kindle 2nd generation and when it gave up the ghost, I purchased the Kindle Keyboard (no longer available).  Over the years I have owned or used both of those devices along with the Kindle Basic, the Kindle Touch, and the first generation Paperwhite.While I have loved them all, I believe this latest Paperwhite is my favorite.  While I like the manual page-forward and page-backward features of the Kindle Keyboard better than just the tapping you do on this one, that is the only feature that I miss from any of the older models.I have used the first generation Paperwhite and love it but decided to go ahead and get this newer one due to the improved contrast of the screen/text.  As I am getting older and my eyes aren't quite as sharp, the improved contrast really is very helpful.If you have never used an e-reader, I would encourage you to go this route if you are primarily reading books.  This price is a bargain and the ability to increase or decrease the font size at will, the ability to increase or decrease the brightness of the screen, and the non-LCD screen is a huge plus in my opinion since it allows you to read in all kinds of light, including in direct sunlight.  I was one of those people who "loved the smell and feel of paper books".  I never thought I would use an e-reader except for travelling when I wanted the convenience of the small size so I didn't take a suitcase of books along on every trip.  Over time, I have come to prefer the Kindle over paper books.  It has reached the point that I will purchase my own e-copy rather than borrowing a paper copy of the same book from a friend.Easy on the eyes, easy to hold (people with arthritis should enjoy the light weight), and so, so, so convenient to have multiple books on hand, and easy to purchase more without leaving the comfort of your own living room.

When I think of mysteries, what comes to mind most often are the cozy mysteries which I enjoy as a comfort read or suspense/thriller mysteries.  This first book by Tana French is neither of these.  In my mind, it crosses genres by being both literary fiction as well as a mystery.  Louise Penny's books are similar in that way as the mystery drives the plot but the author takes time to flesh out characters and storylines in addition to the central theme.After glancing at a few of the other reviews prior to writing this, they are totally correct in saying there are actually two mysteries --- one in current time and one in the past but both sharing the same geographical area.  One of the mysteries is resolved and tied up very neatly while the other one leaves the reader on slippery ground as the mystery is left unresolved but with some hints at several possible solutions. For me, I actually liked that as it gives me something to ponder and I feel like I was given flexibility to imagine different resolutions.  It also tantalized me a bit and motivates me to move on to the second book in the series where the answer may lie (or not).While I thought the book dragged a bit in the middle and got bogged down which results in a 4-star review rather than a 5-star, it was intriguing, well-written, non-formulaic.  All of which add up to the desire to read The Likeness: A Novel which I have downloaded on my Kindle.

My husband and I were taking a red-eye flight across the country and I bought us each one of these to help us sleep while on the plane.  I purchased one in navy blue (almost black) and black in order to tell them apart.The eye mask:- is very soft, not velour but soft like that and not scratchy- has a roll of fabric which runs along the bottom of the eye mask; it conforms to the contours of the face to keep light from creeping in from the bottom- has a very nice, adjustable clasp in the back; you get it adjusted to the right length and never have to adjust it again since it set from that point on (kind of like a seat belt would be in a car).There are absolutely no negatives that I could find.  My husband ended up using it in the hotel room one afternoon as well when he wanted to take a short nap and there were no room-darkening curtains.  It worked well and accomplished the goal.

I purchased these pants for my elderly father who was in rehab after a fall.  The therapists indicated that sweatpants would be ideal since he could move easily in them and get them on and off without dealing with buttons or zippers.  He wore them through his time in the rehab hospital and found out he liked them so much, he asked me to order more for him.  He likes them better than track pants and because they are true-to-size with elastic around the bottom, I don't have to hem them either which is really nice.The other thing I have noticed is that they wash well.  He will get stains on them which come out with only adding a spritz of stain remover before going in the washer.  The color hasn't faded after multiple washings and they look as good as the day I bought them.Great product.

Well, just in time for Thanksgiving week, here's the final release from Mattel's 2015 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection - Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty (the term given to these little forklift characters who are members of a racer's pit crew.)  Ponchy himself is a single in this collection as well - one of 36 racers from the original "Cars" movie's first race at the Motor Speedway of the South, with "Bumper Save" as their sponsor.  This little guy was originally released way back in 2010 as part of a Target exclusive 4-pack called "Team Bumper Save Crew" that included Ponchy's crew chief and a couple of other pitties, and it's a little surprising that it looks like they didn't make the change to a unibody sculpt as they have with other recent pitties.  As a single, he does come with a little stack of plastic tires (unlike the pitties in the 2-packs of this collection) as they always did, along with his little plastic tool chest (no, it doesn't roll, but the plastic pieces - including those forklift prongs - are quite sturdy.  We've had no issues with the plastic pieces in our grandsons' ever-growing collection of these very nicely detailed and durable models.)The only thing we'd suggest, if you're a beginning collector, is to come up with a strategy!  Many people enjoy starting with either the original movie or its sequel and collecting all of the racers, their pit crew chiefs and pitties (and don't forget their haulers!)  We opted for beginning with the major characters from both movies, then extending out as the years passed into minor characters.  It's easy to feel overwhelmed by the sheer volume of diecast possibilities, so take your time and figure out what you think your youngster would most like to play with first (you'll go broke otherwise... there are a dozen themed collections from Mattel in 2015 alone!)  Others characters in the "Piston Cup" collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

My husband and I had to chuckle when we began looking at Mattel's new 2015 offerings in their small, 1:55 scale line of diecasts, and saw yet ANOTHER Lightning McQueen version!  If you're a parent/grandparent who's thinking about beginning a collection of these diecasts, I'm sure you'll be as confused as we were several years ago when we began collecting for our grandsons... there are a million different versions of him (maybe a million and one!)  There's actually a nice difference with this model (stemming from the original Cars movie) from a somewhat similar model of McQueen with an "aggressive" or "angry" expression that came out years ago as part of a "Dinoco Showgirl" 3-pack, in that this is an all-diecast unibody sculpt (versus the plastic mouthpiece in the former model) - super nice!  And if what you'd like is a McQueen model without his typically smiling facial expression, this is your best bet... it does look like he's gritting his teeth in determination (and also looks a lot more aggressive and angry than the former one, in our opinion!)  You'll love the attention to detail on these models - so very nice, and having the durability to match.The package also includes a poster with a representation of just a fraction of all of the models available within the dozen themed collections Mattel's released this year (so if you're planning on getting just one or two of these guys, better hide that poster before the collecting bug bites!)  We were certainly "bitten" by that bug in 2012, and even though we now have innumerable McQueen models, it's always amazed us how youngsters can detect subtle differences long before us older folks can.  The nice thing about this year's collections is the wide variety of both major and minor characters from both the original movie and its sequel, and one thing we've definitely learned the hard way is that the time to purchase is when the models are readily available and reasonably priced (that collecting bug's bite packed quite a "sting" several times when we were hunting for older models!)Determined Lightning McQueen is part of the 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection, along with Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, along with 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

I think my husband and I enjoyed the Cars/Cars 2 movies almost as much as our grandsons have, and we've had a heckuva good time building a collection of these little 1:55 scale diecasts for them over the past several years!  Mattel does such a terrific job with the detailing on them, and we can't say enough about their durability.  Once we'd collected all of the main characters, it's been fun for us as the holidays roll around each year to pick and choose which minor characters we might like to add for the boys.  There are a couple of Piston Cup race officials from the original movie - Dexter (the flagman) and Charlie Checker (the pace car) - included in 2015's "Piston Cup" collection that we're looking forward to adding this year, to give the boys a little enhanced action during their racing!  (By the way, this 2015 model has a yellow flag as shown in the 3rd photo accompanying this listing, not a green flag as shown in the two packaged photos.)As these small scale models go, Dexter's bigger than most regular car models (just as a compact pickup is larger than a typical car), and we like everything about him... except for a couple of things.  First, in the movie, the flag pole he waves is attached to a thingamabob on his rim, while the diecast has it attached through a small opening near his window - doesn't seem like it would've been that difficult for designers to make it true to the movie's depiction.  The other thing is that he's been released - SEPARATELY - with each of the flags a traditional NASCAR flagman has at his disposal (green for the start of the race, checkered for the end of the race, and - like this model - yellow for "caution")... despite this model's great detail and durability, I'm going to deduct a star for what seems like a bit of greed on Mattel's part - since you attach the flag to Dexter after he's opened, why not include all three flags with the model, instead of having to purchase three different models?!  (We certainly won't be making three separate purchases... grandmas have a way of devising solutions to "problems" like that, and somehow the grandkids will have all three flags by the time Christmas comes!)There are a dozen different themed collections to choose from this year - Dexter is from the 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection, with the other characters in it being Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, along with 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

This is a fun time of the year for my husband and I, as we look through all of the yearly offerings in Mattel's small, 1:55 scale diecast line and decide which minor characters will join the collection we began for our grandsons back in 2012.  With a dozen different themed collections in 2015, there sure is a lot to choose from!  I'm pretty sure we'll be adding Richard, one of three Piston Cup security officers in the original Cars movie.  Richard's the one who helps Motor Speedway of the South team leader Marlon "Clutches" McKay push the crowd back while they try to determine who won in the 3-way tie, and he's also seen yelling at the paparazzi, as well as at the Los Angeles Internation near look-alike Marco Axelbender at Speedway near look-alike Marco Axelbender when Marco refuses to admit Fred to pit row without his garage pass. We really like the looks of this "deluxe" security van (he's larger than the typical car models in the line, just as a van would be larger than a car in real life)... though we really don't see ANY difference at all between he and Marco, other than the facial expressions on the diecasts!  We think our Radiator Springs model of Sheriff would enjoy a security guard pal!If you're thinking about beginning a collection for a special youngster in your life, I think you'll be SO pleased with the detailing they put on these models, and how well they hold up.  Our grandsons really put these models through the wringer with all of their racing and crashing (and occasional hurdling through the air in the hands of our middle grandson!), and we're sold on their durability!  Other than Richard, the remainder of the models in the 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, along with 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Having collected all of Mattel's small, 1:55 scale diecasts of the main characters from the Cars/Cars 2 movies back in 2012, after our oldest grandson had received both DVDs from Santa and fell head over heels, my husband and I have had a great time during the holidays in the years since looking over all of our other options as far as which minor characters to add, trying to get a sampling of each type of vehicle.  Knowing we wanted to add an R.V. this year, we were so excited to see both Doug RM and Larry Camper included in 2015's 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection - we've decided to go with Doug for now, and we know our grandsons (there are now three of them!) will think Doug is so awesome!First, other than his NUMEROUS flag attachments, he's solid diecast!  Certainly a very large model in comparison to the regular Mattel models (just as an R.V. is much larger than a car), and definitely earning its "deluxe" category.  The detailing is just SO very nice... love the ridges, the big tires, the color, and the grandkids are going to go nuts over all of those flags!  There's a total of six - one with a Lightning McQueen lightning bolt that attaches to his left side, a flag for multi-time champ Strip "The King" Weathers on his right (comes already attached in the package), and four Piston Cup flags (one attaches to the rear, another goes on top, a pole with a double flag attaches to his right.)  Our experience with these models assures us that the flags WILL stay attached during play, and there's some "give" to the plastic so that they don't easily break (believe me, that's been tested in our home!)  I like that they're detachable, since we store these in plastic Plano cases with dividers when the grandkids aren't here, and Doug certainly wouldn't fit with them all attached.  We'll probably eventually have to add Larry, since he and Doug are "best buds" who've bonded over Piston Cup races, and are seen together at the original movie's first race at the Motor Speedway of the South, along with the tiebreaker at the Los Angeles International Speedway.  (If you've seen the movie, you might recall Doug's funny line, "Well, dip me in axle grease and call me slick!")We know this guy will be a favorite when gifts are opened this year!  Along with Doug and Larry, other characters in this year's "Piston Cup" collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, along with 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

When we began collecting Mattel's small, 1:55 scale diecasts for our grandsons back in early 2012, there were already SO many models that had been released from both the original movie and its sequel that we had to try to stay focused on getting the major characters first (since my husband DOES intend to actually retire one day, and it'd be nice to have a little money left for that endeavor!)  Now that we've been at it for a while, it's fun for us each year to take a look-see at the new offerings come the holiday season, especially in the way of models that aren't yet part of the collection.We knew we wanted to add a R.V. this year, and this first release of Larry Camper (based on a 1991 Winnebago Itasca and named for his voice actor, Larry Benton) is such a SUPER nicely detailed deluxe model with his Piston Cup flags, dual wheels and ridged detailing on his back section!  With only so many dollars to go around, I think we'll be opting for another model from this 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection (Doug RM), for a few reasons... first, only Larry's cab is diecast (though the rest of him, like other deluxe models we've had, is made of very sturdy plastic) while Doug's completely diecast, Doug's larger than Larry, and - what will interest our grandsons most, we think - is Doug has a lot more flags!  We'll probably eventually add Larry though, since the two of them are best friends who attend both of the original "Cars" movie's races - the first at the Motor Speedway of the South, and the tiebreaker at the Los Angeles International Speedway.  (By the way, those plastic flags on Larry WILL stay put and aren't easily breakable, as our experience with Mattel's accessory pieces have proven to us.)Aside from Larry and Doug, other characters in this year's "Piston Cup" collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, along with 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Ponchy is one of the re-releases in Mattel's 2015 "Piston Cup" collection, one of a dozen such collections released this year, and the 18-piece collection features several of the 36 racers from the original "Cars" movie's first race at the Motor Speedway of the South.  We've been busy collecting these wonderfully durable (small) 1:55 scale models for our grandsons for over 3-1/2 years and have been just so happy with the nice detailing on these models!Though our collection thus far doesn't include any of the minor character racers like Ponchy (been focusing on the main characters and branching out from there), one of the really neat things about him if you're considering a purchase is his unique designing... there are NO other racers among the 36 who have this design!  And his pitty is also a part of this collection, so if you have a youngster who's enthralled with the original movie, it's nice to have some of the previously released models readily available and at a nice price.  Ponchy's sponsor is "Bumper Save" (as if you couldn't tell!), and we've always enjoyed the cars-related references throughout the movies, whether it's a character's name, a sponsor, etc... very cleverly done!  We also get a kick out of reading the little bios they put out - they say Ponchy was working as a stunt-double prior to being recruited as a professional race car, which has meant "a lot less intentional crashing" (then again, Ponchy hasn't been in the hands of our grandsons yet!)Our own experience with the countless models who call our home "home" has been nothing less than super - the grandkids love them, and we've been very impressed with how quality-made they are.  The other characters in this year's "Piston Cup" collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Well, even though we don't have any of the minor character racers from the original "Cars" movie's first race at the Motor Speedway of the South as part of our grandsons' collection yet, we're not going to be able to resist adding Charlie, the official Piston Cup pace car this year!  Seen in both that race as well as the Los Angeles International Speedway tie-breaker between main character Lightning McQueen, main antagonist Chick Hicks, and retiring multi-time Piston Cup champ Strip "The King" Weathers, it's Charlie's responsibility to set the pace and positions for a rolling start in warm-up laps prior to the races, as well as returning to control the pace during any hazardous conditions that occur.  There's plenty of racing done in our home with these terrifically durable and nicely detailed (but small) Mattel 1:55 scale models to warrant the necessity of a pace car, given the number of crashes that have occurred over the past (going on) four years!Charlie's been released numerous times before (can't tell from this listing whether he's got yellow tail lights or the correct red ones as seen in the movie - he's been released with both in the past), but it was costly enough just to build up a collection of just the main characters from both of the Cars movie, so it's nice at this point to be able to choose from the HUGE selection of minor characters among the dozen 2015 themed collections Mattel's released this year.  We know the grandkids are going to enjoy having Charlie (part of the 18-piece Piston Cup collection) in the mix now!  Other characters in this particular collection are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Oh my gosh - how's this little guy for a stocking stuffer?!  Gingerbread colored with candy canes shaping his number, with other candy detailing all over him - so very cute!  And the bonus would be that he's one of Mattel's extremely durable 1:55 scale diecasts, a line we've been collecting for our grandsons since 2012 and one we've been so impressed with in terms of both quality and "play-ability" in the hands of youngsters who can tend to get pretty aggressive when it comes to racing.Greg - modeled as a Capitol Motors Verve XT - is one of 36 cars who compete in the first race at the Motor Speedway of the South in the original Cars movie, one of two "Tach-O-Mint" sponsored cars (the other, Guenther, who's modeled as a 2006 Dodge Charger and also candy-decorated, is Greg's reserve driver in case he's sick or injured.)  This is a GREAT time to purchase a Greg model, since his previous release with rubber tires was a Kmart exclusive years ago (with rubber tires... this one has the typical plastic tires) that's now 4-5 times higher than his original price, and the only other way to get him was in a super exclusive (only 1000 made) pack called "Motor Speedway of the South" which contained all 36 racers (I just checked, and it's asking price right now is anywhere from $1,400-$3,000!)  The little "bio" the put on on Greg is as cute as he is... apparently the Tack-O-Mint owner's niece is the one who got to choose the designing for this racer (something he's not too keen about!)These Cars/Cars 2 models have been a really nice investment for us, one that I think we enjoy almost as much as our three grandsons!  He's part of 2015's 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection, along with Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Our advice to any parents/grandparents who are considering beginning a collection of Mattel's 1:55 scale Cars/Cars 2 models for their youngster is just to make sure you have a strategy in place first... there are SO many models and SO many different ways to collect, it's easy to spend a small fortune, and even easier to get sidetracked from your strategy with all of the cool looking models you'll find!  We've been collecting these for our grandsons for over 3-1/2 years now, and while many people enjoy having a collection of all of the racers, their pitties, crew chiefs and haulers, we decided to start with the main characters from the movies and then be choosy about the minor characters we added... our wallet only opens so far, and this is one of a couple different diecast collections we have going for the grandkids.  We do have a few of the little forklifts, along with Mack (Lightning McQueen's hauler), and if the grandkids remain as enthusiastic about the collection as they are now, we might consider expanding in the future.BUT, if you think you'd prefer to start with the original movie's racers and their racing teams, this is a very nice 2-pack!  It contains both the crew chief and little forklift (called a "pitty", in reference to his being a pit crew assistant) for Winford Bradford Rutherford (how do you like THAT name?!), one of 36 cars who compete in the first race at the Motor Speedway of the South in the original movie.  The striking colors and terrific detailing on these models are so sharp.  Both characters have been released before, but we like it that Petrol has a unibody now (with just a slightly different hat and back end than previously released), and there are slight adjustments to the crew chief as well.  If you're worried that the plastic pieces like the chief's headset or Petrol's prongs will easily break off, our experience with them is that they stand up well to the typically aggressive play of the targeted age group, and even though Petrol's little took box is completely plastic (and doesn't actually roll), it's sturdy plastic.  The only reason we're deducting a star is because the pitties have usually come with a little stack of tires, missing in this package, which we always thought was a nice touch.Our grandsons' collection has been a good investment for us - we don't think you can beat them in the durability department, and Mattel's come out with a dozen themed collections for 2015.  This 2-pack is from the 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection, which also includes Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and a 2-pack of Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

There'll be a lot of parents/grandparents out there this Christmas who have a special youngster in their lives just discovering the Cars/Cars 2 movies, possibly looking at beginning a diecast collection of characters from the movie.  2015 is a great year to begin, since Mattel's released a dozen new themed collections which contain both major and minor characters (including both brand new releases along with re-releases) from both movies - the more recent the models, the more readily available and reasonably priced they are!  This 2-pack is from the 18-piece "Piston Cup" collection, which also includes Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and a 2-pack of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski.Ruby "Easy" Oaks is modeled as a "Crown Celesta" (along with other racers like Ryan Shields & Manny Flywheel), his sponsor is Easy Idle (with the slogan "A warm start to a cold morning"), and he's one of 36 cars who compete in the first race at the Motor Speedway of the South in the original movie.  According to the little bios they put out on these characters, his nickname stems from his easygoing approach to both life and racing.  The little forklift (called a "pitty", in reference to his being a pit crew assistant) is diecast with plastic prongs that have a bit of "give" to them and won't break off during typical play in our experience, and he comes with a sturdy little plastic toolbox (though the wheels don't actually move).  Both are very nicely detailed and durable models, as all of these small 1:55 scale diecasts from Mattel are!  Think we'll have to deduct one star on this package though, since all of the pitties usually come with a little stack of tires (missing from this 2-pack) - not a big deal, but was always a nice touch.  Both of these characters have been released previously, but this is the first time they've come packaged together... there ARE a few variations between them and previously released models (i.e. Ruby no longer has eyelids that are raised up a bit from the rest of his windshield eyes and he no longer has white teeth in between his lips - at least not on the model we saw - but we think his pitty is a bit nicer as a unibody model who now - ironically - DOES have coloring in between his lips when he didn't in the past!)Some people enjoy having a collection of all of the racers, their pitties, crew chiefs and haulers... this isn't the only diecast collection we have going for the grandkids, so - due to a limited budget, as most folks have - we decided against adding the majority of the little forklifts (though they're SO cute!) and haulers (other than Mack, Lightning McQueen's hauler.)  Maybe someday!

Any parent/grandparent whose youngster has only recently discovered the "Cars/Cars 2" movies is going to be confused as to who all of the various characters in Mattel's dozen 2015 themed collections are - there are just so many of them!  Some major, some minor... regardless of which version of Sarge you end up purchasing, this is one of those "must-have's" in any Cars collection.  Modeled as an early 40's Willys MB army jeep, Sarge is a patriotic WW2 vet - owner of Sarge's Surplus Hut in the small town of Radiator Springs - and his ongoing annoyance with/affection for his hippie friend/neighbor Fillmore is a great example for kids as to how people can have differences can still be friends.  (The excellent character actor, Paul Dooley, gives Sarge a voice in the movie.)Although this version of Sarge holding a (non-removable) plastic gas can has already been released a couple of times before, it's a terrific little 1:55 scale model as he appeared in the original movie when main character Lightning McQueen's new Radiator Springs friends arrived at the big 3-way race in California to serve as his pit crew.  He's part of the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection, and another version of Sarge appears in 19-piece "Radiator Springs" collection.  We purchased our Sarge model over 3-1/2 years ago, as one of the original numbered singles series stemming from Cars 2 (Race Team Sarge) since those were the most readily available (and most reasonably priced) models at the time, and we have just been SO please with the amount of detail on these models, they can't be beat as far as we're concerned!  Our experience with the little plastic accessories (like that gas can) they use on these diecasts is that they stay put - don't break off during typical play (which means a lot to us, since these models are making their way through three grandsons!)Others in the "95 Pit Crew" collection are Pit Crew Member Fillmore, Pit Crew Member Guido, Mater with Sign, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, Pit Crew Member Mack, and a 2-pack of Hydraulic Lightning Ramone & Pit Crew Member Flo.

Since we began collecting Mattel's 1:55 scale Cars/Cars 2 diecasts for our grandsons over 3-1/2 years ago, my husband and I have looked forward to the holiday season and checking out any new offerings each year to see which ones we might add.  There are a dozen new themed collections to choose from in 2015 - although Ryan Shields is a re-release, it's always nice when new collectors (or those who, like us, have been in it for a while) can take a closer look at some of the minor characters while they're readily available and reasonably priced!  Modeled as a "Crown Celesta" (as are other cars like Ruby "Easy" Oaks and Manny Flywheel), Ryan's sponsor is View Zeen Corrective Windshields (ha!), and according to the little bios they put out on these characters, he's also a customer who couldn't drive at 200mph without them!Out of the 36 racers who participate in the first race at the Motor Speedway of the South in the original Cars movie, Ryan's one of 33 who get piled up due to some dirty shenanigans pulled by the movie's main "bad guy", Chick Hicks.  (Interesting tidbit... apparently there are 43 cars in a starting field of NASCAR races, which is what the Cars movies are based on, but only 36 appear in the original movie - no one knows where the other 7 are!)  There's a 3 way tie at the end... retiring multi-time Piston Cup champion Strip "The King" Weather, main character Lightning McQueen, and Chick Hicks go on to compete again at the Los Angeles Speedway, where it's rumored that whoever performs best will inherit the coveted Dinoco sponsorship upon The King's retirement.  We love Ryan's predominant turquoise coloring (a bit lighter on his doors), and all of the great detailing that is commonplace with these Mattel models.While nice detailing is great, the name of the game for us when it comes to collecting for three youngsters who are subjecting these diecasts to some pretty heavy-handed racing, crashing, etc., is how durable are they?  VERY!  This has been a very nice investment for us, and one we highly recommend.  The others in the 18-piece "Piston Cup Collection" that Ryan's a part of are Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Well, it's that fun time of year again when my husband and I enjoy looking through all of Mattel's latest 1:55 scale diecasts to see which ones we'll add to the collection we began for our grandsons going on four years ago, and they've come out with a dozen new themed collections for 2015 so there's a lot to peruse!
