This listing's a little confusing, since it shows Kevin with predominantly red coloring... the interesting thing is that even though he WAS actually released with that color in his initial releases, his predominant color in the movie is just as it appears on the packaging - hot pink - and though he appeared early in 2015 in the exact same packaging with his red paint job, they've corrected it so hopefully what you'll get is the revised, hot pink version.Kevin's one of the 36 racers who took part in the first race in the original Cars movie (one of the first to be hit in a big crash) at the Motor Speedway of the South, from which - after a 3 way tie with multi-time Piston Cup champion Strip "The King" Weathers - main character Lightning McQueen and the film's primary antagonist, Chick Hicks, go on to the Los Angeles Speedway to determine who might get the coveted Dinoco sponsorship after The King's retirement.  Don't you love that determined look on Kevin's face, and the great detailing with all of those decals?  He's designed as a Capitol Motors Verve XT, and the "Shifty Drug" logo you see is his sponsor... according to the little bios they put out on these characters, he doesn't have much going in terms of natural ability or knowledge of the rules/history of racing, but thanks to an in-law owning the big pharmaceutical company who sponsors him, he's been able to stay on the circuit!What we can tell you from years of collecting these diecasts is that they're as durable as they are detailed - when our middle grandson isn't able to destroy something, it's darned near well indestructible!  The others in the 18-piece "Piston Cup Collection" are Chick Hicks, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck with Cart, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

There've been COUNTLESS releases of Chick Hicks (primary antagonist from the original Cars movie) since Mattel began producing their line of terrifically detailed and durable 1:55 scale diecasts... this one's the latest, from the 18-piece Piston Cup Collection, which means it's widely available and reasonably priced - good news for beginning collectors (he's @3-3/16"L, 1"H, 1-3/8"W).  We didn't begin collecting these models until after the 2011 Cars 2 sequel came out (our oldest grandson was about to turn 4), and though we began just with the Cars 2 models (which, for us, were the most recent and readily available), we also tried to pick up the main characters from the original movie as well.  We ended up with the model that had the little Piston Cup trophy included, but there are SO many versions so be sure to check them all out before settling on one, if you're a parent/grandparent whose youngster has just discovered them.  One thing's certain, though - any collection of diecasts from the original film HAS to have Chick!You'll be amazed at the detailing that goes into these little diecasts, especially Chick with his (we heard) 334 decals!  He's designed as a 1987 Buick Grand National, his sponsor's name (Hostile Takeover Bank, or htB) is seen in several places, and his number (86) is in honor of the year Pixar came into existence.  Both he and main character Lightning McQueen end up in a race against mutli-Piston Cup winner Strip "The King" Weathers... The King is about to retire, and his highly coveted Dinoco sponsorship is being rumored to go to whomever wins the race.  Though both racers begin the movie as arrogant, full-of-themselves personalities, McQueen "grows up" with the help of his newfound, small town Radiator Springs friends, learning the importance of fair play and teamworks, while Chick - despite ultimately winning the race after some nasty shenanigans during the final lap - ends up with an "empty cup"... his cheating to win the race gets him no where when it comes to fan support OR the Dinoco sponsorship.We've had two more grandsons since we began collecting, and we've really been pleased with the quality of these diecasts and how much enjoyment the boys (and us!) have had with them.  This re-release is part of 2015's 18-piece "Piston Cup Collection", with the others being Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, My Name Is Not Chuck, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

One of the things my husband and I have enjoyed about the Cars/Cars 2 movies is how many "teachable moments" have resulted with our grandkids, as we've been collecting Mattel's small, 1:55 scale diecasts since our oldest grandson's 4th birthday back in 2012.  (And when I say "small", diecast "Not Chuck" is @ 1-7/8" from his rear to the tip of his fork prong, 1-1/8"H, 15/16"W, while his plastic tool box is @ 1-1/8"L, 1-3/16"H, 7/8"W.)  If you're a parent/grandparents who's unfamiliar with the original Cars film, "Not Chuck" (humorously, voiced by a San Francisco DJ/actor named Mike "No Name" Nelson!), is designed as a 2003 Nemomatic forklift, and is main character Lightning McQueen's temporary crew chief (with McQueen having fired the first one) in the original, 36-car race at the Motor Speedway of the South.  At the beginning of the movie, McQueen is a super arrogant race car (he matures as the movie progresses), and he ignores Not Chuck's advice during a pitstop to change his tires - McQueen insists on gas only so he can quickly return to the race (ending up with burst rear tires!)  McQueen does eventually end up in a 3-way tie at the end of this first race, and during an interview, he dismissively tells this little forklift - whose name he hasn't even bothered to learn - to get out of the way of a camera shot, saying "Yo, Chuck.  Chuck, what are you doing?  You're blockin' the camera!  Everyone wants to see the bolt."  The forklift has had enough, gathers the other pit crew members together and says, "We quit, Mr. One-Man Show!"  McQueen sarcastically asks how he'll ever be able to find someone else who knows how to fill him up with gas, finishing with "Adios, Chuck!"  As his crew stomps off, the forklift responds, "And my name is not Chuck!"SO... we had to chuckle when our grandson opened his model, with packaging reading "My Name Is Not Chuck", and said "But Grandma, his name IS Chuck!  That's what Lightning calls him!"  As adults, we tend to forget that some of the nuances of a movie can be lost on youngsters, and we used the opportunity to talk about the concept of "team" (... "How would you feel if we colored a picture together, and when someone complimented it, I pretended I colored it all by myself?", going on to the longer explanation that McQueen wouldn't have been able to be one of the three winners if it hadn't been for the team who helped him.)  Anyway, we love all of the little details on these Mattel models - we keep adding more, now have a couple of additional grandsons who are enjoying them as well, and they are very durable models that can withstand a LOT of punishment.  Even the plastic pieces attached to the diecasts (like Not Chuck's prongs) and the props like that tool box are amazingly durable (ours came with a little stack of 4 tires, while it looks like the re-release has only 2... just be careful - we lost ours, and you don't want a baby/toddler getting hold of that little piece and popping it in their mouth!)  There are innumerable little forklift characters in this diecast line... can't afford to collect them all, but given his role in the film, we HAD to have this little guy... whatever his real name may be!This model is being re-released as part of 2015's 18-piece "Piston Cup Collection", with the others being Chick Hicks, Kevin Racingtire, Ponchy Wipeout, Richard Clayton Kensington, Greg Candyman, Dexter Hoover, Ryan Shields, Charlie Checker, Determined Lightning McQueen, Mario Andretti, Ponchy Wipeout's Pitty, Doug RM, Larry Camper, and 2-packs of Chief RPM/Petrol Pulaski and Ruby "Easy" Oaks/Easy Idle Pitty.

Though we already have a version of the Fabulous Hudson Hornet as part of the collection of Mattel's terrific (small) 1:55 scale diecasts we began for our grandsons going on four years ago, I have to say that it is SOOOOO tempting to add this 2015 "deluxe" model from the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection... it is, as our grandsons would say, absolutely "AWESOME!"  Even though he's been released with a headset before (our model didn't have one), this is the first time he comes with the cool stand he's seen sitting on in the original Cars movie, as main character Lightning McQueen's pit crew chief, when all of his new small town Radiator Spring friends show up to serve as his pit crew during the big 3-way race in California!  Though the stand is plastic, our experience with all of the plastic accessories in the Mattel line are super, super durable, and it's just so neat - both the diecast model and the stand are so amazingly detailed... the top of the stand even has a piece that flips over to become a ramp for him to drive up onto his perch for the race, the antenna moves up and down, and - unlike so many other of the little tool boxes in the Mattel line, this one actually rolls!  The only thing that would make it cooler would be if those side panel doors went up and down.  Just an excellent "deluxe" package.If you're a parent/grandparent unfamiliar with the "Cars/Cars 2" movies, here's a bit of info about Doc.  First, you KNOW he has to be a great character in order for the Disney/Pixar producers to convince Paul Newman to give him a voice!  In the original movie, he's known as "Doc Hudson"... he'd been a former 3-time Piston Cup champion racer in his early days, until a terrible crash during the 1954 Piston Cup's final lap sidelined him, and his attempt to return to the racing circuit was met by taunts of being a "has-been".  He became jaded and gave it all up, studied medicine and became a "doctor of internal combustion" (don't you love it?), disappearing into the small town of Radiator Springs and opening Doc's Clinic (while also serving as the town judge.)  When famous (and arrogant) race car McQueen accidentally becomes "lost" in the small town on his way to the California race, Doc and the other characters become his new friends, and Doc (who as a physician/judge sports a dignified dark blue color in the town), dons his Fabulous Hudson Hornet attire when they all travel to replace the former pit crew who'd justifiably quit on McQueen due to said arrogance.Doc is designed as a '51 (what else?!) Hudson Hornet, and we thought it was so poignant that - after the death of Paul Newman - the producers decided that Doc himself would have already passed away when the sequel came out (though he's referred to several times in the movie)... a very classy move in our opinion!  We love our Fabulous Hudson Hornet model, and as far as we're concerned, this deluxe model is a "no-brainer" if you're just starting a collection - readily available and reasonably priced.  There IS a plain blue Doc Hudson as well, in 2015's 19-piece "Radiator Springs" collection, if your budget allows for two different models of him!

There are "must have's" and "nice-to-have's" if you're thinking about starting a collection of Mattel's small, 1:55 scale Cars/Cars 2 diecasts for a special young person in your life... the characters of Ramone and Flo are "must have's" (though maybe not these particular scene-specific models stemming from the original movie - but they're definitely "nice-to-have's", and part of 2015's 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection, along with Pit Crew Member Sarge, Pit Crew Member Fillmore, Pit Crew Member Guido, Mater with Sign, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, and Pit Crew Member Mack.)  Other readily available and reasonably priced models of both Ramone and Flo as singles are in 2015's 19-piece Radiator Springs collection, so be sure to check both out before making a purchase to see which you think your youngster would like best!If you're a parent/grandparents who's learning about the Cars/Cars 2 characters right along with your youngster, that's exactly what we were doing several years ago when we began a collection of these terrifically detailed and oh-so-unbelievably durable diecasts for our grandsons!  Ramone (designed as a 1959 Chevrolet Impala Lowrider, with a license plate that reads "LOW N SLO"!) is a very colorful - both literally and personality-wise! - character who owns Radiator Springs' "Ramone's House of Body Art", whose had innumerable paint jobs (in this 2-pack, he has the red body with yellow flames in support of main character Lightning McQueen, as depicted in the original movie.  Though Ramone's been released several times prior with the same paint job, this is the first time he has his hydraulic suspension lifting him up for a better view!)  He's married to the owner of the the local fuel diner next door to his store, Flo, who's quite a character herself!  She's modeled as a composite of a few different 1950's "show cars" (sporting the license plate "SHOGRL"), and this 2-pack has her equipped with a (non-removable) side tray with a gas can sitting on top, ready to help McQueen is whatever way she can in trying to win the big 3-way race in California.  (You might think that little plastic tray would pop right off of the diecast, but we can tell you from experience that all of the little plastic pieces on these models are attached in such a way that we've never had any break off over the course of going on four years, and now three grandsons actively playing with them.)There are SO many past models of both of these characters available, so be sure to check all of them out and see which ones you think best fit not only your youngster's taste, but your budget as well!  We have a couple of Ramone models that were part of the original numbered series stemming from the Cars 2 movie (which, for us, were the most readily available/cost efficient models at the time we began) - a purple Hydraulic Ramone and a Radiator Springs Ramone), but the only Flo model we have is one of Disney Store's larger (1:43 scale), heavier models - she's gorgeous (as all Flo models are!), but we'll be adding the single from the Radiator Springs collection this year.  The Mattel collection has been a good investment for us, one the grandkids are getting our money's worth out of!

We were a little surprised, when we saw Mattel's dozen 2015 themed collections of 1:55 scale diecasts, that they included Guido in the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" series but not Luigi!  Guido - modeled as an Alza/Tutto forklift - is the Italian speaking best friend/assistant to the owner of Radiator Spring's "Casa Della Tires", and both of them are a part of the small town group who rally to become main character Lightning McQueen's new pit crew in the original Cars movie.  This model of Guido - with his little plastic screw driver in hand, and little plastic tire stack and tool box accessories included - had been previously released, but what about Luigi?!  Not including both is like having salt without pepper, in our opinion... if you're thinking about starting a collection for your youngster, and have a limited budget (as we did!), even though this scene-specific model with accessories is cute, we suggest taking a look at the Luigi & Guido 2-pack from 2015's Radiator Springs collection.Keep in mind that Guido is SUPER tiny in a line of diecasts that's already small (@ 1-5/8"L, 3/4"W, 1-1/16"H), but it's part of what makes him so irresistibly adorable in our opinion!  We'd begun a collection of these diecasts for our grandsons over 3-1/2 years ago, and have been so impressed with their quality - both in detailing AND durability!  We loved Disney Store's larger (1:43 scale), heavier models, but they were more brittle and we just didn't feel they held up as well.  Our experience with all of the little plastic pieces on Mattel's diecasts, as well as any plastic accessories included, has been great in that they use a highly durable plastic that doesn't break with the normal wear and tear youngsters put toys like this through - including intentional crashing, etc.!  Other characters in this "95 Pit Crew" collection are Pit Crew Member Sarge, Pit Crew Member Fillmore, Mater with Sign, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, Pit Crew Member Mack, and a 2-pack of Hydraulic Lightning Ramone & Pit Crew Member Flo.

Starting to look into collecting Cars/Cars 2 diecasts for some special youngster in your life?  We've been collecting Mattel's small, 1:55 scale diecasts for our grandsons going on four years now, and we swear by their terrific detailing and the fact that our middle grandson, who's especially tough on toys, hasn't been able to mangle them despite his best efforts!  2015 is a great year to start collecting, since Mattel's come out with a dozen themed collections of both major and minor characters from both movies - it's just a matter of deciding where you want to begin, and Fillmore - is one of those loveable Radiator Springs characters who appeared in both movies, so regardless of which model you decide on, he's on the "short list" of must-have's.Modeled as a 1960 VW bus, popular with "hippies" from the 60's, this colorful (figuratively AND literally!) character runs Radiator Springs "Fillmore's Taste-In", where you can always pick up a tie-dyed mud flap or some of his organic home-brewed fuel.  Though his WWII vet neighbor Sarge isn't too happy about his psychedelic symbols, crazy lawn ornaments or unkept lawn, they're good friends and are among the small town characters who become main character Lightning McQueen's pit crew during the big 3-way California race at the end of the original movie.  That's what this particular Fillmore model stems from, with little (non-detachable, plastic) gas cans tucked into his headband!  (We thought it was a stroke of genius for Disney/Pixar to recruit George Carlin to give him his voice in the original Cars and, though Lloyd Sherr did a great job in taking over the role in the sequel, it was just so sad that Carlin himself passed away before he could reprise his role.)We purchased our grandsons' Fillmore model as part of the original numbered singles stemming from Cars 2 (Race Team Fillmore) since it was the most readily available and most reasonably priced model, and there are a couple of Fillmore choices in Mattel's 2015 collections... this one is from the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection (which also includes Pit Crew Member Sarge, Pit Crew Member Guido, Mater with Sign, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, Pit Crew Member Mack, and a 2-pack of Hydraulic Lightning Ramone & Pit Crew Member Flo), and another - without the gas cans - in the 19-piece "Radiator Springs" collection.

Sometimes I wonder if Mattel itself has kept track of how many different versions of its small, 1:55 scale Mater models its released!  We began collecting these wonderfully detailed, equally durable models over 3-1/2 years ago... our Mattel model is from the original numbered series that came out after Cars 2 - Race Team Mater - because they were more readily available (and more reasonably priced) than the older models from the original Cars movie, but we've got a ton of Disney Store's larger (1:43 scale), heavier Mater models as well that we'd collected prior to deciding to go with Mattel for the vast majority of our grandsons' collection, finding them just all around more durable.  Even having collected all of these years, it's hard for US to keep track of all of the different Mattel models!If your a parent/grandparent with a youngster who's developed an interest in the movies but not too familiar with them yourself, Mater is main character Lightning McQueen's best friend, and we challenge anyone to find a reason NOT to love Mater!  Back home in the small town of Radiator Springs (where famous race car McQueen gets "lost" on his way to a big race in California), he runs Tow Mater's Towing & Salvage as well as the local impound lot.  His character is voiced by Larry the Cable Guy in the movies, and he's an absolutely hilarious, down-home, devoted and loyal guy, whose body is shaped like an old '50s tow truck, resembling a 1951 International Harvester L-170 "boom" truck with some mid-'50s Chevy qualities mixed in.You can't have a Cars collection of ANY kind without Mater, and among Mattel's dozen 2015 themed collections, there are a few models available - this one, holding a "Radiator Springs Racing Team" sign (as he did in the original movie when all of McQueen's new Radiator Springs friends saved the day by becoming his new pit crew after his original crew had quit due to McQueen's initial arrogance) as part of the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection, as well as Mater and Brand New Mater from the 19-piece "Radiator Springs" Collection.  Be sure to check them all out before deciding, if your budget's got a limit (as ours does!)  Others in the "95 Pit Crew" collection are Pit Crew Member Sarge, Pit Crew Member Fillmore, Pit Crew Member Guido, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, Pit Crew Member Mack, and a 2-pack of Hydraulic Lightning Ramone & Pit Crew Member Flo.

2015 is a great year for any parents/grandparents out there who have a special youngster in their life who's just discovering "Cars/Cars2" - SO many nice choices in Mattel's dozen themed collections of 1:55 scale diecasts!  As far as we're concerned, Mack - whether this one, which has him featured as Lightning McQueen's "interim" crew chief in the original movie, or one of the many other models with haulers - is a character you've GOT to have!  After all, if it wasn't for Mack getting spooked by the "delinquent road hazards" and accidentally emptying Lightning out of his hauler in Radiator Springs, we would never have met all of the endearing characters who live in that small town, and not only became his pit crew after the once arrogant McQueen's original pit crew quit (with good reason!), but also showed him that friendship and loyalty were a heckuvalot more important than winning!Mack's a friendly, seasoned professional hauler for main character Lightning McQueen of the "Cars/Cars 2", based on a 1980's era Mack Super-Line truck, (and voiced by John Ratzenberger - "Cliff Clavin" of "Cheers" fame in the movies). This "deluxe" model is a long-awaited version of Mack, the first to feature him with his racing headgear and oil/gas cans attached to his front... it's how he appears in California at the three-way race between Strip "The King" Weathers, a retiring Piston Cup Champ, and the two racers who hope to inherit the coveted Dinoco sponsorship after him... McQueen and the movie's main antagonist, Chick Hicks.  You DO have a decision to make, though. if your budget is limited (as ours is, and has been since we began collecting these terrifically durable Mattel models for our grandsons over 3-1/2 years ago)... is this the version you want (there's no hole on his rear to connect a trailer up to), or do you want one of the Mack haulers?  Years ago, we'd purchased the transforming hauler version of Mack, and it's been great, but it's probably a lot more expensive now.  This Pit Crew Member Mack model is just chock full of so many terrific details, so if you decide to just go without a trailer, we're certain you won't be disappointed in having him represent Lightning McQueen's loyal hauler!We really do love both the models and the endless hours of enjoyment our grandsons have had with them!  Others in the 8-piece "95 Pit Crew" collection are Pit Crew Member Sarge, Pit Crew Member Fillmore, Pit Crew Member Guido, Mater with Sign, Fabulous Doc Hudson with Stand, and a 2-pack of Hydraulic Lightning Ramone & Pit Crew Member Flo.

When my husband and I saw Mattel's new 1:55 scale Terry Gong model (only Terry is diecast... the rest of this "deluxe" package is plastic, and unfortunately no, the gong doesn't make a sound), I asked him if he remembered "The Gong Show", and we had a good laugh over the fact that not only our grandsons, but SONS would not even remember it, that's how old we are!  It also made it a certainty that we'll have to add this to our grandsons' collection (even though it has NOTHING to do with "The Gong Show", which was a silly show where contestants - who were most often lacking in the talent department - would be judged by a celebrity panel who would "gong" the really bad acts!)  In "Cars 2", when Lightning and his team arrive in Tokyo for the first leg of the World Grand Prix race, they travel through the city taking in many different sights, during which an old top 10 hit by "The Cars" (how appropriate!) called "You Might Think" was being sung (though by a different group) - they end up in the Tokyo National Arts Center and, as the song ends, Terry (whom you see for maybe all of two seconds!) hits the gong, which makes a reverberating sound - very cool!This is such a unique little package... Terry's modeled as an Alza Facile utility vehicle (a Tutto, same as Guido, which means "everything up" in Italian!), and your youngster can insert the tip of one of his forklift prongs into a little circular piece on the end of the "thingie" to hit the gong (don't you love my official terminology... "thingie"?)  We think our grandsons will really get a kick out of this, and we're not concerned about the heavy amount of plastic used in this... we've been collecting these small Mattel Cars/Cars 2 diecasts for going on four years now, and our experience of the plastic used as decor with the models is that it's a of sturdy consistency which hold up well to typical play.Lots of neat new characters in the dozen 2015 themed collections Mattel's come out with this year that we're excited about adding!  This one's from the 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection, which also includes Shigeko, Acer, Holley Shiftwell, Okuni, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tsashimi.

Some people think Professor Z is the main "bad guy" in Cars 2... but it's actually Miles Axlerod who's the REAL "evil behind the evil"!  Designed as a green Range Rover L322, at first you Sir Miles is a great guy - organizing the 3-country World Grand Prix race to promote his renewable, clean-burning fuel Allinol, throwing great parties... well, he ends up being the one behind a secret plot to actually turn the world AGAINST alternative energy, and to rely more heavily on traditional gas (since he and the "Lemon" families own the world's largest untapped oil reserves!)  Even his license plate (it says "ALT NRG"!) is part of his spiel!We purchased one of Mattel's small, 1:55 scale Miles Axlerod models @ 3-1/2 years ago as part of collection for our grandsons, and these models are just terrific in terms of durability and detailing.  One thing I do want to point out, though, is (at least as of this writing), the photo accompanying this listing isn't accurate... "Miles Axlerod with Microphone" - part of 2015's 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection - has an open mouth and a little plastic floor microphone (that you'll need to keep out of reach of any infants/toddlers in the house.)  There are a couple of points during Cars 2 that he's using a mic (at the Tokyo welcoming party, again on the "Mel Dorado Show"), and though we do like the fact that the model accurately depicts the chrome grille and clear plastic over the headlights as the character does in the movie, we prefer our model (one of the original numbered singles,with his frowning face, since we think it more accurately reflects who he is.  In fact, the photo accompanying this listing looks like our model!)BUT, what you do get by purchasing this one is a readily available (and therefore reasonably priced) model, as compared to higher prices on the older models.  For someone just beginning a collection, we know how important reasonable prices are because we went through the same thing!  Other characters in the "Tokyo Party" collection are Shigeko, Acer, Holley Shiftwell, Okuni, Terry Gong, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tasashimi.

With three grandsons, I've always appreciated when the toy lines they're interested in and we've started collections of (i.e. Thomas the Train, Disney/Pixar's Cars/Cars 2 and Planes/Fire & Rescue) have some strong female characters in the mix, and Holley Shiftwell certainly qualifies!  The Holley model we purchased back in early 2012 doesn't sit on the sidelines - designed as a Jaguar XJR-15, this gorgeous purple British spy car works with Finn McMissile and she's loaded with spy gadgetry... an on-board computer, projection lamps, dual mounted trackball platforms, headlight cameras, digital readouts, retractable wings, her front wheels have concealed guns, an electroshock device, and a telescoping utility arm - wowsers!  (Now, the CHARACTER has all of these things, not this particular diecast model.)  There are several Holley models available, a few of which do feature one or two of these spy gadgets, but if you're looking for a Holley model that's readily available and reasonably priced, one with which your youngster can work that imagination, this one - part of 2015's 10-piece "Toyko Party" collection - is perfect.Our model is still in great shape after years of play, and you'll love all of the nice detailing and how well these models hold up.  You might be unfamiliar with what "1:55 scale" equates to in terms of actual size when it comes to these diecasts... Holley measures @ 3-1/8"L, 1-1/2"W, and 1"H.  Others in this collection are Shigeko, Acer, Okuni, Terry Gong, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tasashimi.

For parents/grandparents who are considering starting a collection of Mattel's small, 1:55 scale Cars/Cars 2 diecasts for some special youngster they know, we can tell you from going on four years of doing the same for our three grandsons that you can't beat the durability of these little models - all of them are so nicely detailed (with NO paper stickers to start peeling off!), and the Acer model we purchased in early 2012 is still in SUPER shape (well, as good of shape as a car INTENTIONALLY designed as a beat up old 1975 AMC Pacer is supposed to be in!)  Any basic Cars 2 collection has to have Acer and his cohort (Grem) - as evil Professor Z's henchmen, they're the ones who chase Mater (mistakenly thinking he's an American spy) around the world during the 3-country World Grand Prix race.  Mattel's 2015 themed collection have three different offerings of Acer - this one that's part of the 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection, a "deluxe" model that comes with a luggage cart in the 6-piece "Airport Adventure" collection, and a 2-pack of "Grem in Trouble/Acer in Trouble" in the 7-piece "Ye Left Turn Inn" collection.Although he's one of the "bad guys", I can't help having a personal soft spot for Acer, since I learned to drive in a car just like him - except that it was maroon.  His license plate says "FSHBWL", which is hilarious because you certainly did feel like you were driving in a fish bowl, and even though it was considered a "lemon" with a terrible track record, I LOVED that car!  (I guess all teens love the car they experienced their independence in for the first time!)  One suggestion:  with the 2015 collections readily available and reasonably priced, we'd suggest going with the "Grem/Acer in Trouble" 2-pack if you're just starting out, since Grem isn't offered as part of any of the other collections this year.  Others in this collection are Shigeko, Holley Shiftwell, Okuni, Terry Gong, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tasashimi.

So, do you want the good news or the bad news first?  Let's start with the good (at least as good as it can get with Take-n-Play models from 2014/2015.)  If you're a parent who's only looking to move your child through what you believe will be a brief "Thomas phase" (versus seriously collecting), then there are a half dozen "value" packs Fisher-Price has come out with that should satisfy that need at a reasonable price (by "reasonable", I mean that the MSRPs for the packs are more reflective of the models' actual worth, versus the outrageous $6 MSRP for the small models when sold separately... they USED to be worth that, but are far from it now.)  This "Sodor Celebration" 4-pack is in honor of 70 years of Thomas, and includes a specially decorated Thomas, his coaches (Annie & Clarabel), and Sir Topham Hatt's blue car.  The MSRP is $15, so effectively you're paying @ $3.75 for each model.  Here's a list of the other "value" packs, so you can compare (you'll notice some character duplications):Lift & Load Cargo Crew 4-pack ($15 MSRP) includes Harvey, Max, Monty and a rail car with removable rubble.  Dieselworks Fix-Up 4-pack ($15 MSRP) includes Diesel, Den, Dart and a cargo car that "rattles and shakes".  Brendam Buddies 4-pack ($15 MSRP) includes Percy, Salty, Bulstrode and a blue Troublesome Truck.  Steamies vs. Diesels 6-pack ($20 MSRP, equating to $3.33/each) includes steam engines Thomas, Percy & Charlie and diesel engines Diesel, Iron 'Arry & Iron Bert.  Thomas' Favorite Friends 10-pack ($30 MSRP, equating to $3/each) includes Thomas, Percy, Diesel, Victor, Dash, Kevin, Winston, Harold, Captain and Bertie.  Of these, the 10-pack is your best bet, possibly adding Sodor Celebration (even though Thomas is in both, at least this pack has a specially decorated Thomas, and you'll probably want Thomas' coaches and the guy who runs the railway, Sir Topham Hatt.)Now for the bad news.  If you intend to seriously collect and can afford wooden trains (we couldn't), get them, because Take-n-Play is no longer the amazing line of weighty feeling, exquisitely detailed diecasts and high quality playsets that it was when Fisher-Price took over the diecast line from Learning Curve's "Take-Along" in 2010 and re-named it "Take-n-Play".  (If you can afford the typically higher asking prices for the no-longer-manufactured Take-Along models combined with older models of Take-n-Play - immediately noticeable by the older models' protruding, squarish magnets versus the round, flat magnets of Take-n-Play's 2014/2015 heavily plasticized, severely detail-stripped models - then by all means go for it, if you don't mind doing some hunting and pecking.  Even "used" models, if they're the older ones, have it all over these "brand new" so-called "diecasts".)  We were completely thrilled with the quality and price/value relationship during the first two years we collected for our oldest grandson (2010/2011), still pretty happy in 2012, but by the end of 2013 we'd witnessed such a quality decline that we stopped collecting at the end of that year (we'd still be collecting for two additional gradsons who've come along, had it not been for the quality issues.)$3/each for the 10 pack?  Not terrible.  $3.75/each for these?  Starting to lose that cost/value relationship.  You work too hard for your dollars to pad Fisher-Price's pockets when they're putting out Take-n-Play products that are in no way, shape or form comparable to models from just a few years ago.  You and your youngster both deserve better, and if you could hold one of the 65th Anniversary Toy Fair Thomas models in one hand, this 70th Anniversary "Sodor Celebration" model in the other and compare the two side by side, I think you'd pass on this line altogether.

What a tease!  Mattel's 2015 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection has only TWO of the three super tiny but hugely darling 1:55 scale Japanese fan dancers (Okuni and Shigeko) from Cars 2... where's Tamiko?!  Though all of them have been released previously in multi-pack form, this is the first time two of them are being released as singles and, at least to my knowledge, they've never been released all together.  I think a 3-pack would've been amazing!It's going to be SO hard for me to resist adding Okuni to the collection we've been putting together for our three grandsons for going on four years now - just so beautifully detailed with her traditional Kabuki makeup and gorgeous kimono!  And these little models are as durable as they are great to look at.  There's just such a long list of minor characters we want to add this Christmas, and since the "girl cars" usually end up in my hands during playtime, I guess I'll just have to be patient for now in favor of some others I think the boys would be more interested in.  Aside from Okuni and Shigeko, others in the "Tokyo Party" collection are Acer, Holley Shiftwell, Terry Gong, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tsashimi.

Although they've been released previously in multi-pack form with other characters, Mattel's 2015 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection is the first time two of the three darling (TINY) and amazingly detailed 1:55 scale Japanese fan dancers (Shigeko and Okuni) from Cars 2 are being released as singles!  A bit disappointing to see they're not also releasing the third (Tamiko) as a single right now as well, but I guess Mattel's got that old saying in mind... "Always leave 'em wanting more!"Modeled as a 2009 Smart ForTwo Passion coupe, Shigeko is adorable in her traditional geisha get-up - look at all of the intricate detail work!  I would SO love to add her to the collection of these terrifically durable diecasts we began collecting for our grandsons over 3-1/2 years ago, but since all of the "girl cars" are typically handed right over to me during playtime, and there are SO many other neat minor characters we want to add this year, I guess I'll have to wait  :-(  Aside from Shigeko and Okuni, others in the "Tokyo Party" collection are Acer, Holley Shiftwell, Terry Gong, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, Mike Fuse, and a 3-pack of Mater with Allinol Cans/Edamame Tsashimi/Daisu Tsashimi.

What a terrific 3-pack this is, stemming from one of THE funniest scenes in Cars 2... during the Tokyo party to welcome all of the World Grand Prix racers, Mater - who doesn't have the opportunity to get to fancy parties much and can't believe all of the free food and beverages! - with his truck bed piled high with free Allinol cans, eyes some extremely hot wasabi at a stand manned by two Sushi chefs (Edamame and Daisu), mistaking it for pistachio ice cream.  Just in case you're a parent/grandparents unfamiliar with the movie, I can't resist filling you in on the hilarious lines from that scene:Mater: "Hey, what you got here that's free? How about that pistachio ice cream?"Sushi Chef: "No, no, wasabi."Mater: "Oh, same old same old. What's up with you? That looks delicious!"Sushi Chef: (gives a little piece of wasabi)Mater: "Er...little more, please. It is free, right? Keep it coming. A little more. Come on, let's go. It's free. You're gettin' there. Scoop, scoop."Sushi Chef: (gives little by little, then gives a big scoop when Mater said "Scoop, scoop.")Mater: "There ya go! Now that's a scoop of ice cream!"Sushi Chef (in Japanese): "" (Okiyami moshia-arimasu, My condolences.)This Mater model is TERRIFIC - loaded up with his free Allinol cans (even his tow hook has hold of one!), along with a facial expression that matches his excitement at all of the freebies.  The Sushi chefs are so very tiny and adorable, with their bandanas and little knives, and with Daisu also holding a little take-out box full of wasabi for Mater (the knives, etc. are flexible plastic, so though you're probably worried they'll break off, but our going on four years of experience collecting these terrific Mattel 1:55 scale Cars/Cars 2 models for our grandsons tells us that won't happen.)  This is the first time that memorable scene is coming out in the Mattel line... back in 2012, we'd actually purchased Disney Store's larger, 1:43 scale models of both Wasabi Mater and the Sushi Shefs (that was before we'd experienced both and then decided to stick with Mattel's smaller and more durable models)... our Mater model does come with sound - he has his tongue sticking out with a piece of wasabi on it, and when the switch on the bottom is turned to the "on" position - Mater screams... "Aughhhhhhhhhhhh!"  BUT, ours doesn't have the Allinol cans, and I guarantee you that Mattel's Sushi Chefs will hold up better than ours (not to mention neither of ours is holding a box of wasabi.)  This is just such a neat packaged set, and they're three of Mattel's 2015 10-piece "Tokyo Party" collection, with the others being Shigeko, Acer, Holley Shiftwell, Okuni, Terry Gong, Miles Axlerod with Microphone, and Mike Fuse.

With four different listings of Mattel's 1:55 scale model of Skipper, it would be very confusing to someone just starting to purchase "Planes" diecasts for they're youngster... what's the difference between them all?  That's just it - there isn't any difference, other than the packaging!  This listing shows model #CKF46, the original packaging shows #X9461, the "Fire & Rescue" packaging shows #BDB94, and the 2015 packaging shows #DLK98 with a "Propwash Junction" motif - ALL the same plane, so shop around for your best price!An old Navy F4U Corsair and former flying ace, Skipper Riley was a recluse until he met Dusty Crophopper and became his mentor.  He's based on the real-life WWII VF-17 squadron known as "The Jolly Rangers", and in the movie, he was the instructor of the elite Jolly WRENCHES fighter jets (very clever!)  He's a handsome shade of blue with white, sporting the Jolly Wrenches insignia and the number "7", along with "VF-17" on the rear of his fuselage.  He re-appeared in the sequel.This Skipper model measures @ 3-3/4"L with a wing span of 4-3/4", and stands 1-5/8"H (not including the additional 1/2" his propeller extends.)  These smaller Mattel models (as opposed to Disney Store's larger, heavier 1:43 scale models) have been our choice in building a collection for our grandsons (ages 7, 3 & 1).  Disney Store models are always beautifully detailed, but their heavier metal concentration also makes them more brittle and prone to pieces breaking off.  We've been watching "Planes" races put on by our grandsons for 2 years now, and despite how aggressive the racing can get during these air shows, we've yet to have a propeller, wheel or anything else pop off.  We're confident all of these diecasts will still be in great shape to take out of the attic when our great-grands arrive one day!  Other models being released with the "Propwash Junction" motif are Strut Jetstream Dusty (formerly released in a boxed set under the name "Qualifying Dusty"), Chug, Leadbottom, and Mayday.

While becoming "Cars" and "Planes" fans right along with our grandsons, part of what my husband and I have really enjoyed has been the casting of the voice actors in the movies - can't see this diecast of Harvey without hearing Jerry Stiller's voice!  In "Planes Fire & Rescue", the name "Harvey" is a tongue-in-cheek play on words for "RV" (Harvey... RV), and he's the former RV tire store manager who comes to Piston Peak National Park to celebrate his 50th wedding anniversary with his former showroom model bride, Winnie (a Winnebago, of course, voiced by - who else? - his real life wife, Anne Meara, part of that great old comedy duo my husband and I fondly recalled from our younger days!)  So ironic that Stiller and Meara were, in actuality, celebrating their own 60th anniversary in 2014 when the movie came out, and so sad than Meara would pass away this year.There are a couple of different listings for Harvey - this one shows model #CDT87, and another shows #DLT07 with a "Piston Peak" motif on the packaging - same Harvey, so shop for the best price.  It'll be nice to add these diecasts to our grandsons' "Planes" collection, which has grown to 40 characters over the past couple of years!  We're very big fans of Mattel's 1:55 scale models, and Harvey is one of the larger models (though not as large enough to be considered "deluxe"), very nicely detailed (don't you love the glasses framing the windshields?) and with a solid, weighty feel to him.  We've had such a great experience with both the "Planes" and "Cars" 1:55 scale models - so highly durable, and although we were originally a bit concerned about the plastic pieces like sideview mirrors, wheels and propellers breaking off, they're so well-constructed that they're surviving our 3 year old grandson who's a LOT rougher on toys than his 7 year old brother.  That's a good thing, because our 1 year old grandson will want his turn with them too, and we have every intention of boxing these guys (& gals) up for our great-grandkids to enjoy!The ONE thing that annoys us is that we heard Winnie might not be made available as a single, but rather make her debut as part of a boxed set.  On the backer, it shows Winnie as part of the "Piston Peak" motif series (along with Harvey, Linus Lines, Secretary of the Interior - otherwise known as Teddy - Tractor Buck, Trudy Trailway, RacER Dusty - as opposed to RacING Dusty in the WATG Racers series - and a re-release of Ol' Jammer are part of the motif as well), and says "each sold separately", so hopefully that rumor is false since - unfortunately - those boxes sets usually include characters already in our collection, so oftentimes we can't take advantage of them and have to buy a "loose" model.  Sure do wish they would've included Harvey and Winnie together as a duo... we realize Mattel's strategy has occasionally been to include otherwise unattainable new models in boxed sets to drive sales, but it's frustrating to long term collectors.  (Not to mention - how can they justify separating Stiller & Meara?!)

There were three "singles" versions of main character Dusty Crophopper stemming from the original "Planes" movie (Racing Dusty, Supercharged Dusty, Jolly Wrenches Dusty) in Mattel's 1:55 scale diecast line in 2013, adding a couple of new ones in 2014 stemming from its sequel "Fire & Rescue" (Pontoon Dusty, Firefighter Dusty) while re-releasing Supercharged Dusty with a "Fire & Rescue" backer card.  There was just one other version during that period - never sold as a single, only in a ToysRUs exclusive boxed set called "North Atlantic Sprint" - named "Qualifying Dusty".  This is THAT Dusty, finally being released as a single, just re-naming it "Strut Jetstream Dusty" (the moniker Dusty chose for the qualifying race to enter the Wings Around the Globe Rally.)  We didn't purchase that set for our grandson's extensive collection of Mattel diecasts from the two movies, since we'd already purchased all of the other characters in the set (and didn't want to hand over our first born child to purchase a "loose" model!)  There are a couple of different listings for Strut Jetstream Dusty - this one has model #CKF42, while the other is #DLL85 and shows a "Propwash Junction" motif on the packaging - same plane.We were excited to see the "single" version, which is part of the "Propwash Junction" motif (Mattel has gone to new backers this year on all of their "Planes" products, giving each one a themed motif - both neat NEW models and re-releases are included, so if you've already been collecting for a couple of years as we have, you want to be careful not to pick up a re-release just because of the new backer.  Others with the "Propwash Junction" motif we know of so far are re-releases of Chug, Leadbottom, Mayday and Skipper.)  But we REALLY got excited since hearing about a boxed set they're coming out with that not only has this Dusty model we were never able to add, but also FIVE OTHER BRAND NEW models - that's a rarity.  The others to be included are Fonzarelli #8, Piston #12, Firebird #16, Hammer #17 and Jackson #18, so if your youngster is asking for "Strut Jetstream", you might want to keep that in mind!  They've actually come out with yet ANOTHER Dusty model called "RacER Dusty", included in the Piston Peak motif series, as opposed to a re-release of "RacING Dusty", included in the WATG Racers motif series... DUSTYS EVERYWHERE!We're head over heels in love with the durability of these Mattel models - they're already surviving our first two grandsons (7 & 3), with a 1 year old who's patiently waiting for his turn.  Had some experience with the larger (1:43 scale) Disney Store models too, and while they're really beautiful and heavier, they're also more brittle - the majority of our investment has been on the Mattel models, and couldn't be happier.

Mattel's version of Yellow Bird is really a handsome looking American plane, modeled after an Extra EA-300 (we're learning all about aircraft models while reading up on these "Planes" characters!),  with his striking yellow color contrasting with the black checkered pattern on his sides and tip of his right wing, and his racing number (17) on the other wing and his tail.  We started a collection of the 1:55 scale Mattel models for our older grandson (now 7-1/2) a couple of years ago, and my husband and I have enjoyed being in the audience during innumerable races!  There are a couple of listings for Yellowbird - same plane, so choose the one with the best price.  He's included in a Target 4 pack called "Take to the Skies".We've experienced both Mattel's 1:55 scale and Disney Store's 1:43 scale items from his "Cars 2" collection, deciding to go with the Mattel models when we started on the "Planes" collection.  Although Disney Store's are super neat (not only larger, but also definitely a much heavier metal concentration than Mattel's, which feel more like a very strong plastic to us), it was annoying to have to keep super-gluing back on pieces of the Disney Store models - just an accidental drop to the floor, and off would pop a spoiler or something else, let alone the on-purpose crashes that happen during races!  The Mattel "Planes" have held up really well (even when our now 3-1/2 year old grandson would get hold of one and throw it - his way of participating, I guess, but not one his older brother was happy about!)

We thought this was a neat little Walmart 3-pack that includes the Pontoon version of Dusty Crophopper, along with two of the "Smokejumpers" team - Drip (who has a skid-steer claw for clearing fallen trees and debris) and Blackout (who's equipped with a saw).  We've been collecting Mattel's 1:55 scale diecasts stemming from the original "Planes" movie and its sequel ("Fire & Rescue") since 2013 - our grandsons thoroughly enjoy playing with them, we love their durability, but just one suggestion if you're just starting out... there are MANY boxed sets, with MANY character duplicates, so sort through them all and develop some sort of game plan prior to purchasing!  Sometimes you save money with the boxed sets, sometimes you don't - each of the three figures included originally sold for @ $6 individually, so it's something to keep in mind.

You'll see quite a few listings for Mattel's 1:55 scale Bravo model (this one shows model #CDR41, another shows #X9462, and still another shows #DLL90 with a "U.S.S. Flysenhower motif on the packaging - they're all the same plane.  Mattel's gone to a motif-themed packaging design in 2015 for their "Planes" models this year - while there are some cool looking new releases under this motif (Delta, Falco, Jigsaw #29, Roybal, and Lucas #36 models), there a few re-releases too - this Bravo, along with Echo and Jolly Wrenches Dusty.  I suggest checking out the various listings and purchasing whichever is most reasonably priced.Bravo is one of the Navy's "Jolly Wrenches" top fighter troops (along with Echo, and now Delta), who helps keep the skies safe during the Wings Around the Globe Rally.  They're based on Boeing F/A-18E Super Hornets, and while there are various design elements that distinguish them, the most immediately recognizable is that Bravo's helmet is silver, Echo's helmet is red, and Delta's is yellow (if you take a super close look, they also have their names on their helmets).  They're all gray & black with bits of yellow on their tails, and have the Jolly Wrenches insigtnia in several places, but another distinguishing element on Bravo is his number - "113" on both sides of his nose, and a little "13" under the yellow/black checkered stripe on his tail.  They (along with two new U.S.S,Flysenhower additions Falco, a helicopter, and Skipper look-alike Jigsaw #29) have a special affinity for Dusty Crophopper, the underdog main character of the movie, who ends up adopting the Jolly Wrenches insignia in the Jolly Wrenches version of Dusty.In terms of actual measurements for Bravo, "1:55 scale" equates to @ 4-3/4" from nose to tail, has a wing span of just under 3-3/4", and stands 1-7/8"H at the top of his tail fins.  We were hoping to get Jolly Wrenches Dusty, Bravo & Echo as part of a Target 4 pack a couple of years ago called "Jolly Wrenches", which included Hector Vector (a Mexican Coast Guard helicopter), but couldn't find it anywhere.  We ended up having to purchase the first three separately, and were disappointed to discover that Hector Vector apparently hadn't even been released singularly (still hasn't, as of this writing.)  There's a Disney Store version, but our experience with Disney Store items is that while they're bigger - 1:43 scale as compared to Mattel's 1:55 scale - and definitely constructed with a higher metal concentration than the Mattel versions which feel more like a sturdy plastic, they're not as durable in our opinion... we had to keep super-gluing pieces of the Disney Store versions that broke off.  Racing can get pretty aggressive in the hands of a 5 - now 7 - year old, especially with a 3 year old brother now playing (roughly!) with them, and a 1 year old brother who'd just love to grab hold of one as his latest teething toy!

The original "Planes" movie and its sequel ("Fire & Rescue") has already netted us 40 of these Mattel 1:55 scale diecast characters - our grandsons get such a kick out of playing with them, and my husband and I have been treated to numerous air shows and daring acts of bravery!  One of the characters we'd really wanted (a Mexican Coast Guard helicopter named Hector Vector) was only available through a Target multi-pack called "Jolly Wrenches", but we already had the other characters in the boxed set and didn't want to pay an arm and a leg for a "loose" model.  We're so happy to see another one named Falco being introduced!There are a couple of listings for Falco - this one has model #CKF50, while the other is #DLL05 and shows the "U.S.S. Flysenhower" motif on the packaging - same helicopter.  These "regular" singles are smaller than Mattel's "deluxe" helicopter models (Blade Ranger & Windlifter, and 2015's new "Blazin' Blade Ranger")... a few inches less in length (@ 4-3/4") and not as tall.  But I think this is definitely one we'll be adding to the collection this Christmas, having been SO pleased with the quality and durability of the models we've collected over the past several years (from both of the "Cars" as well as both of the "Planes" movies).  If you're thinking (as we had), "Oh... those propellers will pop off in a heartbeat...", our experience has been the exact opposite, happy to say!  A couple of years into heavy duty racing of the "Planes" models - by both our 7 year old and 3 year old grandsons - and nary a prop or wheel has broken.  Considering the punishment the 3 year old is prone to inflicting on toys, that's saying a lot!  We've got a 1 year old grandson as well, and there's no doubt in our minds that not only will he be able to have a turn with them, but they'll still be in great shape to box up for visits (hopefully!) from great-grandkids one day down the line.A number of themed motifs are being introduced by Mattel in 2015 to extend the life of its diecasts from both the original "Planes" movie and its sequel ("Fire & Rescue") - while there are several re-releases among them, the "U.S.S. Flysenhower" motif has some new ones - Falco is one, along with Delta, Jigsaw #29, Roybal, and Lucas #36 models, as well as the previously released Jolly Wrenches Dusty, Bravo & Echo.  All of these guys are part of the Navy's "Jolly Wrenches" top fighter troops, who help keep the skies safe during the Wings Around the Globe Rally in the original movie, and are especially fond of Dusty Crophopper, the underdog main character of the movie, who ends up adopting the Jolly Wrenches insignia in his gray/black version.If you're just beginning a collection for your youngster, this series of Navy characters is a sure-fire bet in terms of both quality and ability to elicit an "AWESOME!"

I know this sharp looking two-tone blue Jackson Riles plane will be a favorite of our oldest grandson, since blue is one of his favorite colors!  If you've got a youngster who's a "Planes" fanatic and you happen to be a parents or grandparent who hasn't yet seen the original movie (or need a refresher),  Jackson's in the same position as main character Dusty Crophopper, a plane with a lot of passion who's making his first attempt to qualify for the international "Wings Around the Globe Rally" at "Nebraska Trials" (the motif that appears in the corner of the packaging.)  Only the top 5 qualifiers would go on to compete... unfortunately, poor Jackson hit one of the gates and didn't make it in!  (Though main character Dusty Crophopper originally placed 6th, he was bumped up a notch after Fonzarelli - who'd placed 5th - was discovered to be using an illegal fuel and was disqualified.)Heard about a very nice boxed set they're coming out with that contains not only Jackson, but four other BRAND NEW MODELS (Fonzarelli #8, Piston #12, Firebird #16, and Hammer #17) - which doesn't happen often (usually the boxed sets contain a re-release of at least one or more characters already in our grandson's collection) - along with the one Dusty model we were never able to add (Qualifying Dusty, which is now being referred to as Strut Jetstream Dusty - first time he's available as a single, and it'll be a bonus to have him included in a boxed set!)  If you're considering a Jackson purchase, it's something to keep in mind - think we'll hold off on a Jackson purchase until then.The other planes we've heard about coming in under the "Nebraska Trials" motif (at least so far, if you have any interest in collecting) are Secord #4, Fonzarelli, Tysonitis #9, Pack Rat #10, Piston, Firebird #14, and Hammer.  We swear by these very durable Mattel 1:55 scale models, having collected both the "Cars" movies versions and now the "Planes" - all still intact after ruthless racing and flying by both a 7 year old and 3 year old grandson, with a 1 year old grandson now awaiting his turn (though I'm sure he'd like to try munching on them right now!)

I'm usually more excited about it than our grandson when Mattel adds a new one for the 1:55 scale diecast collection we started for him years ago, since I'm always offered to "be" the girls during our races (to say there isn't an overabundance of female characters in either Disney's "Cars" or "Planes" movies would be putting it mildly!)  Pack Rat (although a very minor character who had no speaking lines) reminds me somewhat of Rochelle with her color scheme - they both look like flying valentines with there red/pink/white!  But what's really neat about Pack Rat is that her pink coloring is sort of metallic looking - very neat!There are a couple of listings for Pack Rat - this one has model #CKF54, while the other is #DLK96 with a "Nebraska Trials" motif on the packaging - exact same plane.  In case you're unfamiliar with the "Planes" movie, the motif in the "Nebraska Trials" was the qualifying race in Lincoln Nebraska that all of the "wannabe's" had to complete in, with the top five moving on to the prestigious Wings Around the Globe Rally.  Unfortunately, Pack Rat wasn't one of the qualifiers, but it's great to see some of the gorgeous looking planes who DIDN'T qualify now coming out as diecasts too (I've always rooted for underdogs!)  Others in this motif series we've heard of so far are Secord #4, Fonzarelli #8, Tysonitis #9, Piston #12, Firebird #14 (another female... YES!), Gordon #15, Hammer #17, and Jackson #18.We're probably some of the biggest fans of Mattel's smaller scale line, which our experience has shown us have the tendency to hold up a bit better than the larger (1:43 scale), heavier (and more brittle) Disney Store models when it comes to the aggressive racing tactics employed in our basement family room during all of the multiple airshows we've witnessed over the past couple of years!  After all of this time (and a collection that already stands at 40 characters!), I haven't swept up a single broken propeller, wheel, etc, and seems super glue was no longer on our shopping list once we stuck with the Mattel models.

Mattel's gone to themed "motif" packaging in 2015 for its "Planes" 1:55 scale diecast models, and the "RSN Racing Sports Network" motif includes Vasquez (a Mexican helicopter painted in the green/white/red color scheme of the Mexican flag), along with another chopper named Roscoe and Colin Cowling, a blimp (Vasquez, however, has "RTV - Racing Television" printed on him rather than RSN.)Like previously released Mexican Coast Guard helicopter Hector Vector (whom we missed out on, since he came only as part of a "Jolly Wrenches" boxed set and we already had the other characters included in it), these helicopters - along with a new Navy chopper named Falco - are smaller than Mattel's "deluxe" helicopter models stemming from the sequel, "Fire & Rescue" (Blade Ranger & Windlifter, and 2015's new "Blazin' Blade Ranger")... a few inches less in length (only a bit more than 4") and not as tall.  But having been extremely pleased with the quality and durability of the Mattel models we've collected over the past several years (from both of the "Cars" as well as both of the "Planes" movies), we'll more than likely be adding these new guys to the Planes collection we began for our grandsons in 2013 when Christmas rolls around.  I remember thinking back then that the propellers would never survive our middle grandson, but am quite happy to say that hasn't been the case!Especially as compared to a larger (1:43 scale) "Team Lightning" helicopter we'd purchased from Disney Store years ago... my gosh, the landing gear was broken off of that model SO quickly - it was sharp to look at, just so much more brittle.  But a Mattel "Dinoco Helicopter" we'd purchased around the same time has been "through the wringer" with our grandsons, and is still holding up terrifically!

Perfect.  I wanted a sturdy, longer spoon to use with my slushie glasses... The stainless I use for my daily use stuff are just not quite long enough or shaped right (small enough) to really stir and grab the slushie stuff at the bottom. So, while these are for iced tea, they work for many things.  The bowl is small... smaller than your usual teaspoon which is perfect for my use.  They are heavy duty and don't feel like they will easily bend, also perfect.  Dishwasher safe.  Stainless.  They arrived in great shape, quickly (I have prime).  I will update if there are any wear or other issues.

I have several sets of Bodum glasses in this particular style and really, really like them.  I have the smaller 6 oz glasses which I usually use at the holiday with hot punch.  And bought these for a larger coffee service.  They are, of course perfect for cold drinks as well.  Because of the way this style is shaped they are also particularly comfortable to hold. They are double walled so cold drinks stay colder a bit longer, but more importantly they don't sweat.  Same with the hot drinks.  They are thin, so you don't want to bounce ice into them roughly or drop them obviously. But I put mine through the dishwasher and have yet to break one in use or cleaning.  They arrived in perfect condition, packed well and quickly with some other items I had ordered (I have prime).  I will update right away if there are any wear/use issues.

I had a set of Tweezermen tools that I had for years  - a very expensive set. At the time I complained about the price... but here I am 15+ years late and just now deciding I might like a new set....  This set is a very nice, quality set. The instruments are sharp and solid... not cheapy or "tinny" feeling... Have to admit I have no idea or use for the pokey sticks... but they are also sturdy and heavy.  I think the scissors are "nose hair" trimmers as they are rounded at the ends... don't need those either, but they too are a nice quality.  The case looks and feels like fine black leather and has a very sturdy zipper.  The case itself is about 4" x 5" (guesstimate) and about 1" thick when closed. The instruments are held in place by either and/or both a snap closure and/or an elastic strap.  Everything stays were it's supposed to be.  I tiny bit tricky the first time you pull them out, but easy afterwards. They arrived quickly and in excellent condition along with some other items I had ordered (I have prime)I will update immediately if there are any wear or other issues.  I would consider buying this brand again.

CLASSIC story. I don't care for all of James Mitchner's "states"... but because I love the Hawaiian culture, I am particularly drawn to this one.  It is a tale taking place over many years and characters.  If you are a student of Hawaiian culture, you will most likely enjoy this tale.  It is rather involved, more than a weekend for me.  But once I start it, I find it hard to put down.  Of course I have read this several times.

Holland America Cruise tags works perfectly with these.  Shared with family members also taking the cruise.  They will be able to be reused and definitely better than stapling paper to your bag that could be easily torn off.  I recommend these if you cruise!  If there are any issues to report I will update.

Tough, heavy duty, thick plastic material... use in a couple of ways... right now it holds the large, commercial-like popcorn machine!  Sooo easy to serve and store spare popcorn and supplies!  I store my large  stainless steel crab pot boiler on the bottom shelf.  It just makes things SOOO easy to move about.  Took my husband a few minutes to attach the wheels, putting the rotating wheels on the front (away from the handle) so you can more easily steer it. I will update with any issues if there are any!

I have a torn rotator cuff and while I work on recovery, I needed a comfortable sling.  The padding on the neck strap is really the winner here.  I've had many slings, this one is by far my favorite.  I am 5'8", size 14/16 female.  This worked well with easy adjustment, even with one hand.  Honestly, if you need an arm sling, this one is a total keeper.  I will update if there any issues to report.

I use this in my on site "storage unit" to move things to my house... unload groceries from my car to the house.... and any thing I can't comfortable lift.  It's the narrower version which is perfect for this use.  I have a detached garage/storage/office building.  It's a heavy duty, thick plastic type material.  My husband attached the wheels in nothing flat.  He put the rotating wheels in the front which makes it considerably easier to steering. The narrow width is easy to move through doorways.  I will update if there are any wear or other things to note.

The box arrived tortured and nearly destroyed.  I was really thinking we would open the box and see total destruction. Thankfully the lights had been packed well within the outer box and no breakage or damage to report! All's well that ends well, right?  My husband set to replacing the old florescent fixtures with these, in our garage.  They are bright, compact and will probably last longer than we will need them to.  It took my husband a couple hours to install 4 of them, including taking down the old lights, he does have experience doing such things working with lights, fixtures and wiring.  They look great and are every bit as bright and clear as the old lights in my opinion but so much more energy efficient.I will update with any wear or other concerns.

These are tiny... about 4" long.... a little brittle... but they are workable for small bites and small plates.  I bought to use with a tiny dessert cake I made.  Worked well, although I wished the prongs were a bit bigger, the handle fit the small bite dessert plates I chose to use.  They are a solid black and shiny.  They arrived quickly (I have prime) and in good shape with a few other things I had ordered.  I will update if there is anything else to share.

Daughter says my 4 year old grandson LOVES the backpack (he calls a packpack) and he is VERY excited to carry his colors and color books in it for a plane trip they will be taking in a few weeks.  I will update if there are any wear or other issues.  Came very fast (I have prime) and in great condition along with some other items I had ordered with it.

I bought these to stuff into our emergency car kits. They are nicely boxed and I left them in the box, obviously for emergency use.  I have a larger size messenger bag that put my emergency items in and these fit in perfectly. They are super lightweight and don't take up much room, however will provide critical cover and/or warmth if needed. Perfect. I will update if there are any wear or other issues.  Honestly I hope I never post an update as that would mean something awful would have occurred.

This mix is hard to find locally for me for some reason, so I order via Amazon... because I LOVE this kashi mix.  It's a great option to plain rice and in my opinion healthier because it offers 7 whole grains.  It tastes a bit nutty, but not overly so.  There are sesame seeds in it which I think are not terribly necessary.. but it's ok.  If you haven't tried it, I would say it's worth a shot if you like whole grains.

I purchased these to fit into an order from Amazon pantry... I LOVE Walkers shortbread cookies.  If you love to have a little tea in the afternoon these are such the perfect accompaniment.  Buttery and rich, but not terribly sweet. Not soft or crispy really, but not tough either.  They are the perfect texture for a thick shortbread cookie.  Of course, this is personal opinion.

Small, minimal, but ok for MINOR emergency use. I needed one for new car we purchased.  I just feel better if there is SOME method of emergency kit. I have other things in a larger messenger bag to "add" to my idea of personal emergency items.  This fit in nicely.

Bought these for our car "emergency" kits.  If you're out and about placing the lights/triangles/other safety items in bad or good weather, you'd like to be seen.  I bought really big so it would fit over coats/sweaters and my big-guy husband too.  They are thin and lightweight... not meant for heavy duty use, but that's ok.  They are in the "emergency" kit.  Just my thoughts.

It's cheap, small and easy to use.  I really like that it "auto" mutes after about 4 beeps.  Handy.  Keeps your eyes on the road.  Honestly, I use it as "reminder" to myself to watch my lead foot tendency.  The lights are a bit hard to see even on the brightest  "light" option...(lost a star for that) But, you can definitely hear it.  I honestly don't need to "see" what it is that is tracking.  It is pretty compact, but as I have seen, effective.  It has a cig lighter plug in and fits firmly in it. I have owned several radar detectors over the years, some hundreds and hundreds of dollars and the ones I hold on to are the ones that cost a couple of 20's. Surprisingly, or maybe not so, the cheaper ones seem to last a LOT longer too.  The expensive ones didn't "detect" any more effectively and offered things I would never and did never use.  Just personal choice/observation, everyone chooses for themselves. I will update with any wear or other issues.

I purchased 2 sets, one for each of our vehicles.  There are 3 lights in each set and they are small, but fairly bright.  I am storing the batteries in a baggie (not in the lights themselves) and then inside the carry case they come with.  The case is handy and I think one of the best things about this set. Keeping them all together and easy to get a hand on is good. The lights themselves are very lightweight.  The batteries, which are NOT included, do add a little weight, but I am concerned about whether or not they will be heavy enough to stay put on a road in a rainy or icy or windy weather...?? It would be nice if they weighted the bottoms quite a lot.  However, I also think in the long run, it is better than nothing.  Will update with any wear or other issues.

This brush is awesome and effective.  The "brush" portion is soft, as you would expect.  It spreads nicely and then you toss in the top shelf of your dishwasher.  I have a basket for such items and it cleans nicely there.  I have also just put in a glass with some detergent and washed it by hand.  As well as heat tolerance, I believe one of the best things about silicone is the ease of cleaning.  The handle is long, but not super long... eyeballing it.... about 12" inches or so?  The "brushes" are about 2" ?  I didn't find the length of the bristles or the handle to be too short or too long in use, both were just right to me.  I believe that it s a quality item and will last for a long time, however, I will and do update if I find any issues in wear or otherwise.  It arrived quickly (I have prime) and in good condition with a few other items I had ordered.

As with other reviewers, I report that the case does read "made in korea" inside... probably NOT LG. The "G4" shown embossed in the ad picture is NOT on the case.  The sticker on the box says "genuine OEM Original LG Leather."  Probably not.  And most likely NOT leather.  The outside is NOT at all "soft" as reported by another reviewer... at least mine is not.  It is textured and hard. It is "matte" finished, sort of leather "like."  The inside is a plastic-like material, no way to really see if the outside is leather or just a textured plastic itself.  It does fit, all the slots and holes are accurate. I have a sparkle/clear outer case (purchased at the Sprint store when I got the phone) that I use over the whole backside that provides a rubber bumper that covers the edges completely and then the outer plastic cover also provides a "lip" that protects the glass if the phone is dropped.  The pink shows through nicely, tho it is a very light pink. I think the photo is fairly close to reality (at least to the one I received). In my opinion, you'll be paying $70 for a back that is worth about $5 and that is being very generous.  Honestly, I would pass unless you just really want the "look" they advertise on TV all the time.  However reviews are ALL subjective and personal.  Everyone should make choices and decide for themselves. I will update with any wear or other issues. I hope this has helped in some way even if you don't agree. Please let me know if there is any other info that would be helpful to you.

I use a lot of smart water... and I really like that I can get it delivered to my door.  This size of Smart Water is great to carry around and have on hand.  I will continue to have it delivered as long as they carry it.

I bought this for when I am kayaking.  I a LG G4, so it's bigger. I checked it with some water in the sink... no bubbles.  However, if you think you will be using your phone through the bag... it doesn't work. I had a waterproof bag that DID work... but when I upgraded to a larger phone, of course I couldn't use it anymore as it didn't fit.  Opening it while you are kayaking is risky.  Mostly because the "bag" is a silicone type material it "sticks" to your phone and other plastic objects making it a tricky process from a kayak while you are balancing and yanking on your phone to get it out. This also risks the seams of the bag too.  Hmmm.  I am keeping the bag for use when I just can't leave it safely at home.  While a quart size ziplock bag isn't "cool" it's still the best, most economical choice for me. It arrived quickly (I have prime) along with some other things I had ordered.

I need a coin purse in my car to throw the loose change that floats around and I like to keep a couple of dollar bills in a separate part for when I need a quick "tip" somewhere OR I just need a snack.  :)  This coin purse is about 3 to 3 1/2" by about 3" (eyeballing it because I can't find my ruler at this moment) and a bit larger than I had expected.  I liked that.  It's a lovely slate gray... a cloth material... two zippered areas... the main portion and then a side slot (where I keep my dollars).  The print is an Asian type motif and very lovely. It's a perfect fit for me.  I will update if there are any wear or other issues to report  I arrived quickly (I have prime) along with some other items I ordered.

This purse is nearly an exact replica of my favorite I've had for about 15 years. As my old one has aged I keep saying, I just need a couple more inches all the way around and this bag would be perfect.  (Ha - that's what she said - I know)... My old bag looked like a huge balloon ready to pop after I have everything I need in it - I've reduced as much as I can.... It says that it is genuine leather and removable tags on the bag also say this.  The texture is very smooth... To be honest, it doesn't really feel like real leather... but who knows? The texture is so perfect, not usually the case with  leather - there is always a flaw somewhere... on the flip side, perhaps this is just a really fine quality. I am hoping that it is real and will become as supple as my old bag with some wear and use. The stitching seems really good.  I also hated the skinny strap of my old bag... the new bag has a lovely strap that is about an 1" in width... for me, just right - and so much more comfortable.... but everyone has a personal preference.  I like that I can shoulder it or crossover, which I do when I need my hands free - doesn't bother my back as much as just shouldering it. There is plenty of adjustment on the strap for the hang length as well... I am about 5'8" and there was spare length at about low belly/high hip. When you open the flap there are a couple of magnetic envelope pouches, the largest fits my new LG G4 perfectly, three slots and a zippered area.  In the main body of the bag there are two zippered organizers and a couple of side slots, that would hold a very small cell phone, keys fobs or other things you want to reach quick - too short for reading glasses, though... The bag itself isn't terribly heavy which is good. When I "load" it with everything I need it's still reasonably weighted... 3-5 lbs (?) It came with a storage/dust bag, a nice touch, although it will probably not spend much time in it. It arrived quickly (I have prime) along with some other things I had ordered.  I will be updating  with any wear or other issues as necessary.  I will try to include some pics if they get past the censors and they include my old bag for reference as well as a 12" ruler for comparison.8/27/2015... I have been using this bag exclusively for a few weeks.  It's STILL my fav.  I should also add that if you wanted to you could slide in a kindle or an IPAD if you wanted to. I have the larger Kindle and when I am going somewhere I know I will be waiting, I slide it in.
