I am seriously considering buying a second one to have a backup when this one gives out, hopefully years from now.  :)  Could go with a different color... but honestly I usually buy the black as it goes with everything, all year.  But that's just me. I did get a like smudge of something grayish/white.  I used a little leather cleaner and wiped it off, a very slight amount of black come off too, but didn't leave any noticeable trace.  So I am ok with that.  It has NOT left any color on my clothing.  And I have been in damp area with rain/mist and/or sweaty humidity - so... I think that is good.  I will continue to update with any issues or other thoughts.

These napkins are a lovely deep turquoise and went beautifully along with the bright colored plates I chose for a party I had. They are a bit stiff, but worked. The were as described, a "luncheon" size.  Again, perfect for me. The arrived quickly (I have prime) and in great condition along with some other things I had ordered.

I wanted something a bit nicer looking than the usual "plastic ware" and these are perfect.  It's hard to tell these are plastic until you actually touch them.  They are a bit "shiner" than most stainless steel I guess... but still... I liked the effect. I was wishing they were a bit thicker, but over all they are good.  They arrive quickly (I have prime) and in great condition along with several other things I had ordered.

These are pretty ordinary plastic plates...but I just hate a flimsy paper plate.  The colors are very bright when stacked together... a bit less when you actually have them in hand, separate, more a "clear" color.  You can reuse them... hand wash only.  These are the 9" rounds... with the curved edge there is about 8 3/4" of flat space - just eyeballing it.  Perfect for appetizers or dessert.  I use these for "seconds" when people have already put aside their originals. They arrived quickly (i have prime) and in excellent condition with some other items I ordered.

These are pretty ordinary plastic plates...but I just hate a flimsy paper plate.  The colors are very bright when stacked together... a bit less when you actually have them in hand, separate.  You can reuse them... hand wash only.  These are the 6" rounds... with the curved edge there is about 5 3/4" of flat space - just eyeballing it.  Perfect for appetizers or dessert.  I use these for "seconds" when people have already put aside their originals. They arrived quickly (i have prime) and in excellent condition with some other items I ordered.

I have several old eagle creek travel shoe bags (5+ ? years old) and I was so excited to get some additional bags!  As is often the case with "new" versions, there have been some changes... sadly the new ones (these) seem to be thinner, less durable material, feels less rubbery to me than the older version.... and the handles are thinner, more narrow, less heavy duty braid as well.  We'll see. I love this style and will use them. Initially I thought they were a tad smaller, but when I flattened them out and compared with an old style, they may be slightly smaller, but not really enough to notice.  There is enough room for one pair of larger style shoes (big heels/wedges) or three or four pairs of flipflops or maybe two pairs of flats with shoe tops...depending on the size of your shoe (mine are generally 8 to 9) There is a zipper, which, again, seems less durable but I remain hopeful. I like that my shoe bottoms don't touch my clothes as I am traveling. And with the zipper, the shoes stay in the bag as opposed to drawstring style.  If color is important to you, they are a darkish gray, zipper and handle is black.  They arrived quickly (I have prime) and in great condition with some other items I ordered. I will update if there are any wear or other issues to report.
I bought these with the holders to use at family buffets.  They really add a touch of class I think.  And not just for name/place holders!  I will update if there are any worthy issues.

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while, I was pleased to receive this A261 Dash Camera in return for an independent and unbiased review.  Pleased to say its excellent.Please Note:  Unusually, there are two different Dash Camera products for sale on the same page.  This is a review of the A261 - the small slightly square looking device, not the longer horizontal device.What is it?--------------A tiny little device that sits attached to the windscreen to record your journey, and (in the unfortunate event of an accident), record what happened in fantastic high quality HD (1920x1080) video.  It was recently reported in the news, that in the UK video footage is now being accepted by insurance companies as evidence in the event of an accident - so a useful device.Whats it like---------------Measuring just under 3 tall by 2.5 wide and an inch deep, its the the smallest dash camera Ive reviewed, but its still a pretty neatly designed device, and weights only 96g (to put this in context an iPhone 6 or Samsung Galaxy is 133g).  It will record in full HD (1080p) or 720p although youll need a large Micro-SD card to fit a lot of recording on it with about 130Mb a minute for full 1080p footage.It also has a built in GPS to record your exact location and speed (which may be critical evidence in the event of an accident which was not your fault).In terms of design, it has a 2 inch (diameter) rear LCD screen to show whats being recorded, and 4 buttons to cycle through the numerous menus.  Pleased to say the buttons are nicely placed at the base of the screen making it easy to navigate when the device is fitted to the car.The device comes with a small and quite nicely designed 2.5 diameter suction cup to secure it to the windscreen.  A small plastic catch is used to secure the camera to the suction cup which is handy as its easy to detatch and remove it if you leave the vehicle for a while.  It also comes with a hugely long (3.5m) power cable and a cigarette lighter adapter which is a great bonus.  Sounds daft, but it means you can replace the adapter with a two USB socket device meaning you can power your smartphone and camera at the same time.  (Ive also reviewed a product from a household name where the cable was fixed to the adapter, making it useless if you have two or more devices in the car).Finally, you also get a short USB to Micro-USB cable (nice touch, means you can download video to your computer without removing the cable from the car), and what appears to be a comprehensive instruction manual - which unfortunately turns out to only have 10 pages - and lots of languages.  Still - it was pretty easy to operate.In terms of set-up and use, the 2 inch although it was a pity the battery on mine was flat when it arrived (although that may be just because it was a review item).  All settings seemed fairly logical, and it was pretty easy to fix to the windscreen with an extra long cable which was very useful as it means you can hide it discretely out of the way.  Oddly enoughIt didnt come with any CD or software - but Ive found most of this to be pretty usefulness anyway - so no loss there.In everyday use I found it a breeze to use.  Recorded image quality was excellent, (both day and night), and its nice to see this will take a micro-USB card up to 64 Gb (not the usual 32Gb of most devices).  I found the LCD screen a little small, but once Id set it up, I didnt bother to look at it again, and it was nice to see it automatically powered on when I turned the ignition.Overall, a nicely designed device.  Aside from lane detection system (which warns you if youre drifting out of your lane), it doesnt have lots of useless features and toys which I personally find great to play with initially - then completely ignore.Overall - gets a thumbs up from me.Whats good about it?--------------------------* Video quality is excellent both during the day and night - it was easy to identify the all important licence plates of other vehicles* Built in rechargeable battery - means you can use it away from the car if needed* Easy to access and use buttons - seriously - this is important - some of these devices are a pain to operate* Extra long cable with a USB plug at the end, plus a separate cigarette lighter adapter - great as you can replace the adapter, and the long cable is a bonusWhat's not so good?----------------------------* The instruction manual was a little brief - but I admit it passed the bloke test - could I get it working without instructions.* Its a pity the charger is not a dual USB - which would mean you could charge your smartphone at the same time - but these are cheap on Amazon* Doesnt come with a Micro-SD card - but these things never do.  I bought a 16g Micro-SD from Amazon for about 5/$5.Conclusion---------------Smashing dash cam - works a treat

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while, I was pleased to be offered this desktop charger in return for an independent and unbiased review.Measuring just 6 x 2.5 by 1 thick and weighing only 192g (slightly more than an iPhone 6 at 133g), its a surprisingly dinky charging device, and would make a great travel charger, or to keep the entire family powered from a single socket at home.It comes complete with a standard plug and power cable with a figure of 8 socket which plugs into the rear, with a sequence of six USB sockets on the top - each placed with a half inch gap between them, so theres plenty of space for all your mobile devices to charge at the same time.  This is handy to know, as it means you can plug in a European plug and cable - provided it has a figure of 8 connection which is a common socket on electrical devices.In terms of design, its nicely made, sollid build quality and very small.  Again to put this in context, Ive reviewed another charger which had a separate external wall charger which was bigger than this entire device.  It also has a subtle blue power light which comes on when you plug it in so you know its powered on at the wall.  So full marks for design.In terms of functionality,  you can plug in up to six separate USB plugs to charge anything from a Kindle, eCigarette, iPhones, iPads or Android tablets, and they each draw as much (or as little) power as needed.  Again this is a nice design feature, as Ive seen other devices which have separate sockets for tablet computers (which draw lots of power) or smartphones (which draw less).  In total you get 50 watts (evenly distributed with 10A) of power, and it certainly worked well for me with an iPhone 6, iPad Air 2, iPad 3 a Kindle and iPhone 5S all charging at the same time.The real killer feature of this device however (and so obvious Im amazed nobody else has managed to implement this already), is the USB sockets are reversible.  A tiny feature - but its really irritating to find yourself plugging and un-plugging USB devices as they only fit one way.With this device, you plug in a USB any way - it works correctly every time.In summary, a tiny desk top charger, small enough to take travelling but with enough power for six devices at once.Gets my thumbs up.

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while I was pleased to receive these bluetooth headphones in return for an independent and unbiased review.Open up the quite smart packaging to reveal a really quite impressive pair of light weight comfortable headphones with quite impressive sound quality for the price.  Build quality is great, and theyre as cool in real life as in the photos with a piano black glossy band over the head, and silver plastics with steel headband extenders for additional strength and durability.Overall look and feel is one of quality, and the ear cushions (although a little small for my ears), are soft and comfortable - even when wearing these for several hours.  Its also nice to see they fold away for storage, although they dont come with a carry case which is a pity.In addition to the headphones, you get a short 6 page instruction guide, and a micro-USB cable (to charge them) along with a standard 3.5mm Aux cable if you prefer to be wired.  I was disappointed to find mine flat straight out of the box, so left them plugged in for a couple of hours to charge up, after which I found they ran for what must have been nearly 24 hours over the coming week.  As with nearly all these devices you dont get a charger, but you can charge them from a standard USB port on a computer or use a smartphone charger.Once fully charged, press the power button on the right earpiece to power them on, and theres a volume up/down button which also serves to switch tracks.In terms of use, the sound quality is really quite impressive at this price point - theyre certainly punching above their weight.  While Im no audiophile, so I cant comment on the treble response or mid-range highs - theyre clearly stand out terrific.While writing this review, Ive listened to a series of test tracks including, the solid bass beats of Radioheads High and Dry, and the haunting deep echoey lyrics of Exit music (for a film) - used in Baz Luhrman's version of "Romeo & Juliet" - great film.  Bill Withers - Aint no Sunshine - just sounds wonderfully smooth.  While the punchy rock in Should I stay or Should I Go (The Clash) just sounds terrific (always a good test track), and finally the punchy bass beats of Blue Monday (New Order) is just wonderful!Even on soft quiet tracks like Hollow Ponds by Damon Albarn, (ex lead singer of Blur and Gorillaz), sounds wonderful.  You can hear his fingers moving up and down the acoustic guitar, and the haunting backing sound of children playing.  The separation (the fact you can identify and listen to individual instruments), is just wonderful.Overall, Im pretty impressed by these.  If they were just a wired pair of headphones Id be pleased.  As it is, the fact theyre wireless bluetooth is just a fantastic bonus.The lack of a carry case is a minor issue, and overall they get my thumbs up.Highly Recommended.

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while I was pleased to receive these digital bathroom scales in return for an independent and unbiased review.Having used these for a month now, I can honestly report they work a treat.  At 13.5 square, you get a huge area to stand on, with a large 3 x 1.25 bright blue LED display that even if youre short-sighted like me its easy to see.The main plate is covered in a thick (5mm) glass cover which is both hygienic and easy to wipe clean, and the device itself is nicely thin at just 1.25 which means its easy to stow away if youre bathroom is not large enough to leave it lying around.  At 2.1Kg in weight, its also light enough to lift and carry about, but certainly feels good quality and well built.In terms of functionality, it comes with 4 AAA batteries which are easily installed, and displays your weight in old money (Pounds) or new money (Kilograms).  Its a pity it doesnt show your weight in Stones and Pounds (that Im more used to), but I quickly adapted to comparing weight in Kilograms.  I did compare the accuracy to my previous (very expensive, very heavy) scales, and can confirm these are also very accurate.Of course the USP (Unique Selling Point) of this device is it uses a bluetooth connection to pair with your phone, and you can record, and track your weight directly into the iChoice App.  I have to admit, while initially I was quite pleased by the idea, Im not convinced it works very well.  Firstly, I seldom take my smartphone into the bathroom with me, (expensive electronics and water dont work together very well), and while it does quickly connect via bluetooth, I found the app rather over-complex, and yet another place to store information.Personally, I just ignore the bluetooth aspect, and record the information in the Apple Health App - Im sure if youve a fitness tracking device youll be able to store your weight in that as well.So, as a bathroom scales I found it terrific.  A large easy to clean surface area, a huge bright display, but narrow and only 2Kg (so easy to stow away), its a hit in our house.  Have to say the App was less useful, but thats just my opinion.  As a set of scales theyre great.Highly Recommended.

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while, I was pleased to be receive this tablet computer for free in return for an independent assessment.  Ill concentrate less on the technical jargon and numbers and more on the experience.  After all, it doesnt matter if it has a Quad Core 32 bit processor with 8 gigabytes of storage if it doesnt work very well.Before I start, lets put this in context.  For the price of a Nexus 7 or iPad mini, you could buy several of these tablets, and still have enough money left for a massive 32Gb SD card.  Youre looking at the value end of the spectrum, but the real question - is it any good?While you could compare devices based purely by specification  (eg. 16Gb of storage is double the 8Gb size), its often quite a subjective area.  For example, how do you assess sound quality produced from a tablet computer.  Ive therefore given this device a percentage score in a series of categories.* 100% means I think its just fantastic. The best you can buy.  For example an iPad Air 2 (costing ten times the price) would for example get 100% for design and build quality.* 50% means I think its great - about average.So here goes.*** Overall Design ***  80% ***Clearly this is aimed as a first tablet computer for a child, and thats reflected in the child friendly packaging.  Opening it up, youll find a standard sized 7 tablet computer, a thick rubber case to protect it, and a wall transformer and micro-USB cable to charge the device.  It also comes with a short user guide which is surprisingly good, including photos and screen shots to illustrate the basics on how to get to going.Clearly this device gets bonus points for the thick foam case which gives lots of protection.  Its light and small enough for little hands, and has survived some heavy handed use by my 3 year old granddaughter.*** Screen ***  60% ***As with most budget tablets, the screen is plastic rather than the Gorilla Glass of the Nexus, and theres noticeable screen reflection  - so you wont be able to use this in bright sun-light - but thats not uncommon.  While the 1024 x 600 screen resolution was acceptable, colours were decidedly muted, even with the brightness turned up to maximum which is likely to drain the battery.  I also found there was a significant lag (often up to 2 seconds) when the device was switched from portrait to landscape mode which I personally found irritating, and Im sure a child would quickly tire of.*** Sound Quality *** 40% ***Sound quality wasnt brilliant (again as youd expect at this price), and unfortunately it doesnt come with a bluetooth connection.  This is a major issue for me, as I often listen to music on these devices connected to a bluetooth speaker.  It also means you cant connect a bluetooth keyboard, or in fact any wireless device.  Youre limited to using a pair of wired headphones (none-supplied), and sound quality was OK but way too quiet to listen to anything in a noisy environment.*** Cameras *** 40% ***As youd expect theres a front and rear facing camera (although details were not provided), so you can take snaps or video, or use it for Skype.  Again, quality was not brilliant, and in fact colours were really muted - almost sepia in colour despite being shot in bright sun-light.  Video likewise was very poor quality even outdoors.*** Web Browsing *** 40% ***I quickly connected it to Google and my photos, eMail and address book were immediately available.  I then tested it on a few web pages including the image rich Daily Mail web site.  While its unlikely your child will watch this web site, its an excellent test of the processor speed on whats a fairly basic function - navigating web pages.  Sorry to say, that while it scrolled up and down the screen pretty quickly there was a an awful delay in zooming into or out of web pages which is a real pity.  I tried it on a few YouTube screens, and video played OK, although again, the delay between selecting a video and it playing was irritating, and sound very quiet.*** Game Playing *** 40% ***While I wouldnt expect a device at this price point to run the most expensive, complex games, I do have one favourite Air Wings which has some basic 3D graphics, and runs on everything else.  Its a useful test, as I try it on every device, so can compare the experience.  Again, sorry to say, the lag between tilting the screen, and the aircraft actually moving on screen made it really hard to use.  My worry is a child would equally find it difficult, and just give up.*** Storage *** 90% ***In terms of storage it comes complete with 8Gb of space although not all of that is fully available, and I found out of the box there was about 7.7Gb left.  Of course, you can always add a 32Gb Micro SD card for as little as 10.00 on Amazon which should be enough for most people to store books, videos and music.*** Battery Life *** 80% ***Finally, you should expect to charge this every day.  I got about 3-4 hours out of it before I needed to charge it.  Unusually, in addition to a standard micro-USB connection (to connect the tablet to a computer for backup), this device has a separate pin socket for charging, and it comes with the UK plug.*** Value for Money *** 90% ***In terms of value for money, this really is terrific.  At the time of writing, this is one of the cheapest tablet computers on Amazon, and provided you take account of the limitations, its terrific value for money.  So, OK, it doesnt have a metal back and gorilla glass screen of an iPad mini - but it does almost everything an iPad can do at a fraction of the cost.*** Overall Conclusion *** 70% ***In conclusion, if youve never owned a tablet computer before, and want to dip your toe in the market, this is a functional (if rather limited) device - the lack of a a bluetooth connection is particularly poor.  The screen and sound quality could be better, it could be a bit quicker switching from landscape to portrait, but youre getting a usable tablet for little money.Technically, this is not a bad device.  A 1.2 GHz processor and 8Gb of storage on a 7 tablet computer is certainly a good starting point.  Even the lack of bluetooth and poor sound quality could be forgiven, although Im less impressed by the muted screen colours both in use in photographs.  For me, what really lets this down though, is the lack of responsiveness.  A tablet is designed to be tilted from horizontal and vertical, and should be responsive in basic games.  Likewise, the fact the screen doesnt immediately respond to two finger zooming is a concern, although web sites and you tube display fine.My advice is if you only intend to use this for displaying video from BBC iPlayer, Amazon Instant Video or You Tube itd be fine, but I think a child would become quickly frustrated if playing games on this.  Having said that, its useable, and as long as youre aware of the limitations its a good starter tablet computer.

Having reviewed on Amazon for a while, I was pleased to receive this replacement metal Apple Watch band in return for an independent and unbiased review.Like many people, I've been pleased with my Apple Watch, but dismayed at the hugely expensive Apple watch bands. I'm sure they're top quality, but they're eye waterinngly expensive.Equally, I was a little skeptical of the cheaper 3rd party alternatives, but I've been pleasantly surprised by the quality of this particular watch band.Measuring 800mm long by 22mm wide, it's really quite impressively made, with machine milled steel links, and has a wonderfully "chunky" feel to it. It clips on and off from the watch within seconds which means you can quickly change it, for example to the rubber one to go off to the gym, but it adds a level of style and quality.The "chunky" feel of this watch is partly due to the heavy weight. At 91g it has a nice heft to it, and feels great on the wrist. To put this in context an Sports model with the standard black band (ie. watch and band) is 56g in weight.The release catch requires both finger and thumb to open it which means it's highly unlikely to accidentallly pop open, and risk losing your watch. Even if it did, it's the "closed" design, so the strap will stay loose on your wrist, but I wore it for a weekend, and didn't have any problems at all.Finally, the fact it comes with a device to adjust the size is a bonus, as it saves you a visit (plus the cost) to a jeweller to have it adjusted. Top marks for that.My only advice is to clearly request the colour you need. I have a "Space Grey" Apple Sport model, but received the silver band, and it just doesn't go with this model at all. I took it into the Apple store to compare, and it looks great on the Steel "Watch" model which has a more silver colour.I do think this would look brilliant in the grey colour though.Overall, I think you'll be delighted with this watch band. Fantastic build quality, lovely finish (absolutely no sharp edges or rough patches), and a great price.Highly Recommended.

Theres an awful lot of these "power banks available on Amazon, but I personally prefer these smaller sizes as youll always have them with you.  While its great to have enough power to keep you going for days, I personally find Ive only ever used mine in an emergency.At just under 4 inches long by an inch thick, this little device sits nicely in the hand.  Designed to be kept in a pocket or handbag, wrapped in white plastic shell, it weights just 69g (to put this in context, much less than an iPhone 6 at 135g), so you can carry it with you everywhere.The battery is rated at 3,000  mAh (the higher the better).  To put this in context, here's the battery capacity (mAh) of some of the more popular smartphones:-* Google Nexus 5 - 2,300 mAh* Samsung Galaxy S3 - 2,100 mAh* Samsung Galaxy S4 - 2,600 mAh* Samsung Galaxy S5 - 2,500 mAh* Samsung Galaxy S6 - 2,600 mAh* Apple iPhone 5 - 1,400 mAh* Apple iPhone 5S - 1,570 mAh* Apple iPhone 6 - 1,810 mAh* Apple iPhone 6 Plus (Phablet) 2,915 mAhEach of the above are estimates (you never quite get 100% efficiency out of a battery), but theyll give you an idea of the power youll have.  Certainly enough to charge your smartphone in an emergency.What's Good about it?-----------------------------* Nice little device, small and light weight, but sits nicely in the hand* Solid build quality - should last for years* Comes with a USB to Micro-USB cable (to charge your android smartphone)What's not so good?* It doesnt come with a wall charger or USB to iPhone cable (but these devices never do).* As it doesnt have a light, theres no indication how much charge it has, so keep it topped up if you use it regularlyConclusion---------------Small and lightweight - great for emergenciesDisclosure: I was kindly sent this by the manufacturer to give an independent unbiased review.

This is a heavy duty pan that fits our Calphalon XL Digital Convection Oven perfectly.  It is described as a heavy duty pan and it is  made of impact-resistant 16-guage aluminum.  It does not warp in high heat and it cleans up easily.  The price is right for this quality pan.

This Remington hair dryer is supposed to be superior to 'ordinary' dryers because it has an advanced ceramic coating on the grills.  This is purported to give frizz-free hair dried with the thing.  Maybe it does, but it hasn't dramatically evidenced much to that end.  I guess it couldn't hurt.The main things that stand out about this dryer is how well it is made, the rubber-like finish and how versatile it is.  With two attachment heads, 3 heat settings and 2 speed settings the appliance has a lot of choices built in.The cool shot setting is a plus as is forcefulness of the air stream. The purplish color is attractive and it just seems like it would last for years of use.The Remington AC2015C is an excellent dryer and it is accurately priced in the mid-range for similar units.

I like these high quality UGG slippers and they look great.  They are warm, soft and generally comfortable to wear.  However, the heel is cut a bit low and wide and the slippers tend to slip in that area when walking. The soles are heavy and do not bend easily.  Perhaps with some 'breaking in' the soles will ease up and improve those slipping heels.  I do like these slippers, but that slipping heel cost them a star in my opinion.
Smaller than I thought it would be and the drawstring broke almost immediately. Pretty, but not so good.
Good for the scalp and feels good too.  It is well made and easy to hold. Try it you will like it.
Stylish,bright and work from night to day as they should.  Well built, easy to put together and to place.

These plastic razor blades are terrible at removing burnt on junk from a ceramic cook top.  They are not sharp enough or substantial enough to scrape much of anything off of a ceramic top. And I am talking about minor spots with a blade mounted firmly in a sturdy holder. I have no idea what these plastic blades would be good for, but cleaning cook tops ain't one of them.

This is another model among many in the George Foreman line.  There are George Forman grills in a round shape, rectangular ones, lids with vents, some with temperature gauges, several with stands for outdoor use,  A few with removable cooking plates and grills in various colors.  This one (the GFO240S) is some of all of these.This is a basic outdoor/indoor electric grill and probably near the bottom of the line for George Foreman grills.  It comes in one color (gray), it has a lid without a vent and is round without a temperature gauge and the grilling plate is not removable. However it has the essentials and probably grills as well as the other George Forerman models.The GFO240S is certainly a very nice electric grill. It is well built and easy to assemble.  It does a great job with cooking meat, fish and veggies.  It is supposed to be large enough for 15 servings.  I have not put that to the test, but the grill is quite largeabout twenty inches across (240 square inches they say).The grill has the standard plug-in temperature switch found on George Foreman electric grills with adjustable control and indicator light. The grill has a removable stand used for outdoor cooking, but the main unit can be detached and the grill can then be used on a counter or table. The big aluminum lid has a sturdy keep cool handle.Grilling on an electric grill is simple and doesn't require propane or charcoal or have flare ups, but for that convenience one must give up a bit of smoky flavor. A steak or burger still show sear marks and the meat is juicy and tasty. Peppers, mushrooms and onions cook nicely and also show the desirable grill marks.The non-stick grilling plate is easy to clean with a paper towel and there is a removable grease tray.There is a brief instruction booklet that comes with the grill and it includes some interesting recipes.I will be using my George Foreman Grill for occasions where my big Weber gas grill is not appropriate or when I don't want to go the propane route. There are times when simply plugging in an electric grill is preferable to messing around with LP tanks or charcoal. This grill is a perfect choice where apartment or condo restrictions forbid gas and charcoal grills.If you are looking for a basic, no frills, electric grill this George Foreman GFO240S will fill the bill.
A sturdy measuring cup with a good design.  It looks like it will last a long time.
Expensive, but worth the price.  Heavy metal construction with glass globe.  Easy to assemble and place.
Nice little brush, but it clogs up with the stuff it cleans and has to be cleaned itself.

Finally, a smart phone mount that works. It screws down to size--no springs.  It holds my Samsung phone and iPod firmly while attached to a tripod. This version of the RetiCAM comes with several sizing rods that make the mount very versatile.

These sox are great.  They are light weight and do not constrict my lower legs. They are a combination size so wewe a little bit large.  They don't slidevdown all that much and remain  comfortable a ll day. Just the thing for avoiding swelling in the legs from poor circulationy in theblegs. They are light weight and look good.  This is my second pair.

After a professional hearing exam and consultation with an audiologist I was advised to get a $2000 hearing aid and probably one of those for each ear.  Faced with such a large investment in a device(s) that might not do much more than just amplify sounds.  I am 82 years old with a significant hearing loss in one ear, but I really didn't want to spend so much money for a high tech hearing aid or maybe two of them.The New Digital Hearing Amplifier seemed like it might be worth a try.  I thought at $60 it would be good experiment.  I had already tried three of the really cheap gadgets like the TV Ears, Whisper Rechargeable amplifier and such.  Those cheap ones were not very good and a couple of them really didn't do a lot except make things louder and sounds were hollow and unpleasant.  None of them fit very well. The New Digital Amplifier could have been another one of those--it wasn't.The New Digital Amplifier is smaller than the lower priced and junky devices.  I would say the size of the New Digital Amplifier is somewhere in-between the large size of the cheap gadgets and the small size of the bona fide behind the ear hearing aids.  It is comfortable to wear and will work in either ear.  i wear mine with glasses and have no problems. The controls (on/off, volume and mode) are easy to reach and adjust.  The 'mode' adjustment is a high frequency/low frequency switch. Once the adjustments are made the amplifier holds them so one doesn't have to re-set the device each time it is powered up.The color is tan and does not stand out all that much positioned behind the ear.  However, I suppose this device is not for the very vain. There are ear tips in three sizes, three batteries and a cleaning brush provided in a nice storage case.I am using only one New Digital Amplifier and I am amazed at what I am experiencing with it. I can hear the TV, voices and ambient sounds I had not heard in years.  There is no humming or echo and the background noises are minimal albeit not blocked completely. I did encounter a feedback squeal when I sometimes accidentally cupped my hand over the microphone and speaker at the same time.  That was my own fault.The amplifier is powered by a single LR44 battery, but it is not a battery hog and replacement batteries are quite cheap.  I prefer this battery powered design preferable to the rechargeable type.  Having used a rechargeable amplifier I can tell you it is a lot easier to replace a little aspirin sized battery than wait all night for a recharge.There are some competition amplifiers out there that appear to be similar in looks and I do not know anything about them, but the New Digital Amplifier was a good choice for me and I am completely satisfied with it.

A good buy.  The Panasonic quality is built in and I like the base station with hand set attached.  Have been using these phones for months now and they work very well.  The KX-TG4773B phones are full of fancy features that I don't really need, but it is nice to have them and some people will appreciate the versatility.  I have been very satisfied with these phones.

The socks are working OK, but the size (14-17) I picked was more like a 17 than a 14.  I  like the socks, but will order a smaller size next time. I wanted socks without a tight elastic top because of my pre-diabetic legs and these are working for that. I suppose I should have known that socks purported to fit four different sizes wouldn't.
I should say my granddaughter loves it.  The speaker is cute, simple to use and sounds pretty good plugged into an iPad Mini.

Just what I needed.  It comes in a sturdy storage box and the caliper is plenty accurate for the home woodworker, handy man or amateur auto mechanic.  The quality in this tool is OK, but it could stand some finishing and polish.  For the price this is probably the best caliper you will find.

Still haven't listened to all of the tunes on this album.  It was a good value on Amazon.com and the audio quality is generally good.  I do wish the that many of the songs from concerts had been recorded without the commentary and applause.
Good quality, good fit and did the job keeping the back of a closeup lens protected.

For the past 3 years I have been using a 27" 1920x1080 Asus monitor for my PTC Creo CAD work.  I like the size of that monitor, but being that it's a TN panel I find it to be fatiguing after a long day.  My experience with IPS displays in several of my Chromebooks (HP Chromebook 11, Toshiba Chromebook 2, and a Pixel) made me realize how much easier it is to look at these IPS/PLS displays for extended periods of time.  When I saw that the price of this monitor had dropped to the mid $400's I snapped one up.  I connected this Asus to my Nvidia Quadro 5000 via Display Port, and it looks and works great for me.  For my CAD work everything looks great, and I find that I feel much better after a long day of looking at this screen that I had with my old monitor.  I was a bit concerned that the Creo text and icons would be too small, but things look really good (albeit smaller), and I actually like that I can have more icons and tree items visible without having to expand menus or scroll the tree.  I like all of the connectivity options, and the fact that all of the various cables were included.  I like having the ability to adjust the height, which I couldn't do with my old Asus.  And, the cheap built-in speakers actually sound okay (for system sounds).  I really like that the bezel around the screen is a matte finish, because the glossy bezel of my old monitor always showed the reflection of the lights in the ceiling (very annoying).  The non-glare coating (as opposed to a true matte screen) also works well.The only issue I have run into is a single stuck (on red) pixel.  I hoped it might un-stick itself after a couple of long days, but unfortunately, it hasn't.  I wouldn't fret too much about a single pixel if it were in one of the corners, but this one is near the center of the screen right in line with my left eye.  Even with it's tiny size, I am constantly aware of this pixel; especially with the light background of Creo's main window.  It has just been too distracting for me, so I decided to do a return and see what happens.  But, I still love this monitor and I'm hoping for the best with the new one.  It actually amazes me that you can have nearly 3.7 million pixels on a panel and only have 1 bad one, but it's also crazy how much that 1 tiny pixel can stand out when it's right in the middle of the screen.For my specific needs this is a great monitor, and I'm hoping to get many years of service from it.  If anyone has any "Creo specific" questions about this monitor, I'd be happy to answer as best I can.I'll be sure to update this review when I get the replacement monitor.I received my replacement monitor, and it also had a single goofy pixel in almost the same area as the original.  However, this one only shows up against a black background.  Since I never really work with a black background, I decided I'd keep it rather than continuing to mess around with doing exchanges.  Another thing I have noticed, now that I have been using my replacement for a few days, is that the fan on my first unit was seriously loud.  This new one is much quieter, and the monitor also seems to run cooler.  I even did a test where I cranked up the heat in my office, and while the fan was audible, it was not loud at all; even in a pretty hot environment.

I have purchased several of these cables over the years, and for the price they are very well built, however, I did have one go bad after only a few months of use.  Still, an excellent value for an HDMI cable.

As far as I can tell after a thorough inspection, this is NOT a knock-off product; which is a good thing.  However, I wouldn't call it "factory fresh" either.  The unit I received functions fine; it charges at the same rate as my original charger, and the indicator light looks and functions like the original as well.  But, it was in no way packaged as it would have been had it come from Google.  The cord looked as though it had been re-wrapped, and didn't have the same little tapes holding the loops together that the original had.  It should also be noted that while you get the charging block and the removable plug insert, it does not include the extension cord with the grounded plug (even though it's shown in the picture).  The little 2GB flash drive works fine as well.  In the end, this was a great deal for the convenience of having another charger for my Pixel.

Worked without issue with my Chromebook, and I like that you can change the DPI sensitivity so easily (especially since Chrome OS is too slow with a lot of mice).  The L/R buttons have nice snappy clicks that give really good feedback as well.  The problem I have is that this thing just felt so cheap in my hand, and it was far too light for my own personal preference.  I didn't care for the feel of the scroll wheel either.  There are much better mice out there for only a few bucks more, but if you need something on the really cheap, this thing will do the job.

Great product and a great seller.  I picked these up for a friend, and the product arrived much faster than I expected.  He did the install yesterday, and said they went in very easy.  He also reports that the lifts work perfectly for his application.  The trunk doesn't fly open when released, and it stays open after it's up all the way

My headphone stable includes the likes of Sennheiser HD600's, Beyerdynamics DT-880's and AKG Q701's powered by Amps from Schiit, Nuforce, and Little Dot, so one might question why I would get so much enjoyment out of these Momentums.  The fact is, these are some fun little headphones if you use them for what they were designed for.  Head over to iTunes, Spotify, or Google Play Music and look at whats mostly topping the pop charts these days, or drop into a club and listen to what the DJs are playing; youll understand the the type of music that these phones sound the best with.  Classical, Jazz, Singer-Songwriter, Adult Contemporary your style; then there are much better options out there.  Drake, Nicki Minaj, Ariana Grande, Zedd, David Guetta, Astrix; you will probably really like these.  These headphones werent designed and tuned to be audiophile headphones, they were set up to play back todays popular music.The efficiency of these headphones is excellent, meaning they can play loud with much less power (like what youd get from a phone, tablet, or laptop).  The bass can hit plenty hard (try Astrix High on Mel), though it cant always reach as deep as Id prefer and sometimes falls off too soon.  However, I noticed that the more I used them, the better the lows sounded.  The highs roll off pretty quickly too, but the mids are well represented, and for a headphone with a DJ Tune these Momentums sound excellent.  Ive found the imaging to be pretty decent as well (for a set of closed phones).  The build quality is top notch, and I like all the available colors and different materials used.  They can feel a little tight after a while, which is to be expected for on-ear headphones, but the clamping force will soften up a bit as you use them, and you can always relax them by working the headband a bit.  Its important that you angle the cups properly and place them on your ears/head correctly.  The discomfort level can really take off quickly if you dont wear these properly on your head.  The material used for the cups is very soft, never itchy, and has never made me sweat.  I use Android phones, so I cant speak to the function of the remote (I believe it will have limited function with an Android), and if I did have one gripe with many of the Sennheiser phones I have used, its that the chords seem to stay kinked forever.  I appreciate the included bag and soft-case, but since the headphones dont fold up, the overall package is rather large for an on-the-go headphone.If you use these Momentums with a laptop/desktop computer you can really make them sing with an external DAC/headphone amp.  I use mine mostly with my Pixel, and when I run them through my NuForce uDAC-3 the sound is very impressive.  In the end; for the buck-twenty I paid for these they were a great investment.

I've been using Koss Porta Pros at work on a daily basis for almost 20 years now, and they still amaze me.  But, I have been finding that there are more and more times when I'd like to have a little more isolation from the noise of the office without having to turn up the music to a level that's distracting.  I have plenty of closed headphones at home, but I'd rather leave a pair of $40 headphones laying around the office than sets that are far more expensive.  When I saw that these Koss ProDJ100's were going for cheap, I ordered a pair.  Based on the response curves I found online, I knew I'd have to do some equalizing to tune them more to my liking.  These just aren't the kind of headphones that you can plug right in and get some nice natural sound out of.  I plugged them into my little NuForce uDAC-2 and fired them up.  It did take a bit of time, but I was able create a curve I was happy with for the volume I listen at.  After a week, they had settled in a bit, and I made some minor adjustments, and after 2 weeks I really felt like I had them dialed in pretty well (for a set of $40 cans).  I was hoping I could get some sound similar to my Sony MDR-V6's (that I run without EQ), but I had to settle for "close enough".  I know that some users disagree with the "DJ" labeling of these headphones, but with the way they are tuned I did find that they gave the best overall sound when using them with that style of music (when listening without an EQ).  One thing I did not like was the fact the sound (mostly on the low end) would change quite a bit if I didn't maintain a tight seal to my head with the earcups.  I have experienced this issue to a much lesser degree when using other closed headphones, but with the Koss' it was very pronounced.  And that led to the final issue I had.  I probably would have kept them, even though I own a lot of other headphones, but in the end they were just too uncomfortable for me and I found I could not wear them for any extended period of time.  It wasn't really the size of the earcup, it was the shape.  The MDR-V6's have small cups, but they are oval shaped.  The small round cups on the ProDJ100's either hurt the top of my ear or the bottom; depending on how I had them adjusted (and I don't consider my ears large at all).I could have lived with the sound of these headphones considering the occasional use they would get, but I found them to be too uncomfortable so I sent them back.

This is just a flat out fantastic case.  I purchased the 12.5"-13.3" model for my Chromebook Pixel and it's an excellent fit.  The case is very well made, and the lining is really nice as well.  It's nice to have a big pockets front and back that can hold the charger cords, and the other little pockets come in handy too.  I wouldn't expect this to offer loads of protection against a longer drop, but it would certainly fare better that a simple sleeve.  The main zipper feels really well made, and the swivels/clasps for the shoulder strap fell very solid as well.

Great Little Mouse!  It tracks pretty accurately, and the wheel has a very nice solid feel.  We have 3 of them on different machines.  The battery lasts for what seems like forever.  The only issue I had was that one time the sync between the mouse and receiver was lost, and I couldn't re-establish it using my Chromebook.  I had to use a PC and download software to make it happen.

Another fine pair of Asics.  No surprises with these shoes.  I have been wearing Asics for as long as I can remember, and it's nice to be able to buy them online and know exactly what I'm getting.  This particular model is very comfortable for the casual wearer.  They were a bit stiff righto out of the box, but they have loosened up nicely.  I don't work out with them, I just wear them because they feel light on my feet and they fit me well.  The colors come off much brighter than they may look on your computer, but again, that wasn't an issue for me.  Overall, very nice shoes.

I couldn't tell you the brand of charger I had previously been using in my car with my Nexus 5, but it could barely keep up when using the GPS.  The phone would stay powered, but the battery wouldn't really charge.  And forget about using the thing with 2 devices.  This Anker has much more power, and when I get where I'm going my phone actually has a greater charge than when I left.  It's a nice solid fit into my car's socket, which is a benefit too as the old one would sometimes work its way out.  I have also used it with 2 devices connected and it does slow the charge speed a bit, but nothing like the old unit.  All-in-all, a great purchase.

I got this cable to connect a DAC to a tube headphone amp.  I wanted something high quality but flexible.  I do wish I could have gotten a set that was half this length.  The connectors are solid and they haven't stretched out like the ones on my last set of cables.  Is there a sound benefit to monster cables?  I'd say nothing that pretty much anyone could hear (especially at such short distances).  The value, I think, comes in the quality of materials and the durability of the cables.  If you're having interference issues these would also help, as Monster products are always very well shielded.

Got this for my son, and he's happy with it.  The fit was good for him and the thing didn't really shrink too much when we washed it.  It's a pretty light material when compared to some of the hoodies he owns so we'll see how well it holds up.  I though it was pretty pricey and I hope he doesn't outgrow it too fast.  If I had one complaint, it would be that the image isn't as clear and bright as it appears in the photo.  It isn't bad, it's just not as good as the picture.

My daughter had the original model of these shoes and she had completely worn them out.  She liked the originals so much that she wanted another pair, so we grabbed a set of these.  She has been just as happy with this new model as with her old ones.  She runs quite a bit, and she does go through shoes pretty fast.  These super light shoes aren't built to last forever, but that's what I'd expect from something so light.  If you're hard on shoes, you'll no doubt wear these out pretty quickly.  The fit was as expected and the colors were pretty accurately represented on the product page.

The wifi in my daughters dorm room was hit or miss so she wanted to get several things connected up to her Ethernet port.  This little switch was the perfect solution at a great price.  Simple plug and play, and she has not had any issues whatsoever.  It's really small and inconspicuous, but if I did have one complaint it would be that the power wire is a bit short.  Unless you have some sort of crazy speed requirement this is a great little switch.

I have a lot of Chromebooks, and I have purchased 6 Acer C720's since the release last year.  I have an original 4GB and 2GB model,  I purchased two of the 2GB models for my nephew's, I set my sister up with a 2GB-32GBSSD and I just bought myself a 4GB i3.  All of the C720s have been flawless performers as of this writing.  They are fast, reliable, pretty well built, and they are an excellent value.  I've also purchased 2 Chromebook 11's (1st gen with IPS), a Samsung Series 3, and a Toshiba 13.  We also have a Chromebase and a Chromebox.  All of these have been problem free as well.  I have written lengthy reviews for most of these machines, but for this unit I just want to stress what a great value it is.  Be careful of non-Amazon sellers trying to gouge on these machines.  They should cost you $200 or less.  And please take the time to research what a Chromebook is, what it can do, and what it can't do.  The majority of negative Chromebook reviews are written by those who didn't know what it was they were purchasing and bought on price alone.  If anyone has a specific question they would like to ask about the C720 line I would be happy to answer it as best as I can.

I've had some Sony MDR-V6's for a lot of years now, and after reading tons of opinions on how they compare to their sibling, these MDR-7506's, I figured I would pick a pair up and do my own comparison.  I know this horse has been beaten to death, but it only took a short amount of listening to realize the differences.  But, before I get into it too far I just want to say that both models are excellent headphones; and it's amazing that either set can be had for less than $100.And a WARNING to all buyers.  Because these phones have been around forever, and because they are so popular (I think Sony sells more than 35,000 pairs of these a month) there are lots of fakes out there.  You can research this on the web, but the safest way to insure you are getting the real deal is to make sure that when you purchase here on Amazon you only buy when it says "Ships from and sold by Amazon.com".  It is the easiest way to be sure you're getting the genuine article.Everybody hears differently, and everyone "listens" differently.  We don't all enjoy the same types of music, and similarly, every set of headphones is not necessarily suited for every genre of music.  We all own different source components, and most of us have a limit as to what we are willing to spend on our gear.  I believe every headphone review should include a brief summary of the reviewer's musical tastes, sources, and gear and should always including references to other sets of cans they own, have auditioned, liked, or disliked.  With so many variables affecting peoples like or dislike of any pair of phones it is my goal to help those with similar musical tastes and similar gear to determine whether or not these headphones will be a good investment for them personally.To that end; I listen to music in practically every genre.  I tend to go through different phases, but I enjoy Mozart as much as Metallica, 80's one hit wonders and New Orleans Jazz, Lady Antebellum or Lady Gaga, Eminem to Zedd.  Music has so much to offer in all genres that one could spend a lifetime discovering new things they like.  I use my computer to play all the usual manner of digital files, and an Onkyo C-7030 CD player to handle disk duty.  Both feed into my Nuforce Icon DAC/Headphone Amp.  The digital files via USB and the CDs via analog RCA (the Onkyo has excellent onboard D/A conversion).  I have also been playing around with a Little Dot MK2 ii Vacuum Tube Amp (which I am really starting to love).  It should also be noted that I use no equalizer to modify the sound of my music (because I don't have one available in my setup).  My headphones include Sony MDR-V6s and these MDR-7506s, V-Moda Crossfade LPs and M-100s, Audio Technica ATH-M50s, Beyerdynamic DT-880 250ohm Premiums, Sennheiser HD 598s and HD 600s (my personal favorite) as well as my 4th pair of Koss Porta-Pros (easy to exchange when you live in Milwaukee) .  I've tried Grado SR 80s and SR 225s (just too darn uncomfortable), some Beyerdynamic DT990 Pro 250ohms (I prefered the DT 880s), and my son even owns a pair of first generation Beats Solo phones (Yuk).  The other day I threw away some Denon's (no clue what model, but circa 1990) and a set of Sony MDR-V600s that were both totally worn out.  I also own lots of buds as well (my Klipsh X10s being my favorite).Like I said at the beginning, these headphones sound great.  They are by far my favorite set of closed phones.  The crossfades are fun (they'll make your teeth chatter), but the sound is very unnatural.  The ATH-M50s sound excellent as well, but I prefer the Sony's more natural midrange.  I like them with most genre's of music, but I prefer them with classical, jazz, adult contemporary, jazz rock, and other similar genres of music.  The 7506's (and V6's) also give the widest soundstage of all my closed cans.  When comparing the sound to the V6's I would say this.  Both models have some of the most natural sounding mids I have heard in a headphone.  The V6s have more bass and noticeably higher highs, where the 7506's are flatter through the audible spectrum.  That's pretty much it in a nutshell.  It isn't hard to hear the difference, and you can see it as well by going to Headphone dot com's "build a graph" page and comparing the two.  The build a graph is an excellent page and when I look at the graphs for the various phones I own it shows exactly what I'm hearing myself.  I have heard many reasons for the differences between the two sets of Sonys from wiring to cup shape, and I've read all the references to the parts list that says they have all the same pieces, but all I'll say again is that there is a difference.  If you like a flatter sound with less of a "smile curve" then these 7506's are what you're looking for.  If you like a bit more bass and treble I'd recommend the V6's (though the highs can cause fatigue after a while).  If you are looking for cans to monitor or edit video then the 7506's are the ticket.  It's amazing how accurately they can playback the sound I record with my video camera, and it's no surprise that you see these on the heads of people in the movie business when you watch behind the scenes extras on DVD's and Blu-Rays.  I have taken the V6's to work and I use them with my little Nuforce uDAC-2 as the two pair together very well, and the 7506's are my go-to phones at home when open cans won't do.  The phones are very efficient as well.  They play plenty loud without a lot of power, though they sound even better with a nice amp.  They are also very revealing.  While you will hear lots of details in your music, you will also hear all of the flaws.  Music with accentuated highs may also sound shrill and sibilant when using these phones.  If you want lots of booming bass you'd be best to look elsewhere.  The 7506's have nice low, accurate, detailed bass, but they aren't thumpers by any means (nor are the V6's). If you want some serious thump on a budget watch for the V-Moda Crossfade LP's to go on sale (you will sacrifice detail and clarity, however).The build quality is excellent and I'm alright with the earpads wearing out and needing replacement from time to time (I'm on at least my 5th set in 2 decades with the V6's).  All earcups need to be replaced sooner or later, and if you shop around you can find the Sony replacements for a cheap price.  If you opt for some of the velour replacements that are out there you will (or you should) notice a change in the sound (I've tried them with the v6's).  It's also important to watch the foam part of the cups that covers the driver.  If it starts to break down it will get pushed into the holes in the front of the driver itself and it will ruin it (this is what happened to my V600's).  The phones are very light, the comfort is excellent, the clamping pressure is pretty light, and the sound isolation is really good too.  I also like the coiled cord and the quick change screw plug.  I have never had an issue with my cord on my V6's in almost 20 years and I don't foresee a problem with the 7506's.  The carry bag is handy and surprisingly durable as well.  I do wish they locked in a little tighter when you opened them as they often seem to want to close back up while trying to put them on.  You also have to be careful for the right side wire as it can get pinched in the whole works and possibly become crimped.You just can't go wrong with The 7506's or the V6's at the price they sell for.  You just have to decide which response curve you prefer.

Probably my third favorite Moriarty book behind Alice and Secret.  I just started reading the new "Big Little Lies" and it hooked me pretty quickly.  I was hoping for one of her awesome epilogues, but the book did seem to end rather abruptly without one.  My favorite part of the book was the way my feelings towards the main characters changed from chapter to chapter.  One chapter you like someone and the next you don't.  In the end I liked everyone so much I'd probably read a sequel.
My wife and daughter (not the same person) love this magazine and we have been getting it for years.  Amazon's price is pretty good as well.

This is a pretty decent set of phones.  I use them with an Ooma Telo, and only when I'm not using my cell.  The cost of these phones was less than replacing the batteries on my last set of cordless phones.  The setup was easy, and the range seems good.  All in all, a pretty good buy.

Last year I pre-ordered the original Acer C720-2800 4GB Chromebook and received it the day after the release.  I did have a minor issue with a rattle in the touchpad which was a simple fix that I addressed when I upgraded the SSD to a 128GB unit.  The rattle aside, my C720, and all of our Chromebooks, Chromebox, and Chromebase , have been flawless performers.  The C720 2GB has been perfect, I love the screen and keyboard on the HP 11, my Toshiba 13 is great, and the Chromebox and Chromebase have replaced our desktops.  My son took over the 4GB C720 when I got the Toshiba, and he has pretty much retired his Samsung Series 3 that we purchased almost 2 years ago.  It still runs well, but the battery life isn't what it used to be.  I purchased this new i3 C720 4GB (my 4th C720) primarily because I wanted to see if the performance is worth the additional investment.  However, because I'm a dedicated Chrome OS user who's looking ahead to what's in store for Chrome OS and it's evolving compatibility with Android (and my Nexus 5) I also wanted to make sure I had the fastest Chromebook available (with the exception of the Pixel) to take advantage of forthcoming features.For this review, I will primarily be comparing this C720 i3 4GB to my original C720 Haswell 4GB. With all the Chrome OS devices available today, it's impossible  to reference them all. If you'd like my opinion on how this i3 stacks up against some of the popular models please feel free to ask.  Again, our family has the Samsung Series 3, three C720's (2GB and 4GB Haswells and the i3), two HP-11s (the ones with the good screen), the 13" Toshiba, an Asus Chromebox, and an LG Chromebase.  I am also well versed in the other models available or coming soon.FIRST IMPRESSIONS:  Love it or hate it, it's still a C720.  As I unboxed it, I again wished Acer would pack their Chromebooks better, but nothing was damaged or strewn around the box.  I was a bit surprised that the battery was totally dead when I opened the lid as all my previous Chromebooks had a decent charge when I got them.  I plugged it in, and from totally empty to full charge took just under 2 hours (I was at work and not using it during the charge).  Log in was simple; all of my apps, extensions, and settings loaded incredibly fast, I did an update (it was still at version 31 and is now 36), and was up and running faster than with any of my other Chromebooks.  The power brick is the same as my old C720, and at 9 feet long I still wish it was a bit longer (The Toshiba 13 charger totals 12 feet).  A few other quick impressions that I will cover in detail below; the screen seems to be the same, but the keyboard has a distinctly different feel to it.  I also noticed this on the C720 2GB I purchased last month for my sister.  No touchpad rattle; which is good, and the overall fit and finish seems to have improved a bit over the past 10 months.  But, the main reason to buy this i3 is.......PERFORMANCE:  Yes... The i3 Chromebook is fast!  The speed is immediately apparent with this machine.  From power off to the login screen is around 3 to maybe 4 seconds, which is half the time it takes my Haswell start.  Both machines are pretty much instant on from sleep, but that's really where the performance similarities stop.  I will include some quick benchmarks I ran at the end of this section, but I have always felt that the best measure of performance is how the computer feels when you're using it for whatever it is you use your computer for.  I have a monster Windows 7 XEON CPU CAD workstation I use at work and this i3 browses just as fast.  One of my primary uses for my Chromebook/box at home is listening to music.  I connect my Chromebook/box to an external DAC, via USB, which feeds my vacuum tube headphone amp with streaming music from Google Play Music Unlimited.  This usually works well enough with the old Acer and the Haswell Chromebox until I start browsing other sites.  Depending on the contents of a page, I sometimes get a very annoying skipping sound (like a machine gun) during loading that drives me crazy.  Listening to music while browsing with my wireless mouse would also cause the cursor to skip or behave erratically sometimes as well. I connected my DAC up to this i3, started some music, opened some known problem sites, and had no issues. I was all over the web and everything ran very smoothly; even with the mouse connected.  I have to say right now, that getting rid of that issue alone was worth the price I paid for this machine.  My Google Play Music page has tons of songs, playlists, and radio stations, so it does take a bit of time to load, but with the i3 it loaded almost twice as fast as with the Haswell.  HD shows on Netflix, Hulu Plus, Amazon Prime Instant Video, YouTube, and several network sites started fast and played smoothly without interruption.  The only issues I noticed were caused by the poor service I often get from my ISP (I pay for 50mbps and I expect 50mbps).  I don't really tend to be a tab maniac, but it's nice to know that I was able to get this machine with 4GB of ram.  My 2GB machines work fine for me, but the 4GB should help going forward with Chrome OS and the internet.  I also observed that the i3 loaded some rather large Google Documents very quickly.  My Gmail opens a lot quicker, as does the Google Plus Photo app; and the video previews in the photo app run much smoother as well.  All of this speed does come with a small compromise though, and it's important to note that this system still uses a small fan.  Like my old Acer, the fan is incredibly quiet, and with the activity happening around the house I never hear them running on either machine (as compared to the jet engine on our old HP laptop).  It's only in the early morning or late evening that I even realize there is a fan coming on from time to time (sometimes for only a few seconds).  So, does this mean that the Haswells are slow?  Absolutely not.  They just aren't as snappy as this i3.  And that snap comes at a price.BENCHMARKS:  This first set of benchmarks were completed as a logged in user and are an average of three tests.  HTML5 Fishbowl (Around 495 fish at 60 FPS).  Peacekeeper (3205 and 7/7 for HTML5 browsing).  SunSpider (296ms).  Octane (14374).  This set of tests was done in guest mode and also averaged results of three tests.  HTML5 Fishbowl (Up to 540 fish at 60 FPS).  Peacekeeper (3246 and 7/7 for HTML5 browsing).  SunSpider (282ms).  Octane (14237).  I had read comments by people who ran these tests saying the results were better in guest mode, but I would say that based on my results, guest mode isn't really a factor.  While running the Peacekeeper test I was also impressed at how well the video tests performed with this i3 and the HD Graphics 4400.  The test with the small spheres inside the big sphere looked incredibly smooth, as did the HD codec tests where you fly above the river.  Much smoother than they look on any of our other Chrome machines.SCREEN:  As I mentioned earlier, the screen looks pretty much the same as my old C720.  I got myself an HP 11 about a month ago, and while the thing is slow, the IPS screen is wonderful.  The colors on the i3 are a bit washed out, but decent, and the text is pretty clear, but the contrast is poor and the vertical viewing angles are very limited.  Streaming shows with lots of night or dark scenes yield a pretty poor picture and you have to tilt the screen just right to be able to differentiate close colors (like dark browns and blacks).  Still, this is unfortunately par for the course with Chromebooks, and many of us are still waiting for that fast machine with serious speed and a great display.  On a positive note, this i3 performed a lot better while extending or mirroring the screen via HDMI than my old C720 did.  Everything just seemed to run a lot smoother with 2 screens going, which is a testament to the improved graphics section in this model.  And, the picture this thing put up on the 24" Asus IPS was impressive.  For the record though, I would have to say that this display is certainly the biggest compromise with the Acer i3.KEYBOARD: Aside from the obvious speed boost, the keyboard on the newer C720's seems to have also been improved.  It isn't as nice as the HP11's, but it is certainly quieter and more responsive that the old Acer.  The keys feel a bit firmer/heavier (in a good way), and travel seems to have been slightly increased a bit as well.  I would probably put this keyboard it as my second favorite, ahead of the Samsung Series 3 and my Toshiba 13.TOUCHPAD:  The touchpad feels the same to me as my old C720, and I was glad to get one without a rattle (always a fear for me when buying a C720, though I only ever had the one).  I still prefer the pad on the Toshiba for it's texture that never seems to feel like it's getting oily, and the pad on the HP 11 that just plain works well for me.  I also need to add that I really enjoy using Chrome OS touchpads in general.  Once you get the hang of them and learn ALL of the gestures (1, 2, and 3 fingers), reverting to a pad with left and right buttons and scrolling partitions seems very cumbersome.  This i3 also worked perfectly with my little Logitech wireless mouse, though the low Logitech DPI rate really slows down the cursor.BATTERY LIFE:  I'll address this mainly in perceived time and not actual hours, because that's the easiest way for me to rate the battery.  The first charge did seem to run down pretty fast (less than 5 hours I'd say), but it was the first charge, I was all over the web, I had my uDAC-3 plugged in, and I had the screen all the way up most of that time.  The screen is certainly the biggest battery killer, along with my Nuforce uDAC when I use it, and if you use the display as low as you can tolerate you will get the maximum usage times out of your battery.  I also like that the Haswells and this i3 don't seem to drain a lot when they're sleeping.  This is an issue with our ARM Chromebooks.  They'll run down pretty quickly, even when they're in sleep mode.  If you really want to save your battery power it's best to just turn the Chromebook off.  After all, they start in just a few seconds.SPEAKERS:  The speakers are pretty much the same also.  As long as you're on a table or using a lap desk they can play plenty loud for their size.  I never expected much from such tiny little things so I've never felt disappointed with their sound.  The Toshiba's are a bit louder, and the HP's probably sound the best.  I also have a Bose Soundlink Mini that paired up quickly using the Bluetooth and played without any problems.  Running music out of the combo headphone/mic jack works really good too, and sounded nice with my Koss Porta Pros.GRAB BAG:  The ports are exactly the same as the Haswells, the SD cards still stick out pretty far, and still just one USB 2, one USB 3, and the HDMI.  The ports may feel a little tight at first, but they'll loosen up over a couple uses.  I'm plugging and unplugging things all the time, and I've never had any problems with my Chromebooks.  If you need more ports, you can always grab a USB hub.  My cloud printer was available as soon as I logged on, and I love that this thing instantly became MY Chromebook just by logging in.  I was able to connect my phone and my digital camera, and Chrome found the DCIM folders and uploaded my pictures (though the pics I take with my phone automatically sync to my cloud drive already).  The webcam is still pretty bad in all but the best light, but I also have a Logitech USB webcam that works well with Chrome OS.  The chassis of this C720 is pretty rigid as well, and only my HP 11 feels more solid when lifted by the corner.  And please, NEVER handle ANY computer by the screen/lid!  This Chromebook also worked well with my Plugable USB 2 to Ethernet adapter, which is handy to have.  As to the SSD; I had put a 128GB unit in my first 4GB C720, but since that time I have also started using the cloud a lot more.  The extra 16GB of space you get with this model is nice if you travel, because you can take along several movies (yes, you can download your Google Play videos for offline use now), plenty of music, and still have space left over.So is this the Chromebook for you?  Aside from the inability to install software, any Chrome OS device you purchase will require a compromise on your part; even the incredible Pixel with its shorter battery life (that I could totally live with by the way).  While this C720 i3 is really fast, and an overall improvement over my original C720, it still doesn't have the great IPS screen or keyboard of my original HP 11. But, the HP 11 has only adequate speed, short battery life, and long charge times.  If you want serious battery life in a great all-around package then you should consider the new, and highly rated, Asus Bay Trail Chromebooks (C200 and C300), though you will sacrifice a small bit of performance and they do come with TN panels.  The first Dell Chromebooks were praised for their great build quality, and now they are said to be coming out with an i3 Chromebook as well; no word though on whether or not they'll include an IPS display.  The new Samsung Chromebook 2's are very well built as well, but again, you will be making a compromise in speed, battery life, and screen quality (based solely on my extensive research).  The Toshiba 13 is a great value with very good performance, great battery life, and a decent build.  The extra screen real estate is nice too, but the low resolution takes away some of the sharpness.  The bottom line on the C720 i3 is simple.  If you have to have the fastest Chromebook on the market (besides the Pixel) this is the machine for you.  The improved music playback alone made this purchase totally worth it for me.  Just remember though, you can get the exact same package with very good performance for just $179 with the Haswell C720 2GB and you'll still have $200 in your pocket.  If you have to have this i3 you could also drop to the 2GB model and save $30 (Though I recommend the 4GB if you're getting the i3).  In the end, all the Acer C720's are a great value, and the i3 models offer a great new addition to the line.If anyone has any questions or comments I would be more than happy to answer them as best I can.  I will also update this review as I spend a few more hours with this Chromebook.Thanks for Reading.Update 7/29/2014:  With a few more days under my belt, I really feel that the main benefit of the i3 chip in this Chromebook is multitasking speed (and the 4GB helps there as well).  The thing just runs a lot smoother while you are opening and closing  new tabs.  Pages that used to make my music stutter while they were loading have no effect anymore.  I've kept videos playing while adding a tab to look up something else and the video doesn't stumble or lose it's audio sync.  The thinks I do with my Chromebook don't generally involve having a ton of things going at the same time, but when I do, everything just runs a whole lot better.

I know I dont show up as a verified purchase, but I bought this amp from a factory authorized seller on EB (davidzhezhe).  My research revealed this was essential should I need warranty support if anything goes wrong.What a fantastic little amp!  Great sound and plenty of power!  It definitely needs a minimum 50 hours of burn-in before it really starts to open up, and even with the stock tubes the sound is very nice (more on that to follow).  Just remember that its recommended to turn it off every 4-6 hours and let it cool for at least 30 minutes.  You dont want to let this thing run unattended overnight, but with tubes you dont want to be turning it on and off all the time either.  Cold starts are where vacuum tubes are stressed the most.  If your going to listen for an hour, take a break, and then come back, its better just to leave the amp on.  I paired this amp with a Schiit Modi DAC and it was necessary to open it (Little Dot) up and set the gain switches to 10db so I could get the performance I needed with my high impedance phones and the low output of the Schiit.  Now I have plenty of power on tap.  If youre planning on using the amp with high sensitivity/ low impedance headphones its better to use a lower gain setting which will give you more accurate control with the volume pot.  Ive used this amp with my Sennheiser HD-600s and HD-598s, Beyerdynamics DT-880s (250 0hm), Audio Technica ATH-M50s, V-Moda Crossfade M-100s, Sony MDR-7506s and MDR-V6s, and even my Koss Porta Pros.  I use Google Play Music 320kbps MP3s as my primary source, and also CDs played with my Onkyo C-7030.  I would say that with either the MP3s or the CDs the HD-600s are my favorites with the Little Dot, and for closed phones I like pairing it with the MDR-7506s.The amp is built very well, and its the perfect size for my desk.  The included RCA cables are okay, but I picked up some better ones.  The RCA cable package also has 2 additional jumpers in case you lose one of the jumpers from inside the amp (used to switch things up for different tube families)  The power cable has also been mentioned as an issue for some people, but its easy to replace with any 3 prong cable like youd use with a computer tower or monitor.  The manual will get you started, but it is really poorly written and contains many grammatical and even operational errors.  The whole section on setting the gain switches is a disaster.  If you have questions in this area (or any area) please feel free to ask me in the comments.  The most up to date manual can be found at littledot (dot) net which is really a forum.  Just go to the Little Dot Models and Pricing area, choose the MK II section and then look for the dropbox pdf link at the bottom below the pictures.  And even that manual is wrong in the Recommendations section of the gain control table.  All the recommendations are essentially backwards.  For example: You want to use a gain setting of 10 for HIGH impedance/LOW sensitivity phones, not with LOW impedance/LOW sensitivity phones.  The sensitivity part is right, but the impedance part is backwards as high impedance cans (say 250 ohm and higher) generally need more power or a higher gain setting to play as well as phones in the 32 to 60 ohm range.  And dont use phones (or buds) below 32 ohms with this amp.Well sound is really what its all about, and the Little Dot MK2 ii doesnt disappoint.  The amp has an excellent noise floor (as does the Schiit) and I have had no humming or ground loop issues as some have mentioned.  Like I stated earlier, the sound was pretty decent with the stock tubes after about 50 hours of burn-in.  Nice and warm; and when combined with the glow of the tubes in a darkened room and some sweet jazz, just makes the whole listening experience that much better.
