The amp also gave a noticeable improvement to the soundstage (especially with open phones) when compared to my Nuforce Icon DAC/amp.  I was a bit disappointed with the low end from the stock tubes, but this wasnt surprising based on the reviews I had read.  Remember though, tube rolling is all part of the fun in owning a tube amplifier, and the Little Dot is built for it.  I found a wonderful tube rolling guide on Head-Fi that pretty much runs the gamut of options for the Little Dot MK2 and 3.  Just search head-fi little dot tube rolling guide and youll find it.  I chose to stay in the EF95 family to start (the default jumper setting), and picked up some better power tubes (though I havent used them yet) and a couple sets of driver tubes (the smaller ones in front that really affect the sound).  The Mullard M8100s and Voshkod 6ZH1P-EV tubes that I purchased are both a noticeable improvement over the stock tubes in all essential areas, and you can hear the differences between the two of them as well.  Its pretty cool that you can mix and match tubes and headphones to find that just right combination that suits your listening tastes.  I still have a lot of combinations of tubes and phones to test, but thats what this hobby is all about.  I dont think Ive reached the end of my tube purchasing either.This is a really great amp and I am very happy with my purchase.  I personally dont see the need for anything more for myself, but this amp is also a great place to start for someone who wants to see what the whole tube amp world is all about.  Especially given the wide variety of tubes that are available for it all over the internet and the seemingly endless combinations one can experiment with.
If you have Porta Pros you'll need these sooner or later.  Easy to put on (turn inside out and roll on) and your PPs are as good as new.

Well, I guess after owning a pair of these Porta Pros for over two decades now, I thought I would come here and write a quick review.  I live in Milwaukee (where the Koss Headquarters is located), and I believe I'm on my fourth (maybe fifth) pair of the Porta Pros, but I only ever paid for the first pair.  All of the replacements were courtesy of Koss (I actually still have my original receipt from Soundstage).  Some pairs just wore out and a couple were damaged out of carelessness, but Koss has always come through for me.  And of course, I have gone through LOTS of ear pads.  I'm listed as a verified purchaser on Amazon because I just ordered some of these for my son.  I am an admitted audiophile and I own a very nice assortment of headphones and amps, so when I praise these Porta Pros I am doing so from a quality and value standpoint.  Obviously these phones aren't going to keep up with high end pairs costing up into the hundreds of dollars, but the sound quality is excellent for what these little babies do cost (my son's pair was $30).  What's more, it wasn't until I started to get into the nicer cans that I really started to appreciate what these Porta Pros were capable of.To understand these phones, you have to understand the pop music (and hardware) from the decade in which they were designed.  Just like lots of  bass is all the rage in much of the current pop music; in the 80's it was treble.  Dolby processing was starting to become common on portable cassette players, and CD's were just starting to hit the market in mass.  Both formats now allowed for the ability to play back higher highs with improved clarity but without distortion and artist were really taking advantage of this.  Just go back and listen to 80's music that hasn't been re-mastered and you'll see what I'm talking about.  If you go to Headphone dot com's "Build a Graph" page and look at the graph for these Porta Pros, you'll see that they're tuned to bring up the low end while reducing the highs, thus providing a much flatter response from the players and recordings of the time.If you have an equalizer available in your system (computer, phone, etc) it is very easy to "flatten" the sound curve of these little Porta Pros, and the results are amazing.  Using the Koss Porta Pro graph on the "Headphone" Build a Graph page, viewed in the 15db dynamic range, I simply reduced and raised the available frequencies to flatten out the curve.  These are excellent starting settings and you can tweak for personal preference from here.  Just make small changes and sample a variety of your favorite tracks.  The numbers below are the frequency adjustment points from Windows Media Player, and they are almost identical to iTunes. If you're limited to maybe a 5 band EQ on your phone just adjust the frequencies available to you.  This really kills the volume in Goolge Play Music on my Nexus 5 which isn't all that loud in the first place, so I use an external amp and the sound is great.31Hz to +1 / 62Hz to -6 / 125Hz to -7 / 250Hz to -5 / 500Hz to -1 / 1KHz 0 / 2KHz to -1 / 4Khz to +5 / 8KHz to +3 / 16KHz to +9I now use the Porta Pros mainly at work in combination with my Nuforce uDAC-2 and it's an excellent pairing that gives a really impressive sound.  The soundstage the Porta Pros are capable of is pretty big as well.  If you want to experience this for yourself, just start playing a song (live music works well for this test) and then cover the outside of the phones with your hands.  You should hear the soundstage collapse significantly and then re-open when you take your hands away.  Obviously, the Porta Pros can't always keep up when recordings start getting louder and more complicated, but at the moderate to low levels I generally listen at any problems are much less apparent (and really almost unnoticeable).  And, they can still play pretty clean and loud when I feel like it.  Especially with the audio quality and power available from my little DAC/amp.What can I say about the styling?  When I got my first pair they weren't even cool anymore.  I think they would look a lot better if they dumped the blue parts and went with all black and steel.  The stainless steel band will catch your hair from time to time, but after you learn to put them on and off it isn't much of a problem.  The "Comfort Zone" adjustments really do work/help me, and like I said earlier, you should order some spare ear pads right away too.  If you wear these out in public enough you will definitely get some stares, but you may also meet some fellow Porta Pro enthusiasts.  I also noticed that the bag that came with my son's pair is a bit smaller than the old bags.  I get the feeling they've made it as small as possible to save money.  What it does is make it really hard to put the headphones in and out easily.All in all, these phones still sound as good as ever; and for people who buy these, sound is what matters.  If you can live with the styling and the loss of a few strands of hair, I don't think you'll find anything better at this price.  Save your receipt and you can always get a new pair if anything bad happens. Koss hit a winner 30 years ago, and I'm amazed that these are still so popular today, but really, once you hear them it'll all be clear.

Simply put, this bag is an excellent value.  I use the bag with my Acer C720 Chromebook when I have to travel, and it's perfect because it has plenty of space for my charging brick and cords  There's also room for my Icon uDAC 3/headphone amp, my Koss PortaPros, and even a travel mouse.  The bag is made very well and while I don't feel it would offer serious protection from drops or things being knocked against it it is a great way to haul around my computer  I am extremely glad I didn't spend a lot of extra cash on a more "name-brand" bag.

I'm using this Schiit Modi to convert 320kbps MP3s from my Asus Chrome Box and output to my Little Dot MK2 ii headphone amp.  Works perfectly with Chrome OS, and I have also tried it with Windows 7 Pro where it has performed without issue.  I know they say its plug and play, but with Windows you will have to make it the default playback device, and you'll want to crank up the sample rate and bit depth on the devices properties.  I had been using my Nuforce Icon DAC/Headphone amp to feed the Little Dot, but I like that the Modi uses USB power and is just a simple in and out.  I am also very happy with the sound, as it suits my listening requirements perfectly.  I feel it is an excellent DAC for the money.  I did have to open up the Little Dot and increase the gain settings as the output from the Modi is a bit on the soft side compared to my Nuforce, but looking at the specs prior to purchase I had expected that.  I also wish the shipping from Schiit was a bit quicker, but that's really my only complaint.  All in all, and excellent product that I highly recommend.

I guess I'm partial because I have the Soundlink Mini, but this thing just didn't meet my expectations.  Expectations that weren't even all that high.  I don't own a plethora of Bluetooth speakers to make a broad comparison, but I would recommend some research (not on Amazon) prior to purchasing this.  It connected well, had decent range, and everything worked, it was just too quiet and too weak sounding (very narrow frequency response).

Yes, I'm a guy who occasionally reads "Chick Lit", and I really liked this book.  I connected with the characters and the story, and I tore through the book in three sittings.  I liked this one a bit better than "The Husband's Secret", and I am now reading " The Hypnotist's Love Story".  Like all of the Liane Moriarty Books I have read, you have to reserve judgement until the end.

SPOILER ALERT: In a nutshell, this movie was just okay.  Sure, the effects were superior to the original, but the storytelling was weak and I just didn't connect with the characters.  In the original film I wanted Clarence and Dick to die so bad I could taste it.  In this movie I really don't even know exactly how he was able to overcome the "Red Asset" restriction to defeat Sellars.  And that thing with Sam Jackson at the end was just stupid.  It was a good purchase, but I'm glad I didn't waste time in the theater to see it.

Nice mats with colors that really pop.  I thought they would be a touch bigger, and they seem to sort of curve away from the table making them susceptible to spinning on the center.  Hopefully they will flatten out after a while.  On several mats the brown color on the perimiter was a little flaked, but we just touched it up with some paint we had lying around.  Hopefully they hold up to a lot of wiping.
I have purchased many of these sketch books for my art major daughter and she really likes them.  She says the work good with many different types of media (charcoal, pen, pencil).

I have been a Chrome OS/Chromebook user for over a year now, and in that time I went from one Samsung Series 3 Chromebook to owning 5 Chromebooks and a Chromebox.  I have the Samsung, the HP-11, an Acer C720 4GB (with upgraded 128GB SSD), a C720 2GB, and the Toshiba 13.  I also have the Asus Chromebox Haswell with upgraded memory and SSD.  All of my Chrome OS devices have served flawlessly and they all get plenty of use in our house.  I purchased this LG Chromebase for my wife to use, but I have spent a fair amount of time with it as well.  I also purchased a Chromebase for my in-laws to replace a 9 year-old Toshiba laptop they had been using.  The LG Chromebase is an excellent example of a Chrome OS device, though there is room for improvement.  It really represents a great value (in my opinion), and its the perfect computer for someone whos just wants to surf and email, and is always calling you for technical support.  However, If you want more flexibility, something in black (which I thought LG was going to offer in the US), or the ability to upgrade RAM and SSDs, the Asus Chromebox, along with the monitor of your choice, is probably a better pick.  The Chromebase cost me $329 while the Chromebox, monitor, cable, keyboard, mouse, and speakers came to just over $400.  The memory and SSD upgrade I did to the Chromebox added another $150, but prior to that upgrade the Chromebox and Chromebase had the same basic specs.SCREEN:  Like a Chromebook, this Chromebase is tied to its screen so of course, the quality of that screen is very important.  While the IPS screen is more than adequate with good color and brightness, it isnt a class leader by any means.  I have an Asus 23 IPS screen set up with my Chromebox and it beats the Chromebase screen in really every regard.  Its brighter,  has better colors, and has much better contrast.  And, I can easily upgrade it if I choose to do so.  Still, as part of this easy all in one package, the LG Chromebase screen gets the job done just fine.  It took about 5 minutes to assemble the base to it using the 6 phillips head screws.  What people also need to realize is that the monitor has its own settings that are controlled by the touch buttons on the front.  Its not like the screens in the Chromebooks that have no adjustments (aside from resolution).  I suggest taking the time to play with the settings if you buy one of these.  The Reader button on the monitor is nice allowing you to quickly drop the brightness to preset levels, and the Chrome button makes it easy to switch sources from the Chrome system to the external HDMI input.  The built in speakers work well too; just remember to turn up the volume on the front of the monitor itself or you wont get enough volume (as some reviewers have complained about).  To do this you just touch on the left and right arrows of the monitor (when the menu is not up)COMPUTER:  The performance of the computer is as good as any of the Haswell Chromebooks and Chromeboxes Ive used.  Its disappointing that you cant easily upgrade the SSD or the memory, but with the lean Chrome OS and the low cost of online storage neither of these is an issue (and everyone should learn how to work in the cloud).  I have not had any problems with the WiFi, and the Bluetooth works good too.  Its nice that it has a built in port for wired operation as well.  I was disappointed that the Chromebase didnt include a built-in card reader, but with 4 USB ports you can always add an external drive or a card reader.  If you have a newer digital camera, you can connect it directly to the Chromebase and it will automatically upload your photos to your Google Drive for you.  It will do the same if you have a phone as well.  It searches for the DCIM folder on your device, and if that folder has media files like pictures and videos it will save them automatically.  Another nice feature is the HDMI port that allows you to connect a second HDMI source to the monitor.  I havent used it, but I have read other reviews that were quite happy with this capability.  When I logged into my Google account with the Chromebase it automatically set itself up to work with my cloud printer, and the Chromebase also works well with my external DAC/headphone amp, just like all the other Chrome OS devices I own.KEYBOARD AND MOUSE:  The included keyboard and mouse are adequate, but they are cheap.  One of my favorite island style keyboards is the one on my HP Chromebook 11.  The keys are good sized, have a good feel, decent travel with a nice snap to them while still being incredibly quiet, The Chromebase keyboard is a good size for my hands, but its only other positive quality is that it has the built in Chrome OS buttons.  I chose to purchase a Samsung Chrome keyboard to use with my Asus Chromebox, and it isnt all that great either. It would be nice if someone came out with a nice Chrome keyboard now that there are several devices on the market that would benefit from one.  You can use a wired or wireless standard keyboard if you want, you just have to relabel (or reassociate in your brain) the F-buttons for the chrome functions.  The mouse tracks just fine, but it is really cheap and light and it is lacking a few functions.  You get far more features and capabilities with a Chromebook touchpad than with the Chromebase mouse.  At least the Logitech mouse I bought for my Chromebox has a wheel that can tilt left and right to page back or forward. But it would be nice to have a button on the mouse that could launch the Chrome app switcher (the button on the keyboard that has a rectangle followed by 2 lines).  I know another user had mentioned swapping the LG mouse and keyboard for Apple products, but he didnt speak to any added functionality.SUMMARY:  I am rating this product 5 Stars for its quality (so-so mouse and keyboard aside) value, and simplicity.  My wife really enjoys her Chromebase, but I think my in-laws like theirs even more.  Their old computer had been so bad for so long, they had no idea how much computing had changed over the past 5 or 6 years.  They especially like the speed and screen quality/size (and they LOVE Hangouts calls and Spotify).  I like the fact that aside from answering the occasional Chrome OS operational question I dont have to provide constant IT support for system problems (virus/malware/spyware software, java updates, plug-ins, updates that install 50 other programs, clicking on links that hijack your browser, and the list goes on).  If you want a Chrome OS device for home use only, arent interested in upgrading the internals (which are very capable for most users), are okay with the white color, and you dont want to have to deal with finding the right screen, mouse, and keyboard this is the machine for you.

Nice cable, and the perfect length to connect my DAC to my Little Dot Amp.  I wish the cables were a bit more flexible, but once they settled into place they stayed put,  They were a bit tight when pushing them onto the jacks for the first time, but they got easier after that.  Can't really beat them for the quality and price.Update:  After using this cable for a while, the ends have loosened up to the point that they can slide off of the jacks far too easily, and have actually slid off on several occasions as the wire tried to return to its original bend.  I am changing my review to 3 stars at this point.

I would like to preface my review of these headphones with the following:  Everybody hears differently, and everyone listens differently.  We dont all enjoy the same types of music, and similarly, every set of headphones is not necessarily suited for every genre of music.  We all own different source components, and most of us have a limit as to what we are willing to spend on our gear.  I believe every headphone review should include a brief summary of the reviewers musical tastes, sources, and gear and should always including references to other sets of cans they own, have auditioned, liked, or disliked.  With so many variables affecting peoples like or dislike of any pair of phones it is my goal to help those with similar musical tastes and similar gear to determine whether or not these headphones will be a good investment for them personally.So with that in mind; I listen to music in practically every genre.  I tend to go through different phases, but I enjoy Mozart as much as Metallica, 80s one hit wonders and New Orleans Jazz, Lady Antebellum or Lady Gaga, Eminem to Zedd.  Music has so much to offer in all genres that one could spend a lifetime discovering new things they like.  I use my computer to play all the usual manner of digital files, and an Onkyo C-7030 CD player to handle disk duty.  Both feed into my Nuforce Icon DAC/Headphone Amp.  The digital files via USB and the CDs via analog RCA (the Onkyo has excellent onboard D/A conversion).  I use no equalizer to modify the sound.  I will also be receiving a Little Dot MK2 ii in the next couple days and I may update this review once its well broken in.  My headphones include Sony MDR-V6s and MDR-7506s, V-Moda Crossfade LPs and M-100s, Audio Technica ATH-M50s, Sennheiser HD 598s and HD 600s (my personal favorite along with these 880s) as well as my 4th pair of Koss Porta-Pros (easy to exchange when you live in Milwaukee) .  Ive tried Grado SR 80s and SR 225s (just too darn uncomfortable), the Beyerdynamics DT 990 Pro 250 ohm, and my son even owns a pair of Beats Solo phones (Yuk).  The other day I threw away some old Denons (no clue what model, but circa 1990) and a set of MDR V600s that were both totally worn out.  I also own lots of buds as well (my Klipsh X10s and S4s being my favorites).As I briefly mentioned, I had tried the Beyerdynamics DT 990 Pro 250ohm headphones.  In fact, I had tried the 990s and returned them prior to purchasing the DT 880 Premium 250 ohm set.  The 990 Pros are very well built high quality headphones, I just wasnt happy with the exaggerated high and low ends and the subdued midrange. I blame myself for not doing enough research prior to that purchase (and for being cheap), and I would still recommend them to people who like that type of sound.  They really do sound good, but their signature just wasnt for me.Im much happier with the 880s having listened to them for a couple weeks now.  They have a much more up-front midrange, and while theyre still pretty bright, they dont have nearly as much sizzle as the 990s.  To my ears, the 880s sparkle a bit more than my Sennheiser HD 600s, but the Senns have more pronounced mids.  The bass seems well defined, though I wouldnt mind just the slightest bit more of it (and yes, Im nitpicking).  At first I was wanting for more middle from the 880s as well, but after a lot of listening and experimenting with different genres of music I know when to use them and when to use different cans.  The soundstage the 880s create is excellent as well.  Since Ive gotten into open headphones, and since Ive found several pairs that I really like, I find it incredibly difficult to throw on a set of closed cans anymore.  Im also amazed at how the 880s can sound so big but not leak as much sound as ALL of the other open headphones I own/have tried.  I dont want anyone thinking they dont leak sound; they just dont leak as much.  Like any other open phone, you need to be in a quiet environment to truly enjoy them, and everyone else in the room will hear what you're listening to.  The 880s power-handling is excellent and I really had to push them to create any type of distortion (Coldplays Magic will buzz the heck out of my Senn HD 598s well before these 880s or my HD 600s).  The 800s can handle complex musical sections without issue, and had no problems whatsoever with anything I threw at them.  They are a little less sensitive (db) to input than my HD 600s, but I have no problems driving them with my Nuforce Icon DAC.  I am also looking forward to seeing how the 880s (and all my phones) play with my soon to be arriving Little Dot MK2 ii.Another element that I have always felt is essential to a fulfilling headphone experience is comfort, and the DT 880 Premiums excel at it!  The 990s I had were the Pros, and they were a bit tight on my melon.  I cant speak from experience about the 880 Pros, but they do have a different headband (similar to the 990 Pros), and are designed to clamp tighter than the 880 Premiums.  It only takes a short time for my 880s to disappear on my head.  They do absolutely nothing in terms of discomfort, to take away from the listening experience.  As much as I enjoy my HD 650s, they still grab you tighter than the 880 Premiums.  If it werent for the 600s oval shape, as compared to the 880s round cups, I probably wouldnt be able to wear them (the 600s) for extended periods.  If you do a lot of moving around, however, you may want to consider the 880 Pros.  As comfortable as the Premiums are, I could easily sneeze them off of my head they clamp so lightly.  I like that the velour earcups are replaceable, I have no issue with the long straight cable, though I wish it was detachable, and I appreciate the 3.5 / 6.35 mm screw type plug.  The carry case that comes with the premiums is also a nice touch.All in all the Beyerdynamic DT 880 Premium 250 ohm headphones are an excellent set of cans.  Im proud to own them, and I highly recommend them.  My only advice to shoppers is that they research the Beyerdynamic line and understand the differences between Pro and Premium, the 32, 250, and 600 ohm impedances, and the unique sound signatures of the different models.

I would like to preface my review of these headphones with the following:  Everybody hears differently, and everyone "listens" differently.  We don't all enjoy the same types of music, and similarly, every set of headphones is not necessarily suited for every genre of music.  We all own different source components, and most of us have a limit as to what we are willing to spend on our gear.  I believe every headphone review should include a brief summary of the reviewer's musical tastes, sources, and gear and should always including references to other sets of cans they own, have auditioned, liked, or disliked.  With so many variables affecting peoples like or dislike of any pair of phones it is my goal to help those with similar musical tastes and similar gear to determine whether or not these headphones will be a good investment for them personally.To that end; I listen to music in practically every genre.  I tend to go through different phases, but I enjoy Mozart as much as Metallica, 80's one hit wonders and New Orleans Jazz, Lady Antebellum or Lady Gaga, Eminem to Zedd.  Music has so much to offer in all genres that one could spend a lifetime discovering new things they like.  I use my computer to play all the usual manner of digital files, and an Onkyo C-7030 CD player to handle disk duty.  Both feed into my Nuforce Icon DAC/Headphone Amp.  The digital files via USB and the CDs via analog RCA (the Onkyo has excellent onboard D/A conversion).  I use no equalizer to modify the sound.  My headphones include Sony MDR-V6s and MDR-7506s, V-Moda Crossfade LPs and M-100s, Audio Technica ATH-M50s, Sennheiser HD 598s and HD 600s (my personal favorite) as well as my 4th pair of Koss Porta-Pros (easy to exchange when you live in Milwaukee) .  I've tried Grado SR 80s and SR 225s (just too darn uncomfortable), and my son even owns a pair of Beats Solo phones (Yuk).  The other day I threw away some Denon's (no clue what model, but circa 1990) and a set of MDR V600s that were both totally worn out.  I also own lots of buds as well (my Klipsh X10s being my favorite).So what do I think of these DT 990 Pro 250s? In short, and for my personal tastes , I think they're just okay.  Let me put it another way.  When I got my Sennheiser HD 600s I plugged them in, fired up Chris Isaac's "Wicked Game" and in less than 30 seconds had a chill running up my spine.  I spent many, many hours with those 600s over the next couple days tearing through my music collection like a kid in a candy store who'd just gotten his first taste of sugar.  With the 990's I spent a lot of hours listening and a lot of hours feeding white, pink, brown, etc. noise in hopes that the middle range would open up and the dynamics would improve, but any change was negligible.  Do I think the 990's are bad headphones with terrible sound?  Not at all.  I spent many years listening to music  with my EQ looking like a couple of deep V's, making for accentuated treble and bass and a subdued midrange.  But as I stated earlier, I now use no equalization in my system and have really come to appreciate a more flat and balanced presentation.  I've also come to prefer the sound of open phones to closed cans.  For $140 these are an excellent way to get into a pair of high quality open phones, especially if you're looking for those boosted lows and highs.  They clamped a little tight and the pads were a bit stiff when I first put them on, but they have become very comfortable over the past week and a half.  They are made very well and being able to replace any broken or worn part is a big benefit.  I like the coiled cable and the plug with the screw-on " adapter (though I wish it was detachable), and I think the phones are nicely styled.  I wish the midrange had a bit more presence and that the phones had better dynamics (difficult with the subdued middle).  The soundstage is very good, though it doesn't feel quite as wide as my HD 598s or 600's (at least to my ears).  All in all the DT 990's are very good cans; they just aren't for me.  Still I debated for quite a while as to whether or not I would keep them.  But, in the end I decided I would send them back.UPDATE:  I didn't want to give up on Beyerdynamics, so the day after I returned these 990s I ordered a set of DT-880 Premiums.  I'm hoping that the sound will be more what I like, and based on most of the professional reviews I have read I think they may be.  I admit I was being cheap when I chose the 990 Pros over the 880s.  Not that the 990s are cheap in any way other than price, or that they aren't an excellent value (probably one of the best in the world of headphones).  I will add to this update when I've had a chance to audition the 880s, and I will be sure to review those as well.FINAL UPDATE:  So I got the DT 880s (250 ohm Premium) today, and I knew right away that I liked them.  Much more in line with my personal preferences.  Still a tiny bit of sizzle on the top, but the mids are much more "up-front".  The bass is very detailed, but also less pronounced than the 990s.  The 880 Premiums clamp A LOT lighter than the 990 Pros as well (super comfortable, though I could probably sneeze them off).  In the end, I was glad I auditioned both sets, and even though the 880s are almost double what I got the 990's for I will be keeping them.  I can see the appeal of the 990s, but still, for me they were just okay (and I'm talking sound wise only).  Beyerdynamics makes some really nice cans, but a person needs to do their research to figure out which model will suit them best.

I like the strap for the most part.  It's well made and the leather ends are nice, but I just can't seem to get it adjusted the way I want so that the pad is centered on my shoulder and the plastic buckle isn't digging into my neck.
Well we got this for $5 and even though guitar has pretty much faded away its still a pretty fun game and it's always good to have more songs to play.

Got this for my son and he really likes it.  He's tall and it easily covers his whole body.  It also seems thicker than the thin leopard print snuggie my daughter has.  Price was pretty good and the product arrived quickly and in perfect condition.

My son is starting summer marching band this year, and he will be needing to ride his bike to daily practice.  Since so many of the other soft cases were rather expensive I thought I would give this case a try.  Long story short, it is working out great for him.  The case offers no protection from anything major, but even with the trombone inside it is very light and easy for him to carry back and forth.  I will update this review when we have more experience with durability.

This little gadget is perfect for getting rid of that pesky nose hair, and it does it without causing pain or tickling your nose in a way that has you sneezing like 20 times.  It's well built, easy to clean, and is a good value.  I highly recommend this product

I don't travel with my Sennheiser HD 650s all that much, but I did want a case I could store them in at home without having to constantly remove the cables.  This case fits the bill, and because of it's shape I can also leave my earcups extended (even then the phones still do slide around a bit).  I put the phones in with the cables pointing to one of the corners and there is hardly any pressure on the wires (see customer photos).  The build quality is okay, it's sewn well, and the zippers are smooth, but I wish it had the quality of the CASEBUDi cases as well as their carrying strap.  The case just seems a bit expensive for what you're getting.  And, aside from keeping everything organized and protected from the elements and some short drops, don't expect that you could sit, step. or pile a lot of weight on this thing and it wouldn't get crushed; it's not that solid.  It was packaged nicely inside a bubble wrap bag within a cardboard box and arrived in perfect condition.  All in all a decent case, but a bit expensive. lacking a carry strap, and not all that strong.

It would seem that my review has turned out to be a sort of comparison of the Sennheiser HD 598s to the HD 600s.  While it wasn't where I intended to go, I think the comparison is valid when deciding if the $200 premium is worth the payout (it is).I have owned/auditioned a ton of headphones over the years, and I currently have a pretty decent assortment in my stable.  But these HD 600s are probably going to have all those other pairs collecting dust.  About a month ago I had purchased a pair of HD 598s and they were the pair of cans that finally sold me on open phones.  I really like the 598s, and they are excellent for classical, jazz, classic rock, and many other genres music.  However, when it came to listening to contemporary popular music they just seemed to come up short.  The HD 600s are a much better "all around" headphone, and well worth the additional $200 (in my opinion).  Their superiority was evident from the moment I put them on and plugged them in.  I played Chris Isaac's "Wicked Game" and I literally had a chill run up my spine.  More bass than the 598s?  Yes; but it's not unnatural in any way whatsoever.  It just adds to the richness/quality of the overall sound.  These make everything just sound more real, and they seem to do it almost effortlessly.  After listening to the 600s for an extended period and then going back to the 598's, the differences become more noticeable.  Again,  where the 598s start to struggle, the 600s just power through.  I completely understand why so many people consider these to be some of the best phones ever produced.  I have also been tricked into looking around the room for that noise I just heard only to realize it was part of the recording.  If you need to stick to a budget, the 598s are an excellent choice and a fantastic bargain (just watch and wait for the price to dip).  However, if you can afford the premium price, the HD 600s are worth every penny.My listening setup consists of a variety of digital files played from my computer, an Onkyo C-7030 CD player, and a Nuforce Icon DAC/Headphone Amp.  I should also add that I don't use any equalization with my phones.  I messed around running the phones directly off the computer's headphone jack, and I have to say that I highly recommend a good DAC/Amp to get the most out of these cans, as the added power really brings them to life.  And remember that to truly "Listen" to these phones you need to be in a quiet environment.A few other observations:  The 600's clamp quite a bit tighter than the 598s, though they do seem to be loosening up a bit with use.  I think the 598s actually sound a bit wider and a touch brighter, but my 600's only have about 15 hours on them at this writing and like the 598s, I expect them to open up after more time.  I may invest in a better cable in the future, but the included cable gets the job done, and it's more flexible than the one for the 598's (which I also replaced).  I had thought about comparing these to some of my other closed phones for my review, but really, I don't feel that any of them even comes close to these 600s. I've also noticed that with the 598's it is important to find that sweet spot in the volume where the sound really starts to shine, while the 600's play much better and more balanced over a wider range of volume (high and low).I am looking forward to enjoying these headphones for many years to come.  If you have any comments or questions I welcome them and will try my best to answer.  I did extensive research prior to this purchase, so if I can't answer a specific question I may be able to point you in the right direction.Update 1:  After probably 20 more hours of listening I can clarify my comment about the 598s being a little bit brighter.  On certain pieces when I hear a high-hat cymbal on the 598's, I hear it as one sound, and mostly the sound of the cymbal.  On the 600's you clearly hear the stick hitting the cymbal, and the sound of the cymbal itself.  So, I would say the high end of the 600s may not be perceived as being as bright as the 598's, but it is much more defined, clear, and controlled.

I have 3 pairs of these, 1 I use and 2 in reserve.  They have excellent sound and the take well to equalization.  If you like thumping bass and clear highs these are the ticket.  If you like jazz, classical, etc, you can easily dial down the bass and adjust the middle and top a bit for more "flat" listening.  They have a high SPL rating so they'll play loud with not so powerful sources, and the bass will having you looking around for the subwoofer.  I can drive these to incredible levels with my Nuforce uDAC 2 and they play loud and clear.  I could take or leave the uneven cable lengths.  The added carry case comes in handy, and if you take care of these they will last a long time.  My first pair is 2 years old and I use them a lot.

I have converted to Chromebooks for my home computing, so when I needed ink for my old Canon printer I instead opted to buy a cloud ready machine.  The fact that I was able to pick this printer up for only a few bucks more than the cost of ink for my old Canon is good and bad.  Good in that the printer was affordable, and bad because Canon ink is so expensive.  Ink prices have conditioned me to keep my printing to a minimum, preferring to print as pdf files to my Cloud Drive.  I like that I (or my family) can print to this machine from really anywhere they can get online.  This has come in handy on more than one occasion.

I have owned all of the PS systems, and each new generation never fails to impress.  We use it for gaming, watching movie discs, and streaming from the usual sources.  At this point, my only wish is that there were more games available.  Though, from what I understand, there will be over 100 new titles released this year.
Great magazine, and Amazon's price is pretty good.  I often wish for a bit more variety in the articles, but it is pretty typical for magazines of this type.

Great pan.  I use it quite a bit and it is holding up well.  Hopefully it will last a while for me, as I use it pretty regularly.  Most of these pans will fail miserably if you even think about putting them into a dishwasher, so don't do it.  And get some nice wood or plastic utensils as well because you don't want to scratch the coating.  I know that may sound like common sense, but I have lost more pans to the dishwasher or sharp utensil because someone was too lazy to take a second and wipe out the pan or grab a different spoon.

Decent picks.  Much better then the plastic junk that came with the guitar and bass packages I purchased.  Even with my bass these have proven to be quite durable.  I had ordered some heavy gauge (.94mm) picks as well, and I'm hoping they aren't too rigid.  I will likely get some of these in "light" as well.

I have been an Asics guy for a long time now, and I like ordering online because the selection is excellent and I can almost always find my size.  These are a decent shoe, but unlike some of the higher end models, they will take a little bit of breaking in as they were pretty stiff when I received them.  The colors were accurate to how they looked online as well, which is always nice.  I have purchased items that looked deep burgundy online only to look highlighter red when I received them.

I got this cable to use with a Toslink to Coaxial convert that I purchased, as I had run out of optical inputs on my receiver.  This did the job, the sound is great, and the price was right.  I've had good luck with CtG cables in the past and this one was no exception.

I love feather pillows and every 2 years I buy a new expensive one to replace the old. I find them absolutely delicious. So I was a bit disappointed when I received these in the mail. The 2 pillows combined are about the size I'd except one good one. The feathers inside poke through and feel hard, rather than like pillowy down. These are way cheaper than what a good feather pillow would cost though so for the price maybe they're acceptable. I would much rather spend the money though and get a real quality down pillow. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

I like this facial scrub because it's an interesting combination of flavors that don't seem to be very common. They have both contain good properties for the skin as well as smell really good. It lightly exfoliates the skin and I enjoy the feel. My skin looks refreshed when I'm done. I received this product at a reduced price in exchange for an honest review.

These are nice aviator glasses that would look good on a man or woman. I like the look and while the lenses aren't polarized they are anti-glare. They are comfortable to wear and I like the look. The regular price is a good deal for the glasses but I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

This supplement contains many ingredients that are supposed to be great for weight loss so I was excited to try the combination. I haven't experienced any negatives side effects that can often happen with weight loss pills. However I haven't had any noticeable results either. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

I have a lot of friends who swear by the 21 day fix. I haven't wanted to try it because I already have a good work out regime that I enjoy. However the idea of using portion control containers was interesting to me. I was excited to try this product because it gave me that opportunity. I have to admit I was kind of shocked when the product arrived. The containers were way smaller than I expected. But I guess that speaks to over eating and how large our portions have become. I can definitely see how using these containers will make me more aware and help me to lose weight. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

These cufflinks make a nice cheap gift for a man. My husband likes cuff links and have many pairs. I wouldn't say these are the most original or highest quality but for every day use they're fine and they're much cheaper than many of his other pairs. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

I haven't noticed any results yet and I'm assuming this is something that takes awhile to really make a difference. I have used many products with hyaluronic acid but never before in pill form. However I think it's one of the most effective ingredients for aging on the market. I look forward to see results after continued use. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

I've been meaning to go to the doctor to get my thyroid tested but haven't gotten the chance yet. I've been fatigued and I know many women have thyroid problems after having a baby. I was excited to give this a try and see if it helped or not. I honestly don't think it has helped with my energy levels though to be fair I'm not sure that they're due to thyroid problems. What I did notice however is I've been a little more zen and relaxed so I have been enjoying taking them. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

This is a cool looking shower head, very different. Though I think it would look strange in many bathrooms with traditional decor. I love the premise of it filtering the water. Really all shower heads should do that. I was pleased that it was easy to install. I do wish the pressure were a little heavier though. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

My husband swears by creatine to help bulk up and build muscle. I never tried it until now because I don't want to get too big. But I'm actually really happy so far with the results. It hasn't made me huge or bulky but my muscles have gotten more definition from the same amount of work as usual. I'm pretty impressed and glad I finally tried it. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

My legs and feet have been lightly swollen and very painful following a 3 month stint on bed rest. I was interested to try these to see if they'd help with either the swelling or pain. I've been liking it so far, it even seems to help my feet. I think it just keeps the fluid from pooling in my lower extremities in general. This then helps reduce the pain. It's not completely solved but it does help. I received this product at a discount in exchange for an honest review.

I love the stainless steel measuring cups. They well made and sturdy. They can be thrown in the dishwasher and I don't have to worry about lettering coming off as I do with my plastic sets. The spoons are okay but aren't my favorite because they're the older kind where they're really shallow and long. I prefer the deeper kinds that most newer spoons tend to be. It seems to be a more accurate measure that way. I received a discount on a product in exchange for an honest review.

As a big fan of sci-fi I found this futuristic book fascinating. It's well written and I couldn't put the book down. I read it from start to finish in one long and enjoyable sitting. Hiro Suzuki was an interesting character who became more complex with the turning pages. Poppy and Oliver were likable characters and I enjoyed following their story. It was fun to learn more about Japanese culture and some of the futuristic technology was crazy to think about. I'd love to read more books by this author.

I got these for my husband who has been having multiple issues with his feet resulting in a lot of pain. I got him size Large and he usually wears about a size 12. They fit well; he can get them on yet they're snug as they should be. He's been really happy and says that they help his pain a lot. I'm not sure why they work but they do.  I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is a really nice sized bottle of hyaluronic acid which is one of my favorite beauty products. I like that it has a dropper so I can easily get the right amount and not waste any. I like the added ingredients in this serum though because it has a really nice feel and smell. I'm looking forward to continued use to see what improvements it makes on my skin. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is the second set of stroller hooks that I've owned. I loved my old set but it was made of a cheaper plastic which eventually broke. I like that these are a higher quality. I'd be surprised if these ones broke at least anytime soon. They also hold securely to the stroller with velcro. I'm kind of 50/50 though on the actual hook where you hang your diaper bag. The swivel is convenient and it's really easy to hang and remove the bag. However sometimes it can be too easy to remove the bag. My old hooks clamped onto the bag so kids couldn't pull it off and was more secure. It was more of a pain removing the bag but with a wild toddler it was probably a better system. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

I've heard great things about spirulina so I was excited to try this supplement. I was particularly excited since this brand said there was no bad taste, because that was another thing I'd heard about spirulina. I haven't had any problem with the taste. When you're taking a capsule the taste doesn't really matter because it goes down so fast. However I also haven't noticed any difference in how I feel. It's possible it's doing things to help me such as cardiovascular health and it's just benefits I don't feel. I also haven't finished the bottled yet so if I feel differently as time goes on I'll update my review. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

This serum contains all of my favorite ingredients for skin care, vitamin C being my top favorite. It has a nice scent and isn't greasy feeling. I haven't been using it very long so I can't attest to results. I'm assuming it will improve my skin due to the high quality ingredients but I'll update again after using it for longer. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

I got this cream for massaging my muscles since it said it was a muscle relaxer. I've been in a lot of pain lately and was interested to see if my husband used this while massing me if it would help work some of the pain out better than massage alone. I haven't found that it works better than any other massage lotion but I do find the scent to be pleasant so I won't have a hard time using up the container. I can't speak to the effects against cellulite because I thankfully don't have any yet. I received a discount on a product in exchange for my honest review.

We've only had this a few days but so far we're loving it. I never knew you could have so much fun with a toaster... I had seen this originally while looking for a new toaster but passed it by because the name made it sound like it wasn't also a normal toaster. However a friend randomly mentioned wanting this toaster and it made me take a closer look. It does everything I wanted in a normal toaster. It has a defrost feature, it lifts the toast really high so it's easy to pull out and has a bagel setting.The egg component is just a fun bonus. All weekend long we've been making breakfast sandwiches and our kids love them too. The unit comes with a little measuring cup that tells you the amount of water to use depending on what type of eggs you want. You pour that in and then crack the eggs into the compartments. The measuring cup has a point on the bottom so that you can easily break the yokes. When you select the toast and egg dual setting it will wait to start toasting until the eggs coordinate to be done at the same time as whatever doneness you want your toast. This way everything is nice and hot. You can warm the meat at the same time too, though for many of our sandwiches we made fresh bacon in a pan. The egg comes out hot enough to melt a piece of cheese.My only disappointment was that the toaster couldn't handle a small croissant, since I prefer those with my breakfast sandwiches to English muffins. The first one came out burnt to a crisp. Once we realized it was burning there was no way to stop it since it was toasting at the same time as the eggs. I tried then toasting separately at a lower setting and this time it got stuck and mangled. So not great for croissants but it's not billed as such anyway. I haven't tried making soft or hard boiled eggs yet but I'm excited to try that setting next.

I typically use a CBTL single cup maker which offers espresso pods. While I enjoy the convenience it provides and the coffee is pretty good considering sometimes I do crave a more authentic full blown taste or simply want to make more than what a pod outputs. I honestly didn't even realize there were stovetop espresso makers, I thought you needed to have a big expensive machine. I love that with this unit we can make up to 6 cups and it's actually much faster than I expected. The coffee it makes is good and obviously dependent largely on the bean and quantity used. I marked one star off because it's lighter weight and a little lower quality than I was expected but functionally this is great. I received a discount on this product in exchange for an honest review.

This is a really high quality cord. The nylon coating is much better and stronger than the typical plastic. I put this in my car to charge my phone on the go and I've had several friends ask where I got it because it has a nice look and just seems nicer than the average cord. It does a great job of charging and of transferring data. I received a free product in exchange for my honest review.

I had a previous blanket by JJ Cole that I had since lost. I loved the look and quality of the blanket, however that one I had to fold up and try to fit inside some straps. It was a pain and the blanket would fall out of the straps so it wasn't the best design. This blanket is majorly improved. The bag shown on top of the blanket in the picture isn't a separate bag, it's what the blanket looks like when it's folded up. It's super obvious how to fold the blanket and then it just velcros shut into what looks like a small bag. It's incredibly easy to do and then it can be carried like a purse on my arm. I like the look of this blanket as well and I love the material. It's thick enough that grass and sticks don't poke through and it's really comfortable. It's easy to wipe clean with a wet rag. My only complaint is I wish it were bigger. I may just purchase a second because it's not big enough for my whole family. It's ideal for 2-3 people depending on their size.

I've owned this brand before in various sizes and I love all the cords. The fabric holds up the better than regular cords and I like the look as well. They work just as well as OEM cords. This 3 ft is a great in between size where it's not too long but not too short whether you want it for bedside, computer or car charging. I received this product for free in exchange for an honest review.

The size on this is great, it really is the size and maybe just a tiny bit heavier than a credit card. It is very convenient to be able to have these type of tools in your wallet. I think some of them are more to seem cool than to be usable; I'm not sure why you'd need a microscopic red LED light. The magnifying glass is too small to be of use and not good quality. But I think having tweezers, scissors, a stylus and the tiny screw driver can all come in handy at the right time. I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest review.

This cord is the perfect length if you want something short that doesn't look messy or take up a lot of space. It's too short to get tangled. I liked using this length at my computer because I can't stand having cords all over the place. It works perfectly for that purpose. It's high quality and charges really fast. I received a free product in exchange for an honest review.

This glass is really thin which is nice because it doesn't add any bulk or weight to the phone. I was afraid to try smashing it or dropping it on my phone in case it didn't work, so I tried it out off the phone first. I tried scratching it with a knife, dropping it on the floor, and banging it on the counter. It didn't crack or scratch. So I then felt comfortable that it would be able to adequately protect my phone. It hasn't interfered with my ability to use the screen in any way. I received this product for free in exchange for my honest review.

I really like two things about this cord. The first is that the 6 ft length is really nice because it's long without being too long. I also really like that it's covered in a durable fabric. It makes it so it doesn't get tangled up, plus it's just a higher quality that lasts. I wish all cords came this way. I received a free product in exchange for my honest review.

I've often tried to do an at home mani to save time and money from going to the nail salon but mine never turns out the same. I've realized that a big part of that is because I don't remove the cuticles the same. I've used a stick to push them back but then it's just kind of a thick lump. I was excited when I saw these because it seemed like it would get a better manicure by actually removing the excess cuticle rather than shoving it back. It took me a little bit to master it because at first I was nervous about ripping my skin. I managed to do it without bleeding and it looked good so I'll call that a win. I received a discount on a product in exchange for an honest review.

We've had an Aeropress for several years and have been very happy with the coffee it makes. Since we find even doing the "4 cup" setting it really only makes enough for one person so between my husband and myself we go through at least 2 disposable filters a day. The packs are large so they do last quite awhile however it seemed like a nice idea to have a reusable one since the cost does add up over the years. My biggest concern was that it would somehow alter or affect the taste of the coffee and thankfully I haven't found that to be the case. It works well and we're happy with these new filters. It's slightly more work since it's another part to wash and keep track of, we seem to always be losing small parts. But overall I think it's worth it for the savings that would accumulate over time. I received a discount in exchange for an honest review.

This is a great starter kit if you can find it locally and get it at a good price.  I was able to do both, and I am really happy with the purchase.The terrarium itself is well made, and the top works very well.  It slides in and out, and has a small attachment that makes it so that your crabs won't be able to get out of it.It comes with some substrate, but you'll probably want to get a bit more for keeping your hermit crabs adequately.  It's got two bowls for water, and the conditioner to have the water dechlorinated and one to turn it into salt water.It's got food, and some treats.Is absolutely everything you need to raise healthy hermit crabs included?  No.  You'll need lights, thermometer/hygrometer, some more substrate, and another bowl...but it's a darn good start.I notice that most of the reviews that are negative involve the terrarium arriving damaged.  This is why I mention looking for this locally...then you don't have to worry about any damage.

This lamp stand works great with our 10 gallon terrarium.I have it holding a Zoo Med Mini Combo Deep Dome, and it does the job really well.  It's held in place by the weight of the terrarium, and the knobs lock everything in place really well.  I like that it's got adjustments on it, it makes it so that I can lower it a bit when using it at night (only 40w bulb) and then raise it a bit during the day (60w bulb).Overall, I'm very happy with the stand.

My wife and I bought this lamp to use with a 10 gallon terrarium that houses three small hermit crabs.  The light holds a 40w night bulb and a 60w day bulb, and it works great.  It's well made, doesn't get hot to the touch (with the bulbs we are using) and has the convenience of cord mounted on/off switches.Overall, I would recommend this lamp to anyone...if it fits your needs.

Comfortable?  Check.Basic?  Check.Well made?  Check.Warm?  Check.I bought this sweatshirt to use with a Mr. Robot costume for Halloween.  Oddly enough I didn't have an all black zip-up hoodie, and this one was the least expensive.  Being from Hanes, I knew it would be good quality, too.For the price, I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better hoodie.  It's comfy, warm, looks good, and well made.I recommend it.

I purchased a Prism Isotope on a recent trip to Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.  I've had experience with all types of kites, but the Isotope is a style I've never flown before...it's kind of a hybrid box and diamond kite.The kite goes together easily, comes with a really nice set of line on a really nice winder, and comes packaged in a very nice kite bag.  I also really like the giant tail that comes with the kite.I put the kite up in the air the day I got it, and it was a pretty steady 15 MPH wind.It flew wonderfully.  It climbed steadily, had a nice amount of pull, and looks AMAZING in the sky.  The tail flutters in the wind while the kite stays locked in place.  I really can't describe how great the kite looks in the air.I let all 300 feet of the line out, and the kite is so large that it's still easily seen in the sky.  I flew the kite for about 90 minutes before starting to slowly reel it back in.  The kite pulls so hard, and there is so much line, that brining it back in took me about another 30 minutes!!  Good stuff!!This kite looked so great in the air that I had several other people on the beach tell me that they had actually stopped by a shop and bought a kite after seeing mine in the air so that they could fly one themselves.Overall, I'm VERY happy with the Prism Isotope...and when the wind picks up here in Michigan, I'll be putting this up in the air as much as I can!!

I bought a Prism EO6 on a recent vacation to Myrtle Beach, South Carolina.I'm an experienced kite flyer...dual lines, single lines, quad lines...however, I'd never actually flown a box kite before.  I thought the EO6 looked like a cool option, and I've had experience with the Prism brand before.I took the EO6 out the day after I got it, in probably about 8MPH winds.  After a few launches, I was able to get it up into the air...and man, what a cool kite.It looks amazing floating in the wind above you, and really generates some looks from the other beach goers.  I was able to get the kite all the way out on it's line without crashing it, and it flew steadily and gracefully for about an hour, before I reeled it back in.The winder that comes with the kite is a nice one...it's much better than many of the handles with line on them that come with some other kites.I also like how the kite folds down and stores easily with a few pieces of elastic.  Good stuff.Overall, I really like the kite, and I'll for sure be flying it more in the future.

I bought this battery for another quadcopter that uses a similar size with the same style of JST plug.This battery fits perfectly, provides good run time, and is holding up well.If this fits your vehicle, give this a go.  It's a good quality battery.

These are one of my cat's favorite toys, yet they end up being difficult to find locally.This package gets me enough of them to replace them when she loses them, which ends up being fairly often.I really like these, as they're cheap, colorful, and come in a good quantity here on Amazon.  If your cat likes this type of toy, this will not disappoint.

Great micro for use in the house.It's nice and stable, a great size for indoor use, and turns and hovers very well once you get it trimmed correctly.The nice part about it is as you get better with controlling it, you can turn up the sensitivity on the controller, and once everything is all maxed out you'll have a responsive, quick, agile RC for using in a bit more open spaces.I've had a lot of fun using mine, and I would recommend it to anyone.

I purchased my Galaxy Seeker from a local specialty toy store.  I like the guys that work there, and they were quick to praise the other Odyssey Toys line of quadcopters, so I took a chance on this one for flying around the yard.I've been very happy with this quadcopter.Earlier this summer I sold my DJI Phantom because I was getting tired of being bothered by people while I was using it about who or what I was "spying" on with my "drone."  It got old, quick, to the point where I didn't even want to take it out and fly it.I did like flying quads, though, so when I found the Galaxy Seeker at the store, I quickly took a liking to it.Lets get this right out of the way, this is a rebrand of a quad with a different name...it seems to be a licensed rebrand, but you can look around and possibly find the "original" for a bit less money than what Odyssey is selling it for.  That said, Odyssey is a company based in the United States, and they have actual humans that answer the phone when you call them...which is good.  You can get parts from them if you break anything, and they seemed to me to be a good group of people.  The small toy store I buy from prides itself on only selling good products, and the owner was impressed enough with Odyssey to carry the stuff in his store, so I trust that Odyssey is working hard to keep customers happy with good products.There are a couple of other things that should be noted about the product, as they differ from what's on the box.The most notable are two fold.1.  The box says that this quad features an HD camera, yet I have found that I can only display videos from it in 640x480 resolution, which is fine for the included monitor, but it's far from HD2.  The box says that the system runs on a 5.8ghz system, but I've found that it actually runs on 2.4ghz.  This won't mean a lot for a lot of people, but for serious users (hobbyists) it means the range on the FPV system will be a little bit limited.For me, I have not found either of these to be an issue, really, so I'm not letting it impact the score of the quad...however, they do need to be noted, as they are being misrepresented on the box.Finally, for my last negative...the manual leaves a bit to be desired.  There are a few features mentioned that it doesn't really explain how to use...I was able to figure them out by some trial and error, but I'd like to see a manual that actually tells you how to use all of the features.Now, I know that this seems like a lot of negatives...but, they really don't detract, to me, from the fun that this quad has provided me.Let's move on to the good!!!First off, the packaging looks very nice.  It's a good quality cardboard with a front that "flips open" to reveal the contents of the package through a clear plastic window.Upon opening the package, I was impressed with the look of the quad.  The black and red looks are sharp, and I'm a big fan of the "fin" on the back of it...it makes it look like a spaceship to me, which I like.  For the record, I'm an experienced RC pilot, so I am not using the blade guards...it saves a bit of weight, and I feel it looks better without them, however, they are included so you can add them if you need to.The quad body is made out of a lightweight, but strong feeling, plastic.  It almost feels like a kind of Lexan.  It feels like it has a "bend but don't break" kind of build, so I'm guessing that a hard crash would cause the plastic to bend but not actually break anything.  The landing legs are made out of the same material, and I've had a couple of rough landings, but nothing has been damaged.  Finally, the graphics on the body are actually painted on...they aren't stickers or decals, so that's a good quality touch.The camera that is included clips onto the bottom of the quad, then plugs into it.  I found it a bit difficult to get it clipped on the first time, but since I've gotten it on the first time, I've had no issues getting it on again and again.  A quick note about the camera...the manual mentions that you need to put the Micro SD card in the monitor for recording, but this is incorrect.  You can put the SD card in to VIEW the things you've recorded on the monitor, but in order to control the camera, you will need the SD card in the camera.  This is one of those "errors" in the manual that I was mentioning.The included transmitter is basic, but it gets the job done.  It feels good in the hand, has all of the necessary controls, and the top actually has a spot to mount the included 4.3" monitor for viewing the FPV from the quad's onboard camera.  With the monitor installed, the whole thing feels a bit heavier than I'm used to, but that's to be expected, as I'm not used to having a monitor on my transmitter.  The monitor can be taken off of the transmitter, so you could have someone else watch that while you watch the quad.The transmitter uses 4 AA batteries, and the quad uses one 3.7v (1s) 700mah LiPo battery.  The charger included for the LiPo plugs into a USB port, and seems to charge the battery in about an hour.  The good news about the battery is it seems to be a fairly standard size, so a bit of looking around should net you some inexpensive extra batteries.The quad flies really well.  It's pretty fast in it's "fast" setting, and nice, slow, and stable in it's normal setting.  I've flown the quad in 15 MPH winds and had it survive just fine.  It's a bit of a handful in that kind of wind, but it can handle it.  In low winds, it flies like a dream.I really like flying the quad.  It's easy to control, nice and light so if you do happen to crash it in the grass it's not going to end up getting damaged.  It has a "flip" function built into the transmitter that works very well.  I would actually kind of classify this as a mild "sport" quad due to it's speed in the faster setting...it's really quick, and it can cover quite a bit of ground fairly quickly.The FPV function works really well.  This is my first real experience with "real time" FPV, and I've been really happy with it.  The frame rate drops as the range increases, but it works well out to about 50 meters, more if you seem to be in the right place at the right time.  Flying FPV is certainly a different experience...it's strange.  I found that at first I made sure that while flying while looking at the monitor, I still made sure that I could see the quad in my peripheral vision, which helped me to make sure it wasn't going to crash, or fly into a car, or something.The only thing wrong with the whole FPV system is the monitor doesn't have a sunscreen on it.  This doesn't really bother me, as I typically fly while standing in the shad anyway, but for someone that has to fly in the sun, it might be a good idea to create a shade for the screen.I've been impressed by the battery life on the quad, as well.  It will fly on it's tiny little battery for a good 7-8 minutes in relatively calm wind...less in higher winds, more in completely still wind.  You can fly even longer if you take the camera off and just fly while watching the quad.The motors in the quad were one thing I worried about, seeing as they're just tiny brushed motors...however, after quite a few flights they are still holding up just fine, so I think that their slightly larger size (they're 8.5mm where a lot of small quads use 7mm motors) is helping to take some of the strain off of them even though the quad is a bit heavier than other small quads.So far, I've really enjoyed the Galaxy Seeker.  It's fun to fly, which is the most important thing about a product like this.  The FPV works very well, also, which was a major selling point of the quad for me.  I, personally, even enjoyed trying to figure out how to get those features that I wasn't sure how to work.If you are looking for a good first quad to try FPV, I think the Galaxy Seeker would make a good choice for you.

This is a good indoor quadcopter.It's very unique looking, it looks like the Helicarrier from the Marvel Movies, which is very cool.  It's got a LOT of lights on it, and it's very easy to see even in the dark.It's large, at over two feet long, and this size ends up causing it to move fairly slowly.  I didn't mind that it was slow, because I felt it gave it a "scale" look compared to the Helicarriers from the movies.  Some people might not like the slow speeds, however, so keep in mind that this is in no way a "fast" quad.The controller feels good in the hands, works well, but is very basic.  For this quad, that made no difference to me...I just wanted to be able to fly it.This quadcopter makes a great indoor flyer, and it CAN fly outdoors...however, you must do so in VERY little wind.  It's large body tends to be fairly susceptible to wind blowing it around and causing it to not fly very well.  In still conditions, though, it works just fine.Overall, I'm happy with this product.

Stikbot Studio is fun.  I'm absolutely terrible at it, but it's fun...and with a LOT of practice and experience, I'm guessing that anyone could make a pretty serviceable stop motion animated film with these characters.The Stikbots themselves are wonderful.  They are put together well, easy to pose, and the suction cups on their limbs work well to hook them onto things for you to film them in various different poses.The included "tripod" isn't the greatest quality, but it works.  I find it works best if you use a timer on your camera app, which then makes it so that the phone isn't moving at all from being touched when the photo is being taken.  The free app that you can use for this product, which I am using on iPhone 6, has the ability to set a timer from 1-10 seconds.  I've found that setting it for 5 seconds gives you time to touch the phone while it's on the tripod, let the tripod and phone "settle" from the vibrations from you touching the screen, and then take the image with the camera still, so the images come out clean and clear.I actually bought this product to "animate" a character that I'm creating for a class.  I can't draw to save my life, and the class only requires the "concept" of the character to be brought to life.  Ultimately, I will be using one of the Stikbots to represent my character, and the other to represent his "enemy," and I will be making a short animation of them fighting for the class.I think it will turn out really well, as the stuff I've made with the product already has been solid...if not very imaginative.I like the product, and am having fun with it.  The characters are great, the app works well, and the tripod is serviceable.  I recommend this to anyone that is on the fence about buying it.

This is my first real balaclava, and I have to say I'm really impressed by it.It fits me well...and I've got a pretty big head.It's comfortable, easy to get on and take off, fits you multiple different ways, and can easily be smashed down and stored in a pocket of your jacket when you're not using it.I love the material it's made out of it.  It's one of those "high tech" fabrics that somehow breathes while remaining warm, yet doesn't make you too hot when it's actually warm out and you're using it in the sun.  It also wicks sweat away from your skin which helps to keep you nice and cool.I've been using it for several things while testing it out this summer.  Under my motorcycle helmet it's nice because it wicks the sweat away from my head and helps to keep me cool.  When I take it off after taking my helmet off, the balaclava is moist, but my head is less sweaty than normal, and the liner of my helmet seems to be less "moist."  I believe that this is because the balaclava is basically retaining most of the moisture, which is awesome.The other thing I've been doing is wearing it as a facemask while working on some landscaping projects around my house.  These projects have ended up being VERY dusty, and I was finding myself coughing quite a bit while working on them.  With the balaclava on, I'm able to easily breath yet it doesn't cause me to feel like I'm lacking any oxygen...basically, the air flows through, the dust and dirt does not.  Very cool.Overall, I'm really happy with this product, and I can't wait to get it on during the winter when it's time to snowblow.  It's gonna be great for that!!Highly recommended!!!***I was provided a sample for a discounted price in order to review.  I was not compensated for the review, and my opinions on this product are my own and accurate***

I've been using the money belt when riding my motorcycle for the last couple of weeks.I couldn't be happier with this product for that purpose.When I used to ride with my wallet and my phone in my pockets, I was constantly reaching down to make sure that they hadn't fallen out.  I'm not sure what I would have done had I reached down and realized that they HAD in fact fallen out...I mean, it's not like I'm really going to be able to suddenly stop and instantly find them.Anyway, now that I've got this belt, I just toss it on underneath my jacket and throw my stuff inside it.  When I zip up my jacket, I'm superbly confident that the items aren't going to end up being lost, and I don't have to worry about reaching down to check my pockets.As stated, I'm wearing the belt over my clothes, however, for even more secrecy (or maybe when traveling) you could wear this under your shirt and it would be very comfortable and easily concealed.The belt is well made, has two different pockets, nice zippers, and a nice plastic side release buckle to make sure that it stays in place.The best part of this package is that it comes with two belts, so you can use one until it starts to wear out from use, then swap it out for the new one and keep right on going.Overall, I'm very happy with this money belt, and I've found it to be a real pleasure for when I'm riding my motorcycle.Recommended.***I was given a sample to review for a discounted price, however, I was not compensated for the review in any way and the opinions are true and accurate***

I got this to use as a utility belt for a Captain America costume I'm working on.The belt is made well, looks nice, has good stitching, nice hardware, and fits a wide range of waist sizes.  It's easy to adjust, the buckle works well and is nice and strong, and each pocket opens and closes easily.I needed it to be a darker brown for my use, so I dyed it with RIT dye.  It took the dye pretty well, but if you are planning on doing this, I would recommend washing the belt first with some soap and water...it seems to have just a tiny bit of water resistant coating put on it.  After rubbing the belt down, it took the dye a lot better than when I just dipped it in the dye.I'll attach some photos of it in the darker brown to show how it turned out.Overall, if you're looking for this type of belt, this one is a good choice.  Recommended.

I love this external battery.I've been testing it for a few weeks now, and I can honestly say that it's the best external battery that I've ever used.  It charges devices at both 2.1 amp and 1 amp, depending on the needs of your device.  Obviously the 2.1 amp setting will charge the items faster if your item can accept the higher charge rate.The screen on the device is really nice.  It shows you the percentage of charge left in the battery itself, the voltage output, and the amperage output.  Being able to see how much "juice" is left in the battery at any given time is really valuable.  You know if you should worry about charging it, or if you can get by with waiting and using it one more time.It holds it's charge well, also.  After using it several times, I fully charged it and depleted the battery to 86%.  It stayed at 86% for over a week without dropping at all, and based on my use of it after doing this, the 86% was accurate as I was able to use the battery to charge devices just as much as before letting it sit.The battery also has a flashlight on it, which is a nifty feature that can come in handy.What I have been mainly using this battery for is charging my iPhone 6 while I sleep.  My phone's charger in my bedroom is nowhere near the bed, so I can't reach the phone to use the alarm clock.  This battery allows me to leave the phone on my nightstand and charge it, then during the day I recharge the backup battery when it needs it.  It's working like a charm.I also wanted to take a quick moment to note how nice the product looks.  It's minimalistic in design, yet very pleasing on the eyes.  It's not just some ugly box that you're connecting to your phone...it looks like a nice product.Overall, I highly recommend this.***EDIT***I was provided a sample product for a review.  The review is honest and contains my accurate impressions and experiences with the product.

My wife got me a Rover 2.0 for Christmas this past year.I'm a big RC fan, and I also like things that take pictures and videos.  The Rover 2.0, she thought, would be right up my alley.She was right.I tore into the box before even finishing opening my other gifts.  I loved this thing right off the bat.I got it all set to go and set about on a mission to get some footage of the elusive Presto...the black cat that lives in my house.Controlling the Rover was simple with the app on my iPad.  I feel that the larger screen real estate on the tablet helps with controlling the device.  My iPhone worked really well, also, but I just thought the larger screen helped make it a bit easier.The Rover 2.0 looks cool, too.
