I received this book early from another website I belong to. I hope this review is helpful to you.Pearlman's stories and incredibly descriptive, with an excellent use of symbolism, tone, and some surprisingly cynical surprises.The short stories primarily take place in Massachusetts, with Rennie as the main character in most.I must warn you there are some vivid accounts of some deeply troublesome topics, such as female circumcision. For me this was a bit shocking and far outside my comfort zone. However, it was handled in a tactful way and easy to digest once the initial shock wears off.Overall, the stories are quite intelligent and are based on the simplicity of regular people who experience a shocking or unexpected event/situation. Certainly an interesting, smart, and moving way to spend your time as a reader.My hat is off to Pearlman and hope you found this review helpful. I didn't want to give too much away. Certainly worth getting!!!

I hope this review is helpful, as this is the whole reason I am taking the time to write this. I did receive an advanced copy of this book, through another website, and am sharing my review on here as well.Let me start by saying I have read many different diet books, and this is in the top tier of them. Its informative and easy to follow. Basically, DR. Phil doesn't just tell you what to do and what results to expect, but he goes into detail on why. For me, understanding the reason behind things makes it easier for me to motivate myself. After reading this book, I shy away from less healthy foods simply because I can envision the damage they are doing to my body, and not just because I know they are "bad".The major purpose of the book is to identify the foods your body needs to "fuel" itself properly. Basically, how to put super unleaded in your car, instead of cheap gas that overtime will break down the system. This is done in 3 phases.Phases:These 3 phases are two 5 day and then followed up by a 20 day.Phase 1 (days 1-5): "Boost" - You eat every 4 hours, increasing metabolism, with basic foods.Phase 2 (days 6-10): "Sustain" -  Same pace, but now adding in more diversity of foods.Phase 3 (days 11-30): "Attain" - Same pace, but by now all foods have been added in.Foods:The approach to food is simple. Dr. Phil knows that we simply can not eliminate foods forever. So what he does is just have you "put them off" for amounts of time. This allows you the comfort of knowing you will eventually have that piece of cake or other goodie you love. However, since he is keeping it space out, you have controlled "slip ups" and only end up having these treats a harmless amount of times over the course of the program, or however long you choose to live your lifestyle this way.Overall I think the program and goals are obtainable. Out of all the books/programs I have tried, this is one of the few I have been happy doing, and personally bought into. I understand the reasoning, can handle the program and am seeing results!!!Trust me when I say get this book. Its not expensive, and at minimum it will increase your health and make you loose a few pounds. At best, you could make an entire lifestyle change and see dramatic results!!!I wish you all the best on your journey to physical change through diet. Keep in mind we are all beautiful and you can reach any goal you set your mind to. Keep the faith in yourself!!!I hope this helped!

I received these as a Christmas gift and thought I should offer some advice to help anyone considering making the purchase.Pros:They are super soft. Almost cashmere soft. I'm not an expert on fabric and thread counts and such, but however they made these, it's made them super soft.Also, you will not have an issue keeping warm. Typical with hat and mittens like these, the heat is kept in well. You'll find no difference here.Cons:We did find a stich that needing fixing on the hat. I did fix it myself quickly, but it may be enough to deter other buyers. It wasn't a major issue at all, just a end stich for the seam. Looks like they didn't back over the track and simply used an end knot.Cosmetically they are a bit boring. I doubt anyone will be thrilled to pull these out of the closet and add to an outfit. They just look like every other pair I have and previously owned.My summation is that these are not bad at all, but will quickly enter the world of other forgotten gloves, hats, scarves, and so on. They are not bad at all, but not great enough for you to have a feeling one way or the other.My recommendation is only buy these if your drawn to the way they look. If the style does it for you, I'd grab them. Otherwise take a pass in my opinion.They were about 30 bucks at the time of this review.Hope this helped!

purchased the large (5'8" 150lbs) and it fits like a glove. Not tight and hangs very nice on my body.Material is polyester, so it's not the most breathable, but it doesn't get overly hot to sleep in or walk around the house in.I just toss it in with the rest of the laundry and have had zero issues in that area.Material is very smooth and light on the body. I can only compare it to having a "summery" feeling, if that makes sense. It's just really comfortable and relaxing to be in.It's really lovely and well made. Lots of small little nuances make it seem not so typical. The stitching is also top notch. Not a thread out of place.Overall a safe choice if you like these. I'd order a size bigger than you need to have a little more "flowy" feel, but that's just my opinion. Standard sizing will fit you just fine.I hope this review was helpful, as I tried to think what I would have wanted to know.You will be most happy with this purchase!

I hope this review gives the info to make an informed purchase.My body type is not magazine worthy to say the least. I've got a heathy layer of insulation for the winter and I'm happy with that. However, these underwear are not the most flattering on my body type.My backside kinda hangs out the sides in the back a bit more than im comfortable with, and doesn't get any extra "lift" at all. It should have been clear from the pictures, but I figured there would be some tension in the back, but there's none.The band around the top fits like a glove and just the right amount of tightness where they are secure but not tight.The material is comfortable and the style is very pretty and feminine in person.These are very similar to the pairs you would get at VS, and similar sizes as well. You may be able to get a deal on here and no one, including you, could tell the difference between these and VS.Overall I like these, and only took the star away because I felt a bit more info on the body type these are for could have been helpful. Maybe that's silly, but I wish there was a note somewhere saying these really offer zero support.I hope this helps you make your decision. They are very comfy and got perfect. I guess I'm just not built for this specific style.

when making a Jewlery purchase I care about a few things the most. Quality, size, weight, appearance, price. Hopefully going through each will be helpful for you.Quality - This is very well made. The clasp seems like it's ready for years of use, with an almost hard to pull lever, making me know it needs to be broken in. Also, each section is spot welded together, instead of cheaply glued. This looks like it will stand the test of time and several tosses on the top of your dresser at night.Size - This is certainly chunky. It's going to look best on a low cut top or tank. It spans the majority of my upper breast plate area. There's no way anyone would miss this dramatic statement.Weight - it's slightly heavy. Not shocking but heavy enough to notice. I didn't put it on a scale, but it feels like having my cell phone hanging from my neck. You will be able to forget it's there, but it's not light enough not to notice at first.Appearance - the pictures don't do it justice. The color is so deep and attractive. The design and overall appeal is enough to garuntee at least one person in the mall approaching me about it. You can't miss here!Price - I got it for around 250, which was the top of my price point. However, it's well worth that price tag. The overall quality and joy I get from it are worth more than that price. Anything over and Id wait for a sale.I hope this helps! Overall I'd say go for it and enjoy this necklace!

Fitment was a little tight and gave me really bad back fat. For the 90 I paid, it wasn't worth it.They also don't give the kind of support most other mainstream pairs would.Overall not a good purchase.

I hope my review is helpful, and I will try to provide the info I need when making a purchase.These are very similar in quality to VS. No fear of a dreaded wedge.Overall I really love these and can't wait to grab some more. A solid purchase and as good as it gets!

This stylish hooded sweatshirt is the ideal option for that young girl looking to stay warm and be stylish yet presentable.The soft cotton construction not only allows for easy washing, but doesn't make you overheat if you wear it for a while.My absolute favorite part is the cut of the sweatshirt. Mary Casanova does an amazing job putting together an easily read book for young women, while making it fun and delivering a positive message.Overall the book is about choices, teamwork and responsibility. It follows the leads choices when tackling hard problems with a business, friends, family, travel, and a dog.These topics are mearly analogous to problems we all will face as young adults. Is it worth taking on added responsibility for added success/happiness? How do I deal with group dynamics? Am I a leader? How to I handle failure?This book couldn't be any more positive and fun! An absolute joy to read (as I try to read my kids books)! A must buy for girls between 8 and 16 in my opinion.

For those of you not familiar with the back story, Ben Franklin (yes, the inventor Nd founding father) had done a lot of creative writing in addition to inventing and working towards the independence of the USA in the 1700s.One of his works was trying to indentify the virtues a person would need to exhibit to achieve almost a transcendent, pure, and ideal way to live. These are things like patience and humility.Think of the opposite of the seven deadly sins.The books goes through each one and delves into them, while keeping the authors message in small, digestible pieces.Overall, this book gives the reader a clear understand of Ben Franklins 13 virtues as well as some interesting thoughts on his motivations and what the sum of them bring.Overall a great, light, easy read. Fun for the train or perhaps a gift for someone looking for spirituality, without it being faith based.

This cookbook is one of the best I have ever owned. It's clear, consice, and easy to follow.The vast majority of dishes are accompanied by clear photos, so you can at first glance decide if your in the mood for it.All the details are contained for each dish as well, not just ingredients like some other books, but times, step, and helpful little tips and tricks (like fold instead of kneed).My favorite part of the book is the high health level of each dish. The foods called out for are unprocessed and low in fat/sugar.There are however a lot of recipes youd expect: lemon chicken, veggie stir fry, fruit salad, etc. Which is why I removed a star. However, there's loads more I haven't tried all in one easy to follow place.Overall I say it's a safe bet. While these may not all be brand new dishes, they are all good for you and presented in an easy way to follow, with pictures to help along the way. You won't regret this purchase!

let me start by saying, this set is really beautiful and a must buy! Here's why:Construction:The coat and pants are really, really well made. Not a stich out of place and feels higher end than I was used to. The shirt is also really nice, but doesn't feel like a 10/10 as the others, but still an 8/10 and great. The shirt we got did have a couple loose threads, but not a huge deal.The shirt and pants are cleverly made from cotton while the coat is polyester, keeping baby cool when in the house and having the coat off.Upkeep:The shirt and pants are ready for a mess! Spit up, formula, anything. Just toss them in the wash with everything else, since they are made from all 100% cotton.The coat is polyester, so while you can still machine wash it, just be sure to put it on the correct settings when you do. We hang dry ours, but that's up to you.Cosmetics:I can't say enough. The pictures on Amazon don't do it justice. It have some little touches on the ends and neck line that make it really uncommonly nice.Looks beautiful in little girls and still nice on boys, but maybe a touch feminine.Fitment:Fits a little loose on a 10lb bundle of joy. I'm assuming they have a decent amount of time before this becomes a hand me down!Easy to get on, no funny pulling of arms or stretching over the head. Just well made!Price: price point anywhere under 75 is good in my opinion. While it may seem a lot, your getting 3 pieces, with one being a coat. It's also warm, comfy, and fits right. It's similar to other high end brands you would find at the mall.Overall I say buy this. If it's a gift, you'll look like a master of baby gifts! It's 3 seperate pieces making a beautiful outfit! Worst case, you return it..... Which you won't. What do you have lose!?

This is an easy read for a young adult that hits a homerun for fast forgot family values!My girls both read this book and were not only learning about countries abroad (France/Europe), but we're asking questions about resolving issues like an adult.I read this, like most of my kids books, to stay current and have a discussion point. I'll keep this review short - buy this book.Unlike all the other diet books that promise something they can't deliver, this did it. Me and my wife both could follow the logic, understood the message, and love the entire path laid out for us!!It's a real winner!!

This is a no frills, easy to use way to just get rid of nose hair. You put in the batteries, and your good to go. Just put it in your nose, hit the button and in 15 seconds your done.This really doesn't do much for any other spots like your ears or eyebrows, unless you are planning on spending a long time feeding hairs in one by one.Overall it's awesome at the low price point. I have a spare in the glove box since it's so small and I tend to grow nose hair faster than I do on my head. If only it would fall out of my nose too!!Give this a shot. Don't waste your money on some overpriced tool. This is all you need.

Tired of the same old breakfast coffees but want a light roast? Look no further!This coffee has a really nice taste, similar to what you would expect from a drive through coffee store. I'm used to the DD coffee in the morning, and this is really close.This coffee is not overly caffeinated and very smooth. A great morning and all day coffee.No cons here. It's really the best option for a light roast drinker.Give this coffee a try, you'll never go back to a breakfast blend or drive through again.

I have this shower with corian-type walls. It was here when I moved in. While I like it very much, it is difficult to hang anything on. Suction cups always slide for me, especially in the winter. I don't know if it is because the cold reduces their flexibility or what, but my old baskets were a total pain. I hate those over the showerhead things, so I was stuck. I really didn't want to drill through that material.This item is very nice. Big...so both my daughter and son can have their products here including a razor (super nice that they included a hook for that!) and some hooks for the poof things. The only trouble was that I didn't want to use the included adhesive. I worried that if I ended up not liking this or it broke, I would be stuck trying to pry the thing off the wall.What I did was use 8 large Command Water-Resistant strips instead of their adhesive. I put two on the bottom of each mounting area and two upside down near the top of each side. That way, I still have access to the removal tabs if I ever do want to take it down or move it. Be sure to follow the directions with cleaning using alcohol first. And I let mine sit there without the refill bottles for 24 hours. Then I added the bottles and filled them. Perfect!I also had some trouble with the pumps not wanting to dispense. I pumped the shampoo about 30-40 times before it came out. And the body wash still isn't coming out (I just put it up today.) I counted 100 pumps and gave up. I may dump out my body wash and try water first, then add the wash back. It's weird because the body wash is actually thinner than the shampoo...so it seems like it should come out.The item isn't super high-end thick polycarbonite and steel. The middle is metal, but the bottles are plastic and chrome colored plastic. It looks nice though and is super functional. I used to have one of these at my last house (and of course used their adhesive and didn't bother trying to remove it when I moved!) That one didn't have removable bottles and it was a little bit of a pain to fill it. I really like that these come off (although I did knock one off accidentally TRYING to pump it.) Remember to just push, not push and lift or it will pop off.I do really like that the buttons are on the bottom...sort of like a soda machine. My old one had the buttons on the front, therefore you always needed two hands to dispense. Plus, those buttons weren't easy to clean. This has a nicer look from the front.So far my kids and I really like it. I love that there is room for additional stuff (we seem to have all kinds of products.) I also like that the back was flat for the command strips to hold. I will update if it falls or if I cannot get the other pump to work.

I looked these, but they are out of stock. I currently use two wooden school rulers which are the right thickness for me (1/4) but was looking for other thicknesses. I suppose it might be just as easy to use different rulers since these aren't available! Or I could look at the hardware store for different thicknesses of wood or even dowel rods (they come in lots of sizes. The silicone is nice though.

I am a long time Photoshop Elements user. But let me say right away that I am not a professional photographer or publisher. I am just a hobby-type user. I first used photoshop a few years ago when I was in charge of our local high school yearbook. So most of the layouts were really made by the publisher, and we could upload things (photos, graphics, text, etc.) I did need to sometimes take someone out of a group photo (like kids being in say the Honor Society photo that weren't in the Honor Society) or a hand signal (you know how kids are! ha ha!!)  I like to also make composite photos of my family or create cards (like last year our christmas cards were my family's photos put in a Brady Bunch squares type of setting...you can get the Brady Bunch font online for free, btw! It was pretty groovy.) But my computer died and I needed to get a new copy. So I figured now was the time to look at other products.Anyway, I have also always been a huge fan of Corel WordPerfect. It is such a superior word processing program over any I have ever used, so I figured I might like Corel's version of photo software. Maybe Corel and I just "fit" better than other companies. So far, I am right. It does seem to "fit" me better. I am not exactly sure how to explain it, but things are placed where I expect them to be...for me it is more intuitive than elements. I realize that my "intuitive" is different than other peoples, though.So far I have been just poking around with it (like I said I use this product as a hobby only) and have used the internet and the PaintShop Leanring Center to help me with the features. To be fair, I STILL have to depend on tutorials for elements when I want to do something new (like a gradient fade-type photo I made for a light scribe cd.)  So far I really like the adding text to photos feature much more than the elements version. I also like the one-step noise removal for improving my sometimes crappy photos.Overall, I like it very much. I like especially that it is cheaper than Elements. If you are really adept at Elements, you may not like the learning curve with a new program. I never got super skilled at elements, so as I was always learning that, I can always learn here. Plus it is nice to see the giant having a little competition sometimes!

I like to wear socks around the house in the winter. I am not a slipper person...mostly because they are too clunky and big. Can't they make slippers more like little shoes rather than big fluffy things? Still, that is just my preference.These fit well, and I like that they don't go all the way up to my ankle. They remind you of those little see-through footie things they sell to wear inside shoes, but these go up a little higher on the vamp part of your foot (you can see by the photo.)  They are thin. Which may be good if you don't want socks to stretch your shoes at all. But if you are looking for warmth or cushioning, they aren't the socks you want. My son has liners made by Vans that have this same low cut and they are thicker. They are called "socks" though. I am not sure if there is really an industry standard for those terms, though. I figured I would post this review so people would know. Not as thin as those peds/stocking liners, but not as thick as typical socks.

The design of this is awsesome! My kids love this character and couldn't wait to get this for their bathroom. It took longer than usual to get this (it isn't prime) maybe 2 weeks. It came with little plastic hooks, but I just used the rolling hooks I already was using for the liner. I did keep my liner with this. It is a nylon type fabric, and it says it is waterproof. But I have used other curtains like this, and while they kind of work, they absorb water in the weave, and if you are in there too long, it will drip and come through. It is just as simple for me to keep up the cheap liner with the same rings. That stays in the tub, and this one stays outside. No worries.I did have one problem with this (for which I deducted 3 stars): it isn't WIDE enough. There are only 10 holes in mine! I didn't order a smaller version or a "shower stall" one. I got 12 rings with it. But it is only 10 wide. The photo even shows 12 (I counted!) I guess I could have sent it back, but my kids like it so much that I just left the end two as liner-only. It does cover the whole opening of the shower, and the liner curves to protect from water, but still, it should have 12.

I wanted a rug for a small space that had nice design, but wasn't overly feminine or traditional. I saw this and thought it might work. When I got it, I was VERY impressed. Nice thick pile and the design is like a modern take on a traditional floral design. Very appropriate for men and women. It does come rolled of course, and the first few days it doesn't want to lay flat. I know you aren't supposed to roll them the opposite way, but I did roll the ends under for a day because I couldn't wait for gravity! ha ha!!It sheds a little at first. Many of my thicker wool rugs do. But but not like some rugs where there are tumbleweeds of wool. Everyone that sees it absolutely loves it and asks me where I got it. I tell them, "amazon, of course!" And people that know me don't even ask...they know I get so much here!

My son goes through backpacks at least once a year. Cheap ones to expensive ones (although the cheap ones do fail faster.) I don't know if it is him, or if it is just the nature of using something many times a day that they just break. We have the most trouble with zippers. Either they don't pull smoothly and you end up yanking them which misaligns the teeth. Or  they have that flap over them, which I suppose is for water protection, but ALWAYS end up getting caught in the zipper. I was very happy to see that this backpack didn't have that flap. I mean, for our use, he isn't outside long enough where water soaks through the zipper fabric. I like to use packpacks for traveling on short, weekend trips. I don't like carrying a big bag, and if you have to walk any distance to a bus or train, I don't like to lug along a big handheld bag.The bag is nicely shaped and feels nice while wearing it. The items' weight is nicely distributed. Sometimes these backpacks feel like simply square bags with straps sewn on, and they pull uncomfortably. And if you try to just use one shoulder, they constantly want to tip over. This one has also has that back section designed for a laptop. It is nice because you have to be flash your lacy girl things to everyone near you (unless you WANT to! ha ha!!) I don't always carry a laptop, but I do carry other small electronics (like a tablet, ipod, kindle, etc.) On the train, I like to have a drink, snacks for my kids, mints, a little makeup bag, etc.  It is very nice to have a whole separate section for things I want ON the trip and things I want once I get there.Overall, I really like the size and functionality of this bag. It isn't huge, so if you need a ton of space, please check dimensions. But it is indeed big enough for most uses.

I have loved Scharffen Berger chocolate for a while. It was acquired by Hershey and I worried that the chocolate might change. I like Hershey bars and kisses, don't get me wrong, but it isn't really complex type chocolate. Scharffen Berger is. But happily, the chocolate that I liked before has NOT changed...still delicious with lots of notes of flavor.I was very excited to see this jar. The jar itself was smaller than I expected...about the circumference of a paint can, but not as tall. Still, it held a PILE of these little squares. YAY!!!  If you have ever bought the little bags of tasting squares, you will realize that this is an awesome price for the amount of chocolate you get. If you haven't bought them, it will seem skimpy for the price...until you taste them and realize you aren't buying a jar of Hershey kisses, but something much better in quality.HOWEVER, as much as it was beautiful and how happy I was with the amount, mine was flawed. I removed the protective plastic from the jar, opened it (and of course ate a piece!) and tried to put the lid back on. It wouldn't fit. Hmmm...it is dang round...how hard can this be?! So I tried again, thinking the candy must have gotten in the way of the lip of the lid. No go. So I take out half the candy and try again. Still nada. Am I crazy? The glass is sort of cut and sanded on the edges, not like that smooth molded edge like a drinking glass. Almost like a wine bottle someone cut. So I look at it...it looks round, there is no lock like a teapot lid or anything. But I spin it and try...and it goes in. Therefore, it isn't round, but lopsided somewhere. Then I try to take it off...and it is stuck. I spin it trying to find that sweet spot where it actually fits...but cannot. So I pull and spin...and I chipped it. Just a little, but who wants to serve chocolate in a chipped glass jar that could cut someone? And where did that chip of glass go? In the candy? DANG it. It is wrapped but only in paper and foil...not sealed. I might chance it with myself and open each one carefully...but not for anyone else. I am very careful with my things and maybe have chipped a plate or glass once every 5 years. I guess with the cut nature of it, the edge was just too fragile.I can't figure why mine doesn't fit. It isn't like glass should warp like wood or plastic. Maybe the molds for the lids and jars aren't perfect. What a shame. I hope other people get one that works. Just be careful with that lid..if it doesn't fit right, don't try to make it fit. I posted of picture of what happens if you do.

This moisturizer is very nice. The texture is smooth--almost whipped, and slightly pearlescent. It goes one smoothly and absorbs seamlessly into my skin. This isn't like drug store creams. The scent is very light and floral...nothing obnoxious.  Does it remove wrinkles? Well, the jury is still out on that, I have only had it a few weeks. I can say that my skin ~feels~ very nice. Honestly, in this time I haven't noticed any real "lifting" or "erasing" properties. I did say it was pearlescent...which may diffuse the light in a way that makes your skin appear brighter and smoother. I am not saying it is glittery---I don't enjoy glitter or even frosty make-up (well I LIKE them, but they don't flatter my no-longer-20 skin!) I took a star away for this product sort of claiming it does more than any product really can (except maybe some prescription.)Is it a nice cream? Definitely. Is it better than cheap stuff? The texture, absorption, and fragrance are. And time will tell if it does improve my skin more than the cheaper stuff. I probably would buy this again because it does go into my skin so nicely, but the price might make me use it carefully and trying not to waste it (like putting it on knowing I am going to shower in a few hours or when I know I will perspire it off shortly doing something.) Some people spend a lot on face creams and things, but I can be kinda cheap. While I enjoy good products, I feel guilty about spending too much. One amazing cream would be worth it...and hoping over time that this might be it. I will update in a few months if I see any serious results.

I have a large yard, about a third-acre. The previous owner must have enjoyed buying plants, shrubs, and trees. Unfortunately, he didn't apparently enjoy cutting any of those. So when we moved in, it was almost like a jungle in places, you couldn't even see where one thing ended and another began. I started with hand pruners...which was a joke. Then I got those lopper things...better, but it would have taken 3 lifetimes. And I found out I can't swing an ax for crap. Then I used hedge trimmers, but couldn't get the big stuff. I did buy an electric handsaw, and it helped greatly, but it wasn't super fast. I knew I needed a chainsaw, but was afraid of them. I didn't grow up around tools. And men often wouldn't show me because I was a girl. :p I was scared to death to use a drill the first time...but figured it wasn't that much different than a sewing machine! ha ha!!  So I taught myself to use most power hand tools. I still get nervous with big things, mostly because they are heavy and I really am not that strong to handle any kickback or anything.I saw this and thought, "hey! this is for ME!" It is electric, which means I don't have to fool around with gas, mixing oil, starters and all that.  I don't know how to do that. And I knew I wasn't going out there to slay the giant oak or be Paul Bunyan or anything (ok he used an ax...)  This is a great size. It is not unwieldy so I can handle it. It isn't obviously the most powerful thing since it is small and electric, but it totally got the job done on cutting down shrubs and getting rid of big branches. I haven't cut down any trees with it, but have some about 9 inches in diameter that need to go this spring. I will update if this doesn't do well with those.

I like the idea of a table top torch. I also like that this one is on the smaller size that fits on your table. I do agree with the other reviewers that the insert does look a little plastic-y. I don't mind plastic stuff, (I even have pink flamingos!) but this one almost makes it look like it is a kid's toy.  When the LEDs, it looks pretty cool, though. I do see that there are other models now, and would have liked some sort of crackle glass or something, but this one is still fun! It doesn't come with fuel, so you will have to fill it.

My son sometimes has problem areas with acne, not super bad, but here and there (especially where his hair/bangs are on his forehead.) He has tried a few things. He does like that this goes on sort of smoothly and without a color or shiny finish. He said he really liked the way his skin felt using it, however...for blemishes, he said that it wasn't much different than much else he has used. I think the price is sort of high for a product like this, and maybe would recommend trying a similar, lower priced product (or two) first. For instance, my son likes the combination of two products I got here on amazon: Topix Benzoyl Peroxide Wash and regular Witch Hazel. His skin seems to clear up well and quickly with those, so he sticks with that. Plus the price is good!For us, the price is sort of prohibitive, so we mostly only be tempted to try this if other over-the-counter items weren't working. Others may feel the price is fair. It does make his skin feel nice, just not enough to justify the price difference. As an aside, if you haven't used this type of medicine (benzoyl peroxide), please know that it will bleach your bath towels. My son didn't know that and his favorite towel has white blotches. He uses bathroom papertowels now mostly to dry his face after using these types of products.

I wasn't really sure the size of this, would it be like a key chain or more like the size of a dinner plate. The original Bop It (which I have) is pretty big, but it is fun. When this came I surprised to see it was about the size of my hand. (I attached a photo just to help you judge the size.) It was so cute!!!The batteries were already installed so all I had to do is start playing. My kids and I played it before even taking off the cardboard!! ha ha!! It was attached with sort of a string which I cut off. I had to open the battery compartment with a screwdriver t remove the strings the whole way...a little bit of a pain, but not like those evil plastic clamshell packages!It has "solo" and "pass it" functions with spoken commands (e.g., "bop it" twist it" or "pull it") there is no game where there are just sounds like in the Bop It Extreme (which we also have.) It keeps track of the high score which it announces when you start a new game. It also gives you a little reward sound when you get to 100. (I quit after that, not sure if there is another milestone to reach!!) You do need two hands to play....at least I haven't found a way to pull or twist with one hand. But it is nice and small. We have ours on our coffee table/ottoman and people are always picking it up for a quick little game. I really like it!!!!

I realize this is marketed to younger kids, but my teenage daughter loves these type of items. She has painted on glassware and ceramics, but has always wanted a plate. She thought that this kit had an actual plate in it, but it is just paper that you send to become a plate. It's fine that way, just takes a little more patience to wait for your item!!I think lots of teens and even adults would have fun with this. She loves to draw cartoons and put her original little dudes all over the plate. She doesn't want to eat off of it, though, it is now an art item in her room! I may get her additional ones to give as gifts to her friends who always like her artwork.

Maybe it's me, but I seem to like different types of fragrances based on the season. I like fruity, floral-y things for spring and summer, and more spicy/musky things when it gets colder. Sort of like how I pick food! (ok, not musky food! ha ha!!)This has some fruity top notes, like pomegranate and persimmon, so you think it might be a sweet light fruity scent, but as time goes on, the low notes start to blossom...they are more vanilla, musk and patchouli. I was sorta hoping that the fruit plus musk/vanilla might hint at the original Dior Poison (which I loved), but it isn't like that...but in the same sort of family, if that makes any sense.  So it is more of a deep luscious scent, not a light flirty one.I do like it very much, but I think I will save it for autumn and winter. My body seems to react better to these type of scents when its cool. Some people can wear these scents in any season and they seem right. If you do buy it and maybe aren't sure if you like it, try it in a different season and see if it changes.

I leave my table and chairs out all winter. Mostly because it is heavy and I don't really have anywhere to store it indoors. And it snows where I live...I mean piles of snow. I had a different cover that was cheaper, and it was almost like tyvek or something. After one winter, it just wore so thin where it rubbed on the chair backs, it tore. So my cheap item wasn't so cheap anymore since it didn't last.This is one of the higher end items from Classic Accessories. The fabric is noticeably heavier than my old one, which gives me hope that it can withstand a tough winter. I do like the handles very much, especially when you are putting it on by yourself.

I have the MX model (i used to have an older one, but it sort of died after about 5 years.) I used my MX one for about 3 years just using batteries. I finally got this adapter, and the same week I plugged it in, the lid/motor quit. I don't know why for sure, but t worries me that I may have done something to it by switching from the batteries to the adapter. The sensor seems to know to open as the light changes color, but there is no noise, no motor, no nothing.I did just go to the itouchless website and you CAN buy a replacement lid (for about 40 bucks plus 10 bucks shipping) which I did. I am planning on going straight to the adapter with it to see if it messes up the new lid. Hopefully it doesn't happen and it was just a coincidence. If  it DOES ruin the new lid, I will come back and note that in this review. I will also note if itouchless either replaces that new lid and adapter.

My  daughter fell in love with the little Japanese cat, Maneki Neko when we saw one waving at us at a store. When I saw this squishable, I knew she would have to have it! She is a little older, but loves these pillows. She sleeps with one or two and (when she makes her bed!) decorates the bed with them. The little paws on this one are like little flaps, but not the whole arm which probably would be odd looking on this anyway. She gives this little guy a squeeze every time she sees it!

My daughter has a Moto X phone with a wood back and is always looking for earphones that aren't ugly. I didn't even know they made wood ones until I saw these! They look like they were made to go with it perfectly! They sound good too! The wires are nice and not chintzy, with a slightly thicker insulation than many earphones in this price range have. She did experience a slight echo and I was worried that it was because of the phones, but a simple change of the rubber tip fixed that (then include three different sizes.) My son sometimes takes these and wants a pair of his own, now!

The person who had my house before me thought it would be cute to have a paver-brick patio WITH things growing between the cracks. There were morning glories (which are pretty invasive), moss, grass, weeds, etc. in between every single brick. What a mess. Plus all that growth between the bricks prevents them from drying properly after a rain and can even push them out of position.  It looked sort of country rustic I guess, but it wasn't nice to walk on. I was worried that I would never be able to have a regular patio, but took  a chance on round up. YAY!! It worked wonderfully! I sprayed it between all the cracks and now we have a normal place to walk and sit.  I do have a small border of annuals that I plant around the patio and this hasn't effected that at all...only where I spray it. I usually buy two gallons of this to kill stuff between the expansion joints on my concrete driveway and sidewalks. I also use it to kill weeds and anything that likes to grow in my fieldstone border fence. I try to do it before anything gets too established each spring and sometimes I have to do a few spots again in august.  I have tried it on english ivy (which was covering a few of my trees and a small part of my garage (another bright idea by the previous owner.) That stuff is evil! This helped, but it needed to be pulled by hand. I did read once that for waxy things like ivy, to spray it first with a detergent like a Dawn mixture (to break the wax) and then the poison. We managed to get rid of almost all of it (some of the vines were as big as my wrist!)  but every year a few hangers-on want to come back.I also have sprayed it on a few mystery vines and weeds that are trying to take over my shrubbery. I try to get the vines down to a little stump, and then just spray it carefully on that. It works sometimes this way, but other times I think I would need more spray (which I fear doing around my small shrubs) so I just dig.This stuff has really saved me from hours (more like weeks!) of work to try to keep the weeds/grass out of places where they don't belong to avoid damage to my hard surfaces.  I am careful not to spray it on a really hot, sunny day as it seems to dry too quickly without getting a chance to "seep." But I don't want to do it right before a rain so it washes where I don't need it.

I have a favorite, tweaked chocolate chip cookie recipe that I have been using for years. I like them chewy in the centers, but still a little crisp on the edges. Not cakey, not flat. I have been using Nestle semi-sweet chips for years and they are adequate. I really like the flavor of Scharffen Berger bars, so I knew these would be good. Actually, I like the "rich milk" type the best...and I am a dark-chocolate lover! I didn't want to use that though in cookies because I feared the 41% cacao might melt too much; these chunks are 62%.Regular baking chips have less cocoa butter in them to withstand oven heat and still retain their shape. They aren't good for melting though for other uses. These do melt, so I wasn't sure how my cookies would fare. I ended up deciding to use half of these and half nestle (one for melty flavor and one for shape.) My cookies did taste AMAZING, however, they spread too much.The cookies had a nice smear of chocolate from these, and still some visible chips from the Nestles. They didn't spread so much that they were one giant cookie, but enough that they were quite fragile removing from the pan and kind of thin to hold. I imagine it was from the additional cocoa butter melting and thinning out the dough slightly (I am no chemist, just a guess.) I don't know if I would have used ALL this type (instead of half and half) what would have happened. I will have to re-experiment to maybe lessen the amount of fat (butter/shortening/egg) in my recipe or raise the amount of dry ingredients (or even a long chill in the fridge first) to regain my desired texture.I haven't done so yet, but I imagine these would be great for recipes using melted chocolate (like cake or brownies) rather than that weird "baking chocolate" stuff. I just wanted to post that if you are using these for chocolate chip cookies you have made with other chips, be prepared for possible changes in your finished product. I will update my review after I figure out what percentage of "typical" recipes need to change (if I DO figure it out that is!)

I have worn mine many times and my stone is fine..not loose, didn't fall out. I do usually look at prongs on things when I put them on, mostly so I don't snag anything. If they seem a little not-tight, I press them down with the tip of an old pair of flat tweezers. I never had to do that with this though. My stone is nice an shiny. I also got the white one on a lightning deal...love them both!

I wait for these thermal ones every year! I looked for them in the fall and couldn't find the ones with the thermal bottoms, but found them during a lightning deal (twice.) They are so comfy and cozy! I like them because they aren't too too pajama-ish and look ok for hanging around the house. Especially nice that they come in colors other than pastels (why is nightwear so often pastel?)  It would be even nicer if the the bottoms didn't have the design too..then they would just like like casual pants. But, the designs are cute enough. They are sort of on the loose side (like the image shows) so if you like them tighter, you can size down. I like them sorta big though. My daughter and I both get a set of these from Santa :)

Very fun sweater for thanksgiving. My son likes to wear funny things and this is perfect. The turkeys look a lot like a handprint (as you can see from the photo.) Everyone just loves it when he wears it...even his high school friends think it is funny/cool. Nice and soft and fits true to size. I will probably not dry it completely in the dryer...just a dry until damp and then lay flat. The instructions don't say that, but sweaters seem to fare better that way. And wash/dry inside out to help resist any pills. My daughter got the shark with christmas lights one...also super fun.

I bought one of these for my mom, and after it arrived I was so impressed that I had to have one, too!! (I am actually back again to buy another one for a gift.)It is very shiny and the stones are set nicely in the pendant. The "bale" (the part where the chain goes through) on the item is not an additional tab like projection as you can see in the photo. It is actually two holes in the setting where the chain is woven in then out. You have to look a little to see where the spaces are wider to know which is the actual area for the chain and which is just the setting. Once you do it a few times, you will know. I have noticed that certain chains bend more easily than others, so you may have to experiment with chains you have to find one you like best. The included one is nice, but I have an adjustable one I like better (so I can change the length.) A thicker chain, thicker cord, or something with bigger links won't weave well through the setting.I just think it is quite unique and pretty. It looks awesome in the winter with a black turtleneck where it is the center of attention!

I host all the family gatherings at my house every year. I really enjoy it, but sometimes washing all those dishes can get to me. I wanted something nice and pretty that could handle the dishwasher (good china cannot.) I looked and looked at corelle (which I love for everyday) but it never seemed formal enough for holiday dinners. Then I saw this!!! I was really impressed with corelle offering more styles that weren't so casual. These could certainly be used casually, but do have a more formal look.I saw it online and wondered what it would be like. So once at a department store, I found a plate and really liked it. The embossing is really there! It isn't just paint or swirls embedded in the glass...but actual texture you can feel. And the plain white design lends itself just as well with the oranges and browns of thanksgiving linens as it does with pastels for easter. And most chefs agree that serving food on white increases the appeal (and doesn't distract from the food itself.)So I bought them. (I bought just the plates...don't need cups or bowls right now.) But I got 16, so I invested in them! ha ha! (hint: if you sign up for corelle emails, you often will get sale notifications for their site...I waited for that.) I am so excited to use these for thanksgiving. They are characteristically light like corelle always is, but still strong. And they aren't thick, so a stack of 16 only takes up 3.25 inches of height in my already crowded cupboards. Ever try stacking 16 pieces of stoneware!? It is very heavy and is a foot tall at least!!! Plus I have cracked porcelain plates by stacking too high to store them...they crack under their own weight.Additionally, I don't have to worry about scratched paint on dishes, chipped porcelain (which you shouldn't use since germs can get in where there is no glaze and you can't get it out), scratched platinum rims, kids banging utensils on them, using liners between each to store...or any of the other things you worry about with china or stoneware. And the BEST? The dishwasher, baby!! oh yeah! I don't care if I have to run it twice for everything to fit...it is still easier than handwashing all that china. (Tip: if you happen to get those gray lines on your corelle from flatware, Barkeepers Friend cleanser or a light rub with a Mr. Clean magic eraser will talk them off.)The only thing negative (maybe) that I noticed was that since the pattern occupies the rim of each plate, the area for food seems smaller than some other dishes. There is no reason why your food can't sit on the embossed area...it just LOOKS like it is a smaller area. Maybe this isn't such a bad thing...I usually eat too many mashed potatoes anyway! ha ha!! (doubt this will stop me ...maybe someone else might take less, though!)

My mom told me once that I shouldn't get rid of lids to pans if they are in good shape (even if you pitch the pan) because you never know when you might need one for an odd pan.I have an older T-fal skillet that came with no lid. Of course ~I~ buy one that doesn't have a matching lid. I thought one I had might fit...nope. And then I figured, "no big deal" I will just buy one of those universal ones!" But unfortunately, those are mostly 12 inches (not 12.5) or huge for paella. I found one that JUST fit...I mean just...but it was flat (I prefer at least a little dome) and the lip balanced precariously on the edge of my pan. And it is really low quality.This one has a larger lip and is slightly larger, so it sits on my pan. I would love one that had a ridge where it fit inside (like most lids do) but it would have to be made specifically for this pan. It isn't as heavy duty as some other lids I have, but I thought it was much nicer than some of the bigger "universal" ones I have seen (including one I own.) I didn't think it was too thin or bendable. And I really like that it has a vent.

I have a few of these small speakers. I like to listen to music outside in the summer and want an item that is loud enough so I can hear while doing yardwork. So many of them are either too small to project enough sound, or are too big to haul in and out every day. This one is about the size of sausage sandwich (ha ha!) and fits in my hand very well! I have had no trouble tethering it to my bluetooth on my phone or just using the wired jack (on my old pod.) The sound is nice and loud so I can hear it from far away.Now, it of course isn't a giant speaker where you would hold a concert or block party or something, but for its size it is quite nice. I like that it is water resistant because rain can pop up quickly in the summers and I don't always get my stuff away before it gets wet. It doesn't say waterPROOF, so I don't purposely try to get it wet, but it is nice that a some water won't ruin it. We have also used it with our projector when we watch outside "drive-in" movies in our yard. Loud enough for everyone to hear, but not obnoxious to the neighbors or a annoying to carry.I agree with some other reviewers that the initial voice prompt is obviously done by an english-as-a-second-language speaker. It is only a few seconds though and I have come to anticipate that female voice saying "ready for connection!" in that slightly accented voice. I WAIT for her now!!! :D I also like that it charges with a common mini usb plug...I have a few of these around from other items so it isn't some proprietary charging cord that is impossible to replace. I think it is a great little item and am very happy with it.

I got a Foreman grill years ago (like 15 years ago!!) and l like it very much. I have gotten used to it's shortcomings (no removable plates, a hinge like a book, etc.) so I was very happy to use an improved one!! I used to just heat it up and sort of "cook" hot water to clean mine...now I can really wash the plates without using 5 papertowels!! I love that feature. I also love that the hinge accommodates thicker foods. My old one would close tight closer to the hinge side, but the far edge didn't really press down. This hinge seems to fit the thickness of the food well so the cooking is more even.It really has only one heat setting...on. I sort of expected an "improvement" where you could change the setting...but realized that I just sort of use one setting. It is like a waffle iron or many other itchen appliances (or even my furnace!) where it cycles on or off with an internal thermostat. So even when many seem like they have different settings, they just turn on and off more frequently. I suppose if you wanted to just keep something warm in this, it wouldn't work well, but I don't do that. You could just leave it open or unplug it or something if you wanted to experiment. I just "cook" with mine and the non-temperature setting sort of makes it simple so I don't have to think about if something cooks at 400 or 425 (which I really don't do anyway...even on a stove.)My kids also like it because they can cook things like burgers or chicken breasts and not have to worry about heat settings or skillets or flipping or anything. They already told me they are taking this to college with them in a few years. I might have to give them my old one and hide this one!

My son is at an age (high school) where he doesn't want to wear jeans all the time, but "dressy" items just don't really cut it at school. So...he likes chinos and khakis in different colors. I think he looks nice in them, especially with a buttoned shirt or sweater. These are very nice pants. The fabric is nice...heavy enough to hold their shape, but not stiff. And the cut is modern enough for even younger men. The Dickies brand has always held up well for us, and these (so far) have been no exception. The fit is true to size, even with my son's more muscular legs. He wants more colors now!

The subject of Lisa Grunwald and Stephen Adler's book is marriage, which may be why it fills 560 pages and weighs 3.7 pounds. "You won't able to put down," someone said. That was one buffed reader. Me, I could barely pick it up.Lisa Grunwald was a close friend in my lost youth. In recent decades, as happens in my city, she morphed into a friend of friends, married with children. Our paths didn't cross again until a school smart enough to put Lisa on its board was dumb enough to reject my child --- in truth, given how my city works, to reject me. Fortunately, I could tell the difference between Lisa and an Admissions Director; Lisa remained on a pedestal.She's on a higher one now. Until I looked into "The Marriage Book: Centuries of Advice, Inspiration, and Cautionary Tales from Adam and Eve to Zoloft," I didn't know that Lisa has had colon surgery and a double mastectomy, topped off with Multiple Sclerosis. And yet here she is, with the third book she's co-authored with her husband of 27 years, the president and editor-in-chief of Reuters.Who you gonna trust?On this topic: these two.The book spans millennia. Smartly, it's arranged in alphabetical order, by topic (Adam and Eve, Bed, Coveting, Devotion, Expectations, Fidelity, etc).  Everyone you can think of is quoted, plus hundreds unknown to you. A definitive survey? I can't think of writers with more energy and dedication. A gift for about-to-be-marrieds?  Duh.Some samples:"I swear if you existed I'd divorce you"- Edward Albee, "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?""I send this token, but how little can it express my gratitude to you for making my life & any work I have done possible, and for giving me so much happiness in a world of accident & storm."- Winston Churchill"To keep your marriage brimming, With love in the loving cup, Whenever you're wrong, admit it; Whenever you're right, shut up."- Ogden Nash"Love seems the swiftest, but is the slowest of all growths. No man or woman really knows what perfect love is until they have been married a quarter of a century."- Mark Twain, who had then been married for 25 years"My mother once told me that if a married couple puts a penny in a pot for every time they make love in the first year, and takes a penny out every time after that, they'll never get all the pennies out of the pot."- Armistead Maupin"Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's wife, for there are plenty of others."- Otto Rank"When you were sick, you worried because you could not give me something that you wanted to and thought I needed. You needn't have worried. Just as I told you then there was no real need because I loved you in so many ways so much. And now it is clearly even more true -- you can give me nothing now yet I love you so that you stand in my way of loving anyone else -- but I want you to stand there. You, dead, are so much better than anyone else alive."- from the letter Richard Feynman wrote to his wife a year after she died."Marriage is so tough, Nelson Mandela got a divorce! Nelson Mandela spent 27 years in a South African prison -- got beaten and tortured every day for 27 years and did it with no problem. Made to do hard labor in hundred degree South African heat for 27 years and did it with no problem. He got out of jail after 27 years of torture, spent six months with his wife and said, 'I can't take this no more!"- Chris RockA patient says: "Doctor, last night I made a Freudian slip, I was having dinner with my mother-in-law and wanted to say: 'Could you please pass the butter.' But instead I said: 'You silly cow, you have completely ruined my life."- old joke"I think a man can have two, maybe three affairs, while he is married. But three is the absolute maximum. After that, you're cheating."- Yves MontandJohn Kennedy and Jacqueline Bouvier? A photo taken on their wedding day.  Because to say more might be to lie.

There is no dream thats more of a clich than a young womans dream of living in Paris.Wild parties, suave lovers, memorable encounters with giant intellects? Shes blond and beautiful, but that clich doesnt fit Kate Betts, 22 years old, arriving in Paris in 1986. Shes fourth generation Princeton. Shed written her college thesis on the Paris riots of l968 and the impact of student-worker action on French political consciousness. And shes haunted by her parents divorce when she was six.Her first smart move was getting herself to Paris, where she scrambled for entry-level jobs, missed her college boyfriend, met a sweet young Frenchman and was adopted by his charming family. And then she was hired as a features writer for M magazine and W, the biweekly society paper, both owned by John Fairchild, the publisher of Womens Wear Daily.John Fairchild was an odd kind of genius. He loved fashion, but he loved power more, and he loved the arbitrary exercise of power most of all. The kind word for him was mercurial. I knew him socially and saw something else: a Wizard of Oz who played the bully to keep people off-balance.Kate Betts had a modest sense of personal style and even less knowledge of fashion when she started in Fairchilds Paris office. But Fairchild had also gone to Princeton, and his ferocious attachment to that snobbish credit saved her from his random cruelty. Her ambition, which was considerable, was the more important ingredient in her ascent, and that ambition is the reason My Paris Dream is essential reading for any young woman who wants to become Someone.Fairchild was obsessed with observation, preferably at the distance of inches. Details were huge for him. And atmosphere was everything. When Betts was assigned to a story in Provence, this was his advice: Run through the lavender fields!The most fertile field at Fairchild, she quickly learned, was fashion, and she pushed her way into reporting on it. She stood with Fairchild at Saint Laurents studio, like walking in on someone in their bedroom during an intimate moment. Helmut Lang sketched for her. She collected another, of a Christian Lacroix lace wedding dress. She partied with then unknown Christian Louboutin. And she watched makeup artists transform models.And here we come to the section of My Paris Dream that takes fashion dish and makes it something more, something grander  the section that chronicles the writers own transformation. This is Betts, at 26, in Paris:"I took advantage of my pet status at Fairchild. I disregarded many of my colleagues or pushed them aside, reaching for the best stories, the most bylines, the favored position. A few times I caught them whispering about my cocky, bossy attitude. But I was too young to care, blinded by ambition. I was impatient with people who couldnt speak French as well as I did or couldnt secure an interview with a designer. I bought into Mr. Fairchilds games and favoritism. Deep down I harbored thoughts that perhaps fashion wasnt a serious occupation, that it was something too frivolous to build a meaningful career on. And when these thoughts overwhelmed me, when I daydreamed about becoming a foreign correspondent, I would snap out of it quickly, reminded that fashion was now my ticket to the top."She broke up with her French boyfriend. Had she made a mistake? Vas retrouver ta famille, his mother told her. Go find your family.Anna Wintour spirited her back to New York. At a Vogue party, she met Chip Brown, a writer with no tendency toward ephemera. At the wedding, he read a poem hed written: Nothing is real that is not first imagined. She was well on her way to becoming the Kate Betts I sort of know: a force field.My Paris Dream is about imagining yourself and making it real.

Fashion Lives is big as a MacBook and heavy as a small barbell, but if you like to read about fashion, youll find it as light as an airport page-turner. Dish? Honey, the dish does not quit. Emotion? Hey, this is fashion, not physics. Intelligence, compassion, ideas? Yes, in quantity, and not so much because the 19 designers, photographers and editors interviewed here are so verbal but because the interviewer is so haimish and well prepared that her guests nearly forget theyre onstage at the 92nd Street YHMA.All praise, therefore, to Fern Mallis, who invented this series and got almost everyone she asked to participate. But schmoozing the talent is the least of it. Doing your homework and getting guests who are usually guarded by a wall of publicists to say more than they may have intended  thats the trick.There are no impertinent questions, only impertinent answers, Oscar Wilde said. Few interviewers today agree; they trade relevance for access. Fern Mallis uses her access to get great anecdotes, and then she slips in a few pointed questions. She gets answers because everyone knows her story  shes been fashions champion for decades. In brief: Mallis was the Executive Director of the Council of Fashion Designers of America from 1991 to 2001. She created Fashion Week, which generated a fortune for the city, before moving on to IMG Fashion and her own fashion and design consultancy. Why no reality TV show? Producers found her too nice. But in this format, a friend talking to a friend yields gems.Among the many anecdotes I marked: Norma Kamali, in the early 60s, worked for an airline and got to fly to London for $29 round trip, and what she saw in London gave her the courage to lease a shop on East 53rd Street  for $285 a month. Mallis asks Calvin: What do Customs agents say when you get back from a trip and they look at the passport and it says Calvin Klein? And Klein replies, with some amusement, Well, I generally dont go through Customs  they get on the plane. Tom Ford, as a kid in Texas, carried a briefcase and wore suits. Michael Kors, on his marriage to Lance LePere: Were probably the only people who got married on the beach, jumped in the jeep, went to Easthampton, had pizza at Sams and saw The Help. Polly Mellen flees a chance for sex with William Holden. Oscar de la Renta gives John Galliano a second chance. Bruce Webers dogs get acupuncture. Bill Cunningham explains why the best time to photograph on the street is 8:30 in the morning.For Fern Mallis, charm begins and ends with a small public ego  so small it would be easy to focus on the bold-face names and ignore the woman who gave them a platform on which to dance. Better, I thought, to shine a spotlight on their enabler. Ms. Mallis, I have ten questions for you.JK: I remember being backstage with Isaac Mizrahi after his blowout show in 1989. His mother was there, beaming. Marc Jacobs joined them. My mother never comes to my shows, he said. And I thought that there, right there, was a major difference in everything these two men did. And you, I see, start every interview with questions about childhood. Why are the early years so important for you?FM: I think we are who we are because of our parents and families, and our early upbringing and environments play a key role. For creative people and designers Im curious what they were surrounded by, and what visual imagery they remember, what helped form their taste levels.JK: You ask every guest about his/her astrological sign. Lets deal with yours. You were born on March 26, 1948, on the cusp of Pisces and Aries. Significance?FM: Aries, with Gemini rising. Im headstrong, a leader, and I start lots of things but dont always finish them.JK: For the designers you interview, Studio 54 comes up again and again. What was its influence on fashion?FM: Studio 54 was the first time any of us had seen gala black tie dressing mix with poufs and roller-skates, jeans and every form of costume available  as well as the barely dressed. Thankfully it happened before social media and everyone in the world partied with a camera in hand.JK: Ive marked revelation after revelation, from Jacqueline Kennedy having the Dallas dress dyed black for the Presidents funeral to Yves Saint Laurents drop-dead letter to Tom Ford (In 13 months, you have destroyed what it took me 40 years to create). What was the biggest surprise for you?FM: Those two are at the top of my list. Add Andr Leon Talley sharing that Karl Lagerfeld gave him $50,000 for his 50th birthday; learning that Marc Jacobs dad, an agent at William Morris, once represented Joan Rivers; that Betsey Johnson was a Phi Beta Kappa at Syracuse University; and that Vera Wang grew up in Peter Cooper Village.JK: In the late 80s, I wrote the CFDA awards shows. They were held in the Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum, which seats just 700. The night felt like a family reunion. I know nostalgia is pointless  but are you nostalgic for that pre-corporate era?FM: A little. It was nice when sponsors names werent plastered all over everything, but just supported events and causes because it was the right thing to do.JK: Along the same lines, I kept thinking as I read: If these designers didnt have licenses and perfumes and do second labels for discount stores, theyd all be out of business. Is the pure fashion designer a thing of the past?FM: Close to it. And since so many of them have become public companies, they have to keep making bigger and bigger profits to satisfy shareholders. The high-end collections of most designers are the least profitable. Fragrances and licenses are where they do the biggest business, at price points that make it affordable and accessible.JK: Isaac Mizrahi mourns the death of Loehmanns (That is like global warming.) But theres a new Loehmanns  Gilt. Im fascinated that none of your guests seems to have much interest in the Internet. (The exception is Bill Cunningham: Look at the lines waiting to get into the Apple store on Fifth Avenue and 59th Street. Do you see a line waiting to get into Bergdorf or Saks?) Is this generational?FM: Yes. Most of these designers text; social media and Internet presence are for their staff. Bill Cunningham rightly identified the importance of this age of technology  but he doesnt have a computer or a cell phone and is impossible to reach.JK: The most emotional interview for you?FM: Probably Bill Cunningham, as hes the most private. He was quite moved while discussing his family and early upbringing. His was an epic interview, and I could feel his pain at moments. I touched his hand to let him pause several times. And Norma Kamali  weve known each other and have been friends for so long. We shared friends who have passed away from AIDS, and that meant a great deal to me.JK: The most emotional interview for the designer/guest?FM: There were many. Vera Wang talked about having to do her fashion show at the tents the morning after she raced to be with her father who passed away the night before; she cried the entire walk around the runway when she took her bow. Calvin and Marc were very honest about their addictions. When Diane von Furstenberg shared the story of her mothers experience in the concentration camps, you could hear a pin drop.JK: As we used to say in sexy Internet chat rooms: What are you wearing?FM: Donna Karan Urban Zen cashmere sweater and jersey jodhpur pants.

The Tibetans are said to believe that if you have a dark thought about someone and the thought does not directly strike that person it will travel around the world and hit you in the back of the head. On this theory, I have spent almost a decade not thinking dark thoughts about Judith Miller, the former New York Times reporter whose reporting about Saddam Husseins weapons of mass destruction was so useful in the Bush Administrations campaign to sell an Iraq invasion.But in the last few days, Miller has published a piece in the Wall Street Journal, The Iraq War and Stubborn Myths,"  and The New York Times has reviewed her just-published book, 'The Story: A Reporters Journey, and I find myself thinking again about the 4,400 American dead, the hundreds of thousands of dead Iraqis, the untold wounded and maimed, the waste of $4 trillion, the connection between the shattering of Iraq and the rise of ISIS, and, not least, the fact that no one involved in the greatest American disaster since Vietnam has been held remotely accountable. So when I read Judith Miller saying, yet again, that a journalist is only as good as her sources, I found my blood pressure redlining.And when I read, in the pathologically cautious Times review by a non-Times employee, that the agenda that comes through most strongly [in the book] is a desire to land on the front page, I find myself transported to an earlier time, when citizens like me ate rage for breakfast. And then I recall an interaction I had with Ms. Miller in 2005 and the question that forced me to write about her.For those who have had the good fortune to know nothing about Ms. Miller and her role as an enabler of the Bush Administrations marketing of the Iraq invasion, heres the briefest of primers.Miller was a dogged reporter whose special knack was cultivating powerful men as sources. Its tricky to write a sentence like that --- you cant help sounding like the pundits who call Hillary Clinton aggressive. But that was, in fact, how Miller operated; Nina Totenberg recalls Jordans King Hussein spotting Miller at a party and shouting Juuuudy! and Miller, in response, shouting Kiiiiiing!Miller was one of the first journalists to be interested in bioterrorism. With her colleagues, she won a Pulitzer and authored a prescient book.  But when Bush became President, her sources narrowed: Richard Perle, Paul Wolfowitz, Douglas Feith, Scooter Libby. If she didnt have an agenda, they did. They have it still, and if anyone took them seriously, we would have already leveled Tehran.In the run-up to the invasion of Iraq, government officials made remarkable claims. Dick Cheney insisted that 9/11 hijacker Mohammed Atta had met an Iraqi intelligence officer in Prague a few months before Atta flew a plane into the World Trade Center. (That meeting didnt happen.) Condoleezza Rice also saw ties between Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. (Despite all evidence to the contrary, Rice was still saying this in 2006.) But the biggest whopper was Millers claim about Iraqs intentions to develop weapons of mass destruction.As an embedded reporter in Iraq, Miller saw buried ingredients for chemical weapons production. Well, she didnt exactly see them. Clad in nondescript clothes and a baseball cap, she wrote in the Times, a former low-level Iraqi scientist known as Curveball pointed to several spots in the sand where he said chemical precursors and other weapons material were buried.A few hours after that piece was published, Dick Cheney went on Meet the Press and quoted Miller. Others followed. Bob Simon, of 60 Minutes, was quick to see through the kabuki. "You leak a story to the New York Times," he told Franklin Foer of New York Magazine, "and the New York Times prints it, and then you go on the Sunday shows quoting the New York Times and corroborating your own information. You've got to hand it to them. That takes, as we say here in New York, chutzpah."It took two years for Miller to admit her reporting couldnt be confirmed: WMDI got it totally wrong. But it wasnt her fault; she was deceived by her sources. Well, not even deceived. They meant well. They just got it wrong. Its a defense we hear often. Indeed, its the single best argument against the passive voice: Mistakes were made.By 2005, there were many factual takedowns of Millers reporting. Correctly, they focused on her false assumptions and inadequate reporting. I read none that linked her blunders to her character.Then, about a week before Harriet Miers pulled the plug on her disastrous Supreme Court nomination, Judith Miller went to a dinner party.There, I was told, she had a question: Why is everyone being so mean to Harriet Miers?"It was a memorable question. Miers was White House Council for George W. Bush. She had not one credential that suggested she belonged on the Supreme Court. Her nomination was widely viewed as an expression of Bush's contempt for the Court.  Even Republicans declined to support her. And here was Judith Miller, as if shed been on Mars for months, wondering why Washington was mean to Miers.When I learned about Millers astonishing remark, I decided to write about her. And I wrote her to ask for confirmation.Her response was brilliant weaselspeak."You're probably going to hear a lot of things that I supposedly said that I don't remember saying," she told me, via email. "Like this. Don't think I ever voiced an opinion on her, or asked the question you raise about Harriet Miers."I didnt respond, but my source was Don Hewitt, creator and producer of 60 Minutes. I knew Hewitt --- he told me the Miller story while I was reporting a piece about him; a few years earlier, 60 Minutes had bought some research from me. He could be crusty. But he was reliable  he had the greatest track record in broadcast journalism.So if Hewitt said Miller asked that question, Im siding with Hewitt. As for Millers slippery non-denial, it speaks to character --- shes not a good reporter and shes not a good source. Now embedded at Fox News, shes finally found her true home.

How often do I read thrillers?Rarely.How often do I stay up until 3 AM, manically turning pages so I can see how a thriller ends?Never.And yet reading until my eyes blurred was exactly what happened the night I read Night Life, by David C. Taylor.As the book opens, a New York cop, Michael Cassidy, has a confrontation on a sidewalk with Roy Cohn, legal assistant to the fearsome Senator, Joe McCarthy. He has no reason to know Cohn. So he is less than respectful. This doesnt fly.Im Roy Cohn.Happy New Year, Mr. Cohen.Not Cohen. Tight with anger. Cohn. Roy Cohn.Well, my congratulations to Mr. and Mrs. CohenWhats your name?Cassidy. Detective Michael Cassidy.Youre going to hear from me, Cohn said,Always a pleasure to hear from a citizen, Mr. Cohen.Right there, on page 23, you know that much is going to go wrong for Cassidy. .Whats in Night Life for you? Great fake tough guy dialogue: You want to go get loaded? I always work better with a hangover. Add an acute sense of a vanished New York, the New York of jazz clubs and men in hats. And vivid characters: Michaels unlikely lover, some dodgy FBI agents and some CIA agents who, of course, are not supposed to be doing any domestic investigations. Violence? Yes, none of it textbook.The secret of a great thriller, Im coming to realize, is a credible plot and set pieces that dont read like set pieces  yes, well accept less, but we thrill to stories and characters that feel new. Well, Night Life is 332 pages of new.

The best book Ive read this year begins like this: Whenever I wake up next to a man, before Im fully awake, I think its Ted. Of course it never is.Lillian, the narrator of Lillian on Life, goes on to identify some of the major elements of her romantic life: a man, red wine, K-Y Jelly (because shes now of an age when lubrication is necessary before sex), and waking up early and using the bathroom to get that all out of the way before they get up.Sex is not the subject of Alison Jean Lesters terrific first novel; its a matter-of-fact presence in a life rich in romantic experience and practical knowledge. And that, for me, was the first surprise of this book. For all its literary ambitions, its not bloated with the kind of pretense that makes me run for the exits. In this novel-that-reads-like-a-memoir, Lillian is credible, likeable, even lovable. In a word: real.If I had to summarize, Id say that these 238 pages tell the story of a woman whos 60+, alone, with a healthy interest in sex and not much interest in figuring out what went wrong. Thats the novels second surprise: Lillian has no agenda, her book is not a screed. Born in the late 1930s, she grew up when a womans story was, to a great extent, the story of the man she married. But no one married Lillian; her story is not, in the conventional way, his story.Looking for an overarching thesis about the lot of women? Look elsewhere. For Lillian, the story of her life doesnt lead to any grand conclusion: So many people say that everything happens for a reason. Ive always felt that things happen because the things before them happen, thats all.Lets stop here and consider our lives. Do you see a cosmic plan unfolding for you? Do you assess your life through the prism of your hard work and focus and will? How much of who you are is just dumb luck? Bottom line: How you explain that you are reading this in a room with heat and a computer that springs to life as soon as your fingers touch the keyboard and a dinner table set for two or more?This comparison of your life to Lillians is an essential part of your reading of her book, especially if youre a woman and you have a decent sex drive and the question of a man has not been permanently answered for you. But you probably wont make that comparison right away, because, in the beginning, Lillian fills your head and heart, and you want so much for her to have a great life.Lillians story, in brief: In 1956, while she was at Vassar, she was offered a job as a typist in Munich. For 6 weeks. She arrived with one suit. Met a man. One thing led to another and she became secretary in the Paris bureau of a newspaper, and met Willis, and moved to London and then New York, and met Ted.The culture shock of Europe knocked the ability to judge other peoples behavior right out of me. Nobody came from where I came from or felt what I felt, so I adapted. Gay men loved how unconventionally I lived, I think. But I wanted to get married and have children. That had been the plan. Lovers and wine, cigarettes and skinny black clothes  those were the detritus on the rings circling the planet of my dreams. I was in orbit and I couldnt find my way across the void.How was she launched in orbit? Of course it started at home: a handsome, attentive father and a mother who didnt appreciate him enough, so he lavished affection on his daughter. Lillian doesnt lean on that explanation. She moves on to other men. Dave, who looks like a fashion model. Laszlo, the cosmopolitan Hungarian. Willis, a photographer from Texas, who picked her up at a caf in Paris.
