No doubt her sisters would be as well.Indeed they are.The band is sometimes described as a latter-day Fleetwood Mac, but Este, Alana and Danielle Haim are so much more than that. For one thing, they're blessedly less self-involved. In fact, they're unscrubbed at every level. They perform in what might be called daywear. Their makeup, if they wear any, is subliminal. They couldn't be more relaxed --- except in their music, which is crisp and inventive. Their voices mesh. Their lyrics bite. Their guitars sting and chime, as needed. Think of them as the children of Fleetwood Mac and Joni Mitchell.They're opening for Mumford & Sons now. Soon they'll be headliners. Then they'll be huge.How did they get so good? When they were pre-schoolers, their father woke from a nap with a vision: a family band. Guitars were acquired. Soon the parent-daughter band had mastered "Mustang Sally."The all-kid version was born in 2007, when the youngest daughter was on the verge of graduating high school with no plan to go to college. Lyrics materialized. Recording began. "For each of the last four years, we made an EP, which we hated," they say. "There are many Haim records that will never be released."In what they've let out, there's joyous variety. If there's a through line, it's sophisticated rhythms and solo voices that can come from any of the trio. They have a male drummer. To his credit, he can keep up.Their full-length CD will be released later this year. Nice that you can get in on the ground floor now.

If you want to see the Rolling Stones --- and they're 70-ish now, so this really could be the last time --- prepare to break the bank.To sit behind the stage at the Brooklyn arena, you'll pay $300. Back of the arena? $650. And if you want to sit right up front, you'll spend $3,500 to $5,000 --- that's for one ticket.Who will pay those prices? Boomers. And, specifically, hedge-fund sharpies, top-tier bond traders and their clients. As Mick Jagger told the crowd at one of those million-dollar gigs the Stones play for corporations that create profits but not jobs, "Hope you're enjoying this --- because this is your bonuses."If you love the Rolling Stones and want something new in your collection or if, at this late date, you're curious to know what these guys are really like, I have a cheaper suggestion. It's an enhanced e-book, "Mick and Keith: Never Stop: My Conversations with the Rolling Stones," and it's the handiwork of Rona Elliot.At the dawn of rock, Elliot was an LA kid, "driving to concerts in my Dad's 1960 Plymouth." A few years later, she was covering rock music for the "Today" Show. She was in the mud at Woodstock, backstage at the Fillmore. She interviewed everyone who mattered.In 1970, she convinced Mick Jagger and Keith Richards to answer a gazillion questions. She met Jagger in New York, at the Waldorf. Three months later, on Antigua, she had her conversation with Keith. They were both relaxed, thoughtful, amused. And more: revealing.What comes across most dramatically in these conversations is that Jagger and Richards share few opinions.Are the Stones a family? No agreement.Were they hurt when they were called "ugly" and "rude?" Ditto.Did they know "Satisfaction" would be a monster hit? Keith (who wrote the killer riff): "We needed an extra track. I thought it was filler." Mick: "Oh yeah. I knew."Innocence on the road? "The road is terribly innocent," Mick says. "The girls have such high-pitched voices I'm surprised they let them out without their mothers." Keith: "If you're a musician on the road, you don't keep your innocence for more than a few weeks."Fun. And giggles. But what I really valued is how much seriousness is required to create a Stones show. Keith talks about "dedication" and why he isn't quite the goofball he may seem to be: "The stage is my space, the one place I can get some peace." And a much larger point: What happens between the band and the audience "makes you aware of how much people can do when they put their minds to it."Fifty years on, the Rolling Stones still put their minds to it. (Well, you say, they have many incentives, and their payday is surely not the least.) So does Rona Elliot, who has done more than recycle old interviews; she's compiled rare photos, ticket stubs and personal memorabilia in the service of a smart, joyous celebration of a group that calls itself "the world's greatest rock band." They may not be that now, but this e-book makes you want to agree.

I was high on New Orleans when I finished Debra Shriver's book, so I logged on to JetBlue and checked the fare from New York to New Orleans.Would you believe it is as low as $197, one way, tax included?Boy, I wish I did not know that.If you lay your hands on a copy of "In the Spirit of New Orleans," I hope you live far from an airport that has cheap flights to that city, for Debra Shriver's book is so full of positivity they ought to build a shrine to her on Bourbon Street.Part of the attraction of this book and this city is that, as a writer says in these pages, "This is possibly the least American town in the country." I know we live in the greatest nation on God's green earth, but have you looked out the window lately? Most of America is a giant strip mall. Not a bit of eye candy as far as the eye can see.New Orleans, in contrast, gives you a glorious past. Okay, somewhat sanitized. Just as New York is an urban theme park, New Orleans gives you Dixieland strut and swagger without the brutality and racism. Its people are stunningly resilient --- there are 300 new restaurants since Katrina. Across race and class, they seem to realize that they are all in show business, and they play their parts admirably. As does Debra Shriver.Ms. Shriver works at the Hearst Tower in New York. (Disclosure: I occasionally write for Hearst.) But she and her husband have restored a house in New Orleans; she has recorded that story in her beguiling first book, "Stealing Magnolias: Tales from a New Orleans Courtyard." If I had to lay down money, I'd say that she would much prefer to vote there. A twelth-generation Southerner, she writes with the verve of a native. And the imagination: You'll find a recipe for a wicked seafood gumbo here --- and also one for the city's official cocktail, the Sazerac (bitters, rye whiskey, absinthe, sugar cube --- yikes!).A word on the photography: This photo editor will work again, ditto the designer. Here's a two-page spread of a beautiful restored red-and-white paddle-wheeler. A few pages later, a spread of a giant oak tree, festooned with Spanish Moss. An old black-and-white cityscape has been drenched in red. There's a picture of the domed vault at St. Patrick's Catholic Church that makes you want to rush there and lay on your back. And a close-up of Fats Domino's right hand, the pinky sporting a ring with a rhinestone-encrusted piano. And more. Much more.Debra Shriver's New Orleans is a dreamscape, heaven with a back beat. She doesn't ignore Katrina, but she takes it as much as metaphor as reality. Avoiding a tour of the Lower Ninth Ward --- still largely abandoned, with only a quarter of its pre-Katrina population --- turns out to be good sense. A tourist bus that included that blighted zone on its tour of New Orleans was recently fined $150. Who knew that "disaster voyeurism" is a crime?If you've got friend or family with a trip ahead, this is the ideal gift book. But don't, for heaven's sakes, crack it open if travel is not in your immediate future.

Susan Mary Alsop (1918-2004) was a society beauty who morphed into a great saloniste and hostess, but the best reason I found to read this 193-page biography is that it chronicles a low-battery marriage, a torrid romance with a married womanizer and, after the deaths of her husband and lover, a second marriage to a gay man she never slept with.In short, "American Lady: The Life of Susan Mary Alsop" is a tale of life in the Upper Class before women threw off the shackles.She knew everyone. She had tea with Edith Wharton. Her frequent dinner partner was Winston Churchill ("He has decided I am . . . French . . . and nothing will deter him from speaking French to me."). The gratin of Paris, Noel Coward, the Duke of Windsor. In Washington, John Kennedy came to her house after the Inaugural parties for a midnight bowl of turtle soup. Lyndon Johnson "pinched her behind and exclaimed, `Why does such a thin girl wear a garter belt?'"She was, in a word, the best --- and last --- of her breed. And she knew it. "All these stories will be in the history books," she wrote, "but it does send a chill down one's spine to hear them told by the actors in the drama."So come for a peek behind the curtain of International Society. But stay for the sex. And then the cost of sex in Susan Mary's world: no shame, but great secrecy. And hypocrisy. And the kind of deprivation caused by the absence of flesh on flash. And, finally, the reckoning.This is surely not the book that Caroline de Margerie, a family friend, believes she has written. As she tells it, this is the story of a prominent young woman --- a descendant of founding father John Jay --- who was born in a time of low vocational and high social expectations for upper crust women. Susan Mary married Bill Patten at 20. He had severe asthma, which limited his activity, but he was gentle and kind - he would be "a dear and tender friend."When she was 18, her mother offered her either a debutante ball or a trip abroad. She chose the trip. And did it again in her marriage --- in 1945, she helped her husband get a government job in Paris, and there her life really began.The jolt came from her affair with British diplomat and writer Duff Cooper. He was married to Lady Diana Manners, a high-spirited beauty who knew exactly the kind of man her husband was: a compulsive womanizer. This was not, for her, a problem. "She asked only to be kept informed."Susan Mary's husband had no such tolerance, so he was never informed. Or maybe he knew but pretended not to --- in those days, many couples had secret, separate lives. And women like Susan Mary were, in their way, great actresses. "She walked into adultery as tremulously as a governess into her first job; yet she turned out to be a natural, maneuvering like a seasoned courtesan."Very seasoned. When she learned she was pregnant, Duff Cooper could not have been less interested. The boy was named William Samuel Patten, Jr. He looked a lot like Duff. Bill never knew. Or pretended not to.Patten died. His close friend Joe Alsop came courting. The world didn't know he was gay --- he was an important Washington journalist, and the revelation would have ended his career --- but he didn't lie to Susan Mary. Why marry him? She needed a father for her children. And she and Joe would make a great team.The Alsops took Washington by storm. Just one problem: In private, Joe could be a total jerk to his wife. And was. Often. This time she didn't take a lover. She just endured. Wrote. Entertained. And found comfort in alcohol.The last years of any life can be problematic. Susan Mary was too well-bred to surrender to bitterness --- in company, she never dropped her game face. But in a stint in a rehab center, at a family meeting, she drops a bomb that shocked me. And will make you rethink much of what you've read."American Lady: The Life of Susan Mary Alsop" is a cautionary tale.

These fishnet thigh highs are very nice. The netting is a little bit different than normal fishnets, which are usually made from more of a cotton fiber. This has more stretch to it, almost like the netting is woven from elastic thread. It also has a more delicate netting size that gives a diamond appearance rather than little squares.The top cuff is a pretty lace flourish, about three inches in width. It's a delicate, yet functional touch that adds even more to a simple fishnet. The lace cuff is comfortable on the thigh.There's a seam on the back of the leg that also gives these a retro feeling while still looking modern. You could even wear hosiery underneath these to change the look further.These are a good value and well-made. Unless you really snag these on something sharp, they will likely not unravel anytime soon.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I do not automatically provide four- or five-star reviews when I receive a low- or no-cost item as is evidenced in my review history. I do not receive compensation for my reviews.

I love this headband but only after I made a small alteration to it. This headband is a nice width but comes with a cincher band that pulls it in to a turban-like configuration. I cut it off because I prefer a smooth band that covers my ears completely. The little cincher prevented full ear coverage and made the band look less elegant than it really is.This is made from a microfiber/jersey that is super soft and extremely stretchy. It clings to the head where you place it without it shifting around or feeling tight.I have the black version, which, turns out, is a true black, not that weird dyed brown/black that passes for black today (cheapens the look).This can be used for a variety of things - outdoor sports like running in the colder weather, as an ear cover in the wind (I'm using it for indoor cold right now) and even for pulling the hair away from the face for a facial or mask.Minus the cincher, this is pretty great.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I do not automatically provide four- or five-star reviews when I receive a low- or no-cost item as is evidenced in my review history. I do not receive compensation for my reviews.

These boot socks are so lovely and girly, I can't wait until boot season is in full swing (just about here!) so I can get good use out of these.The foot is a lacey knit in a stretchy yarn but the cuff is a cotton cording with a crochet lace look and little shirt-sized buttons that are there in a decorative way. (not functional). The sizing seems standard and they fit nicely, neither loose or tight.These are toeless so you would have to wear a thin hosiery underneath but they're still thin enough not to create bulk or affect the fit of a boot.A really nice boot sock that looks really pretty peaking out from my ankles.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I wear a 7.5 regular in shoes, which I consider average or even a little below average. These toeless compression socks are size X/XL but they look child size. Once I got them on (it took some muscle), they felt good except for the bands around the toes and ankle because they constrict circulation and I felt numb after a little while. I don't think that's supposed to happen.That said, the parts that fit around the foot feel so good that I'm going to give these to my friend who wears a size 6 and get another pair for me these once I figure out what the correct size is.The quality of these socks is high. The fabric/weave is solid with a nice thickness. Travis Mills, for all intents and purposes, was a normal, American boy, not unlike many of his generation. He excelled in sports, had many friends and a loving family. He also loved his country and joined the U.S. Army where he was a member of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division deployed to the Middle East.During his third deployment, an IED planted by Taliban soldiers injured him so severely, it resulted in a quadruple amputation. His road to recovery is both fascinating and awe-inspiring. I mean, trying to conceive life without arms and legs (even one) is almost impossible to imagine.But true to his determination and will to overcome the challenges facing him, Mills has surmounted obstacles only the strongest among us could even envision (I'm not one of them).While still in the midst of recovery and physical rehabilitation, Mills' genuine personality is clear despite the pain and suffering and struggles he has endured since his injuries in April of 2012. In the three plus years since his injuries occurred, he has taken his life back to the fullest extent  driving, running, cycling and assisting other wounded veterans with rehabilitation through his foundation, The Travis Mills Foundation. And that's just the tip of the iceberg.It may also shock you to learn he harbors no animosity for "the enemy," while providing straightforward descriptions about how things really are for our soldiers who are in the field under such harsh conditions. He also describes the deep commitment and loyalty he and the other troops share with each other.To say he is an inspiration would almost be insulting as it could never capture adequately the sheer force of his will and determination to live and to succeed. He does all of this with great compassion, humor and an undying love of country.Highly recommend.

This is the bamboo version of a set of EMAX brushes I tried recently but it has a slightly different configuration of brush styles. This set comes with 12 brushes, a teardrop-shaped makeup sponge and a carry bag. The big difference with this set is that it contains Kabuki brushes for mineral powder, eyebrow and eyelash brushes and a flat (liquid) foundation brush, which I love, and really miss in the other sets of EMAX brushes I have tried. The pointy side of the teardrop sponge is also nice for liquid foundation because it gets into all the nooks around the eyes and nose that fingers can't get, though I still prefer the flat foundation brush for liquid makeup because it gives a really nice finish to the face.Like the other EMAX brush sets, these have a strong glue smell when you take them out of the bag and plastic that washes out with a little bit of gentle shampoo and an air dry. The smell completely disappears when washed. These brush heads are very soft for synthetic bristles with no strays popping out (I don't like stray bristles on my brushes!).This set includes a foundation brush, a big eye shadow brush, highlight brush, smudge brush, concealer brush, eyebrow brush, eyelash brush, small eye shadow brush, blusher brush, multifunction foundation brush, multifunction blush brush, Kabuki brush and a teardrop-shaped makeup sponge in pink (latex free and non-allergenic).I really like the bamboo handles on these brushes and the overall quality is nice for the price. At $15, this is a good value and makes a nice gift for a teenager as a first set or simply for people who just want a nice, inexpensive full set of brushes.These brushes are appropriate for use with liquids, powders and creams. They are handmade and are not supposed to shed for the lifetime of the brush. Time will show us whether or not this is true.Overall a very nice set of brushes that have a luxury feel to them, even more than some of the brushes I've received with some high-end prestige cosmetics.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. The backdrop for this novel is the U.S. Army's experimental nuclear power reactor (the SL-1 Nuclear Reactor in the high desert of Idaho), which had some type of steam explosion in January 1961 and killed three of its operators. I believe this is the only nuclear event in U.S. history that produced fatalities.Two years before this nuclear event, in 1959, Nat and her husband, Paul (a U.S. Army Specialist) move to Idaho Falls as Paul's assignment is to oversee the reactor's facilitation about 50 miles away from their home in Idaho Falls. With them are their two young daughters. Though Idaho Falls is a military town, it is still a remote and lonely place and Nat finds herself struggling with isolation and loneliness while Paul is working. Things were not 100% with them before the move and this has only exacerbated their problems.In the meantime, Paul has learned about a major safety issue that could potentially cause a lot of harm that his chain of command wants to cover up, not correct. He makes the decision to not tell Nat of the problems he is having at work and her restlessness grows. Paul is deployed for six weeks as a result of the conflict he is having with his boss over the state of the reactor and when Nat finds herself in need of help, a friendship blooms with a local man who is a help and a comfort to her during this time of isolation. This friendship is kept from Paul and the inventory of secrets they keep from each other continues to grow. Things go on like this for a while and rumors about Nat and her "friend" begin to make their way around.When the accident comes to fruition, Nat and Paul are forced to deal with breakdown of marriage head on.In The Longest Night, the author did an amazing job of re-creating the late 1950s/early 1960s in so thorough a way, I almost felt I was there. The story is told from varying perspectives that include Nat, Paul and Jeannie (the wife of Paul's superior officer). Each one of them, bring their own skewed perception of events to the table, provide food for thought and make sense, individually. As a whole, they couldn't be more different.This is a rather fascinating look behind the scenes of a rather big, but hidden away, event in U.S. history. You'll want to do a little research as you read this.Recommend.

Having read much of Mary Gaitskill's work, including Veronica, I understand her to be extremely skilled at getting us invested in characters that are most definitely off the beaten path or even outright  unlikable in some situations. This is the story of a young Dominican girl named Velveteen Vargas, age 11, who is sent from her home in Brooklyn to upstate New York as part of the Fresh Air Fund program to send inner city kids to places that could potentially help them deal with the difficulties in their lives. Velveteen is sent to the home of Ginger and Paul, who, despite their own issues, want to make a difference in Velveteen's life. They are basically doing a dry run of what it might be like to adopt an older child and having Velveteen with them for a couple of weeks might shine some light on how this idea could play out.The differences in life in the city versus life in the country are significant, as you would imagine. Aside from an abusive home life, Velveteen must contend with an equally awful school environment. Her father is the absentee sort and her mother's constant working yields little in terms of money or luxury.Ginger is a recovering alcoholic and Paul is an academic. Paul is worried about Ginger's growing attachment to Velveteen. Silvia Vargas, Velveteen's mother is jealous of the relationship her daughter is forming with this new "family." Despite her harsh treatment of Velveteen, she does appear to love her daughter in her own flawed and frightened way.Add to this mix of people a horse named Fiery Girl, as damaged and fragile and untamable as her human counterpart, Velveteen, who has a natural way with her that does much to change Velveteen's future outlook despite the never-ending boulders that seem to line the road before her at every turn. This book really makes the case for how loving animals changes us and how the gifts they give us in return are numerous.With her usual expertise, Mary Gaitskill gets inside of the characters to present their innermost feelings from their most personal moments in life, rife with anger, sadness, despair and joy.Easy relationships are not always the most rewarding. Sometimes the difficult relationships are the ones that transform us for the long haul, despite our intentions at the outset.

I'm not sure what the demand is for webcams these days considering that most laptops have their own webcams built in and smartphones are all set up for this already. I'm also not sure how big the audience is for webcam cameras but I guess there are still a small group of people without laptops or smartphones who could use this for chatting with their people in other places.The camera itself has a nice build quality to it. It comes packaged simply (which I like) and comes with a mini cd of drivers and what not, though you don't really need it since it's a plug and play type of camera.I tried this camera on two different laptops and I had some issues with it on both but no deal breakers. The main issue is a slight delay on both video and audio (worse on audio) so it's like when the voices don't sync to the video on a TV show. It's just a matter of a second or two so I can live with it if it's just being used on video calls.The quality of the video isn't bad, it's pretty good, in fact, although my iphone is somewhat better. The only sort of smallish issue is having to manually focus the camera before use so that you aren't blurry to whomever you might be chatting with via web services. Which is fine, if you're staying in one place or recording video for something without a lot of range of movement around the room while having a discussion. It's lightweight and sits atop the screen with a good amount of stability so it won't fall off if you tap the screen or move the laptop.Overall, it's a decent camera for video calls, though I wouldn't use it for other things like making youtube videos or other types of video projects.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is my first mud wrap experience. I'm trying to work on my upper arms, in particular, so that I have really good ones next summer during the sleeveless season (I have a lot of work to do so I'm starting early!).Since I'm coming from a place of not knowing what to expect or having nothing to compare this with, I will give you my impressions from a place of newness.So you first have to heat up the wrap in boiling water (15 minutes but I was afraid it would be too hot, so I did it for 10). Then you will need to mix the mud clay with water so that it's at a good consistency for spreading on the area you want to use it on (upper arms for me). Once the wrap is as hot as you want it, squeeze it out and wrap the area. It felt really good on with the warmth and when I removed the first application of it after about 75 mins (you're really supposed to keep it on for an hour but I got stuck on a phone call I couldn't end so I had an extra 15 mins), my skin felt really good. After that, I just kept in on for 75 mins at a time. Honestly, my arm appearance hasn't really changed with the three applications I've used but my skin feels really great and there is absolutely no dryness or need for extra lotion afterward. However, I do have a little bit of eczema that seems visibly calmer and a lot less scaly after using this product. So that's something.I guess these need to be used consistently and over time to see really visible results. Even so, I still like the process, which is very relaxing and refreshing. The mud (clay) pulls toxins from the skin and excess fluid, which I think will help with appearance over time. The clay is organic volcanic clay made with herbal extracts.One last observation I want to share. I thought this had a nice, mild and pleasant fragrance to it. Not overwhelming but enough to enhance to spa feel to the treatment.After a few applications, I will continue to use these and track my progress. If I eventually get the desired result that's image-worthy, I'll post pics as I have already taken a "before" photo. But even if I just come away with improvement to my skin afflicted with eczema, it would be worth it.This set comes with eight packets of volcanic clay and two reusable wraps.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is marketed toward making nut milks (it comes with a recipe for almond milk). But, this is also great for making yogurt cheese or for preparing other cheeses for thickening (removing the whey). I love nut milks but I have heard about some of the things that go into them that I don't really like. Unfortunately, nut milk is the only beverage that transforms the taste of protein powder from completely non-palatable to kind of delicious. For whatever reason, almond milk tempers any bitterness from even the high-quality protein powders.The recipe that comes with this bag is just okay. It calls for the almonds to be soaked for six hours or more. In reality, the almonds should be soaked for two days, at least, in order to get the creaminess you want from them. Also, the almonds should be raw and the recipe doesn't state that. You can google better recipes. But this is a good bag for the straining portion and works really well. The mesh is a fine quality but easy enough to extract the liquid from the pulp. If you save the almond pulp, you can use it in cereal like oatmeal or dry it out in a low oven (around 200 degrees) until it's dry (almond meal). So there isn't any waste and raw almonds are extremely healthy for you.Easy to clean with dishwashing soap and hot water. Air dries quickly. Durable.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This review is for the ThermoPro TP10 Digital Probe Oven Roasting Thermometer, which can be used as a meat thermometer as well as an oven temperature thermometer. It is programmed to measure the temperature for nine different meats and fish (ground beef, ground poultry, beef [steaks/roasts], veal, chicken, pork, poultry [other than chicken], lamb and fish). For each different meat setting, the LCD screen will provide colored light indications of when the meat is done (blue to start, green for almost done, red for fully cooked and ready to eat). This allows you to also select the desired "taste" outcome of the meat from rare all the way up to well done (five settings altogether). The light indicators adjust to the settings.The meat probe (thermometer) is made of food grade stainless steel with an angled tip. The length is about four inches so you can get it into the meat far enough to really get an accurate read. It can be used in temperatures up to 716 degrees but that's not anything I'd be dealing with. The screen is easy to read (outdoors too) and seems accurate as I tried it against another meat thermometer I know to be extremely accurate and both produced the identical temperature reading.This thermometer comes equipped with a built-in timer and AAA batteries (two) are provided in the package. This is also pretty easy to care for and clean by washing the probe in hot soapy water and wiping the unit with a damp cloth.This is a sturdy, efficient meat thermometer, which is appropriate for both indoor and outdoor cooking situations.I can recommend this without hesitation.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. Wow! What an amazing facial steamer. I used it several times before reviewing it to see how it worked on my skin over a couple of weeks so I could review it more effectively. Now I can really see and feel a difference in my skin, which feels deeply cleaned with a silky texture.It works just like a professional steamer in a salon that opens the pores and clears debris and preps the skin for blackhead removal. I don't have a lot of blackhead activity as a middle aged person but I do have exfoliation issues that constantly need to be addressed.  Dry, unexfoliated skin clogs pores and creates eruptions over time (at least with my skin) so it's nice to have this at home to clear up some of the deeper areas that are missed by simple exfoliation scrubs.The steamer itself is lovely. Nicely designed and pretty. It kind of looks like a pretty, pink-detailed water pitcher. Also, it's lightweight and very easy to use. You must use filtered water or distilled water in this to prevent operational issues that come from using unfiltered water over time (calcium buildup). You have to fill the tank as indicated so that a good pure steam is produced from the vaporizer. While the instructions say that you could potentially use this once per day for up to 10 minutes, that's not really a good idea. Two to three times per week should be adequate for most people (I'm doing two). Each full tank of water is good for about 10 minutes of steady steam. It takes less than a minute to heat up and release steam and will shut off automatically when the tank has been depleted of water.This is an ionic steamer that through the Positive Thermal Coefficient (PTC) ceramic heating element, it adds an additional element of clean water vaporization. This steamer has a UV lamp that sterilizes the vapor before it arrives on the skin so you're only getting good, clean steam going into your pores. There's an internal fan that that directs the steam and gives it the power to penetrate the skin through layers, which is supposed to help with natural collagen production. The steam is also supposed to help with dark spots over time but that remains to be seen. It definitely helps to reduce potential breakouts.I'm very happy with this steamer and hope to be using it for years.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. It will adjust to a variety of head sizes.One minor issue is light leakage when you sleep on your side as the mask no longer makes full contact with the face when one side of your head is against the pillow. However, people who need to use a mask to block out daylight may take issue with this so I mention it for that reason.The material that this is made of is soft and smooth, almost like the material that the newer types of padded bras are made of.The fact that this is machine washable is an added bonus although I prefer to hand wash with a gentle soap. It dries very quickly.Very nice eye mask, overall.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This silicone wristwatch/pedometer is similar to other pedometers except that you dont clip it to your belt or pocket. Its a wristwatch with a cool slap band that adjusts to wrist size from child size to grown man size and everything in between. I do a lot of walking in New York City and like to get my 10,000 steps in each day. This is a nice way to keep track of those counts. It works like a pedometer in that you measure your stride and set the settings and time, etc. This charges via mini USB (cable included).I compared my clip on pedometer to this one and there was a slight difference in steps (about 50 less than the clip on). I might have to jigger with my stride setting to see if I can get this closer to my very accurate clip on pedometer. The numbers are close enough that I think I can fix this through adjustments in order to calibrate the two.This watch is perfect for the person who may not have a smart phone or a person who may not like using apps to count steps. Or who may want just the basics. You just slap it on and go, count your steps and be done with it. Its lightweight and comfortable, too.I like it.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This waist pouch is a little bit on the petite side. I think its best for those times when you need just a small money/card belt with the bare minimum of items. I put in an iphone, ID, some cash and a credit card and it was tight. I couldnt get the keys in (on a ring).Though small, this is well-made and otherwise very comfortable. I think a good use for this is for taking runs, walking the dog  keep your pack light with just the essentials. There are two pockets with mesh panels and the fabric is a high quality sport fabric that will stay dry in both weather and sweat conditions.Very nice.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is not something I need every day. I need this for road trips and long drives to distant shores. That's a bit dramatic but this really is a great device for when you have a few things that need charging on a long road trip (phone, GPS, ipod, etc). Having it all in one place is helpful. This has a nice long cord so I can place it anywhere I need it on the dash area so that I can reach it (they include a 3M adhesive but I like to keep it loose so I can move it around as needed).The big thing I like about this charger, aside from converting one outlet into three, the outlets are individual and you can power on one at a time or all three at once. They each have their own power button. I also think it's fairly well-made, though it will be time that will provide the evidence of this.So now here's the other thing. The display is a little bit lacking in readability and usefulness. First, in daylight, forget trying to read the display. Just plug in and forget about it. Second, this charger displays the interior car temperature (Yay!) but it's only in Celsius (Boo!). If you plan to market this in the U.S., at least make sure it displays in Fahrenheit. Just an observation. If there is a way to switch from Celsius to Fahrenheit, I can't figure it out. And you can't switch the display language from Chinese to English (as far as I can tell). So there's that, too.Anyway, the main functionality is excellent as chargers go. Just as a side note, when Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012 and I had to charge everything in my car because the power was out for two weeks, I would have really appreciated having this around to speed up the process.A few tweaks and this could be a winner.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is made to be worn around the waist but I sized up one because I like wearing these lower on my hips (I don't like anything tight on my waist or against my skin). The fabric on this belt is really nice. It has a nice sheen and it's very soft and stretchy, like a bathing suit. But it's also a nice microfiber that will wick the sweat away if you wear this running or for working out. I wear mine over my pants but it will work in whatever way suits you.This belt has a nice modern look to it. Very sleek and minimally designed. There is a zipper that you can adjust to size, which is a nice touch. I thought the zipper would add bulk and be annoying but it really wasn't. I love this belt. It's a nice stretch design you pull up around your waist, although I sized up a notch since I don't like anything pressed against my waits and prefer to use this on the hip area. It's a lot more comfortable for me that way. One thing that I like a lot about this is that there is no Velcro, which somehow always finds a way to stick to pants and damage them with pulls.The material is like a microfiber so you can wear this next to the skin and it will wick away sweat. Solar-powered lights solve the age-old dilemma of lighting up the trees and bushes in the yard when there are no outlets with which to plug your lights in. Not a fan of extension cords out in the elements, either. Luckily, solar power saves the day. This is a strand of 100 LED lights that can easily be hung or strung over a wreath or a bush. These are dainty lights, aptly named "fairy lights," which can be used year round as these are not specific to the winter holidays. They have a couple of different modes to select from  "long bright" and "single flash."  They have a day to night sensor so that they charge all day (8  10 hours) and run for 6  8 hours in the dark. The solar battery will continue to charge even if you have the light switch in the off position.While these are water resistant, it's not a good idea for these to get saturated. The instructions state that these will work normally in the rain but I guess maybe not so well in a torrential downpour. Maybe these are best utilized for a wreath on a door that has some protection provided to it. You can definitely use LED lights on a wreath since they don't get too hot like the standard lights. Nothing will be bursting into flames, in other words.The set includes the lights with solar panel, a ground spike for positioning the solar panel and the user manual.These are very nice lights appropriate for a variety of uses on a year-round basis.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is a great little camera set up. It works on Wi-Fi and a phone app. Through the app, I can scan a room with a swipe of my finger on the screen, change the settings, hear audio and speak back and the list goes on. It even records audio. If you're at work and someone at home needs you, like an elderly person or the babysitter, they can communicate. The camera is very good and the video is pretty clear for a "cam" of sorts.This is also cutely designed, lightweight and minimalist in design, which I like, because it blends into the surroundings. It's like a baby robot. You can place this on a shelf or mount it to the wall in a corner of the room or even on the ceiling (if you had an outlet on the higher end of the wall because the cord is only a little more than three feet) with the included mounting hardware.The camera is adjustable to night vision with its infrared lights positioned around the lens. You can change the mode to night from the app, which has a nice, easy-to-use interface (from your phone). There is an indicator light when the device is powered on and this can be used with an Ethernet cable if you don't have Wi-Fi for some reason. There is also a micro SD card slot on the back of the device too. You will need the SD card for taking instant snapshots or to record video since there is no internal memory in the actual camera. I think you can go up to 32 GBs. And you do get a one-year subscription to Amazon's cloud.This camera will work with iphone and android phones because they have the app capability that other phones don't have. You can otherwise set up a desktop version (Desktop PC Client) if you still have a flip phone (do they still make those?).Set up was fairly easy after a rather lengthy boot up (a couple of minutes at least). I used Wi-Fi by pairing via the WPS button on my router. When you download the app, you scan the QR code on the device and that's how the app recognizes your camera. Very easy setup.That's the good news. The bad news is the app is a little bit buggy (I had to remove a star for this), especially when trying to schedule recordings. But you can record continuously as well, 24 hours a day (audio and video) and you can adjust the quality of the video, too, from the app. The video resolution is pretty good quality and the audio is decent, not great, because it picks up background noise but you still get a coherent, understandable audio track. I am confident the app will improve with updates.This is a nice little security camera useful for so many things.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. As much as we like to think that we are making strides in the treatment of mental illness (we are but), there are still so many levels of mental illness, the layers of complexity are overwhelming. This is a page turner, told from the perspective of a caregiver to a partner with mental illness.Some of what is discussed and described in this book will seem very familiar to you if you have ever been in the position of dealing with mental illness in a family member or friend. But there are so many things that are brought to light about the causes of as well as the things that exacerbate the illness.Sheila Hamilton, a reporter, was married to David, a businessman and they had one daughter. Over time, David's behavior changed. Infidelity, bouts of mania and depression, and generally, erratic, volatile behavior became a regular occurrence. David tried prescription drugs but these, ultimately did more damage and he hit a low, having to be hospitalized. He was diagnosed with bi-polar disorder, spent a couple of months in the hospital and then ended his life. In the wake of this, he left behind a legacy of grief and lots of messes to clean up, including a large amount of debt.Sheila's quest for answers led to her writing this book. The emotional toll of loving a person whose behavior is frightening and dangerous is incredibly sad and confusing. She also highlights all of the inconsistencies in the healthcare system that cause so many mentally ill patients to fall through the cracks. It's an extremely overwhelming and frustrating topic. I felt profound sadness, not just in Sheila's personal story but for those people who fall through the cracks and end up with dire consequences, not just for themselves but for others.This is a compelling book, which also provides a lot of factual information and data about mental illness that will sadden and surprise you.

Told from the point of view of "Music," The Magic Strings of Frankie Presto opens up at the funeral of Frankie, a musical genius and superstar. "Music," the narrator and giver of musical talent, has gifted Frankie with exceptional musical talent. Frankie was born during the Spanish Civil War and orphaned. His life is almost pre-destined to become a superstar. On the road to superstardom, Frankie crosses paths with many other superstars, whose names come from the top tiers of the entertainment industry.What struck me are the similarities to fame today  or at least the quest for it  and the journey from unknown to megastar. "Music" has this sort of emotionless manner in that he is only narrating, rather than judging Frankie's management and use of his gifts. Frankie's quest for fame is almost like a drug, partly composed of the life-changing impact his music has had on others and the life-altering tolls it has taken on him. It has given so much to him, yet it has stolen things from him, too. The pleasures/burdens of superstardom permeate every fiber of his being.I felt like I was reading the biography of a real person backed by a musical soundtrack. Upon his death, we are left with questions. What mysteries are behind Frankie's talent and what influenced Frankie's drive? And, is there a bigger message in the story of Frankie's life? I don't know.  It's not as clear as some of Albom's other books. For me, viewing Frankie's life from the rather unemotional perspective of "Music" provided some food for thought. We may think we know or speculate upon what motivates a public figure, but we really know nothing of the person underneath the outer shell of fame.Interesting, well-written and thought-provoking.Recommend.

I judged this book by its cover and it paid off, big time. It's about 50-something John Nichols, who comes to the table with A LOT of baggage.  That baggage includes adultery, divorce and lots of "ex" careers amongst other things. He also has a teen-aged developmentally challenged son (Ethan) he has the main responsibility for and two grown daughters (Karen and Mindy).There's a lot of stuff going on. A LOT.Even with all of his "issues" (for lack of a better word), John is a caring sort and keeps trying. His daughter, Karen, is getting married and John decides to take Ethan on a road trip to the wedding in Charleston, SC, to avoid unpleasantness on an airplane (Ethan has airplane history John wants to avoid). But things still come up en route on the road trip that are stressful and challenging. And this is all before John proceeds to make an announcement to the family that is somewhat shocking. Karen has some sharing to do as well. And John's ex-wife, Mary, will also be in attendance, which is another problem, as John still has a thing for her.The lion's share of the book deals with the unfolding of John's earlier pronouncement, of which you will need to read the book to learn the subject of. Some of this story was difficult to read without getting emotional but much of it is also humorous and told with a certain kind of honesty that highlights the best in a group of flawed, fumbling people. This group of people add new insights into dysfunction in families.But I have to stop and say something about how well-written this book was and what a pleasure it was to read, despite some of the unpleasant moments (meaning difficult emotionally).At the end of the day, there is a lot of love on the pages of this book, despite life's challenges presented therein and it's definitely worth the time it took it took to read (I had to put it down every once in a while to reflect).Definitely recommend.

We can all practice a little bit of forgiveness, especially when doing so will relieve pain (your own). This is something that is common to everyone, religious or not, though this book is religious in nature and uses Joseph's story to present lessons on forgiveness. Joseph had lots to forgive others for (he was sold into slavery by his brothers, for one thing).Forgiveness is a lot bigger than you might think it is. While we can learn to forgive others, it's often harder to forgive yourself. The study is divided into lessons that are helpful for unearthing the hidden anger and pain we carry around. There are six weeks of lessons that cover acknowledging pain, waiting to be remembered, your dreams, the roller coaster of emotions, setting boundaries and moving forward in life.At the end of the six weeks of lessons, the author provides a reading list of books that focus on the forgiveness process. Even without the religious ramifications of this book, there's value in taking steps to forgive people, not for their sake but for yours.Recommend.

This is yet another version of the Common English Bible (CEB). I have just reviewed the YA version of the CEB Bible, which I thought was a nice translation that made Bible facts and stories more readable and identifiable to the YA demographic. This CEB Bible is the Deep Blue Kids Bible and features a "soft" hardcover with a beautiful teal sea of fish swimming across the cover. Since this book is for the younger set (maybe about 7  11 years), it features kid-friendly illustrations, cartoon people, Nat Geo maps and lots of nice color.The actual text is more of a storytelling type of translation with a child-appropriate introduction and facts set apart from the text in the form of notes that are useful in explaining important bits and pieces of the text in language that a child could better comprehend. I especially like the introductions to the people we will get to know in each book. As with the YA edition, there are some very nice maps included in this that put a face on the geography and logistics of the time.This is a lovely little Bible, though for the younger age range of kids you might select this for, you may have to read it with them since the print is small and there's a lot of it.Recommend.

This Bible is a "Common English Bible," which presents the old testament as well as the new testament in language that is more understandable and relatable. I believe this particular translation is a YA level translation. But I found that what I read of it is also appropriate for adults. I wish I had had one of these when I was going through catholic school. It would have made it way more understandable, in general.This CEB edition also features a lot of extras like historical introductions that precede each book so that you can have some context in your head before diving in. There are also opinions and writings from biblical scholars that present additional food for thought as well as some philosophical type questions to ponder. The inclusion of maps is a nice touch. I found the maps helpful for understanding the geographical logistics found across the pages of the Bible.Even for people who are not religious, this is an interesting version to read as a piece of historical material. My feeling is that hardcore Christians and maybe some Jewish scholars could find fault in some of the more modern translations and storytelling. But I found it tells the stories in a more straightforward manner. And if it gets a person to read this just once in their lifetime, it's worth it.

You could say this is a book about three men. Or you could say this is about four men. Free Men by Katy Simpson Smith deals with the various levels of disenfranchisement of three men: an American Indian (Istillicha), a white man (Cat) and a black man (Bob). On their heels is the fourth man  LeClerc  tracking them. These four men are connected because of circumstances that have put them together, all of them symbolic of something other than what they are. Together they are the physical (American Indian wildness), the mental (white man's intellect) and the emotional (black man's heart of darkness) components of man, for good or bad, with the upper class (LeClerc) condescending to understand the elements beneath him (um, and he's French) before he must kill them.The year is 1788 and the story takes place over 14 days in March. Bob is a slave on the run from a life he has tried to accept but has come to understand as a life of slow death with no hope. Cat is a hopeless, lonely mute who has only known abuse and death. Like Bob, his life has been a prison. Istillicha is a member of the Creek tribe who has been overlooked by his people and betrayed by a woman he loved who has robbed him, not only of his silver but of the trust he once had in his heart. Defiant and angry, he leaves the tribe to seek retribution with the intention of someday returning and taking what he believes is his rightful place among the tribe.As these three men find themselves thrown together, a fateful decision is made to act upon an opportunity that has presented itself, ultimately resulting in tragedy and finding themselves in the position of being hunted.As the story progresses, we learn more about each man and what came before their fateful union. We also learn a lot about LeClerc and his intentions for the men. I will stop there without spoiling this masterpiece.I haven't read anything since The Heart is a Lonely Hunter that has so affected and moved me. Though this time period and Southern location are so far out of my personal existence, there is something in each of these men that corresponds to some of the deepest places in the human soul.Reading this will make you question your own life and intentions in ways that will challenge what you one thought you believed about yourself.Recommend.

This is the second of two phone mounts by Comsun that I have had the opportunity to try out. Unlike the first one I reviewed, this one is more suited to phones with a smaller case as I don't think the bulkier defender cases would work in this holder. In a way, this holder is like a little seat you mount to your bike handle and the phone sits in it with the help of a spring-action clamp that grabs the phone on the sides as well elastic banding that goes over the phone. The main problem is not having a defender-type case on the phone during certain biking conditions could be disastrous to the phone. The bands that are used to help secure the phone work well now but the material looks like it could deteriorate with use. I would feel safer with silicone bands but that's just me.It's a nicely manufactured phone holder and it's also very handsome (as bike phone mounts go) but there are few things that need to be addressed. First, if you have the type of bike that has a straight handlebar, the side-to-side rotation (via the ball rotating mechanism) becomes obstructed because it can only turn just so much to the right or left thanks to the bar. I'm not sure what the fix is other than to extend it up a bit from the bar so that range of motion is freer. No problem adjusting up or down, though.The spring-action clamp that holds the phone doesn't seem to make contact with my phone solidly. This problem stems from the clamps being semi-circular with cut outs on the sides so your phone only makes contact with a portion of a semi-circle (see the images in the product description). The simple solution to this is to make the clamps rectangular in shape and without cut outs. Problem solved.To me this is a good, solid bike mount for smaller phones, which don't require as much adjustment as a bigger phone (like the 6 or 6 plus) would need. I don't think the iphone 6 plus would even fit in this. I tried a 6 and a 5 with minimal cases. The phone stays in the clamp until you unlock it by pushing a safety button. The 6 was a tight fit. The 5 was much better and in fact, a very good fit for this (but not with a big case). Moving on, there are absolutely no issues securing this to the handlebar. It screws on and stays put very well. This was one area that felt very stable.At the end of the day, this is a nice bike phone mount for smaller phones, with enough protection for leisure bikers. I would say that for people in a more hardcore biking environment, this isn't going to be the best choice. However, Comsun has another bike mount that is really excellent and would work with a wider range of phones. Do a quick search.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I do not automatically provide four or five star reviews when I receive a low- or no-cost item as is evidenced in my review history. I do not receive compensation for my reviews.

First, this case is sleek and very good looking. The feel of it in my hand is like silk but not slippery. This means less opportunity to have it slip out of your hand. However, if you do happen to drop your phone, this is not a very protective case. If you drop your phone and hit the corner, which seems to be ground zero for screen cracks, your phone will take the hit but not in a good way. This is what accounts for the one-star deduction on this review. But this is not specific to this case. A corner drop on most iphones will be detrimental on any case without extra corner protection, which this does not have.That aside, for people who don't like big bulky cases and tend not to use a case at all, this could work. It adds no bulk, looks elegant and minimal and protects the phone from scratches and other body issues. And a big one  it won't get in the way of charging ports on charging docks.The cut outs are perfect, very precise.  This looks like an expensive, high-end phone case but at $9.99. A steal.I like this case a lot. It's very well-made with a lot of attention to detail in the manufacturing process.If you like a minimalist look and need a case for scratch protection, this is a very good choice. It also resists fingerprints.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I do not automatically provide four or five star reviews when I receive a low- or no-cost item as is evidenced in my review history. I do not receive compensation for my reviews.

I have tried a few types of this spray. When I received the first sample, I was convinced it was a goof. Spoiler alert  this is not a goof. It's really interesting and kind of ingenious, in fact.The concept is simple. You spray the water in the toilet before, you know, and it creates a top layer (invisible) that traps any unpleasantness below the surface of the water. It really works. I am amazed.The one I received is "Santorini Breeze," which kind of smells like the boardwalk of a beach more than the breeze. It's a pleasant, not overwhelming scent.This is a small, 2-ounce bottle but it's good for 200 uses and that's certainly a good deal. This is made from natural ingredients that won't send more toxins into the environment. You can also carry this in a purse or suitcase and it will not leak thanks to the leak proof gasket technology in the cap.Perfect for a stocking stuffer goof. Or not. Or as part of the toiletries in the guest bathroom. Or when sharing a hotel room. Or at the office. I could go on but you get the gist.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. Okay, up front I have to say I love this little gadget. I've been thinking of upgrading my car stereo (it's not the most up to date, let's just say) because I wanted Bluetooth compatibility and to be able to play the content from my iphone. Now I can. And I am very happy by how this device works.It's really the simplest thing as all you need to do is pair the transmitter via Bluetooth to your phone and then set your transmitter to an FM station that corresponds to the number on your car stereo  it worked on a number of different frequencies in my car. Like magic, what's on your phone comes out of your car stereo. In stereo.I made a few test phone calls and that worked really well  no hissing noises or interference. And the transmitter automatically switches to phone mode so you don't have to compete with the caller and your stereo blaring in the background.This is also very pretty. I have the rose-colored transmitter. It fits right into the power outlet in the car and then you can rotate the face of it to whatever position you need the transmitter to be in to operate. On the stem of this is a USB port so that you can also charge your phone while using the transmitter. Charging was equivalent to any other standard car charger so I didn't notice anything strange unusual there.  It also supports use of a TF card but I've never used TF cards so I cannot speak to that functionality, specifically.There is a microphone on the face of the device as well as a knob for adjusting the frequency and volume buttons. The lights are a pretty blue that match the blue lights in my car at night. But the lights are high contrast and very visible even in sunlight. That is fantastic.Overall, this is an excellent transmitter that worked with my iphone with little to no effort. I'm very, very happy with this. Excellent price, too ($19.99 at the time of this review).Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. I do not automatically provide four- or five-star reviews when I receive a low- or no-cost item as is evidenced in my review history. I do not receive compensation for my reviews.

Anyone who rides a bike has a big old protective case on their phone. That's a given. If you're going to use your phone or phone GPS while riding, it's best to have a bike mount that can accommodate a phone with a big protective case on it. This one is really interesting because it's small but it has a rubber frame around it that stretches out to fit the frame of the phone and whatever case you have on the phone. It really accommodates all sizes of phone cases.The handlebar mount has rotating ball on the underside of the mount and can be adjusted to fit different bike bar sizes. So if you have more than one type of bike, you can easily switch this from one to the other. The rotation is nice and smooth and doesn't move once you rotate the phone to where you want it.In addition to the rubber frame, there is a spring-loaded clip (like the kind you would use on a dashboard) that adjusts to fit the width of the phone while the rubber holds it in place on the corners. This phone isn't going anywhere. It's protected all around.Recommend.I received a free or low-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion. This is a nice, raspberry-colored iphone 6 folio case. Its faux leather but it has a nice pebbled look and the inside cover has card slots for your cards, money, etc. Its best not to overstuff these as the magnetic closure isnt very strong. Also, theres a lanyard, plastic screen protector (not tempered glass), raspberry-colored stylus and cleaning cloth.The cutouts on this are nice and dont obstruct the camera or any of the button functions. I do find that folios are more protective, in general, than open-faced cases if you drop your phone. I just wish the magnet closure was stronger and didnt open up so easily.Very nice.I received a low- or no-cost sample in exchange for my honest opinion.
