UPDATE: I've continued to test the accuracy of this scale against the EatSmart and just now found a good 15.0 pound reference weight that I could easily put on the platforms. So, which scale is more accurate? The answer is neither, not really. The Smart Weight reads 14.8 pounds, while the EatSmart reads 15.2. Plus/minus 1 percent is still excellent, but if you're using the Smart Weight, adjust your weight up by 1 percent to get your true weight.ORIGINAL REVIEW:If you want to add a touch of dazzling elegance to your bathroom, this scale is a real tour de force. The manufacturer was kind enough to provide me with a silver unit for review, and it makes my treasured EatSmart scale look clunky in comparison. The pictures of the Smart Weigh scale simply don't do it justice. It has a very slim profile and sits significantly lower than the EatSmart. The platform is also somewhat larger than the EatSmart, by about 0.75 inches per side. This doesn't sound like much, but the difference actually makes the Smart Weigh scale much easier to stand on to get a stable reading.Operating the scale is simple. Put in the batteries, zero it out by tapping on the scale, and then stand on it long enough for the scale to take a reading. The first time you do this, your weight is stored in memory and used for future comparisons. Future readings flash in green if your weight goes down and red if it goes up. Getting a good benchmark reading (e.g., first thing in the morning) is pretty important, since that's what your weight is judged against. I had no trouble making this system work.Add a second or third person, and the scale figures it out, up to eight people. My companion tested it along with me, and the scale correctly tagged her weight. But she wasn't happy with the red light.Prefer metric over English? A push button on the underside of the scale lets you change. It appears to adjust the memory reading accordingly. It also will weigh you in stones, if need be.The weight readings are very stable from one reading to the next. The weighing mechanism doesn't introduce random fluctuations. My own weight readings were consistently 1.2 pounds less (-0.6%) of my EatSmart readings. If I can get a good reference weigh, I will report further on  which of the two is most accurate. Since the readings over time are consistent, however, this is an excellent scale for tracking weight gain and loss.When I agreed to review this scale, I didn't really think I needed anything other than the EatSmart. The Smart Weigh persuaded me otherwise. It's easy to use and beautiful to look at.UPDATE (3/31): I've found that it's relatively easy to set up one's self as a second user profile by accident. This can lead to confusing displays, so don't throw away the instructions. They're needed to delete one or all profiles. I deleted everything. This corrected the display. I also found that the difference between this scale and my EatSmart dropped to 0.6 pounds. More updates on accuracy and consistency later.NOTE: if you buy this scale, make sure you receive the cover to the battery compartment. Mine came without one, causing some difficulty in day to day operation.

Boring and cliched with cutouts for characters and rehashed plot lines stolen from The Hunger Games. Not even some decent supporting actors can save this turkey. For juveniles only, who may be much more appreciative of a post-apocalyptic future where teenagers save the day.

I used this drill with brush attachments to facilitate stripping the wax from linoleum floors in an apartment. I honestly expected the drill to be underpowered, but the speed and torque was excellent for some very heavy duty work. I had also half expected the drill to give out completely under the stress, but it chugged through everything. Paying someone to do the same job would have cost twice what the drill ran.I also used it to put together some shelves, but that was gravy. This was a great purchase, and I'm very pleased.

I've been using this brush to help strip floor wax from linoleum. It does a generally excellent job on normal wax. It's not quite abrasive enough for tougher areas; I didn't expect it to be and got a different brush for that. So far the brush has held up very well in stripping the linoleum in a large apartment, and I would not hesitate to buy it again

I used this to strip scum and wax off especially soiled areas of linoleum and bathtub porcelain. It did a pretty good job while it lasted, but it only lasted through portions of two small baths and an entry hall. Then the bristles started giving out. If it had lasted longer, I would have given it five stars. However, I will not hesitate to order another one in due course.
This s was a pretty nice cap at first, especially for someone who is bald. After six weeks and one washing, the elastic gave way completely. It now fits so loosely as to be useless.

It took four weeks for this to arrive from China. It's a fairly sturdy wristlets that looks good. Even better, it sounds great, making a very resonant jingling sound that travels easily. I plan on getting several more. I have a big white beard and already look like Santa. Now I can sound like him, too.One cautionary note: the size is just barely adequate for an adult American make wrist. It should probably be fine for most women and children, but if you have an above average wrist size, it might not fit.The only downside that I've found to these bells is that the cat can hear me coming and runs and hides from the sound. But she'll get used to it. She always does.

I took one look at these "towels" and wanted to return them. They're much too small to be very useful. However, it wasn't worth returning them, and then I discovered that I could use them as hankies or napkins. This helped me salvage the buy, which is why I gave them two stars. But I still had to buy a real set of dish towels afterward.

I will be throwing this hat out. It is sized for a child, not an adult. The fabric and overall construction is very poor. The color is nowhere close to that pictured and is a shade of green that is pretty disgusting. Given the high ratings from other reviewers, I can only assume that the manufacturer or third-party vendors seeded the reviews with misleading hype. Don't buy this.

t the ago of 67, I grew a very full beard which was gray-white. In late November, I realized how close I was to being a dead ringer for Santa, so I bought Manic Panic to complete the picture. Everything above the neckline was treated, including my eyebrows. I let the first coat set for 90 minutes, rinsed it, then touched things up with a second cost. The eyebrows took three coats, being somewhat darker.The result was a snowy white Santa beard. Little children now smile broadly when they see me at Food Lion. Even my 25 yo son and elderly friends call me Santa. My companion insists that I accompany everything with my red pants, reindeer sweater, and red fedora.One warning: there was a fair amount of skin irritation on my face, but it subsided after a day. The scalp was much less affected.After a month, there was some yellowing. A hairdresser friend assured me that this was normal and recommending  bluing agent like Shimmering Lights to restore the whiteness. That seems to work. After about six months, I will repeat the bleaching to prepare for next Christmas

Lynnette asked me to review her book, and I accepted. I also explained that I'm not a good reviewer for this kind of book. I flew around the world for decades on business. People like me think we know everything, and often we do. But the stories we would tell would scare the bejesus out of a first-time traveler. Not a good idea.And to be sure, the book has some unexpected nuggets of wisdom, like the need to wear compression socks to avoid vascular problems on long flights. This surprised me, since I've never known anyone to suffer such problems, but the CDC does in fact have a substantial write-up on this. Herein lies the main value of the book: conveying tidbits of valuable information that may be just what you need to avoid flying disasters. These tidbits will be different for everyone. Just one may save you a THOUSAND times the cost of this book.The book is sensibly organized into the following sections:Buying the Ticket11 Things To Know About FlyingSeveral Weeks BeforeThe Week BeforeThe Day BeforeParkingThe AirportTSABoardingFlyingLost Bags and Item TheftPacking ListThe treatment is generally light-hearted and humorous. However, the book is meant to convey information, and information tends to be dry and generic. I think Lynette might, in a second edition, do a bit more to characterize the information with personal anecdotes from her own experience. We remember facts better when they come in the form of stories, and stories help to maintain a humorous tone.Although the book is intended as a reference, it has one flaw in this respect: there are few links to further information. Many people will want to drill down to more details on specific problems, so links and footnoting help in any reference guide.While the book is directed at first-time flyers, I'm not sure how many such people are still out there, at least of the people who would be buying this book. However, there are many of us who may be experienced traveling by ourselves but who find that we must escort others who are inexperienced, or where the situations simply go outside our experience.I would include in this group adults traveling with children and adults escorting senior citizens (who may be attuned more to the 1970's than the 2010's). Addressing the needs of such travelers in specific sections of the book would improve its value. There's plenty of room in this book for expansion.It is also true that air travel is increasingly used by people who have special considerations and need special treatment. To name a few: parents with autistic children, vets experiencing serious PTSD symptoms, seniors with dementia, people who have mobility problems requiring the use of wheelchairs or prosthetics, etc. Perhaps such special needs populations can be covered in later editions. We owe it to everyone to make travel as accessible as possible.One value of a first edition can be that it opens a conversation between Lynnette and her audience on both special considerations as well as tips she might not have thought of. A blog, for instance, would be a good way to do this (and it works much better than Amazon reviews in this respect). I've already conveyed some things privately. They're the sorts of things that would make many people blush, but they involve the real concerns of real people. When Lynn addresses in greater detail the things we are too scared to ask about, then we will have a winner.My rating is four stars at this moment because I can see a multitude of ways to improve what is a fine beginning. It's a beginning, though. If this beginning initiates an open process that extends and refines the material, and makes it more personalized and accessible, then that fifth star will be added.By the way, I now loathe air travel and have avoided it for the last 12 years. Planes have become uncomfortable cattlecars, and the TSA has conspired to make the experience at the terminal about as miserable as possible. If you want to enjoy traveling, take the train. It's more fun. If you just can't avoid flying, buy this book. $2.99 is cheap if it reduces the misery of air travel even a bit.

This product is a nootropic, that is, it helps with cognitive and memory functions. Each capsule contains 300 mg of alpha-GPC and 100 mg of phosphatidylserine (PS). The manufacturer recommends two capsules a day before 4 p.m.; that's pretty standard for all alpha-GPC products, and over the last four years I've tried most of the major ones. The manufacturer also says you might be able to go up to six capsules a day; that's on the high side although I've seen (and tried) recommendations to use four per day for the first month.I started buying this formulation from Amazon on a subscription basis because that's the most economical way for me to get alpha-GPC, which is pretty generic. Does this particular formulation work? To cut to the chase, yes. Explaining how it works and what more you might do requires much more explanation, though.Alpha-GPC is the real thing in that it definitely boosts those parts of the brain involving memory and cognition although you are most likely to notice the effects during activities like mindfulness meditation or intense focus on work tasks. On the bottle, Doctor's Best also claims that their product may help with stress and facilitate "growth factor action"; these are dubious claims that unnecessarily gild the lily (and also ignore that fact that too much alpha-GPC may make stress worse).I tend to classify my experience in the following way when it comes to nootropics:1. Acetylcholine (ACh) enhancers. Doctor's Best Natural Brain Enhancers, and Alpha-GPC in general, falls into this class of nootropics. ACh is a key neurotransmitter that can facilitate both memory and cognition. Alpha-GPC gives a sharp boost to ACh, much more than something like choline bitarate. Much of the research into palliatives for dementia and Alzheimer's focus on this line of inquiry. I settled long ago on a strategy that uses anti-cholinesterase agents to maintain ACh levels combined with choline-related supplements to also boost those levels. Combining Huperzine-A and alpha-GPC (or Doctor's Best) is one example of such a combination. Donepezil is an effective substitute for Huperzine but available only by prescription.2. Hippocampal supplements. Magnesium l-threonate may (according to research) help significantly with the long-term memory functions of the hippocampus. I've used it but find it still pretty pricey. Zinc might also help here but can rapidly cause cramping if you aren't careful.3.  Vasodillators. Some vasodillators that act on the brain are showing a lot of promise as well with memory and cognition, and they have the virtue of complementing rather than conflicting with the ACh enhancers. A good example of a vasodillator is vinpocetane although use early in the day may cause nausea. Ginkgo biloba is purportedly helpful in this respect, but the research evidence is mixed.Amazon carries products in all of these classes, and if you're serious about cognitive and memory enhancement, you might find it worthwhile to try products in each class (many of which are available by subscription).As an aside to my above points, I should explain that I don't really care about the PS in the Doctor's Best formulation and doubt that it has much value (for me, anyway). The FDA has reviewed the available research and concluded that there is no scientific basis to believe that PS helps with cognition and memory for the general population (although it may have more specialized uses in sports nutrition and with ADHD). I agree with the FDA.Both memory and cognition benefit the most from these supplements when we're taking steps to exercise both. The brain is similar to a muscle in that respect. You wouldn't expect to become a great runner watching daytime TV. And your cognitive and memory functions aren't going to benefit much from that either.Which brain exercises work the best is very individual. For my part, I complement my use of nootropics with meditative exercises based loosely on Buddhist practices. I also use psychoacoustic soundtracks in the gamma and theta ranges. More recently I've begun experimenting with the MindPlace Procyon mind machine.One warning with nootropics, at least those involving ACh: they can lead to agitation, irritability, and insomnia if you overuse them or take them late in the day. Diphenhydramine (Benadryl) will counteract this up to a point, since it has anti-cholinergic properties. Ultimately, though, you may just have to wait it out.

I had no idea if this eyepiece would work out on my D7000, but it was cheap enough that I thought I would give it a try. By now, I've used it for about 2,000 shots and am presently inclined to go back to the standard Nikon eyepiece. While there are other similar eyepieces on the market, I suspect that they have the same design problems as this one, plus they cost more.This eyepiece does in fact provide nice coverage around the eye that can help to reduce extraneous light. The rubber portion pivots fairly easily around a plastic bracket so that you can adjust the eyepiece for either the left or right eye.However, the bracket is not very secure. I've had it fall off at odd moments, causing me to retrace my steps to find it. My use of a wrist strap probably makes this problem worse for me than it might be some some people.The biggest problem for serious shooters, however, is that this eyepiece, and probably all others like it, have a tendency to obscure part of the frame. I like to know exactly what is in my frame, and I like to know it fast. This eyepiece slows me down. I can work my eye around to doublecheck the framing, but this is slow and imprecise.So there are trade offs with this accessory. They might be worth accepting to some people, but anyone committed to careful framing will find this deal worth foregoing.

With this costing me under $4, I was sure this was going to be a waste of time and money. I was pleasantly surprised to find that this is genuinely a bargain, fairly well made and a lot more handy than the standard neck strap. I put it on a Nikon D7000 and liked it so much that I bought a second one for a D200.The strap screws to the tripod mount on the bottom of the camera. The connection at this end is very secure. It is necessary to unscrew the strap to get access to the battery, but this operation is much less laborious than I expected. The top part of the strap passes through the eyelet on the side of the camera. I thought it might have a tendency to come loose or part company entirely with the eyelet, but after 2,000 shots and no problems, I have a lot more confidence in the strap.In point of fact, this strap makes it much easier to move around in framing shots, since I can easily hold the camera securely with one hand. No more chest banging from trying to use a neck strap.Construction is fairly sound. I had expected the stitching to be coming loose by now, but it hasn't. It also takes up minimal space. I can still get the D7000 into a Case Logic holster without difficulty. And of course, the strap has a certain cool factor, since people even more amateur than me look at the strap and conclude that I must know what I'm doing. All this, and for less than $4.

Like many other bargain hunters, my immediate response to the D7100's release was to buy a deeply discounted D7000. Then I searched for something to complement the user's manual. Based on the many glowing reviews, I thought that this was the ideal complement. I was wrong.This book's strength is in the professional advice it provides on menu setup and use of the camera controls. That goes beyond Nikon's user manual and is welcome. However, the advice often drifts into chattiness that becomes overly familiar and distracting. The author also attempts what become inane excursions into the deep Nikon past with references to what "your grandpa" might or might not have thought The only point seems to be to display the author's long experience with Nikon.The book is also strong in its discussion of the various menu options, but in fact the book does little more in this area than Nikon's user manual, and I can download the Nikon manual into iBooks for $0.Where this book is very weak is in its organization and prioritization of topics. Fully the first 60 percent of the book is on the camera's menuing system. Rather than highlighting those areas likely to be important to a shooter, and leaving the less important topics for later discussion, the author just marches relentlessly through each menu option in sequence, one right after the other, whether or not the menu option has any importance to the majority of shooters.This approach creates anomalies that were frustrating to me in my efforts to take the camera out and start shooting. For instance, there is no section early on that discusses what the various control dials, knobs, and buttons do. The author does eventually have a chapter on the exposure mode dial, but this is in the second half of the book and after an exhaustive discussion of the retouching menu. Since when did post-production come before shooting?There are other examples of such anomalies. For instance, if I want to learn the proper use of the bracketing button, I have to delve deeply into that part of the book that discusses bracketing menu options. The book basically tends to subordinate a discussion of camera controls, and actual shooting operations, to its preoccupation with menus. It has the look of a hurried rehash of the user manual to get something out on the street for enthusiastic users.  It is not a book you will want to live with for very long, though.If you are willing to be patient and search throughout the book for the information you need, then you will eventually find it in this volume. On the Kindle version at least, the table of contents and index won't be as helpful as you might think, so you may have to spend some time searching. If you want something that places an emphasis on getting you out there and shooting, then you are better off looking elsewhere.

Mom used to drag me to John Bitch Society meetings when I was a kid and all it did was persuade me that conservatives had jumped off the high board without their trunks and no water in the pool.I would buy these shoes in a heartbeat for my girlfriend's next filibuster at the Legion of Mary, but I already gave my money to Wendy's Moveon pledge campaign. Winning campaigns need money. It's a good cause.BTW, the couple of people who are voting against these reviews supportive of Wendy Davis really ought to get a life. Don't you have anything better to do than to snipe and try to put women down?

I'm not exactly a Sinatra wannabe. That would be my father. Still. I really liked Sinatra and remember his movies and music with great fondness. I recently started buying hats suitable for dressier occasions. My Stacy Adams homburg is a little too dressy, however, so I began looking at trilbys.If you don't already know, trilbys are sort of crushable fedoras but with a lower crown and a narrower brim snapped down in the front but up in the back. They became popular for the wealthier crowd at British race tracks (and possibly the seedier crowd at American ones). Their popularity peaked around 1960 and has declined since. I think hats are coming back into style. We'll see.I'm generally pleased with this trilby and would rate it at 4.5 stars for quality, five for value. The Sinatra brand has turned out to be better than I expected with respect to materials, design, and construction. I rated my homburg at only four stars.Here are some more detailed notes:1. Value. I paid about $55 with shipping. That's a bargain for a well-made, lined fedora-type hat.2. Material. My homburg is made of hard wool felt that has a somewhat rough texture. This hat is made of soft wool felt with a finer feel to it. While rabbit hair felt is the traditional material for a trilby, I have hats of this material and would be hard pressed to pick that as any better than this. I can't really tell the difference.3. Lining and finishing. The lining is very nicely done and has a luxuriant look. The band appears to be grosgrain. The sweatband is ample and very supple leather.4. Construction. The stitching and boxing of the hat are very sound. I can find nothing to fault.5. Sizing. I wear a medium. The sizing was exact.6. Style. The styling is correct for a trilby. Although gray would certainly be very stylish, I chose black. The orange trim referred to in the description is on the inside lining. FYI, brown trilbys were the tradition for the British crowd. Because of the narrow brim, the hat appears smaller than I had expected and it will take some adjusting to get the clothing combinations right.7. NOTE ON THE BRIM: a trilby must be worn with the brim snapped down in front. For shipping, this hat arrived with the front brim up. Snap it down to get the proper look.I bought this through Headchange on Amazon Marketplace. This company deserves a special note of appreciation. They changed an order slightly to meet my specifications, got the hat to me ahead of the delivery window, gave me a promo code for future purchases, and packed the hat more securely than others I received. These people are serious about doing business.

I bought this for a friend for Valentine's Day. It didn't cost much more than a card, and it will last a lot longer and give her pleasant memories.The toy is cute, cuddly, well-made, and guaranteed to drive cat lovers nuts. It also comes close to matching at least the coloration of one of her cats, if not it's cactus disposition. It may be a toy, but 55 yo ladies also like these.

I bought this partly because my pink Himalayan sea salt, while fine for cooking, has a tendency to coat my fingers when I pinch it to spread on food. Salt flakes sounded like a better idea.I was right. These salt flakes are more coarse, perhaps a bit larger than sesame seeds but certainly not on the level of corn flakes. They taste fine, have a very nice texture while pinching, and give a delightful crunch when chewed. It's tough to argue with all this.The container has a certain dclass air about it and would be right at home in a French bistro, so you might not feel a need to get a salt box. One would be advisable anyway, just in case, since box can't easily be used as a dispenser once it starts to empty out significantly.

I bought this on a whim as table salt for the odd occasion. The label on the jar advises that this product is good for sushi, fish, grilled chicken, and steak. The salt itself is very tasty, a bit less sharp than my pink Himalayan sea salt. I think the black lava helps to moderate the flavor. It may also scare the bejesus out of the kids but impress guests with your gourmet sensibilities.In general you should consider getting a salt box, but that isn't necessary in this case. The small plastic jar is very presentable and nicely placed on all but the fanciest tables. And unless everyone at the table knows exactly what it what, the label will help to identify this is salt. Your guests will probably appreciate the coaching.The grind, by the way, is neither fine nor very fine. It is somewhat coarser but much less so than rock salt. Black sesame seeds would be of comparable size.

If you've found yourself looking at homburgs, then you may fancy yourself to be Al Pacino in The Godfather. I may be the exception to this rule. I needed a formal hat to wear to Mass with a black suit and a black overcoat. Homburgs were once very popular for this type of purpose, at least until the 1960's. Churchill used to wear one. So did Eisenhower at his 1952 inauguration.I'm generally pleased with this homburg and would rate it at about four stars for quality, five for value. Stacy Adams is a good general brand, but I own other hats of greater quality with respect to materials, design, and construction. Here are some more detailed notes:1. Value. I've seen this hat listed at $120 and sold on the Internet for $96. $50-60 is more typical. I paid $36 with shipping. That's a bargain.2. Material. A homburg, like the bowler, is traditionally made of hard felt. This model is indeed of hard wool felt. The texture is a bit on the rough side, as anyone who has handled fur felt would realize if they picked up this hat.3. Lining and finishing. The lining is decent enough but nothing luxurious. The band is indeed grosgrain. The sweatband is thin leather.4. Construction. The stitching and boxing of the hat are sound although I think the lining on the brims could have been more finely stitched.5. Sizing. I wear a medium. The sizing was exact.6. Style. The styling is correct for a homburg. Although black has tended to be the favorite color since 1960, I chose gray with a black band as the more stylish choice.This hat is more than you need for a costume party and pretty good for most occasions. Only very discerning onlookers will be able to tell that it was inexpensive. For Mass, weddings, and the like, it is very workable.

I've been wavering between giving these four or five stars. In the end, anything less than five would be plain unfair. These are well-engineered and constructed tuning mechanisms that were easy to install on my Takemine acoustic electric. The operation is smooth and precise but takes some practice.Some further details may be helpful to anyone seriously interested in using these:1. Installation. You will need a 1/2 inch head on a socket wrench and a small Philips screwdriver. I thought I was going to be using a micro driver, but the amount of torque required made something bigger a necessity. Replacing the existing Takemine mechanisms didn't take more than 15 minutes. The Planet Waves ones simply slid into the existing holes. Even the screw holes lined up.2. Stringing. These mechanisms are designed with a screw clamp for the strings. Line the marking on each peg to face the bridge, nest the string with some degree of slack (for winding), tighten the thumbscrew, and tune. The mechanism snips off the excess string within half a turn of the peg.3. Operation. The 18:1 gearing makes the tuning very smooth, precise and stable. It really puts the standard Takemine pegs to shame (at least on the less expensive lines).4. Build quality. Very high. These are very solidly built pegs with a brilliant chrome finish.Would I buy these again? Absolutely. Do they improve the tuning? Yes! Would I put them on other types of guitars? Well, I'm considering retrofitting a Stratocaster with PW's 6 in line model. Amazon has these at a fairly economical price for this kind of quality, and I had every reason to think these mechanisms will outlive the guitar.

This is a pretty good supplement for facilitating long-term memory, but it is by no means a silver billet. As with others here, I've been interested in l-threonate because of the studies showing promise in the use of this supplement to improve memory, which it does by crossing the blood-brain barrier and boosting levels of magnesium in the hippocampus. Other forms of magnesium can't do this.I've used so-called nootropics for the past three years to enhance memory and cognition. The effects are real and can sometimes be profound.  My efforts have  involved a lot of experimentation that eventually led me to use a strategy comprising a number of elements:1. Hippocampal supplements. Both zinc and magnesium l-threonate can help significantly with the long-term memory functions of the hippocampus. I take both. The latter is still pretty pricey, as those buying the Jarrow formulation clearly know. You'll probably find the effects of these supplements to be fairly subtle. Memory, in particular, benefits from being used. You may get the best results if you also use standard memory exercises. Pills don't do everything all by themselves.2.  Acetylcholine enhancers. ACh is a key neurotransmitter that can facilitate both memory and cognition. Much of the research into palliatives for dementia and Alzheimer's focus on this line of inquiry. I settled long ago on a strategy that uses anti-cholinesterase agents to maintain ACh levels combined with choline-related supplements to also boost those levels. Combining Huperzine-A and alpha-GPC is one example of such a combination. Donepezil is an effective substitute for Huperzine but available only by prescription. And now it's clear to me that DMAE is an effective substitute for alpha-GPC. Its effects are a bit more mild, though, which is just as well--alpha-GPC can spike ACh levels and cause anxiety and insomnia.3.  Vasodillators. Some vasodillators that act on the brain are showing a lot of promise as well with memory and cognition, and they have the virtue of complementing rather than conflicting with the ACh enhancers. Two good examples are ginkgo biloba and vinpocetane. I've had very good results with both. The ginkgo biloba works better earlier in the day, since the vinpocetane can sometimes lead to nausea.There are other things you can do as well. At the very least, though, DMAE would be a modest and economical beginning. Since Amazon also offers Source Naturals Huperzine-A at a reasonable price, you might consider that as a second and complementary supplement. L-threonate would not be my primary approach but I find it useful as a way to support the other things.Source Naturals also produces this supplement as Magtein. In the past, Amazon has been pretty aggressive in its pricing of SN products. For this reason, I am monitoring the SN Magtein offering in hopes of finding a better deal.

I'm finding this to be a very good alternative to supplements like alpha-GPC, which are typically much more expensive and also more difficult to integrate into an overall strategy for enhancing memory and cognition. I've used so-called nootropics for the past three years. That's involved a lot of experimentation that eventually led me to use a strategy comprising a number of elements:1. Acetylcholine enhancers. ACh is a key neurotransmitter that can facilitate both memory and cognition. Much of the research into palliatives for dementia and Alzheimer's focus on this line of inquiry. I settled long ago on a strategy that uses anti-cholinesterase agents to maintain ACh levels combined with choline-related supplements to also boost those levels. Combining Huperzine-A and alpha-GPC is one example of such a combination. Donepezil is an effective substitute for Huperzine but available only by prescription. And now it's clear to me that DMAE is an effective substitute for alpha-GPC. Its effects are a bit more mild, though, which is just as well--alpha-GPC can spike ACh levels and cause anxiety and insomnia.2. Vasodillators. Some vasodillators that act on the brain are showing a lot of promise as well with memory and cognition, and they have the virtue of complementing rather than conflicting with the ACh enhancers. Two good examples are ginkgo biloba and vinpocetane. I've had very good results with both. The ginkgo biloba works better earlier in the day, since the vinpocetane can sometimes lead to nausea.3. Hippocampal supplements. If you delve into the neurophysical research, you'll find that both zinc and magnesium l-threonate can help significantly with the long-term memory functions of the hippocampus. I take both. The latter is still pretty pricey. You'll probably find the effects of these supplements to be fairly subtle. Memory, in particular, benefits from being used. You may get the best results if you also use standard memory exercises. Pills don't do everything all by themselves.There are other things you can do as well. At the very least, though, DMAE would be a modest and economical beginning. Since Amazon also offers Source Naturals Huperzine-A at a reasonable price, you might consider that as a second and complementary supplement.By the way, standard diphenhydramine is a good remedy for choline levels that have gone a bit too high. If you find that you're becoming too edgy taking these supplements, back off on the dose and take some Benadryl. And of course, if things become more interesting, best to check with your doctor.

It's hard to know quite what to say about a clear piece of plastic that is supposed to protect my phone's screen, since I haven't actually broken my phone's screen while I've had this on. Maybe it's working. If Corning had created their initial version of Gorilla Glass as well as advertised, I wouldn't think a protector was needed at all, but the new version of Gorilla Glass suggests maybe protectors make some sense after all.The shipping was fast on this. It cost very little. Installation was easy, the highly negative reviews notwithstanding. I had no trouble with fit, glue balls, etc. I honestly don't know what these other people are talking about. Maybe the manufacturer made some adjustments.If you aren't hard on your phone, you may not really need this. The problem is finding out that you really do. I was willing to spend $2 for a little insurance.

After months of diligently crushing peppercorns with my mortar and pestle, it dawned on me that there might be alternatives. No, I don't mean the chrome-plated froo-froo inner party grinders we once dreamed of. I meant a real production grinder, but preferably hand-powered. I'm not planning on feeding the Armed Forces.This is a step in that direction. For the price, it's a terrific addition to my kitchen. And the elongated handle with a solid grip makes it a much more efficient way to grind pepper than the more typical twist grinders.This grinder is not an absolutely great grinder for a couple of reasons. The peppercorn tray, for instance, cannot be removed and filled as a bin. This means that filling the grinder can be a bit awkward. I usually spill a number of peppercorns. The plastic part holding the peppercorns in can in fact be removed, but not as a container, just for cleaning.In addition, the fine/coarse grind selector, while helpful, is not engineered up to Oxo's usual standards. I find it a bit loose and inaccurate so far as getting the grind right.Last, the grinder has a snap-on plastic bottom cap to keep the ground pepper fragments in. I'm not sure I see a good way around this design, but it still feels less elegant than Oxo's usual fare.But none of this really detracts in the end from the fact that this is a very nice utensil. I would definitely make this purchase again. And with luck, Oxo's version 2.0 will be even better.

It's fun to be a food snob. It's even more fun to be a cheap food snob and to amaze your friends and family with your apparent gourmet sensibilities while spending next to nothing. Salt is tailor made for this role.As anyone who has read Mark Kurlansky's history of salt knows, salt is all over the place. You don't actually have to rely on sending your neighbor to the salt mines, either, although that is certainly a time-honored tradition. The price of salt is largely a function of transportation, packaging, and how much either merchants or the government can get away with through taxes or marketing.This is pretty good salt. I'm not giving it the highest rating because the salt is too finely ground to be as convenient as I would like. Spooning it out for cooking is ok, but pinching it for a dish means coating my fingers with salt. And you have to use a salt box. A shaker, which is decidedly gauche anyway, will just drizzle this salt out no end. As is typical with sea salt, a little goes a lot further than typical table salt, which is more granular but not as sharp in taste.Since the salt is pink, it has impurities. Sorry. They're harmless. People lusted after white salt for millennia to avoid this, and now we pay extra. Go figure. I plan on buying black Hawaiian salt next. The confusion at the dinner table will be priceless. Also, I'm pretty sure this salt isn't iodized. If you aren't taking a multivitamin, you might reconsider. I hear gout isn't fun.I originally bought a one pound pack of this, figuring I was a single person and how fast could it go? That was a mistake. It was smaller and goes faster than I thought. It's two pounds next time. Otherwise, good luck. I hope the meals come out well.

This case has honestly worked out better for my HTC One V phone than I really expected. I started looking at it originally because the JKase cases everyone seemed to be buying were a combination of overpriced and out of stock. So I got this instead.I had three major objectives in buying this case: spend as little as possible, be unobtrusive, and protect the phone. This case accomplishes those objectives. It is an entirely dull piece of molded gel that has holes in the right places. It feels nice, with a pleasant nonslip grip. I haven't trying testing it by dropping the phone, but the skin is thick enough to protect the phone from waist high drops. Shipping is fast. It must be working well in general because I don't notice it.Would I buy this again? Yes. Is it a style statement? I hope not. Are there better forms of protection? Probably, but the phone didn't cost enough to justify them. The only thing I regret is that I forget to tell my girlfriend to get one for her phone. Oh well.

I've tried just about everything to compensate for the fact that I lost a small part of my left index fingertip 40 years ago. It makes pressing down on top of a guitar string more difficult. Cutting tips off dishwashing gloves hasn't worked. The rubber tips for sewing or sorting paper don't work. These are the closest I've been able to come to a really good solution.These tips are thicker at the ends and thinner on the sides. This gives them a surprisingly good feel. They are pretty snug, so there's no slipping. I have a much better feel for the strings through the rubber than I had expected. They basically make it a lot easier to play the guitar and open up things like fretboard fingering that I had avoided previously.I am a guy who usually wears large gloves. This particular size worked just right for me, but I urge you to check the sizing chart on the Gorilla Tips web site. That way you can make sure.In the old days,  would have given these five stars. I'm cutting back on that rating. For five stars, these tips would practically have had to grow me a new fingertip. They didn't do that. But they definitely really good, and for me they were worth the money.

I bought this hat six years ago. It wasn't from Amazon but another company whose name rhymes with bats in the belfry. That would be neither here nor there, but you can save a little money, about 20 percent, if you go to this other vendor (I just checked).Anyway, I wore this hat for 3-4 years, then stopped, then started wearing it again. Just today, as a matter of fact. First thing I walk out the apartment door and Rose spots the hat and tells me how wonderful it is and how much better it looks than all my other hats. Rose is 93. She used to be a professional ballroom dancer and probably dated the real Indiana Jones. And she's a lot sharper than people I know half her age.Rose is from an era and the era has spoken. This hat is definitely one to get if you want a classy fedora. Beng able to showboat like Indy also helps, but remember that Harrison Ford exercised a lot of style sense when he got the original from a London hatter 30 years ago. The hat is great regardless of the movie.If you're an astute shopper, you probably realize that there are much cheaper Indy-style hats that can be purchased.Why not? There aren't overwhelmingly strong reasons to spend the additional money on this hat, but I can tell you why it costs more.First, the name Indiana Jones has been licensed, which gives you a little more assurance that the hat is modeled exactly on the movie.Also, the hat is made of fur pelt. This is nowhere near as pricey as beaver pelt (and honestly, you should leave the beavers alone), but it is definitely more expensive than wool-based felt or canvas safari hats. The fur in my opinion looks good and wears very well, but I would be hard pressed to justify the additional cost over good wool.Last, the hat is lined. This really does make a difference in how the hat feels to me, since it seems a bit cooler with less heat build-up. It also makes a big difference in how the hat looks although only the hat check girl will know that you really are a gentleman and not a bum.If you are into fine hats, then this really is one worth having. I think so. Rose agrees.

There's just no way I'm going to give five stars to a piece of rubber. That's what this is. It doesn't even look quite as good as the picture, largely because the guitar picks laying on the top help a lot to dress it up. Without those picks, it's just black molded flab.The damnable thing is that this flab is actually quite useful. I bought this on a whim and cringed when I opened up the box. But for the last two weeks, it's been propping my Takemine up against a coffee table. The rubber is thick enough and non-skid enough that it keeps the guitar in place. Effortlessly. It may not be much to look at, but it works really well.The top portion that rests on a table surface is about 1/4 inch think. There's a nub in the front hat pushes up against the corner of he surface and fixes the rest in place. That's about 5/8 inch thick. The cost of materials is probably not more than 50 cents, but it's the design that sells this thing.If you can find this for less at a local shop, go for it.  I paid Amazon $6. Even at that, I consider it a good buy.

Having written more than my share of five-star reviews, I think I should explain up front why you should take five-star reviews with a grain of salt, but why I'm giving these strings five stars anyway.Amazon reviewers typically fall into three classes, the wildly enthusiastic, the downright nasty, and the largely indifferent souls who wrote a review only because Amazon sent so many nagging emails about writing reviews. I've been guilty of all three things. If you read my previous reviews, please keep that in mind.You should also realize that many of the people who get the cute little badges about being top reviewers have often (but not always) stacked the deck by shamelessly going after votes (the techniques for this are endless). Some also write reviews so incessantly for products no one really cares about that Amazon bumps them up in the ratings. It's pretty tawdry, especially considering that no one I know even cares.You should buy these strings because of the G string. That's the third string up, including when you're doing open-G tuning, which is what you should be using if you're playing blues. The reason this G string is better, not worse, is because it's NOT wound. Other reviewers have complained that this makes it a bit harder to keep in tune. Pfftt! If you play blues, then you need to buy a fretboard map and learn fingering notes and scales. A lot of guitarists stop with chords. That's a big mistake. Fingering and scales are what give us riffs, and a wound G string (no lewd jokes here!) doesn't work as well for the sliding and fingering involved.Anyway, an unwound G string is standard rock style. This is just how the program goes.These strings are bronze, sort of. The wound strings are wound in bronze. The unwound strings are steel, so basically the bottom three strings on this set are shiny silver steel. There really isn't much point to wondering whether you might get a better tone from phosphor bronze, zinc bronze (which is what these are), or rock-style nickel wound. Except for bass and rhythm, you're not supposed to be playing those wound strings that much anyway.So...these really are great strings. This is all I'm buying now for my Takemine acoustic electric. They play well, feel good, and sound fine. They are, as the description says, ideal for rock and blues style playing. And Ernie Ball makes good stuff. If it makes a difference, Ernie Ball is what Keith Richards uses. And if you want to play like Keith, lose your 6th string (the one on the top) and tune to open-G. The gauge on these strings is even close to what Richards uses, but he does use nickel wound. He's an electric guy.

I really love these cards. I wait for people to return them to Amazon, and then I scoop them up cheap through the Amazon Warehouse. They're a great bargain.But after some 400 reviews, you probably figured you didn't need to read another one. And if I really wanted to get your attention, I would give this one star, and a lot of people would read the review figuring that I'm either pretty honest or just very nasty.This product is genuinely excellent. If you know what you're buying, then you can't go wrong. But there's the rub. DO you know what you're buying? I thought I did when I started buying these things. I found out that I didn't, so I'm writing this review not to tell you how great this product is but to help you understand what the hell all the letters and numbers mean.First off, SD cards come in different sizes. A regular size SD card works in cameras and Blu-ray players, some of which require these cards to operate BD-Live. There's another size called micro. Micro SD cards work in cell phones. This is a micro size card. Some of the micro cards come with adapters, in which case you can probably use them in cameras and Blu-Ray players as well. But it's best to get the right size, something I forgot when I bought this particular card. It was for a Blu-Ray player, but I ended up sticking it in a cell phone (it did have an adapter, but I tend to avoid adapter, since they seem like a kludge).Also, these cards come in SDHC and SDXC. The HD means high capacity, 8-32 GB. The XC means extended capacity, more than 32 GB. That's all. That X won't get you fancier performance.Card classes are a whole nother world. Chips perform at different speeds. Class 4 is 4 MB/sec, good for full-motion video. Class 6 is 6 MB/sec, HD video. Class 10 specs should now be obvious. The price differences have become minimal, so if you have a newer device you should probably get Class 10. I would consider 6 if the price is low enough. But usually it isn't worth it.These days, buying an 8 GB chip is just a way of announcing you're cheap. They really don't store that much by today's standards. I buy minimum 16 GB chips, which seem practically free compared to 6 years ago. 32GB is good if you're storing a lot of files on your phone. Just be advised that many current phones will not support more than that.My hat's off to you if you actually read this. You're a real trooper. Good luck.

With 1,000 reviews already, you probably figured you didn't need another one. This product was once excellent--about two or three years ago (I bought it in 2011). Now it's obsolete. Don't buy it. you can do better. I had better explain further.when it comes to SD cards, if you know what you're buying, then you can't go wrong. But there's the rub. DO you know what you're buying? I thought I did when I started buying these things. I found out that I didn't, so I'm writing this review partly to help you understand what the hell all the letters and numbers mean.First off, SD cards come in different sizes. This is a regular size SD card. It works in cameras and Blu-ray players, some of which require these cards to operate BD-Live. There's another size called micro. Micro SD cards work in cell phones. Some of the micro cards come with adapters, in which case you can probably use them in cameras and Blu-Ray players as well. But it's best to get the right size. Don't do as I once did and buy a card suitable for a camera thinking I could fit it into a cell phone.Also, these cards come in SDHC and SDXC. The HD means high capacity, 8-32 GB. The XC means extended capacity, more than 32 GB. That's all. That X won't get you fancier performance.Card classes are a whole nother world. Chips perform at different speeds. Class 4 is 4 MB/sec, good for full-motion video. Class 6 is 6 MB/sec, HD video. Class 10 specs should now be obvious. The price differences have become minimal, so if you have a newer device you should probably get Class 10. I would consider 6 if the price is low enough. But usually it isn't worth it.THIS CARD IS A CLASS 2 CARD. IT IS OUT OF DATE. IT WILL NOT SUPPORT VIDEO. FOR THE SAME PRICE YOU SHOULD BE LOOKING AT CLASS 6 OR 10 CARDS. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.These days, buying an 8 GB chip is just a way of announcing you're cheap. They really don't store that much by today's standards. I buy minimum 16 GB chips, which seem practically free compared to 6 years ago. 32GB is good if you're storing a lot of files on your phone. Just be advised that many current phones will not support more than that.My hat's off to you if you actually read this. You're a real trooper. Good luck.

With 4,000 reviews already, you probably figured you didn't need another one. And if I really wanted to get your attention, I would give this one star, and a lot of people would read the review figuring that I'm either pretty honest or just very nasty.This product is genuinely excellent. If you know what you're buying, then you can't go wrong. But there's the rub. DO you know what you're buying? I thought I did when I started buying these things. I found out that I didn't, so I'm writing this review not to tell you how great this product is but to help you understand what the hell all the letters and numbers mean.First off, SD cards come in different sizes. This is a regular size SD card. It works in cameras and Blu-ray players, some of which require these cards to operate BD-Live. There's another size called micro. Micro SD cards work in cell phones. Some of the micro cards come with adapters, in which case you can probably use them in cameras and Blu-Ray players as well. But it's best to get the right size, something I forgot when I bought this particular card. It was for a cell phone, but I ended up sticking it in a Blu-Ray player.Also, these cards come in SDHC and SDXC. The HD means high capacity, 8-32 GB. The XC means extended capacity, more than 32 GB. That's all. That X won't get you fancier performance.Card classes are a whole nother world. Chips perform at different speeds. Class 4 is 4 MB/sec, good for full-motion video. Class 6 is 6 MB/sec, HD video. Class 10 specs should now be obvious. The price differences have become minimal, so if you have a newer device you should probably get Class 10.
