Just be advised that many current phones will not support more than that.My hat's off to you if you actually read this. You're a real trooper. Good luck.PS: just for the record, SD means secure data. I didn't bother explaining this initially because it doesn't really mean anything except that this is a reliable memory chip. Some manufacturers make unreliable memory chips and label them SD, but I've had good luck with Transcend, SanDisk, and AmazonBasics.

Usually I will only review items I bought on Amazon. This hat I bought five years ago before Amazon carried the product line. I have a couple of reasons for introducing this now.But first, women love this hat! Forget about what I might think personally. Women come up to me in places like supermarkets and compliment the hat, just out of the blue. No one ever compliments my other hats like this, not even my much more expensive Indiana Jones hat. But they love his hat. Unfortunately, the interest seems to stop there, and they don't ask me out.The hat itself has stood up pretty well to five years of use, so for the price it's a good deal. It's not a highly finished hat and doesn't have either a liner or chinstrap, but both would be obtrusive.My first specific reason for writing has to do with deals. A well-known company whose name rhymes with bats in the belfry is putting these hats on clearance at half what you might see on Amazon. Check these things out, you might get a real bargain.Second, you will probably find after a couple of years that the crown of the hat is crumpling and the hat looked pretty, well, squashed. This happened to mine. I used spray starch on the inside, a hair dryer to heat up the leather on both sides, and crumpled newspaper to stuff into the hat to help it keep its shape. Then I waited a day. The hat regained its shape. A wipe down with leather conditioner completed the process.By the way, if you're tempted to spend more to get one of these hats with crocodile or kangaroo leather, don't bother. The regular leather is just as good. Save your money.

I bought this as a quick and inexpensive way to cook up stir fry. The skillet cost me $15 through the Amazon Warehouse, so it seemed like Lodge and Amazon were practically begging me to buy it.The skillet works extremely well for its intended purpose. It does take a little getting used to, though, in that washing it with detergent would take off the preseasoning. I'm not overly concerned about this--reseasoning a skillet requires no more than a coating of Crisco in an oven at 350 for an hour. But I don't want to be doing it overly much. In the end, I've found that scrubbing out the pan with plain hot water and a synthetic pad or brush will do the trick.Did I mention that this skillet is HEAVY? I'm 190 and in relatively good shape, and the skillet can still be a bear to handle. Using two hands (there's a handle on both ends) is safest. Try one hand only if you're trying to show off. The elderly or less strong will have difficulty with this pan. My girlfriend, a 55 yo RN, can't handle it.But if you don't mind the heft and have the storage space, it's a great pan to have around.

I bought this in December for about $90. A friend got it on an Amazon lightning sale for $70. Radio Shack has knocked it down to $50 at points. This is a very good choice if you want an entry-level smartphone with a decent set of features and mostly acceptable performance. If you have more money to spend, in the $100-200 range, you might check out the HTC Evo instead (right now Virgin has it for $150). Above that, try looking at the Samsung Galaxy SII (which I've seen for as little as $225 on Boost). These pricier phones will give you better performance and bigger screens with HD resolution.But if you're dipping your toe in the smartphone water, this is a fine choice. Some additional observations:1. This comes with Android 4.0 Ice Cream Sandwich. The current version is 4.1/4.2 Jelly Bean, but HTC will probably not upgrade the OS on this phone due to RAM restrictions. And 5.0 Key Lime Pie will be out in the spring. These new systems are not absolute musts, but I do clearly prefer JB on my Nexus 7.2. This phone has a smaller 3.7-3.8 inch screen. I prefer that and have tablets if I really need a big screen experience. You might not like this, though.3. The phone does not support NFC, so you can't use your e-wallet. It's still a bit early to worry about this, but NFC will probably catch on by next summer. So you need to think through just how carefully you want to prepare now. CVS is already installing the equipment to accept e-wallet payments from phones with this capability. But don't worry. Debit cards won't be obsolete for a little while.4. The phone does not support mobile hotspot operation, which is nice if you are carrying tablets.5. The screen is OK for video although I really think you should consider a bigger phone or a tablet if this is a priority. Angry Birds looks fine on it, though. YouTube works pretty well off a wifi connection but stutters on a 3G link.6. Network performance for Virgin on this phone has been adequate for me but nothing special. I can make calls, read email, get CVS and UPS text alerts, and check the news and weather. That's been fine for now. But the 3G networking is clearly not up to zipping along. If you're in a locale with a lot of public wifi hotspots (e.g., Long Island), you might be able to hop from one to the other. In less metropolitan locales, keep your fingers crossed.7. If you get this phone, invest a little time and money and energy using Google Play to download widgets and active screensavers. Use these to customize your screens to suit yourself. Unlike iOS (which I also use), Android 4+ offers customization opportunities that Apple can't match. In skilled hands, this phone has the potential to make your iPhone friends envious. By the way, while there are ways to purchase through the Amazon Android store on this phone, I've found that it isn't worth the bother. I don't really save anything, and going through the Amazon market makes transferability between my Android devices more problematic.I intend to keep this phone for a year. When the fall 2013 sales heat up, I will replace it with something covering the deficits I mentioned above.PS: If you get this phone, you're also going to need a micro SDHC memory chip. I recommend at least 16 GB. 32 Gb is also OK, and you can always swap it to another phone later. Make sure you get a MICRO chip. Otherwise it won't fit. And get a Class 10 chip, not Class 4 or 6. The performance is better and the additional cost is mnimal.

I bought this for $10, which was practically a giveaway. It's still at a very good price and deserves five stars for that.The convenience of the pitcher is also indisputable. It's very easy to fill from a tap (preferably to the side of the filter), and the pitcher holders almost enough for one person for one day. However, the size isn't quite as optimum as I would like, and for more than one person it is probably inadequate. Four stars.Filtering is OK. I can taste some difference in the water, but it's not enough to make me jump and shout. Offhand, it's just enough to get me to buy some more filters to try them out for another year. Be forewarned that initial use of a filter will leave black specks in your water. Uou need to take care to flush the filters first.Overall, this is a buy that I like but don't treasure. I would do it again, though.

These bowls deserve five stars for their quality. They are highly functional and practically n destructible. My spaghetti used to slide off my dinner plates. With these bowls I have eliminated the problem.These are not the best value in Corelle pasta bowls, however. I spent $26 to buy four of these. Recently I discovered that Amazon is selling a set of four of these bowls PLUS a two quart big bowl for $20. That's a much better deal.If you're a value shopper, you should check out this alternative. And if you're REALLY a value shopper, then you should check to see if you can get it through Amazon Warehouse, which can often bring you an additional 10-20 percent discount.

After having a number of Pyle-Pro cable-related items fall apart after very light use,  started buying Monoprice. I was paying a bit more and expecting a lot more. Monoprice delivers some of the best value cables around.The cable portion is of very good quality, but it's really been the connectors that concern me. The quality, design, construction of the Monoprice connectors are really much better than you're going to find on cabling in a similar price range. They hold up to more use. The set screws don't fall out nexpected lay.For home studio use and practice jamming, these are a good choice. For professional performance use, different considerations (e.g., crosstalk minimization, greater strain relief) come into play and you may need to look at pricier alternatives.

I bought this popcorn as a cheap and convenient treat but did not expect the quality to be as high as premium popcorn. And perhaps it isn't, but I can't tell. I know that it pops efficiently with very few orphans, and the popped kernels are full, fresh, and fluffy. It amounts to a cheap thrill.Bulk popcorn would be cheaper per batch but require the use (and cleaning) of equipment. I got tired of this. As a single person, it's easier for me to just throw a bag into the microwave and nuke it. It takes 2 minutes in an 1100 watt oven. I season it will various forms of sea salt, which lets me pretend that I'm being a gourmet chef.Best of luck. I hope your batches turn out as well.

At less than $8 this was a very good purchase for a single person who doesn't require a great deal of toilet paper. On price alone, I would give this five stars.The quality is not as good as I recall for Cottenelle, though. In spite of the ultra part of the label, this toilet paper still has the somewhat rougher feel of a budget brand. This corresponds to the reviews I've seen on those sites that devote themselves to such things. In general, Quilted Northern Ultra ranks the highest. Cottenelle Ultra comes out somewhat slightly above average, a B+ grade more than an A grade. I would give this toilet paper no more than 3 1/2 stars for quality.If overall cost is your priority, this is a wise purchase. If quality is your priority and you don't mind 48 rolls at a time, buy Quilted Northern Ultra from Amazon. That's what I plan on doing next time.

I started wearing reading glasses in November after cataract surgery. I originally bought an inexpensive pair from CVS for $10. It didn't take more than a month for me to realize that I had better start buying more pairs. If I didn't sit on them and break them, hen I was going to mislay them. This happened numerous times each day.I bought these as a backup to give me the additional pairs I needed. As a backup, they serve well enough, and the pricing is very good. I would give them five stars just for the pricing.For comfort and quality, however, they do not compare well to the somewhat more expensive CVS pair. The frame is less comfortable and considerably less well constructed. The focus is OK but not superior. This is to be expected of something costing around $3 per pair.In the end, I have my backup and am satisfied in that respect but will be buying further pairs through my local drugstores. The cost is greater, but not enough so to offset the advantages of trying on and assessing firsthand the quality of something I expect to be wearing quite a bit during the day. In that context, the slight additional cost makes this assurance worth it.

I've stopped writing reviews for Amazon. After reading some of the other reviewer comments, I decided to make an exception. To be up front, this is not the absolute best hummus that I've tried. That would be what I used to eat when I lived in Cairo, and my own homemade hummus is pretty decent as well. Straight out of the can, this is a fairly good hummus. If you use if as a base and mix in a little imagination, then you should be able to get hummus that can match just about anything else around.This also happens to be a terrific deal at its current pricing of just under $16 for 12 cans. Don't believe me? Check out the pricey supermarket hummus in the teeny plastic containers in the deli section. Right now, this specific offering is a better deal than Amazon's own subscription offering of the same brand of hummus, and the 15 ounce cans are for me a bit more convenient than the 30 ounce cans of the subscription offering.Unaltered, this hummus is a bit more thick and pasty than it should be for an ideal dip. It's also a bit on the bland side. Being bland makes it great as a base, since this opens up the possibilities for some doctoring and personal variations. It also makes it a bit safer for the American palate, since hummus can be an acquired taste and many people who are new to hummus may not want too much in the way of surprises.Anyway, I've found that, while I can eat this straight out of the can, I prefer mixing in some more lemon juice, a bit of water, and tahina. In my opinion, that has to be done to make this a good dish. I also mix in sea salt, crushed peppercorns, and sometimes either chili powder or Louisiana hot sauce. Garlic powder is also a fair addition. In fact, if you like to play around in the kitchen, then I would suggest experimenting to your heart's content. I'm obviously not a hummus purist, if there is such a thing. Hummus is an occasion to celebrate new ideas, whatever we figure we can get away with. To serve with a bit of flair, drizzle a high quality olive oil on the top of the dip and sprinkle black sesame seeds as a garnish.By the way, one reviewer said this product was too lemony. It's really not, and adding more lemon juice helps this to reach the right consistency.Many people would say that the best way to serve this is with pita bread ("esh baladi," or people's bread). That IS the traditional way to eat it, but we don't really need to follow tradition that much (as long as you don't spread it on Twinkies). Since I can get Panera day-old baguettes for next to nothing, I just slice these up into chips that can be dipped. There's no need to get too picky about something that is close to street food in the Middle East. If it tastes good, it's appropriate.In the end, with a bit of playing and the proper ingredients, you should be able to make this hummus into your own special dip. Your friends will envy you, and you will have saved a bundle.I don't know how long Amazon is going to keep the pricing at this level. Right now, they're pushing hard to establish their market for Middle Eastern dishes. You might want to lay in a good supply before the inevitable price hike. And in the meantime, enjoy a bit of the Middle East. Boy does this make me wish I could go back.

I've worked extensively with choline-based cognition enhancers for the past three years. This includes various forms of alpha-GPC as well as time-release formulations of choline bitartrate. I also have considerable experience with formulations which have a similar objective, including things like piracetam as well as cholinesterase inhibitors like Huperzine-A and donepezil. Last, I have a lot of experience in supplementing these with nootropics like vinpocetane, which acts as a vasodillator to improve blood flow to the brain, also improving memory.To recap briefly, choline-based supplements can augment the brain's supply of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter critical to cognitive and memory functions. They can be used in tandem with cholinesterase inhibitors, which slow the degradation of ACh and keep the overall levels in the brain somewhat higher. Things like piracetam and vinpocetane are not directly related to ACh but can work in tandem with choline-related supplements to further enhance the effects.Inositol is not related to any of this but has benefits of its own, notably as a mild anti-depressant. For that matter, choline is useful in clearing the liver and resolving fatty liver disease, something helpful for recovering alcoholics and those who've simply binged too much. The two together are usually recommended as well as a supplement for anyone on a strict vegetarian diet, since such diets are likely to be lacking in choline and inositol.My slight downgrade in the rating reflects my assessment of this supplement as a cognition enhancer. For general dietary purposes, and especially for recovering alcoholics, it is fine. Taken strictly as a cognition enhancer, though, the following observations may be significant:1. The best combination of choline-related supplements for cognition enhancement is alpha-GPC and Huperzine-A (donepezil is better, but that's by prescription).2. The best single choline supplement is probably alpha-GPC, followed closely by Huperzine-A. Alpha-GPC is much more bio available than other forms of choline. This isn't a myth dreamed up by industry.3. The most effective formulations of choline bitartrate are the time-release formulations such as that from Solaray.4. The least effective formulation of choline bitartrate I have tried, for cognition enhancement, is this one from Source Natural. I'm surprised to be saying this since Source Natural turns out very high quality products, but the results are what they are.As I tried to note above, this is still a very good general dietary supplement, but if your objective is cognition enhancement, there are better alternatives. Unfortunately, those alternatives cost more.By the way, the tablets are in fact bigger than average, as some reviewers have complained. At least they're not as bad as K-Con potassium tablets, which are really huge, but some people will still find them uncomfortable to swallow. I suggest mixing them in with applesauce or yogurt. This will help a lot.I hope this helps.

In general, Del Monte canned fruits are of excellent quality deserving of a five-star rating. These peaches are no exception...except for what seem to be persistent problems in Amazon's handling of Del Monte products.I use subscription purchases to get Del Monte peaches and mandarin oranges from Amazon. Of the last four shipments I have received in the last two months, three have been very unhygienic. The cans were dusty and scraped, and they looked like they had been rolling loose on a warehouse floor and then gathered up and repackaged. Cans in one shipment were severely dented almost to the point of rupturing.It's not clear where in the supply chain this problem is occurring. It may be in an Amazon warehouse. Or Del Monte may be selling seconds to Amazon. Either way, the product being delivered to the customer is something I would not choose myself from a supermarket shelf.I've advised Amazon customer service of this problem. You should do the same if this problem occurs. And I will update this review if the problem is resolved.

This is very good tahina deserving of a five-star rating. I bought it as an experiment to make sure that I could still prepare proper hummus myself. I had grown very tired of the commercial brands sold in the US, which are geared towards an American palate and are on the bland side for me (I lived in the Middle East for 15 years). Because the unit price of the Al Wadi brand is so much less, however, I expect to be buying that in the future.This tahina is good for up to two quarts of hummus or baba ganoug, depending on your recipe and tastes. It seems to settle, so you may need to stir it before usng to get the proper consistency. You can also mix it with pekmez for a dip, or you can fake this with grape jam (which is cheaper). Baba ganoug is the same thing as hummus but using eggplant instead of garbanzos. You can also use fava beans.Please keep in mind that this is people's food, not haute cuisine. It doesn't have to be served on a silver platter with pita bread (which is "esh baladi" or people's bread). I'm cheap. My apartment building distributes free day-old Panera bread, so I slice up baguettes and use that instead to dip into the hummus.And the proper Arabic is "tahina", not "tahini" (at least in the Egyptian, Najd, and Hijaz dialects). If you say "tahini" in Cairo, people will stare at you strangely and tag you as a tourist. Don't get tagged as a tourist.

There's not too much to say after the first 558 reviews. This kettle is a bargain that is well-made, easy to use, easy to clean, and an excellent choice for small gifts. I got it to make tea. I'm sure I'll find plenty of other uses. It sits nicely on a small burner on my electric stove. I bought it hrough Amazon Warehouse in very good condition (i.e., new with slightly damaged packaging) for $9. That was a nice bargain. If you want to clean it, consider an Oxo Good Grips bottle washer.

I'm not going to bother repeating all the accolades already bestowed on this little gem. They're true. I use ths for hummus and vinaigrettes. It's not absolutely necessary, but it IS a timesaver and labor-saver for a 64 yo cooking for 1-2 people.Instead, I'm going to tell you how to buy this cheaply. Click the link to "Used" items. Look for Amazon Warehouse and anything labelled as used but in good or better condition. This invariably means that someone returned it to Amazon and that the packaging is damaged to a greater or lesser degree. The product itself is new. I bought one this way for $33. I've seen them drop to $28 at times.The bandaid is because I cut my finger on the blade whrn I opened the processor up. Those suckers are SHARP.I plan on buying more of these as gifts for friends. But not at the full price.

Currently, I can buy a 6-ounce can of jumbo pitted olives at Food Lion for $2.49. These are a bit more expensive per ounce, even on a subscription basis. However, I've weighed a number of factors and just now ordered a second lot of these ahead of schedule. Aside from price, here are the things I considered:1. These are at least as good as any other black olives I have tried.2. The sizing is much more convenient. Using an entire 6-ounce can at once is often not very convenient. Suppose I just need smaller amounts for stir fry or salads? In the end, using one of these cans serves my purposes better and is more economical than the bigger store-bought cans.3. While I can certainly chop whole olives myself, this product saves me the trouble. And there IS a certain elegance to having neatly sliced olives, especially when presentation makes a difference.4. I'm pretty lazy, and it's hot outside. Sometimes it's nice to just push a button and wait for UPS to drop things on my doorstep.

I purchased this a year ago and have used it off and on since then. With its red color and Coke logo, it has an undeniable charm that is hard to resist. It's performance, however, is marginal, and I do not regard it as an especially good value. I finally gave it to my son, who I thought might have better uses for it.My offhand observations include the following:1. This unit will keep drinks cool. It is not an effective way to cool drinks off and will do so only very, very slowly.2. The cooler is best used as a mobile unit in cars or trucks. It has a 12-volt connector for this purpose. It also has a built-in carrying grip on the top that is very handy.3. It might also be used in bedrooms or dorm rooms where access to a refrigerator is limited, but it's lack of any real cooling ability will be frustrating in these situations.4. The door latch is poorly designed. I had to slam the door repeatedly to get it to shut properly.5. The overall construction is very lightweight, which is good for mobility but probably a poor sign for durability.I hope this helps.

Peanut butter gourmets who enthuse over esoteric brands won't like me for saying this, but Skippy usually bests everything else in taste tests, and Peter Pan often ties Skippy. Don't believe me? Check out the published reviews of tests with 12 year olds, a key consumer population. The Cooking Light website also has some good reviews.I picked this up because it was less expensive than Skippy's alternative. In a straight-up comparison with Skippy's super chunk, I can't taste any significant difference except for the honey-roasted flavor. And that flavor really makes this offering a winner. It is not cloyingly sweet but just flavorful enough to make eating this peanut butter a real treat just by itself.And I do exactly that, especially during my mid-afternoon hypoglycemic periods. This peanut butter will serve well anyone with diet-controlled type 2 diabetes who hits a low-sugar rough patch.Each jar has 13 servings, and each serving has 190 calories, most of which are from fat. This is enough to chase many into the arms of reduced-fat alternatives. OK. Just remember that this fat is mostly monounsaturated and possibly good for you. Removing such oils may undermine the nutritional value.Don't believe me? Again, check the web. I switched away from reduced-fat peanut butter when I realized that it was more politically correct than nutritionally correct. Anyway, I love this stuff, and so long as I eat moderate amounts, there should be no problem. But it's still tempting to get a spoon and eat a whole jar in front of the TV.

If spreading this solution on and wiping it off could magically remove all the wax, then I would give it five stars. But that is not the case. This solution can be effective, but only if you're willing to spend time and effort in using it. A LOT of effort.I got one unit of this for two small bathrooms and a smallish kitchen. In retrospect, that should have been enough if I had used it with care. I didn't. I poured half into a mop bucket and tried to treat relatively large areas with a sponge mop. While this removed some wax, it still left me with blotchy and soiled floors.So I backed up and used the rest more cautiously in the following manner:1. I put up to one cup of this product in a pitcher with water in 1:2 and 1:3 solutions.2. I then spot-treated up to 10 square feet of linoleum tiles at a time by pouring small amounts of the solution where I needed it.3. I got down on my hands and knees and scrubbed with a very hefty Oxo cleaning brush.4. I scrubbed until I got lots of suds, and then I scrubbed even more. The suds made more of a difference than the strength of the solution.5. I used a scrap hand towel to wipe off and rinse each small section, and then I moved to the next section. I used plenty of water.6. Once things dried, I checked for shiny spots indicating wax, or for really soiled areas, and I repeated the above for up to five times.This approach is effective. A power scrubber would also be effective, but I didn't have one.Aside from wax, this product also does pretty well in cleaning baseboards and dirt on kitchen walls. It takes off scuff marks. It removes general soiling. But this all comes at the cost of considerable time and effort.

I've been buying these soups as a matter of cheap thrills and convenience. They are probably best used as a no-fuss and light lunch st work and school. Not all of the flavors are created equal, however. I rank the ones I've tried as follows:1. Tomato Parmesan2. Cream of broccoli3. New England clam chowder.The first two are very tasty. The third is a bit bland but still pretty decent.I can think of three advantages of going with this product:1. Cost. Bloom charges me $1.89 a can for this soup. Amazon's subscription plans often make the soup significantly less expensive.2. Ease of preparation. Just shake, microwave for 90 seconds, and you're ready to go. No other cooking utensils or preparation is required. The metal rims on the containers do not cause sparking. Pretty neat.3. Ease of consumption. Just sip from the container, which seems to be a foam material or plastic that doesn't conduct much heat and is easy to hold. It fits easily into car cup holders. No spoons or bowls are required.Anyone on a low-salt diet should think twice. The soups have 30+ percent of the RDA. The fat content is a bit elevated. These things are to maintain the flavor. Calories don't go above 220 or so.All in all, these soups have turned out to be an unexpected winner. I expect to be buying more.

This is a decent enough general glue for a limited range of situations. Here are my actual, true-life experiences:1. I applied this in lieu of mastic to re-attach loose linoleum tiles. It worked.2. I glued back on some kitchen baseboard molding that had come loose. It worked.3. I glued insoles back into some water shoes. One session of pool walking dissolved the glue.4. I glued a plastic toilet hose to a metal fitting. It came loose after the first flush.This glue does not work if it has to survive immersion in water. Otherwise it should be fine. It is especially good when Sticky Ass glue is just too strong and permanent.

I've used this scale to weigh harmonicas, toenail clippers, wok covers, and...well, yes, even food. I cut a notch in a plastic container so I could weigh out exactly 2.00 ounces of spaghetti. The plastic spaghetti measures are useless next to this gizmo.The automatic zero adjust is very handy. I can put a container on the scale, turn it on, and get just the net weight. I use both the gram and ounce settings. Variability from one weighing to the next is negligible. The more I use this scale, the more I find additional uses for it.So it increases daily the quality of life. I know this with certainty. I use the scale to weigh that, too.

I'm not sure what to make of a 55 yo matron who has gone completely ga-ga over Futarama and is now buying everything In sight if it relates to the series. Even Bobbleheads. I thought we were finished with that after Mythbusters. Anyway, we got this for $20 through Amazon Prime, which was actually a very good deal for this kind of plush toy. She thinks it's adorable. I agree, and I haven't even watched Futurama yet. The cats aren't sure what to make of it yet. But it does sit around quietly and brighten up otherwise bare corners of her apartment.

I always struggle to get protectors on without air bubbles, which is why I prefer this kind of protector with multiple tabs and things to peel off at each step. I just bought a new Fire and a screen protector is crucial, imo. This lines up over the camera lens and then you pull it slowly down/off. I use my bank card to smooth it along the way, but next time I may use a pack of unused checks as it is a nearly perfect width. Take any bubble out before going on and be patient.  I particularly like that they included 2 protectors--I got the second one on right.

These are acceptable as all-purpose, absorbent (though somewhat thin, not thick) gray-blue microfiber  towels, They are not DII towels at a great price, though, the quality is not the same. As microfiber towels (20% microfiber and 80% polyester), they're good to have around and get the job done (spills, drying dishes, washing car, etc. they were fine). There are six colors to choose from--these gray-blue match my kitchen and look like they do on the product page picture--the color runs true.

This is a nice, thin and fairly soft long sleeved crewneck undershirt for layering against the cold. It is "70% polyester/ 30% polyamide" so you know it won't breathe exactly like cotton. However, it does keep you pretty dry and doesn't have seams rubbing against you when you move. It is easy to move in. The "large" size IS not *very* large, in the sense that the sleeves are long (over the wrists). But the fit was like a loose-ish t-shirt on my tall, thin friend who I got it for. The fabric has some stretch, but t seemed as if it would be too small if a man was large and heavy/overweight.  For someone well built, trim and muscular, it is probably a close fit--fine as an undergarment in the cold..It got good marks for warmth and yet stayed dry. Overall, nice shirt and fairly stylish for something intended to be worn underneath. I could see some men choosing it for a pajama top and sleeping comfortably.

This is a pretty, typically well made Lenox porcelain ornament. It does not look as delicate as in the photo, though, perhaps because it is so large (4 1/2" from top to bottom and about 3 3/4" between the widest sides. It is not white, it is ecru (which I like) and while the gold pattern and red jewels are very noticeable, the green blends in with the center decoration. I didn't mind that, but if someone is looking for a Christmas ornament with a lot of red and green on it, this wouldn't be it.  (It also doesn't have the year on it, if that matters to you. I actually prefer it without that, so this new style worked for me.)The "arms" of the snowflake are wider and heavier-looking in person than the way the photo shows them, which makes sense for porcelain, but might be disappointing if you expect it to be very delicate. I like the lattice-y ness of it.  This is a large and unique-looking ornament. It would go well on a tree with many,many different ornament styles or, alternatively, an all porcelain or all snowflake-type tree. I have mostly glass balls and things that look a lot a like, so I'm planning to hang this as a household decoration for Christmas. .I may also get one for Chinese friends who celebrate Christmas as, to me, as with the red and gold box it makes a nice gift.

First, this is ONLY for the Fire HD 8. I think the size is very important because, for example, there is a magnetic closure that keeps the cover shut (unlike my old case--so I like that). Also it automatically wakes and puts it to sleep by opening and closing the cover--I like that, too.  I was hoping the landscape view stand would work (as it hasn't with every other case I've ordered except one that was plaid and so ugly I couldn't bear to use it, practical though it was).  Unfortunately, the landscape view doesn't support the Fire well enough with this case either. Other than that, it's lightweight as promised and, personally, I like the bright pink color. Maybe some day someone will design a good looking case where you CAN watch videos, etc. by just opening it and folding it back. So far, I haven't yet found one.

Such nice warmth when you're cold.This Serta electric mattress pad arrived on my second day with the flu. I had moved to the couch, with a blanket, but was having chills. So "electric warmth" sounded so good. I didn't have the energy to read a lot of the booklet, just took a look and plugged it in, using it almost as a heating pad to see if it would take the chill off.The control was so easy to use--you just choose the level of heat that you want, from 1 to 10. The timer is similarly configured--it shows the length of time (in hours or half an hour) that you want it to be on. Even with a slight fever, it was extremely easy to figure out. I kept it low for about a half hour--it was nice and warm, took the chill off--and my blanket-and-couch set up started to feel so much better.The following day I put it over the mattress as it's supposed to be and it fit without no problem as I do not have any thick topper with foam. I don't sleep with it on, but I love being able to warm the sheets before getting into bed. It feels amazing actually--so cozy.  I love the timer and even dual controls if you and a spouse/significant other have different preferences for warmth (as so often is the case).  I think it's a great product--easy to use and did exactly as promised.

My picky cat loves Friskie's Temptations, so I was curious if she would like these or not.The package rattling made her think it was Temptations at first but when she got a whiff of the smell she got even more eager to try them. I put down two of each kind to see if she had a preference, but she just ate from left to right and finished everything. If I was guessing, I think she liked the crunchy ones (Chicken and Turkey) better and generally preferred the chicken over the salmon.  But she ate everything.She's a small cat--runt of the litter--so I did consult the chart that Irresistibles puts on the Product page to see how many pieces a day she should be having (about 14 a day = 10% of her calories in treats).There's real meat in these and no artificial flavors. I liked having the Variety Pack which had four flavors --: White Meat Chicken (soft), Salmon (soft), White Meat Chicken & Turkey (crunchy) and Salmon & Ocean Whitefish (crunchy).  At first I thought the two salmon were identical, but you can see the crunchy one mixed with whitefish. As I say, I think she preferred that and the crunchy chicken and turkey over the soft ones, but she did it them all, and very quickly.They do use BHA as a preservative and titanium dioxide for the color, but thatdidn't really bother me. Not crazy about Red 40 or Yellow 6 (is it really necessary? I think pet owners could accept grey-colored treats if they knew they were better for the cats. They also use corn gluten meal, which doesn't bother me, but might be avoided by others, so FYI.  Overall, I thought they were a success although all natural Temptations may still have the edge most of the time.

There was a lot to like about this, starting with the fact I always prefer to use glass for hot drinks for health reasons--not having the bad chemicals leeching from heated paper cups. And the flavor is much better than in paper or in stainless steel (ceramic's not good for you either) . At home I have glass mugs, but getting a drink outside you usually have do without it. This solves that problem really well.  It's also always nice to bring your own container to coffee shops so that I know I'm not adding to more trash problem. It's sad to see how much trash one coffee shop creates in a single day.Anyway, I like the glass (borosilicate) container and it handles heat very well, as promised. I poured boiling water in, steeped my tea and carried it immediately. The foam sleeve around it was not cool to the touch--it was warm actually--but very comfortable. (Actually, it was a cold day and the container--which has a slight "give" nicely warmed my hands. A bonus.) . It comes in a variety of colors but I really liked this plum shade--not boring like black and not loud like green or orange. The foam sleeve also covers the bottom of the mug to help prevent slipping. It has a convenient handle on top, like a thermos. The foam sleeve provides a comfortable grip and helps with heat retention, but it is not a thermos. The drink stays hot-to-warm for the time it would normally take to drink it slowly. It's not something you would travel far with and expect to keep hot for an hour or more.The cap screws off and on easily, but you have to be careful to line it up correctly or there might be some leaking, as with any thermos. The cap is made of BPA/BPS-free polypropylene (PP#5) with no phthalates, PVC, or polycarbonates.  It is designed to minimize spillage--so its  concave all around, and the opening that you sip through is recessed and flows a small amount at a time. This was the only thing I wasn't that crazy about. It makes sense design-wise, is even a good idea (and makes it difficult to burn yourself by drinking something hot too fast), but its a little more difficult/slow to drink from this than other thermos-type containers.You can wash the sleeve and glass together and it is all dishwasher safe, but not for use in a microwave..

It's Lenox, well-made with a very nice glaze that has a sparkle to it that the photo doesn't show. I thought it might be too large..or too small...or look tacky with the snowman, but I really like it. It is heavier than I expected and that, plus the beautiful finish, gives it a very 'quality" feel. The snowman is cute, head about the size of a tangerine and the candy dish is the perfect size to me--small enough to keep filled easily (people who said a bag of MnMs mean the large bag--that's just about right), but not taking up too much space on the table--really the perfect size, about 6" across. Cute, useful, a nice size and festive. I like it.

Heads up for anyone who doesn't sight read the bass clef well.This  "piano solo" sheet music is all written for double bass clef. No treble clef at all!  It is a low song--I didn't realize it played the melody in the octave below middle "C".  I thought it sounded fine transcribing to start on the "B" below middle C, but apparently the actual sheet music  starts (as written in the bass clef) goes down as low as D sharp...  So, even if you wanted to accompany yourself (and I just wanted the melody line), you're looking at two bass clefs and no treble clef at all.Speaking for myself, if you're not that good at sight-reading, it is very difficult to play two bass clefs. That might be great "reading bass" practice for someone (else) but I'm disappointed.

I normally prefer dark chocolate, but I was very happy to get this Nestls Cailler L'Ecorce in milk chocolate instead. I know they also make dark chocolate bars (a couple of kinds) but, good as European chocolate is, the dark chocolate from Europe--usually with at least 80% cocoa--is just too bitter for me.I did "ding" them one star for making it seem like this is a small swiss company that makes the chocolate at home (from milk from grass-fed, grazing cows, not factory farming) and they roast the hazelnuts themselves as well. That may all be true (except the "home" part; Cailler has been around since 1819), but it's part of Nestls.  Not exactly like mom and pop making chocolate from their  farm which is the impression the literature gave me.Anyway, the chocolate tastes good, there are lots of finely chopped hazelnuts in it and each bite has some hazelnut texture and taste. It's not super creamy as a result, and milder in terms of sweetness.Because it's milk chocolate, with the sweetness, crunch and smoothness, Even though the bar is very thin, about 1/2-1/3 the thickness of a typical Nestls or Cadbury bar in the market. But I find that just a square or two at a time is very satisfying. If you like milk chocolate and hazelnuts, I would definitely recommend this

A well-done adaptation, directed by Joseph Sternberg on a low budget.  Peter Lorre is a fine actor--as is Edward Arnold--but is a bit miscast as Roskolnikov. This is a crime story that about so much more than murder.My one objection is to the Product Description. "A Great Masterpiece becomes an even greater movie!" Really, who writes and approves copy like that? Dostoyevsky's novel IS a masterpiece and one of the best things about this movie is that it will get more people to read the book. But it is an insult to a competent movie to pretend that it in anyway achieves equivalence--much less superiority--with such a deep, complex and beautifully written book--something that is -truly- a masterpiece.. Crime and Punishment (Enriched Classics)

I know there are so many benefits of fish oil but it is difficult to get them through diet alone. When I've tried Omega 3 supplements in the past, there was an unpleasant after-taste, even if mild.  These fish oil gel caps have a lemon coating so if you have any burping or aftertaste (I couldn't detect any) it will not be fishy. These have the usual benefits of Omega 3 for heart and circulatory health, as well as improving immunities. Zenwise claims they also "boost energy and regulate mood"--which would be another great benefit although I haven't noticed it yet (still early)They have 2400mg of Omega 3 fatty acids which boosts heart health, plus 880mg of EPA (Eicosapentaenoic Acid, an anti-inflammatory) and 600mg of DHA which is good for the brain, heart and eyesI like that the capsules are made in the U.S. and are FDA regulated. What I like even more is that they are cruelty free and sustainable.They are also gluten free and avoid many ingredients that cause allergies--there's no wheat, egg, milk, peanut or soyThere's even a  "no questions asked" money back guarantee. All in all, a well prepared product with many important health benefits for both men and women.

I've bought a lot of Anne Klein watches because they are well designed, versatile and have that extra removable link in the bracelet that really helps if your wrist is small. This has a larger face than other AK watches I've had--about as large as a 50 cent piece.It's a pretty watch, and I liked it more than I expected, because the crystals aren't trying to seem like diamonds. The crystals around the outside are under the glass, add a subtle textured sparkle--nice, not too much. The mother of pearl finish on the face of the watch gives it a bit more ecru color than bright white--which I like and think looks classier than white would have.It is easy to read (no numbers on the dial, but lines that are clear, like a little sunburst.The watch keeps time well, as expected, and even has a second hand which many watches don't have anymore. The bracelet part is just a typical shiny gold colored (not matte) band.  I was looking forward to the two bracelets but didn't find them particularly worthwhile to use. They hang loosely (annoying for me), are oval and don't really add anything to the watch or work well on their own, at least not  on my wrist. I thought the watch looked a lot better without them.So, in my opinion, the price really would just be for the watch alone wihich makes it a little  more expensive ($25 or so) than my usual AK watches that don't come with bracelets.. Is it still worth it? I think so. But I've noticed since it arrived that Amazon frequently discounts the price to between $110 to $135. If it were me, I'd  wait till it dropped a bit before buying. It has quickly become one of my favorites -- can go dressy or casual as AK watches are so often good at.

This is the first product I've tried from Prepworks by Progressive and I'm a fan!  I have had opened bags of brown sugar wind up hard and unusable more times than I care to remember. This product is such a clever solution for that. It's a good shape, clear to see what's in it if you forget, and a convenient size--can store 2 lbs of sugar with no problem and some room to spare. There is a silicon strip around the inside rim of the lid for a tight seal and, on top of that, the front latch snaps easily and securely into place. But the creative part that is so innovative is the terra cotta disc that comes wrapped separately. There is a whole sheet of colorful product labeling that comes with it but none of it has any instructions! Instead it says, "look under the lid". Well, my lid didn't come with any instructions so I don't know why they couldn't write the simple directions on that big colorful product sheet.Anyway, the direction is this: unpack the terra cotta disc, cover it in water (it will hiss as it absorbs the moisture) and after 10 minutes or so, take it out and snap it into the space in the lid. It goes in very easily, but tightly, and doesn't fall out. They say it's also fine to put the terra cotta disc directly into the sugar and leave it there, but I prefer it inside the lid where it provides some moisture. The sugar really does stay loose and fresh. Great product!

These are really cute and comfortable. They have an inside ear on the side --in pink -- just so you know. I wasn't expecting that, but it was just slightly visible from the side, actually kind of cute. From  the front and back they're straight black, not as big as they look on this page--just like you put cat ears on that were proportional to your head. The band looks too small in the package, but several people tried them (looked good on everyone, even the men) and thought they were as comfortable as did. Fun for a costume. Recommended.

I'm a big fan of Turbo Tax. I used to pay way too much to have my (fairly simple) taxes professionally prepared because I had no confidence in my ability to do them.  Turbo Tax is truly "user friendly". The way it leads you through every category in such a clear, easy-to-read-and-follow way is fantastic. It really does eliminate all lthe stress (until that "pay up" part) and has also made me understand the process--and the information I need to save throughout the year.  It has been helpful in every way.However, what motivated me to write a review was that this year I made a mistake. Someone in the household bought Turbo Tax on disc before April 15, but then we asked for an extension. When it came time to file in the fall, the only thing left at Amazon was the PC download. I ordered it, not realizing that there was already TurboTax  software on my computer. $100 is a lot of money to throw away, so I called Amazon almost immediately.  They sent me the confirmation email and told me TurboTax has a guaranteed refund (I think within 30 days of purchase).I wasn't optimistic, but I emailed the information (took under 2 minutes to do it) and--to my surprise--in a few weeks, there was the refund check! No muss, no fuss. That is so impressive. And...really appreciated.  What a great business model. So I wanted to post here and say that they really do stand behind that offer if for some reason you're dissatisfied with the program (yes, you do need to uninstall it first, of course).  It's great software, though, but nice to know if you make a mistake as I did, you're not out the money. They really do follow through.

Mine were shipped and arrived without the crumbs that others complained of. They are nice round raspberry-colored balls, about the size of a cheetohs puff, bigger than popcorn and dense inside, not hollow.They are very crunchy--which I liked. I also liked the flavor a lot--it is a little sweet, and a bit tart (possibly a little too tart for many young children who would otherwise enjoy the crunchy snack). You taste the Fuji apple more than the raspberry. (Apples are the first ingredient, then raspberries then pectin and juice concentrate--nothing else. I liked that.)Each bag is 120 calories, "0" nutrition in all categories except for 10g of carbohydrate and 1g of dietary fiber. It's a snack, pure and simple, with no sodium, cholesterol or fat. As an "empty calorie" alternative to so many, many packaged snacks, I think this is a good choice. It feels like a snack food, a "junk food" if you will, but without anything bad in it. Not a healthy food, but a good choice as an empty calorie (and fairly low in calorie) snack. I iked it.

I liked using this program. As a photographer, I like to use photo editors for more than fixing the photo problemscropping, sharpening, adjusting hue, etc. If you primarily want to adjust your photosfixing them as photos including adding some color enhancements--there are several other very good, much less expensive programs like Paint Shop Pro and Photoshop Elements that do that.This is a pretty expensive program and I wouldnt get it unless I felt it did something that I couldnt do less expensively elsewhere (or couldnt do at all elsewhere) or unless it made something much easier to do than a less expensive program did.Painter 2016 doesnt make thing easierthe interface isnt horrible and the tutorials are goodbut it is not all that intuitive and takes a little patience. (I also found some of the Youtube videos helpful). If youve used Photoshop, etc. youll see a lot of the same concepts herethe layout of the workspace, the toolbox, palettes, brushes. You can use layers and adding one is just as easy as clicking New layer.What I like is taking a photo and using it to make something that is less like a photo and more like a painting (obviously those who start from scratch can use the tools to create a drawing or painting from scratch. The dpi is good.) The cloning tool and tracing features are very useful. It will do underpainting for you automatically. You can choose the texture of your paper and between all the things youd expecta watercolor effect, pastel effect, charcoal, etc. Choosing the right brush is a big thing in Painter, but it isn't that hard to get used to.  In addition to the texture of your paper, you can control the brightness of it and  adjust the texture to customize it for your own needs. It was good for landscapes,  okay for portraits. There are some special effects filters, wood cut, kaleidoscope, glass distortion, and so onnot useful for me, but someone may like it.If you want to make art, particularly from a photo, this is a good program for it. I found the graphic capabilities able to add the kind of artistic details that made the end product look more like something that had started out as a painting done from scratch rather than a digitally enhanced photo. If you understand what that means and want to do it with your photos (and have the time to do it--it's not like applying a filter, it's like actually making a work of art), you would probably enjoy this very much. (Theres a free 30 day trial).

In the old days, it would have been laughable to think that you needed an entire book to use a telephone. But, times change, and today what we call a "phone" is really a hand-held computer that can make calls. The little computer we rely on and carry everywhere is a highly sophisticated and incredibly versatile tool. Books like "Android Phones for Dummies" remind you just how complicated and versatile a tool a "smartphone" is--and how few of us really bother to learn all the incredibly useful things that it can do for us.This is another well designed, well written "Dummies" book (really for smart people because despite the easy writing style and occasional bits of humor that mark this series, there is an awful lot to know and it takes patience to read through the directions and try them out). This book starts with the basics--making it a good book for anyone getting a smartphone (Android one) for the first time.But the best use is for someone who's had the phone for a while, does some of the basics already, but wants to know what all it can do--and how to quickly do it.  There's the phone basics, of course, voice mail, texting, etc., plus using maps, taking photos/videos, playing music, using a variety of apps.  Part IV then gets into customizing, working with apps, various other navigation and utilization instructions where you're doing things, not hard really, but thing that most people probably just don't know about.It winds up with the section of tips: "Ten Tips, Tricks and Shortcuts and "Ten Things to Remember".  (The first thing I read in this book was actually the last page of that section--and, though randomly selected, it was very useful--how to take a screenshot. Didn't know it before, do now, in just a paragraph.. The tips in these two sections alone would make the price of the book worthwhile).You can start at Chapter One for the concepts and set up and go forward to keep building on what you know. Or just jump around to the things you know you want to do and skip the rest. Either way, this book is well explained, well illustrated and a fount of information. Definitely recommended.

This is a well made microphone, heavy, about 6" long and very professional looking. (So professional that it looks a little funny using it to take smartphone videos, but... why not? Kind of ups the "smartphone game", at least that's what I was hoping.) The cable between the mic and the smartphone is about 6' long, about the right length as you might even want someone else to hold the microphone a ttime.Things I like? I really like the quality of the construction--as good as my $200 microphone. I also really like that it is an EXR mic--fits on my near-professional Panasonic digicam perfectly (although it cautions that it is "only for mobile devices". I've never seen a mobile device that allowed for an EXR cable, but they must be out there). In addition, the EXR has an adapter for the built in mic jack in smartphones and tablets--easy to put on, fits perfectly and is obviously the.way most people will be using it.It comes with an attachment that you can use with a mic stand. It also comes with a small black vinyl carrying case--about 6" long--fits the microphone but if you want your mic jack, you have to take it off before storing them together in it. It's compact and convenient.The mic jack is standard size-- 3.5 mm (1/8) jack, so it fits into pretty much all mobile devices. Mine had no problem fitting into a phone and two tablets, a laptop, etc. (Again, there is an important warning not to use it with a standard XLR cable--it is only for mobile devices so I'm not sure why it is made for an EXR cable to begin with.)The manufacturer claims that it has both omni and cardioid patterns--so it can be directional for a speaker or general noise recording for an entire room, for example. I was unable to accomplish this change no matter what I tried.  (The page of directions is only about the obvious things--connecting the audio jack adapter, nothing technical or to help with troubleshooting.)  The recessed switch was hard to reach and didn't seem to do anything, despite the claim that it switched between omni and cardioid settings and also raised or lower the gain. None of that worked, as far as I could see.When you use the mic jack you are often taking up the same jack that your headphones would have used--and I really really like that this has a split cable with its own jack that lets you plug your headphones in while using the microphone. That's a great feature.If only it worked well. :(  It did not work at all with my Android smartphone (BLU) but did work after I downloaded this app for the Kindle Fire. It definitely amplified the sound and improved vocal quality considerably. But the problem was that no matter what I did (and you can adjust it by sticking something into the Hi/Lo switch) the background sound was like you were at the ocean. Right at the shore a constant and loud "Whoosh".  If I find a solution, I'll reevaluate this and post what it is. But it's a plug and play and even after tinkering with the few options available--I'm not optimistic.  .

It was great to use these in a lot of ways. They worked well with the computer wirelessly or with an audio jack. But, of course, the real test was how they would work with PS4.At first, it was hard to figure out how to get them to work wirelesly with the PS4. There were no instructions, but basically you put the USB wireless adapter in, push and hold the Power button on the side of the headphones,, Go to "Settings" and choose "Output to headphones". Sound from "Metal Gear" transferred to the headphones,  leaving the room silent (much appreciated by others in the household).  The game playing experience was greatly improved . The helicopter sounded like you were really there--completely different from playing through the tv. Music, sound effects, speech--everything immediately sounded different and so much better.  I asked my friendly neighborhood gamer to try it and his first response was "It's amazing how much better this sounds!"The bass mode is not overpowering and added a nice depth of sound, especially compared with other headphones we've tried where the bass often overpowers you. I know someone else complained the fit was a little too small and might be good "for kids". That was not our experience.  I think kids--not too little--wouldn't have a problem, but for two different adults these were not at all small, even on the smallest adjustment. If anything, I could have made them a little smaller--if possible--but it wasn't a problem. They are adjustable so my feeling would be that they would fit the vast majority of people fine. We also found them very comfortable (and the blue light on either side looks very good).The only slight drawback was that, as others have noted, mine had a slight hum in the right ear in wireless mode--no problem at all if its not wireless--the buzz is noticeable when the game is silent, not when there is any noise. It didn't really bother me but, in fairness, I did drop off a star because -- not quite perfect. Otherwise, it was very much a "5 star" experience.

I have a small Vornado that only works at close range. I like it for what it is, but a heater that is designed for an entire room is much more useful. Like the smaller one, you can choose between two heat settings or use the fan. I really -really- like that you can set a timer to turn off automatically, as it is also used by a relative who could easily forget that its on. Also, for that same reason, it is nice to have a remote control so heat can be controlled even if you're bedridden (permanently or just for a bout of flu). That probably seems a small thing, but I love the option of not getting up to turn something off, especially late at night. As "heating requirements" are different in my household--and central heating wastes so much heat and electricity for those who don't need it while they are sleeping--this individual room unit is really great here.  It is small, easy to move or store and provides a nice, even heat.  Again, given the variety of people using it, I appreciate that it will automatically turn off if someone knocks it over or something inadvertently blocks the vent and there's no risk of anyone burning himself from touching it, even the grill isn't metal .The Vornado is compact, safe and easy to use, not a fire hazard, works well to heat a room and is very convenient with its remote control and timer. I definitely recommend it.

Two months ago,I paid $50 for Corel After Shot 2 alone.  It's included free with PaintShop Pro X8 Ultimate, so, seriously, how can you go wrong with this program?  I had a little difficulty with installation but that was, I'm convinced, the fault of the laptop (Toshiba with Windows 10--not my favorite). The supplemental dvd (with After Shot 2 and Perfect Effects 9.5 on it installed right away. (Perfect Effects, by the way, gives you lots of customizable filters and a choice of presets. I haven't done much with Perfect Effects, but I mention it for someone starting out, it would be a real confidence-builder as you see how quickly and easily your photos can be improved.) . I had to try a couple of times with the main dvd  for PaintShop, but as I say--laptop problem as the third time everything installed just fine. I mention it in case you have the same experience--the discs are fine, don't give up.This is a great program for working with photographs (and, as I say, a really good value). It has all the usual things that others do--red eye correction, face-recognition, cropping, geo-tagging, etc. One difference is with RAW. I've been trying to use RAW more (actually RAW+JPEG) and really appreciate the ease of converting RAW photos here. No, it's not super fast, but like all Corel products I've used, it's user friendly and reliable. Plus, there are such benefits of keeping a RAW file while editing your photos that I'm a believer in any software that makes it easy to do. There is also batch processing, selection tools are better and everything works--not super fast, but faster.There is a lot to like about this software.  If you've used other photo editors, you'll feel comfortable with the layout and interface, even though "layers" are a little bit different, the concept is the same. (And if you haven't used Photoshop, being introduced to layers here will make you feel more up-to-speed if you ever take on Photoshop).I'm especially a fan of Corel since they still make it possible to buy this versatile photo editing software as a disc--I am really sad and sorry to see Adobe take Photoshop to a subscription.  Corel gives you the features you'll need at a fraction of the Photoshop price--similar to PS Elements, but with added features--and puts it all still within your control by disc (no internet connection if you don't want, ever) on your own computer. All in all, this is an affordable program with all the editing tools most photo enthusiasts will ever use or want--including the ability to easily convert and work with your RAW images, a  big advantage right there, imo, that Photoshop doesn't even have.

An epilator isn't "pain free" and this one was no exception. However, it is very helpful that you can use it in the shower--at the end, with some soap, its bearable, like a lot of bee stings with some redness that faded quickly.Apart from the pain (this isn't a razor), it charged fast and I like the color (the box, on the other hand, has kind of a weird vibe, but...who keeps the box?)  I didn't find the alternate head useful or the trimmer, which was too aggressive, but others may.  I like the grip--very comfortable and easy to hold onto in the shower. Overall, it shaved smoothly and was easy to use (although, as I say, the experience was improved using it near the end of a shower).

I am always happy when I can say my cat liked something. She isn't a big eater and doesn't need a weight loss food--I worry more that she's so finicky and doesn't eat enough--but she really seemed to be looking forward to this as soon as I opened the bag. I think it has a strong fishy aroma because she actually followed me to the kitchen as I brought in the bag and then, to my amazement, got up on her back legs to get closer as I opened it. She is -never- excited about food (only about Temptations cat treats). I poured the kibble onto the plate and she practically was running into the room with me. Unbelievable!Anyway, there must be something very enticing about this. She didn't finish every piece of food (very small pellet size) but she never does--and she did eat most of it, didn't just sniff and walk away (per usual). So that was actually very exciting--a food she's enthusiastic about.  (Her excitement wore off in a couple of days, but at least she'll still eat it with her usual, "Is this the best you've got for me?" attitude.)The price at $20 a bag is pretty expensive, although I think it could last a while--no way would she eat more than half a cup a day, about 160 calories--so if its at all affordable, who wouldn't want to give their cat a kibble where the #1 ingredient is "Atlantic Pollock fresh caught from the Bering Sea"?  I aslo like that it is grain-free and gluten-free--no corn, wheat or soy (common allergens for cats)--and includes good, healthy fats like olive, canola and salmon oils.This is particularly designed for weight control (330 calories a cup), an issue that would have helped my two previous cats, but not the current one. At 12, she is just fussy and its more of an issue to get her to eat enough of anything--kibble or canned food--or to keep her interested in any food she seemed to have liked yesterday. So it's always a complete unknown how any food is going to work -- or how long she will like it.  I'm very impressed by this Solid Gold product because she's never acted like this before. I'll post more if the novelty wears off, but so far, except for the price, it seems like a very good choice with many benefits, including for an older cat like mine.

Although I initially received this through Amazon Vine, it is a product I look forward to buying more when it becomes available again . Recommended use is in spring, before the summer drought conditions come to the states where it is available for sale. But I got it in the middle of summer, in the middle of California's five year drought, so hardly ideal testing conditions.  (It is only available in states with these kinds of severe water problems: AZ, CA, CO, FL, KS, NM, NV, OR, TX, UTNevertheless, I tried it, liked it and feel that it worked. I applied most of the container to the front yard (a slight hill, so runoff can be a problem--the reason I chose that location). It was easy to shake the pellets across the lawn by holding a handful of them at a time. It says be careful of your eyes, but I had no issues. Scotts says these are safe for vegetables and animals so that was important, too.We are restricted to watering twice a week now and the grass was looking pretty bad. The soil is not a clay-type, but is hard and I liked the idea that this product was designed to force water deeper into the soil and at the same time reduce water needs by 2/3s.There is no real way to measure how much water one is saving because our use is already so restricted that many things are just dying. However, after three weeks--still no rain, no clouds--the front yard was looking greener, even I could say a bit more lush, than it had the previous month. Since nothing else had changed, water-wise, I do attribute the difference to Scotts--and under less than ideal conditions. We are expecting heavy rains this fall and spring, and I plan to use this next year before the start of summer as even El Nino isn't going to fix our drought for 2016 and I really do think this product helped considerably, as intended.

I asked someone if he liked it. He studied it critically for a moment. "Is it real?" then "Was it expensive?" I understood the questions came because this pretty necklace does look prettier and more expensive in person than in the picture. I was surprised how pretty it was, actually. It is quite delicate--not only the thin chain (which is a little hard to fasten with the small clasp--my only complaint)--but the pendant itself which I found much prettier, more delicate and more like fine jewelry in person. The gold plating to me looks like real gold jewelry and the topaz are pale sky blue, but not clear, just enough color and sparkle to go with an outfit in a tasteful way. It is a bit dressy, but can "dress up" something casual as well. Very nice piece, about 1 1/4" long.

This is pricey, no question, but it's also a very high quality kibble. The first ingredient is chicken and there are many great natural ingredients  including probiotics, omega 3 and 6, and taurine and others for heart health. Healthy grains only--brown rice and barley--no corn meal.  It includes anti-oxidents like vitamin C and E. and healthy foods including carrots, pumpkin, cranberries, blueberries, broccoli, almond oil, kelp and lentils" I was wondering if it might be -too- nutritious and not taste good, but that wasn't the case at all.The kibble is a good size and a little water releases the aroma. The dogs gobbled it up. Loved it.  This formula is 385 calories a cup and intended for active dogs. If your dog is sedentary they have others that are equally good for them but lower in calories. Great product.

I like these earrings very much. They are about the size of a quarter--a good size, dangling, and the filigree design is very pretty.  The finish--gold plate over sterling silver--was perfect and people assume they are gold.  The clasp is well made, very easy to open and secure--and they are comfortable to wear all day, much lighter than they appear. They are attractive and easy to notice and go with nearly everything. I'm very pleased.

This is the kind of product where a review is not "one size fits all" since there's a certain amount of personal taste and individual "feel" preferences involved. These are not fancy, but my feelings about them is very positive.They say "hipster" but fit over my hips which actually I prefer. They are soft cotton, no nylon liner which again, I prefer. These are not delicate, beautiful panties, and they have no ornamentation on them, but they are very good for basics. The solid colors were fine--again, the basics: brown, black, pink and white. Mainly, I liked the fit, the soft comfortableness (the elastic doesn't bother me) and the affordable price. I was pleased.

I've never taken biotin outside of a general multimineral/vitamin pill but now I've read some reasons why I should have been doing it all along. Biotin is useful for so many things--cell growth (including hair and skin), fat metabolism and possibly (per internet) "even helping to maintain a steady blood sugar" (and--possibly--helping with MS). I've tried this, a little worried about 5000 mg just because I don't take large doses of things, but everything I've read says there are no side effects--and I haven't had any--and a lot of possible benefits. I think my hair looks a little shinier and fuller but that could be wishful thinking. However, I'm positive that the biotin has made my fingernails stronger.I also like it that this capsule includes 222mg (22% RDA) of Calcium. Calcium is so difficult to get enough of so getting this boost is great.It seems to work--no side effects--and a lot of possible benefits. A good idea.

I don't envy people who develop food for cats. They are such picky eaters! Even when they like something, they often don't like it for very long. That's how my cat is--picky, picky, picky!So it's always great to try new food in the hope--hope!--that this will be the magic one that she'll love and eat forever.  At first glance, the Nutro food looked promising. Unlike another reviewer, I thought it smelled perfectly fine (in all three flavors--turkey; chicken and tuna and salmon).  It's called "sliced" but is actually "minced" which I thought might make it even more appealing (it didn't). They are all in "savory sauce", but in all but the turkey, it didn't seem so much "saucy" as "not dry". The turkey actually had some broth, although of course you get more actual food the other way. (I say this as someone who is forced to buy the Fancy Feast Broths for my cat-- $1.79 each for a packet with a teaspoon of food and a lot of liquid. So these little 3 oz cans--about the size of the CANNED Fancy Feast--which my cat also won't eat--seemed like very good portions by comparison).I couldn't read the microscopic list of ingredients even with reading glasses, so I got help. For the turkey, in order, they are: turkey broth, turkey, turkey liver, pork broth, egg product, natural flavors, minerals (about 30), xanthan gum, and taurine. It uses NO grain. So...very good ingredients. They should let you see them.I liked that these flavors are especially made for cats who "like chunks of meat in sauce" and are designed "with tender meaty pieces that are easy for cats to pick up with their tongues".  Sounded perfect for my cat but...alas...she lapped up a little here and there (preferred the chicken & tuna, then the turkey and last the salmon), but most of it remained on the plate (luckily the crows love it).  I'm going to try again, leaving it for her overnight which may work better.Since cats are so individual in their tastes, and since--like other Nutro pet foods we've tried--is a very good product, I would recommend trying one of each flavor in the hope that at least one would "be a hit".  It could happen and I think it's worth the effort (and price).

Things I liked a lot: the selections, including "Sway" which you don't find that often in these jazz play-alongs and which has a nice bossa nova beat. There's a mix of slow, medium and fast songs which is nice when you're learning or mixing practice level to skill level.Of course, the concept itself is great--four different lead sheets for each song--for B-flat, E-flat, C, and Bass clef instruments--to play along with the track on the CD.I also like the full CD arrangements with the melody track, very nice and it sounds good when you play along with it.  The Table of Contents is a little confusing at first. Basically there are two arrangements for each song--two tracks each. (1) Split Track/Melody -- Woodwind, brass, keyboard and mallet players can play along with this.  Bass players can play along by removing the bass track by turning the left channel off.  Keyboard and guitar players can perform with it by tuning the piano off with the right channel.(2) Full Stereo track -- this is a rhythm section for soloists or groups.What I didn't like:  (I think of myself as a "high beginner" so please take that into account for the following. It's possible that my skill level (or lack thereof) makes a difference here):I don't "get" the stereo track. To me, it sounds completely unrelated to the music.  Similarly, there's a section of every Split/Melody track that has rhythm only, no melody and it seems completely useless as accompaniment if you're trying to play along.  Possibly this is a fault of the CD player, although I also tried it on the computer which definitely had two channels. I wish they didn't put that part in the middle on the melody track.

The current SAT will be administered until January 2016 and then will be replaced by this new one. It is completely redesigned, with big changes and a new stated philosophy. After taking one of the 8 practices in this book, if I were in high school, I would quickly take the current SAT and not wait for this new one. However, if that's not an option, I'd definitely get this book. This is very different from the old SAT test. The new one tries to eliminate any advantage from memorizing things in advance (like vocabulary) and aims at testing higher level thinking skills in all areas as much as possible. Practice with the format--lots of it--will help.This is the first new SAT design since 2005 and reflects a new philosophy at the College Board which designs it.  Students are no longer asked vocabulary words in isolation but in the context of 400-750 word reading passages. (This is not as easy as one might think. For example, in one of the Kaplan practice passages, the word "casual" was used in a sentence to describe the "observer" and you were given four choices for its meaning in that story--"careless, occasional, comfortable, or relaxed" . I chose "careless"--secondary meaning of it--and still disagree with their "correct" choice. However, they made a case for it, and I understood better how to decide between two possibilities in the future. These practices really do help you quickly narrow it down to the two best choices and eliminate one. (The correct answer, by the way, was "occasional").The Old SAT had: 3 Critical Reading sections 20-25 minutes each 3 Math sections 10-25 minutes each 3 Writing sections 10 - 25 minutes each 1 Essay test (25 minutes) 5 answer choices for multiple-choice questions 'The New SAT has:' Reading: 1 65-minute Evidence-Based Reading section' Language:  1 35-minute Evidence-Based Language and Writing section' Math -- 55-minute section with calculator' Math -- 25-minute section without calculator' 1 Essay test (optional) - 50 minutes' 4 answer choices for multiple choice questionsOn the pre-2016 SAT, the highest possible score is 2400, The New SAT is going back to a highest score of 1600, with the essay an additional separate score.The changes are dramatic as you can see by the list above, and they say to "expect an increased emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, and data analysis.".I think these Kaplan practices did an excellent job of capturing the feeling of this SAT and helping a student get used to practicing the various ways of extracting information from the reading (whether in the reading test itself, or language or math) and applying it. I really like the way they gave the answers--categorizing them as "easy, medium, hard", explaining the skill needed, and often elaborating on why the answer was correct. I didn't expect to miss any at my age, but I did, and as I worked through the problems, I had a better understanding why I had missed them. Taking all 8 practice tests would definitely be helpful--not only did I improve from the first to the second but, more important, I felt more comfortable with the format after finishing the first one. Eight practices would be useful.Whether it's math, language or reading comprehension, you have to be a great reader for this new SAT, so practices like this are be very important.  That's why I'd recommend LOTS of practice, to build up those reading skills, improve note-taking ability and working back and forth from the questions to the information. (Also to prevent your eyes glazing over from the sheer number of words everywhere. This is nothing, if not tedious, and maintaining concentration in three hours of reading and answering gets tough).Reading.
