In the reading passages (which now are ALL longer, 450-700 words), everything is about understanding a passage or line in the context of the overall meaning of the article. There's also a new kind of question, that has you support your previous answer by reading four different passages from the article and choosing the one that supports your answer to the previous question. On the one hand, this can help you catch a mistake with your previous answer when you can't find support for it. (That happened for me once) But it's also pretty word-heavy, sophisticated reading skill even at my age and I think most of the time, people won't catch mistakes, but will just make a second one, by choosing the wrong supporting statement for the wrong previous answer, thereby doubling their mistakes.  Again, practice helps.Language:  There are no more "obscure" vocabulary words tested in isolation. Now they're all in the context of sentences and passages that require more interpretation and understanding.  Worse, in my opinion, is that writing is now tested as part of "Writing and Language", rather than through the essay. This isn't really testing your "writing", to me, it is testing "editing". You are (again) given paragraphs or passages to read and then asked about word choices, whether a grammatical structure works or needs changing, what stylistic change would improve it, etc.This requires reading through four fairly long phrases of possible answers and then going back to the original and re-reading the paragraph. Again, being able to keep up one's concentration is very important. If you're not a good reader, or start getting tired, I could see the mountain of words in all three skills tested--reading, writing and math--getting overwhelming at some point and leading to a lot of guessing.Math.  In the old SAT you could use a calculator throughout with the math.  Now they've limited the use of a calculator. There's one 20 minute section with a calculator--and one without. (Here's one of the "without" questions that Coleman gave as an example: " The gas mileage for Peters car is 21 miles per gallon when the car travels at an average speed of 50 miles per hour. The cars gas tank has 17 gallons of gas at the beginning of a trip. If Peters car travels at an average speed of 50 miles per hour, which of the following functions f models the number of gallons of gas remaining in the tank t hours after the trip begins?")Coleman explained why there's been the shift away from calculators: "The math section will focus on data analysis and real world problem-solving, algebra and some more advanced math concepts -- areas that most prepare students for college and career."  He added, "No longer will it be good enough to focus on tricks and trying to eliminate answer choices. We are not interested in students just picking an answer, but justifying their answers."  That gives you some idea of what this is like.Many of the math questions are multi-step solutions embedded in a lengthy paragraph. In addition to being very wordy, the math sections (both with and without calculators) are very visual. There are many graphs and diagrams to interpret in order to answer the questions and often a selection of formulas to choose from as the correct way to set up the problem. I know I said it before, but there is a LOT of reading, lots of wordiness, on every section of this test.Essay:  The essay is now optional (adding 50 minutes to the 3 hour test if you choose to take it)., and will be scored separately. In the old days, it was about the writing itself and your reasoning, not about whether your facts were right.  Now, facts matter and the essay--same question for every test which seems odd--also is scored based on how well you understand and evaluate the writer's argument. If I were a student taking this new SAT, there's no way I would make the essay optional. I'd take it, because this test is difficult.One interesting change is that with the new SAT you will no longer be given a penalty for wrong answers.  It is easy to run out of time, so that's something everyone should know: no blanks! DO guess!There are so many changes but Coleman has an interesting plan for helping students prepare. The College Board is partnering with Khan Academy to offer test preparation free online beginning in spring of 2016 (check for some things that may be uploaded earlier). That is an intentional challenge to Kaplan and other test prep companies because Coleman's stated goal in doing this is to "remove any unfair advantage that wealthier students have in being able to pay for SAT preparation classes". That sounds good, and the idea that they're contracting with Khan to offer "free prep" might put pressure on the SAT design to be something students can really prepare for, even if it won't require much rote memorization.After going through the Kaplan practice tests I think if I were a student, I'd be practicing all the time for this--with this book, with the other Kaplan book with the 3 full tests, with Khan Academy online....everything. It's not something you would want to take blind--or just cram for with one prep course.  I found this book well organized, with an excellent variety of examples--a good difficulty level (range), and very helpful.

The 8 songs are classics, among my favorites from Stevie Wonder.  The arrangements were a little disappointing, emphasizing the rhythm on the backing--this isn't like having a combo behind you. It's still fun to practice and play along with--to hear it played at the right speed and learn to keep up. It's easy in concept but challenging for a high beginner. The first track gives you the piano with it, the second one is the backup only. What I really liked was how it looped throughout it more than once, so you really have the chance to "get it".The disappointment was just how little of the song is included--for example, I really got it for "Isn't She Lovely". It has the lead line and below it a treble and bass easy-ish arrangement, plus the chords noted above and it's in the right key --E major-- even if it is challenging with 4 sharps. However, it only spans two  pages, meaning it's just the first verse, no chorus, none of the interesting bass line. I had to go to Youtube for that but it would have helped to have the complete sheet music. With 8 songs only, I really thought it would have included the full songs at this price, since it isn't like other books in this price range that have arrangements in various keys for several different instruments..

This is the first Nexxus product I've tried and I'm a fan! It did an amazing job smoothing and de-frizzing my fine, color-treated hair.  Of course, it can't "put back" hair that isn't there, but for some reason, it just doesn't look as broken and frizzy as before.It must be the ingredients they tout so much--"elastin protein" and "marine protein".  I wasn't sure what "elastin protein" was, but it is apparently (per "WiseGeek"), "a protein found in the skin and tissue of the body that keeps it supple...Elastin listed as an ingredient in anti-aging skin care products are not from human sources; they typically are harvested from either cows or birds and in theory should promote better skin elasticity."Similarly, I didn't know what "marine collagen" was and found out (same source), that, " Marine collagen is a material derived from the substance found on fish scales. It has been widely used in Japan for many years as a natural supplement. People who use this substance claim it has various benefits, which include healthier bones and skin." WiseGeek.com adds, with some relevance to this conditioner, that "Collagen production is vital to healthy skin, hair, bones and joints.... Often, vitamin makers will put collagen in with vitamins as an extra bonus for skin, hair and nails." So, seems like a good thing, if you don't mind that cows, birds or fish may have been used to produce it.The conditioner with all these collagens in it, did the job as promised. My fine, thick, wavy, somewhat heat-damaged and frizzy below-shoulder-length hair looked smoother and healthier, much less frizzy and color/sun damaged after I used this a couple of time. (Leave it on for 3 minutes after shampooing then wash it out--no problems with the washing, even though it looks dense coming out of the bottle. You don't need much, even with long hair.)  Nice look, definitely healthier and I like the idea that it can somehow actually "reinforce the cuticle wall" and make hair more resistant to breaking. So far, so good! I'm impressed and surprised!

Updated: Okay, I really love this airboard. It sounds good and couldn't be any more fun to play. Love the design, the colors of the melodia and the case. I want to give it a full "5 stars" but the mouthpiece just doesn't fit. (See below for an inexpensive solution if you have the same problem. After buying the usual mouthpiece and extension tube for it (altogether it cost $6), 20.9" Length Plastic Flexible Melodica Pianica Tube w Mouthpiece I'm having a blast with this. Wish I could rate it higher than "4"--I actually prefer the mouthpiece and extension to the bendable mouthpiece this comes with--but, well, shouldn't it be more or less perfect on arrival?  But apart from that one problem, I really do recommend it.*****Original review:  First I ordered the most familiar Hohner melodica, the 32 key one in black (it also comes in blue or red, for a higher price although they are otherwise the same). Hohner 32B Piano-Style Melodica Black_ I tested it with my tuner and the pitch, to my surprise, was near-perfect (tuner showed slight variations, but not enough to register as either a sharp or a flat. Very acceptable). It was fun to play, so much fun that I gave it to someone who wanted one, too (for under $40, it makes a nice gift).When I came to order another, I found this one. It, too, had the same consistent pitch, and the tone. was also very good, just like the black Melodica above. Although this one is more expensive and the description indicates it has a different construction, I felt that playing it--and the sound--were pretty much the same. Possibly the keys on this one have more consistent action, possibly a little smoother, but if that's so it is subtle.I really enjoy the colors--bold and cheerful--and like the boldness of the case as well, I kept this instead of getting another 32B. (And kudos to Hohner for going so bold and colorful. This is not a  conventional look and to me suits the "feel" of a fun, street-jazz kind of instrument..Design-wise there were two things that I didn't like, one small and one important. The small one was that the case--which is soft--only unzips on one end and partially around each side, meaning you have to reach in and take the airboard/melodica out. I actually preferred the 32B case that unzips fully on three sides and partially on the fourth, meaning that you can  lay it flat and  open it  as a place to lay your melodica in flat and play it from there, if you wish, using the white extension tube.  The case is roomy at the top, too, about 4"This one doesn't come with a black mouthpiece or the white extension tube. However, on the plus side, it has a nice pouch on the front of the case where you can store things, including the mouthpiece and a tuner--or even a wallet, smartphone, snack or drink.The sound is very good--mostly like a harmonica (but much, much easier to play) with a little accordion thrown in.  I've heard you can bend notes b y partially pushing down a key, but have yet to successfully do it..  .It doesn't come with any documentation , but that's because it is such an easy instrument to learn. Any lead sheet or melody line will work for music, anything in the range that doesn't go below "F" below middle "C".  I had a lot of Fake books for piano in "C" and  they were naturals for it  This is a great instrument to introduce someone to playing music,  and is often used for that in schools in Asia.All in all, this is a very enjoyable instrument, you can play well solo or with others and a great gift as well, either as the airboard or the more traditional looking melodicas in black, blue or red. It's lots of fun..

I saw the new "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert" debut this week and his band leader, Jon Batiste plays one (check Youtube for clips of him playing a melodica). As soon as I saw it, I had to have one. It just looked so fun and online info made it sound easy and so versatile--a little like a saxophone, a little bit like an accordion--and a lot like a giant harmonica (that is much easier to play).  I've read these sometimes play a little sharp (but still fine), so I was actually surprised to test this inexpensive 32B melodia with my tuner and find that every key was pitch perfect (what variations there were weren't enough to register as a sharp or flat). Really surprised! It sounds great.Despite having a keyboard, the melodica doesn't sound at all like a piano because when you blow into the mouthpiece and press down a key, your breath crosses a reed that vibrates under that key. It's a woodwind that's "free-reed"--you just blow into it--and the sound is produced like a harmonica which is also considered a free-reed instrument (and, of course, has historically been Hohner's specialty. Hohner also were the ones who developed the melodica, back in the 1950s. Because they have the trademark, the other companies making them--Yamaha, Suzuki, Hammond, etc.--have to call their melodicas something different--a pianica or melodeon, or "MYlodica", etc. But they're all the same idea as this, with slightly different designs, and different tones, build quality, action and performance, sometimes--but not always--related to price.) If you like the feeling of hitting piano keys, this is much easier to play than either a harmonica or an accordion. As Lauren Bacall said in the movie "To Have and Have Not" (in a different context, but it works), "You just put your lips together and blow."The melodica's simplicity is probably why there are no directions with this, nothing at all, except a sturdy padded case with a carrying strap (about 18" long case) and inside the black mouthpiece (which I greatly prefer) and the white tubing that you can use if you are carrying it, or more commonly, if you put it on the table to play flat while you blow through the tube. That's an easy way to practice, but it looks a little strange. Because there aren't any instructions, I've included the few things that I do know about playing this below.You can regulate the sound (which can be pretty loud--and I like that because beginning an instrument its often difficult to get decent volume). Blowing gently makes it softer which seems obvious, and harder of course makes it louder--and you can vary the dynamics in between more than I expected. Experiment with your breath control to see.  It is a nice single note instrument that can solo or accompany others (guitarists can keep the guitar in their lap and switch back and forth pretty easily).Yes, you can make chords, but personally, I like the single note (or paired notes) sound better for this. JMO. You don't always tongue each note like, for example, with a clarinet, because you'll usually tie a whole phrase together with one breath. But you should try the attack at the beginning of each breath, by seeing whether saying "two" or "do" or "who" gives a better sound for that phrase. Someone said that if you can get a growling breath coming from low in your throat it sounds a bit like a saxophone but I have not been able to do anything like that. Still trying.For sheet music, just find songs that you like where the low note doesn't go below "F".  I've found that "C" fake books work well--play the melody/lead, adding partial chords here and there as needed.. Simplified classical music works too, if it has a strong melody line.After about 30 minutes, the melodica will have accumulated some saliva so depress the "spit valve" at the bottom end, remove the mouthpiece, shake the body gently, and then blow gently while holding the spit valve. I've actually found most moisture is in the mouthpiece so have something handy to shake that into as well . Surprisingly, people who've taken these apart after much use find them very clean inside--nothing like dirt or mold, etc. like you might expect. Maybe whatever residue remains evaporates quickly.Unlike some other melodicas (like Yamaha), Hohner has a hand strap for your left hand. This is very nice to keep it steady. You can also lay it flat on a table or in the case, and use the tube.I also like the Hohner "Airboard" (basically the same instrument sound-wise, but very colorful and a little more expensive.)Hohner AIRBOARD32 32-Key Airboard with Bag  All in all, to me, whether you choose the 32B or the similar airboard or a different style altogether, if you like the sound of harmonica and want to get that sound in a very easy and fun way, the melodica is a great choice..

The ET4500 --an ink-jet, not laser, printer--came perfectly packed in Epson's large box--no chance of damage en route. Unpacked, it was a good desk size model--about ... wide and ...deep and ... tall. It looks nice and was easy to move.The set up directions were easy to follow. Do take their advice and wear gloves when pouring in the ink. The 4 bottles come extremely carefully packaged--separately--and open easily by removing the inside foil cover and then just easily popping off the top. I put down plastic as directed but there was "0" spillage. However, removing the foil lining, while easy, did get ink on my fingers because there is a residue underneath it if you're not -very- careful. (They warn you about this in the directions, but I was too confident. It wasn't much, but it doesn't wash off.)It is easy to fill the reservoirs--just turn the bottle over. Be sure to put each color in the correct reservoir--cyan, magenta, blue and black. You run the CD in your computer, plug in the printer and it found my wifi network on its own.This might seem a little pricey, except for all that it does. Also, that Epson promises a good savings on the cost of ink. They claim roughly 4000 copies per "load" or about the cost of 20 cartridges. The b/w printing was fine. The color as accents were fine. But personally, if I were printing photos, I still think it would be cheaper to do it through Walgreen's etc. Personally, I would print photos in color as kind of "rough drafts" to see what I wanted to change before sending them out. But if you want to use it for photos, it does have the color combination to do it and does fine with it.  The copies were good and clean, but if you need double sided, you need to flip the pages (not so bad for a few pages, but if you do that routinely the ET 4550 or other duplex printer would probably be a better choice).I had no problem printing from my computer. I scanned a bill into it without problem and was also able to use the fax without difficulty.  The booklet is clear for what it says, but there's little about troubleshooting. (Just FYI, if you do have a problem, you can download the drivers at the Epson website).All in all, it's a good looking, easy to set up and versatile machine that should also prove economical over time, due to the ink bottles rather than cartridges (and Epson has a recycling number you can call when that time comes).

The publisher describes this as an "authorized biography", which is true, in that the author was a close friend of Gore Vidal's for many years. Vidal was happy about Jay Parini's plan to write this biography and gave him full access to friends and papers and lots of shared conversation and life experiences. But, since it was written and published after Vidal's death (in 2012), it is probably (fortunately) more candid than the word "authorized" usually implies. Parini makes a sincere attempt--from the introduction on--to wear both hats--that of a devoted and admiring friend (who saw in Vidal a mentor and a father-figure) and that of an objective biographer who is writing about an important American man-of-letters.The friend usually trumps the biographer, I think, but a lot of that may be for the best (for example, he tells more than enough--but probably not too much, considering the role it plays in his writing--about Vidal's homosexuality. For those who want even more details, he refers you to another book by a different author, "In Bed with Gore Vidal". Would that all biographers had that option!)Parini was a Vidal friend, not his lover, and this too is probably a good thing. Because that friendship is such a big subtext here, I was interested how Parini's wife and children don't seem to have contact with Vidal although for others--like Paul Newman's kids, he was a genial "uncle" figure. For some reason, I particularly wondered about Parini's wife--did she know him, too? Like him? Not want to spend more time together than necessary? We never know. After all, Vidal does seem like he could be pompous and cold if he didn't like you--too ascerbic, too self-centered ( even often too drunk) and so might not be to everyone's liking, particularly if they're not willing to subsume their interests to his, as I think the author indicates that he was very willing to do, always. It may seem a trivial question, but I think Parini is a protective friend and has left out some of the uncomfortable, unpleasant parts of knowing Gore Vidal for those who didn't make him the center of attention..There were some surprises in this book. For example, on the "early life" front, like many, I had assumed Vidal came from an upper class family. That was not, as Parini makes clear, exactly the case. His father was born in small town South Dakota , such a talented athlete that he was recruited by West Point mid-college,. then went on to the Olympics in 1920 and 1924. Later became a pilot (and the great love of Amelia Earhart)  and an aviation pioneer, co-founding three airline companies, including TWA and Eastern, and the Boston and Maine Railroad.--so he -was- wealthy, but as a self-made man (and "married-into-it" money), while Gore was growing up. He also had strained relations with his son, several troubled marriages and problems with alcohol--something Vidal seems to have shared.Vidal detested his mother who -was- born into high society. But it was her divorce from Vidal's father and marriage to wealthy Hugh Auchincloss later, that gave Vidal the connection to the Kennedys, since Hugh later remarried again and became Jackie Kennedy's stepfather. Vidal had a testy and increasingly distant relationship with the Kennedys and Parini doesn't quite show quite how obnoxious Vidal could be (for example, he doesn't mention Vidal's derogatory attitude toward JFK's lifelong best friend, Lem Billings, calling him JFK's "slave" even making gay slurs about Billings who was, like Vidal, a gay man--but, unlike Vidal, a very very constant and loyal, UNself-centered friend.  Parini does describe one White House dinner party that Vidal attended and I could understand why Bobby Kennedy wanted nothing to do with Vidal afterward. And no, it wasn't because Vidal was gay, although he liked to think so. RFK travelled with Billings who was gay--but, unlike Vidal, at a White House dinner Billings was respectful and socially appropriate.  Bobby Kennedy--like Gore Vidal, I suspect--didn't suffer fools gladly.)Vidal's nastiness toward Billings' as being too subservient to JFK particularly struck me as surprisingly lacking in self-awareness since Vidal seemed to require more acolytes than anyone, whether friends like Parini or his longtime companion (not a monogamous relationship), Howard Austen.  Unequal relationships seemed the name of the game for him.For all his air of erudition and education, it also came as a surprise to me to learn that, after graduating from prep school, Vidal had never gone to college. Instead he went into the army (the setting for his first book, Williwaw).  But he read widely, and deeply about history, and--college or not--was an intellectual and at ease with his well educated peers. His output of fiction was really astonishing, even writing mysteries as "Edgar Box", a pulp novel as "Cameron Kay", and several teleplays, including the well received "Visit to a Small Planet" and, for the stage, "The Best Man: A Play about Politics". The latter was also made into an excellent movie, still available on dvd, starring Henry Fonda as a character who was considered modeled on Kennedy, Cliff Robertson as a rival "Tricky Dick" type and Lee Tracy as an incumbent president reminiscent of Harry Truman). The Best ManParini, as a close friend, often smoothes out Vidal's narcissistic edges and mutes his sarcasm so that we see more of his warmth and wit and fewer flashes of the meanness. This tender approach to Vidal is fine for the personal things and it was nice to see that he was a warmer, more generous and kindly friend than I had envisioned, less self-involved and self-destructive than many of his literary peers, rivals, and sometimes-friends like Tennessee Williams or Truman Capote (the latter who was never really a friend, and occasionally was the target of some of Vidal's more cutting remarks--as well as one lawsuit.)Vidal, handsome, with a dignified manner and resonant baritone --plus his own desire to be considered bisexual rather than homosexual which he considered "degenerate"--had a different public persona than Williams and Capote did when it came to sexual orientation. So it is very interesting that Gore Vidal, as the writer who was less "out", was the one who wrote about homosexual characters with (at the time shocking) openness in his novel "The City and the Pillar" while Williams and Capote shied away from it.  [per Wikipedia In 1948, The New York Times book critic, Orville Prescott, was so offended by the homosexual content of The City and the Pillar, that he refused to review it or have anyone else at the NYT review it.] "The City and the Pillar" was a very courageous novel in 1948--and would still be controversial today.Parini reminds us that from the beginning Vidal's novels always dealt with very interesting and often unexpected situations and themes. In the 1960s  he wrote "Julian" about the Roman Emperor who fought against Christianity spreading through the Roman Empire and then tried to bring back polytheism;  "Washington, D.C." was about the time of the  Franklin D. Roosevelt presidency (even though Vidal, like his grandfather, Senator Gore, didn't care much for FDR, writing to his grandfather when Roosevelt died, "The king is dead, long live the president."); and "Myra Breckenridge", which is alternately considered "his worst" and "a mess" or "hilarious satire".  I read Myra Breckenridge in my teens and remember feeling shocked through the first part, then laughing that it was so completely over-the-top and ridiculous through the rest, eventually shrugging it all off as hit-or-miss satire that didn't seem particularly funny or tragic, just pointlessly absurd..Now, reading Parini's description of "Breckenridge" and thinking about the gender discussions in 2015, I think it probably was much more perceptive and original than I appreciated at the time and deserves to be reread and reevaluated, not just ridiculed. In Parini's assessment of "Breckenridge",  Vidal sounds quite a bit ahead of his time in his thoughts about gender roles and gender identification.If nothing else, this biography should remind people that Vidal was not just a good novelist but that he wrote about interesting original topics in a thought-provoking way--hopefully,Parini's biography will encourage more reading of Vidal's work--it has for me--particularly as he isn't anthologized like many other writers of his time.And it is stunning to be reminded of just how much work there was. He even wrote a story about an alternate universe ("Duluth") and a time travel story "The Smithsonian Institution". And "Washington DC"  became the first part of a series of historical novels in his "Narratives of Empire". (The others were "Burr", "Lincoln"--both critically well received--"Empire", "Hollywood" and "The Golden Age".Also refreshingly different are the religious/philosophical novels--"Live from Golgotha" about an early Christian bishop,  the novel "Kalki" about the end of the world, and "Creation", which he considered his best work (and the one I most want to read now). The premise is so complicated that I'm giving the link: Creation: A Novel  Parini's description of how the publisher demanded that Vidal delete 4 key chapters in "Creation" is painful to read--but gives a welcome insight into the realities of being a professional writer. Good to know that in 2002 he was able to restore those chapters to the book and republish it.  And somehow in all this writing he found time to write a memoir "Palimpest" and then its sequel.I liked and appreciated that Parini mentions each work in some detail (ambitious, since Vidal was incredibly prolific) including the premise and approach and also the critical response to it. My one disappointment here is similar to the criticism Vidal and Parini had of a biography they read, "It lacks a strong narrative."  The sad thing here is that a strong narrative was handy--if Parini had shown more about the political developments in Vidal's lifetime that increasingly radicalized him (and he did not become that cliche--"the liberal turned conservative" as he aged.  Agree or disagree, he was always a trenchant social critic with the courage of his convictions. Unfortunately, those are little on display here, nor are the events that shaped them.)Maybe Parini doesn't share Vidal's left-leaning politics that openly had him speaking out against American foreign policy for the last 40+ years. Or maybe he doesn't want to turn off a lot of readers because it was his politics and his blunt talk about what was wrong with the American (Eisenhower's words) "military-industrial complex" and now also "national security state"--not his sexuality--that made Vidal so controversial, even reviled, by many Americans--and would still do so--more than ever--today.  As a political critic, Vidal's thoughts still have teeth and they are still relevant and important to ponder in their boldness. We miss much of that provocative "sting" here.Not to say there isn't some--the gratuitous (and unfair) verbal sniping at Bobby Kennedy after his assassination. The interesting (and strange) correspondence with Oklahoma bomber Timothy McVeigh (and even Vidal gave up on trying to make McVeigh a sympathetic figure).  His thoughts on 9/11, Cheney and oil, and the Iraq war. And yet, like the writings spurred by the Vietnam war--they all get short shrift as far as historical fact goes. It's too bad, because the changing history of America in the 20th/21st centuries--and how Vidal changed with it--would have given it the narrative direction it lacks and prevented it being so much about traveling here or there, seeing these various famous friends or writing this work or that.For example, the notorious televised exchange between Vidal and the condescending rightwing publisher of the National Review, William Buckley Jr, at the Democratic Convention in 1968 is given several pages. But the context of this exchange and that violent convention--President Johnson having 500,000 troops fighting in Vietnam by 1968 accompanied by massive bombings (plus over 55,000 American casualties; and over 2 million Vietnamese killed, mostly civilians)--is barely mentioned. Historical events are often a much-needed context here and they don't appear very much. Sadly, neither do Vidal's critical thoughts about them in interviews and essays--an unfortunate lack and it also keeps us from the vitality of his "voice".He was blunt in his criticism of the Patriot Act--but we don't learn about that here. You will read it elsewhere that he called George W. Bush "the stupidest man in the United States".  Or his critique of American foreign policy, that he felt it was not as Bush said, because of being hated "for our goodness" but, per Vidal, for the greed of oil interests and other multi-national corporations, and a government that was comfortable with deposing democratically elected leaders--and starting wars--on behalf of corporate America. Vidal was blunt in labeling the defense of "freedom fighters" and the claims of "spreading democracy" as simplistic propaganda.  He liked to challenge Americans' assumptions and beliefs about ourselves and our country and point out when he felt that government was lying. More of that voice of Vidal-as-social-critic would have made this a less amiable but more thought-provoking (if also more controversial) book. Somehow more controversy would have been fitting, though, for a biography of Gore Vidal.Parini does cover Vidal's own two political campaigns although again, without his anger or passion for things to change.  It would have been interesting to read one of his speeches, as a writer (philosopher?)-turned-politician.As time passed, Vidal lost his place on late night television and was left getting his critiques of American political power out at the National press Club speeches. We read about that, also his disappointment that there was no longer an audience for him as there was in the days of Johnny Carson. But one wonders if Youtube videos plus a blog might have been rewarding, had someone taken the time to do it with him. Vidal might have found a natural presence in social media, but perhaps by then he was already feeling too old--or had no one to initiate it with him. A loss, as he was a natural for Twitter--even as he undoubtedly would have mocked the development of social media.Parini resolved the problem of how much of himself to interject by wisely starting each section with a personal anecdote about Vidal. This gives us a story, a personal tidbit, but does not interrupt the flow of chapters. And he starts many chapters with some of Vidal's witticisms, but they are the "clever" ones, not quotes that make you really think about the world you live in. Perhaps Parini felt "the real Vidal", complete with his political views, would turn off too many readers.  I certainly didn't care for his remarks about the Kennedys (or think they were fair) and many wouldn't like to see Ronald Reagan called "a triumph of the embalmer's art", even if it was a double play on his age and what Vidal saw as the outmoded age of Reagan's ideas. Still, that was his voice and it would be a better book to hear it.Oddly, one of the most disappointing things to me in this book was the description of Vidal's will. It is only a postscript following his death in 2013--but, without adding a spoiler, it greatly disappointed me after what I had read up until then. Thinking it over though, I think it was an apt ending for a book called "Empire of Self", as I think in the end, Vidal's ego and vanity were just much stronger than his empathy and concern for those who helped him, for causes, and for friends.  Other biographers have said he died as a bitter alcoholic. If true--and Parini doesn't say so--that also would explain it.In sum, this is a good overview of Vidal's life and personality and just as much an overview of his work. For those who lived through those times, this book brings back some memories, fleshed out from Parini's knowledge behind the scenes. For those who are much younger, you may enjoy contemplating a time when America's finest writers were also some of America's most colorful and wittiest personalities--Vidal, at the top of the "witty" chart. Occasionally, as with Vidal, they also had something challenging to say about current events and politics and the ideas we believe and take for granted but which may very well be untrue. Hard to hear or not, Vidal's ideas, like his work, remain worth reading and thinking about and this is a very good introduction to him.

I've wanted this lens for a long time, but just wasn't sure about it because I already have the 35mm Fujinon XF 35mm F1.4 R. Would this really be worth it? I kept looking for one of Fuji's semi-annual sales and when it dropped to $250 last week, I took the plunge.Very very glad that I did.  First, no, it doesn't lie near-flat on the camera as I'd hoped for but for $250 this is a nice alternative, The XF27 makes it a very light, very inconspicuous, snapshot-looking camera, taking much better photos than people actually expect..The XF35 is a great lens, too. Beautiful quality to the photos, wonderful in low light, beautiful bokeh.  But the XF27 really -does- feel like a different lens and makes the camera feel different. It is sharp and light and because you can boost the ISO so high with Fuji, even low light shots at f2.8 often are turning out, though of course the 35mm is better. The glass itself is a little over 1/2" in diameter, so when you're taking someone's photo it really doesn't look like you're taking "A Serious Picture". Perfect for street photography.I was very surprised that the 27mm (41mm equivalent) field of view really -does- make a big difference to me compared with the 35mm. I like the 35mm--and it is lovely for portraits--but I have to admit that it is often a pretty tight shot in some places where you can't back up. The 27mm felt like a much more comfortable, more natural framing (supposedly the closest to what our eye sees)--I really did notice a significant difference--and it gives more context for people when you -want- to see the background. Again, nice for street photography.The lens cap is tiny, with pinch edges, and I use a tether. It takes 39mm filters which are generally pretty expensive. But I got this one from Fotasy Fotasy MRC 39mm Pro 1-D Multi-Resistant Coating Super Slim MC UV HD Filterfor under $10 and it's working well  I put a comparison up to show the different FOV between the 35 and 27 (both at f5.6 for comparison). Really glad to have this, perfect addition to any kit I think (at the sale price).Note: The photos below show two different comparisons. (1) Yard shot, the left is 35mm FOV v. 27mm and (2) the brick wall shows without filter and with filter (dim lighting, but showing the comparisons).

Update:  After two weeks I unfortunately felt I should come back and reflect the frustrations (numerous) and drop it from 3 stars down to only 2. Too bad, as right out of the box it looks easily like a "4 star+ machine".  But many things just don't work.First it was the touchpad. I'm not super-techie, but I'm not afraid to go into menus and look at settings and try to fix things. There was nothing that fixed the touchpad except restoring the computer to its factory settings (but then you are no longer able to customize the setup as I had before). When I ran a diagnostic test, Windows 10 said touchpad was working perfectly! Too bad that it has been completely frozen and useless for over a week.Luckily, there is an alternative in the touchscreen. It works, but there are times when it's not the right tool for the task. I will get a mouse and see if that will work, but it seems that a touchpad should last longer than two days on a new computer.There is no dvd/CD player, but I have two external ones.  Tried both of them--neither work.  (But, good news!  The diagnostic says they're also "working perfectly"). This morning one of them at least did successfully install some software (previously I had been tryinig to play movies). So that was some improvement.But then we have the internet. My original plan--because of the data mining and security problems with Windows 10--was to use my current computers at home (Windows 7 & 8) and take the Toshiba when I'm out sometimes using Word and the internet down at Starbucks. Well, I didn't want to download the new Word because (yes, old-fashioned and security conscious) I like to install from a disc. The current Word (a free trial is offered with this machine) only is available as a download and disables features if you don't connect with the internet every 39 days or so. (Luckily I had my old Word 2003 disc which installed fine and worked just fine for my purpose--transferring an in-progress file from one computer to the Toshiba just to do some work down at Starbucks). Anyway, the old discs do work with this laptop, if you don't want to tie yourself to MS on the internet.So, there is no working touchpad, it doesn't play movies on an external dvd (does load software though). And then there's the internet problem. As I say, my first thought was to avoid all the data mining, spyware etc (I disabled what I could find, but trying to troubleshoot have discovered it's actually in quite a few different places). and just use the Toshiba--which isn't saving any important personal information--at wifi hotspots like Starbucks.This plan didn't work because neither Starbucks nor McDonalds' wifi worked.  Nor, when I finally broke down to try it, did my home internet. The network shows up (along with many others) and says its connected but it isn't.Finally, two days ago, although I'd done nothing different, it asked me to log into my router and then began working. (Meanwhile, it sent a message to another computer that uses that router asking if it could make changes to it. I didn't like that, particularly as I thought I'd disabled all those "contacting others" features. My router doesn't need anything but the password to connect.Also, at some point, it worked at McDonalds.  And then it didn't.  And after it worked at home, the following morning it wouldn't work. A diagnostic test showed there was no internet access no matter what browser I tried, although the main screen said "connected".The other desktop and laptops in the house are working fine with everything (and the laptops had no trouble at Starbucks or McDonalds).Touchpad. DVD drive. Internet access. That's a lot of things to malfunction in barely over a week of minimal use.****Original review:This was a difficult product to review. I'll try to separate the Toshiba design pros and cons from the issues with Windows 10, although of course, they are interwoven, particularly since with 128 GB RAM, this is not a computer where you can choose to install any other OS. It's a Windows 10 machine and you're pretty much stuck with it, for good and for bad.  (I will not be comparing it with the MacBooks because (1) not a fan and (2) they're about 3xs the price). This is a medium-capability, medium-to-inexpensive laptop and has strengths and weaknesses that will be of different importance/weight to different users.To begin with the positives. Right out of the box, it is a pretty silver laptop that is considerably lighter (at 5 lbs) than my current one. The case is sleek, less than an inch high, but if you don't have long fingernails it will be a challenge to open the lid. It lies very flat and there's no lip to pull up on.  Despite its 15.6" size (measured diagonally), I got this 16" Case Logic laptop case and it fits just fine and is very light. Case Logic VNA-216 16-Inch Laptop Attache (Black)The picture quality is sharp and bright (1920 x1080HD) and I didn't find the screen unusually glossy at all, as a few other reviews have said they did. Personally, I was very happy to see that MS listened to some complaints about Windows 8.0 and has made the interface here far more user-friendly. Most important, they have brought back the "Start" button with a clear menu including Control Panel and Settings (The File Explorer is conveniently already pinned to the Task Bar). It also opens to the desktop view unless you want to enable the tablet (you can choose either one at any time either from the menu, from the little button on the left side of the laptop, or from just changing the position of the touchscreen from upright to flat. Easy.)I really liked the keyboard--both that it is nicely backlit and so easy to see and also that the touch is so nice. Much better "feel" than any of my other keyboards through the years. There is a touch screen, touch pad, and you also can use a mouse if you get one (more about these three options later).  I like that it has a lot of ports--1 for a memory/SD card; 2 for USB 3.0, 1 for USB 2.0 and an HDMI port, as well as an audio jack for headphones. This is very important for my usage and many laptops (including Macs) have very few these days.I have had problems with the cursor freezing, most recently when I was activating Windows (you have to go online or call them to activate; I'd chosen "call" and a machine reads you a long set of numbers to type in. The cursor froze mid-way and would not become unstuck no matter what I tried). Luckily, in that case, it was possible to finish by using touch screen alone.I think the Skullcandy speakers are good and the sound can get nice and loud if you need it to fill a room (for example, in "presentation view" or if watching a movie at a distance); much better than my current laptops in both quality and volume.Now for some of the problems:.  First, I was surprised that it has only 128 GB of memory. Now, it's true my first computer had 4MB, but...time's moved on and you expect 500GB if not 1T these days. However, I'm making allowances for this because this has an SSD hard drive which uses up a lot of memory but is so much faster. The load time is amazing now. And 128GB will probably be enough for most people's  programs and media, unless you do a lot with video or have huge software to store. (This is not a machine for serious gamers anyway.). In any case, external hard drives are so cheap that I don't think the relatively small memory here is all that bad.  And people react in a very impressed way when they hear it has a Solid State Drive, something usually reserved for much more expensive machines.I was -very- disappointed that it doesn't have a built in DVD/CD player, though I know that's a common omission now--compounded by everyone wanting you to store things on the Cloud. Eventually the goal is "stream everything/store everything" from remote servers. I know it's the way of the technology world, but I don't like it and plan to delay that in my life as long as possible.  Not only does it not have it's own DVD/CD player, but I was even more disappointed that it couldn't work with the one plug and play, less than a year old, that  I already have, even though the troubleshooting message assured me it was "working perfectly".It says it has Media Player (although I didn't see it until I went into Settings and configured it as the default), but I have yet to get it to work. I'm going to try downloading the driver from the MS website (free) and will report back if that fixes the problem.  I had to go into settings to change the music (played off a thumb drive) default from MS's default "Groove Music" software to Media Player (Groove Music does work well though with MP3s, I haven't yet tried other kinds of files, but it seems the USB ports and music players have no compatibility issues).Now for my two biggest areas of dissatisfaction. The first is the amount of useless bloatware it comes with -- and they sit annoyingly visible on your tablet or on your desktop. Some, I was able to go in and delete. But lots of others, like Xbox Zappos, ebay and Groupon (among many others that are displayed like valued apps, but actually are just urging you to buy things online) I can't get rid of (so far). You have some options to uninstall programs and apps, but not nearly enough. There are many of them here--on the desktop, all alphabetically listed in the Startup menu--and I think that's wrong, actually. Anyone who wants them will know how to add them and where to find them. The consumer shouldn't buy a product, especially something as expensive as a computer, and be forced to look at unwanted advertisement all the time.The second --and for me, biggest-- problem is regarding privacy and security concerns with Windows 10. I had read a bit before the laptop arrived about how Windows 10 is constantly collecting data about you and beyond that has various settings (often that the user is unaware of unless you know to look for them) where your contacts and other information are automatically being shared with MS--and with others, your "contacts, friends, family" and also if people are nearby on the network you're using..I find this idea of forced (and imo sneaky) data mining unacceptable, even unethical.  If you feel the same way, my first advice is to NOT do an "Express Set up".  Do "Custom". It is easy to read through all of the choices--nothing at all complicated to do, just click "Yes" or "No". You will probably be as surprised as I was at some of the things it will do without your knowledge if you don't do this.For now, I am keeping this computer off of my home network until I'm sure it's working properly, as I'm not sure how it accesses other computers in your network and if any information is being collected and stored. More to the point, since some of the "automatically share" settings are the Windows 10 defaults, you really should go through all the "Settings" on your own too, even if you do a Custom setup since other things are embedded in various settings that facilitate sending information to MS and others.  Activating Windows was a slight hassle as I chose to do it via phone rather than the internet--still, appreciated having the choice. The Starbucks wifi hotspot that worked yesterday only gave "limited" access today and McDonald's didn't give any at all. No additional settings had been changed since yesterday, when it was working perfectly at Starbucks. And everything was working perfectly with my Windows 7 laptop which I also had with me.Basically, until I fully understand the limits and extent of the data Windows is collecting from my use and also from other computers "in my network", as well as how it is accessed by others nearby, I'm staying off my home internet and not doing anything online with this laptop that I would worry about security-wise (banking, etc.) I don't do Facebook, but I'd read up more on Windows 10 before doing social media with it either..That may seem too extreme for some, but some might be interested in considering how much access you want to give Windows 10 from the beginning. (Definitely, avoiding the "Express Setup" is a good idea, even if you don't want to go through all the other setting choices, too). Btw, you start with a 30 day free trial of McAfee but I'll probably go back to Norton, even though it will use more storage space.  For this reason--skepticism over all the information MS wants to collect, I'm not going to be using Cortana (the Siri equivalent--a data mining dream) or One Note as I can do without the MS cloud. Also I'm not configuring it with my smartphone. YMMV on all this, but for me the (slight) added convenience of these interconnections with the laptop just isn't worth it.I -do- use the Amazon cloud, reluctantly, but generally feel "less is more" when it comes to storing your information on multiple servers. I don't plan to use the MS cloud at all (beyond Windows activation) and they have a lot of ways to get you to do it on this laptop.  I recommend that you go to "Settings" and check through every sub-category. There's not that much and it will give you a good feeling for the machine, what it offers and what you are free to change. It's pretty quick and easy and if I didn't know what something meant, I just didn't change or delete it.Given a choice between Windows 8 and 10, I'd definitely choose 10 (less the spyware and bloatware). But between Windows 7 and 10 there's no question--I much prefer Windows 7.  Oh, and if you prefer Internet Explorer to Edge you can choose easily which you want to use and switch back any time. If you want Firefox, you're on your own.Re battery, it took 2 hours to charge and lasted 5 hours--very very good.online on the fly. It doesn't come with much instructions--just a warranty and a double-sided, brief "Quick Start" guide (the "On" button is on the side, top right, easy to overlook, especially if you're used to having it on the top). But that's why going into settings on your own is a good idea--and choosing "Custom" set up.Oh, and I find the rotate-able screen very convenient. I know its not good to sit at the computer too long and with "presentation view" or "tablet view" I have much more flexibility to stand or move around, or take it with me when using the treadmill or if I want to look at something while cooking. Very nice, in that respect.  I could see the large, flat tabletop style being very inviting for a team that is  standing and collaborating on a project.  The text is easy to read and there are modifications in "Settings" to help with access for visual or auditory difficulties. It's easy to enlarge things using the touchpad (actually, it was -too- sensitive, continuing to enlarge it all after I'd enlarged it slightly. But you can decrease that sensitivity in the settings).All in all, this laptop is a good looking and sounding computer with many good things about it, especially in this price range. But I'd be wary about the Windows 10 philosophy of knowing everything about you and I'd recommend to at least opt out of the Express Setup and, if you use your home internet, to avoid giving it the ability to interface with your other computers and instead use a different way of identifying/naming the network to this machine (your internet provider can help with this)..

This watch was a nice surprise--very well made and attractive at a price that's a third of the two-tone AK watches I usually get. This is my first Armitron watch and it is quite nice as well as a surprisingly good value.One correction re: other review saying the band is 1/3" wide. It is slightly over 1/2" which is not heavy, but is also not a delicate band. It is about the width of a typical woman's leather wristband. This is probably a good width for the vast majority of users, but if you like a more delicate, narrow band, I think this wouldn't be a good choice.More re: band The alternating two-tone gold/silver pattern is gives a nice textured look, good for casual use and nice for work, but not dressy. To me, although the links are even in gold and silver, I thought it looked a little more on the silver side for the band. The oblong face--again, medium+ size, not big, but not small and delicate either--is classic and modern-looking with its oblong shape, rounded at the corners. The dial doesn't have numbers, but the dots are very easy to read against the goldish/silver-ish face, and there is a second hand which I always like to have (and you can actually see the diamond accent on the dial, unlike many watches that mention "diamond" in their name). I like the slightly beveled edge on the gold around the face because it changes it in the light, sometimes going darker, near-black when you move your wrist in a strong light. Armitron is known for reliability and keeping good time.One word of caution if your wrist is so small that you -always- have to remove links when you buy a watch. This band is adjustable, with one 1/2" link that does come out (and, no, per other review, you don't need to loosen a screw to remove it. You just have to find the right side of the link and pop it open the same way you would if you were opening it to wear it, but the link will slip off if you need the smaller band. If your wrists are -very- very small, though, that one link will not be enough and because of the design of the band, there is nothing more than even a jeweler could remove. So, that would be my only caution, that this is probably not the best choice for those with very small wrists.Otherwise, it is a very nice watch that goes well with a variety of activities--and is so waterproof that you can even shower and swim with it! (I was happy about this as I often forget to take off my watch in the shower. With this one there were absolutely no problems!)  :

I am so impressed by this tuner. It is so accurate--not just giving you "A", for example, but showing you the red lights until you get the exact, pitch-perfect "A". It was a noticeable improvement to have all the strings turned so precisely. Love this!It is a nice size, too, just a shade over two inches long, with a nice clip that allows it to flip over/down for easier positioning (it doesn't rotate, but that wasn't necessary). The button is on top (narrow side).  My experience with the Polytuning was perfect--after I'd tuned the strings individually and strummed all strings open, it showed a display of all green "in tune".  When I threw one out of tune, it showed up clearly in red and was quick and easy to readjust with this tuner.  FYI, I used it for an acoustic-electric guitar, a mandolin and a Chinese erhu. Very happy with it!

I have had other cases through the year, but this one is exactly what I was looking for. It is the thinnest & lightest I have, but still comfortably fits my 16" laptop. It has a handle (as in the picture) and a loop in the back to put it around a cart for airport travel.The shoulder strap is not detachable, but I always carry it that way anyway so for me it didn't matter. I like the deep turquoise nylon lining rather than black or orange and the small USB holder inside is convenient. Outside there is a pocket that zips sideways for the power cord etc. and there is also a generous sized pouch with a zipper across the front underneath it. for even more storage--always a good thing.It is sturdy and well made but very lightweight. I like the two narrow gray stripes on the front as well, since it makes it immediately distinguishable from the other laptop bags. I'm very pleased with this attach.

I sometimes see a hummingbird in the yard, but have never fed them before. So I'm giving this product an extra star, up to 2, because its a good idea to do it, especially during our drought. (Good reminder to leave drinking water out for birds and other animals, too).The good points? This is very easy to mix, as promised.  3 oz of water (I used a pyrex measuring 1 cup--the line for 3 oz is right there) plus 4 level teaspoons of the mix. Stir for a few seconds and the powder dissolves, leaving the water clear. This is all good. (I would -never- get the one with red dye in it. Why would anyone want to give Red Dye 40, suspected of being carcinogenic, to a little hummingbird?)That said, this is not just sugar and water either, which is why I've lowered the review to two stars. Sucrose (sugar) is the first ingredient, but two other preservatives are also listed--sodium benzoate and tartaric acid. Those put me off a bit because, like the red dye, it seems like a bad idea to give artificial preservatives to hummingbirds, especially when it isn't really difficult to make your own sugar and water combination.This is good in that you don't need to boil anything--mixing is extremely quick and easy. But if you do it yourself, you don't need to give the hummingbirds the extra chemicals and it only takes a little longer to mix and boil and cool it (like making a simple syrup only instead of 1:2 you use 1:4).Just combine 1:4 ratio of regular white sugar to water (for example, mixing  1 tsp sugar to 4 tsp water or 2 oz sugar to 8 oz of water.) Heat in a pan on low flame while it dissolves for a minute or two and cool completely before putting it in your feeder. Pretty easy. I think it's better to just make a batch on your own, than to give hummingbirds artificial preservatives that are so unnecessary and may even harm them over time.

As a purse this exceeded my expectations. Knowing it had a nylon exterior, I expected it would be filmsy, but it wasn't. It's collapsible, of course, but has more sturdiness than I expected because of the cloth lining. The two front-facing pockets with magnetic closures have limited usefulness, I think,  but there is also a zippered pocket kind of concealed on the outside of the purse right behind these two.  On the other side there is another zippered pocket running across the length of the outside front.  Nice design, with a variety of zippered pockets, inside and out, impressive in such a relatively small, and inexpensive nylon bag.I was so glad to find a shoulder bag this size--not small, but smaller than any I have, a nice "medium" size.I also like that there is no flap on top--just the zipper across the top giving a quick and direct access. Inside there are  two "open" pouches on one side and a zippered pouch on the other. Sometimes it seems a little difficult to open wide enough to search for things (the interior is also black) but the zipper goes completely across the top from one side to the other, so that's probably a matter of getting used to a bag this size, about 9" across.The burgundy and purple ones look like nice colors and at the time I purchased this, they were $3 less expensive. But I wanted black, to double as a camera bag (with some Velcro and pads added inside--I've been through so many and dthis is great, and about $40 less than the closest thing--not as good--that I was looking for.)  The only negative is that the shoulder strap is about twice as wide as ost people would probably like, and doubled over, too. At least its sturdy, but it takes a little away from the nice design of the bag. (Again, a perfectly fine strap for a camera bag). Great price. A nice find.

I really like the Wellness products because the ingredients are so good and they put effort into the "presentation". It may sound funny but those with a fussy cat know that what makes them eat one thing over another can be mysterious. A lot, for mine, has to do with the smell, I think, and the texture. At the moment, the only wet food she'll eat is $1.79 small packets of Fancy Feast Broths Fancy Feast Broth for Cats Classic Tuna, Shrimp & Whitefish, Creamy Salmon & Whitefish and Classic Tuna & Vegetables, 1.4 Oz Pouch, Pack of 27 (sometimes available at $1.20, but still frustrating when she eats a little and is done with it. Seriously, I could get a day of meals at Taco Bell for the amount of food/money she wastes every day in what she rejects--and that's when she's actually eating a few bites. I think they recommend several Fancy Feast Broths a day--probably more for my cat who only licks up the broth and leaves all the chicken or fish. (Dry food is doing better for her, but I've been told its not good for the kidneys for cats to have -only- dry food. A balance of wet and dry is best.).  So the chance to find wet food she might actually EAT was irresistible.The Wellness Divine Duo seafood variety pack has all three seafood flavors they make, all grain free -- Tilapia pate with Ahi Tuna on top (when it's served; it's sensibly on the bottom in the package);  Tuna pate with Salmon on top, and and Chicken pt  with Salmon on top. I liked how it came out--the nice brothy-gravy spilling appetizingly over the pate.  And then...the (somewhat) good news. She sorta kinda likes them. Not easy to give 1/2 in the morning and 1/2 at night as the gravy/sauce/juice is at the bottom, cleverly designed to spill over the pate when you put it upside down on the plate. It's still about 3xs the amount of the Friskies broths, though and she does nibble a little on the pate after licking up most of the gravy. (Still like a "broth" thing, though, for the most part.). I like the pull-off top--doesn't get cat food on my hands--but I wish instead of plastic the containers were biodegradable. .These are fairly costly--about $1.50 per package--but it's good for her and worth a try for any cat, I think..  I see there are also these Wellness packets that look like the Fancy Feasts broths and may also be worth trying. Wellness Healthy Indulgence Natural Grain Free Wet Cat Food, Salmon & Tuna Recipe, 3-Ounce Pouch (Pack of 24)http://www.amazon.com/Wellness-Healthy-Indulgence-Natural-Food/dp/B0038C6X8A/ref=pd_sim_199_4?ie=UTF8&refRID=1ZE9NECVYZQ7H2M2QJM8  I've ordered them for her to try. Maybe this brand will be the "winner" we've been looking for.  (ETA: The Salmon ones arrived and weren't really a hit. Again, she liked the broth, but left the food. Luckily, the neighborhood crows really enjoy it all.)

This is a dressier, prettier watch than the AK ones I usually get. It is also, surprisingly, about $60 cheaper than the other one.This is a very pretty watch, unusual with the chain bracelet and Swarovski crystal covering over the watch. I really like it. The only criticism one might have is that the watch face itself is fairly small and has the "modern" lines on it rather than numbers. I like that it has a second hand and keeps time well.

I liked the look of this online--it seemed large enough for a small dSLR and a lens or two--and the grayish-purple color seemed a refreshing change from the usual black camera bags.  I have many Lowepro camera bags and they make a good, quality product. The discounted price here at Amazon brought it from "puzzlingly expensive" at $70 to "realistic" even possibly a good deal, depending on the construction and design, at $30.Unfortunately, I was very disappointed when it arrived. First, it is bigger than it looks--if you hold an 8x11" paper horizontally and imagine adding about 2" more so its 8x13", that's about how large it is, like a large shoulder purse, not so much like a slingshot bag.But that actually wasn't a problem. The problem was that it is a nylon bag without padding. Yes, it has some nice design features--like an ouside open pocket on the right side for a small tripod or some other gadgets or a lens, a zippered pouch on the front and back, and a double zipper across the top of the bag itself (something I always like, being able to open and close it from either side). But...it has no padding!!!I don't know what Lowepro was thinking because in terms of protecting your camera, you'd be better off with a regular leather purse and an insert for the camera.Maybe that's what the thought is here. Because there IS a gray soft "box" with heavy protective padding and Velcro strips on the bottom so you can position it in the center (or the sides) of the interior of the bag.  It's about 7" tall and 4" wide, so you could probably stand a small dSLR or similar camera on its end with a short telephoto lens on it and it would fit. But since it doesn't attack to the sides of the bag, it seems kind of "floppy" in the middle or, as I preferred it, pushed over to one side, leaving half the bag for other things.It seems like such a good idea, but didn't quite work for me. Maybe if you only had the one camera to fit in the padded box it would be a good travel bag, particularly abroad, because there is significant amount of room for your other things and it doesn't look at all like a camera bag. But if you are looking to bring several camera-related things in a bag with good protective padding for all of it, I don't think this would be a good choice.

Initially, I was excited to try this. At this price point, it had to be exceptional, right?Unfortunately, while most of the ingredients are very good, I don't understand--especially with non-organic ingredients--how Nature Valley justifies the price.Other than that, though, after trying it for a week I had to come back and raise it from 3 stars to 4 stars because I actually -do- like it quite a bit. Things I -do- like?  I like that the oats are toasted (though very lightly and apparently that's where the sugar content is, in the oats, because they are slightly sweet--there's no sugar in the bag itself. The dried blueberries don't have a "fake" taste and are nicely tart and chewy. I also like the nuts, the sunflower seeds, although I wish there were more almonds. It is easy to throw in anything more to change the proportion (I'd add slivered almonds, personally, and chopped dried apricots for some added vitamins and flavor. But its also fine just "as is").On the downside, it doesn't taste too sweet. I was surprised to see sugar as the second ingredient.  (The calorie count--230 calories per serving--doesn't really bother me because this is obviously supposed to be treated as a meal, not a low-calorie snack.).On the "hot v. cold" debate, I often cook oatmeal, but I like it very non-mushy, a texture I was not able to achieve with this. And it is muesli, not granola, and didn't work for me eaten alone, cold, as it isn't toasted/crunchy enough. However, when I make cooked oatmeal, it's nice to stir it in right before serving for some nice extra flavor and texture.Where I really liked it a lot, was mixed with cottage cheese and fresh fruit (strawberries, bananas, etc.) for some nice added sweetness and crunch. The blueberries worked well to add tartness that was nice--a very nice summer lunch. It also was good either replacing the Nature Valley bran cereal in my breakfast or added to it--a combination of cereal, fresh fruit, non fat milk and a splash of half-and-half then topped with a ribbon of honey that is very refreshing and delicious,. So, I guess I really do like this quite a bit--just not so much on its own as mixed with my usual breakfast. At the price, that might be a good thing as it will last longer added to oatmeal, bran and cottage cheese which are all pretty inexpensive.

I wish when I was a child we'd been able to do this--pay $22 to write and illustrate a 14 page book that comes back as a nice little 8 x 5.5" (a standard trade paperback size, though of course, very thin) book! This provided so much fun--and is not the kind of thing a child finishes all at once if s/he's really enjoying it--so a nice project to bring on errands where lots of waiting is involved, to take out on a rainy day, bring to someone's house when you go visiting, even entertain your child when she's finished a meal at a restaurant and you want to stay and visit longer. Also a really nice gift. I got one to keep at home when a friend's child comes to visit--he can start it here while we talk, then take it home to finish later. (For less independent or younger children, of course, it's a nice time for parents to sit together with them while they're creating something and want to talk about it/need your help).The kit comes with 14 "book pages" with a box for 2/3's of the page to include the drawing and 1/3 below it, with six wide-spaced lines, for the text. There are also two completely blank pages (except for the omnipresent border so you know the part that will be printed) for the front and back cover.  One cute thing:  You can send a 2x3" photo and a couple of lines (again, there's space designated for it in the instructions) and this will be printed as "About the Author" on the back.The kit also includes the clear and simple instruction sheet (obviously, for the age of child intended, this will be read and explained by the parent in most cases)  The "hardest" direction is probably about the page numbers--write them in pencil on the back of each page; otherwise, its printed in the order received.It also comes with a set of "Ultra-clean Washable Crayola Markers", a pre-paid mailing envelope with postage pre-paid (the $22 for the kit really IS the only added cost, unless you want different markers than these 8 bold colors).  You might want to make Xeroxes of the pages while they're still blank--I did and was glad to have them in case of mistakes.A note about the book in finished published form. The quality of the final product is nice, and I was surprised that anyone would be making a bound paperback so inexpensively until I saw the company listed "Lulu Jr".  Lulu Inc is a major self-publishing company with clients that now occasionally include some of the major publishers in the U.S. when they need a quick copy of a book "Printed on Demand" (POD). I've used them myself and their books are indistinguishable from any paperbacks you see in Barnes and Noble. Obviously, this book only has 16 pages so it looks a little different; nevertheless, in getting it, you are dealing with one of the major "publish on demand" companies in the United States. Thinking about it, I actually think this is a rather brilliant marketing idea--not making any money on these little individual books for children, but letting parents become aware of how easy it is to publish their -own- book (cookbood, memoir, photos etc) through Lulu. Clever!In any case, this little book your child makes is going to be printed by a major independent publishing company which means you're not gambling with the quality when you buy and send this. Terrific for young children and a great way to get older kids and their parents thinking about publishing longer books of their own, perhaps as gifts or to sell.**Note re: using Lulu for self publishing books of your own. They're great for individual copies. If you want to sell a book on Amazon, however, I'd recommend instead: (1) reading Aaron Shepard's book on POD (printing on demand); (2) buying your own ISBN from Bowker and (3) using Amazon's CreateSpace.  You'll save considerable money and be able to track your sales that way, with CS, in a way that you can't with Lulu. But for easier-to-format-on-your-own copies that you don't plan to sell, Lulu is excellent and will give you a product that looks the same as CS or other reputable POD company.

I try a lot of conditioners and this one is unique. At under $5 I thought it was a good value, especially since it really worked. They say it's for "aging" hair--dry, brittle, heat-and-color treated--so regardless of age, many women will find it helpful. I wasn't sure what to expect--didn't leave it on the suggested 3 minutes (more like 1 minute)--but it was a genuine surprise. My hair (normally wavy) was straight without blow drying and not flat like any conditioner remained--it had volume, softness. It normally doesn't look dry (because I've stopped coloring it), but I could see it has a nice shine from the coconut oil. There is very little scent, and what there is is faint and pleasant. I like that, too. A good product.

If I were in a hurry when charging things, I wouldn't be marking this as high, but I'm not. I tried charging a cell phone (1 hour) and my Kindle Fire (4 hrs) and my small camera (1 hour) and I was fine with all of it. This portable charger takes about 4-5 hours to charge from a laptop and that was fine, too.  It is able to deliver at least 1 full charge for a smartphone (iphone or Galaxy) or tablet (and possibly even 2, depending on the smartphone).I also didn't find it large or heavy or awkward. It fits in your hand, a little longer than your palm--4.5" long and 5.5 oz--a size and weight that I find perfectly acceptable for the purse or luggage or camera bag or laptop bag that I would be carrying it in.  It has a belt clip that I wouldn't use, but someone else might find convenient. As for the flashlight, while it wasn't powerful, it illuminated the dark yard just fine--easy to walk or see what you are looking for. I don't see how it is like a cell phone light--at least not mine--because it is definitely directional and shines a spreading (if not super-bright) beam of light in front of you.I really like that it is waterproof (not just water resistant) to the point where it can be emersed in water for 30 minutes, possibly as much as 90. I also like that the top removes so you can use the micro USB or regular USB port to charge from BUT the top remains tethered to the powerpack so it cannot be lost. (The disadvantage for me is the very short cable that comes with it--the length isn't such a problem but when the powerpack is closed you can't attach it--meaning it can't be left with it and could be more easily lost).Overall, I thought this was durable, a good size and weight to carry on a trip, keep in the car for emergencies, or keep in a camera bag. I have had cameras, tablets and cell phones go dead before when I either didn't have the charger or had no way to charge it (as in camping). For me, this will be a very handy product to avoid those kinds of problems in the future.

This is a very good biography, with an amazing amount of research and detail integrated into the story of Lyndon Johnson up to his second run for the Senate in 1948. I particularly appreciated the description of the difficult, draining life for farmers in the Texas Hill Country. Of particular strength, for me, was the lengthy description of the hardships women (including Johnson's intellectual mother) faced in raising families and keeping the home without any running water or electricity. Beyond the lack of electric light, gas stoves, washing machines and dryers--conveniences that we all take so for granted now--even ironing clothes was arduous, not to mention lugging the gallons of water from the well to the house in order to take a weekly shower or wash clothing and dishes. Everyone living in America today should read those chapters because it is a great reminder that as overwhelmed as we can be by housework today, rural families in the years before Franklin Roosevelt had it much, much worse.What impressed me most about this biography was Caro's ability to organize so much information, so much research and details about so many people into clear sentences, paragraphs and chapters. It is almost overwhelming to read it all and impossible to imagine it wasn't overwhelming to contemplate organizing it all into clear, readable prose. But Caro did, and there are even many times when his sentences go beyond "competent and informative" to sparkling and even brilliant prose.He makes a compelling case for a Lyndon Johnson who is far from the fatherly figure he tried to achieve in his Oval Office addresses as the president who started--and stubbornly presided over--the Vietnam War.  The child of a charismatic, idealistic father who descended from social status as a Texas legislator to a dirt-poor,failed cotton farmer, Caro's Johnson is convincing as an insecure boy who used every bit of intelligence, magnetism and personality in the service of his one goal: "to be somebody", in particular, to achieve the highest recognition from the public as President of the United States.On this path to the White House, Caro introduces us to the Lyndon Johnson who had tremendous talent for making people like him (I would never have guessed, for example what a natural teacher he was--and a motivator among teachers as well, even when he was only in his teens. Caro left no doubt for me that he could have excelled in the classroom and easily reached the top administrative positions in education, if he had wished to have that career.)But instead his single-minded ambition required political power--his own and others'--and it also required lots and lots of other people's money. Caro shows the hard work Johnson brought to any task he took on--campaigning for Texas congressmen and showing "political genius" in the process while only in his teens, becoming one of the most effective legislative assistants in congress, developing all of his political skills as a congressman and finally reaching the pinnacle of his career as a wheeling and dealing senator, doling out punishments and rewards--the latter, whether in committee appointments or cold, hard cash, since eventually he had access to millions thanks to his favors done for oil and construction interests from Halliburton (Brown & Root) to the oil men who knew that, Democrat or not, Johnson was their man in Congress. They paid him back generously for his favors.This volume does not go as far as his successful run for the senate. Those 7 years are covered in "The Means of Assent" followed by "Master of the Senate", and "The Passage to Power", about his years as vice president. Caro's fifth volume (and it is hard to imagine there won't be a sixth needed to cover this period, 1963-1973) is still being written.
