The arc from Johnson's life in the Texas hills as a poor boy to the reviled multi-millionaire president who presided over the Vietnam War that killed over 58,000 Americans and over 2 million Vietnamese is an fascinating, if often dispiriting, story of megalomania and greed.  To his credit, Caro does not skimp on the positive attributes Johnson had, but they fail to balance out the tragedy for the nation in the way that he used them.I admire this book and certainly learned a lot from it, particularly about the workings of Washington poiticians from the mid-1930s to the mid-1940s. But when the admiration began to fade amid the wealth of minute political detail, I felt a little disappointed, almost cheated. Caro is so fixated on the political life of Lyndon Johnson--so much on the personalities in Washington at the time--that the "big picture" of life in the United States during the years of the 1920s through the 40's is often missing. He touched on Coolidge and Hoover's attitude toward the poor, but I would have liked to know more about the economic forces behind the Stock Market Crash in 1929 and more about the effects of the Depression. He mentions the opposition to labor unions in Congress--and the support for them by other politicians--but the labor movement itself gets little attention. Similarly, this is the period when World War began in Europe and also, two years later, when it began for the United States. Again, I wished for more of a "big picture" more global events, more social history, more economic forces. There is too much for me at any rate) of the battle between Roosevelt and John Garner (his VP). It goes on and on and on and that's true of so many things here, including Johnson's relationship with oil man and publisher Charles Marsh (and his affair with Marsh's mistress), his relationship with the Brown brothers (very important, but you know these are not the only wealthy patrons he has--where are the oil men who Johnson told Bobby Baker he was "working for" when he reached the Senate?)The machinations of Johnson in purchasing a struggling radio station then and using his position to get special favor from the FCC is important because it shows a pattern of turning political power to personal financial advantage. But Caro sometimes belabors the point to an exhausting degree. If I want to know in detailed chapters about something from the 1940s, I would rather it is about the economics of the New Deal and how it was changing America, or how the U.S. was changing in response to the rise of fascism in Europe, instead of about the bitter feud between FDR and Garner, and how it involved Texan Sam Rayburn . I think these nearly 1000 pages could have included more of the "big picture", and instead painted much political minutiae with broader strokes in many cases (and also kept the focus more on Johnson--often Caro goes for pages with no mention at all of Johnson) AND could have cut many of the unremarkable details along the way to do it, and still been 200 pages shorter. Not to say it isn't a valuable biography of Johnson, but I wanted to make it clear why such a monumental work isn't getting the highest rating possible, despite being so well researched and well written.Also, for those who want to learn more about what Lyndon Johnson was like from two men who worked for him, I recommend press secretary George Reedy's highly readable, "\\\Lyndon B. Johnson: A Memoir

"On March 13, 2013, Cardinal Jorge Mario Bergolio, Archbishop of Buenos Aires, was elected to the papacy, becoming the first  Pope Francis."So begins the introduction to this book, written by Dublin's Father Michael Collins. There is text on nearly every page--clear and succinct, often several paragraphs long--but it takes a distinct second place to the full color pictures taken by one of the pope's official photographers, Rodolfo Felici, a man whose family  has been photographing the Pope  since his great-great-great grandfather began back in the 19th century.I included the quote aove from Father Collins because it illustrates his succinct  writing style, a style that I appreciate from someone describing this much admired and increasingly controversial, Pope. It is flattering and informative without being fawning.From the beginning, Pope Francis--the first Jesuit to become Pope--was different. Finding ways to reduce ostentation, in one of his earliest decisions he chose to live in a simple room where guests usually stay at the Vatican rather than in  the opulent quarters reserved for Popes and he continues to seem determined to avoid many of the luxuries favored by some of his predecessors. To the surprise of many, he has continued to take inspiration from Jesus' humble work with the poor, and to seek out those who are marginalized in society, reaching out to the poor and ill, but also to Rome's prisoners and even to convicted Mafiosa as part of his effort to remind people--Christians and non-Christians alike--of the love that Jesus had for his fellow men and women, no matter how "lowly" society may feel they are.I am not a Catholic, which I mention only because--although I enjoyed this book very much and think other non-Catholics would, too,--I think much of the text (and many of the photos which aren't particularly "art photography") would be even more meaningful to those who share  Pope Francis' faith. Still, it has much to offer to non-Catholics as well, and I'd like to give some of those highlights (other than Father Collins' clear prose and the fascinating photos of Pope Francis before he became Pope,  his parents, his childhood,, and even a few from his ministry in Argentina.)I had read about him washing feet in prisons and hospitals on Holy Thursday, but I love the photo of him actually doing it--really one of my favorites in a book full of good photos. There is a section about the conclave (election), showing the Cardinals preparing to vote for the new Pope, and also photos of the farewell of Pope Benedict.  These, like so many photos in this book, show details that the television cameras did not capture. If you are at all interested in the traditions and rituals (including many special Masses) that accompany being a Pope, this book is a well done reminder of them.The largest section traces a year in the life of Pope Francis, again, with many  detailed photos including the many many holidays observed throughout the year--again, very interesting and this book makes it easy for a non-Catholic to absorb more about the holidays they have not heard of and to learn more about their timing and meaning.The photos are large--this is a coffee table book--and the page quality and reproductions, though not of the finest quality, are glossy and good considering the amazing price this book is offered (normally $25 aleady an excellent price for a full color hardback cpffee tab;e book, but Amazon discounts it nearly 50%--so, even better--what a bargain!) . Many of the photos are of the Pope and the Cardinals and it may feel a little repetitious in that way--(although there's a nice one of a crowd in Germany is one; and a fascinating view of the Apostolic Palace is another)...one with Barack Obama and so on.  The joy on people's faces in the crowds in St Peter's Square are very moving and the last section was my favorite, showing his travels and the happiness he inspires in the crowds who meet him.(some of the crowds are downright scary in size, though--so huge even when pressed so tightly together. You can feel how vulnerable Pope Francis is, and also how committed he is to reaching out--from Turkey, to Brazil, to South Korea, to Sri Lanka. to the Philippines. .This is not a top-of-the-line art book, and I also had to deduct a bit because the type face is quite small. But, overall, it is a delightful and sometimes even moving look at the very special man who is currently leading the world's 1.2 billion Catholics. Definitely recommended.

This is a nice addition for coffee lovers. It looks very nice--7 inches tall and about 2" across--a narrow, sleek stainless steel cylinder that looks a little like a modernistic pepper mill. It is ridiculously easy to assemble and use. The canister is in two parts. Gently pull the top off and put in your coffee beans (it holds about half a cup at a time). The handle is placed on top of the lid (like a nut and wrench, only so effortless to turn). The bottom part of the canister holds the grounds (you can see them through a little clear plastic slit in the side). I like that it holds the grounds so neatly as you grind the beans and that you can use it immediately or just keep them in the storage space for later.The manual grinder surprised me in two ways: First, it is very quiet. I had to look in to see if it was even grinding (it was). Second, I thought it was so effortless to use the crank. I expected to have to exert some force on it, but, no, you just turn it clockwise or counterclockwise (depending on whether you are making espresso or using a French press) a few turns that glide so easily--nothing like the effort involved with a pepper mill. You can adjust the burr by tightening it or loosening it and that is designed to give you finer grounds or coarser ones. It comes with a brush and a storage bag where you can keep it, the canister and the handle).I love this because it is simple, small and sleek and gives you the opportunity to grind coffee without using electricity (or making noise) and the coffee stores well and tastes so good. Great for an office, for camping, if there's a power outage (I'd pair it with the simple "My Cup" which "brews" coffee without electricity). A nice gadget at an attractive price (currently nearly half price, at a shade under $20). If you like this kind of thing--a manual alternative with an elegant design--I definite recommend this..

There are a variety of uses for this excellent product. Since Dawn is mild, I even used it on my car. and it cut down the need for so much water to keep rinsing and soaping in our water-conserving state. But for me, these thick Bounty towels + dishwashing detergent are so GREAT for washing dishes that even if that were -all- they did, it would be worth it to me.I'm not a germaphobe, but I really don't like using a dish sponge to wash dishes, even with separate ones for the counter, the dishes and another one for the cat's plates. Even though I microwave the sponges regularly to kill bacteria, it always seems like a basically unsanitary process and also inconvenient. I love using these towels instead.  (You can also use it any way that you would a "two towel process" where one is wet and soapy and one is damp and clean (like for quick floor spills cleanup in the kitchen or wiping off things in the bathroom, or cleaning walls or the front of appliances.)I tear off one or two towels per load of dishes, depending on how big it is. These are very sturdy throughout the entire wash--feel like cloth in your hand, no shredding like many regular paper towels would.. There is a lot of soap embedded here and that's fine. It soaps well and rinses well and for me,...just used for the dishes alone...I think these are really worth it. I can do a whole load (without ever touching a sponge; scrubber of course for pans), then rinse it and wipe the counters (it's mostly just full of water by then, so really, it's all that's needed, ring it out and wipe.). And then, here's the best part... I just throw this one sheet away! (in the recycler because now it's just basically a slightly damp paper towel).If you routinely use paper towels in place of napkins, or to carry food on, you obviously wouldn't replace those uses with these. We've been using napkins and the kitchen towel more regularly for food carrying and hand drying--it's less wasteful than always grabbing a paper towel anyway.It is easy to also have a regular white roll of paper towels and not get confused between them. These Bounty have a very distinctive light blue pattern on them so that it's easy to tell these are the ones "for cleaning only".They are also useful to have in an RV and for campingSo much better than using a sponge and soap. So convenient and, since they are recyclable (unlike the sponges), it doesn't even adding wasted materiel to the process. You still need dry paper towels for other kinds of uses, where you don't want soap (dryng your hands, etc.) These are so ingenious and useful. Really really like them.

Anything that helps with organization and is unobtrusive doing it, I appreciate. This is exactly as it claims to be--a clear plastic tray with 1/2" --wide cut outs all around--wide enough to let things stick through when you want--like long pens or long narrow tubes- but narrow enough that nothing will fall through them (and only about halfway down each side). It sticks, as promised on stainless steel, glass, finished wood, plastic, tile or metal--I tried it on all of them and it (1) adhered and (2) removed without damaging the surface when I pulled it off. The backing is "an innovative dry adhesive technology"--very cool, and clear. Even though it doesn't stick permanently and doesn't leave any marks behind, I wouldn't move it around too often (although Elmer's says you can reuse again and again. After three times it wasn't working ve ry well any more. However, they are washable so I'll test if that restores it.I have this one holding my sunglasses at the front door (Tried to hook the car/door keys hooked around one of the little groove in front.but they were too heavy.. I'd like to another one for the computer room to keep pens, reading glasses and memory card holders in--very useful. A very good product.ETA: Just to add, I put it on the side of an oak desk and hung a ring of keys over the edge. Too heavy. It fell on the carpet. Tried again to be sure. Fell again. Now had too much carpet residue to be able to stick at all. I thought "wash it!" to restore the sticking. I did, but so far, it isn't sticking well enough to even hold my sunglasses.  My advice would be to not put anything as "heavy" as a car/house key ring in to begin with and also not reposition it much. Also, don't count on that "washable" part to restore the stickiness. Other than that, it is convenient to put anything about the weight of glasses into.

I got one of these a few years back and loved it so much that I got 2 more when the others in my house needed to be replaced.  Setting them up to all talk to each other was a breeze. I would happily recommend this to anyone.  You can get much cheaper smoke detectors, but if you are getting one that detects both slow-smoldering and also fast-spreading fires (requires 2 different sensors) AND one that detects carbon monoxide, then you're going to probably be up around $70, anyway.  For an extra $30, you get all kinds of nice extra features and to me, it's totally worth it.

I used these for a Halloween costume and they worked great.  The ones in my ear were comfortable all night, but the one in my nose got a little sore after about a couple hours.  I don't think I would change the pressure, though--they were as light as they could go without having to worry about falling off/out.  The look is very convincing.I did have one break when trying to put it on, but for a pack of 8 at this price, I'm still perfectly happy.  The rest have all done just fine.

Cute shoes.  We haven't had any of the problems other reviewers have posted, although to be fair, they get pretty light use as they are intended to be wear-to-church-on-Sunday shoes (= a few hours a week).  My daughter doesn't wear any pair of shoes all day (she's a bare-foot kinda' gal) but I suspect she could go all day in these as easily as any of her other shoes.  I will update this review if anything changes my mind about them...

I already own a Milwaukee 48-22-2008 8 Piece Screwdriver Set in my work area, but I wanted another set of screwdrivers for the garage so I got these.  My first impression is that the Crescent drivers feel cheaper in the hand and I can't help but wonder if one day the handle will break off of the shaft.  I was going to take a star off for this, but really, if they DON'T break, then it's good enough, right?  That was my thought.  (If I ever do get one that breaks, I'll be sure to update here...)The Crescent set *is* a bit cheaper and has not only more drivers, but all the drivers it includes are useful (I'm sorry, Milwaukee, but I have yet to find a good use for your "ECX Bit" drivers.  Must be for jobs I don't do...).  If you are going to get 1 set of screwdrivers to do the broadest set of jobs, this would be better than the Milwaukee set and at this price, it would be hard to find a better option anywhere else.Side note: Having a magnetized tip is good in many scenarios, but not all.  If you want better magnetization, just rub a permanent magnet across the tip in 1 direction a few times (the stronger the magnet, the better).

I'm pretty happy with this shirt overall, but I can't say that it's my very favorite; the fit is a bit looser than I like and the collar is just a bit perkier than I usually wear, but otherwise it looks like a good quality of fabric, and seems well made.  I suppose I could also do without that logo... what is it... a yak?  Weird.Anyway, I suspect a different body shape would do better in this particular cut, but I would be open to trying other things by this company.

I love heated blankets--it is hard to beat the sensation of slipping into bed on a freezing cold night when the bed has been heated to a point where if it were any hotter, it might start being uncomfortable. <contented sigh>I've used several blankets by Sunbeam and they are all fine--they do the job. However, this Serta blanket is superior in a couple ways:1) The timer.  How I love the timer.  You see, once you slip into your nice warm bed, you want to relish in the warmth for a while.  However, the warmth combined with the end of the day soon overtake you and you fall asleep only to wake up in an hour all hot sweaty because you fell asleep sooner than you had thought and didn't turn the blanket off.  The timer allows you to set the blanket to turn itself off after a predetermined period of time.  That time can be as little as 30 minutes to as much as 12 hours.  From .5 to 10 you go in 1/2 hour increments and then from 10 to 12 you go in full hours, which gives you 22 choices for how long it's on.  That's all nice, but I must ask, who stays in bed for 12 hours??  I mean, maybe if you're sick, but then, do you really need a timer?  Anyway, I would have preferred being able to set the time in 15 min segments, at least for the first, say, 2 hours.  No worries, though--30 min has worked out just fine for me.  Love the timer!2) The material the blanket is made of is much softer and thicker and warmer by itself than most other electric blankets I've seen.  Just by itself this is a nice warm, comfy blanket.  Also, because it is a thicker material, you don't feel the wires as much.3) The heating coils go further to the edges which in effect makes it a bigger blanket.  I have a queen sized blanket on a king bed and it does just fine covering the whole top (it just doesn't hang down the edges much).So this sounds like a glowing review, right?  Why the 2 stars?  Well, after using it 4 or 5 times, suddenly and without any provocation, the control on one side of the blanket refuses to turn on.  It's not just that the blanket won't heat up (although, that too), but the LCD display doesn't even turn on.  Nothing.  (Note that the other controller still works fine).  Now I'm going to have to go through a returns process which at the moment sound very unappealing.  If I can manage to talk myself into doing it, I'll update to let you know how it went...

My phone's headphones jack is broken so I rely on Bluetooth in order to get music out of my phone without having to use the horrible built-in phone speaker.  Usually that means I have to use an adapter, but these headphones get rid of that need and are that much smaller and easier to work with.  I don't think they are ideal, but overall, I DO think they are pretty good.PROS:* Small, light, not a lot of excess cord dangling around, no extra adapters needed* While not water PROOF, they are pretty water resistant* A fit that is both comfortable and secure.  I haven't tried to wear them for more than an hour at a time, but that hour was completely painless.  It also stayed put as I rode my bike off-road.* As part of the above point, they come with different sized ear pads, which is pretty common, but the size difference between the largest and smallest is actually pretty significant. A lot of other headphones have pads that are all pretty close in size so if you have very small ears (like kids, for example) or if you have large ears (hey, some people do) then you're out of luck, but if you are some variant of "average", then they got you covered.  With these, Jabra instead decided to cover all practical sizes instead of catering only to the most average sizes.* I like to listen to music while I bike which is a challenge because there is often a lot of wind noise when you use headphones.  I thought these would be especially bad since they are so large, but they actually did fairly well.  Don't get me wrong--there was still a fair amount of wind noise, but it wasn't as bad as by other ear buds.  I guess the shape is more aerodynamic or something...CONS:* The wire is not as supple i.e. it is more stiff than most headphone wires.  This makes it a bit unruly and difficult to get it adjusted just right.  HOWEVER, on the plus side, I suspect this means less bounding on the back of your neck when you run (since I don't run, I can't say for sure).* Although you certainly CAN wear glasses (prescription or sunglasses) with the headphones, the over-the-ear design does make it so they do interfere just a bit.* The headphones has a microphone built in, but the person on the other end said I sounded very distant and quiet.  I'm sure this is because the microphone winds up more behind your head than by your jaw (as is pictured in the ad).  That was in a quiet room.  I didn't bother trying it outside.OBSERVATION:The music sounds very flat to me--not as much bass as I'm used to in ear buds.CONCLUSION:Currently my best set of headphones for use while biking.

These chocolates are very soft and very creamy and just melt in your mouth.  The texture is masterfully done.  My only disappointment was the fact that so many of them were just smooth, creamy chocolates.  The ones that had any texture at all had way too little.  Based on the descriptions, I picked out all the "nuttiest" ones I could find and felt like all of them were underdone from a crunch standpoint.  It was a bit disappointing.  For reference, See's "nuts and chews" are more my thing.  And that leads us to an important point: these are Swiss chocolates.  There are many chocolate lovers that will insist that European chocolates are the best and that everything from the US is garbage.  I agree that they taste different, but in all honesty, I prefer the domestic stuff, generally speaking.  That's a matter of personal opinion and I suspect I'm in the minority (my wife thinks the creamy-only texture and European quality is perfect), but these chocolates absolutely have that European chocolate quality to their taste (whether that's good or bad is up to you).The box the chocolates come in makes for fantastic presentation which in turn makes this a great gift.  I was going to post a few pictures, but it appears that Amazon has already provided a good detailing of what you will get.  I am uploading a picture of the little "booklet" that people are talking about because I was under the impression after reading the reviews that it would be something more than what it was.  Really, it's just the same as what you see in the "From the manufacturer" section.  This isn't a bad thing, but I wanted to set the record straight.A great gift idea, if you like being a bit spendy.  There are many people (ex. my wife) who will find the super-creamy texture and the European style an absolute delight and I'm sure they would all love this decadent gift.  Just make sure you buy when the weather is cool--it would be a pity to have them all melt in the delivery truck on the way to your house (it was very cool when I ordered mine, so that wasn't a problem for me).

A while ago I got a BRAVEN 805 Wireless Bluetooth Speaker [18 Hour Playtime] - Orange/Gray.  I was very impressed with the sound quality, esp. given the size and gave it an excellent review.  I still like the Braven, but I have to say as good as it is, this NYNE has a much bigger, fuller sound.  That makes sense given that it is quit a bit bigger and heavier.  The Braven weighs in at 2 Lbs. 13 oz. (1.3 Kg) while the NYNE is a hefty 6 Lbs. 10 oz. (3 Kg).  The physical dimensions are also significantly different, as you can see in the attached photos.  This, along with the shapes, make the Braven easy to pick up as is, while the NYNE really does need the carrying handle to tote around.Speaking of shape, I was worried that the speaker would have a tendency to want to tip over backwards, but it appears to be pretty solid.  If it's going to tip, it will be backward, but I am not going to worry too much about it.  However, if you have anything plugged in, it will be in the back, so having the foot just a little longer in the back wouldn't have been a bad thing.The buttons on the NYNE are huge, but all black.  In contrast, the Braven's buttons are much smaller, but the high contrast actually makes them easier to see.  One of my primary complaints with the Braven was the fact that they were trying to do all the functions with as few buttons as possible.  I'm pleased to see that the NYNE has dedicated "Skip forward" and "Skip backward" buttons.  It also has a little light to indicate that the power is on (in addition to a physical switch which you can use to prevent accidentally turning it on, say, in a bag).  Another light flashes when it is trying to pair to a Bluetooth device.  These address other beefs I had with the Braven.The battery indicator light is better on the Braven--there are 5 LEDs that show you the relative amount of power left in the battery whereas the NYNE has 1 that starts blinking when the battery is low.  Also, the NYNE's battery charging light is a light blue when it is charging and turns green when it is done.  Now that I know this, it makes sense, but it wasn't obvious what the status of the battery was when I plugged it in.  Was it charging?  Was it just on?  Both the Braven and the NYNE have aux level inputs and USB outputs to charge your devices.  Both can be used as a hands free device for your phone (though I haven't really ever used this feature on either one).The Braven has a cool feature that lets you pair your phone to it and then pair it to a second Braven for stereo sound.  I was not surprised to find that the NYNE doesn't seem to  mention anything about being able to do this.  The Braven also has a sound enhancement mode (I forget what they call it... if you are familiar with Sony's "Megabass" it's like that), but honestly, I don't see why you would ever want to turn that off, and as mentioned before, NYNE's sound is pretty rich already.The NYNE also allows you to pair your device to it by using NFC.  Simply turn your Bluetooth and NFC functions on and then tap the side of the speaker, and voil, you're connected.  I have another Bluetooth device that was supposed to do this and I couldn't get it to work.  The NYNE, however, worked perfectly on the first try.  Not that pairing Bluetooth is in any way difficult, but it's a nice touch.The NYNE comes with a power adapter that, like the Braven, appears to be able to be adapted to different country's voltages/plug styles.  Unlike the Braven, the NYNE only came with the one for the US (that's OK--I doubt I'll ever use the other ones that came with the Braven, anyway).  It also comes with an aux cable (1/8 stereo mini jack, male-male, straight and right angle) which you can use if you are trying to play audio from a device that doesn't support Bluetooth.Another strong win of this over the Braven is the price.  At the time of the review, it is close to 1/2 the cost of the Braven.The only "con" I found was a small thing--at full volume there was some distortion.  Not a buzzy or crackly sound of the speaker being overworked or the amplifier chirping, but rather it made me think that perhaps some capacitors couldn't hold quite enough charge for the peak sounds as there was sort of a quick fade-out-fade-in sort of distortion.  That's OK, though because I don't plan to listen to this at full volume.  I just turned it down 1 notch and the distortion was almost completely gone.  1 more and I couldn't hear it at all anymore.  And that was still quite loud.  What this means to me is simply that they allow you out of the "RMS" range and a little further into the "peak" range than I want to go, so I won't go there and we can all be happy.If you are ok with a large speaker, this will do you very well.  If size is an issue, then the Braven would probably be better for you.  Both are great speakers but the NYNE really does have a much fuller and bigger sound.Recommended!

The pieces are thick and sturdy.  Durability is an important attribute for us since our little guy is very hard on his toys and I think this will be up to the challenge.  Note that there are multiple vehicles that are the same color (2 blue, 3 yellow, 2 green) which makes the puzzle slightly more challenging; however, the pieces are large enough that there is plenty of context on each piece that helps to offset this by a bit.Recommended.

Installing this was a snap.  It comes with everything you will need from wire nuts, to pre-stripped wires to a cover plate.Pop the cover off the bottom and you have a 3-position switch to choose the mode and 3 different dials to change sensitivity to motion, sensitivity to light and time delay to shut off if there is no motion detected.The 3 position switch lets you choose between "Off" (fully manual--you have to press the button to turn on and again to turn off--like a normal light switch), Occupancy mode (auto on/auto off) and Vacancy mode (manual on/auto off).  I use "Vacancy mode" because my kids for some reason can't ever remember to turn the light off in their room, so it's usually on all day.  This has fixed that.Something I would have liked would be a way to have the motion sensor "look" more to one side or another.  In the kids' room, the light switch is off in a corner so almost all the action in the room will be going on to the sensor's left.  99.9% of what goes on to the right is out in the hall and should be ignored.  It would have been nice if the sensor could be angled slightly to either side to try and pick up more of what goes on on the left side and nothing of what goes on to the right.  -1/2 starI was a little worried that the net result of this light being automatic would be that the kids would get (even) lazy(ier) and just quit trying to turn any lights off at all.  So far, that hasn't been an issue...An easy solution that has been good enough so far.  Installation was easy and the price is reasonable.  If you have the right setup in the room you want to install this in, it could be a handy little device.Recommended.

I like this tablecloth more than I had anticipated.  The 100% polyester is nice because it cleans well, but usually polyester is coarse to the touch and feels... gross, for lack of a better word.  This one feels more like linen.  It is a very handsome tablecloth with attractive detail and it fits my Ikea table perfectly.  I like the color--it is dark enough that it should hide many food stains, but also a light enough color with enough saturation as to be attractive without drawing too much attention to itself.  I appreciate the understated style.Other reviewers complained of uneven seams and other flaws. I looked, but didn't see any such problems in my cloth.It's really amazing what a properly-fitting tablecloth can do to make a room suddenly feel fancy and elegant.  The kids came in for dinner and immediately assumed there was something very special going on.  The same place settings we always use look better and somehow even the food is more visually appealing.  It's all psychological, I know, and yet I literally felt like last night's normal dinner served on our normal set of dishes and normal silverware was somehow fancy and special.  It sounds silly, but there you have it.We'll be breaking this out for Thanksgiving, Christmas, and whatever other special occasions come along.

We are expecting our 5th and final little one in a few months.  With each of our other kids, I always have a time when I WISH I had a UV filter because everyone in the house is sick except the baby and, since babies can't take cold medicines, I especially feel bad for them when they get sick.  I originally wanted a filter like this one, but it was just too expensive.  Then I tried a cheaper one, but it's so tiny and I don't think it moves enough air to actually do anything.I love that this one has no only the UV light, but a filter as well.  I'm not so much worried about allergens, but I did notice that my cheap UV air sanitizer would get all dusty and I can't help but think that all the dust collecting on the UV light inside has to make it less effective (and it was already woefully inadequate in the first place, as noted).  I also like that this has 3 speeds so that you can balance noise with air flow.  (The good thing is that babies tend to like the fan noise, anyway, so as long as there isn't an ear-piercing whine, they'll probably enjoy the white noise from the fan).One change I would make--the UV light button is a one where you push it once and it is pressed in more and then you push it again and it is popped all the way out.  Other than whether or not the button is all the way in or not, there is no indication as to whether the UV light it is on or not.  I assume "in" means "on", but it doesn't even state in the instruction booklet if that is the case or not.  I would have liked some sort of indication (a small, not-too-bright LED would been perfect) that the UV light was on. -1/2 starIt's hard if not impossible for me to rate the effectiveness of the UV sanitation without experimenting with it for a few cold and flu seasons, but my initial instinct is that it will do enough without being overkill.  I'm happy with it.

This is essentially a yogurt in a squeeze pouch.  1/2 my kids liked it, 1/2 did not.  Personally, I thought it was too sweet, although they kind of need it to be sweet in order to counteract the tangy-tartness that is also present.  The overall flavor, in my opinion was fine, but not great.  I'd eat it if I was hungry and there wasn't anything else around, but I'd likely choose something else first if that was an option.The color is very unappetizing, but that's a good thing--it means they didn't add artificial colors to try hide it.  Since you have to go out of your way to see the color, it doesn't really matter, anyway.As I understand it, Horizon is a dues-paying member of the Grocery Manufacturer's Association (GMA) which has donated millions of dollars to campaigns to prevent mandatory labeling and as such, their whole "We're organic and we care about your health" thing is kind of lost on me.Bottom line:It's fine.  I won't get it again--I'd rather give my kids lower sugar yogurts or perhaps applesauce in a pouch than this stuff.

First of all, if you have not used Tom's of Maine toothpaste before, you need to give your mouth a week to get used to it.  Most toothpastes have all these additives that make it1) super sweet2) super foamyand Tom's does not.  This means that at first, it may taste or feel wrong compared to what you're used to.  That's fine--give it a few days and you'll get used to it.  Then, when you switch back to a "normal" toothpaste, you'll find that it's too sweet and or too foamy and prefer the Tom's.  That's what happened to me.As for the Spearmint flavor--it is nice at first, but quickly starts to taste like gum that's lost its flavor. I prefer the peppermint.

This isn't bad--it does the job and everything, but I do have 2 gripes:1) It isn't magnetic like my old wheel was so I cannot hang it on my magnetic strip2) The round, stainless steel handle can be a bit slippery/hard to hold, esp. if you get a little pizza grease on your hand. I prefer a handle that is NOT round and has some texture to it.

We've had a "Cooshee Classic" for years now.  It is now seating it's 3rd kid and we have LOVED it--best "high chair" solution we have found for any kid that is about 1 or 2 to about 3 or 4 years (depending on how tall your kids are).Unfortunately, "kid #3" is... shall we say, very hard on all his belongings.  We were surprised when our Cooshee's side got ripped--we had thought it would last forever, but then when we thought about all the other things kid #3 has destroyed, we were a little less surprised.  At any rate, kid #3 is still short enough that he'll be needing a booster for a bit longer and kid #4 has just decided that she refuses to be the only one in a high chair--she wants to sit in a normal chair like the rest of us.  "OK," I thought, "I suppose I can understand that" and I headed over to Amazon to get another Cooshee..."$50??!"Yes, that's right--a real, BabySmart brand Cooshie is about $50 which is quite a bit more than I had remembered or guessed it would be, seeing as it's essentially just a chunk of foam.  I started to explore my options.I saw that on a certain online auction site, you could get a used Cooshie for about 1/2 that (at least, that was true when I was doing my searches), or for roughly the same price, I could get this "Prince Lionheart", Cooshee knock-off brand new here at Amazon.  I went with my second choice-partly because I like Amazon and partly because I like new.  Now I'm thinking I should have gone with the auction site (no negative reflections on Amazon--this is purely based on the product itself).  Here's why...For those of you who like the short version, the Cooshee:1) smells better2) is more stable3) feels better to the touch4) is easier to cleanFor those of you who like details:So, yeah--the first thing I noticed when I took it out of its bag was that this thing smelled awful.  Like chemicals.  Holy cow!  Fortunately, after washing it was warm, soapy water and leaving it out in the hot summer sun all day, *most* of the smell disappeared.  Relief.I've attached 4 pictures to help illustrate my next points.Let's start with the one where we are looking at both seats side by side.  It appears they are nearly identical in size and shape and, indeed, they are very close.  A toddler sitting in either chair will be boosted about the same height and will have ample room for their little diapered bums to sit comfortably.  Note that the texture of the chairs is different.  I'll talk more about that later, too.Next, observe the picture of the underside of the chairs.  Again, the size and shape looks very close.  You can see that the Cooshee is a solid piece of foam with little "suction cups" cut into it for better "traction" on smooth chairs (and it actually works, too).  Prince Lionheart decided to cut manufacturing costs by leaving a bunch of empty spaces--which is fine, it's stiff enough that it doesn't really need to be filled in.  However, it is noteworthy that material is actually a bit slippery, so they had to put those orange dots on--that's where the friction is that will keep the booster from sliding off the host chair.  I personally found those 3 pegs sufficient, but only just barely.  I would have really liked it if they had doubled the number of those pegs for better stability.The next picture shows my hand squeezing the chairs.  You can see that the Cooshee is more squishy than the PL is, but that both are at least a bit squishy.  I don't know if that's really an important point or not--since the bottom of the Cooshee is solid foam, and since kids are so light, they aren't going to be *squishing* down into either one.  HOWEVER, you can also see that the texture of the material is different.  Both feel smooth, but the PL is much smoother (at least on the arm and back--the seat part is textured).  You can't tell by looking at a picture, but it is also a bit slippery and leaves sort of a slippery residue on your hand if you touch it too much.  I'm hoping that washes off over time, but I certainly don't like it for now. As I was mentioning before, the fact that the material the PL is made of is slippery means they have to add friction points to the bottom, but the Cooshee did not need to do that because although it is smooth, it isn't at all slippery.Which brings us to the last picture: the texture of the seating area.  Obviously, a slippery chair would not be good for little kids to sit in, so they textured this thing up on the seat.  Personally, I don't like the way it feels to touch, but just about as importantly, it's harder to clean.  Little bits of food get mashed down into the texture and then it's very hard to get it back out.  You can see some in the picture I've included.  It's been scrubbed with a dishrag, but I think we'll need a stiff-bristle brush to get that out.The Cooshee Classic is clearly a superior product and arguably worth the extra cost.  NOTE, however, that BabySmart doesn't appear to sell Cooshee Classic anymore--they have changed the design to the "Hybak" model.  I don't know if this new model is as good as (or better than) the classic--hopefully someone else can fill us in there.  However, if you're on a budget, the PL is probably good enough, though I'd recommend that you first check that auction site and see if you can't get a used Cooshee Classic, instead.

I received this yesterday and gave it to my 7-year old who likes to get all dressed up and look fancy.  For the price, I think this is a very nice piece.  In my experience, when you buy jewelry online, the item that comes is usually a little bit smaller than I perceived it would be and the colors are less saturated than what it looked like online.  I'm not accusing anyone of being deceptive or anything--it's just that when the pictures are taken, they positioned and lit to look their very best but in normal, everyday usage, they aren't under ideal conditions. Anyway, I was pleasantly surprised to see that this pendent was at least as big as I had perceived in my mind--perhaps even a little bigger.  The gem itself is small, but the surrounding heart gives it a feeling of being bigger.  Also, the color of the amethyst looked as just about as good as pictured here (your mileage may vary, but I got a good-looking stone).  The chain is very delicate, but not any more so than other necklaces in this price range (i.e., for a necklace in this price range, the chain is exactly what I would expect it to be).Again, for the price, this is a very good piece and I would happily recommend it.

At first I got all excited about this because I thought it had solar panels built into it.  It doesn't.  Upon further review, I saw that the description says solar READY.  Maybe I'm missing something here, but if you have one of Goal Zero's solar panels, I'm pretty sure you could charge just about any external power pack (with USB input), so I don't know why we are even bothering to mention that.Now with that out of the way, it's still a pretty slick power pack.  It's IPx6 rated and the instructions say"Spray it down, take it to the beach, leave it in the rain - and never worry about rubber plugs.  It's engineered to get out, stay out and handle whatever Mother Nature can throw your way - even a quick drop in a puddle.Do not submerge Venture 30."Besides the IPx6 rating, it is ruggedized with a rubber surround and I suspect it will handle an occasional drop without complaining.  Everything looks like it can handle abuse.As other reviewers have mentioned, its flashlight is super bright.  If you look straight at it when it is on full, then even in the day time, you'll be seeing spots for a couple minutes.Charge times are rated at:Nomad 7: 8-16 hoursNomad 13: 6-12 hoursNomad 20: 5-6 hours2A USB Source: 5 hoursFinally, it has a shelf mode that allows long term storage.  In this mode, it should keep a charge for up to "3-6 months".  The only down side is to exit storage mode, you have to plug it into a power source to reactivate it.  It's a little like priming a pump--if you want water, you have to give it a little water first.The only down side to this battery is its size and weight.  Compared to my other power packs, it's large and heavy, but since it has a high capacity and a rugged body, it's focus isn't just on portability.  This pack is for taking abuse and charging multiple devices at once and it does that well.

I recently lost my pizza cutter that I've had for years and was looking for a new one.  Compared to the other various options out there, this looked like a good choice:1) It looked nice and sturdy2) The handle appears to have a good grip to it3) It's by a brand that typically puts out good stuffI'm very sorry to have to report that this is almost a great product, but falls flat on its face for 2 reasons:1) First and foremost, the wheel does not spin freely.  It spins freely for about 300 degrees (as in there are 360 degrees in a circle) but for the other 60 degrees, there is so much friction on the center axle that it takes a great deal of force to turn the wheel.  This results in the pizza wheel behaving like a round knife that is only somewhat sharp and it just tears the pizza up.  FAIL.  A quick scan through the existing reviews leads me to believe that I just got a lemon, although I do see 1 other review that says his/her cutter's bolt tends to come loose and has to be re-tightened.  This sounds like the same problem, but manifest the opposite way (the opposite side of the same coin, if you will).  That reviewer's bolt was too loose.  Mine is too tight. Hmmm...2) Even if the bolt wasn't a problem, I can't help but notice how much area there is for cheese and sauce to get stuck between the wheel and the supporting structure.  The guard around the wheel is a nice idea, but it's just that much more area that is a bit harder to clean.  I think most dishwashers will handle it, but it's something to be aware of.  I just got a KUKPO Stainless Steel Pizza Cutter Wheel, and since its wheel spins freely, I think I'll get rid of this one and use that instead.  Not that I love that other one--its round, stainless steel handle gets slippery and hard to hold, especially if you have a little grease from the pizza on your hands (the Cuisinart handle is MUCH better in this regard).I miss my old wheel... where did it go?  How does a pizza wheel just disappear like that??  Oh, well, I guess I'll have to keep looking for a good replacement...

I used a black light flashlight designed to detect urine stains and sure enough there were 2 areas on my carpet that showed up under the light. My dog is housebroken but I suspect a visiting dog of "marking" those spots. I used the Pogi's Pet Stain & Odor Remover as directed and lo and behold-stains are gone! There didn't seem to be an odor in those spots but that might be because I recently had the carpet steam cleaned. I'm going to lend the cleaner to my daughter to see how it works on her guinea pig carrier. This is an excellent product for those pet owners who need frequent stain and odor elimination from carpets or upholstered furniture. From some of the other reviews I have read-it works well on human by-products as well! Product received from Pogi in exchange for an honest, unbiased review.

Beverly Swerling's City Of God is the fourth installment of her five fictional treatments of early American history.  City Of Glory is another sweeping epic of (primarily) two competitive families that takes place in New York City from the 1830s up to shortly before the start of the Civil War; and addresses issues of the times such as poor immigrants living in unsanitary neighborhoods, progress in health and medicine, religious conflict, entrepreneurs in businesses growing wealthier and wealthier, organized labor, slavery and abolitionism.In City Of God, which is the third of Swerling's books that I've read, the author once again provides the right blend of interesting historical facts about (in this case) life in mid-1800s New York City, mystery, excitement, sex, a well-developed plot, and a array of fictional and real characters to make City Of God a book that is difficult to put down. Her strong writing ability made me feel that I stepped back over 150 years in time and was right there with the characters experiencing life during a fascinating time in our history. I highly recommend The City Of God if you are a fan of historical fiction. I'm looking forward to reading Swerling's two other books, Shadowbrook and City Of Promise.

The Killing Lessons is the debut crime thriller by Saul Black (the pseudonym of Glen Duncan who has written some novels about werewolves), and it is a book that will grab your attention from the opening page and, for the most part,  keep you turning the pages at a fast pace throughout.I won't spend time providing a plot summary as this can be found in the Amazon Book Description above. I'll just say that the plot pertains primarily to two of the most psychopathic, violent serial killers you've probably ever come across in your thriller readings who travel around the country killing young women in a horribly sexually violent manner, and to the troubled female detective obsessed with capturing these killers. These killers in some ways make Hannibal Lecter seem tame and in control. Be forewarned that author Saul Black is quite graphic in describing these murders.In addition to the plot being well-developed, the author does a well-above average job in developing his characters and in making the reader understand the mindsets of the killers, the female protagonist, as well as some of the more secondary characters, and particularly of the young girl who escapes from the killers. Further, overall, Saul Black does a very good job in telling his story from alternating viewpoints, settings and time periods -- although, at times, this "jumping around" made this reader work a little harder than I would have liked in order to follow everything that was going on.While I, personally, didn't have a problem (at least a big problem) with Black's narrative style, you should be aware that he spares no words in making sure the reader fully understands why the characters act and think the way they do, as well as in making sure the reader has a vivid picture of the various settings in which the plot unfolds. As a consequence of this writing style, I  won't be surprised if some readers will, at times, find his narrative to be too wordy and repetitive. Further, I also won't be surprised if some readers at times feel that the actions of some characters require a suspension of disbelief; although this is something I've have come to expect in many thrillers and, as such, it did not in any way detract from my enjoyment of The Killing Lessons. As a matter of fact, if Black is planning a sequel to The Killing Lessons or another book that features his main character, Detective Valerie Hart, I will be one of the first on line to get a copy it.

Edward Klein once again demonstrates his ability to write a highly informative and insightful expose of our nation's leaders. In Blood Feud, Klein uses his highly regarded reporting skills and his strong access to sources close to the Clintons and  the Obamas to provide a no-holds barred expose pertaining to the mutual dislike, if not loathing, between the two leading families within the Democratic party.Now, as the Clintons attempt to maneuver their way back into the White House, Blood Feud provides some key insights on the political spectacle to come during the 2016 Presidential election.Specifically, some areas in which you'll gain insights in Blood Feud include, but are not limited to, the following:...The deal: why Bill Clinton supported Barack Obama for reelectionand why he feels betrayed...How the oneand onlyWhite House dinner between the Obamas and the Clintons was fraught with tension and contempt...Benghazi: how Barack Obama set up Hillary Clinton to take the blame and why she agreed to go along with (i.e., lie about)  the initial cover-up...The secret Hillary Clinton is keeping that could make it impossible for her to be president...The very serious medical conditions Hillary has had for several years, and that Bill in particular has, that have mostly gone unreported in the media...How the true power behind president Obama is not Michelle, but her close friend Valerie Jarrett, who sets the administration's policies and personnel......Why Michelle Obama's political ambitions could rival Hillary Clinton's...How not just Bill and Hillary, but Barack and Michelle, lead largely separate lives, and...The Oprah factor: how she was used by the Obamasand stroked by the Clintons.Regardless, of your political affiliations and your personal feeling about the Clintons and Obamas, Blood Feud is a book well worth reading for the insights you might glean about these two leading "first" families, and about the woman who might be our next president -- and the man who views her presidency as his third term.

While I didn't think it possible, the reindeer-designed Christmas collar from Blueberry Pet has made my little (well, not so little) French Bulldog, Luigi, even more handsome! I selected the collar in size medium for my 34 lb. fur boy and it fits very well, is easily adjustable and is very well-constructed. Plus, its three-layered, multi-colored bow tie quite eye-catching and appealing. At $12.99, this collar is well-worth the money and will make a nice gift for your dog with the Christmas Holidays being not too far away.I received a sample of this collar from Blueberry Pet in return for an honest, unbiased opinion, and it is a product I very highly recommend to you.

For Smart Phone owners, particularly those with an Android phone, in the market for a multi-functional Smart Watch, serious consideration should be given to the 007plus GT08 Bluetooth Smart Watch with SIM Card Slot and NFC.First off, let me assure you that after charging the watch with the USB cable provided, pairing this watch with its NFC function with my smart phone via Bluetooth was as quick and easy as placing them next to each other. Further, if you choose to, which I did not, this Smart Watch can be used as a standalone phone by using a micro SIM card (watch is not included), thus enabling you to do everything on your wrist without having to have access to Bluetooth.Once setup is completed, you'll be able to easily receive and make phone calls and text messages, as well as to read or send emails. Further, this watch has several useful preloaded apps, such as but not limited to, a calendar, a message reminder, a stopwatch, a Sports health monitor, a pedometer, a sleep monitoring function, a calculator, and an ability to listen to music. And, if that's not enough, it comes with a 1.5M pixel camera so that you can take selfies if you are so inclined. In addition, those with an Android phone will also have access to functions like: notification push, remote capture, anti-lost. (These functions are not currently available on IOS because Apple has not made the IOS app available at this time) Oh yes, let's not forget that since this is first and foremost a WATCH, it enables you to see the time brightly and easily from three different watch faces that you can switch between simply by tapping the interactive screen.Since receiving this 007plus GT08 Smart Watch from the seller to test and review, I have been very satisfied with it and would recommend it to anyone looking for a Smart Watch that is attractive-looking, user-friendly and very reasonably priced. That being said, however, there are two suggestions I would make to the manufacturer that I think would make it even better to its customers. One is to provide an instruction booklet that is larger in size with larger font to make it much easier on the eye. While the booklet currently provided contains what you need to know, the font is so small that I, at times, had to use a magnifier app to be able to read it. The second suggestion would be to provide a way that the time could be displayed on the screen without having to press a button on the side of the watch to turn on the screen.

I received this clock in exchange for an unbiased review.The ZHPUAT alarm clock has all the features you would need at a very reasonable price. The display automatically brightens when the room darkens-but not too bright to disturb your sleep. The clock displays the date as well as the room temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius. The alarm gradually gets more insistent until you turn it off and the snooze button is large and well placed. My only criticism is that the set up instructions are a little tricky and take some trial and error effort. All in all a good product for a fair price.

We received this camera in exchange for an unbiased review.Full disclosure-my wife and I are pretty technologically challenged!  This camera comes with a quick set-up guide that really makes the initial set-up a breeze.  We downloaded the app to my wife's IPhone and installed the camera with no problem.  The camera comes with a quick set-up guide but no user's  manual, which would be very helpful.  We tried to connect my IPhone to the camera as a second user but could not figure out how to do it so we called the Customer Service line. Chris Lee was extremely helpful and patiently walked us through the process.  He even followed up by sending us a link to a user's manual.  The quality and features of the Amcrest ProHD have been covered by previous reviewers and I agree with their praises!  We may not use all of the features-we really just like to watch our dog when we're out-but this product provides a lot of quality features for very reasonable price.  I see multiple Christmas gifts here!

Edward Klein, in Unlikeable, once again uses his no-holds-barred style of writing and his strong ability to accurately interpret the facts and information obtained from his "in-the-know sources" to provide readers with a very insightful expose into Hillary Clinton. Whichever way you lean politically, Unlikeable is a book all readers should read who are willing to have an open mind about the type of person who could be the next president.If you weren't already among the many people who feel Hillary Clinton is unlikeable and, more importantly, untrustworthy, those who read Klein's expose with an open mind will come to learn that Hillary entered the 2016 presidential campaign with a boatload of baggage -- including a tissue-thin resume as a U.S. Senator and Secretary of State, a mountain of scandals, widespread Clinton fatigue, a reputation for mendacity, no clear rationale for her candidacy, a brawler's reputation for foreign interventions and a very forbidding personality.Further, without going into detail, Klein makes the reader abundantly aware of  several other facts that generally go unmentioned in the media, including, but not limited to: (1) the intense dislike of Hillary (and Bill) towards the Obamas and the Obamas' at-least-as-strong dislike of the Clintons (e.g., one way Klein makes this evident is by Obama and his staff giving the FBI tacit approval to proceed with the Hillary private email server investigation; an issue, by the way, Obama --despite his public denials -- has known about throughout her period as Secretary of State); (2) Hillary's and Bill's use of the Clinton Foundation in unethical, if not illegal, ways; (3) Hillary's and Bill's serious health issues; and (4) Hillary's long-term knowledge of Bill's sexual exploits long before the Monica Lewinsky scandal, which she has been willing to condone and use to her advantage in exchange for Bill using his political connections and providing his political savvy to foster her ambition to be the president.Klein also points out that, through his research with many people who are/were ardent Hillary defenders, the arguments in support for Hillary being president boil down to three main points; and for each Klein presents an insightful point of view as to why these arguments are flawed. I'll leave it to you, the potential reader, to find out what these three arguments and their counter- arguments are. Instead, I'll just state the fundamental question Klein posits that Americans should ask themselves when they decide on whom to select as their next president, which is: "Have our standards and morals declined to the point that we will elect someone who is so shameless that she lies without a tinge of guilt, and so untrustworthy that she engages in massive cover-ups?"

If after having Obama as President for the past 6 1/2 years or so you think you know all you need to know about the type of person he is, perhaps you might want to rethink what you know -- or think you know -- and read Edward Klein's The Amateur. Admittedly, the time to have read this book was shortly after it was published in May, 2012, so that it perhaps could have given you food for thought regarding your decision to vote to (and not vote to) elect Obama to a second term as President.The Amateur is not a straight reporting of facts about Obama, but rather it is based on facts and information Klein obtained from nearly 200 interviews of people from both inside and outside the White House who came to know Obama well -- or thought they did. To paraphrase from the jacket flap, The Amateur is Klein's expose that pulls back the curtain of one of the most secretive White Houses in history, and reveals Obama to be a callow, thin-skinned, arrogant president with messianic dreams of grandeur supported by a cast of true-believers, all of them united by leftist politics and an amateurish understanding of executive leadership. If this portrayal upsets you or if goes against your beliefs about Obama as president, then I highly recommend that you avoid reading this book -- unless you are willing to keep an open mind to reading about some things you might not have REALLY known.Some of the things you'll get insight into in The Amateur are:Why the so-called centrist Obama is actually in revolt against the values of the society he was elected to leadWhy Bill Clinton -- who originally referred to Obama as an "amateur--  loathes Barack Obama and tried to get Hillary to run against him in 2012,The spiteful rivalry between Michelle Obama and Oprah WinfreyHow Obama split the Kennedy familyHow Obama has taken more of a personal role in making foreign policy than any president since Richard Nixonwith disastrous resultsHow Michelle Obama and Valerie Jarrett are the real powers behind the White House throne.Whether you are or are not in agreement with Klein's (and others, myself included) referring to the President as The Amateur, I'll provide the author's rationale for doing so to help you decide if "the shoe fits" or not:"A president who is inept in the arts of management and governance, who doesn't learn form his mistakes, and who therefore repeats policies that make our economy less robust and our nation less safe. A man who blames all his problems on those with whom he disagrees ("Washington," "Republicans," "the media"), who discards old friends and supporters when they are no longer useful (Democrats, African-Americans, Jews), and who is so thin-skinned that he constantly complains about what people say and write about him. A person who derives no joy from the cut and thrust of politics, but who clings to the narcissistic life of the presidency."I hope this review is of help in deciding if The Amateur is a book you'll want to read.

The Swan Personal Scale (Not For Business Counting  hahaha that cracks me up that its so prominent on the package, as if its part of the product name!) is not one I will be using regularly.  I received the scale from the vendor to review in exchange for an honest, unbiased review and was excited because I was thinking about buying a new scale and the Ohuhu scale is sleek and attractive looking. Also, I was interested in trying this product because I've had good experiences with other Ohuhu products.Unfortunately, however, this scale is NOT a good replacement for the one I have...and I am glad I hadnt gotten rid of it yet!!!  First of all, it registers a different weight almost every time I step on it  even if its like 5 seconds apart!  And if I put it in different spots on the floor, I get different readingsVERY different!!!  On every scale I have ever had, the readings are sometimes different if I move it around because of imperfections in the floorbut this one gives WAY different readings.  Also, it gives much lower reading than my other scale and the scales in my gym.  There is always some discrepeancy, but this gives much lighter readings.  Which normally I would loveif I could fool myself!!!  But I cant so this scale will likely just collect dust in my bathroom or be discarded, sorry to say. Also, just a side note about the written instructions provided  not that you probably need any elaborate instructions  but the English is so bad in them that they are of very little help.

Without going into details of the plot, which can be read about in the Amazon Book Description above, I'll just say that Secrets Of State is an entertaining and informative thriller that pertains to a potential nuclear war between India and Pakistan that may be instigated by a group within the Washington, D.C. area.Palmer, a 20-year veteran within the U.S. Foreign Service (and the son of bestselling author, Michael Palmer), makes his knowledge of international politics and intrigue clearly evident in his second thriller. Secrets Of State slowly builds into a complex exciting page-turner, with pretty well-developed characters, interesting locales and enough plot twists to keep you in suspense about who the "white hats" are and who are the "black hats." Having said this, I should point out that a few times I found some elements within Secrets Of State seemed a bit hard to believe but that didn't really detract from my enjoyment. Further, I wish that Palmer could made his hero reach "first and second base" a little faster than it took him; but he had no problem getting his hero to "round third and reach home plate" at above average speed.I enjoyed Secret Of State and recommend it to those who enjoy international suspense thrillers and political thrillers. I now plan to go back and read Palmer's first thriller, The American Mission.

The Apple MFi certified DLAND aluminum sync and charging cable does exactly what it claims to do, thus making me very pleased with its performance. In addition, I like the fact that the cable is braided, which makes me feel that it will "stand the test of time." And it's champagne gold color is quite attractive.Definitely recommended,I received this cable from the seller in return for an honest, unbiased review.

If you are in the market for good quality, lightweight wireless in-ear headphones without having to break the bank, i recommend the Soundpeats Q8 wireless sports stereo earbuds headphones. The reasons for my recommendation are as follows:...They provide a rich, crisp sound quality -- even when exercising...They pair easily and quickly with your device...They fit snugly, yet comfortably in the ear/ear canal, and provide 3 sizes of cushions and ear hooks to allow you to find the one that fits best,...They work well to cancel out noises around you...They provide a speakerphone mode so that you can answer phone calls...They provide up to 6 hours of use on a single charge, and...They come with an attractive, ring-shaped box to make the headphones easy to carry when you are on-the-go, as well as for conveniently storing the headphones, its ear cushions and hooks, and its charging cable all in one small, yet roomy place.While I don't have any major complaints about these headphones, I do have a two minor Issues. One is that while its bass is acceptable, I would have preferred a stronger bass sound. The second is that the buttons on the headphone's spaghetti-like strap are a bit hard to push and to figure out by feel which button is which; and so, I found myself fumbling around a bit to pause them or to adjust the volume when I needed to.I received a sample of this product from the manufacturer in return for an honest, unbiased review.

House Of Echoes is a very atmospheric "scary" reminiscent of the "good old days," when "scaries" didn't have to be filled with vampires and the like to be suspenseful. Without going into detail about the plot, I'll just say that House Of Echoes is a tale of how a young family's dream of a better life by moving to an estate in a small village in upstate New York turns into a nightmare.To his credit, Duffy, in his debut novel, does a very good job in making the reader clearly feel that he/she is right there with the Tierney family every step of the way as they work to restore the sprawling estate, in their efforts to fit in with their new village neighbors, and as their lives start to turn into a living hell.This book just oozes with atmosphere!However, Duffy's focus on atmosphere tended to dominate this book, and resulted in this reader experiencing little "first hand" thrills and edge-of-the-seat suspense until the last quarter or so of the book. Put another way, Duffy kept the pace of the book in second and third gear for too long before shifting into fourth gear.Further, Duffy fills the book with characters that are serviceable enough to maintain interest in the story; but, in my opinion, they are not developed well enough to really care much about them. Further, when an author takes the time to describe how much the family dog is loved and then has it disappear, he should at least spend a little more time on creating some sense of emotion about it from the family members.Despite these flaws, I enjoyed House Of Echoes enough to consider reading a second book by Brendan Duffy to see if he has further developed his potential as a suspense writer.

I've been using Frontline Plus to control fleas and ticks on my 34 lb. French Bulldog for about five years and have found it to be an excellent but expensive product. So, when I was offered a free three-pack of Sentry Fiproguard Plus, which is positioned as having the same active ingredients as Frontline for less money, I accepted the offer from the Amazon Vine program.So far, after applying one application of the Sentry product, it seems to work as effectively as Frontline Plus in that, like with Frontline, my little man continues to be free from any ticks and fleas. However, this product has only been "put to the test" for one of the three treatments provided, whereas Frontline Plus has proven itself to be effective on my dog for five years. I will use the  two remaining applications of Sentry I have but, to be honest, I almost certainly will be going back to purchasing Frontline Plus. The reason for this is that, despite the  price advantage Sentry is purported to have over Frontline, I have been purchasing Frontline Plus from an online vet for less money than Sentry is selling for through Amazon's Marketplace sellers.

The Miele Complete C3 Kona Canister Vacuum lives up to the quality you would expect from a $900+ machine!  The Miele touch is evident in every aspect of this machine.  It is a relatively lightweight canister and yet all the components are of much higher quality than the Electrolux machine I have been using.  The devil is in the details-an easily adjustable wand length, a very long cord, a convenient switch on the handle for the power component so that you can switch between hard floors and carpet easily and tools that store easily in the body of the canister.  Don't even get me started on the suction power!  You can adjust the suction from Level 1 to 5 and you had better keep small animals away if you are using the Level 5!  A Hepa-Filter is included in this model and I look forward to a dust-free future with this Miele!

I received this Michael Kors watch from my wife for Valentine's Day and couldn't be more pleased with it!It was easy to size the watch to my wrist, which now fits perfectly and is very comfortable to wear. Most importantly, I love its very in-style, yet classic, appearance -- particularly the way its strikingly attractive blue face contrasts with its brushed gold tone stainless steel band. To be honest, I tend to shy away from gold tone bands but I consider this particular gold color and brushed finish to be well-suited to my taste. As a matter of fact, the picture shown on Amazon's site of the colors of the watch face and band doesn't do them justice.In just the few days I've been wearing this watch I've already received some very nice compliments. I highly recommend this Michael Kors watch if you are in the market for a reasonably priced, good quality, very attractive watch that is suitable for both casual and more dressy occasions.

The Gembonics 3-port USB Car Charger is ideal for when you have the need to charge your smartphone, tablet or music players -- and particularly when you need to charge all 3 devices simultaneously.Its technology works by distributing the necessary charge to each device with its micro chip; and it automatically stops charging the specific device when it's battery is fully charged. Further, it enables you to power your devices without worrying about overheating and overcharging.I've used a few other triple port car chargers but the Gembonics is the most powerful and thus the one I, to-date, use most often. While it is very compact in size, it provides 7.2A max across its 3 USB ports -- with each port providing up to 2.4A max to charge any combination of 3 smartphones, tablets or other mobile devices.I am very pleased with this Gembonics car charger but one suggestion I have for making it even better is to have the charging light go out or change color when the device(s) is (are) fully charged.I received this car charger for free from Gembonics in return for an honest, unbiased review.

The Ohuhu 2 in 1 Salt and Perpper Grinder is a useful and stylish addition to your kitchen or dining room table.  It is easy to fill, shows exactly how much salt or pepper remains, can be adjusted to accomodate the amount of each substance desired and has end caps to prevent spillage.  I think the best feature of this product is its attractive brushed steel finish which make it great for everyday useage or more formal dinner parties.  My wife and I have purchased individual salt and pepper grinders in Costco but they are not really suited for use when we want to serve nicely for company.  The Ohuhu solves this problem perfectly!

Having read Susan Wilson's One Good Dog, The Dog Who Danced and A Man Of His Own, each of which I gave 5 star ratings, I was concerned about how her latest book, The Dog Who Saved Me, would measure up. Well, I have to say that while I wouldn't rate it quite as high as those books, I do consider it to be a very good book that deserves a large reading audience.I know when some of my Amazon Friends see I've written another review about a book that features a dog, they are going to dismiss this book from their consideration (and possibly me as well). That will be their loss. But if you are a "dog person" do yourself a favor and put The Dog Who Saved Me on your reading list. I think you'll find it to be a well-written, emotional book with a cast of characters -- of course, one of which is a dog you'll really care about (and perhaps even more than about the people characters) -- that will hold your interest from the first to the last page.I won't summarize the plot as you can find out what The Dog Who Saved Me is about from the Amazon Book Description above. I'll just say that it is a heartwarming novel about a very special dog and the human lives he touches. I think you'll find that this book will make you feel things that at times will have you laughing and at other times feeling quite sad (perhaps to the point that you might want to have some tissues by your side). And, very importantly, it will make feel glad you decided to read this moving book. Is it perfect? No. Is it predictable? Yes. But, I think your overall reaction, like mine, will be "who cares."Now, having given The Dog Who Saved Me the praise it deserves you might be asking yourself -- why the 4 star and not the 5 star rating that I gave to Wilson's other books? The reason has to do the level of intensity in regards to plot development, character development and narrative. For me, in each of Wilson's other book, her plots and narrative were even more emotionally-charged and touching and her characters were even more fully developed -- to the point that I still remember them long after having finished the books. Please do not take this as a "knock" against The Dog Who Saved Me. It is not intended to be. What it is intended to do, if you haven't already done so, is to encourage you to not only read The Dog Who Saved Me but to read Wilson's three previous books mentioned at the beginning of this review.

Similar to other silicone gloves my wife and I have used, we haven't had a chance to try these Kitchonics silicone gloves on the barbecue yet because of the cold weather here, but they have performed very well in our oven. We have able to touch the oven racks at 400 degrees with no problem at all. We have also found them to come in handy for opening tight jars, as the silicone provides a good non-slip gripping surface. I have rather large hands and these gloves are fine for me-my wife has small hands and she tells me the gloves fit her comfortably as well. Further, in addition to these gloves being very functional, my wife (and I admit that I do too) find the orange color to be quite attractive.They are easy to keep clean with soap and water-unlike fabric gloves that often stain or char.All in all this is a product that we didn't know we needed but are glad we received! Silicone heat resistant gloves are now the only type of gloves we will be buying in the future for grilling and cooking. We can't wait to use them outdoors with our grill!These gloves from the seller in return for an honest, unbiased review.

When Kootek offered to send me a complimentary sample of their Foldable Monopod Selfie Stick in return for a honest, unbiased review I accepted their offer because I wanted to see how it compared to the The Original Selfie Stick brand I had been using. I had considered the Original Selfie Stick to be good enough but far from flawless. Mainly I found that stick to be a bit cheaply made overall, to do just a so-so job in terms of the stick staying firmly in place when extended its fullest or even close to its fullest, to being adequate AT BEST in securing holding my iPhone 6 in its holder -- especially when extended, and to its bluetooth remote shutter button being a a bit annoying since it is a separate piece that slides onto the handle and, thus, doesn't always stay in the place where you want it to be.My in-going expectation was that this Kootek Selfie Stick was probably not going to be any better than The Original Selfie Stick. I couldn't be more wrong!Since I started using the Kootek product I have been very satisfied with it in every way possible.
