(The 6V cords that I have from other devices do not fit the plug.)There is an app for Apple IOS devices on the App Store and the manufacturer indicates that there will soon be an app for Android devices via Google Play, although no release date is known as of this writing.  Where I use the phrase iPhone/iPad below - that is because I can only test on those devices, not that the feature will be limited to those devices.  The monitor pairs with your smartphone or tablet via Bluetooth but you should verify your device compatibility on the A&D web site.A HUGE feature for iPhone/iPad users not discussed by A&D:  their IOS app DOES offer to share its data with Apple's Health App (via "Health Kit") in IOS 8.1 and above!  It does not 'talk' to any of the other apps that I use - such as DigiFit, Fitbit, MyFitnessPal, etc - but most of them talk to Health (well, Fitbit doesn't...but it talks to others which then talk to Health).The IOS app in the App Store crashed on my iPhone 6+ running IOS 8.1, but the technical support team at A&D provided me with a beta version of version 4.1.2 of their app which has been able to sync fine.  The app still need a little polishing, but is good enough so far.  The pairing process does not follow the steps in the instruction manual or the app screen and looks like it is not successful, but it is.  If you have made multiple BP readings on the device without having the A&D app running on your phone/tablet, then the readings are stored in the memory of the UA-651BLE (up to the 30 most recent readings).  When you do eventually sync, all stored readings are given the date and time of the sync, not the date and time of the reading.  Every time I launch the A&D app, it indicates that it is syncing and downloading data from a scale, but I do not have one of their scales.  The App should be smart enough to not display that message if no scale is associated with the account.  If you accidentally do not get the cuff on tight enough, have the hose unplugged, etc., you'll get a reading of "Err / Err / Err" ... which should be ignored, but is synced to your app.  Almost any screen in the App can be sent to someone else via email, text, FaceBook or more  via a Share button In the app.  The History tab, though, gives a table of all of your readings and the only share option is to AirDrop or Mail the CSV file with the data.  Unlike the other Share buttons, there is no "More" option... which would have allowed the CSV file to be opened in Excel or Numbers, for example, or saved to Dropbox, etc.  A good thing on the History tab is that any row/reading can be deleted by swiping left.  Thus, that "Err" reading, or a reading that is really someone else in your household can be erased so that your graphs correctly reflect your readings.Weakness:  the cuff.  Prior to this A&D UA-651BLE portable battery-powered blood pressure monitor, I had used an Omron 10 Plus Series Upper Arm Blood Pressure Monitor with ComFit Cuff (only USB connectivity) which I had also received as an Amazon Vine reviewer.  The cuff on the Omron is much easier to slip on by yourself than the A&D cuff, as the Omron cuff is completely open, but has an internal material in the cuff that wraps it firmly against the arm before the velcro is used to complete the attachment.  The A&D cuff requires inserting my hand through the opening, pulling it up to my bicep, and holding my arm against my body while I wrap and secure the cuff.Weakness: the built-in memory. The UA-651BLE can store up to 30 readings, and then begins deleting the oldest as new readings are made.  But, for stand-alone use, there is no means to page through these readings as with the Omron mentioned above.  For people who want a home BP monitor and yet don't have or want to deal with a smartphone, this limits the options for stand-alone use.  The only use of the stored readings is to be able to save them for future sync with a mobile app, assuming that no device was paired and syncing during the readings.Multi-user household?  The A&D US-651BLE has no way of distinguishing one person from another.  So assuming you can pair it with multiple devices (I cannot test because of the crash in the public version of their app) - you would have to have the A&D app running ONLY on the device that is supposed to receive the readings.  That is, if my wife wants her BP history on her phone in the A&D and Health apps, and I do as well, then only one of us could have the app running so that the appropriate phone will connect and upload the data.  If you allow the device to save readings for later transmission, you'll have no way of sorting them out to the appropriate mobile device ... they'll all just go to the next mobile device that has the app running at the end taking a new reading.  The Omron has a physical slider switch for users A and B and saves data for 2 users separately.  While that device requires a USB connection to upload data, the concept of a 'user' button is a good one.  Many of us have Wifi scales such as the Fitbit Aria Wi-fi Smart Scale that automatically detect which user is on the device ... and when confused (because weights are similar), lets you tap through a screen of user initials before the device uploads the data.  Because a lot of people have Wifi connected fitness devices such as that, I should emphasize the difference between that and a Bluetooth device such as the A&D monitor.  The Fitbit Aria uploads via wifi - no mobile device required - directly to the Fitbit "cloud";  from there, the readings are viewable in any web browser and are downloaded to any apps connected to your cloud account.  In contrast, your A&D US-651BLE readings are not transmitted remotely via a wifi/internet connection, but directly to one of your mobile devices IF the A&D app is running on that device.  The device uploads the readings to A&D's "WellnessConnected" web service so that any other connected mobile A&D App can see all of the same data.  There is currently no web login that I could find to view the readings stored on the A&D cloud.  (I do not want to suggest that there is anything 'wrong' or 'backwards' about how A&D is performing bluetooth and then cloud syncing... that is the same thing that happens with bluetooth heart rate montors and Digifit, and with Fitbit fitness trackers, too, for example.Bottom line:  Accurate, portable, very reasonably priced and with a 5 year warranty, the UA-651BLE is easy to recommend even without the associated app.  The IOS app - once debugged and improved - with its charting and sharing capabilities - particularly sharing with the Apple Health App for devices running IOS 8.1 and above - makes this a device worth considering for anyone who is into digital health monitoring.  A star is dropped because of the issues detailed above.

Useful self-massage (and assisted massage) tool which allows controlled pressure with no friction/tugging on the skin - or clothes, for that matter - due to the ball-bearings for the center roller.  I found it helpful both for warm-up as well as after running.  It is a different type of massage for your quads and calves (for example) than self-massage with your hands; each has value.

Like so many, I suffer from dry eyes.  So dry that I couldn't wear contact lenses.When my eyes are dry enough that they really bother me, including getting dust/debri in them that I cannot flush out due to lack of tears, Visince Tears Lubricant has been my 'go to' solution.  This 'Long Lasting' version is a slightly different formulation than the prior Visine product I'd been using, and is both soothing and lasting for me.  (Before I went to 'artificial tears' - I tried just washing my eyes with contact lens saline solution when they were dry/gritty - which worked, but of course did not keep them moist which the added ingredients here accomplish.)Recommended.

I applied these door edge film strips to a Chevy full size pickup's front doors, which came without any factory protection.  The somewhat narrow width turned out to be perfect, allowing the strips to wrap without running into inside-edge irregular shapes in the doors.  The strips were also a bit longer than required, trimming being preferable to being too short.Even though I cleaned the door edge first and kept my hands away from the strip, there are still a couple of places where the adhesion did not result in complete transparency, so the appearance is a little off in those spots.  Also, where there was a crease/sharp bend in the door shape on the outside, the inside did not adhere well after wrapping.  Even slitting the material to let it lay flat did not get the inside to lay flat.Satisfied so far for the price, in spite of the above.  The key will be how long this holds up compared to the factory strips on our other vehicle.  I update my reviews regularly as needed, so if you don't see an update here, it means the strips are still going strong.

I think these Nutiva free-trade, organic, gluten-free, vegan treats taste great!  Pretty similar to a soft macaroon, but a bit oilier and less attractive.Compared to other energy bars or coookies that are also free-trade, organic, gluten-free, and vegan (a small list for all of those qualities), the price is slightly on the high side.  But, while I don't feel 'satisfied' until I've eaten 3 or 4 times the calories in other treats, one of these Nutiva O'Coconuts and a cup of tea satisfies my craving for a snack and I sit here typing this review with a happy belly.My one ding is the packaging.  I had to use scissors to open each pack, as there isn't any kind of notch to make tearing the package open an easy task.

These AmazonBasics headphones do not have an audiophile's frequency response and squeeze a bit tightly to my head.  But, they're attractive, with comfortable padding and good sound quality for the price.  That the ear pieces rotate flat for putting in a carry on bag or desk is a nice plus.The sound is a bit boomy with limited high frequency response, fine for rock (a little muddy) - but not that great for classical;  fine with Netflex, etc.  Overall, an excellent value for about the price of a movie ticket.  Very subtle "R" and "L" on the inside of the head band to figure out which ear is which, for when it matters.They feel too snug on my head (almost painful after a while) - compared to my higher end headphones - but that snugness means that you can wear these while working out without worrying about them falling off.

You get what you pay for.  I have two Honeywell programmable thermostats that I purchased from Amazon a few years ago  -  Honeywell  RTH7600D Touchscreen 7-Day Programmable Thermostat.  The instructions for installation and usage for the Honeywell are crystal clear and well-illustrated, programming with the touchscreen (and no physical buttons and sliders like this Lux) is extremely easy and the shell has a solid feel to it.In contrast, this Lux thermostat's plastic shell and buttons feel cheap;  you have to flip the front open and manipulate sliders and hold various buttons down - 2 seconds in one case, 5 seconds in another - to switch into modes that let you program.  The installation instructions are a bit of a joke - so many steps are omitted and so few are illustrated.  For example, the obvious step of detaching the back plate for installation is not mentioned, and it wasn't completely obvious how to do it without trial and error.  After wiring the back plate, they never tell you to push the thermostat onto it.  Not worth detailing every step that had errors or was omitted, but it wouldn't matter too much for someone who has installed a thermostat before - but for someone for whom this is their first, I just cannot recommend the Lux in comparison with the crystal clear and lavishly illustrated Honeywell installation manual - down to Honeywell's caution to properly dispose of the toxic mercury switch in old thermostats.  The PDF manuals for these and most products are online, so I recommend that buyers review them before purchasing to get a full feel for installation and operation.The display on the screen does not look like the photo with this product listing, so they must have changed the software.  The room temperature number is smaller, and there is a permanent battery level display to the right of it in the shape of a battery with a %-sign next to it.  Because my batteries are new (not included), it looks almost like a large black "1" to the right of the room temperature.  Ugly, confusing and unnecessary.Granted, this Lux TX9100Uc is half the price of the Honeywell - and for that I can excuse the cheap plastic, but not the poor instructions and software (firmware).  If you're in a cool-only and/or heat-only climate and on a tight budget, I'm sure you'll find this fine.  If you're in an area that needs heat in the morning and air conditioning in the afternoon, you'll want to look at the Honeywell or other thermostats that can handle multiple modes automatically per day, as this Lux can only be in heat or cool mode based on a a slider switch behind the hinged front panel.UPDATE 11/2/14:  This TX9100Uc is not "daylight savings time" aware.  My old Honeywells, mentioned above, automatically set themselves back an hour last night, but not this Lux.  I see now that it isn't mentioned as a product feature, although another Lux product has it.  Another reason for me to not particularly recommend this thermostat.

CenturyLink recently upgraded me from ADSL (20 Mbps contract speed) to VDSL (40 Mbps contract speed).  I wasn't getting full speed because I only had an ordinary phone extension cord to reach the modem from the nearest jack and there wasn't a convenient way of reducing that distance.Nobody in town, even Radio Shack, sold twisted pair (noise isolated) phone cables, so I ordered this C2G cable... which has been perfect.  The CRC errors reported by the modem at negligible now - about 1% of the errors previously, and my speed bumped up.  Even negotiates a higher speed.  Very worthwhile purchase in my case.

Perfect fit and makes an old pair of QC2's feel like new.  The pair of cushions (and scrims) that we received was shipped directly from Bose as the seller.  I see a different seller is now listed, so it is worth inquiring that the product shipped will be an original Bose component and not aftermarket.

Bose, Bose, Bose.  Years go by and you guys don't learn...  There are two versions of the QuietComfort 2 - which are only distinguishable by the shape of the socket/plug for the audio cable.The original QuietComfort 2 has a perfectly round black plastic shaft.  The revised version, matching this cable, has a slot in the headphone for a long ridge along the shift.  The perfectly round cable will fit any model.  This version with the ridge only fits the newer version unless you use a tool of some kind (I'll try a Dremmel) to file off the ridge.My cable broke a few years ago, and I had to phone Bose to get them to re-ship the correct cable.  My wife's cable just started disintegrating last month (multiple plastic breaks all along the length, exposing the wires) - so I ordered this, hoping that Bose had their act together by now.  Apparently not.If you are not comfortable cutting/filing down the plastic ridge and your old QC 2 was one, like mine, that did NOT have the ridge, you would be better off phoning Bose directly to make sure that they send the correct cable.  If they even still have it available.

I've used NiMH rechargeables since they first appeared in AA and AAA sizes. My previous chargers were dumb "light goes green when done" chargers. This BC-2000 charger is pretty amazing in comparison, offering choices for charge current, progress indicators showing storage capacity and voltage, special discharge and reconditioning modes, and a test mode that works even with alkaline batteries. (Be sure NOT to insert alkaline batteries in any other cycle!)Compared to having to separately use a multimeter to check the status of my batteries - without as much information as provided here - the Ambient Weather charger is a breeze. Love it so far after charging 3 batches of NiMH batteries.Also, my other chargers require insertion of batteries in pairs, and this charger treats each battery bay as a separate charger. You can insert and remove any number as needed.Only slightly strange thing is that the user manual - including the PDF online - says that the device will default to charging at 200 mA, but the default is 400 mA. No biggie, just weird that the online PDF isn't updated. I'm guessing this is something to do with the update to the device, as the box has a big round sticker saying "with 2nd generation firmware and hardware design".The User Manual, like the device, is something only a nerd/geek will read and understand. The average consumer - which includes pretty much every family member I can think of - would not understand half of the manual, nor figure out how to operate the options on the charger. A simple, graphical 'how to' for each task would make using this charger a piece of cake for even a member of Congress.

Durable, good fit, but with a glossy finish, it is somewhat slippery in dry hands.  Had to put some tape strips on the surface so that my wife felt comfortable that her iPad wouldn't slip out of her hands.

These Mead scissors are sharp with a tight fit between blades that cuts paper and thin fabric well, although if the intention is for sewing, I'd recommend a high quality fabric shears instead.The shape of the finger holes is such that they work left or right handed.  However, the geometry of the holes makes these uncomfortable in my hand - which is not that massive - skinny long fingers that normally wear an XL man's glove size.  A similarly sized pair is more comfortable for me simply by having the thumb 'hole' extend at least as far as the multi-finger 'hole'.  (You can see in the photo of the product that the far edge of the thumb hole is closer to the blades than the other hole.Each blade is engraved with metric notches every centimeter for measuring.  As an international product, it would be nice if one blade was metric and the other had inches and fractional inches.Fine for everyday use with medium or small hands.

I cannot believe how bad this "Motorola" streaming camera and the associated Hubble cloud service are.  I've rarely reviewed anything so horrifically badly implemented, and advise all readers to avoid this device even if, as me, it is provided at no cost to you.  Look instead to something like the Dropcam Pro Wi-Fi Wireless Video Monitoring Camera.  Yes, the up front cost will be more, but that will diminish over time if you subscribe to cloud storage - but also, you'll get a true clear, smooth, high-definition video stream instead of the fuzzy, jerky video transmitted by this FOCUS66.This was so bad, that I had to verify that indeed, Motorola does not exist as an engineering firm any longer (we old timers would associate Motorola with quality based on name recognition).  Instead, it is a patent portfolio and the name and logo are licensed for marketing purposes in this case to a company called Binatone Electronics which created this device and the Hubble video cloud service available at http://hubbleconnected.comSetup is a convoluted process using the Hubble app for IOS and Android to connect to the camera as if it were a WiFi hotspot.  My first sign of trouble was touching the link to read the full terms and conditions... as there was no exit or back button to get me back to where I had already entered my desired user name and password.  I got multiple "Unable to join the network" messages on my iPad Air as I followed the instructions to set up the camera even though it was in pairing mode.  After multiple attempts, I finally connected and got it set up ... and then no live streaming would appear.  I connected, and quit the iPad app multiple times and could never get a live stream.  Installed on my iPhone and again no live stream...  and eventually, only on my iPhone, I got a message that the camera firmware needed an update.  After that, live streaming worked.  (As another reviewer has noted - it is not at all clear if a live stream on a local network only uses the local network, as the manual states, or does in fact go through the Hubble cloud servers.)My internet connection is fast.  VDSL with 40 Mbps down and 5 Mbps up.  So, my observations of this camera's quality have nothing to do with my connection...The live stream is jerky (low frames per second), has a very small viewing cone, and is fuzzy.  If I was trying to recognize a burglar, determine if a baby spit up saliva or food, etc. ... it would be impossible.  If this indeed produces 720p video ... the quality of those pixels is so low, that it is irrelevant.  The images are simply horrible.  Yes, I removed all packing plastic and cleaned the lens.Contrast this jerky live stream to the incredibly detailed, smooth, true high-def image that I get from a relative's Dropcam Pro stream.  Night and day - and the Dropcam has a wider viewing angle to capture more of a room or other scene, among other superior features.Motion alerts.  How could they be as bad as they are?  The default is that the camera can send alerts for motion or sound.  You can tune the sensitivity and even turn either off.  Other cameras have an internal buffer so that when motion is detected, the video clip saved begins slightly before the motion.  With the FOCUS66, the video clip starts considerably after the motion (my cats are my test subjects) ... and then continues for a long time with no motion whatsoever.  For example, a typical cat capture with the camera aimed at the door for them wanting in has a couple of seconds of cat, followed by about 25 seconds of the door. Worthless for home security, babies, or whatever you want the streaming cam to capture.  This, too, is something that Dropcam does right.To watch the alert video on your IOS device or for Mac users in the Safari web browser... what looks like a video player comes up ... with a round 'thumb' for the time position within the video as it plays.  But, the IOS app or Mac browser (don't have Android or Windows to test there) will not let you "scrub" the video ... to drag the thumb dot backwards or forwards to a critical frame and then pause.  You must instead close the viewer and then watch again from the beginning.You can log onto the Hubble site on a desktop computer and download these alert videos.  Strangely, you can only download from a desktop - which does not have the ability to control certain other settings that only the IOS or Android app can do (e.g., set the temperature format to F or C).  BUT... is it mp4?  No!  The fuzzy, jagged, jerky downloaded video is in FLV/Flash format.  Who are they kidding.  Have you tried to edit an FLV video?Temperature.  It is kind of cool that the FOCUS66 has a temperature sensor and can even send temperature alerts (you set a low and high temp).  But, Fahrenheit vs Celsius:  you can only choose the scale on the IOS or Android app ... but if I select Fahrenheit there - then I see Celsius in Safari on my Mac.  Have to wonder if these people tested anything at all before going to manufacturing.Even though I got a pre-release version of this FOCUS66 for free, I have absolutely no idea what I might use it for since the picture is of such low quality and the motion capture clips are unreliable and grab the wrong content.UPDATE: Yesterday, the Hubble server would not let me view the motion alerts for at least an hour (I was then without a signal for a while).  If the alert is important:  e.g., baby or intruder, any kind of server issue makes the alert almost worthless.

I've been using the same stainless steel fingertip strawberry huller for about 40 years, one very similar to Norpro 5127 Strawberry Huller with Finger Grip.  It works well with any size berry, as long as it is soft (ripe), particularly with local or wild berries.  The finger grip lets the huller stay on your hand while you have both hands available to work with the berries and waste.  (I slip it on my middle finger; others with smaller hands use their thumb.)  Equally nice is that the edges of mine are blunt, making the finger huller safe for children to use.The OXO Twist & Pop huller here at first seems massive for such a simple job and the teeth are quite keep-out-of-reach-of-children sharp.  Yet, for strawberries on the firm side of ripe and of medium to large size - it works remarkably well!  The teeth go right through the leaves, which is part of what makes this OXO huller so fast.. just plunge, twist and pull.  (In contrast, the finger huller mentioned above cannot press through leaves - making the process a little slower as you brush the leaves to the side or pull them off in an extra step.)  The size is actually comfortable in the hand... and I suspect that the large size would make it comfortable for someone suffering from arthritis, too.The OXO is an epic fail for smaller or very ripe berries.  It'll just mash them into mush.The hole left by the OXO huller looks large when the OXO is pressed halfway in before twisting... but when I look at the removed leaves and hull - there really isn't much waste there at all.  Just an illusion based on the shape of the removed bit, I think.... at least on larger berries.  If pushed fully in, the hole is ridiculously large with a lot of wast.  Even on the largest berries, the OXO teeth did not fully close over the hull when twisted, so I never had a case where I needed to push the button to release the hull.In sum:  not safe for children in my opinion, this huller is efficient for medium to large strawberries that are slightly on the firm side.  For riper or smaller berries, and for children, I would look at other methods.

This Bissell 1305 has enough design features that I really like ("Wow, it fits THERE!") to make up for the ones that have me scratching my head ("What WERE they thinking?!").First off, I have to pick on the ambiguity of the product name.  This is NOT a "pet vacuum" - which would be used, presumably, to vacuum your pets, similar to the Electro Groom which we have to vacuum our horse.  (Really... you do vacuum the horse's coat... and would not believe how great this is until you've done it.)  Rather, this is a vacuum that owners of pets that shed hair inside their home will appreciate.  But, pretty much, it is just a vacuum that anyone can use, pets or not.We have a Dyson (mixed feelings - more negative than positive) and a Kenmore HEPA Intelliclean upright (which is great, even on bare floors, but not along edges).With cats and dogs, the (expensive) bag on our Kenmore fills up with animal hair and stray kitty litter long before it has filled with dust and dirt.  A bagless vacuum such as this Bissell is a great choice when lots of pet hair is involved.  A real plus of the Bissell over our other vacuums is its size and edge-to-edge suction.  The vacuum head is not very tall - and easily fits under the toe-kick of our kitchen cabinets - something our other vacuums cannot do.  Stairs!  The width of this Bissell head is only one foot - PERFECT for being able to vacuum the treads of stairs side to side, something none of our other vacuums could ever do.  And, less effort is required for vacuuming stairs due to the swiveling head and the ability to hold/lift the unit by the handle above the dirt tank.  Super long cord lets you get the stairs done without having to move to another outlet at the other end.Do a quick-release on the tank, and place the end in a trash bag and push the bottom/trap-door release button to dump everything you picked up.Attachments?  Very limited.  This comes with a crevice tool and a suction-activated upholstery brush.  No extension arms, dust brush, etc.  And nowhere to store anything other than the crevice tool (inside the extension hose).PowerGlide?  It works well ... and is pretty much the action of the spinning floor brush pulling the vacuum forward while you work, requiring less muscle.There are aspects of the machine design that are very similar to the Dyson (which is of course much more expensive).  Unlike our Dyson (an original model), the vacuum head has rollers in the front to prevent scratching of hardwood floors.  The cyclone suction dirt container feels like a copy of a Dyson.  But, the hose engineering is really lame in comparison.  The Dyson has a single super-long hose that the handle/wand is inserted into - and when you use the hose with tools, it exits the machine in an upwards direction so as not to kink.  In contrast, this Bissell has an extremely short hose connecting to the floor head.  If you remove the hose to use a tool, it is so short that you would have to be on your hands and knees as seen in the manufacturer's photo on this product page.  To get a longer hose, you attach the extension hose, and can now stand... but the hose is kinked:  it exits the vacuum pointed downwards, and you're now pulling the hose upwards to reach things.  Just doesn't make sense and I have to wonder how many years will pass before the hose will tear at that connection.As others have mentioned, the User Guide's assembly instructions leave a lot to be desired.  The detail images for putting the pieces together are about 1" tall, and the part of any image that you need to see is only 1/4" tall.  They should just provide a web link to a web page with large, color images if they cannot justify a better printed manual.Why 5 stars then instead of 4?  Because I view this as a secondary, not primary vacuum (based on the included tools)... and for getting the hairy areas of the house, the stairs, under counters, and the spilled kitty litter, this lightweight, bag-free Bissell seems a great choice.

I'm very pleased with the value and performance of this SanDisk Extreme PRO 480 GB SSD.I was a SSD early adopter and only felt that I could afford a 120 GB drive when I originally converted my Early 2008 Mac Pro some years ago when prices were much higher.  While that smaller SSD reduced boot time and application launch time, it was too small to fit my user account onto it.  I cloned that drive onto this SanDisk 480GB unit via an external dock, and replaced the smaller SSD with the SanDisk in the Icy Dock EZConvert 2.5-Inch to 3.5-Inch SATA SSD / Hard Drive Converter which fits the pre-2013 Mac Pro drive bays perfectly.  Finally, I migrated my User folders to the SanDisk SSD boot volume from one of the other internal hard disks.Performance is excellent and significantly better than when I only had the operating system on an SSD.  The SATA controllers on my 2008 Mac Pro are only capable of 3 GB/s so I cannot obtain the advertised peak data transfer rates.  Nonetheless, system performance with the SanDisk SSD is excellent and will keep this old computer going for some time to come.

This Logitech Big Bang case provides great protection from abuse via a thick rubberize surround.  If you'll be using your iPad Air in an environment where it is likely to be abused - for example at a trade show with concrete floor - I would definitely consider this.  I don't like it at all for every day use, though, because of its weight and bulk.It's easy to slip the iPad Air into the case, but the cover is a little squirrelly - does not always shut perfectly like an Apple Smart Cover... and so the magnet to put the iPad to sleep or wake it up doesn't always do its thing.  The Logitech description says that the cover safeguards from accidental spills ... but it doesn't cover any of the ports - only the lock and volume buttons - so liquid spilled on the iPad can still enter the headphone jack, lightening charge port, speakers, etc.  The case is so thick, that it is impossible to plug a credit card reader into the headphone jack without buying a special extension cable.I would argue with the product description as "ultra-slim, feather-light".  Who are they kidding?  The case weights almost as much as the iPad Air itself!  My Air (cellular model) is 1.06 pounds and the case is .92 pounds.  Total is about 2 pounds.  The extra weight and bulk make my Air feel like the iPad 1.All of these factors make me drop a star for this case which is still very suitable for many environments.I'd use this when at a trade show or other harsh environment where the Big Bang protects the air from abuse and its stand offers multiple angles securely, unlike the unstable vertical position with an Apple Smart Cover.  But on a day to day basis, try as I did, I just hated the weight,  bulk and tactile feel of the Big Bang and prefer my Belkin Shield Sheer Matte Case / Cover for iPad Air (iPad 5) (Smoke) which only weights 2.5 ounces and my Apple  iPad Air Smart Cover - Black which weights less than 4 ounces.  Total is more than 8 ounces lighter than the Big Bang and feels great in my hand.

I am a very long-time user of Norton / Symantec products and highly recommend Norton 360 Multi-Device 2014 - 1 User / 5 Devices [Download] and various other combinations of multi-license packs of Norton 360.As I write this, the Norton web site does not provide ANY information whatsoever about what software products will be installed on Windows, Mac, Android or IOS devices as part of this "Small Business" package.  That's just unacceptable.  Because it is a business product... I expected top-of-the-line Norton products, namely Norton 360 and Norton Hotspot Privacy for mobile devices.  But that is not the case.I was extremely disappointed that this 10 device "Small Business" pack - which costs more per device than the 360 Multi-Device - installs only Norton Internet Security under Windows, rather than their complete 360 product.  Why pay more to get less?The main features of 360 that I miss in plain Internet Security are the file and registry clean-up utilities.Symantec does not offer multiple options for Macs, IOS or Android devices... so there was no need to evaluate installation on those platforms.  (In general, you can read that people advice NOT installing the product on Macs... and IOS devices already have the features that Norton provides.)The only positive thing I can say for this ambiguously-marketed product is that it allows the distribution of its overpriced licenses to other individuals (presumably in your small business) by registering their email address...so that the recipients do not need access to your confidential Norton ID login credentials.

We've brewed teas from Traditional Medicinals and several other organic producers for many years, but had not tried this Green Tea / Peppermint combination before.Delicious and smooth, it should really be called "Peppermint Green Tea", as there is twice as much peppermint leaf by mass and the mint is the only noticeable flavor.  In one test brewing, I brewed a cup of this tea, a cup of peppermint only, and a large cup with peppermint as well as green tea bags.  I used the Traditional Medicinals long brewing method of 10 to 15 minutes (advised for pretty much all of their products)- which goes against typical advice for brewing green tea (shorter time and lower temperature to avoid bitterness).I could detect no green tea flavor at all in this tea when compared to pure peppermint tea, nor could I detect any bitterness - which was quite evident in my other test cup which brewed organic green tea and peppermint together for the same duration.The box claims about 12 mg caffeine per bag, which is about half that of green tea brewed alone - and is as much as the maximum Mayo Clinic measured for certain decaffeinated black teas and coffees.We choose Traditional Medicinals teas for the health benefits of certain of their blends along with being certified organic, Fair Trade and non-GMO.  This is a very pleasant minty tea at a remarkably good price via Amazon.

I'm very pleased with this Linksys WRT1900AC router so far.  It's replacing a Netgear WNDR3800 N600 Premium Edition Dual Band Gigabit Wireless Router to provide AC service as well as extended wifi range.Setup was painless.  The wizard could be accessed either via Wifi (I used my iPad), or via cable and connection to 192.168.1.1.  The instruction booklet contained the default SSID and password, so that if configuring via Wifi, there was no need to look at the small print on the sticker on the device, as is often the case.  We have a variety of Macs, iPads, iPhones, AppleTV, Nest Thermostat, printers and scanners on our network.  All negotiate their connection to the WRT1900AC faster than to the Netgear, perhaps due to the dual processor managing the Linksys.  I reserved certain network addresses for certain devices as required by our workflow. Set up up our guest network with a different SSID, renamed devices in the network map.  All easy.Range.  We have full bars now in a bedroom that previously required a range extender, and speedtest shows full internet speed at that location.  While some have commented on the potential additional power requirements of this router, in our case, eliminating the power used by a range extender probably makes that a wash.Speed.  I tested transferring a 1.34GB video file from my gigabit-wired Mac Pro to a recent iMac.  With a Wifi AC connection on the WRT1900AC, the transfer was about 24.8 MB/s (megabyte, not bit) and with a wired gigabit connection it was 95.7 MB/s, or less than 4 times faster.  In contrast, the best the Netgear could do at N speeds was 3.7 MB/s.  Getting a factor of 6.6 increase in wifi speed to the iMac via AC is tremendous.The USB port painlessly shared a thumb drive with the connected computers.  I haven't tried the eSATA port yet, which is an interesting addition, as it could potentially give NAS-like speed for the attached device.Range, fast device connection speed, fast data transfer, and easy setup make this an easy router to recommend.  The web interface takes some getting used to compared with others that I've used... for example, finding where port forwarding is buried. But, that's my only quibble at this point.UPDATE:  Even happier now that it is clear that the WRT1900AC resolved various device drops that happened with my prior Netgear WNDR3800.  A Wifi laser printer stays available continuously now, where it had to be restarted daily before.  Apple file sharing between our Macs works 100% of the time now - while with the Netgear, connection by name from Finder was not possible, only by IP address... and even that sometimes didn't work and required reconnecting each machine even though they they were otherwise successfully connected to that router and had internet service.  I suffered through it thinking it was an issue with an OS X update; now I know it was the router.  Great to have fast, reliable connections with the Linksys WRT1900AC.UPDATE 2:  The Linksys USB 3 port and gigabit ethernet give better performance for a USB 3 drive than a direct USB 2 connection in my 6 year old Mac Pro.  About 3x faster copying a video file to a USB 3 drive connected to the Linksys WRT1900AC than the same drive connected to a USB 2 port on the Mac Pro.  Also, almost 2 months after my review... our network is still running smoothly and I have not had to power cycle the Linksys router even once.

UPDATE 8/3/2015: I've dropped another star because after 18 months of pretty light usage (about 100 pages per month), the feed mechanism no longer works.  Worked fine one day.  The next time I turned it on, the feed mechanism is making a nasty clicking noise and cannot separate the pages of a multiple page document.  Only a single page can be fed at a time with a click-click-click sound in the process.  I followed the troubleshooting directions and found nothing visibly wrong with the rollers - which I'd not examined before to observe how cheap they are.  Baffled that just out of the blue it stopped working and 6 months out of warranty.  I've become dependent on this fast scanner, but will look to another manufacturer for a replacement. [Other reviewers are reporting this issue as well.]Original Review: Just awful software and documentation, particularly related to the wireless setup.  You cannot simply switch from USB to Wifi and back again, but must re-install the scanner driver and select the interface.  For Wifi, the Access Point method failed for me - the unit never broadcast its SSID for me to connect to it for configuration.  Instead, I had to use WPS setup, which was an option on my router, fortunately.  You can read some other reviews of issues when your router does not have a WPS setup mode.In the box was a big "Notice" sheet saying that the latest firmware had to be installed for the network interface panel before scanning.  Gave a generic Epson web address and said to download the Epson Firmware Updater... but there was no such thing anywhere on the Epson site.  Googling, I found it redirected me to the standard Epson software updater... which did not provide any firmware update, nor even provide any feedback on the firmware.  Epic fail.This DS-560 scanner is the sibling of the DS-510 scanner that I reviewed in January.  The only difference is the addition of the B/G/N wireless interface.  Both can operate via USB 2.  I'm merging some of my comments from that earlier review with ones specific to the DS-560 here:The speed and quietness of this DS-560 scanner is remarkable.  I tested with both large documents and stacks of thin thermal receipts. I easily got the rated 26 pages per minute on the 190 page report that I scanned. The pages were punched for a comb binding (19 rectangular holes in the side) and the corners were dog-eared. After setting up a new job-type that masked the left one half inch to eliminate the binding holes, the scanned document was like new - no dog ears or holes - a perfect scan, incredibly fast. Even with all of the holes and bends, there were no jams.The 26 pages per minute speed is the speed of the paper getting through the machine. There is an additional delay afterwards as the data is transferred to the computer via USB 2 and the software processes the images.For thermal receipts from stores, I changed the paper setting to 'thin' and got excellent results with text enhancement enabled. I set that job to create a fresh PDF for every page (receipt) - vs my job for the large report that kept asking for more pages until the scan for the single PDF was complete.I tested the color drop-out feature which worked very well. Setting a scan to grayscale, I selected blue as the dropout color and scanned a Costco receipt that had a blue highlighter drawn down it. Color gone, image looked like it had never been marked up. A text that has been highlighted with yellow highlighter will scan as if never highlighted. Nice built-in feature.I'm on a Mac...The hardware scan button can be programmed on a Mac, but it only works when connected via USB, not Wifi.  Launch Document Capture, click the Scan > Manage Job menu or the gear icon in the toolbar. Select or create a job. With any job selected, click the gear icon in the Job List > Event Settings ... and pick the job that should be run when the scan button is pressed. Close Document Capture.The software functionality is typical Epson, with options squirreled away in several different tabs and buttons, and not all options available in all places (e.g., Epson Scan vs Document Capture job setup).Note: If you're a Mac user, there is no software included to create searchable PDF's, one of the top features listed for the scanner.  You'll need your own copy of Adobe Acrobat Pro (or something similar) to do that at extra cost. Windows users, however, can scan to searchable (text-recognized) PDF.The Epson driver, when connected via Wifi, does not work with Acrobat Pro in my experience.  It is not a standard Twain driver and communicates partway, then locks up.  When used via Wifi, the scanner is not listed as an available scanner by the OS X Image Capture app, or the system preferences. This is a really serious issue for Mac users and takes a star off my review.  Since you need to use USB for reliable scanning on OS X from apps other than Epson Scan, just buy the cheaper USB-only  Epson DS-510 WorkForce Document Scanner (B11B209201) which I give 5 stars to.Both Windows and Mac platforms have ABBY FineReader to convert scans to editable word processing or spreadsheet documents.  I've found that ABBY does a better job of text recognition for later editing in Word than doing the text recognition in Adobe Acrobat Pro and exporting as a Word document.The Epson software does not come with an Uninstall utility for Mac. The online Help manual directs you to their web site where you can download an uninstaller. Running it, though, only offers the ability to uninstall each Epson app... it does not offer the ability to uninstall any particular Epson scanner. In my case, I have the driver for an old Epson scanner on my machine... and so that scanner and this new DS-560 both show up every time I want to scan with the Epson software, and I have to choose which one to use. Epson provides no way to remove the unused, old driver (much less this new DS-560 driver).IOS app...I installed the Epson Documentscan app on my iPad and it found the scanner and provided a basic set of settings for the scan, although there was no control at all for compression level.  Scanning a two-sided document created a huge PDF.  Once saved in the app, you can send it to an email, Dropbox, OneDrive, GoogleDrive, Kindle, etc.But, if someone wants to go paperless and only has a tablet, the app just isn't adequate.  Suppose you have a stack of receipts that you want in your Dropbox as individual, named documents for taxes.  You have to initiate a separate scan for every receipt.  From the desktop app, you can specify that each page will be a separate document, load 50 receipts, and you're done (other than renaming the files perhaps).Scanning BOTH sides of a two-sided document so quickly and with so little noise is almost magical. The software issues, difficulty in setting up a Wifi connection other than via WPS, inability to switch between Wifi and USB modes, and the lack of an included carrier sheet drops one star for me.  If I were to give an overall "normal" consumer rating, thinking of non-IT people I know who would find the instructions, software and setup challenging ... or thinking of someone who only wanted this for wireless access from their mobil device...I would give it 3 stars.

This Francois et Mimi (made in China, as are most stainless steel items these days) 50 ounce french press is an excellent value and makes great coffee if you fill the pot near to its capacity.  The actual capacity is approximately 42 ounces - not counting the volume lost to the grounds.... so about three 12 ounce mugs in reality.The reason for my caveat about making a full pot is that, unlike the other dozen or so french presses that I've had or still have, the stem on the press mechanism here is too short - and when pressed fully down, the screen is about 2.25 inches above the bottom of the carafe.  If you make less than a full pot, this means that you'll have grounds and water sloshing around below the screen continuing to extract the bitter remnants of the grounds, agitating the sediment and not letting the other grounds help filter out the finest particles when you pour.With a full or nearly full pot (I added 9 scoops of grounds and water to within an inch of the spout), this screen position isn't an issue and the resulting coffee was super.Assuming that the other presses by Francois et Mimi have the same short press stem, I'd advise choosing a model that is closer to what you would normally brew.I have a variety of smaller (32 ounce and below) presses, so this press is a welcome addition for when we have company or I feel a need to get really wired.  The double-walled carafe keeps the bottom from getting warm - leaving it safe to place on any surface.  It also keeps the coffee hot for quite a while - 20 minutes after pouring my first mug, the coffee was still as hot as I would want it and had not turned bitter yet.My only quibble beyond the short press stem is that when you disassemble the screens (simply unscrew like all presses) - the thin mesh screen just has a hole cut in the center.  I'm not sure how many years this will last ... my other presses, 3 different brands, all have a stainless steel washer welded or crimped to this center hole for reinforcement.  Dishwasher-safe, yet you do need to disassemble the screens to clean thoroughly, unlike Frieling's which are shaped in a way that can often (not always!) clean the screens in a dishwasher without disassembly.This somewhat retro / 60's-looking 50 ounce Francois et Mimi press does not have the heft or the modern design of a Frieling Polished Stainless French Press, 23-Ounce (44-Ounce), but at a fraction of the cost it is an excellent value and highly recommended.-----------Proportions used for testing:I dialed my Breville BCG800XL Smart Grinder down to the French Press position, and selected 8 cups.  This produced 9 scoops of coarsely ground coffee which went into the pre-warmed press.  Water boils at my high altitude at 202 degrees, which is just right for press coffee, so I filled the press halfway with boiling water and covered (plunger up), letting it sit for about a minute.  Removed the cover, stirred the floating grounds gently with a wooden spoon a few times - causing them to sink and the crema to develop.  Added enough more water to reach about an inch below the spout.  Covered again and let sit for another 4 minutes before pressing the plunger.  Perfect cup, smooth and rich.

Hard to beat the price for this Samsung Class 6 32 GB SDHC card.  If you have devices that cannot take cards faster than Class 6 (such as my Canon HD video camera), then this card is the best value out there at the moment.Works perfectly in two Canon cameras that I have.  Tested the speed of a full initialization (format) as well as copying files on my Mac... and while the Lexar Multi-Use 32GB SDHC Flash Memory Card (LSD32GASBNACL6) was a bit more than 10% faster, I don't believe that this would affect normal camera operations.  That Lexar card, at this writing, costs 32% more than this Samsung.My only quibble is that the card does not come with a case.  I have lots of memory cards that I take on video shoots and most came with SD-sized plastic cases to keep the contacts clean when not in the camera and to help organize the cards.

This book assumes that you are already a reasonably competent IOS programmer, knowing Objective-C / XCode and Cocoa (Touch).  If you're not there yet, consider a book such as iOS Programming: The Big Nerd Ranch Guide (4th Edition) (Big Nerd Ranch Guides).Examples of the depth of frameworks and techniques that you'll learn from this book include managing multitasking, background processing, low energy bluetooth, UIKit dynamics,  localization, debugging and performance tuning.  A great breadth of frameworks, techniques and tips not to be found in introductory volumes that cover only the basics.  I like that each chapter ends with a list of resources for further reading or information, including links to WWDC videos.

You can tell when a set of authors have not been through the fire of teaching a group of people something in person, but are doing their best to write up their own, expert experience.  Things get explained out of order or incoherently without the experience of interacting with people as they learn, discovering what they needed to know that you forgot to tell them, or watching their faces screw up in confusion and call you on a recursive explanation that actually says nothing.This is such a book, in my opinion.  It has some valuable information because of the depth of coding experience of the authors - but even for an experienced programmer who might already know some Objective-C and Cocoa, I find the presentation tangled.  For example, the audience is defined as "a reasonably capable programmer", and yet the chapter introducing Objective-C alleges to introduce what it means to be an object-oriented language (something a capable programmer in 2014 should be aware of anyway) ... and then manages to not provide a meaningful overview of what it means to be object-oriented...or to introduce Objective-C for that matter.  The Cocoa frameworks are not so much introduced with their purpose and overview and master hierarchy as much as bits and pieces are simply used here and there.  There is no big picture.The publisher, O'Reilly, should be ashamed of the quality of the printing for the screenshots which are pretty much unreadable and muddy. My 'favorite' is Figure 7-13  which is pretty much a solid gray screen which was supposed to represent a blue gradient fill.  In general, the screenshots are not that necessary for following the content so not a deal breaker.In contrast to this book, the books associated with "The Big Nerd Ranch" and author Aaron Hillegass are clean and clear as one reads and learns and I recommend them instead for those looking for a sequential learning resource.Slight tangent:  Even with the new Swift language from Apple (June 2014 / XCode 6 Beta) replacing Objective-C as the recommended language for new code (or at least new coders), anyone working on the OS X or IOS platforms needs at least a reading, if not working, knowledge of Object-C because of the vast amount of existing code and resources in Objective-C.  So, don't think that Swift eliminates the usefulness of books such as this one.

Ready to just plug into a Mac and use, this high capacity and USB 3 fast Seagate 4 TB drive is an excellent value.  But, the noise it makes is really annoying.  Really annoying.  It varies from a constant grinding whir to a buzzing, most of which seems related to the plastic shell which is a little loose and clearly has no sound-dampening pads attached to the inside.  If your Mac has a fan, you probably won't notice this.  For new iMacs which are almost silent, as well as Macbook Airs which are silent, this could be a factor for you.  Of course, if you have forced air ventilation where you use this, you'll never notice.The plastic shell is attractive and has small rubber feet for placing the drive horizontally on a work surface.  The corners are dangerously sharp.  I'm not really sure why the photos show the drive placed vertically like the previous generation of Seagate drives... because this drive is not designed for vertical orientation.  If you're hoping it will match your aluminum Mac hardware, it won't - the color is a darker, more of a steel than aluminum, but it looks fine.

I'm reasonably happy with this D-Link DAP-1520 Wifi range extender...when it works.  (Note that Amazon has aggregated all kinds of D-Link device reviews together here... be sure you look for reviews that actually cover the device you're considering.  No idea why Amazon does this!)Setup was easy using the WPS buttons on both the unit and my Netgear WNDR3800 N600 Premium Edition Dual Band Gigabit Wireless Router.  You can also perform the setup through a web browser interface to the device.  Be sure, regardless of how you perform the setup, to go to the web interface and update the firmware.  My DAP-1520 came with firmware version 1.00 and the update at this writing was to version 1.02 which was dated 3/24/14.My router is on one floor, and I plugged this DAP-1520 in a central location on the next floor where the signal to the router was strong.  The result is a strong signal everywhere on the second floor for both 2.4GHz and 5GHz transmitters.  I find that I get slightly better speed test results with the 5G frequency, with a big BUT:  the range for 5G is very limited.  If I go out in the yard, I lose 5G pretty quickly, but the 2.4G range is over 50 feet.As with all Wifi, the distance from the transmitter reduces the data rate.  You may see full bars, 2 bars, etc... but those discrete 'levels' do not reflect the continuous small loss of signal as distances increase.  I saw nothing about this DAP-1520 that was out of the ordinary for Wifi performance, except that I believe that the internal antennae are not adequate for both frequencies.  Close to the device, I get slightly higher speeds over 5GHz... at about 30 feet, I get half the speed at 5GHz, but only slightly less performance over 2.4GHz.My house is vertically arranged, so for practical purposes, this device fills my low signal spots and is perfect.  For a sprawling house, you might need several extenders (although you should then centrally locate your router so that you're not extending the extenders and losing performance that way).Neither my router, not any of my devices can handle the newer AC protocol, so I cannot evaluate the DAP-1520 on its acceptable implementation and relay of that.I dropped to 2 stars stars because the DAP-1520 has become 'wedged' daily, offering only about 300kbps downloads on either channel.  After unplugging it and plugging it back in, speeds returned to normal.  Not worth dropping another star is the peculiar continuous handshaking and waste of bandwidth that the DAP-1520 does with my router... transferring about 1k of information every second when no devices are connected.If D-Link comes out with another firmware update to keep the device running at full speed without daily reboots, then I'd be happy considering how effective this is in my house, how easy this is to set up, and how compact and inconspicuous the device is.

FileMaker - A Mixed BagFileMaker Pro 13 (FMP13) continues FileMaker's excruciatingly slow evolution.  Instead of the tag line "An Apple Subsidiary", the FileMaker Inc tagline should be  "Owned by Apple, but apparently with no Apple Product Management Oversight" lest buyers anticipate an Apple-like experience.This should be a great product, but I rate it as just 3-stars, which is "It's OK" in Amazon's rating scale.  I've taken a few weeks to evaluate version 13.0v3, test new databases, and convert parts of an existing database.Bottom line at the top (for those who don't want to read my long ramble):  If you expect that your database needs are and will remain limited to ONLY Windows desktops, then in my opinion, Microsoft Access is your strongest choice.  (Even Access 2002, which I am still using, is more powerful on the Windows platform than FMP13.)  In all other configurations - requiring Mac, Windows and Mac, desktop and mobile, desktop and web, etc - FMP13 is really the only game in town.  Give the 30-day trial a whirl to see if it satisfies your needs.The good:One of the best things about FileMaker is that it is cross-platform (Windows and Mac - unlike Microsoft Access), and is multi-user, including mobile devices with the free FileMaker Go app for IOS.  This functionality is only on your local network (LAN), unless you purchase a subscription to FileMaker Server.  Working with my iPad and desktop at the same time was seamless.With FileMaker Server, you can not only have multiple users on multiple devices anywhere... you can also provide a web interface to your database.  (In FileMaker  Pro 12, you could provide a web-based interface to your database at no extra charge using Instant Web Publishing.  That feature was removed from FMP13.)  FM Server is licensed annually, so it is a continuous cost, and not cheap.  You still need the hardware platform to run Server, but the software fee runs from $348/year for one user to $3,348/year for up to 50 concurrent users.  (Web designers expecting large numbers of visitors would of course look elsewhere to things like MySQL solutions.)Another strength of FileMaker is the attractive presentation of Layouts - which represent on-screen forms as well as reports.  With 13, there is even more flexibility in defining Themes, which allow for easily changing the color scheme, fonts, etc ... and for making groups of Layouts consistent.  (This is not unlike themes in certain design products.  It is not like CSS themes for web sites in that a subsequent theme change does NOT change existing Layouts...only new ones.)The fact that FileMaker can operate on desktops, phones, tablets and web browsers, and has Themes, would lead one to suppose that it might have fluid layouts that automatically conform (per rules) to screen sizes, like modern fluid web site designs.  But, unfortunately, that's not the case.  As the examples included in the product illustrate... you'll most likely want to design separate layouts for each screen type.The not-so-good:Crash example.  FMP13 crashed numerous times while I tried to import a variety of Excel files (.xls).  Opening and re-saving the files in Excel got me past that.Bug example.  Auto-update tables don't refresh the data in linked layouts.  I imported an Excel file with the setting to refresh the contents upon launch and displayed a Layout that showed records that were joined to that table.  I edited the Excel data, quit FMP13 and relaunched... and the Layout looked the same... the linked fields did not change.  Only by switching to the layout for the refreshed table and then going back to the desired layout did I see the effect of the re-import.  Pretty serious as the wrong data is initially seen.  (FMP13 can live-link to other FMP13 databases, which is great, so you can partition your data and share bits of it as needed.  I just wish it could live link to other external files like Microsoft Access always has - allowing live updates as other software exports updated versions of data as CSV or Excel, etc.)Referential integrity is poorly implemented in my opinion.  By default, when you set up a relationship (join) between two tables, there is NO referential integrity enforcement.  So, even if the second table represents data that has no meaning if the parent is deleted... deleting the parent will leave orphaned records.  You must manually edit the relationship to check the box to enforce integrity.  This differs from Microsoft Access which enforces integrity unless you say not to, and which also warns you if records will be orphaned, or if a deletion will result in a cascade of deletions of child records.  I received no warnings from FMP13 during testing.  A typical user database could end up with all kinds of problems, or dead records.  (A professional database implemented in FMP13 would require extra scripting to provide a better user experience.)Data entry.  I like quick entry.  Other database programs let you tab past the last field in the last record to start typing a new record.  FMP13 requires that you click the `new record' button.  (If scripting can change that behavior, it doesn't help the casual user who will not be writing such scripts.)Joins.  Strangely, if you join two tables and there is no matching record, the fields for the missing match are displayed as blank.  I didn't see a simple way to have either (a) records hidden if there is no join, or (b) to not display the fields if they are empty.  These things are easy and standard in MS Access.Queries.  In Microsoft Access, I can create complex and elaborate queries, both visually and in SQL when the query cannot be represented visually.  FMP13 only allows SQL in scripts, and even then, the SQL can only retrieve data - not perform schema updates or deletions.  FMP13 limits me to the relationships I can draw in the relationship graph.  This is plenty for simple databases.  It is extremely limiting for sophisticated use.Computations.  A big difference between Microsoft Access and FMP13 is the handling of computed fields.  In Access, you compute either inside your query or on your form or report.  In FMP13, you add additional `calculated' fields to your table and reference these fields in your Layouts.  This latter approach clutters up your table's field list ...but on the plus side, it also means that you don't have to repeat (and maintain) the same formula in multiple layouts as is the case with Access (unless the calculation is inside a common query).  What I don't like about the FMP13 approach is that if I have a dozen reports that each has several calculations... I'll then have several dozen additional calculated fields in my FMP13 table, not organized in any meaningful way to tell me which Layouts (reports) they are used in.  I won't know if I need them, when I can delete them, etc.... so the list of fields will probably just grow longer and more confusing over time from concern about deleting something that might be in use somewhere.Missing basic features.  It is quite common to have Boolean (yes/no, true/false, active/inactive) values in a database.  It is extremely common in normal application software and web pages to have a checkbox that corresponds to the state of a Boolean - checked is `on', unchecked is `off'.  But, here we are in 2014 and FileMaker does not have a Boolean or Yes/No field data type at all... much less a checkbox object that can be assigned to such a type.  The closest you can come is a radio button set with two buttons, one for yes, one for no.  Do a web search for `checkbox filemaker' and read through the proposed solutions.  Apple should be so embarrassed.Scripting in FMP13 is more limited than in Microsoft Access, where Visual Basic for Applications can do pretty much anything and interact with other applications as well.  Reformatting individual records in a table view based on the content of one or more fields of that record is much more complicated than with VBA, for example.  While VBA can control all other Microsoft Office apps, FMP13 itself, and its script language, are seemingly unaware of OS X and the standard Apple apps and data such as Contacts, Calendar, Reminders, etc.  Reformatting a single field is super easy in FMP13, though, although the formula builder does not guide the user properly through the steps of performing a full or partial text match.Bento, which FileMaker Inc dropped as a product, could link-in standard Apple data such as Contacts.  It is inconceivable that they did not add this feature into FileMaker for the Mac platform when they canceled Bento...with similar access to Outlook contacts on Windows.  Etc.When you add new fields to a table, and specify a validation that requires a value... that value is not auto-populated into existing records as it is with Access.FMP13 pricing is peculiar and has a disincentive to upgrade.  FMP13 Advanced includes additional tools for development and customization (most of which, by the way, are included in the standard edition of Microsoft Access as far back as 2000).  The retail price of FMP13 is $329 and the retail price of FMP13 Advanced is $549.  For a user who has purchase FMP13 and decides that they would like the debugger and additional features of Advanced, you would think that the upgrade price would be the price difference (or less) - $220.  But no.  It is $299 - and it is the same price even for users for FileMaker Pro back to version 10.  (Similarly, upgrading to FMP13 costs the same for someone who purchased FMP12 last year... as someone who has version 10 from several years ago. )FileMaker Go is a full featured, stable platform from the tests I've run.  Yet, it is frustrating if you do not subscribe to FileMaker Server (and perhaps that is the intention).  You can leave FMP13 running on your desktop, and access the open databases on your iPad or iPhone while on your LAN.  But, to access them off-site requires extra steps.  You cannot, for example, store a copy of the open database on your IOS device over the LAN (except via iTunes copy).  Instead, you can copy the database into your Dropbox or OneDrive space (or email a copy to yourself) and then download and open it on your IOS device...launching FM Go.  When finished modifying the database remotely, you go through multiple steps to save a copy within FM Go and then send it back to Dropbox/OneDrive.  So many other IOS apps have Dropbox/etc integrated... and you'd think iCloud would even be integrated for an Apple-owned company ... but not so.  Needless extra work by the user to move the database to and from your IOS device.FileMaker's interface on the Mac does not align with Apple's `pro app' paradigm.  Its dated interface has floating inspectors and no full-screen mode.  Most strangely, it has just a single palette - the Field Picker - which uses the Pro App heads up display (HUD) graphic scheme of dark charcoal/black with white text.  Really odd.  I don't take any points off my evaluation for this.  It's just worth noting that from a UI perspective, it is as if the FileMaker developers don't follow what parent Apple is doing... and the product lacks overall quality control.FileMaker's help files and tutorials are far from Apple-like and make learning challenging.  Filled with FM-specific jargon and without index terms to standard database management concepts, it is a challenge even for an expert to migrate to the FM platform.  Looking at colleagues who would be casual users... the documentation is insufficient to teach them what they need to know.  The online knowledgebase articles are similarly not aimed for casual users.  All FM resources have insufficient  `how to' topics and no illustrated examples for specific needs and techniques and trade-offs.  It is as if they do not expect new users, but only long-time users who are upgrading.Bottom line:  see the third paragraph.

I had hand surgery this past February and couldn't type for 6 weeks.  Did I use Dragon?  No.  In spite of the amazing speed and accuracy of Dragon Dictate, it has too many usability issues for day-to-day use.  I used the built-in, offline dictation in Mavericks instead (fn-fn)... which allowed me to enter text absolutely anywhere.  Accuracy was perhaps 90% with OS X's dictation feature - but entering text anywhere without putting on a headset let me get through my day, even with small corrections.  I tried to use Dragon, but copying/pasting was just too much effort as you cannot simply place your cursor anywhere and start talking, and it was too much hassle to keep putting on and removing their headset.I gave Dragon Dictate 3 for Mac a 3 star review in November 2012: http://www.amazon.com/review/R32K8LO2C2CRSU/ref=cm_cr_pr_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B009348X7QThe negatives beyond those mentioned in that review as I look at version 4.0 include:- 4.0 offers almost no new features.  The advertised transcription improvements did absolutely nothing to the audio on a video file, the same abysmal failure as I had in 3.0 with audio from a voice recorder.- 4.0 comes only on a DVD... yet no new Macs have optical drives!  (How do you say "marketing idiots"?)  Often, software comes with instructions giving a link to a download page.  Not so with Nuance.  Even their web site offers no download link... although if you purchase at their website (for full retail), they send you to DigitalRiver for a digital download.  Duh.- 4.0 STILL does not recognize the microphones built into Apple displays!  Amazingly dumb that they cannot yet manage this - even though OS X itself can do voice recognition using those microphones.  My Apple LED Cinema Display microphone attached to a Mac Pro is not recognized by Dragon 4.0 ... I have to use a headset.- Nuance does not offer any upgrade pricing- The UI is so dated.  Clearly, Nuance has astonishing technology behind the scenes for the engine of this product... but they seem clueless for how to design a modern UI that interacts well with users and the OS X environment.IF you need to dictate long passages of text into Word, or to be pasted into an email, then Dragon Dictate continues to be astonishingly accurate and able to recognize your voice even when speaking very quickly.  But, if you are partially disabled - as I was for 6 weeks - and want to voice enter text everywhere - Google Search, Facebook comment, email reply, tweet, etc - stick with the OS X dictation and Accessibility features.

I'm totally pleased with the 2797LMT for what it offers, particularly in comparison the the 4.3 inch Nuvi 855 that it replaces.  Are there features I wish it had?  Of course.  But, it provides a stress free driving experience.My old Nuvi 855 is only just now 4 years old.  Feels like 10 years old.  The battery won't hold a charge and the cost of a map update and battery was more than a new unit with lifetime maps would cost.The 2797LMT's big, bright 7" screen and large speaker makes seeing and hearing really pleasant.  The bluetooth pairing with my iPhone gave me better sound quality than a separate Motorola bluetooth device.  Traffic was good enough for a recent week-long visit to Columbus, Ohio where the 2979 kept me off congested roads.  New features over my old unit include being able to create your own avoidances.  A road was blocked for a fair, and it was simple for me to tap on the start and end of the blocked area to have the Nuvi route me around it in a variety of ways.  (It seems that the traffic radio should have 'known' that the road was closed for the 4 day event though.)You can tap on routes to see what the alternate routes are to your destination if you have a reason to choose something other than the default (based on your time or distance setting).  The "Up ahead" feature lets you find banks, gas stations or food options along your route... although I did find some of these were not truly along my route and would have caused detours.  Still, a big improvement over my old unit which gave no idea of if something was on your route.  Tapping icons on the screen gives more details on points of interest coming up, too.The lane guidance and split screens made navigating in a strange city easy.  I liked the tone and speed warning display before I entered school zones.  All voice guidance came at just the right time.  I thought I'd miss the old "recalculating" voice when I changed routes... but I actually didn't.  The Nuvi just very quickly came up with a revised route and kept navigating.Everyone else in the car loved the 2797 and one person plans on buying one herself now, or perhaps the 5" version.The basics are done so well... that now I'm looking forward to a future with better internet connectivity.  The iPhone app lets you search and send addresses to the Nuvi... but doesn't support sending addresses received as texts, email, from a web site, etc.  And, while it lets the Nuvi display the weather... it will be great when it also provides information on POIs.  While we looked for places to eat every day, the Nuvi was of no help as it just has names and locations... if it tied into Yelp, we could have seen ratings and reviews and picked places without having to search our phones/tablets for information.  Sure, a phone-based navigation app might already provide all of that... but not with the large useful display and clear sound of the Nuvi.

My wife is always forgetting where she left her purse, so we thought this would be a cool product.  It is somewhat useful - just not as useful as the manufacturer advertises.(Do note that this is Bluetooth 4.0 - so requires a device that supports that (iPhone 4S or newer, iPad 3 or newer, etc.)The 'separation' alarm only works if the app is running - makes sense.  But, there are all kinds of reasons including airplane mode when this may not happen.  You have to be so far away before the alarm sounds, that a purse could easily be stolen from where you left it at that point.The ringer in the device itself is the only thing we found useful in practice when my wife forgot where in the house she left her purse.

Bushnell has a known presence in both the optical and digital (e.g., Trophy Cam) worlds.It wasn't clear to me from the product description that this is a digital-only viewer.  Yes, there is a beautiful fixed optical lens  - but your only view through the eyepiece is of a low resolution 640x480 (VGA) LCD display.  The pixels are very visible, making it appear that you're looking at the image through a thick screen.There is no point in using this scope during the day.  Get an optical scope or binoculars, or even a good zoom camera for better results.Night vision is remarkable in its clarity and range.  Really bright looking at a hillside 100 yards from my house.  (This was my first infrared device...so a funny note was that I first tried to look through my windows and instead of seeing outside, I saw a perfect reflection of something else in the house.  Was a great verification that my new windows with a low-E coating do indeed reflect infrared radiation!)  As others have noted, the digital view is so bright, that my eye was blinded for quite some time after trying to see normally after viewing.  Definitely needs more fine brightness control of the display.Why 3 stars? --all of the oversights and limitations of the device, which has a list price of over $400.First, a little thing: no batteries or microSD card are included... which would have cost Bushnell just a couple of dollars.  Inexcusable at this price point.  I haven't had a microSD card since an ancient flip phone that is long gone and didn't buy one to complete this review.  The Equinox should accept standard SD cards.  With a memory card, the scope can take low resolution (640x480) pics and videos...grainy images that are not compatible with editing into any kind of modern HD video workflow.  The minimal resolution the device should have is  HD = 960 x 540.The button design.  You're using this at night, right?  So, you cannot see the buttons on top of the monocular.  So, there should be some kind of tactile ridges and dots on the buttons so that you can distinguish, by feel alone, which buttons are which.Battery compartment.  The manual illustrations show that the + and - orientation symbols are white on black to help you insert the batteries properly.  Mine were black embossed on black.  Pretty hard to see.  A further dumb design is that the compartment lid can be oriented incorrectly before screwing on.  You must carefully match the + and - on the lid with those on the body before screwing on the lid.Conclusion:  night vision is pretty cool tech, but this device rates only an "OK" (3 stars) for me based on the low res LCD screen, the use of microSD card (and lack of one in the package), the limited zoom, and the poor usability design (buttons, battery compartment, lack of reasonable brightness control).

This Kensington Keycover for iPad versions 2 through 4 is a niche product and I'm just not in that niche.  I tried to like it over several days with my iPad 3.My review unit arrived without any instructions for charging or pairing, although the instructions found on the Kensington web site could certainly have fit onto the box (3 sentences).  After charging, bluetooth pairing was easy.The keyboard is of course not full-sized (keys spaced the same as a desktop keyboard) - since the entire keyboard would then be larger than an iPad.  Anyone getting their first iPad keyboard should be aware of that.  Not a plus/minus affecting this review, just something to be aware of if you hadn't thought about it.The pros:Relatively lightweight (11 ounces)RechargeableHas a convenient row of function buttons at the top of the keyboardConvenient viewing angle when the Keycover is used on a desk.A real keyboard, for those who have problems typing on the iPad virtual keyboardThe cons:Does not protect the iPad - only the glass.  The back and sides of aluminum are fully exposed to get scratched (and mine did during testing).  The Keycover does not work if any other protective shell is on the iPad such as the Belkin Snap Shield Case Secure for the Apple iPad 3 (3rd Generation) (Black) - the keyboard cannot snap to the iPad, and the iPad with the shell cannot fit into the slot in the Keycover.
