So, fully exposed aluminum seems the only option with this Kensington device.  That may be OK for you.If the Keycover is used on a surface other than desk height, the viewing angle is not ideal - and cannot be adjusted.If the Keycover is used in your lap, sitting or in bed, the iPad has a tendancy to pop out of the stand if you try to angle the keyboard for a better viewing angle.  There is very little physical "purchase" in the little plastic trench that holds the iPad.It takes two hands to unsnap the Keycover from the iPad to use the iPad with or without the keyboard, and two hands to snap it back on.The magnets that lock the iPad screen are only on one side of the Keycover - so the autolock function only works if you place the iPad in the Keycover with the dock connector on the right side of the keyboard.  There is only a notch for the dock connector to be accessible on the right side, so this makes sense... except that there is nothing to keep you from orienting the iPad the opposite way and neither locking the screen nor being able to plug in a cable.  I think the case should have been made symmetrically so that it didn't matter which way you placed the ipad glass against the unit.Personally, I can type quickly on the iPad virtual keyboard, but otherwise prefer a full size keyboard such as the Logitech Tablet Keyboard for iPad, iPad 2, iPad (3rd/4th generation), and iPad mini (920-004440).  It's bigger than the iPad itself and weighs 30% more than this Kensington Keycover, but is easily thrown in a bag with the iPad when going somewhere.If the iPad would stay securely in this Keycover during use, and if there was some film to protect the aluminum back of the iPad that was compatible with this Keycover, then I might actually use it.  Instead, I'll just pair it with my AppleTV and leave it in the living room.

I requested a review unit of this TP-LINK TL-WDN4800 wireless adapter for use in an older Windows PC ... not realizing that that PC was so old that it did not support PCI Express.  So, lesson one is make sure you have PCI Express slots (vs PCI).  That older PC was easily added to our wireless network with a TP-LINK USB adapter, TP-LINK TL-WDN3200 Dual Band Wireless N600 USB Adapter, 2.4GHz 300Mbps/5Ghz 300Mbps, WPS Button, 802.1a/b/g/n, WEP, WPA/WPA2.I read other reviews here, as well as other sites, where people had successfully installed this WDN4800 adapter in their Macs, utilizing the built-in driver in OS X.  I finally attempted that today on a 2008 Mac Pro running OS X 10.8.3 (Mountain Lion).  I was initially stoked as the adapter was recognized when I powered on and turning Wifi on resulted in not only my network being seen - but distant neighbor's networks that do not show up on any of our other wireless devices.  So, clearly the antennas on this WDN4800 can pull in a signal.Unfortunately, that was about as far as I got (on my Mac).  When connected to either 2.4 GHz or 5 GHz, no web sites would show up.  Running Ping from Terminal showed that the connection was indeed live and pings were fast, but watching network traffic in Activity Monitor, there would be a short burst of data transfer followed by nothing, as if there were some kind of buffering conflict between the WDN4800 and OS X.  This is NOT something I can fault TP-LINK for!  They do not mention anywhere that the adapter is compatible with OS X and clearly in their documentation and web site only support Windows.I hope this information is useful to some readers - Windows folks assuring that you do indeed have PCI Express, and Mac users realizing that this card might work for some reviewers, but didn't for me.  I would not normally have submitted this review at all, except that the Amazon Vine program, under which I received the review unit, requires that a review be submitted.  I rated 4 stars so that my review does not affect the average review for the product; I would have rated N/A if that had been possible.

I loved this series 30 years ago and looked forward to sharing it with my wife as we catch up on a variety of India-based dramas.  My memory was of a well-acted period piece with astonishing scenery that I never imagined existed in India, with minor historical insights through interesting and ambiguous personal stories.The reality on watching this in 2013 is that the quality of film and BBC productions today is so high, that Jewel in the Crown pales by comparison in every measure.  We laughed after each episode, saying "Is that all that happened (in 50 minutes)?"  I'm not expecting an action movie but at least meaningful insight into people, etc.  Time literally slows to an intolerable pace.The actors are all quite good, while the script and editing create a jumble of disjointed plot lines and characters who come and go without ever really being developed.  As Great Britain loses her Jewel, no attempt is made to explain Congress, the Muslim / Hindu conflict or much of anything really.I agree with others on the poor transfer quality and lack of closed captioning.  It is so easy in a digital video editor to clean up the color and sound, and obviously A&E didn't put the least bit of effort into it.For its time, Jewel in the Crown was great TV on our old low-def tube sets with few quality made-for-TV options out there.  Today, it is 13 hours of slow moving, random depression and hard to recommend.  I'm donating our copy to the local library.

In principal, Norton Hotspot Privacy should be something that nearly everyone with an IOS device or portable Mac or Windows computer would want.  (Strangely, it does not support Android devices.)  It really isn't a software solution, per se, as the operating systems include the key VPN (Virtual Private Network) technology already - it is really a subscription to a VPN service which allows all of your internet traffic to be encrypted so that nobody else on an open network can 'sniff' your data to obtain passwords, account numbers and other critical data that might not otherwise be sent securely.A one year subscription for up to 5 devices seems reasonably priced... if things worked well.But, I ran into the kind of 'version 1' issues that a company like Symantec shouldn't have, particularly on something that should be a no-brainer revenue generator for them. A little glitch in the setup process on my iPhone is that after entering the license key, there was no confirmation or any buttons for downloading the app.  Clicking the browser 'back' button gave me the download icons and a confirmation of the subscription.  A major glitch is that when I enabled the profile for 'manual' use of the VPN - a connection could not be made to the Symantec servers no matter how many times I tried ("Negotiation with the VPN server failed.").  The normal installation is 'automatic', which means that all traffic, even your Netflix movie, will flow through the VPN at slower speeds than a direct connection... since the connection is encrypted and relayed through remote servers.The 'automatic' connection profile, which automatically enabled the VPN for all internet traffic, initially prevented Mail from retrieving my Google Mail.  That turned out to be a useful security feature from Google.  But, I was not happy as I tracked down the solution.  Google sent me an email - which I could only get on my computer, as the VPN was blocking the iPhone - to tell me that my account was accessed by a hijacker at a particular IP address.  Following the instructions there, I went to the web mail interface and found that the IP address belongs to anchorfree.com - a completely different VPN solution provider who appears to not be associated with Symantec at all.  I trust Symantec, after many years of using their products, and expected to be using only Symantec servers.I'm not sure why the 'automatic' profile connected me to the VPN in any case, since I'm currently testing on a secured Wifi network, and the product advertises itself as only connecting automatically for unsecured networks.Because of the failure of the manual connection profile, I've uninstalled Norton Hotspot Privacy, and haven't even tested on Windows/Mac laptops.  I may reinstall when I'm at an open connection at an airport, etc., but otherwise don't want to be bothered with a flakey service that doesn't even use Symantec servers.PS I should add that it is ridiculous that Symantec packages this product in a large box when all it contains is a card with a license key and download instructions.  This goes for lots of other companies and products, too, such as Intuit's Payroll which is just an activation key.  The waste of energy for shipping and handling an empty box is a bit silly.UPDATE:  Since first writing this review, the responsiveness of the 3rd party servers has been fine, connections being made almost immediately on iPhone, iPad and Macbook Pro.  The 'automatic' setting still does not distinguish a secure or unsecured network and is always on.  The manual setting works fine, but there is no option to start in manual mode to begin with:  setting up Hotspot Privacy on a new IOS device puts it in always-on mode.  To change to manual mode, the app leads you through steps to uninstall one VPN profile and install another ... and guides you to where in the Settings app you would turn the VPN on and off.  This process is still too involved for some of my test users.  One noticed that her iPad was too slow at home after returning from a public campus hotspot ... but didn't know how to turn the VPN off to get full speed again on our home network.  The Macbook Pro setup is a bit strange - as the Network Settings on Mountain Lion doesn't show a VPN as having been installed, even when Hotspot Security is enabled.  Some magic is happening behind the scenes that cannot be monitored.  As with IOS devices, I like enabling the "VPN" icon in the menubar when the VPN is active for reassurance, and this isn't happening on 10.8.3 with the Norton product.UPDATE 2:  Another day, another story.  Was unable to connect to either the US or UK server with a dozen attempts over 30 minutes the other day.  Just not a dependable service.

This TP-LINK TL-WDN3200 USB Wifi adapter is a bit large, physically, but comes with a USB extension cord in the even that either (a) the adapter doesn't fit well into one of your available USB ports, or (b) you need to reposition the adapter to obtain a stronger signal.Installation involves installing the driver/utility from the provided CD and doesn't require a reboot.  Within two minutes, your computer will be connected to your Wifi network.Ideal for any computer lacking but needing Wifi, even if only to eliminate cable clutter, the use of USB makes this adapter suitable with very old as well as current models.  My testing was with an old Windows XP box where I obtained 144 Mbps throughput.The software doesn't behave as advertised for me.  After I manually set up a connection to my hidden SSID router and checked the box to automatically connect, the connection was not restored after rebooting and I had to manually select the (single) connection item and click the Connect button in the software interface.  Not a big deal, but enough for me to take off one star.

This Bemis Mayfair 148E2 toilet seat offers the most solid installation hardware of the dozen or so seats I've put in over the years.  The bolts have an adjustable plastic collar that fits (snaps in my case) very snuggly in the hole in the toilet, eliminating the side to side wiggle of some other seat bolts that rely on double adhesive tape for security.  The 'nuts' are attached finger tight first (I had to lift the seat to most easily press the bolts in and get to the finger tight stage) - and then tightened with a 1/2" wrench.  A cool thing about the nuts is that they cannot be overtorqued.  There is a snap off nut that breaks off when the tension is correct.  The remaining stem still accomodates a 1/2" wrench for future removal.The removal-for-cleaning method is part of why this seat is more stable than some competitive seats.  A comparably priced plastic seat that I installed on another toilet has a snap in mechanism for removing the entire seat for cleaning (not that we do that much). You just pull the seat forward, and two clips unsnap from the hinges, leaving the hinges bolted to the toilet.  But, that seat has a fair amount of side to side wiggle because of those clips and different bolts.  This Mayfair seat actually unsnaps from the bolts, after twisting the locking hinge cover.  To return, snap the hinges back onto the bolt studs left on the toilet, and twist the hinge covers to secure.The quiet closing hinge avoids any slamming of either seat or lid.  You can just start closing and walk away.I've taken a star off because of the poor packaging by Bemis which resulted in a chipped seat on arrival.  I've uploaded photos that show the hardware bag placed loose in the packaging, bouncing around loose between the seat and lid.  One of the metal bolts chipped the edge of the seat.  The bag just needs to be taped down to the cardboard.I'm cautiously optimistic, but concerned by other reviewers for whom the seat broke after some use.  I'm concerned that the seat is 'molded wood' (meaning particles and binder) rather than solid wood like our old seat.

I received review units of the TP-LINK TL-PA511 today.  Do note that Amazon appears to be mixing reviews of various TP-LINK products together, do note that this review is for the TL-PA511.These powerline adapters allow you to run a 'wired' network connection to another location in your home using just your electrical wiring for the data transmission.  This is not a Wifi adapter.  The package comes complete with two short Cat5 cables.  Just plug one cable between your router and one TL-PA511 and plug the unit into a wall outlet.  Connect the other cable between your device and the other TL-PA511 and plug that unit into another outlet in your house.  Good to go without further configuration assuming nobody else on your same electrical meter is using this same technology.My router is in my basement and I've connected a DirecTV receiver in my living room.  The circuit breaker panel is at the opposite end of the house, so the total wiring run is probably about 100 feet.  The outlets are on separate circuits.  Throughput measures about 180 Mbps.Power consumption is stated as 6W per unit, so roughly $10/year for the pair.You can purchase additional units for additional remote devices; only one TL-PA511 is needed at the router.Depending on your needs, if you already have a good Wifi setup at your home or business, a Wireless Access Point might be a satisfactory and cheaper solution.  I'm able to get similar throughput with a WAP.There are some odd things about the software, documentation and device.  The software to configure the adapters for special security situations or to monitor speed only runs on Windows.  This is silly, as the device is operating system independent.  A web-based (operating system independent) configuration utility should be provided, as is the case with most wifi devices. The documentation calls this a Gigabit adapter - but of course the 500 Mbps peak is half a gigabit - and yet calls the Ethernet port a 10/100 Mbps port (rather than 10/100/1000).  The user guide is confusing, some due to bad English - for example, for quality of service settings (QoS) in the Powerline Utility, it says "Choose what type of traffic you will user your local HomePlug AV device for by pitching on one of the four radils."  (They meant to say clicking on one of the radio buttons.)  The user guide and short installation handout are pretty confusing as to how or why you would want to change the default security settings, which you would likely want to do if you are in an apartment/condo/office that does not have its own electric meter.Bottom line:  works effortlessly out of the box, more expensive than a wireless access point, potentially faster than wifi, software will not run on Mac OS X so Mac users should only consider this if you live in a private residence and will not need to reconfigure the units.  The Amazon product page indicates that a newer model is available now.

This Epson V370 scanner and software achieve remarkably good results, particularly for its low price which is achieved in part via fairly cheap feeling plastic construction.  (On the plus side, Epson notes that the plastic case is recyclable.)  Making this unit stand out from the crowd at this low price is that it is capable of scanning unmounted film (negatives or positive 35 mm) and mounted 35 mm slides using another light inside the cover, which is exposed by removing  the top document mount.I have almost no reservations at all recommending this unit for document scanning.  It is fast,  instant-on due to the LED lamp (vs old scanners which use fluorescents requiring warm-up), and gives quality results. For Mac users, do note that the buttons do nothing for you - as Epson has not gotten their Event Manager, which responds to the buttons, to operate on Mountain Lion for this device. So, document scan use requires launching the Epson Scan software to do the scanning. Personally, I get the most compact PDF files that have been also converted to searchable text by scanning with the Adobe Acrobat Pro File > Create > PDF from Scanner... command.  The Epson's TWAIN driver is recognized automatically by Adobe Acrobat Pro.The Epson software is a bit awkward (and with an ugly UI), and there is no user-manual.  As another review pointed out, you have to go to the Epson web site and view the documentation for another scanner to find documentation on using the software.  And even then, the documentation is web-only with no downloadable PDF.  The installation software installs a web link to the user manual for the unit itself - but the URL doesn't work.  You have to go to the Epson support site manually to get the link to display.  Pretty ridiculous to not just provide a PDF manual, much less a working link.  The software's settings panels based on a usage choice of "Auto", "Home", "Office" or "Professional" are pretty awkward - with some settings appearing in only one of each, where you might expect 'Professional' to include ALL settings.  The "Home" group seems oriented towards photos and slides; the "Office" group towards documents.For photo and slide scanning, the results are quite good if you are not a 'prosumer'  - and if you are, you wouldn't be looking at such a low priced scanner anyway, I would imagine.  Comparing the results to my Canon CanoScan 9000F Color Image Scanner which is just one step above the Epson, priced 50% higher and for some reason 50% thicker in size as well, the image quality of the Epson at first seems quite similar.  On close examination, though, all medium to dark areas of the Epson scans are filled with digital color noise - pixels of colors not related to the main color of the area.  In contrast, the Canon has none of this, with pure tones in all areas.  The Epson colors, even with color-restoration applied to old photos, seem much more like the original, which is a good thing, I think - while the CanoScan over-saturates.  Saturation is easy to fix;  getting rid of the color noise generated by the Epson scanner is more difficult and hence I cannot recommend it for people with a discerning eye.Scanning a 35mm slide at 4800 dpi took about 90 seconds.  The same scan on the CanoScan 9000F took 40 seconds.Removing the white document cover in the lid to expose the upper lamp for film/slide scanning is easy.  Replacing it is quite tricky, requiring aligning various bits.  (In contrast, the CanoScan 9000F document cover pops out and back in without much attention.)As another reviewer noted, it is annoying that the power 'cord' for this Epson is a large brick that makes the adjacent sockets of a power strip unusable, or which requires yet another short extension cord to plug it into a UPS battery unit.Dust and Scratch removal is via software, and appears to do nothing in my tests.  (The CanoScan 9000F uses an infrared dust removal process, but unfortunately, it doesn't accomplish much in my tests either.  Others have reported success with 3rd party scanner software with the Canon.)Optical Character Recognition (OCR) is made possible with the included ABBYY FineReader Sprint 8.0 which gave very good results in my test.One reviewer claimed that this scanner was completely silent.  Not true.  Like all flatbed scanners, it makes various whirring/whishing/buzzing noises as the optical reader moves across the bed.  To my ears, it is about the same as the CanoScan, but definitely quieter than the scanners built-into our four Brother and HP MFC units.Bottom line:  great value for office document scanning or home hobby photo/slide/negative scanning.  Woefully inadequate documentation; awkward software; scan buttons which do not function for Mac Mountain Lion users; power 'brick' awkward for plugging into power strip.

I received a sample unit of the WD10EZEX 1 TB 7200 RPM drive with 64 MB cache for review.  Formatting and testing it in an external firewire 800 dock on a Mac, it felt as warm (not hot) as a WD 'Green' drive, but was definitely a bit noisier:  there is an audible ticking sound during drive access that I don't hear with the Green line of drives.It seems a good value proposition for internal storage or an external backup drive, although I'm not sure I would have purchased it had I not been offered a test unit.  The Amazon price for either a 2 TB WD Green drive, twice the storage, or a 1 TB WD Black drive - higher performance and 5 year warranty - is not substantially greater than the cost of this drive.  Personally, I prefer WD Black for internal and the larger capacity WD Green for backups or media.  But, if you're on a tight budget, this drive is worth considering.The drive requires a special formatting utility download if you're running XP.  For OS X or newer versions of Windows, the 'advanced format drive' can be formatted properly by the OS.  For Windows users, WD offers a free download of a special version of Acronis True Image to allow upgraders to clone their internal drive onto this new drive to make it your new boot drive.  (Mac users can clone with Disk Utility or various well-known 3rd party programs.)

My review below is mostly unchanged since the last release of Norton 360.  The product I was provided with for review this time, the 2013 Premier edition, differs from the standard edition of Norton 360 by including 25 GB of online (cloud) storage vs only 2 GB in the standard edition.  Considering that Symantec charges almost $60 just to add 25 GB to your Norton account, the minor price increase for 360 Premium makes it an economical choice for those people using the Norton online backup technology.Note that Norton's online storage is accessible only by its backup (and restore) component of 360.  You cannot drag and drop files there, as you can with other cloud storage services.  To email people links to files in your storage, you must use a web interface - but you cannot upload files there.Tip to all Norton users:  the LiveUpdate process does NOT download free product updates to which you are entitled.  From time to time, click on the Support menu and then "Check for New Version".  Even if you are running, say, version 2012, when version 2013 comes out during your 12 month license term, you are able to download and install it free of charge.The review:You probably know somebody that everybody in the family calls to fix their computers when they slow down or have problems.  Yeah, I'm that guy.  Now that I've (finally) discovered Norton 360, I'll be spending less time with the relatives once they buy copies.I've used Norton Internet Security for years and have recommended it often, particularly in recent years when Symantec made it run faster and leaner.  I never went for Norton 360 before receiving a review copy because frankly I couldn't really understand what it was from a quick glance.Norton 360 does everything Norton Internet Security (NIS) does, and more, but with a different interface.It includes firewall and antivirus protection as well as Identify Safe, identical to NIS.  (Your NIS settings and Identity Safe vault all migrate if you switch to 360 from NIS.)  Identify Safe is primarily a password manager, saving and entering your passwords for you under the protection of a single master password so that you are more likely to use appropriate, complex and site specific passwords for the web sites that you visit.360 includes features in two areas beyond NIS:  Backup and PC Tuneup.The PC Tuneup portion automatically cleans up things including:1. Removal of Windows temporary files (no more searching %temp%, %tmp% and all of the other places that these things hide)2. Removal of Internet Explorer temporary files3. Startup Manager - controlling the many hidden programs that launch when you start your computer.  Way easier than running MSConfig, the Norton 360 Startup Manager lets you mark non-essential startup items as "delayed" - so that your computer starts up in a jiffy, and then these things are launched somewhat later (reported to be 5 minutes) by 360 itself.  For example, there is a Microsoft Office and Adobe Reader item in most people's startup group.  These allow Office applications and Reader to launch faster when you need them, but at the cost of slowing down the time before you get control of your mouse when you start your computer.  With 360, you get your desktop sooner - and these things can still get launched, just a little bit later.  (Or you can disable them - which has no affect on the functionality of Office or Reader - just makes them launch slower.) Etc.4.  Registry Cleanup - the Windows Registry is a single, huge database that all software on your computer stores settings in.  The bigger and more cluttered it gets, the slower the computer runs.  360 can find entries for software that has been uninstalled and did not clean up after itself and tidy things up.5.  Internet Explorer history cleanup - nothing special, other than it can be scheduled to run at times you choose6.  Disk Optimization - defragmentation is essential to fast disk performance on Windows machines.  The defragger that comes with Windows itself is fine, but must be run manually.  The Norton 360 one can be scheduled to run automatically, eliminating the issue on most computers of the user either not knowing how to defrag, or continuously forgetting to do it.All of these tune-up activities can be set on a schedule to keep things running smoothly.Finally, 360 adds a Backup service that can backup via the internet to the "cloud", or to local media. This is useful and adds to the completeness of the product, but the user interface is so poor, that I take one star away in this review.Symantec gives you 25 GB of online storage with your Norton 360 Premier registration.  You can purchase more, but at a hefty charge relative to competitors.  You can access this storage through a Norton product or the n360.backup.com web site;  you would have to upgrade your license annually to maintain this 'cloud' backup.  But, the backup service can run automatically, incrementally uploads only files that have changed, and knows where they came from if you need to restore a file right back to its original location.  This is an excellent option for off-site backup of really important files that would make your life miserable if the disappeared in a  fire or explosion.  But, of course, it is slow to transfer large files.Note:  your files backed up to online storage are only as secure as your Norton account login password - hackers could try to access your files via the web interface which is accessed purely with your Norton account login credentials.  And, the web interface can be outrageously slow.  On the plus side, the web interface to your online storage has a search function so that you can quickly find the file you're looking for.  On the downside, the web interface is supposed to include a "Purge" command to allow you to delete files to free up space.  This command does not appear for me, however.You can also backup to thumb drive, optical media, a hard disk, or a network location (mapped to a drive letter).The negative about the backup system is that  you do not have a normal Explorer-like browser tree to select or exclude the files to be backed up.  Instead you have a horrendously ugly long scrolling list of full path names to files - no enclosing folder, nothing, to make it easy to browse and find files that you want to exclude/include.  There is not one person who I help with their computer troubles who would have a slight clue as to what these long file path names mean relative to their data.  I just don't know what Symantec was thinking of, putting this in a program otherwise designed for everyday Windows users rather than tech geeks.  It is not just this list, but the whole backup process which would confuse my less techie friends and relatives - they need a wizard to lead them through the process.One last thing I like about 360  is that in the Activities and Scans window, there is a checkbox to shut down the computer when activities are complete.  So, there's no excuse not to save energy when you leave the computer for the night - let 360 download updates, do backups and Tune-up activities, and then allow it to shut your computer down when it is finished.

This rhyming book is geared towards being read to very young children who will be interested in the illustrations and the cadence of the rhyme.  It feels over-priced at the retail price for the hardcover edition.  I found the illustrations, such as the buck-toothed boy watching the police horses, to be very 1950's in both style and coloring; this may be appealing to some and not to others.Anyone who ever had a working horse or team wearing harness will have a problem with the illustrations of working horses, most of which show incorrect harness and/or connections to the cart or sled.  Most of the other tack is close enough for a children's book.  The black horse on the police horse page (there are no page numbers) has its legs in non-horse places - both the left hind and the left fore are extended and off the ground.  After seeing that, I noticed a few other odd leg positions.The final page of the book, "Popular horse breeds", felt a little strange as it mixes true breeds with Palomino, a color; the illustrations did not clearly distinguish each breed, so perhaps the page is there just to introduce the words to the young horse lover.If horses are not a strong part of your or your child's daily reality, you may be quite happy with this book and not notice any of the hangups I have with the illustrations. Don't let me dissuade you.

I'm an expert Mac user and help a lot of folks from beginner on up, so I was hopeful upon receiving my review copy of this book that I'd find it useful.  But, in my opinion, it doesn't satisfy the needs of any audience particularly well.  The Introduction states that the "book is designed to address" all users:  "new to the Mac", "new to computers", "Mac users who know the basics of OS X", and "experienced Mac users looking to see what's new and different in the latest version of OS X".I think it is impossible to address the needs of all such audiences without an organization and layout that allows each audience to easily find and read the bits that pertain to them and their needs.  For example, the information specific to Mountain Lion could be called out with a margin graphic.  The little information appropriate for experts could be in sidebars.  Etc.Even if only one audience was picked for a revision of this book, the chapter organization just doesn't make sense to me.  For example, Chapter 14 on "Using AppleScript and Automator" beginning on page 249 of the 828 page book, and even the prior chapter about extending OS X with third party utilities, comes before the author even talks about using Mail, Contacts, Calendars, and so forth - a flow that would be bewildering to the targeted audience of "new to computers".

We're quite happy with this Logitech keyboard so far,  my wife preferring a physical keyboard to the IOS virtual keyboard for touch typing.  (I can touch-type fine on the iPad virtual keyboard - but have to admit, I can type much faster with this Logitech Tablet Keyboard.  No question about typing faster when the keyboard is paired to an iPhone.)I bought this on an impulse when it was a "Lightening Deal" - but would have paid the normal Amazon price,  having seen the quality and ease of bluetooth pairing.  Important to both of us was that the keyboard have the same key spacing as a normal keyboard.  (Some cases with built-in keyboards have tighter spacing which can be awkward.)Related, but off topic:  We recently received a Case Logic MLM-111 11-Inch Laptop and iPad Messenger Case (Ink)  - see my review there - and this keyboard fits perfectly in the padded slot intended for an 11" Macbook Air - with the iPad (in case or smart-cover) fitting fine in the adjacent, padded iPad compartment.  A good combo.Update:  since the recent IOS update to AppleTV that lets you connect bluetooth keyboards, we've appreciated this keyboard in the living room with AppleTV also, as it makes searching for content so much easier than even the Apple Remote app for the iPad.

Designed for an iPad and optionally an 11" Macbook Air  and accessories, this bag is perfect for those uses and my wife is quite happy with it.The interior is divided into three compartments, two of them well-padded.  An iPad, even in a case, fits perfectly in one.  My wife prefers a real keyboard for typing vs the virtual IOS keyboard, and the Logitech Tablet Keyboard for iPad 1G, 2G, 3G, 4G and iPad Mini (920-004440) slides easily into the compartment intended for the 11" laptop.  There's still room for my iPad when we go somewhere together.Additional compartments easily hold the iPad cord and charge block and earbuds or lay-flat headphones.  For air travelers, note that the Bose case for their QuietComfort headphones will not fit, but the headphones themselves (with lay-flat earpieces) fit fine and the flap still closes.The outer flap has a zippered compartment (padded) for a phone (or whatever).  An iPhone 4 in a (bulky) Otterbox case fits fine.  The body-side of the bag has an open pocket for mail, paperwork, etc.Attractively made from durable material and with a comfortable strap, my only disappointment is that the carrying handle is stitched in a way that is asymmetrical to the weight of the bag and the bag hangs awkwardly when that handle is used.  The magnetic closure is easy and fast and I don't have any concerns about the iPad falling out as it doesn't weigh enough to cause the flap to open even if the bag is held upside down.An excellent value (compare the price to the price for just an iPad case or cover, or an iPhone case), this bag is a good choice if its capacity meets your needs.

Living Streets is a fantastic resource for anyone interested in or involved in the shape and function of our street-scapes, applicable to both urban and suburban (but not rural) areas.  It is up-to-date, covering current activities in a variety of cities, and providing web links to the resources related to those projects - providing quick access to the most recent information about them.The authors discuss the transformation of public rights-of-way that can build community, improve natural aesthetics, and provide improved and/or more relevant transportation flow.  The many examples and topics are written at a comprehensive but very readable level that is a little repetitive between chapters; that repetition, however,  allows chapters be read out of order and emphasizes the values to be considered.  There is guidance both to the design professional, as well as to the citizen activist.Like others, I was disappointed with the grayscale photos for a book of this price - and with such a beautiful color cover.  You can click on Amazon's "Look Inside" link at the top of the product page to see how this is laid out and if it bothers you.  Personally, I found that by the time I was halfway through the book, I was focused more on pattern and design and didn't mind the lack of color.  Yet, the book would have much more value with color images (or links to them) so that it could be more useful in persuading all of the stakeholders in a project to consider some of the ideas presented.The thing about the imagery that I found frustrating, was that the 'before' and 'after' shots were almost never from the same viewpoint.  Often times, 'before' had the camera aimed East (e.g.) and the 'after' was West.  Or 'before' showed an entire street, and 'after' was a close-up of tables on a sidewalk, with no idea of what happened to the overall road.  It seems that the authors relied on public photos rather than grabbing a camera and going out and taking matching 'after' images themselves.  The only accurate before/after shots were architectural renderings.I'm in the "choir" that this book is preaching to, which is perhaps why I enjoyed it so much and felt so encouraged by the projects described.  However, I live in snow county and I am disappointed that the authors do not recognize the huge issues that snow present to planning transportation corridors.  The only mention of snow is in a passing reference to alley maintenance.  Yet, snow removal is a real issue that can seriously complicate projects.  For example, the authors show projects that replace four lanes with three, two traffic lanes and a center turn lane (with associated pedestrian facilities, etc).  Yet, in areas of reasonable snowfall, plows must create a berm in the center of the roads, to be removed later.  The central turn lane, which otherwise offers so many advantages, fails here since the berm cannot go along either side (cars from that side could not enter the turn lane to turn), and cannot go in the middle (no cars could use the turn lane).  Snow removal in the created park areas, bike lanes, pedestrian areas, etc. is a serious issue.  I hope that it'll be discussed in the next edition.

There was consistent Ravensberger quality to the pieces of this puzzle, with no dust, clean edges and only one slightly damaged piece of the 1,000.We completed the puzzle in one evening plus a bit the next morning over Thanksgiving week.  The semi-glossy finish to the picture side made seeing the details of the pieces difficult for me both in artificial lighting and daylight; but the others working on the puzzle didn't have any problems.  We all agreed that the final puzzle looked much better than the photo on the box.  Speaking of the photo:  we're not the hard-core types that do puzzles often and without looking at the box image.  The iPhone covering up the lower left corner of the image, and the banner covering up part of the lower right corner definitely made this more challenging than the last Ravensberger puzzle we did which had a full image on the box.On completion, we downloaded the iPhone app - which is a bit large as it includes images for several other puzzles as well.  The app is totally lame.  Holding your phone about 30" away from the puzzle (which you've already identified from a list in the app), you hear birds chirping, suggesting spring or summertime.  Tapping over and over, more and more snow falls on the scene and frost forms around the image... but the birds keep chirping.  Stop tapping, or hold your finger down, and the snow goes away.  Yup, that's about it.  Maybe Germans are more easily amused than Americans.Ignoring the iPhone gimmick, this is an enjoyable puzzle with many difficult areas.

Quickbooks for Mac has come a long way since my last  and not-so-positive review of the 2010 version.It's now stable, attractive and quite capable for many businesses.  If you have never used Quickbooks before,  give the Mac version a try for your business.  If your company deals with a single currency, is service-oriented, or if product-oriented has simple inventory needs, Quickbooks for Mac 2013 could fit your needs well.My wife and I still use Quickbooks for Windows on our Macs for about a dozen companies by running the Windows version under Parallels Desktop 8 for Mac.  But, for several of these companies, Quickbooks for Mac is now a viable option.  It still lacks the full feature sets of QuickBooks Pro 2013 [Download], much less QuickBooks Accountant 2013 [Download], which is why most of the companies we work with will stay on the Windows version for now in spite of the additional complexity of running Parallels Desktop on our Macs.Quickbooks for Mac 2013 permits batch invoicing (perfect for homeowner's associations and businesses that bill a group of clients a similar amount), payments via Intuit Payment Network (no monthly fee e-checks and credit card payments), and the ability to attach documents to transactions.  It supports up to 5 users on the same local network working in one company file at the same time (per-user licenses required), with user-permissions that limit what each person can see and do.  Since 2012, it has supported progress or phased invoices, useful for contractors and architects, for example.QBMac still uses the floating window paradigm, one which Apple, Adobe and others are moving away from for Mac applications  (e.g., Aperture, Final Cut, iMovie, iPhoto, Photoshop, Dreamweaver), but it remembers the last location and size of each window, so you can create a working layout of activity windows that suits your needs - you'll just see whatever other application windows are behind these as with all old-style Mac apps.The new Guide Me window automatically changes its content to reflect help and guidance for whatever you are doing, however many of the videos simply display "Work in Progress" when you click on them.  Some of those that do work have muddy sound and are compressed so much that you cannot read the screen text.A personal thing due to my age:  Most program text in QBMac is quite small on my 27" Apple LED Cinema display which, as with most Apple laptops, has a higher pixels-per-inch PPI than older monitors.  I'd like to see Intuit give us the option of changing the type size, the size of which strains my aging eyes, even with special computer glasses.  It is the tiniest text of any program I work with.  (Palette text in some other programs is the same size - but not functional dialogs/windows.  My workaround is to drag QBMac onto an old secondary monitor that is 72 ppi.)  An exception to this is the left-column list of customer:jobs, vendors, etc in the Invoice, Enter Bills etc windows - this is extremely readable for me.  Registers, not so much.  I don't need any of Apple's 'Universal Access' features for anything else on my Mac, so adding 'zoom' or changing from non-native screen resolution just for QBMac is not something I'm willing to consider.For the few companies I have that would work with the feature set of Quickbooks for Mac, there are still small things that will keep me on the Windows version... but only because it's already running on my Mac.  If I wasn't already set up with Quickbooks for Windows, I might force myself to live with these issues in Quickbooks for Mac:1.  Consultants, attorneys, accountants, architects, graphics artists, etc. often like to record their time while the work is actually being done.  The QBWin Enter Single Activity window has a timer built-in.  It's so easy to start the timer and add additional notes as you work on a task.  If the phone rings, or you have to work on another task for a while, just stop that activity, to be returned to later, and start a new one for the phone call.  Etc.  When you return to an earlier activity, just start the timer again to continue on, adding additional notes and obtaining a total time entry for that one task which can later be transferred, with the notes (optional), as a single line to an invoice.  With QBMac, there is no built-in timer.  Instead, you must download the separate My Time application via the Customers > Time Tracking > Download My Time menu, and remember to refresh its lists every time you add or edit a customer:job or billable item (no dynamic linking to your company data).  My Time saves a separate time entry each time you pause it.  These entries can be merged when you export back into QBMac, but not with the same per-activity result as QBWin if you continue to add additional notes for what is intended as a single billable entry.  In general, I find having to launch a separate app (My Time) that requires management and export to keep the company file up to date an unnecessary additional level of complexity over time tracking within QBWin.  QBMac just needs to add a timer button to their Single Activity window, as has been requested for many years.2.  QBMac now allows very long Notes fields for time and invoice entries, and thus is able to import that data from a QBWin file without data loss.  (QBMac 2010, e.g., truncated all imported notes and did not allow data entry of long notes.)  However, none of those fields expands to show the data or displays a scroll bar.  For example, in an invoice, only a single line is displayed - making it nearly impossible to edit a multi-line note.  You can only see the multiple lines if you switch to preview mode - but you cannot edit there.  (This contrasts with the Windows version which wraps the notes in the invoice, giving a live, editable preview.)3.  QBMac doesn't work with Intuit's convenient GoPayment system unless you sign up for a merchant services account at a monthly fee.  For QBWin users, GoPayment is free of fees other than transaction fees.4.  QBMac still only works with Intuit's online payroll, which starts at $25/month.  This $300 per year compares to the street price of about $50/year for the basic 3-employee payroll for QBWin.  One company we have has a single part-time employee with under $4,000/year in wages.  The $300/year Intuit fee is just unreasonable for us.5.  Column width cannot be changed in forms (Bills, Invoices, General Journal, etc) - and thus complete data cannot be read.  For example, if you have nested subaccounts, you'll have no idea what the actual account is by viewing one of these forms unless you click on the account control. Ditto customer:job if the customer name is long.  Dynamic column resizing (and remembering user preferences) is essential (and works in the Windows version).Conversion of QBWin files to QBMac format improves each year, for those who are either migrating, or need to send their file back and forth to a bookkeeper or accountant on the other platform.  As always, it is important to know what things do convert and which things do not.  QBMac does not have a means of importing accountant changes or journal entries, and so if a file is sent to an accountant, the QBMac user must not do anything in their copy of the file until they receive the file back from the accountant/bookkeeper.  (This differs from the abilities of QBWin.)Bottom line:  Quickbooks for Mac 2013 is a solid release that can address the bookkeeping needs of many types of small businesses.  Intuit offers a free trial, and I encourage you to download it to see if your business needs are met by the product.  For myself, as a Quickbooks for Windows user who wants to switch, Intuit needs to resolve the issues in this review before I would migrate.  Naturally, I also look forward to the day that the Mac product achieves feature-parity with the Windows product so that we can completely leave Windows behind.

0:17 MinsI'm incredibly impressed with the accuracy and speed of Dragon Dictate 3, after testing on a 2009 Macbook Pro with dual cores  and 8 GB RAM and a 2008 Mac Pro with 8 cores and 12 GB RAM, both running 10.7.5 Lion.  As far as I could tell, at most one core is used by Dragon Dictate, though.The attached video shows the speed of recognition after voice training by reading the phrases in just the first and simplest voice training scheme.  I read some paragraphs from an advanced equine anatomy text and everything was typed perfectly.  I was truly amazed, not just in comparison with Apple and Google internet-based recognition (which do not involve training) - but in comparison to the last time I evaluated speech recognition using a trained product, several years ago.The pluses for me include:1.  A profile is created for each user-microphone combination.  This profile can then be voice-trained by reading scripts to improve accuracy.  Five script scenarios are included, and all five can be done if one wants to really tune things.  I found amazing results after doing just one script.2.  Individual words can be added and trained, so that names and technical terms will be recognized accurately.  This is easily done via the Vocabulary Editor.3.  I can speak really quickly and the result is still accurate4.  Dictation can be into pretty much any application.5.  Voice commands can be used to control apps, but I have little personal interest in that.  It would be extremely helpful for someone with limited eyesight, coordination, or other physical limitations.6.  A variety of microphones, including smartphones, can be used for dictation.  Sound files from phones and voice recorders can be transcribed.  A corded USB microphone is included in the box.7. Efficient voice selection and correction of textThe negatives for me include:a.  Transcription of a sound file (from a voice recording) can only proceed if a profile (trained voice/microphone pair) is loaded.  Dictate will ONLY load a profile if the corresponding microphone is connected.  Tech support says this is as-designed.  But, it is incredibly stupid when the microphone is neither needed nor used during a transcription process.  The effect is that if you have a sound file containing someone else's voice, and they've trained a profile with a microphone that you do not have, you cannot transcribe the file.b.  Special vocabulary is saved per-profile, so you have to re-enter all special words (and then re-train) for each microphone that you might use.c.  The user interface seems really illogical.  I've attached an image to the product at the top of the page showing that there is a red 'Stop' octagon when the microphone is off.  Clicking it does not stop dictation ... it STARTS it.... turning the symbol to a green circle.  The green then means 'go' ... speak and Dragon Dictate will transcribe or respond to commands.  Clicking the green circle restores the red stop sign.  This seems backwards to me, but that's just me:  I would think that clicking the stop icon would STOP recording and clicking the green circle would START it.  If thinking of status lights, most recorders have a red light when they are recording / broadcasting and no light when inactive.  I can't get my head around what Nuance was thinking here.d.  A variety of actions in the tutorial would not function, particularly spelling mode.e.  It is challenging to type words that are also Dragon commands.  For example, whether I pause before and after "new line" or say it all together within a sentence, the words are never types ... instead a line break is always created.  I can fake it by pausing on either side of "new" and then either side of "line", but the instructions say that this is unnecessary.  Dracton Dictate has so many built-in commands, that you never know which ones will be obeyed versus typed, so you need to watch your output as you speak until getting used to it.  Personally, I'd like the ability to create a profile in which I disable all commands I never intend to use.Bottom line:Useful?  Depends on your typing skills vs verbal skills.  I can type extremely quickly and (usually) accurately and compose best while typing.  Others I know, while reasonable typists, think better when voicing their thoughts aloud, and one friend is particularly interested in Dragon Dictate to get some rough drafts onto paper because of her vocal process.  For those who are slow or poor typists, or who have some physical limitation, I think Dragon Dictate is an excellent value.  For those on Mountain Lion, which includes free internet-based dictation from Apple, the choice will be more personal.  The Apple dictation requires a live internet connection and is not voice-trained, and hence is less accurate; it also does not support voice correction or voice command.  There are audiences for the free Mountain Lion feature as well as for the more powerful Dragon product - I'd suggest first trying the free Mountain Lion feature and if it satisfies your needs, great; if not, take a look at Dragon Dictate 3.UPDATE 11/30/12:  I would take a star off this review based on the absolutely horrible Nuance customer support.  I've never encountered a more useless system - slow web response,  keeps invalidating my support account, preventing access followed by inability to re-activate the account with the logged cases...and staff which give stock responses that do not address the question asked.  Terrible customer experience leaving me feeling pretty negative about Nuance as a company.Latest tech support response (unbelievable to me):  Asking them why the built-in microphone on Apple's LED Cinema Displays is not recognized by Dragon Dictate, this is the response:  "Dragon Dictate requires a mic that has a type that is USB. Go to System Preferences > sound > input. What is the "Apple LED Cinema Display" connection "type?". If it is not USB, What type is it?"  In other words:  they did not even test Apple's hardware for a Mac product.

This is my third Logitech Harmony remote, the most expensive, and my least favorite.  If I had purchased this, it would be on its way back to Amazon for a refund.  The functionality is that bad, for my usage.The significantly less expensive  Logitech Harmony One Advanced Universal Remote is a far more useful remote for me than the Touch, because it puts my most used buttons under my fingers where I can operate things by feel - particularly the play, pause, skip ahead (skip commercials), skip back, fast forward and rewind buttons.With the Touch, SOME of those buttons are at the very top, not within finger reach when the remote is held with the otherwise very comfortable curved back in one's palm.But, get real:  if you watch TV on a DVR  - you are using the 'skip ahead' button all the time to skip commercials, right?  On the Touch, that function is in a scrolling list on the touch screen.  Not only do you have to touch the screen once to wake it up  (no motion sensor wake-up like other Harmony remotes) - but you then have to actually look at the screen to be careful you touch exactly the desired command... if you're lucky enough to have the screen with that command displayed and don't have to go through menus to get it to show up.I could write pages about how poorly designed this Harmony Touch is, but I doubt if anyone wants to read it, so:Bottom line:Good:  if you have an existing Harmony remote, the MyHarmony web site transfers all of the functions from that remote to the Touch.  The remote feels nice in the hand, and they've moved the USB port from the IR transmitting end, to the opposite end, which might give better IR spread.Bad: basic functions are not within finger reach when held as designed.  Many basic functions have no physical button, requiring scrolling and careful touching of the right command on the touch.  Any screen command required at least two taps, as the first tap merely wakes the screen up.

This Seagate Backup Plus 3TB USB 3.0 drive is an excellent value for the price - which at the moment is not significantly different than that of a raw 3 TB drive.  Pre-formatted for OS X, it works perfectly with Time Machine out of the box.  Additional Seagate software is included to allow use with a Windows computer, or for non-Time Machine backups.Seagate offers additional interface options for this drive - which appears to be identical to their GoFlex line.  For example, a Firewire 800 and Thunderbolt adapter are advertised as available, although nothing in the box points you to proper part numbers for ordering them.  Assuming that the Firewire 800 adapter is the same one Seagate has used for the last couple of years, I would recommend against that as there are many reported problems with it.  USB 3.0 with any new Mac supporting USB 3.0 is faster than Firewire 800.  If you have an older Mac, this drive, like any USB 3.0 device, will operate in the slower USB 2.0 mode.

This belt was sent to me as a free sample in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.It looks nice straight out of the package, although there was a smell to it that wasn't pleasant and certainly didn't smell like leather.  It was a nice width and my husband liked that part.  He is not a fan of this type of buckle but that didn't figure into the rating at all.  My husband is a 36, so, since there was nothing on the product page indicating it ran small, I ordered him a 36.  No way this would fit him.  I believe it is PU Leather (which is synthetic made to look like leather), but the smell and the sizing issue means this is unusable.  I wish they would have indicated that their sizes run small, but it is at least 3-4 inches smaller than the size measurement.

2:12 Mins I like to think of myself as a good cook, and I love to eat good food.  One of the things I've learned over the years is that seasoning can take the worst cut of meat and make it seem gourmet.  I've recently discovered different kinds of rock salt that tastes amazing on food, and I love this particular grinder set because it is easy to fill and easy to hold.  It holds a lot more of what you are wanting to grind also, so you don't have to fill it as often.  It also looks good on the dining table or on the counter (I keep mine on the back of the stove).  I am very happy with this product.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

There are so many things I like about this device that I was sent in order to provide a review. First of all, everything you need is in the box. They even provide the two AAA batteries you need, so it truly is ready to go out of the box. I have a few other digital thermometers, and I used them all to test the same pork roast to test the temperature accuracy, and this was was right with the others. It has a program with set temperatures for all kinds of meats and has a screen that is really easy to read and the backlight changes color to let you know how close your food is to being the temperature that you set.  It also lets you know the temp you set it to, and the actual temperature so you can track things yourself. The wire that goes to the probe is really long too, so while I use this in my oven, but plan to test it on my BarBQ when this cold winter is over. Great product!I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I've never worn or owned a reflective vest before, and while it isn't something that my husband or I would use often, just knowing we have it makes me feel better. We sometimes take strolls through our neighborhood at night, or ride our bike in the evening, not always making it home before the sun sets. Wearing this makes me feel safer since I have a friend who was horribly injured riding a bike home from work late at night (was hospitalized 3 months and another 6 before he could go back to work.) I wish he had worn one of these. I am a large woman, and the size it was set when received fit me perfectly. This would easily expand to fit someone far larger than I, and the straps are adjustable enough to adjust smaller for just about anyone. This is a great vest and one I think anyone who spends any time outside at all should wear, especially if they are going to be outside at night.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I have tried one other car phone mount that latches onto the vent, and it didn't work at all well in our 2005 Trailblazer, but since Choicelife was so kind to send this unit (at no cost) for an honest review, I figured I should try it, and it fit well. Even with the phone in the holder, it was secure and stable, so that is a big plus for me. I am not a big fan of phone mounts in cars in the first place, primarily because the only ones that seem to have worked well in the past are either on the dash or attached to the window by suction cup. Both of those, by design, obscure the view through the front windshield to some degree. One of the reasons I like this mount is because having it attached to the vent leaves my line of vision to the road more clear and makes my driving safer. I'm still not a fan of phone mounts, but of those I've tried, this is one of the best!Again, I wanted to state that I received this free for review, and only express my honest and heartfelt opinions about those products I review.

In general, I am not a fan of phone mounts that adhere to the windshield or dashboard because I am a safety girl, and love having my line of sight extremely clear. With that said, I need to state that this particular one is better than most because of its design. With such a long 'arm', I can mount it so that my phone isn't up as high nor competing with my attention with the road. It adheres easily to the windshield or dash.  Just be sure to clean whichever with alcohol before trying to get it to stick. Overall, for this kind of mount, it is good, but still, it isn't my favorite kind.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

We have a 2005 Chevy Trailblazer that is out of warranty, and unfortunately in the 2+ years we've owned it, we've seen that check engine light come on more than any one should.  But with this little gizmo, my husband and I can get the code to figure out what is going on with her (her nickname is VooDoo).  In the short time we've had this OBD2 device, we've discovered that one of our cylinders wasn't firing as it should, and a friend of my husband was able to fix it easily without the costly trip to the mechanic shop to diagnose it and then repair it.  It became much more simple and with a newer used vehicle like this, things happen.  This is saving us money and is easy to use.  We love it.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for a review.  It has helped us save money which is always tight, and the app you use is easy to download, set up and get into operation.

2:12 Mins I like to think of myself as a good cook, and I love to eat good food.  One of the things I've learned over the years is that seasoning can take the worst cut of meat and make it seem gourmet.  I've recently discovered different kinds of rock salt that tastes amazing on food, and I love this particular grinder set because it is easy to fill and easy to hold.  It holds a lot more of what you are wanting to grind also, so you don't have to fill it as often.  It also looks good on the dining table or on the counter (I keep mine on the back of the stove).  I am very happy with this product.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I haven't always lived the healthiest life, and one of the things I've learned is that my hair is the greatest reflection of my overall health.  At 52 I probably keep my hair longer than I should, but I prefer it shoulder length, but because my health hasn't been the greatest, most of my hair is pretty dry and fly away.  I try to use good products on it, but even after using natural conditioners and masques, I still have some dryness that just doesn't always look good (or professional).  I have been using this Macadamia Hair Oil Treatment, and while I know that nothing can 'heal' damaged hair, some products can help it look better, at least for a day or two, and this is one such product.  I don't use it exactly as intended, but as a smoother.  What I mean is that after I dry my hair, I rub a dime size portion of this oil between my palms and smooth it over the worst parts of my hair.  I've been getting compliments from co-workers (It must have gotten bad if they notice an improvement).  The reason for 4 stars rather than 5?  The smell.  It isn't unpleasant, it is just really strong.  I will keep using it because I love compliments, but I wish the smell were a bit more subtle.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

2:09 Mins I love a good mock-tail or faketini.  I don't drink but I used to, and I always enjoyed the experience of having a nice cocktail.  The experience was more important to me than the alcohol was, but I learned to make a great cocktail.  How I wish I had this shaker set then.  It has everything.  I still have friends who enjoy the real thing from time to time, and I still keep a few small bottles around for when they visit, and now I get to impress them with my skills.  I always say, no matter the endeavor, that having good tools is half the battle for a successful outcome, and this is a very nice shaker set.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

2:27 Mins This is a sturdy small messenger bag that also makes a great handbag.  It is marketed as unisex, but the size of it makes it seem more practical as an alternative to a purse.  My husband finds this much to small for his purposes, but it perfect for how I would use it.  It is large enough to hold my Nexus 7 (2013) in a thick case, and could probably hold my Surface 2, but I've not tried that yet.  With the protective sleeve I use for that computer, it ends up being about 12-13 inches, which is too big for this bag.  But this easily holds my other tablet, my phone, wallet and a few other necessities for work or just a day out shopping.  The shoulder strap is expandable and this easily converts to a cross-body bag which is how I generally wear bags anyway.  It is very well made and the workmanship on this is top notch.  There aren't a whole lot of bells and whistles on this, but sometimes simplicity and quality are enough.  For me they are at least.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I love to cook, and for this past weekend I splurged and bought Rib-Eye steaks. Now, if you've done any grocery shopping lately, you know that the price of beef is astronomical, and as such I didn't want to risk over or under cooking these expensive cuts of meat. This cooking thermometer is extremely easy to use, and when I thought the steak was done, I used this to test the internal temperature of the meat, and it was slightly under-cooked (I got thick cuts of Rib Eye), so I knew to keep it on the coals for another minute or two. By the time I let it rest for a couple minutes, it was perfectly medium-rare. This digital thermometer really helped me make a great meal for my husband and myself and I can't wait to use it with my Thanksgiving turkey next week.I received a discounted sample of this digital thermometer in exchange for an honest and unbiased review!

I just recently got my first Action camera (a clone of the GoPro camera), and am still figuring it all out, and this kit gives me a lot of different shooting options.  I primarily use the head mount, but it also has a selfie stick, a chest mount, a dash mount as well as a floater and other accessories all bundled in a nice case.  With this kit, I cannot imagine an eventuality where I wouldn't have the accessory that I would need.  I am really enjoying learning about using my camera, and this accessory kit is making it more enjoyable.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I have several multi-port chargers that do a decent job at charging my electronics, but my Nexus 7 Tablet is notoriously slow in charging. It is older and I fear my habit of letting it run out of charge or get very low has caused the battery to be resistant. But any charger can normally take 3-4 hours with it off for it to get a full charge (most chargers take even longer). I like the multi-chargers because I can multi-task. It takes up an outlet to charge only two devices so I was prejudiced against it right off the bat because outlets are prime real estate in our house. I am not going to be so quick to judge next time because from now on when I need something to charge at top speed, I am going to reach for this. From a low charge <20, it took 1 hour and 30 minutes to get to 97%. I've never seen that with this tablet, so I am really happy.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.

I work at a local community college, and while I am frequently running in between my office (a generous term for a very small cubicle), I don't always remember to bring change for the vending machines.  A couple years ago, my husband installed a mini fridge for me, but it finally died this year so I've either been drinking water from the fountains, or coffee, but haven't really had a way to keep soda cold (and buying it from the machines at 1.50 each just isn't cost effective.  So when I received this I was happy because I don't really use the fridge for anything but soda.  This works great for that, and if I've only got a couple cans in it (which is normal), I have room for a sandwich.  I haven't used the car charging function, nor have I used the heater function, but for what I need this is ideal.  It doesn't take up near the space the mini fridge did, and can fit in the corner of my desk (I also get a lot of attention from co-workers for the retro look of it). I'm happy with it, and if that should ever change, I will update my review.I received a complimentary sample of this mini fridge in exchange for an honest review.

I received this key-chain several weeks ago as a gift, and while I liked it, it was a bit too flashy for me.  Until today.  I knew I had this and searched through my jewelry chest to find it and am wearing it proudly.  It is really pretty, and has 2 Eiffel towers on it: a large bejeweled one and a smaller gold one. This is well made, and the larger bejeweled tower is quite large, but the small one is ideal.  Yesterday was tragedy in Paris, I am glad I have this to commemorate the day and to help bring the victims of this into remembrance by all who might see this trinket.I received this as a gift so I did not buy it myself, however I am reviewing it as if I did.

This is a decent power strip for travel, although it doesn't quite have the quality that I like for everyday use.  I like that the cord wraps and that it comes with a travel bag for easy packing.  I like that it has 4 charging ports, as I usually have at least 3 items that need to be charged using USB, however, only one of them is over 1 Amp, so those will be slower.  I would love one of these with at least half of the ports being 2.4A.  However, the convenience of taking this with me, the fact that the cord winds up (albeit not always as neatly as I would like), and the carrying bag makes this a winner overall.  The housing is plastic, and not the sturdiest, but figure the convenience, the portability and the price, I can't complain too much.  It isn't a 5 star product, but for this price it is definitely a good buy and one that is convenient to take along when traveling.I received a discounted sample of this product, in exchange for an honest review.

I never thought I would like a dry shampoo, but I recently went through a pretty bad injury and bathing and showering was more difficult for awhile.  I can sink bathe pretty easily, but shampooing my hair for about 5 days was darn near impossible.  I had received this and just never found a good time to test it, but after 4 days of no hair washing, I needed something.  I sprayed this through my whole head of hair, and fluffed my hair up, almost like I was shampooing wet.  Then I let it set for about 5 minutes before brushing my hair thoroughly.  My hair wasn't 'clean' per se, but it looked better and cleaner than it had.  I'd also read that many dry shampoo leaves a white dusty residue on the hair that is difficult to get off without wet shampooing, but I didn't see any of that when I used this product.  Granted I have quite a bit of gray (especially at the roots), so it may just not have been noticeable on my head.  Regardless, my hair looked better so I didn't feel as icky as I did, and I only had to deal with it another couple days til the pain of my injury allowed me to shower normally.  I also loved the fragrance of the shampoo and conditioner set, it was subtle and not too perfume like.  All in all a great experience.  I don't plan to use this often, but if I need it, and can't, for whatever reason, manage a normal shampooing, I'm not afraid to use this now.I received a discount on this product in exchange for my review.  I honestly like this product and will keep it on hand in case I need to use it again.

I received a sample of this car adapter/hub to review and I've seen quite a few different car adapters.This one "is" different though.  It has 4 ports in it which in itself is different than any other I've seen and when tested, all four ports charged both my LG G2 cell phone and my Nexus 7 Tablet quicker than most I've tried.  I don't have the tester that some folks use, I am not that tech savvy to be honest, but I am a consumer, and my experience is telling me that this works faster than most of the others I've used.  The fact that it has 4 ports in the one cigarette lighter spot is also important because it helps save space in my car, and it seems I am continually juggling cables to keep all my devices charged.  This will let me charge my phone, tablet, GoPro and sometimes my Bluetooth headset.  It barely affects my cup holders (another bit of prime real estate in my vehicle) so that is another plus.  There are all plusses and no minuses unless you count that it doesn't automatically remind me to plug in my devices when I am leaving to commute to work.  That would certainly help :P.

This wonderful wall mounted plant/flower pot is ideal for my kitchen.  I don't have a lot of counter space, in fact I barely have enough to prepare meals, and while I love fresh herbs, I've never been able to justify even the small space that an herb pot would normally take up.  But this is great, it can easily go on my wall near the sink and by the kitchen window.  Because it is for growing plants in water, I also can avoid the mess I would invariably make since I am a klutz and frequently 'accidentally' scatter coffee grounds on the counter and anything that might be on the counter because it seems I am all thumbs (and none of them tend to be green).  This pot is a no-brainer though because it is a water pot, so watering isn't an issue and the avocado pit I am currently sprouting loves the pot and the exposure to sunlight.  I may just keep a plant alive yet!I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for a review.

3:48 Mins Very well made and roomy sling pack.  I love how there are two roomy compartments to keep my clean change of clothes separate from my towel and sweaty clothes after my yoga class.  This has two sturdy straps on the side that can be used to hold my yoga mat, and it comes with a separate bag for my mat too.  The single shoulder strap is solid and padded, and there are lots of other compartments for my wallet/keys and cell phone.  There is even a mesh pocket the perfect size for my water bottle.  I love it (and love the purple color too!).I received a complimentary or discounted sample in exchange for an honest review.

My husband and I recently moved into a new home, and are very excited about having a real house to light up for the holidays this year.  My biggest concern was that our electric bill would go through the roof, but with this string of lights at least, it is solar powered, so no worries on that account.  This particular string is 40 feet long (about 13 yards) which is the perfect length to outline one of our outbuildings.  I love it.  The power lasts long enough for us to enjoy it in the evening (even after a rainy day which we have had a ton of lately).  It doesn't last all night, but lasts long enough for the purpose it is being used for.  We haven't had a fully sunny day since these were installed, but even on overcast days it collects enough of a charge.  It has several different modes so we can have it flashing or fading.  I'm very thankful that it is waterproof as well, as that has been an necessity in North Carolina recently.  There are 10 clips for installation (we had some from another string of lights as well) so it was fairly easy to install (I let my husband do it).  I'm thrilled with this and they look great.  Once we get a good evening when it isn't raining, I'll shoot some photos to show it off.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of these lights in exchange for my unbiased review.

I sometimes get achy wrists after spending hours typing or using my mouse while gaming so this was a product that I thought would gets lots of use.  Little did I know when ordering this that the day it came, my husband would be riding his hoverboard scooter (don't ask), and take not one, but two spills resulting in what we feared was a broken wrist.  We used this to stabilize his wrist, and he refused to go to the urgent care, but kept this on overnight.  By morning the pain was almost gone and he decided it wasn't a break but a strain or sprain.  This enabled him to keep it immobilized and give it a chance to heal.  He is still riding his toy, so I've had him wear this brace/band as a protective measure and hopefully that will keep my 55 year old man-child from injuring himself too much.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

Well, this certainly is a fun idea, and if it worked I would be overjoyed because there is nothing I hate worse than flies in my house.  I've had this for a couple weeks now, installed the batteries, made sure it works (all the lights come on as they are supposed to), but I've yet to kill any of those pesky critters with this no matter how I've tried.  We've had two flies get into the house and they tend to dive bomb me, but when I push the button and swing this at them, I swear I hit them, but they just fly off.  I'm not sure if it got the mosquitoes I tried to kill, because I still got bit.  I'm not sure if this works at all, or if the electric part of it is just a gimmick, but I'm giving it four stars because I've convinced my gullible neighbors that it does work, and they are all talking about the nifty fly swatter I've gotten.  I cannot give it five stars, and I truly feel that 4 stars is a gift, just for the amusement factor.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

I have been trying to focus on my health over the last year, and exercise was the last piece to the puzzle.  I walk, and do a little bit of strength training, but I needed something to get my heart beating a little faster, and jumping rope appealed to me as I used to be quite proficient at it (about 40 years ago...when I was 12).  The jump ropes I had then were NOTHING like this one which is absolutely amazing.  I am a tall woman at just under 6' tall so the fact that the length on this rope was adjustable was a great appeal to me.  Adjusting is very easy, and this jump rope turns smoothly.  Unfortunately, getting my feet off the ground enough to qualify as a 'jump' was a bit more challenging...I'll work on it.
