But I know that a large portion of the success of any endeavor are the tools you use.  And as far as jump ropes go, I cannot imagine a finer tool.I received a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

2:50 Mins I've had this scarf for a few weeks now, and have worn it on several occasions, including Halloween when I used it in my 'Hippie' costume.  I've gotten lots of compliments on it and it goes with many different outfits.  It isn't what I would call an infinity scarf, but it is certainly very long and even fits around my very ample hips.  I am still learning all the ways that I can use scarves like this, but as I go I try out new ideas.  I talk more about the features of this scarf in my video.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

3:57 Mins It has been years since I've had a compact all-in-one sewing kit.  I usually end up buying a spool of thread, or a package of needles when I have mending to do, but it is really nice to have everything I need in a nice kit, that I can keep in one place and know where to find it!  This comes in a nice nylon zippered case (in purple which I love, but it also comes in black and dark blue).  This kit comes with snaps, safety pins, a tape measure, a variety of sizes of needles, a small pair of scissors, a seam ripper, a fabric pencil, 11 small spools of thread, a different type of thimble than I am used to (but it works), and two little plastic cases: one with a variety of straight pins, and the other has smaller safety pins and a few odds and ends of buttons.  There is also a device called a needle threader, but I must be honest that I have absolutely no idea how to work that.  But even without it, this kit ROCKS and has everything I need (except for a needle threader I can figure out).  This is great for anyone, and in this throw-away culture we live in, it is nice to see a product that will help me conserve and save perfectly good items that simply needed a little mending.I received a complimentary or discounted sample of this product in exchange for an honest review.

3:47 Mins My husband's birthday is coming up and when I got the opportunity to receive this watch at a discount, I jumped on it.  We are both in our 50s, and while we consider ourselves up on all the latest technology, when it comes to some things, old-fashioned is our favorite way to go.  This is a beautiful piece of jewelry, well made and works flawlessly.  It is easy to set, the date is in English and Spanish (we only need the English), and even comes with a tool so that we can adjust the watchband to fit him perfectly.  I didn't even need to shop for a gift bag, because it comes with that, a certificate of authenticity for its Swiss workmanship, and it is ready to go.  The box it comes it is very sturdy, and I am hopeful that my husband will like it as much as I do.I received a discounted sample of this product in exchange for a review!

We got this portable when we bought the Oreck XL and it is the handiest vacuum cleaner ever.Way more powerful than its weight would have you think and the extension wands and tools let you clean baseboards and between cabinets and appliances easily. Very easy to vacuum the stairs when you can hang the vacuum cleaner on one shoulder and put a wand on to keep you from having to stoop over.The bags are cheap and easy to replace, which is good, because this little thing pulls up more dust and pet hair than you even think is there, and the bags fill up fast. I love this vacuum cleaner!I like using the cinnamon scent tablets in this vacuum, too - the floral ones I tried aren't so great, but the cinnamon is nice.We're at eight years on our Orecks and they're still both powerful and working well.

When I see people calling it "discomfort," it reminds me of Lamaze classes where the instructor calls labor pain, "discomfort." The truth is that the pain is so bad sometimes, it makes me nauseated.I use cotton balls soaked in witch hazel on the external ones and that is more helpful than anything else I've ever tried. But it doesn't help the internal ones.These do. Not instantly, but when you're in agony and suddenly you're not, it feels instant.Keep them in the freezer, open them into a little baggie of ice and don't touch them until you're ready to use them because they melt fast from the heat in your hand.No more sitting on ice packs for hours. No more $90 prescription foam. No more of any of the other things I've tried. The relief from this is just as effective as all of them.Never want to run out of these. Witch hazel is almost miraculous stuff for this kind of pain.

A Winter Frost service for 12 has finally dwindled down to just a few pieces left - after more than 19 years.I'm replacing them with same exact thing because they're beautiful and durable. We don't like the cups, much, but the rest of the pieces are great. They go with everything, no designs to hide food remnants, dishwasher safe, microwave safe, tough as nails.I dropped a stack of plates on a tile counter once and there was not even a chip or scratch on any of them.When you do drop and break them from a greater height, they shatter into a bazillion very sharp pieces, so you don't want to be barefoot in the kitchen. And they can break with what seems like hardly any provocation at all. But they have outlasted Italian ceramics from Pat, ceramics from Spain and every piece of plastic ware we've ever owned.And they're no more expensive now than they were when we bought them almost 20 years ago.

I bought the Ultimate system at a quilt show in both the blue and the white iron-away type and the system IS very easy to use.The problem is that when you're quilting, the vibration of the needle hitting the quilt is enough to rattle the particles away, first making them blurry, and after a minute or two, anything within about 6 inches around the needle is obliterated. Quilting complicated designs is frustrating, even in bright light and wearing strong reading glasses.It works great for simple lines and small, single motifs. I tried to mark a whole border and ended up going over it with a Chaco liner tool just to get that border done.Better to mark your design precisely with something that stays put or memorize your design before you quilt it. If you try to mark your whole quilt with this, you are wasting your time.For me, the Frixion fine point markers and Frixion highlighters have been the real miracle tool for marking quilt designs, garment construction marks, embroidery guidelines and designs, etc.

I can't rate this on longevity, yet, but I can say that on the high setting, this fan is no noisier than the box fan it replaced, and it's WINDY out here in the smoking section! The box fan never moved air like this.Hot as blue blazes out here in the garage on this Texas summer day, but, in front of this fan, I can't even tell. I absolutely LOVE this fan!The legs snap on and it's running right out of the box. Can't get much easier. You need snips to get the cable ties off, and no tools after that.

The rounded blade end is great for cleaning up the sides of the nail, but I didn't like the blunt square end.There's another tool that has a curved spoon in place of the square end and it's a better way to remove gel polish and push back cuticles.

The first time took some fussing, but then I figured out how to fold them and make them fit. And now I have clamps to put over them and hold them tight to the nails.I think these wraps are tailor made for people like me, who rarely strip off the gel down to bare nails. Even using half a set at a time to do both hands, it would be pretty expensive to use these every day or two.The thick pad holds a good soaking amount of acetone. I take them off halfway through (after about 5 minutes) to remove the loose polish and add more acetone for another 5-minute soak.Holds the acetone where you need it and you're not tied to a bowl of remover while it's working. And you can reuse them several times!  Just let them dry and shake out the flakes of gel polish after you're done. I will definitely buy these again.

Always running out of silverware, this is our answer. We save the nice, matched set for when there's going to be a crowd and we use these cheapies for every day. Plenty sturdy and the price is great.Not particularly attractive unless you like minimalist, semi-industrial styles, but they work just fine.

I've always been stuck on 3M papers, but I saw this assortment of fine grits and had to try it.The grit stays on, even wet sanding in soapy water, it clogs about the same as 3M.The only thing it didn't do as well is the paper didn't hold its body and remain firm quite as well. Other than that, this was a good product and I would buy it, again.

Learning to work with the French polishing method has been a lot of fun and I like the convenience of premixed shellac.I'm restoring or replacing the clear coat on three antique Singers with beautiful ornate decals, and although there is a slight yellow cast to this clear shellac, it only adds to the gold color of the decals.It's going to be interesting to try refreshing the cabinetry with this, though - you've got to work FAST! :)
Good cleaner and degreaser.The Amazon price was only a little higher than in the big box hardware store, and I didn't have to actually *go* to the big box hardware store.

Reading that these brushes shed quite a bit, I would hesitate to use them in my Dremel. But, they're exactly what I need for my projects.I'm using them to get into tight spots where a regular or mini brass brush won't fit. Held in a hemostat, I can reach way up into the pillar on an antique sewing machine and scrub away decades of hardened oil and lint with acetone. Just held in my fingers, I can get into the inside corners of the cast iron machines and get them really clean,

Soothing and calming. I hope to learn these well enough to chant. Beautiful prayers, perfect background to the rosary.There is nothing jarring or distracting in this album - no clipped syllables or mispronunciations. Just focused prayer, mellifluous and quiet.I have 12-15 chant albums and this is my favorite for the way it flows so easily.

I used to use these pens with paper and polymer clay, so when I needed to refresh the gold trim on the cast iron treadle for my sewing machines, this is the pen I bought.Stinks like crazy, so use in a well-ventilated place. Let it dry overnight before applying a second coat, and seal it with a clear gloss or satin to match the finish on your irons.

Okay, it's a pain in the neck to cook starch. But, the linen I'm trying to beat into submission is now as stiff as a board, which means I can cut true squares and sew true squares - so this is worth the extra trouble.I will water it down to get the gloss effect for the final pressing after the altar linens are made and laundered.The heavy starch recipe might actually work as a stabilizer for machine embroidery. And I love silk blouses, but sewing them is tricky - if I turn the fabric into a potato chip before I cut it, it will be so much easier to handle!Sometimes, the old ways are the best ways. :)

Really wonderful product. I've tried all the brands of this two-part mascara that I find, and they're all the same. Even the same smell - cheap or expensive, Amazon or home party - they're all alike except the price.I don't use mascara, first. I put on the gel, then the fiber, then do the other eye. Let the fibers sit before you do the second coat of gel. It's amazing.  Soft, thick eyelashes like I had when I was young. You can do a second or third coat if you prefer the look of false eyelashes.To remove, just let the water run on your face in the shower - the dried product rinses away in threads, no smudging.I never use anything but this, any more. Practice a couple of times, and you'll love this stuff.

A great big steel brush for $3! A treadle sewing machine I'm restoring has rusted irons and this takes all the loose stuff off and gets a smoother surface - ready for rust converter and then fresh paint.Comfortable to work and you can put the heel of your other hand on the bristle end to get some muscle into the scrubbing. Super stiff bristles.

I specifically bought this belt because it was at least 180cm (71") and one person answered the question,  "How long is this?" with the answer,  "80""It's 67" long and too short for this treadle. I will use it for a different machine.Kind of a shame because a beautiful Red Eye Singer deserves a pretty red belt.

I used this fabric combined with white bridal satin to make the altar frontal, a parament for the ambo and a drape for the life-size Crucifix in our sanctuary for the Easter Vigil Mass.The effect was breath-taking! People were so excited to see this kind of visual reminder of the importance of this festal season.Being a metallic brocade, it is not easy to press or sew. I learned not to try to serge a cut edge - you get shreds and tangles in your serger. Leave an inch when you rough-cut and set your differential way down as if you're trying to get a lettuce edge on a knit, and you'll get a nice smooth cut and finish without puckers. Keep the heat down on your iron and don't press creases too hard if you want a flow-y look.This fabric looks far richer than the price would indicate. I'm now working with the red and gold version because I love it so much.

I love this stuff. Like PB Blaster, it softens up decades worth of hardened 3in1 oil, lint,  dust and grime from the insides of my antique sewing machines and makes them run smooth as new.Sprayed onto a rag, it cleans the exterior of the machines - stay away from decaled designs. Just magically removes decades of old oil and dust.Loosens stuck screws - though not all. I gave up on one and basically mauled it into submission with a SpeedOut and visegrips. Another one felt like it was welded in and was starting to strip, but between Liquid Wrench and PB Blaster applied every day for a couple of weeks, it finally budged and a few hours later, came free.But, this is still a favorite for general cleaning and loosening up of old, gummed up works. Scrub with a brass (on bare metal) or nylon (on black shellacked parts) brush, wipe it all away with acetone or denatured alcohol.  When everything is clean and the gunk is gone, you can wipe everything down with plain sewing machine oil and put a drop at every metal-to-metal point and the machine will turn as smoothly as the day it was made.The only thing I don't like is there's something grey in this, where PB Blaster is clear.

I've tried a bunch of these two-step fiber mascaras including this one and they're all TERRIFIC!I don't use mascara, first - mascara smudges, clumps, and pulls out your natural eyelashes.I put the gel on one eye, apply the fibers to the outer half, wait a minute while i put gel and fibers on the second eye and then apply the second coat of gel.Perfectly natural looking, but beautiful thick, soft lashes like I had when I was young.If you like the look of false eyelashes, just apply a second and third coat.Look down into a mirror to apply the fibers and the excess will fall on the mirror instead of your eyes and face.To remove, just let the water run on your face for a few seconds in the shower, then run your fingertip side to side across your eyelid. The gel will not smudge or streak - It just floats away in little threads.You can get this exact same product a lot cheaper - except for the different packaging, they even smell identical. Same gel, same fibers.Most of these Younique knock-offs are way overpriced. The Love Alpha brand sells TWO sets (four tubes) for $7 right here on Amazon. You won't miss the case one little bit. :)

Beautiful little book that I will definitely keep. The basics for several different methods of appliqu are included - invisible machine, needle-turn, wool - lots of fun!I know lots of people call appliqu,  "the 'a' word," and even though they love the look, they think it's too difficult or time-consuming, so they put off trying it. That was me - I wouldn't even look at a pattern for appliqu because I thought that that was for advanced quilters. I missed out on a lot of fun and avoided some really wonderful patterns because I was afraid of it.I finally tried it a few years ago and found that I LOVE starch-prepared and needle-turn appliqu. Then I went to a class by Kim Diehl and learned a whole bunch of new tricks to speed up my work.Best of all, I learned how to do her method of invisible appliqu by machine and ohmigosh, is it ever terrific! The crisp edges you get from starch-prepared, and the speed of application is phenomenal! The appliqu looks like precise needle-turn when it's done. And because it goes so fast, you're going to finish a lot more projects!She shows you how to add trapunto for dimension and charm, too. So pretty!There's a section on fusible appliqu, which is probably the least intimidating method and great for quick projects that are going to get a lot of laundering and use.There's one pattern for a sample project in the back for practicing the different methods and a couple of layouts for different ways to display your new addiction.This is a techniques book, rather than a pattern book - if you're looking for step by step how-to, this is it, but if you already know all the how-to and seek a pattern book, this well be far less interesting and useful for you.The whole book is full of hints and good advice - and gorgeous photos of Kim's beautiful work, both finished and in progress. I was sorry to come to the end.If you get the chance, take one of her terrific classes, and in the meantime, get this book and get started in this fascinating and relaxing art form. :)

I LOVE these strips. It's worth it to fuss with them a bit to get them on straight because you will more than make up that time when you're cutting strips.Make sure your ruler is clean - wipe it with an alcohol swab/lens cleaning tissue to get skin oils off of it. Don't handle the strips until you're ready to use them and make sure that your hands are clean and dry.Peel a strip off the backing and hold it by the ends in one hand with the adhesive side down - in a "u" shape. Drop the middle of the "u" on the line you want to cut along and with a finger on the other hand, press the middle in place. Then a little on each side, making sure that it all stays aligned. It only takes a couple of minutes.You can cut a LOT of fabric - eight or ten layers at a time - with these strips in place. The ruler aligns itself very accurately and instantly - whoosh. Take away the cut strips and align again.And you don't have to pull them off if you need to cut a different size - just lift the ruler and set it down on the measurement that you need. I actually like these things in place because they really GRIP the fabric underneath to prevent slippage while cutting. VERY COOL!

These are fantastic little lights if you have machines that are not lighted adequately, but in order for a magnet to function, you must give it something that contains IRON for it to attract to!It's not the lamp's fault that your plastic machine won't hold on to it.The solution is very simple - buy a little steel washer or screw plate at the hardware store and glue it to the back of your machine or work table.OR buy a thread cone stand with a cast iron base and stick the magnet part to the base.OR use a Command Strip to attach the flat part of the magnet to a flat part of your machine or the table behind it.It's not fair to the product to leave bad reviews for your own lack of understanding about how magnets work!

It would be trivial to add a true 1/4" and a generous 1/4" line and hole to this tool, making it more versatile.The Qtools Corner Cut has all three, so it's the better choice for a quilter's seam measurement tool.Even better if they'd add 1/2" and 5/8" markings, so you don't need two separate tools for quilting and apparel sewing.Still a good idea and nicely made.

I'm not sure why the company calls this a picot foot, because it does not make anything like a picot edge. If you look at the YouTube video for this foot, the result is so messy looking that you wouldn't even buy it, and that's a shame if you like heirloom sewing by machine.What this foot does is a shell edge. For vintage zigzag machines, it was called a shell hemmer, and it's used with fine fabrics and the mirrored blind hem stitch to create a tiny scalloped effect on rows of tucks or the edges of collars, hems or trims for women's clothing, lingerie and baby clothes.You set the stitch length to give you the width of scallops that you want and you may need to tighten your needle thread tension a bit in order to make the scallops deeper or more pronounced.

The Amazon price is a little expensive for five strips of plastic, and the strips are not very reusable.That said, this is my favorite seam guide.I cut them in half, so I get 20-30 uses from each package. When the sticky back gets linty and doesn't stick well, you can rinse the back with plain water and let it air-dry. Don't scrub, or the adhesive will be removed.Once you apply the strip to your machine (assuming that it's clean - free of oils and lint) it will stay put for hours and hours of piecing, which helps you keep your seam allowance consistent throughout your quilt top. I usually use the qtools Corner Cut to measure a scant 1/4" and lay the strip right next to the Corner Cut and press it down.Once you remove it, it doesn't stick as well as it does the first time, so I try to get it exactly where I need it on the first try.There is another brand of adhesive strip that will take the paint and shellac off of your vintage machines, but this Sewing Edge hasn't ever damaged any of my machines.It's low profile and firm, so you can use your fingers to keep the fabrics lined up perfectly.

The first time I used this, I was able to get the strip applied properly on the first try, thanks to the excellent instructions.The next morning, I had no pain in that toe from ordinary walking, and by the third day, my dog stepping on my foot didn't hurt, where it had caused pretty significant pain, just a few days before.Two weeks later, there was no tenderness at all and I could wear closed-toe shoes. This is *without* digging under the corner of the nail and cutting that prong off at the quick, which I normally have to do every 2 or 3 weeks.It came off after about two weeks and the trouble started with the second application. The glue bottle was welded shut, despite my careful cleaning of the glue tip after the first use. I have yet to find a super glue which does not do this. I usually buy super glue 3-packs at the Dollar store and once they're opened, I consider them disposable.Not only does the top weld itself shut, but this glue begins to change when it comes in contact with air, gradually losing its effectiveness. Since I resorted to unscrewing the top and dipping the end of the cotton swab into the bottle to apply the glue, this chemical change is probably going to happen a lot more quickly.I could not get the brace to stick, despite using the same amount of glue as the first time. It took several tries and finally worked when I used a little more glue.Next time, I will try a fresh tube of super glue, or maybe experiment with the gel form.Overall, I'm very happy with the way that the brace worked and relieved to be out of pain and able to wear my regular shoes.

Usually, I can put on a pair of Clarks and walk all day, but that's not the case with these. I'd read that these are running small, so I ordered the wide width. The fit is perfect in length, but too narrow to be considered a true Wide.Normally 12s are a little too big, and the last pair of Clarks 12M turned sloppy and huge in just a few weeks.This pair just needed a little wearing and they stretched just enough for a good fit.On the up side, there is something magically squishy in the footbed and once you break them in, they stay comfortable all day.Plus, it's nice to find good-looking shoes in my "Sasquatch" size - these are cute and not old-lady-ish. Even though I'm an old lady, I don't want to dress like one. :) They look nice with jeans or dress slacks. And you can't help but smile when you're wearing red shoes! ;)

I love this stuff for refurbishing antique sewing machine parts.The nickel plating is usually at least a little pitted, allowing the steel underneath to rust.Soaking those parts won't remove the plating, but it removes all the rust *plus* the years of old oil and dust that have turned hard and orange and is so hard to remove with other methods. I'd much rather use this than acetone, even though acetone is a lot cheaper.The parts are ready to buff and wax after soaking, unless the rust removal uncovers much worse pitting, which might call for removing the plating. I have found that more with the old handwheels and some slide plates, where taking them down to steel looks nicer than leaving the nickel plate.I also used this to clean up a "widow's mite" bronze coin - It was so corroded, it looked like a little rock, but soaking for a few weeks and brushing with a toothbrush every few days, all that corrosion soaked off enough that I could see the design.But, now I have a real rustbucket of a machine that I'm just going to immerse, so I need the 5 gallon size. This is going to be a major chore and Evaporust is expensive. But like restoring any other old thing, you do it for love, even if it costs you in sweat and money.

I have this booklet in print and Kindle editions because it is so helpful in those times when I am "stuck" or too distracted to focus properly.This rosary contains all twenty mysteries, and each mystery is accompanied by a masterpiece illustration and a meditation. Far from a lecture, the meditations are short enlargements on the statement of the mystery, two or three paragraphs, each. They provide much food for thought, applying the mystery to our own lives or pondering the mystery as it was observed by Our Lord's Blessed Mother. You can even course one sentence at random from the paragraph and meditate on it through the prayers for great reward.All of the traditional prayers of the rosary are included.There are several short articles about the benefits of praying the rosary and the transformations it can bring about in our lives.I try to buy these booklets in bulk, to give someone when I give them a rosary. Being small, it doesn't seem intimidating to those new to the rosary. I recommend it to everyone, whether they've prayed the rosary for fifty years or never.

Introduces a difficult concept - just because we can't see it doesn't mean it isn't there - like air.Getting them started early with these complex subjects is important, because the world is ready to fill their imaginations with garbage if you don't fill it first with beauty and truth.I bought this for a Godchild, far away. Maybe when the parents read the books out loud, it will help them, too.
Charming illustrations and easy for a five-year old to understand.When your Godchild is far away, it's helpful to have books to send them, to keep them learning the faith.

Such a beautiful collection of designs!I loved the previous book of this type and this one looks just as good.My favorite feature is that the author shows you how to combine the individual motifs to create different designs and to fill different kinds of spaces - blocks, patches, triangles, borders, etc.I wish there were suggested "joins" for each one, that would make them continuous, for free-motion quilting, but I'm sure I can noodle that out for myself.Huge variety of themes and the spiral binding is terrific for scanning or tracing.

I'm glad that I gave this a shot - the bad reviews almost chased me away from this one. If I were buying for a restaurant, I would probably go for a heavier pot. But, for ordinary home use, cooking for a crowd just got a whole lot easier for me.I didn't even realize that I wanted one of these until I started looking for colanders large enough for the quantities I normally cook and this set came up as I shopped - perfect!I wonder if the company has improved the quality since they were ordered by the people who left bad reviews? The set that I received is really nice - beautifully polished, nice weight, well-fitting lid, smooth, sturdy handles. (There *is* a little flex in the handles if I pull pretty hard on them, but not from lifting a pot of water.)I didn't think I'd use the steamer basket, but it's the first part I did use - as a colander to drain one pound of cooked pasta - just the right size to pour it all back into the empty pot without spilling some out of the sides.Less than $40 from the Amazon Warehouse, still in the box with all the plastic wraps and looking newly-minted!Really, an excellent buy.

Very clear, even lenses and the frames are comfortable enough to wear for hours without even noticing them.They don't leave dents on my nose or pinch behind my ears and they don't keep sliding off.And they're so cute! I received purple, teal and brown and though I would have preferred the red shown, I would definitely order these, again.

Our Keurig was getting slower and slower, despite regular full tanks of pure white vinegar run through it.This product worked very well and sped up the brewing and it didn't stink up the whole house with boiling vinegar. Not having to deal with that smell is a big thing by itself, but it also seemed to work better than the vinegar.I'm not sure how the Clean Cup works or even IF it works, but I would definitely order the solution, again.

I really like this stuff - almost all of the ink stays put after you heat set it.You get a nice, crisp print on the normal setting - if you use "Best" print, you may get so much ink that it blurs and bleeds.After the print has air dried you can square it up and iron it to fusible web or stabilizer to prevent fraying and keep it square on the grain.
Nice fabric, smooth, soft and even. Color shows up about right on my computer, tablet and phone.Very fast service, too.

I bought the bright white version of this bulb to try, hoping that it would solve my lighting problem with all my old sewing machines that take a dim 5w bayonet bulb.Unfortunately, the bulb doesn't fit into the socket - the base is about 1/8" too short to reach the contacts or the slots that seat the bulb in the socket.I hope the manufacturer will make a bulb that actually fits and works, because these little LEDs are crazy bright, but if you're ordering this for your vintage sewing machine, you'll be disappointed.

I had high hopes for this light, as I had always wanted one for various precision tasks.  However I have been disappointed.ASSEMBLY:This light is heavy.  I was amazed at the weight of the box.  There are 2 pieces (base & arm) and two screws along with 2 allen wrenches and the cord.  To assemble the top to the base was interesting to say the least. It was a 2 person operation for us.  To hold the base on the side as the instructions suggest and align the arm of the lamp in any position is impossible.  It took us nearly 15 minutes to put the two screws in to assemble the light to the base.  We did that by one person holding the lamp upside down and the base on top of that with the other person doing the screws.USAGE:Since you use 2 screws to hold the lamp in the base, it cant pivot there.  That was a major problem for usage.  If you want to use the lamp at a desk, or workbench, it has to be exactly aligned to the back or side of where you want to use it, because it wont pivot.  The second joint, the elbow is limited to only bending as well, you cant twist there either.  Imagine a > symbol.  It can go up and down only.  Finally the wrist joint, can rotate around the axis of the arm and bend up and down.The light is easy to turn on and off.  Seems to from Off, to Maximum brightness.  To reduce light, you have to tap the -.  To increase tap the +.  I was hoping you could slide. If the light is turned off when it is at a lower level, that is the level that it comes back on at.5X sounded like a good magnification until, I used it to look at coins.  My old eyes (Im in my 50s) would like more magnification and this is with my reading glasses on. However looking on the web, this is a common magnification for this type of magnifier.ACCESSORIES:I saw some reference to accessories, such as an arm that would help add the pivot option, but dont have that documentation right here, so I figured I would just look it up on the internet under Black & Decker.  Cant find this product even.  Maybe its too soon, but since you can buy it today it should be listed.  Would also like to swap out the magnifier for a higher value one, but dont know if that is possible.WHAT WOULD MAKE IT WORTH IT TO ME?I want a pivoting base. If you have to make it heavier fine.I would like it to be easier to assemble or come pre-assembled.And I wish I could swap out the lens for a higher power one.

Having never read a graphic novel of this type, I was unsure what to expect.  What I did find was a pleasure to view and read.  This is a fairly large format book, so it is heavy.  A single-hand hold when reading will fatigue you.  But, this is my only negative.  Im sure the large format made the artwork inside more compelling, or at least I thought so.If you read magazines like Discover or some science-based other magazine the content of this book will grab you with its meandering stories of locales, people, etc. and the effects of weather on them. There are several sections each covering an aspect of weather, such as wind or fog and in these sections stories related to this phenomena.  Essential bits and pieces that capture the essence of this weather fact. It is not comprehensive by any means but just facts and info that caught the authors fancy to include.The artwork relates to the stories within.  Some of it very involved and some simple such as an entire 2-page spread that captures that azure blue a sky gets on a warm and humid day.  All the artwork is in a cartoon or caricature type of style, befitting a graphic novel. Some, I could figure out what it was depicting, others no so much.I enjoyed the stories and the artwork, and I guess that would be the whole point.

Reading this and having  heard of various movie stars home life, the drug use and the lack of parental guidance, was not a surprise. However, Kelly Carlin herself, is at times not a very sympathetic figure.  She was nearly in her 40s before she even considered that she needed to be a contributing member of society. But, maybe in making her story so transparent, this is her redemption.She clearly can write.  This book is evidence of being able to do that.  It flows; though the narrative at times is of a spoiled Hollywood brat. George her father and her mother, did not have their act together in the parent role.  George was the typical artist obsessed over his craft and his wife, his enabler in that craft. It seems raising of Kelly was an afterthought..  Parenting is hard work and they sucked at it.  Limits that would normally be on a child, were absent, as the self-control was not to be had for these two parents, themselves.  One was a major drug abuser and the other an alcoholic.  It is no wonder the daughter was aimless, there was nothing to strive for. If she wanted something Daddy gave it to her.  That is except, much of his attention.  When she got that the sun shone and all was good.  That is true of most children and especially those of absent parents..You can see George had quite a shadow cast. It did not seem he shared his spotlight ever, until much later in life in an interview with his family as some stars do.  But based on what I recall of Carlin, his comedy was who he was, not just a role he played.  Hard to share that.When she writes of her Moms death and quitting her job to care for her.  She is lucky she did not have to choose between this care and a job that she needed to support her family.  Most of us would be torn apart, due to the lack of income and the need for care.  However the never-never land of caring for a terminally ill patient did not spare her its unceasing hopefulness/hopelessness and the mind-numbing tasks.  But, unlike us, after her Mom passed she was not able to move as easily beyond, as she had the luxury and curse of time on her hands.Later, she decided to try school, psychology, as she felt she needed help there herself.  Though she was going to school as a counselor, she expressed no desire to help crazy people.  However to complete this degree, she had to and it seems she found her niche.  I have a colleague who went into psychology and had the express opinion, that the people that needed the help the most were the ones that went into the training.  He did not excuse himself from these ranks and it would seem this was true for her case as well.  Later however she ditched licensed counseling for her pursuit of performance, becoming instead a life coach, so it did not interfere.Though I laughed at the start of this schooling when she indicated trepidation about taking on a 40K loan for her education, as several of the cars her father gave her, plus also the houses made that seem like a drop in the bucket.  But, I give her credit for pursuing some worthwhile pursuit, though it seems she ditched it ASAP for performing.  She cant compete with her father as there is only one George, but I think she finally realized there is also only one Kelly.Overall this was a good book and as another reader pointed out, this is a book about Kelly, the daughter of George and this is what it is supposed to be about.

Hard to write a lot about an anti-fatigue mat, but I will give you my observations.APPEARANCE:This mat is a neutral dark brown with a bit of grey in it.  As I have warm beige tiles with a brownish orange tinge in my kitchen and medium oak cabinets it was a good fit.  At work, since it is behind my desk, its color is neutral enough to be not noticed. The finish on top is matt, so there is no shine, but can be easily wiped clean.DIMENSIONS:Mat measures 20 x 30 with a 2 chamfer all around where it blends flatter to the floor.  Thickness in the middle is about .  If you roll a chair into it, it will stop and not creep onto the mat. So if you change between standing and sitting you will need to move the mat. The mat when shipped is not rolled or folded and most likely you dont want to roll or fold it to risk flattening it.USAGE: HOME & WORKHOMEIve used this mat both at home in front of the sink and at work behind my standing desk. I found at home, that it was comfortable but I didnt stand long enough behind the sink (dishwasher makes that possible) to make it of much use there.  Food preparation also happened at various other spots on the counter, such that it would have to be moved around to suit.  You will catch your foot slightly on this mat (very slightly) so you need to know where it is.  Moving it around is makes that hard to predict.  If you are a person who stands in the kitchen, in one spot more than I do, this might work better for you than it did for me.  Another alternative might be at a work bench for a hobbyist. Since that is not me, I cant speak to that.  In my case, work seemed a better fit.WORKIve noted at my standing desk that various shoes had degrees of comfort if standing all day. So this mat really takes the place of a pair of shoes that have great support.  (think high quality running shoes on steroids).  After a few moments usage, I have noted the different of standing on the mat, to walking on the floor.  Suddenly the floor seems harder.  Similar to the home usage, a chair will catch on it, so when I switch from standing to sitting the mat will need to be moved.but, here I feel is where its real benefit is for me and the movement is slight and not likely to be tripped on.  Im more motivated to use it as it works and it will not be difficult to move it.  Still not sure what our office cleaning staff will think of it.Another note, unlike a nice cushioned shoe, the thickness of the mat is constant and your weight on your foot is not.  Much of my weight is on my heels so I felt they were sinking in more, and you feel a slight back tilt. My running shoes has more padding in the heel to accommodate that and you experience less tilt.

This is a wonderfully written book that chronicles the authors early years and vet school.  Jessica is an introvert that discovered quickly her relationship with dogs was more rewarding than with humans.  She has several dogs growing up and her early years as a vet and young mother that provide her companionship and love that only a pet can.Working as a vet can be challenging and rewarding.  This book covers a bit of both.  She also tells the story of a dear friend of her husbands, whose personality reminded her of a friendly dog (in a good way).As you can imagine since she mentions 3 dogs that she also deals with their passing.  This is done in an understanding way. Its sad, but it also the price you pay for loving a pet.  Having had pets all my live (mostly cats but 2 dogs), the joy is worth the pain and she observes this as well.Thoroughly well written and enjoyable book.

This pair of Samba 2 dress shoes was my 2nd set.  The first was a size 11, I had purchased, as I own another pair of this brand (Taos Jive pump) in the size 11.  When I received the size 11 in these, they were way too big.  I had a finger sized gap in my heel.Since I wear a perfect 10-1/2 which no one makes, I would say this particular shoe runs a bit large and I'm okay with that.  Would be nice if the two shoes were consistent, but returning the too large pair only cost me time (thankfully I purchased these in plenty of time).I purchased these for my son's wedding.  I have to wear a low heel due to bad knees and these were perfect.  I also liked the cut out top.Especially nice was the velcro-closure.  If you have ever struggled to put shoes on that have a hole and pin, this was a breeze in comparison.A silver looking shoe is quite dressy.  However, as much as I liked these shoes they did not seem as dressy as I would like.  Maybe it was the beige interior in combination with the silver exterior.  No one saw that but me however.

Caroline Jacobs is a mouse, a mouse that suddenly roared with no warning and then no explanation.  Caroline is the ultimate introvert, that manipulative people know how to tie in knots.  Even her teenage daughter walks over her.Finally one day she has had enough and embarks on a mission to right some wrongs. Deciding she needs a partner in crime, she basically kidnaps her daughter to accompany her.  Along the way they discover who each other is.The author captures the trap of the introverted.  Their best replies go unsaid and planned speaks can get diverted easily.  Often, so used to tamping back their feelings of how people have treated them, they bully themselves they are over-reacting. Bravo in catching this accurately.I started reading this story and finished it the same day. It positively flowed and you cared what was going to happen next.  Funny that one I read just before this (Night Blindness) also dealt with guilt over the death of a sibling.  It seems when tragedy happens, guilt and blame even in accidents play a large part in the families of the deceased. It is rare that it is resolved.This book was wonderful as it flowed.  It was unpredictable and very predictable in the right measures.  The characters were well developed and unique.

When I first started this book, I felt the main character hopping back and forth between the present and the past a bit annoying and hard to follow.. The info on this book indicated there was a deep dark secret and it was clear the main character (Jensen/Jenny) was obsessed with this issue. However, as the book continued, I felt the author smoothed this out.The main character Jensen, is married to Nico, her former art teacher. He is older and clearly controlling her life.  She models nude for sculptors.  Just once give me a girl next door character, without being gorgeous and nearly being anorexic.  Of course these men are all in love with her, she is aloof with them and a knockout.  Later, they reveal her feelings of inferiority over her looks, but it was more of an after-thought. Okay off my soapbox on that one.The characters are well developed and I think they capture the fracturing of a family over the loss of a child.  Grief isnt even.  The irony does not escape me that Jensen does not see the parallel between her own reaction and her mothers.Many of the characters are pretty iconic, the big bear of a Dad, the ice maiden Mom, the counterculture Uncle and his psychic girlfriend, the bad girl best friend, the one who got away because of this awful secret and the sibling that died too young.  BUT, it is a good book to read.  I never set it down due to boredom or lack of interest and I doubt you will either. It has an interesting story and captures the aspect of being different selves with different people.

When we received this rack in the mail, the first thing that impressed us was the sheer weight. It is clear the items are of durable quality just by that metric. After unwrapping assembling and using this assessment became even stronger.  Several friends have commented on its appearance.INSTRUCTIONS AND ASSEMBLY:This was very nicely done.All the parts were well labeled and nicely wrapped to protect all the surfaces.  Stickers were on each part so you know what parts went where.  All the hardware was in a bag.Not only did they show you in wonderful illustrations how things got put together they recommended the orientation of the parts.  Sometimes you installed with the rack in different orientations and they were clear to note when this was to happen.  They also told you when not to tighten up stuff completely, so it had some play while other things were still being attached.Also and these means a lot,  they included extra hardware.  This is a godsend if a part goes ricocheting off somewhere never to be found. I recently put together a very expensive tool that didnt have a single spare and we lost 30 minutes trying to find a nut we dropped.The assembly went smoothly and we carted this very solid rack up 8 stairs and I can vouch for fact, the weight was in the rack not the packing.USAGE:The beautiful wood on the top, base and small shelves is a nice match to my medium oak dining room.  The darkened silver uprights, glass and bottle racks are a wonderful accent.  Not too flashy or tacky.  All 28 bottles that I have put in it, have a  nice tilt and the glasses slide in their holder.  Of course the glasse have some play and are not secured.  Might take them out when the grandchildren come over, but other than that, Im content with their fit.  Any tighter might cause different issues.  I have grasped the rack and shook it to see if there was any play and it was limited only to making my glasses ring.  Very little movement was noted.  Since I have the unit on carpeting that is most likely where the play came from.The dimensions are nice fit in my house. 16.5 tall X 38 wide X 41.5 tall.  Only you will know what works for you.

Not a primer for leaping without a net, but more the authors exploration of her own experience and talking to others who have done the same thing.This book talks about the psychology of what our job means to us and her personal journey of what quitting meant to her.To be honest, I found the first half very repetitive.  Okay, you are not THE Tess Vigeland of Marketplace anymore.  I get that.  So whats next?Later in the book she talks a bit more about what is next, working from home, the money aspects, if you have kids etc. But, these seem very lightly touched. There are other peoples stories in this book, but it didnt flow, quite the way I would have expected someone who spoke for a living.Having never heard Tess Vigeland on radio, I didnt come to this book to read about someone I knew, but more the job change aspect.  I think we all think at sometimes we would like a change and I was hoping for some guidance.  I can empathize with some of her comments about loss of identity years back when I gave up a job I loved due to changes in the office and a dynamic, I could not tolerate, but in my case I moved into another job, so it was not that dramatic.However, if you, like me came to this book expecting a bit more guidance or recommendations, I really didnt find that.

This book caught my eye for two reasons, the author is an ex-pat in Japan, a country I have found interesting and have traveled to a number of times, as well as the aspect of relating issues to yoga.  As I practice yoga, I thought this would be an interesting mix.  I dont think of yoga associated with Japan, though you see Tai Chi in many parks in the AM, so I was wondering how this went together.This book is the story of a young Jewish woman meeting a Japanese man while living in Japan, falling in love and traversing several countries.  They marry and try to start a family to no avail.  Knowing how strict Japan, is regarding race & family, I was curious to see how an adoption of a Japanese child to an older mixed race couple panned out.  In this book you can see the authors struggles, not only with the institution of adoption, but relinquishing the option of a child of her own.  It is a struggle I have seen some friends and family go through. I think she captures the emotional side of it well.The book is wonderfully well written. Even if you dont have an interest in yoga, or have issues with fertility, this book is an interesting read of the authors life.  I had a hard time putting it down and finished it in 2-3 days.

The premise of this story is a young woman is raped in college and walks the PCT to sort things out.  In a nutshell this is what it is about.THE PCT ITSELF:The descriptions of the PCT are great to read and you get a good sense of the harshness of the journey and the appreciation of trail angels.  Hypothermia, malnutrition, dehydration and infections as well as outright injuries or death are a very real part of this journey as well.  You also get a sense of the beauty and pride as well as the sheer athleticism of this walk.  30 miles a day, is as the author called a marathon a day.GREAT WRITINGFirst of all the writing is great, she clearly knows how to tell a story.  I found the latter third of the book however spent more time describing the scenery than the earlier sections.  Maybe at that point she was being more aware of her surroundings, than the people and her own internal struggle. It seemed a real shift in the writing.SOME ISSUES:But, I struggle with some of the inconsistencies represented in this story..Her rape was a complicated thing.  Not a violent assault, but a confusing jumble of being the victim of an overly assertive guy in a compromising situation.  Still rape, but fell within a very grey area, that often finds in favor of the rapist. That was unfortunate.  But, the counselors at the college and her parents reaction was abominable.  Clearly there was an issue and it was not dealt with even remotely correctly.  You sense the damage to her self esteem and it only got worse with the number of people that downplayed it.One issue I had was her characterizations of her parents.  A woman that dresses her teenage daughter through high school, I find it hard to believe could not be unawares of her daughter lying about walking a portion of the PCT during a summer holiday (prior to this walk).  That to me is inconsistent.  Her parents were highly educated professional people.  This level of control (dressing) seems inconsistent with being blithely unaware of where your daughter is for an entire summer.  Then the mothers reaction in the doctors office versus dealing with the college over her rape makes no sense, unless the lawyer in her wrote off the situation as unwin-nable.  Were they so older parents that, they alternatively were overbearing and dismissive.  Seems off the mark.The author herselfs choice of walking the PCT after a rape where she is an extreme minority is peculiar.  She said she didnt think it out but maybe this was her way of healing (baptism by fire).  I guess.  Her actions on the trail; Going naked in the pool, giving herself the name Wild Child has all sorts of connotations and even the prior on-line relationship with the other PCT hiker hopeful all speak to someone testing sexual waters..  Sometimes the water gets  too hot.  I get that she might have been a bit messed up, but it does raise a red flag. Her testing of IceCap seemed borderline on controlling him as well.  Hmm, the nut does not fall too far from the tree here.As far as compassion, she had very little.  What stood out was getting her then boyfriend IceCap to ditch the annoying other hiker when he was most leary of an area.  That kind of casual disregard for another is how people get killed in these situations. Then, she alternately resented her Moms control, yet relied on it.  One minute worrying that her Mom was up all night and then casually forgetting to contact her.  I dont know too many 19 year olds that refer to their Mom as Mommy. That was jarring.  Additionally she seemed to be still fighting very old fights in her head regarding her own independence and did go on about that ad-nauseum. The book is a coming to terms, but highly repetitive.In the  latter part of the book she calls herself out on her relationship with her Mom and it would seem she and her Dad patched things up as well.  Maybe reading her own book over and over provided some sort of judgement on her part for her lack of maturity.Overall, she is a good writer, the PCT is one heck of a walk.  The book was an interesting story, that included a sometimes not easy to like prime character.  If you like to hear stories of the PCT and hiking you might enjoy this.

This book could have been all sorts of facts and figures on how memories are made and recalled, but instead the author took a much more interesting tactic and used personal anecdotes and case histories to bring the personal aspect of memories into play.We all know (at least all of those old enough to read this book), that elusive memory that plagues us.  Or that one we are sure of that, despite facts to the contrary, we insist is true.  Why does this happen?  Why are only certain events recalled from our childhood?  Why are some emotional events dead on, and others shaky?  The author covers this and many other cases (from PTSD to amnesia) in a very readable and interesting way. The chapters are below:Casting a Line: Intro, while trying to remember a specific event.Getting Lost: Remembering gone wrong.  Finding inaccuracies in what you remember.The Scent Museum: The role of scent in triggering memories.The Sunny Never-Never: Events, we have forgotten versus those remememberedWalking at Goldhanger: Memories of conversationsNegotiating the Past: Memory seeding.  Telling others about a person/event and their memoryThe Plan of What Might Be: Architecture of memory and some memory enhancing processes.The Feeling of Remembering: Deja-vu is a chemical processRemember Me a Story: Remembering changes your memoryThe Horror Returning: PTSDThe Martha Tapes: Recollections of a Grandmother how we tend to recall ages from teens to 30s.Special Kind of Truth: SummaryThis  really is an amazing book.  It gets you thinking about what you recall and when and how detailed these memories are. The authors stories help you realize, that you have been there as well.  I especially like that he re-enacted several memories of his own and found them wanting in familiarity in one case and in facts in another.  That kind of twist can leave you wondering.  Its nice to that it is a fairly universal phenomena.  Great book.

This story has an  interesting delivery.  You are reading a young mans story of an adored adopted uncle, while also reading the book penned by that uncle Poxl West..  As you can imagine any story about WWII has the protagonist a hero of his people and this book was no exception.The book is well written and the shift from one voice to the other is well done.  Its a very introspective book.  The uncle often casted people he know as characters from Shakespeare, so if you know Shakespeare (I dont), you have a sense of how he felt about them and their role in his life. You can understand some of his choices, from his youth, even though they mystify himself years later, context is everything and that serves to remind ourselves of this aspect. This I thought was very well done.The young man, is a very typical young man with an overly busy father whos uncle spent a lot of time with him.  The uncle to him was larger than life adored and provided an outlet for his attention.  I found the other important figure in this young mans life, his rabbi an interesting mix of contradictions.  Essentially a hippy rabbi, who was into the Kabbalah and worships the Grateful Dead.  He provided some interesting commentary, in contrast to the young mans concerns.This book makes you think about biographies.  How people reconstruct scenes years later, to give you a fresh sense that they just happened and the liberties around this truth.Overall it was an interesting book, well written, easy to read and an thoughtful premise.  You dont get a clear resolution, or completion however and that is just what life is like.  A minor complaint, is I thought some avenues were left a bit vague and wondered why they were introduced, but maybe I just missed the point.

I opted to get this razor for my boyfriend who uses a 4-5 blade standard razor every AM.  He said prior electrics didnt work well for him, but this one being top of the line was worth a shot.PACKAGING:First of all I was surprised when this razor came.  It was frustration free packaging and I wasnt quite sure what that was.  It meant there was no extra retail box inside the packing one.  Less waste.  That is a good thing.  There is a base, the razor and the triple head as well as a separate head for trims and a carry case for travel.SIZE:While the razor was a fairly common size, it was housed in a base that takes up considerable counter space about 5 x 5 inches and about 10 inches tall. If your counter space in the bathroom is as precious as ours, this is too big.  Im sure you can plug it in elsewhere or only occasionally as I dont think daily (or maybe even weekly) charging is necessary, but thats a lot of bother. This base provides charging and cleaning.  A few times, I think it went through a cleaning cycle in the middle of the night which was a bit weird.QUALITY OF SHAVE:Well, this is what its all about isnt it?  It did not meet my boyfriends expectations. He was hoping for an ease of shave, which he did not find.  He tried it dry and with electric shave lotion.  Still he felt there was too much drag on his face.  He was looking for a closeness of shave, if not as close as a blade, at least a reasonable substitute.  However he remained disappointed.  To be fair, he used the blade about 3 weeks before returning to his normal method of shaving using a 4 or 5 blade standard razor.  He did not feel this was a reasonable substitute in a pinch.How does this compare to other electrics, we can't answer, so please take that in account.  That's why we gave it a 3 and not a 2.

Having a food processor before this I had certain expectations.  My prior one is a Kitchenaide and it sits on my counter ready for use with the large bowl set up, as it is integral to some of my recipes.  I use it for a chicken recipe to grind up the chicken, to grate cheese, to slice vegetables and fruits and to chop nuts.  So this unit has to meet that high bar.The short version, "whys" are below:OVERALL RATING:Height: Negative. Wont fit under counter with bowl attached.Weight: Neutral: Heavy, would not be an issue unless had to movePower cord: PositiveSmall bowl needing big one to use: Neutral since common with other food processorsCover fit: Neutral.  I dont like it as much as what Im used to, but others may have no issueSettings: Positive, More is better.Accessory box: Positive, Nice.Rotating blades: Positive, heavy and adjustableDouble food pusher: Positive, can accommodate larger foodsUsage: Neutral, Comparable to the KitchenaidePositives:  5Negatives: 1Neutrals: 4The neutrals you need to decide for yourself if this is an issue.DOESNT FIT UNDER MY CABINETS ON THE COUNTERWhat I first noticed about the Cuisinart is that it will not fit under my cabinets on my counter.  It measures 17 inches tall with the large bowl in place.  My cabinets are 16 inches from my counter.  My old Kitchenaide measures 15 inches tall.  This is a problem for me as I would have to have it on the counter without the bowl attached.  Certainly I would not want to pull the Cuisinart every time I used it.  It is quite heavy.  Its listed shipping weight it 27.5 pounds, so at least 22-23 pounds of that is the unit itself.WIND UP POWER CORD:This unit has a nice wind up cord.  You pull it to recoil.  This is a nice option, if you like me unplug and wrap it around the unit when not used.TO  USE SMALL BOWL, YOU MUST ALSO USE THE LARGE BOWL:Similar to the Kitchenaide the top cover is for both the small bowl and large bowl and you must use the large bowl with the small, so that this fits all together.  I never liked that.  Often I will use my smaller food processor to not have so many things to wash.COVER FIT:I have been used to the Kitchenaide so this is a bias and might not affect a first time user.  The bottom bowl twists in, the top bowl sets in and the cover has to snap on one side and the back, rather than twist on.  I find this really fussy and would be concerned that any side spill could make this tricky.  I havent found this happening, but there is something fussy about this.SETTINGS: ON, OFF, PULSE AND DOUGH:Having never done dough in my prior food processor, Im not sure how handy this will be for me, but, more is better right?  My prior Kichenaide does not have this.ACCESSORY BOX:I like this, as there is a drawer under the box, that stores the rotating blades. This is nice.ROTATING BLADES:There is a less and more here. The shredding blade is a single one, one thicker that flips to one thinner. But notable is an adjustable Madoline style blade.  You have 22 adjustments from 1-10. This is pretty cool.  I noted that these blades are a lot heavier than my Kitchenaide ones.  The cutting blades are a small one for the smaller bowl, a large one and a dough one.  Overall these blades seem more durable than my Kitchenaide.DOUBLE FOOD PUSHER:This is a positive.  The cover has a food pusher inside a food pusher.  The big one is integrated (for safety no doubt), so you cant run the processor with this not in the cover, the smaller is not, so you can drop food in this one.  What I like about this is you can put whole potatoes in this and not have to cut to fit.USAGE:This being summer, I have not used it as much as I will in the winter, so I will update.  It is comparable to the Kitchenaide.

I had high expectations that were not met.  I had been familiar with a pillowcase offered that the same group that sells the Sleepnumber bed and knew of another pillow a friend had purchased.  So when I saw this I jumped at it.I could feel the cooling surface side of the pillow felt cool to the touch with my hand so I was excited.  However except for initially feeling cool, the pillow was no cooler than my newer Somus pillow that I have used for the last year.  I slept on this new pillow for about a month.I tried this with a cotton pillowcase and even without a pillowcase and still it was not any cooler than the Somus or for that matter any other pillow.Comfort-wise it was okay as well.  My Somus pillow is a little bit thicker and as I have a jaw and neck issue this is preferred.Im going to let my boyfriend try this one for a bit to see what he thinks, but this is just so-so for meIn the past I have often found my buckwheat pillow to be a bit cooler than most.  Maybe I will try that out again.

I found the premise of this book compelling.  3 sisters essentially failing at life compelled to make a pact for suicide when one of the 3 has intractable cancer.  The word in the description of this book used was "hilarious".  I could use some comedy.  Alas for my purposes none was found here.Had I not been reading this book for review as part of the Vine program, I would have put it down and walked away. Nothing is hilarious about a bunch of misfit woman feeling they need to make reparations for a grandfather who was responsible for the means to annihilate the Jews during WWII.  There is a long story here, the why, the when and in about 1/4 of this book you get the full background story.  In fact you get most of the stories of the family suicides.  Do you see my point where "Hysterical" does not cut it.All 3 woman are introverts and have issues with interacting with people.  One is good with puns and can remember her father enjoyed them as well. No one knows where he ended up.  There are a few inspired sections about word usage specifically "then" capturing the elusive nature of before and after in our world but for the most part it is a sad, sorry slog about people you just don't get.

This book does remind me of Maeve Binchys books in the way that you are made familiar with the inner workings of several characters and then they are all slowly brought into the mix of a greater story.  However this author has their own unique voice.I chuckled when I started to read however, not too many books start with a mammogram.As with some mammograms, Iris wound up with the doctor asking her to come in for subsequent tests.  That worried her.  Add to that losing her job and suddenly Iris day was not looking too stellar.  Being a fairly recent widow, having lost her husband to cancer two years prior, suddenly her future and her mortality was looking her in the face.  This prompted Iris to remember her promise to her husband, that she had stuffed in the back of her mind, unacted upon.  Luke was concerned that if anything happened to Iris, since he would be gone, their daughter Rose would be all alone in the world.  As Rose was adopted, her birth-mother was considered a form of insurance, in that instance, she might be someone for Rose to rely on in the unfortunate situation she ended up alone. Luke made Iris promise on his deathbed to find her.As we all do, when faced with crises, we overreact and Iris was not immune to that.  She immediately started a search for her daughters birth-mother and was ready to race to the end of the earth to find her and this is the story of how that went.Rose in the mean time, unaware of her mothers panic was having a crisis of her own.  Faced with a daunting masters program solo, she deliberately did not tell her mother of the date, so she would not add to her worry.  She regretted this, as she needed her reassurance, but then events unfolded that set her on a tailspin of her own.I like the way the book ended, not all wrapped up and tidy, but with pleasant possibilities at hand.  A great summer read.

Having had a holster for prior phones (Samsung S4 and HTC Incredible), Im kind of hooked on holsters.  Part of the reason I like them so much is during work, I always have a belt and a jacket on, so my phone is easy to store and essentially invisible.  When Im not at work minus the jacket and belt, the holster clips on a pocket in my purse.  I can also toss it in a fanny pack, and the screen is well protected.  That being said how did this holster do for the LG G4?  Pretty darn good.PHONE FIT IN CASE:Ease of putting phone in case: Great.  However this is a tight fit and you dont want to have to get it out in a hurry.  My prior cases were like this and I never had an issue with that unless I had to change the battery or pull a card.  Ideally this is infrequent, so I was okay with the tight fit.  The phone will NEVER fall out of this case.CASE USE WITH HOLSTER:Thankfully both case and holster are made of hard plastic (had a prior one that was rubberized...bad idea).  The phone is initially harder to pull out and push in on first usage and it gets easier over time.  I suspect there are two reasons. One the case settles in around the phone, and the holster stretches.  The other is  you learn where to grab it.CASE STAND FOR READING:A prior case I purchased would not hold up the phone to read in any orientation. This does fine in both vertical and horizontal. Mind you, if you poke the screen to page through an e-book in a vertical orientation, you might knock over the phone.  But, this is minor...at least it stays up unpoked.OTHER CONSIDERATIONS:I have a dock at home that I cannot use due to this case.  However I think that might be true due to any case, as the curve of the phone forces the shape of the case.  Also, unlike the HTC and Samsung, this phone does not have side buttons, so this case will be nice and strong on the sides.  A prior one had cutouts on the side and a drop took out a chunk.

The short version of pros and cons:POSITIVES::**** Thin and light**** Beautiful display (1376 x 768)**** Big hard drive (1TB)**** 8 GB RAM**** Battery life (supposed)  - I havent had it off power enough to know .**** Numeric keypad: Some computers this size dont have them.  Keys are smaller.**** Much speedier than a 5 year old HP, it can handle also handle tough tasks like opening multiple tabs in Firefox at once better than the HP.**** Bluetooth works nicely, I sent a photo from my phone to the laptop in approx 10 seconds.  Pairing was painless.**** Connecting a wireless mouse took a bit longer than I expected, but when it did, it added all the extra controls.  I think the delay was due to a network issue we were having not the computer.NEGATIVES:**** Feels cheap. The surface flexes when pressed on, the 5 year old HP is solid, and my work Dell even more so.  The keypad feels cheap when compared to the HP too.  Less material equals lighter weight though. You get a hollow click when you use the mouse buttons.**** Sharp edges on the outside bottom edge where your arm lays, if you are touch typer.**** Hard drive speed - only 5400 rpm, 7200 would have been nice.**** Mouse pad is not as responsive as the 5  year old HP is to a touch.  Taps go ignored at times.  It might also be a learned thing too.Other:**** Ive had problems unmuting my speakers when in Firefox, Ive found exiting FF, unmuting, then relaunching FF to work.  I dont know whats at fault - Firefox, Windows 8, the laptop, or a combination of the 3.FAST, LIGHT AND EASY TO USE:Like the average computer user, Im not an expert in laptop speeds whatever.  But, I do know what I like in equipment.  Fast, light and easy to use.This laptop seems all that.  First of all, this is my first foray into Windows 8 and its a little confusing at first, but Im glad its the 8.1.  Ive used Windows 8 on my daughters Surface tablet and was exposed to this style GUI on a Windows phone as well.  So Im hoping Windows 8 will not influence this review.  I know the later Windows 8 made accommodations to Windows 7 users, so I should be okay.OUT OF THE BOX AND SETUP:The lightness of this laptop struck me out of the box and put next to another computer (a ~5 year older HP) it is  the thickness of the older computer.  Looking at the finish it is a flat brushed black, and that also makes it look unique.The textured area around the keyboard gives it a pleasant feel, compared to the shiny ones that most laptops have.  Sometimes in warm weather my bare arms would stick on other laptop surfaces. The only negative there is the edges around the outside edge of the laptop felt a bit sharp.  Imagine sitting at a table and if you are like me, your wrists scrape across this area a lot when type (touch-typing, not hen-pecking).Start up and set up were smooth and quick. Each new computer I get does this faster and easier.  One thing that struck me odd, was that this was the first computer that did not stress creating recovery disks during setup.  Mind you, it is in the quick start guide step 3. Does anyone but me read those though? Mind you, since Windows XP, I dont think I have used my recovery disks on any computer.  We keep our virus checkers up to date and todays computers are a lot more stable.One of Toshibas advantages is that this computer does not have a whole bunch of added software.  Years ago that might have been a disadvantage, but now, many of us have our email online and our applications as well.USAGE:So far, after more than a few weeks of shared usage (my boyfriend and me), we have combined notes and feel this is a pretty good deal.  He likes Firefox and I like Chrome.  Both work well.  I like a separate mouse at times and he always uses the touch pad.  Both work okay.  He indicated the touch pad sometimes was not as responsive as he liked, but this might be a carryover from his laptop.  Time could change that.  I will update if it doesnt.The one thing I didnt like was Microsoft related.  Windows 8 has all these handy things on the start screen: Mail, Calendar, etc. and to really use any of those effectively you need to use a Microsoft account.  Mind you, this can be set up with a non-Microsoft address, but it is not so easy to figure out.  Since my primary email is Yahoo and Roadrunner and my calendar and shared documents are Google, this gets complicated really fast.  I like the way my Android phone does this a whole lot better.Some spec comparisons between this and a Dell Inspiron 15-5000 at a similar priceTOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** 5th Generation Intel Core i5-5200U 2.2 GHz ProcessorDELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** 5th Generation Intel Core i5-5200U ProcessorTOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** 8 GB DIMM RAMDELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** 8GB 2 DIMM (2x4GB) DDR3L 1600MhzTOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** 1 TB 5400 rpm Hard DriveDELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** 1TB 5400 rpm SATA Hard DriveTOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** 15.6-Inch Screen; (1366 x 768)DELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** 15.6 inch LED Backlit Display (1376 x 768)TOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** Size: 10.20 x 14.96 x 0.93 inches; Weight: 4.8 lbsDELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** Size: 10.0 x 14.9 x 0.9 inches: Weight 5.24 lbsTOSHIBA SATELLITE C55-C5240**** (2)USB 3.0 and (1)USB 2.0**** (1) SD card slot**** (1)HDMI output**** (1)Ethernet**** (1)high-speed Wireless-N connectivity**** (1)with BluetoothDELL INSPIRON 15-5000**** (2)USB 3.0 and (1)USB 2.0**** (1)Media Card (SD, SDHC, SD3.0, MS, MS Pro)**** (1)HDMI 1.4a**** (1)10/100 RJ-45 Ethernet network**** Security slot

We had an older table saw with a much smaller blade so this table saw with its bigger blade and easy storage capability had a certain amount of appeal. Having seen a Delta saw in the store with much smaller wheels, Im glad this one had the larger ones.  Much easier to move around on an uneven surface..ASSEMBLY OF FOLDABLE FRAME: PAINFULAssembling this portable saw, had you only to put together the frame that made it portable and the guards, but the process was made painful by muddy black and white pictures in the manual.The parts were all nicely labeled, but except for accounting for having them all, no attempt was made to use this labeling when it came to put the items together.  I had to look up what they called them in the spot where you accounted for them to figure this out.Also the close ups of the assembly, were so close you could not see the parts that were supposed to be assembled.  Also, at one time during assembly, we dropped a nut and panicked, because if we did not find it, we would have to stop assembly.  Im used to equipment coming with some spare parts, this one did not.  It think a few extra nuts would be appreciated.  It took a while to figure out how to fully assemble the anti-kick piece, initially.  The instructions were not handy in this regard at all.  The pictures on the box and the description in the book dont jive.IMPRESSIONS: VERSATILE AND HAS NICE STORAGEThis saw appears to have everything you could want in a table saw.  It is also clearly made to move around.  I found it quite easy to move it from a storage position to an upright and usable position and back again. (Im a woman in her late 50s)**** It tilts up to 45 degrees.**** It has two slots for its included miter gauge which is fairly common.  I liked that the miter gauge clicked in at every 15 degrees. There is a spot to store it under the left of the saw table.**** Blade raises nearly 5 inches we did not feel it was tall enough for a 4 x 4 piece of lumber though.**** Comes with a fence, like most table saws that fits nicely in place and has storage, though if you dont position it well, it will fall out. Fence can slide out the length of the right extension making the useful table size much wider.**** The wood pusher stick provided slid on its locking tabs under the table.**** The blade wrenches had a spot as well.**** There was a spot to wrap the cord with room for a longer extension cord.**** There were two table extensions: One on the rear for to support long workpieces and another on the right side to essentially make the table bigger and accommodate larger pieces of wood. The fence can attach to this.The manual makes a point of indicating that you can do the following and shows how to approach it.  This part of the manual is okay, as it uses illustrations  It even shows how to do a Dado cut by using stacked blades, but needs a special throat plate.  However the standard ones that can be done with this saw are:**** Crosscuts**** Rip cuts**** Mitered Crosscuts**** Beveled Crosscuts**** Beveled Ripcuts**** Compound Miter cutsPROJECTS:At this time we only had one project to do, so only used it to do simple lumber cuts, essentially all crosscuts. The table extension helped on the long lumber and the fence was nice to push the wood along.  We used a clamp we had to help secure the straightness.  We have not done any angled cuts yet or any ripping, but this saw seems to have the goods.  Wish I had it a few years ago, when I made a table.

First of all the book description and what I read did not jive as much as I prefer.  My expectations were much different. A full 2/3rds of the book had me waiting for detailed talk of cooking, recipes or ingredients.  While there was some discussion of this as part of the story, it was more hidden in context of the story.  For instance the chapter called Chocolate Habaneros was more about the child Eva growing them hydroponically in her closet and then  using them as the ultimate weapon against some bullies.The main character Eva, is followed throughout the book but is not always who the story is about.  She is often described by the main character, the chapter is about.  In fact in one chapter, she is a distant judge in a competition. In some cases you have prior knowledge of the character the story is centered on, but in others they are minor characters that you really never see until much later.  The character development is interesting and sad in some cases and you see how many people can influence another persons life.Ultimately this was not the book I expected.  A fan of food-based or recipe-centered books, I expected more content about what the character was enthusiastic about.  Having read Ruth Reichls recent novel: Delicious, this was more my expectation.Stepping aside from expectations and considering the book on its own merits as a coming-of-age book about a young womans life, it too was lacking.  She was on the periphery of too many of the chapters.  You see her motivations as a young child, but she is portrayed as this magical fairy sort of person that has had a rough life.
