You never really see the growth of the Eva character.  Its all about the food, in many technical artsy ways.  Many of the other characters are developed full, you see their inside story from Jordy to Pat.  In fact in each chapter, these characters form a short story of their own and there is some food aspect to each, but it is not Evas story.It was an interesting read but the description of the book should be redone.

The premise of this book is that several people are having a hard time with their life and see an ad for a cottage in Maine that sounds enchanting.  It is an opportunity to get away from it all for a month in August.  The 4 of them decide they need it.  However this cottage has the reputation for being what people need to get their life back on track.  Rarely do people come back, as they find resolution.  Maybe this year it will include the owner.This years line-up is:**** Lottie, whos husbands job as an attorney in an aggressive firm seems to be drawing him further and further away from her and they are practically only roommates.**** Rose, whose fellow writer husband has achieved critical acclaim only for a book hes written under a pseudonym.  Her own career has been put on hold for his and their young children.  She is struggling with the children and her own lack of ability to get back into her writing.  In the meantime her husband is drifting into temptation.**** Catherine, once an A-list actress is living in shame due to a minor gaffe at an awards ceremony.  She feels all who see her, only see that.  A nice getaway may help recharge her batteries.**** Beverly, whos partner and beloved cat has passed, has let life and happiness drift by and is not dealing with financial responsibilities or duties as well as they should.**** Robert, the owner of the cottage, has hoped the cottage might work for him as well.  He is smitten with Rose when she rents the cottage and hopes something might kindle there.I found this story enchanting.  Everyone is so introspective of their own issues and sees those of others on the periphery, but are considerate in the process.  They all grow and discover the life on the island and start to redefine themselves in the process.  There are several undercurrents and twists and potential issues.Its a fun pleasant story.

I opted to get this faucet for several reasons.**** It incorporates the spray hose into the faucet, I wanted one of those**** It has two settings, one more typical faucet and one more typical spray hose.  Switch is on the spray head**** Design of this faucet is curvy and in keeping with the design of my hot water dispenser that I just replaced. If you have an ultra modern very angular kitchen design this may be too curvy for you.It was a bonus that this sink had a touch feature.  I was not quite sure what I thought of that, but I had an open mind.OUT OF THE BOX:Lots of parts but all well labeled.  Looked like a great installation booklet.  Came with a cover for a 3-holed faucet that we didnt need, but kept as we will need it for another faucet in another location.INSTALLATION:I had a friend who does this sort of stuff for a living install the faucet for me and my boyfriend, as my knees and his back were not up to it.  You see with putting in a new faucet we just had to have a new sink and since we had a hot water dispenser and a garbage disposal, dis-assembly was going to take a while.  It if was the faucet alone we could have done it.From the guy that put the faucet in, while we watched: Instructions were great, more pictures than words.  The illustrated pictures were clear and easy to understand.  This is in great contrast to another assembly situation we found ourselves in earlier this week, where black and white pictures were substituted.  Their pictures had too much in them and were too muddy to make out the detail of what to do.  These instructions were wonderful.The only negative comment, the installer had was that batteries for touch capability seem overlarge.  6 AA batteries in holder take up a lot of room in a tight space.  You would think an alternative could be smallerAlso the other potential point of confusion, though it was sort of spelled out in the manual, the wire (that looks like a ground wire) must be attached as shown in the diagram, no other way.  Our friend (who had never put this type of faucet in before) put it on another piece of tubing, assuming it was a ground wire and the faucet initially did not function properly.  When he was wondering what was wrong, I pored over the manual and said, I dont think that was a ground wire.  All works great now.We also due to a close windowsill did not install the faucet with the handle on the right. If we did that, it would be restricted in its movement.  Instead the handle is facing forward so the LCD is on the left.  The LCD shows what the water temp is.  If you have the touch feature working (by leaving the tap handle open), you need to know what to expect.USAGE:Leaving the faucet on, a tap on the neck or tap handle stops it.  Tapping again turns it on.  Touching the spray head does nothing so it works without interruption while spraying.  This evening, I cooked with raw meat and onions and when I schooled myself to touch the faucet, it was great.  Takes a bit to get used to.  You need to also leave the faucet open to the temperature you want.  An LCD light shows the anticipated temp.  Blue for cold, Red for hot.  Using the integrated spray will take more experience.  My old sprayer however was constantly sticking and had to be pushed back into the sink, so the bar to meet is not too high there.  One thing I had been concerned about, was would the spray handle reach the Keurig tank next to the sink as it has to go sideways and up...It does.INITIAL OVERALL OPINION OF THIS FAUCET:I really like it and found the touch feature is something I use a lot more that I would have expected.  The only negative with the touch feature is when you are cleaning the sink.  I found I kept touching the faucet as I was cleaning the back of sink, so the water was going on and off.So far the cats have not figured it out, so I leave it on a lot.I will update this review as I do more.

This book starts out well and then devolves into advice after advice after advice.The author is a good writer and the book seems well organized, but after a while it seemed like I was plodding through it, going from one story to another.  The author sprinkles the story with a bit of her own history, which livens it up a bit, but after a while it is all so repetitive.While Im not personally anticipating a wedding my son is and I thought this book would give him and his fiance some good advice, but by 2/3s of the way through, it was not something I think they would find interesting.There are several sections in this book:**** Dating**** Commitment**** Breakups**** Weddings**** Making it lastIN BREAKUPSOne thing I found appalling was advice for the brokenhearted and suggesting a rebound relationship.  This does not consider they would be potentially wounding another person and seemed horribly self-serving.IN WEDDINGSOver and over I keep hearing make it  your way, you need to put your stamp on things, but gives only extreme cases such as a goth wedding.  Nothing as simple as the bride choosing the best man and the groom the maid of honor.  Or a cheesecake wedding cake. Sometimes people are at a loss as the subtle level of personalizing.MAKING IT LAST:This section impressed me the most.  She makes a good point about not romanticizing the WWII era relationships when we hear of them happily reaching 60 years.  There are a lot more relationships that didnt.  Divorce-stigma and women not being self supporting played a big part in that and many people in abusive relationships stayed but not because they wanted to.  The bottom line is to dont have such high expectations for marriage.  There will be rough times and it is how you work through that, that defines you more.Overall it was a good book, but, not unique or organized enough to give it a high rating.

Owning a multitude of digital cameras (I mean a real lot) and having a video cam and a sport cam that can go underwater, this is my first action cam made to capture live motion.  I was not sure what made it unique, now I know The remote and the app as well as the size of the camera.SUMMARY:PRO:**** Camera is small due to the lack of live display that can be on the remote or cell phone based**** Smooth recording and playback**** Great sound**** Nice available SW for video manipulation**** Camera shape may make this more secure for a head mounted display than a more traditional camera shape.CON:**** Shape of camera is longitudinal, so cant be flat against a persons chest.FUNCTIONAL EQUIPMENTWell for one thing it is smaller than a deck of cards a bit bigger than  a deck actually.  It comes in a plastic case that still enables you to press the buttons (as there are only 3 buttons and a switch, thats easy).  The case is a snug fit that makes it water-proof to 10 feet. It has a rechargeable separate battery that charges using a USB. Looks like a standard B USB end.The camera uses a micro-SDHC and comes with a 64MB card.This camera has 8 selections in the menu: You can see the specs. on the site, so I wont repeat them here;**** Movie**** Photo**** Interval**** Live**** Setup**** Play**** Power Off**** LoopThere is a wristband with integrated display(Live view remote), that you can control the camera remotely.  This makes it so slick and helps make the camera as small as it is.  You have a power on/off, and the same 3 buttons on the camera, so you can remotely control the camera. In addition you have a display and menu button  unique to this display.  The wristband will fit the meatiest wrist and has a wide rubber band that even when sweating, it wont slip.Some adhesive mounts (3) are included with the camera itself.First of all the plethora of accessories floored me.  This is is really made to stick to something, wear or attach to your head. The quantity may be due to this being a set made for review.  All Im sure can be purchased separately. The only real lack that occurred to me was that due to its shape, it could not be worn against your chest. With its longitudinal axis, the camera eye is on the end of the rectangle instead of the flat center of it. But on side of a helmet it might be less prone to damage versus sticking on top of one.**** Universal head mount**** Suction cup mountOUT OF THE BOXI found when I opened the package and started to charge everything that needed charging, that they were 75% charged already.  The camera battery is a separate one, but the wristband battery is an integrated piece. Both use a USB cable to charge.  The 64GB micro USB has to be put in the camera.  The sleeve for a regular SD slot is included.Once you have everything charged, you sync the camera to the Liveview remote.  What is also cool is there is a downloadable app that can be put on your smartphone to be used like the remote. Both synced smoothly.Starting up the camera and remote, I can see when they are syncing (5 seconds or so) and the next thing you know you have a live feed from the camera.  What struck me was the smooth display.  I was tempted to attach the camera to my cat, to see his perspective, but it really is too big.  A large dog could be a different story. Also for me to see the display, I dont know how far away he can wander before I lose the WiFi.SOFTWARE:On the startup guide you are recommended to go to Sonys website and download the PC software dedicated to the camera: Action Cam Movie Creator.  Using this in conjunction with Sonys  Play Memories Home you end up with a great combo of applications on your computer.  I had already had Sonys  Play Memories Home after the purchase of a Sony point and shoot camera a few years ago and liked the ease to transfer files.  Im sure you dont have to use that, but just indicated what I had.  For that matter you could use the microSD card to transfer.  However I tend to leave those little ones put, to avoid breaking them. However the Action Cam Movie Creator is the secret to manipulate your movies files in a variety of ways.INITIAL MOVIE:After everything was together, I briefly used the camera to walk around the house and take an untethered movie by holding the camera and wristband separately.  When I downloaded the movie, the smoothness of the play and the sound was great.  The SW allowed me to make some shorter videos.  Soon I will have a biking movie and a few kayaking ones.A CO-WORKERS USE OF THIS CAMERA:I lent this camera to a co-worker of mine who regularly walks his dog, by riding his bike.  He wanted to do a better than cell phone version of the process.  He had several complaints about this camera, mostly about the form factor.  If the camera were cylindrical or more camera like, a Go-Pro, he would have liked it better.  It could have been mounted on his chest or front of his helmet.  He wore the headset and felt really dorky.  He called it a shark fin.  Also he complained about no easy way to attach the camera to handle bars.  This maybe because it was not his camera and he was not going to duct tape it as he has done prior ones.  Also as far as the remote, on a bike he felt the width of the wrist strap was too wide on a bent wrist, and the positioning of the screen not suitable.  This was in a upright position, in a streamlined crouched position, he felt he could not get the screen view-able at all.  He was wondering if there was a way to widen or do a macro view, so you could see more off to the side and there was not, that he could see. For a dog off to the side this would have been nicer.  Instead he said the tighter angle would have been great for a bike race, something he gave up a year ago. Overall he gave the camera for his purposes (on bike or helmet) a thumbs down.

When I read the description of this book, I thought it sounded magical.  It did not disappoint.Perdu a Paris book seller has a unique venue.  He sells books from a boat.  Besides that he prescribes them, based on what he feels the reader needs.  This can be met with some opposition, but once the reader takes his advice, they keep coming back.  Perdu finds some comfort in books himself and has searched for an author of a unique book that has helped him, to no avail.Until Catherine moves into his building Perdu lives a spare life with little else.  However there is a room in his apartment that is never opened.  When he decides to give Catherine a table stored in this unopened room, old feelings are jarred and an unopened letter is found. When Catherine insists he open this old letter, this shakes Perdu to the core and this sets many events in motion. He decides the half life he has lead due to events in the past, needs closure and then an adventure begins.Im tiptoeing on not telling you too much.  This book is unique and anyone who has found answers in books can relate.  I really enjoyed the descriptions of the French countryside and the emotions described in the book.  We all experience things different from others and this book captures this well.  I may well read this book a second time as I enjoyed it so much.

I opted for this program in hope of restarting my exercise routine.  Sadly Im not ready for it.  Im going to have to ease into this, or abandon it. The reason this exercise is such an issue is two problems I have: damaged knees, so squatting and lunges are very limited and damage to my elbows (from using a pickax) so that push-ups are very challenging.  If these are not issues for you, this exercise routine may not be a problem. The rest and recovery sessions are mostly rolling out your legs with the foam roller and stretching using the strap.  No issue with those, but they are not the point of this set of DVDs.  A yoga class would address this as well.BACKGROUND:Im a 58 year old overweight woman, who has a sedentary job, though I do pilates, yoga, elliptical, line dancing and couples dancing every week. Outdoor hobbies are gardening, hiking and kayaking. Oh yes and babysitting grandkids, thats the hardest work of all.  So at home I am not sedentary, but far from a fit 20 year old and I do not do exercises everyday. Im most likely not the target audience.EQUIPMENT:**** 1 (5 pound) yellow kettlebell. (4 sizes shown in video, yellow, red, orange, blue)**** foam roller**** stretching strap (could substitute a yoga strap if needed)Note: several exercises  use 2 kettlebells and they use a round matt throughout. Rest and recovery rejuvenation uses a typical yoga mat (not included) and indicates taller people might use a longer foam rollerThere are also ads for equipment and supplements as well as a small meal plan booklet.DVDs provided:**** Introduction**** CARDIO: incinerate the fat**** CORE:  ripped to the core**** RESISTANCE: force the energy**** Supercharged CORE: elevate your strength**** Supercharged LOWER BODY: experience the intensity**** Supercharged UPPER BODY: feel the burn**** MUSCLE PREVENTION & RECOVERY with Rejuvenation (I got 2 identical DVDs of this)You get a chart of recommended exercises for each of 56 days. Pace and duration is implied in each set of exercises. The 2nd set of exercises each day (supercharged) are 10 minutes longer for those that are motivated.  Otherwise each days routine is 20 minutes long.  3 times a week, however there is a rest and rejuvenation routine.Example of first week:Day 1: Basic Resistance strike, Supercharged Core BurnDay 2: Rest and Recovery, RejuvenationDay 3: Basic Core Rock, Supercharged Lower Body BurnDay 4: Rest and Recovery, RejuvenationDay 5: Basic Cardio Ignite, Supercharged Upper Body BurnDay 6: Supercharged Core BurnDay 7: Rest and Recovery, RejuvenationThe type of exercises included for the Day 1 and Day 2:Day 1: Basic Resistance strike (issues with knees and elbows)**** Squat with upright row (tough on my knees)**** Lunge and overhead press (tough on my knees)**** Renegade row**** Offset push up (hard on elbows)****  Figure 8 with a bicep curl (easy to drop kettlebell)Day 1: Supercharged Core Burn (if you do pilates, can do this, but one balance move)**** Crunch with kettlebell to chest**** Twisting crunch with leg extension**** Floating half moon (balance)**** Bridge with kettlebell on pelvis**** Twist with a kettlebell punchDay 2: Rest and Recovery, Rejuvenation (music with this is not relaxing, but too loud & intense)Separated into equipment typesFoam roller:**** glute (butt)**** hamstring (back of leg)**** it band (outside of leg)**** quad (front of leg)Stretch strap: all of these are yoga derived**** hamstring (back of leg stretch)**** adductor (inside of leg stretch)**** abductor (outside of leg stretch)**** glute (butt stretch) really did not emphasize holding ankle straight, potential for knee damage**** quad (front of leg stretch)Overall, this strikes as an aggressive aerobic based workout, that might get results but also might make you ache.  I tend to prefer pilates and yoga for the lack of ache, but Ill not likely ever get a six pack that way.  Pick your poison.  For a busy young person this might be quite the routine as it is brief and doable at home.  For me the potential for ache and even damage is too great.

Georgia is imagining a wedding to the man she loves back at her parents idyllic winery.  Unfortunately all is not what it seems.  During her dress fitting she observes something that sets her world askew and decides to run home, to sort out her thoughts.However at home all it not warm and cozy.  Her parents have some surprising news and her two brother's seem equally unsettled.This is a fun read.  I had a hard time putting the book down.  The ups and downs, the indecision.  Family life at it's finest and the ending, while not a complete surprise while reading the book is certainly a twist unanticipated.I like the author's sense of action and introspection.  You see what drives Georgia's thoughts.  While at times there are things unsaid, you see what the character's conclusions are.  An enjoyable book.

The first third of this book is the authors recounting of all of the issues she has had due to this gap in her brain. Essentially her life has been a trainwreck.  Shes had issues with some very basic stuff: crossing the street, managing her time, keeping paperwork straight and navigating.  She loses a lot of jobs, that require these basic skills and luckily has her parents as back up.  It gets really slow, as she cites all her work and personal life screw-ups. I think she attempted to relay her frustration, but it feels so detached.  She talks further about the testing she goes through to understand what is causing these issues and is somewhat dispassionately plugging along through this.  What struck me is that many of her associates and family members had mental issues of their own. Her father is considered to have Aspergers, but that doesnt excuse some of the jerky things that he does.  He teaches ethics but seems not very ethical or considerate.  In fact it seems his students think so as well.About mid book things pick up and the author starts college and finds her tribe in some sense.  She has some close friends and boyfriend.  At some point she got some good advice and found she was eligible for federal aid as a disabled person and went through the convoluted testing process required to establish this.  The book starts to pick up and you can see the author is struggling with trying to cope and also since categorized as disabled realizing that this is who she now is and dealing with that.  Her writing is excellent.  I think the first part of the books suffers from trying to be too matter of fact and that is not her strong suit.  She has issues apparently with time and this may have affected her ability to keep a play by play narrative with some life in it.The latter part of her book chronicles her issues with her boyfriend and landing a job she likes.  There are still issues and she is struggling to be a person with an invisible handicap.  In fact if you think about, as you are reading this book you might wonder, how is this person handicapped, as she writes so well?  That unfortunately would be the painful assumption others have made about her.  Unlike many of us who go to the doctor for diagnosis, there is some sort of resolution on the other end.  In the authors case, it is just an explanation of her issues and except for few attempts to help her cope she seems on her own to come up with strategies to improve her lot.  At this point it is familiar and will color everything she does and every relationship she has.  She is correctly considered as handicapped, but it would be nice to see that she was offered more coping mechanisms in any counseling she received.

I hesitated getting this book over concern for being sad over the subject matter.  I was wrong to do that.  It is a book about life, not death and that makes it wonderful.Scott Simon, the author did not not have a traditional life, having grown up not only in a mixed religious family, his family was broken by the days standards. However I would bet, he would not trade it for anything.His Mom is dying and in her last days in the hospital she and her son reminisce about their shared past. The author tweeted some of this while experiencing this and has included this in the book so you get a sense of immediacy while reading, like it is still just happening.Rather than hide some of the awkwardness of his past (an alcoholic father) and some promiscuity by his Mother and grandmother (relative to the days mores) he puts it all out there and shares the love that he was surrounded by.  He and is Mom were right in the middle of the hot society of the day and were surrounded by kindred souls that made life interesting. Family is not always just the people you are related to.The only part of this book that bothered me, was when the Mom talked of her own Moms suicide and how it marred her as a grown adult. Her son is solicitous and concerned. She never acknowledges to her son, for nearly following in her Mothers foot steps, in a worst way when he was still quite young.  Her own attempt is mentioned earlier in the book and revolves around an impossible relationship at the time. It would have left her son homeless and alone at the time and I found it appalling and selfish.While I appreciate his Mom for the free spirit she was and it sound like she had a bit of style and class.  She appreciated people who worked hard like she did.  Conventional she was not.  While expensive Thank you notes, a nice table with place cards is quite formal,  her young son saw a lot of nightlife and was around some less than conventional situations. .  Some people, certainly in that time frame might have been very critical.  however it may well have made her son the man he is today.  As a journalist a critical and observant eye are necessary and flexibility is an advantage as well. A more conventional life might have made him limited.The author also captures the hardworking office staff, nurses, aides even janitors.  He was less than complimentary on the doctors who were elusive at best.  As I have had an elderly parent in the hospital, I too have noticed they tend to direct from a distance. Reading a lot of medical oriented books, you get the false sense that the interns, doctors and patients get chummy, but the reality is, that is long before they become a specialist.Overall, this book was hard to put down and a true celebration of the authors mothers life.  A fitting tribute.

It is really hard to imagine that transition of book knowledge to clinical, where a person goes from taking in the information, to applying it to people.  Not being in a medical field, I cant imagine this, but this book gets you closer.  It also gives you a feeling for the insecurity associated with that experience as well. As inexperienced people are reeling with concern for being able to provide quality care, concern for making a mistake and dealing with real patients, they are also subjected to 30 hours straight of work for several days.  A side note: This staggers me, with all the studies showing that fatigue increases errors, we still allow interns to be put through this gauntlet, still.  We have laws for truckers, so it would seem it would not be unreasonable to do the same for the people that literally have our health in their hands.  But, that is not what this book is about.Matt the author opted out of a minor league baseball career and decided medicine was where is next challenge should be.  An interesting choice, but thankfully he is a good writer and documented his seminal first year.  From learning how to stitch a banana, to assisting in the operating room, he rotated through cardiology, intensive care, infectious care (not what its called) and several other twists as well. We see him begin to mature while learning under some very different supervisory styles.  It is good that many of the people that he dealt with really shared useful ways of working from faking it till you make it, to all the anagrams to remember what is important.  The one thing that stood out to me was a statement another doctor made to him, that when you think about is chilling.  The other doctor said you have to decide who you are watching out for; Yourself or the Patient?  This prompted him to report an accidental needle stick in a patients bladder, that prior to thinking this through he was contemplating ignoring this, which could have potentially lead to infection for the patient.  How many others when learning opt to forget mistakes that cause patient issues or worse, to cover their own hide?This book is definitely an insiders look of what goes on during the first year.. Its entertaining, scary and sad at the same time.  Well written, Im sure the author has a few more in his future and Ill be waiting for them.

Having recently purchased an ipad air, I wanted to pair it with a keyboard and Im happy to say this keyboard is everything you could want in a keyboard.It is secure, no chance of my ipad air falling out.All the pertinent buttons: volume, display and power are accessible.It solidly stays in keyboard position, even when on one knee or held with one handIt allows for use as a tablet with the keyboard nicely folded in.The keyboard is metal and solid and secure. Pairing was dicey at first, but once charged, no problem. In use it was seamless and everything I wanted. The only extra I could want was a touch pad on the keyboard, but from what I understand that is not possible on an ipad.The keyboard is small, but works, well. You open the keyboard up, the ipad display turns on, you close it the ipad turns off. The magnetics keep the display solidly in position. When closed the metal keyboard protects your display.If apple designed it, it couldnt be better.

This is my 5th Patrick Lee book.  Having started with Ghost country and its prequel the Breach, I continued on to Deep sky the last of that series and then the first of the Sam Dryden series; Runner.I think given, I am on his 5th book, it is clear I like this authors approach to writing and his Sci-Fi subject matter appeals to me.  My preferences are unimportant to you, but I will give you my logic, to see if you agree.Why do I keep coming back?For one I have a hard time putting the books down.  Similar to Dan Brown of the DaVinci code fame, his chapters are short and to the point and progress you forward.  Sometimes you see whats coming and other times you are blindsided, as is the main character.  It gets  your mind moving.It is real science? Um no, not exactly and the world is a safer place for it.  Is it conceivable?  Absolutely, so you can imagine this kind of stuff happening.  All good SciFi asks you to suspend disbelief and go along with the author.  If that trip is too far, you are grimacing in discomfort.  If it only pushes the edge a bit and just that bit further, you are sucked in.  Similar to David Brin of The Postman fame and Uplift series, you get educated along the way in in what you need to know and its not work, to understand the technology of the book. In comparison, I just finished anothers authors book and he felt the need to overdevelop characters and give too many technological explanations, so instead of a 300 page book it was 1200 pages.  You will not find that here.  The writing is tight, fun and to the point.Now...you want to know a bit about the story? I have to be careful not to ruin it.  Sam Dryden is a former special-ops guy.  He gets contacted by an old friend in distress. Claire asks him to join her in a wild ride across the state and is very paranoid about anyone knowing where he is going.  She is anxious and pretty closed-mouth about what is going on.  When they save some young people at the brink of dying; Sam wonders how their timing could be so impeccable and how Claire knew this was going to happen?  What she tells him is so far out-there he does not believe her until she demonstrates.  Later he finds out why she recruited him and that blows his mind even further.  And here the story begins.

This book interested me on a few levels.  One being female in a technical field, Im very much aware of womens roles changing over the years.  Spinster is an old term, so I wanted to see how this was approached in this day and age.The author a sporadic spinster discusses her own life and that of some women from the past, all authors or artists that have lived a solo or at least partially solo life.  She goes into a bit of detail on 5 of them (author: Edna Millay, essayist: Maeve Brennan, columnist: Neith Boyce, novelist: Edith Wharton and social visionary: Charlotte Perkins Gilman).  These are pertinent, as they lived, what would be considered as spinsters by choice.She talks of the aspirations of women in the past relative to men and how it was assumed most women anticipated marriage as the more desirable option. Living as a solo person financially was often not available to those without independent resources, as women in general were always expected to be dependent on a man, thus their lower wages were justified (stomach burns as I type this).  The few women that pursued the single life had to fight to be considered seriously (while bachelors were lauded) and only the wealthy did so with style.Skip forward a few generations and women living alone still have issues with the finances of living alone (sadly for the same reasons), but the boarding houses for single women no longer exist. As an aside, I found out years ago when I visited Japan, that they have this equivalent, so single women can afford housing in the cities there).The author speaks of her on again and off again pursuit of spinsterhood and you can  understand her logic.  Alone you think different than when you are part of a couple.  Different plans, different outlook. I get this.  As a writer whose work is made up mostly of thoughts and ideas this can certainly change your craft as well. However, Im not sure I would consider the author a spinster.  Her dating was more on the serious side and not as widespread as to discourage assumptions of leading to marriage (as were some of her historical examples, though some did get married).  She on two occasions walked out of relationships that the men felt on the brink of marriage as did their families.  I think most of us consider the philosophy of living alone and not being in a serious relationship as the definition of spinsterhood.  So her lifestyle was for the most part not spinsterish by that definition..Overall the book is interesting. Its funny to think that years ago, this was on the horizon and it still seems to be, but the numbers now would seem to support it.  However I wonder how many women are single (like myself) but living with someone (also like me), which I dont think fulfills the true role of the spinster. I think people have eschewed the formalities but still tend to pair up to a certain extent.

I got this little dust buster with some trepidation.  Having used a pet hair vacuum with a cord that I was less than impressed with, how could a cordless do any better?  Well, it does and it doesnt.  I have 4 cats, so I can speak to how it handled cat  hair.  Dog people, youre on your own.  Dog hair is longer and more wiry (my observation when I had labs).SUMMARY:ProOkay on non-embedded cat hair, not greatGreat for car vacuum (pine needles and croissant crumbs)Keeps stuff in the vacuumNice to empty, easily cleanable.ConPower button is easy to constantly hit and turn off during usageCant touch embedded hair (but what can?)MECHANICS:Essentially you have three ways to use this.  without any attachments, with a nubby rubberized wide attachment and with a nozzle attachment that has a brush slide down.One thing I noticed on this vacuum is that it has a little door in it, that when it is vacuuming in, it opens and when items are in the vacuum they get trapped behind this door.  I have had other vacuums when turned off allowed the previously vacuumed stuff to fall out.  This resolves that.Emptying this vacuum was decent.  It was easy to open and the parts came apart nicely to clean off.During use this vacuums power button is unfortunately in a lousy location.  The one problem I had with it, was constantly turning it off.Power from the charge was plenty to clean my car, so would probably be okay around the house.VACUUMING PET HAIRFor the cat hair on their cat tree and in their cat beds.  As this is embedded, I didnt hold much hope and was not surprised when this was barely touched.  Usually on the washable beds I take an old bristle brush to scrub off the cat hair, before I wash the cat bed.  This requires a real manual effort and that nubby attachment is not rough enough to do this.  Also being at the end of a vacuum, you have no mechanical advantage to scrub it around.For the cat hair on other items like a cloth covered chair or futon.  This vacuum worked well.  The nubby end released the hair from the fabric nicely.GREAT AS A CAR VACUUMWhat I found this vacuum worked really great for, was in my car.  I have pine trees all around my house and I get pine needles in the car all the time.  This did a great job on that and the little door kept them in the vacuum.  It also did a great job on the croissant crumbs I got all over the front seat (a guilty pleasure as Im driving to see my Mom in a nursing home every Saturday).

I had opted to get this book, because I thought it would be more a personal story, or biography and how outside events affected the peoples day-to-day lives.In reading this book, I was given a lot of historical facts about the events around the personal story.  In fact the book was 70% history, 30% biography. However, I still do not understand fully why the family moved to Pakistan from India, as it seemed their community was intact there and the grandfather was being offered a position of honor.  Clearly the family was given the impression that it would be better to live in a country, that was more dominated by Muslims.Later in the book they discussed what it took to be considered a native. It would seem people that were born in that country had all the advantages, but you were only considered a native, if that went back enough generations (about 3).  With that mindset most of the US would still be considered as immigrants.  Unlike the US this greatly influenced schooling opportunities and jobs.  Amazing.I would have liked more of a story of the family  this book was centered around and less history.However, this book was eye opening.  I have had several colleagues from India telling me about what it was like to live there, but only recently a female colleague and I was appalled to realize the difference between a mans life and that of a woman, and that is India.  In Pakistan due to being a country dominated by Islam, it is even more different.  Imagine living in a country where you are considered only  that of another person and that is due to your gender.  You can have the same pedigree as your spouse and he can still treat you like property.  I cant imagine what it is like in the workplace, when the home life is like this.  Im utterly mystified then how Benazir Bhutto ever came to power.  They sort of addressed this in the book, but not really.  It would seem the politics in the country are really that corrupt.The final chapter in the personal story was heartbreaking.  Aminas angst over the 2nd wife dominated her life and her husbands comments to her in the end regarding this, made this even worse.  The bottom line in this relationship is that she had no choice.  His control was complete.This is maddening and unfortunately in this country this is not getting any better.

A friend of mine lent me this book as she knew of my interest in wine.  So over the course of several months, at lunch time (or waiting for my computer to boot up), I read a little bit each day.While how I read it, is of little interest to you, it shows that you can read it nicely in small bites.Having read another wine book, it was not easily digested in small sets of reading, so this was a nice feature.This book first of all dated~2002, is well...dated, so some varieties of wines have changed. But, lets face it, wines been around a long time, so the fundamentals are intact.  The author nicely covers a whole bunch of things in small groupings.The chapters:*** Introduction*** Tools of the trade*** Its all about flavor*** Taste the earth*** Sugar, Sugar*** Firewater*** Getting Wood*** Fiddling Around*** Old verus New*** Tall, Dark & Handsome*** Posh Wines*** Party Wines*** Froth & Bubble*** Pensioned Off*** Altered States*** Wines your Granny Drinks*** Coming Back to your Roots*** IndexYou can see from the titles the first 8 chapters set you up with the lingo. However in each of these chapters, there is a section called Drinking it, that addresses the chapter covered.  The next 9 chapters about specific aspect of wines.I found this book very pleasant to read bit by bit and I have to say I also learned something in the process.

This biography of Shannon Miller is just that.  The author/co-writer gives you all the facts and figures, all the stats and details of this amazing gymnast.  Her fortitude to train for 3 Olympics, though only making it to 2 and subsequent cancer diagnosis and recovery.  The writing is good and flows from one point to another.  Shannon clearly owns her successes and mistakes.  90% of the book is about Shannon the gymnast; 10% about the cancer survivor.My above paragraph is devoid of sentiment and merely states the content of the book. Similarly I felt this book lacked emotion.  It was a recounting of an amazing past without the associated emotion.  After reading this book, I went to youtube to see some of the videos of her performances and was taken back to the Olympics I watched at the time.  I remember looking at a tiny emotionless girl.  She had the most amazing skills yet, kept all her pride and joy locked inside.  This is an amazing woman.  Unfortunately the title of the book captures the conundrum of the book, "It's not about Perfect". I really felt in what I read, is that it is "all about perfect".  I feel she has not allowed herself to enjoy what she has done but has punished herself for what she did not do.  Sadly that might the case for many of these athletes that push against an impossible bar.  How many get injured or age out and never make it this far. While reading this I kept on thinking; "If only".Please do not let this discourage from reading this. It really is an amazing story from a  young girl that truly wanted to be perfect.  Little does she realize that she achieved that.  "Perfect is in the trying".

Dollar for Dollar, if you are in the market for an inexpensive smartphone, this would not be a bad one for an entry level.  If you are used to Samsung, it might disappoint, but your pocket will be fuller.IN THE BOX:Phone, charging cable with ability to separate USB from plug, screen protector, rubberized case and headphones.Also a tool to put the SIM card in place.  Manual in 3 languages (English is the 3rd language).SETUP:Owning a Samsung S4 and this being my 2nd Android phone, I was stunned with the ease of the setup.  Put in the code for my wireless, added my google account and everything was added from my previous phone, apps, contacts the works.  Of course this does not include the pictures on the card, or in the phone.  However having gone through setups in the past, none have gone this smoothly.NO CELL PLAN YET:At this time, I don't have a cell plan for this phone, since I am on Verizon and this phone in incompatible.  I plan to get a pay as you go account for it, through AT&T (due to connectivity issues in areas of the Adirondacks) and haven't researched that yet. However I have it hooked to wireless at home and it works quite nicelySCREEN & BUTTON DIFFERENCES:Since I'm familiar with the S4 and a bit with the S5, the screens through me a bit on this.  Power button is on the left near the volume button. However there does not seem to be the ability to do shortcuts on the home screen.  Makes it a bit of a mess but everything is right there.SPECS:Given, I should not compare this to the older S4 that I have, but instead the S5, here are some of the differences:  Clearly the Samsung wins at specsmanship.  But at a ~$480 to the BLU's $199, it should. A price difference $281 justifies it. But the BLU is lighter and slightly smaller.BLU VIVO AIR: 5.5 x 2.6 x 0.2 inches ; 3.2 ouncesSAMSUNG S5: 5.59 x 2.97 x 0.32 inches ; 5.1 ouncesBLU VIVO AIR: BACK CAMERA: 8MPSAMSUNG S5: BACK CAMERA: 16 MPBLU VIVO AIR: FRONT CAMERA: 5MP 88 degree wide angleSAMSUNG S5: FRONT CAMERA: 2MP wide angleBLU VIVO AIR: 1.7 GHz Octa-core processorSAMSUNG S5: 2.5GHz Quad core processorBLU VIVO AIR: RAM: 1GBSAMSUNG S5: RAM : 2GBBLU VIVO AIR: 4.8" HD Super AMOLED  (720 x 1280) 306 ppiSAMSUNG S5: 5.1" FHD Super AMOLED (1920 x 1080) 432 ppiBLU VIVO AIR: Battery is 2100 mAh non-removable. This gives me pause.SAMSUNG S5: 2800mAh removableBLU VIVO AIR:  16 GB internal storage with no SD card expansionSAMSUNG S5: 16/32GB User Memory + microSD slot (up to 128GB)POINT OF COMPARISON:At this stage I have had a Samsung S4 for greater than 2 years.  I'm eligible for a new phone, but since I'm on Verizon, I'm not able to put this phone on my plan. Would I if I could? No. It is comparable in size to my S4, but smaller than the S5.  I was thinking of going a bit larger.  The price by far is cheaper than the S5 (see specs above), but I'm holding out for the Note 4 or the Samsung Galaxy S6 for my next phone.ACCESSORIES:There seem to be a lot of accessories on Amazon for this phone, wallets, cases, etc.  But, there do not seem to be any hard plastic vertical belt holsters.  This is something I prefer and I don't know why I have not found any.  They have horizontal folding wallet ones, plain plastic ones,  but no plastic ones with a clip, as yet, that I see.  Maybe this is limited to the larger manufacturers or it is too soon.This is not my review, but one I read on this phone after I had it for awhile: http://pocketnow.com/2015/02/21/blu-vivo-air-review

I always like cooking-related books, so I was a shoe-in for getting this one.  Then while reading it, I discovered one of the authors was the same that authored two other books, I already owned. Cool!Pam, Sharon and Maggie (or is it Maggy, inside joke) are a Mom and 2 daughters all talking about a shared love: Cooking and especially sharing a meal with family and friends.  There is some backstory, some biography and some recipes that factor in each.  You see how each has gotten into cooking; some earlier, some later and how it all gels (or not) when they get together.All together makes it an enjoyable book to read.The recipes included are pivotal to the stories within.The two books I have How to cook without a book and Perfect Recipes by Pam Anderson have sat on my shelf for some time.  One is a cookbook I have consulted on several occasions, another is a philosophy of cooking style cookbook.  The thought process being that if you learn some basics you can be less reliant on cookbooks.  Im making an effort to read and review this once, I have finished this book.  I will look at the more traditional cookbook as well.

Shirley Maclaine, is of course unique and if you have read some of her other books she has some interesting observations and has indicated she has had visions or dreams of other worlds.If this is problem for you, this book may be an issue, but a minor one, as this book is primarily about walking the Camino.  Not unlike others she has had some various spiritual awakenings as she continued. However she did have a lot of press interference, but maybe that is also part of her path.The Camino is a path in Spain of approximate 500 miles that people walk for a variety of reasons.  As it has a spiritual past many are seeking understanding of a spiritual nature. However if you read Wild a book by Cheryl Strayed, the act of walking a long distance alone provides insight, if nothing else due to the solitude, change in location and physical duress the walker endures.Ive had the Camino book  in my collection for a bit and was planning on reading it, then the perfect opportunity presented itself.  While reading another book where the author Kevin Sessums planned on walking the Camino also mentioned Shirleys book.  I decided to read the two simultaneously.  Though Kevin Sessums book is only partly about his time on the Camino (less than 25%) it was still interesting to see the contrast.  He too took a day to day approach and kept a journal.  Similarly he had some spiritual experiences.I like that Shirley MacLaine documented her trip, from the formation of the idea to do the walk to the various towns along the way. You understood her motivation, her concerns and issues that she was dealing with.  I admire her for taking the option to stay in the hostels along the way, though this proved problematic with the issues she had with the press.Overall this was a nice read.  You get a sense that she got what she came for and despite the presss best efforts they did not deter her, nor sensationalized her attempt (maybe then they did at the time, but I dont think it overly affected the book).

This book is a combination biography and coming to terms with life and how its been lived by a man very much on the periphery of exalted showbiz circles and he also at the beginning drops a lot of famous names.  The name dropping put me off at first, but it was mostly only at the start of the book and occasionally here and there. However, his writing flows right along. The man  knows his craft.Hes lived a pretty racy life.  His descriptions of drug use and sexual encounters are a bit unsettling, but only make up a small portion of the book (less than 2%). Mind you, he is also contemplating the effects and meaning of this, as he is getting older. You can see his sudden awkwardness in some situations as he contemplates it.  He chooses to directly address this, in this book. Mind you like most addicts he had to hit the bottom before he started back up.  What troubled me, as the author is HIV positive; with the sexual encounters, is that I never felt the disease slowed him down from pursuing these encounters. Despite having no relationship with the partners, I still wondered if they knew he was HIV positive.  His assessing of younger men, as potential partners at some times seemed predatory.  But, maybe thats the way some men think and he is being more honest than most.At first the way the book jacket described, I thought there was an epiphany early on, where the author had decided to change his life and anticipated recollections on his way to doing that or what led up to it.  But, its not really constructed that way, but more a combination of the last several years of his life and a major coming to terms, but also all the things he is mulling on.  We all have themes that keep coming up in our life that shape us and you can see the author is no exception.Overall the book is well written.  The author is well known for years in the business of entertainment writing and that is evident here.  The chapter names prepare you for the contents of each chapter. He describes many aspects of his life, the sordid, the day to day and the sweet.He is clearly an intelligent contemplative man that is struggling with life.  This book is how he is trying to sort it out.An aside: Since early in the book he mentions planning walking the Camino and planning on reading Shirley MacLaine's book of that name, since I had it in my collection, I started reading it too..  Though the two did not walk the Camino simultaneously for me they did and it was nice to see the contrast.  I found his recollection much briefer (as of course an entire book was not dedicated to it) and similar in its mysticism.  While Shirley MacLaine had visions, this author had a few unique situations and synchronicity.

The full first half of this books tells you why this approach works.  Finally in the second half you get down to brass tacks.If you have at all read the more recent "Discovery" based books, you will already know that to get ahead to the next best thing in design, you must test out various hypotheses of designs and then act on the ones that are successful.However this book tells you the success of the design also is dependent on how "doable" this hypothesis is and then gives you an aggressive framework to work this into.They then go on to suggest that designing experiments in a 5 X 5 framework enables you to cover the width and breadth of what is needed to go forward.Let me share with you some things I have highlighted in the book.  This way it will speak for itself.ON THE ASPECT OF THE ABILITY TO DO THE IDEA:"In other words, if you can't do it, it `s not a good idea. If you can't do it well, it's not a good idea. If you can't afford to do it, it's not a good idea. If you can afford to do it well, it's not a good idea. If you refuse to do it, it's not a good idea.""Implementation - not the idea - is the superior unit of analysis for assessing value creation. On this theme the author talks of Sam Walton's assertion that "Most of us don't invent ideas. We take the best ideas of someone else.  While this may be true; Walton didn't take the best ideas for his company, he took what he saw with his own eyes, that actually worked.  What was the breakthrough behavior? Walmart baked implementability into it's internal innovation process.HOW THE IDEAS ARE PORTRAYED IS IMPORTANT:"Words are not pictures are not prototypes.  Initial expressions of ideas powerfully influence their ultimate implement-ability."  As a UI person, just mocking something up also influences the design. What might seem like a good idea in concept can fall apart in practice, but once it holds nicely when prototyped is also serves as a solid tool for persuasion.USERS ACTION SPEAK LOUDER THAN WORDS:As a usability professional, I see this over and over. User testing is a method that clearly shows what people will do, not what they say they will do.ON INVESTING IN EXPERIMENTS:"Don't invest in experiments to solve problems or create opportunities. Invest in experiments to quickly, cheaply and easily gain insight into solving problems and exploiting opportunities. The best experiments purchase actionable insights at fantastic discounts and with remarkable speed."FOCUS ON FUNDAMENTAL VALUE:Amazon's business model: "We don't many money when we sell things; we make money when we help customers make purchase decision".  Hence acceptance of negative reviews of products.ASPECT OF 5 X 5 EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN;"Design depends largely on constraints. Here is one of the effective keys to the design problem: the ability of the designer to recognize as many of the constraints as possible (and) his or her willingness and enthusiasm for working within these constraints. By insisting on constraints 5 X 5 portfolios dramatically improve the likelihood that they will generate high impact, high value returns on investment."RESISTANCE AS A MEASURE:"Resistance offers a remarkably clear window into understanding the internal culture an organizational dynamics of innovation culture." As an example of some responses to designs:*** It cost too much*** The lawyers won't let us*** Our biggest supplier would be upset*** Marketing wouldn't like it*** That's not the business we are in5 X 5 X 5 DESIGN AND CONSTRAINTSA minimum of5 teams of5 people with no more than5 days to come up with5 business experiments that should take no longer than5 weeks to run and cost no more than5,000 euros to conduct.Each experiment should have a business case attached that explains how running that experiment gives tremendous insight into a possible savings of 5 millions euros or a 5 million euro growth opportunity for the firm."The 5 X 5 methodology is more about investment in human capital and capabilities than it is about innovation and experimentation." The 5 X 5 isn't about financial capital; it's about human capital.  Don't ask for money, ask for access - to people, to time, to technology.  As for meeting space."If  you can't write a 200 word mission statement explaining why your organization needs 5 X 5 experimentation launched within the next 100 days, the you are not ready to champion it. Authentic "whys" attract authentic support"SOLUTIONS VERSUS COUNTERMEASURES:When the company performs root cause analysis, it doesn't want managers and workers reflexively proposing solutions.  A solution orientation promotes dysfunctional and even destructive expectations. Toyota instead asks its people to propose countermeasures.  The word solution implies solution. However solution may ultimately create problems of it's own. The countermeasure concept invites experimentation and appreciation of contingency and context.GREAT DISAGREEMENTSIn industry often there are disagreement of what is fundamentally important.  Google tested what is more important more results or more speed.  They found when they experimented with this and provided more results, it took longer to display than the less results which displayed quicker. Traffic dropped by 20% when the more results took longer to display, so they got the answer to their fundamentation questions."No one ignores experiments to resolve or illuminate the firms most significant or controversial business arguments".HOW DO X TEAMS FAIL AND SUCCEED:Your team fails if:*** your conversations become echo chambers of top managements cliches*** if it's business insights sound like escapees from tired executives educational webinars*** if your business hypotheses read like last years strategic visions*** if your proposed business experiments sound like warmed over market research*** if your portfolio doesn't reflect your teams intrinsic ingenuitySuccess begins with*** respecting your teams talents.*** respecting your firms needs and market potential*** from self organizing to tap individual and collective experience and expertiseCULTURE OF THE IMPERFECT IS THE WAY TO GO:Sir Robert Watson-Watt was a master of experimentation demonstration. His culture of the imperfect essay beautifully captures the design ethos that made his investments in experiments so successful: "Give them the third best to go on with; the second best comes too late; the best never comes."INCENTIVES MATTER:Incentives also matter. Consider how many businesses internally recognize and reward new ideas. Now how many companies explicitly celebrate and share provocative hypotheses and experiments? Those celebrations are cultural and operational norms at Capital One, Amazon and the like.  What gets measured gets managed.

SIMPLE TO USE:Very simple.  If you put the small plug in the charger, the big plug goes in your computer, so it stores up a charge.  If you put the big plug in the charger and the small plug in your phone, you are charging your phone.SIZE AND STORAGE:It's the same size as my phone but it has a cable, so I keep it in the zip lock bag it came in with the cable and toss it in my purse.SOME BACKGROUND:First of all you need to know I have a Samsung S4 with a replacement battery. I always have GPS, Bluetooth and Wireless on, even when charging.First use of this charger, when it was at 4 lights of charge: I put my phone on it at 37% and after an hour it got my phone up to 83%.  A 46% charge in one hour; not bad.  Better than my car charger does.Second use when, I had charged it, but it sat in my purse for 4 days so it was down to 3 lights.  I put it on my phone at 28% and after 45 minutes it took it up to 61%.  So a 33% charge in 45 minutes.  Still pretty good.EMERGENCY USE IS WELL WORTH IT:I keep this little charger in my purse when not charging and today it really came in handy.  My cat had knocked my phone off the charger in the night, so this AM, I had a critical battery level  Still I had to head out and wanted a working phone.  Tossed the phone in my purse regardless and hooked it up on this little charger.  The next time I looked at it, it was at 43%...Cool!.Whenever I use it I charge it, so when I need it, it's ready.How does this compare to other charges of it's type or even the higher capacity one?  Couldn't help you there. This is the only one I have ever had.  But, I do know my boyfriend and co-worker are planning on getting one, seeing mine.  The form factor is the size of a phone so they can fit in the same area.

This is my first Kelly Link book and I can tell you right away, her stories are strange. Most recently I read Margaret Atwood for the first time and found her stories unsettling and unique.  I would have to put Kelly Link in that same boat and maybe a nose ahead in that regard.The stories are told in a narrative viewpoint with the main character recounting what is happening.  If they have a peculiar view of the world, their delusions filter your story. I found the story; Secret Identity in its dropping into a RPG game recounting such that you can see the character is compelled to make comparisons when she ends up at a hotel where a Superhero conference is going on.You really dont know how its going to end, but you are intrigued to read on...and see where the twist will lead you.Ive found another author to intrigue me.

I knew the title was over the top, but I thought, what the heck, let's check this out.While I feel the information within is interesting and not dissimilar to my own beliefs, the topic is covered in such an "authoritative" tone as to beg disbelief.  That is a pity.It is also somewhat repetitive and preachy at times.This book will provide a measure of comfort for those who have lost loved ones. But, it will provide the skeptics ample opportunities to shred it.  Maybe they would shred it anyway.Hay House I have noted is somewhat known for the more esoteric titles. While there are some books, even though the topic matter had been a bit "out there" covered the information a bit more softly with supposition and logic and recognizing this is not necessarily mainstream belief.  This one is stating as fact and that is not (in my humble opinion) the best way to approach something like this.At the beginning reading it had a nice momentum and held my interest, but at about the halfway point it became a struggle to finish. Maybe that means the book was too long or said too much about each topic.I did like the letter from the departed loved one at the end of each chapter.Even though you can search within the book, I will include the chapters here so you get a flavor of the whole.The chapters are:*** Introduction*** We're not dead*** There's no  such thing as devil or hell*** We were ready*** You're not ready*** We're sorry for any pain we caused*** Your dreams can really come true*** Heaven is going to blow your mind*** Life is more than fair*** Your old pets are as crazy as ever*** Love is the way, truth is the path*** Epilogue*** Recommended Reading*** Acknowledgements*** About the Author

I love this book.  There are all sorts of families out there and there are all sorts of Moms.These stories capture a flavor of that variation and in each one, there is the love of a Mom. From the traditional family, to adoptive families, to single parents, to disabled parents and same-sex partners.There are also stories that recognize the wrenching aspect of adoption from the birthmother's view, to those who care for the children in the interim. There is the never-ending, question: "Am I doing this right?" And the wide-eyed wonder when we see our children grow up to be people we admire.There are few books that I can't wait to share with others and this is one of them.

I have always struggled with taking close up pictures of items and when I saw this camera, I thought cool.  Not too expensive, if it works half okay, it will be fun to play with.  This was my Christmas gift to me.OPENING THE BOX:The item was well packed.  There was the camera, a cute little bag case a cable and batteries.  The batteries unfortunately had leaked but since they were in the back and in cellophane damaged was minimized.  I have tons of these at home anyways.  There is no camera card, so you have to provide your own. I also had quite a few of these too.PHYSICAL APPEARANCE:Looks like a nice little camera.  Mine was purple as it stated.  Seems durable. Seems also like old technology as the screen seemed a bit dated.USING THE CAMERA:Instructions were brief, but I know my way around cameras, so I figured out most of what I had to do.A button to turn on the camera, one for the light. Another to review and one for menu.  Also one for Camera/video. A rotate lens thing that adjusts the focus and a zoom button.Yup, No shutter button.  I had read this was the case, but since I want to only picture inanimate objects I figured it would be no problem Wrong, BIG problem.  With the focus being as tight as it has to be, no matter how I tried I could not photograph a penny on the table with any level of clarity.  After an hour I gave up.The menu, to delete a photo was utterly hysterical to use.  If I recall (as I have packaged it up to return, before I wrote this), press review, then delete which doubles as the menu button and then choose the two buttons above to go up or down.  Choose all or this image to delete.  And then I scratched my head for a bit.  What now?  I pressed delete and closed the delete menu, so had to do everything all over again.  Finally it dawned on me.no...press the shutter button?  Yep.  Now that was not even remotely intuitive.  Not only does it double as the zoom, but it is on a different surface of the camera.Im a human factors engineer and considered keeping this camera as an example of massive mistakes, to share with my colleagues.  But then I thought this is an expensive example and decided to return it.PLUS SIDE:If you decide you want to risk it the seller has a 30-day return policy and they are accepting it back for a refund.

I ordered this despite mixed reviews.  This is a solid cheese board.  Nicely laminated.Loved the deep curved cracker wells.  Liked the way the board looked.However the drawer for the tools did not fit as well as it could.  No room to correct it.  The wood matched perfectly.Tools seemed okay.  All were sharp enough.The cheese board flat area inside the wells measures 8- x 8-Most people who saw it, said: Cool, thats a neat idea, that was just when they saw the cracker wells.  When they saw the drawer for the tools, then they were impressed.  For the most part, they did not notice the poor drawer fit.  However that was the first thing I saw when I got this board out of its box.  Only time will tell if the laminate holds well.First thing I did;  when I received it, was give it a nice coat of mineral oil.Im posting a picture so you can see the drawer issue I mentioned above.

Easy to read, hard to put down at times.  Mr. Lynch; Dermot, father to Eamonn travels to Spain to visit his ex-pat son.  He is surprised by his sons situation,  as he was under the impression all was well.  Eamonn surprised by his fathers visit is struggling on all fronts.  He moved to Spain to escape from himself and the isolation it provides makes it quite evident, this has become a prison not an escape.There is a lot of back and forth with Eamonns as well as Dermots memories.  One thing I thought they captured well was Eamonns getting to know his Dad separate from his Mom. So often the parents we know are a product of them being together.  We forget they might have a part of who they are suppressed by being a couple.  Another is when Dermot realizes that many years ago, he deserted his younger brother.  At some point, he realizes this sensitive soul is kin to his only son and there is a chance for redemption.As far as the shocking secret, rather underwhelming and besides the point of the story.  Conceptually it may be a metaphor, but it could have been skipped with little lost.The more I read of Eamonn, the more I realized his issues.  He was overly sensitive in some cases and oblivious in others. In other words his own worst enemy at times.  Arent we all?I particularly liked the ending.  I wasnt quite sure how they would wrap this up (Nope, not going to tell you), but it was perfect.

Having a sealer already, this was nothing new, however this new sealer is a bit more expensive model than we had and has a few extra features. We had a seal a meal brand sealer before this.  One thing it did not do was store the roll of bag material.  That's a nice touch. There is also an extended length seal. This can come in handy with delicate or moist items.We have frozen a bunch of things and it worked well.  This is one of those items that needs more long term use than 30 days allows.  I will write more as we use it more.If you don't have a sealer, here's some thought as to why you might get one.We purchase some sausage from a butcher that does some unique combinations.  It's hours away from our home.  For the most part, we buy it in anything from 2 to 5 pound increments.  Sausage freezes really well, so when we get some, we get a lot and freeze most of it.  Using the vacuum sealer, it avoids freezer burn and when we defrost it, it is like the day it was frozen.Similarly, we buy some specialty cheeses.  No we don't freeze those, but when we have some we eat it in smaller increments than we buy it.  We vacuum seal it and keep it in the fridge.  This extends items from weeks, to months.I grow herbs and invariably, I find I use Thyme more in the winter than the summer, so I freeze sticks of it in individual usable sizes.  Voila, fresh herbs all winter.  Not all herbs can be frozen this way, but I have had good luck with Thyme and Rosemary.  I freeze Basil chopped in ice cubes.We had a seal a meal brand sealer before this.  One thing it did not do was store the roll of bag material or have the extended seal.  Also in using the seal a meal we were oblivious to some cheaper bagging material out there.  Using a sealer that's not affliated with a particular bag type put us on to some new sources of bags.

We opted to get this router, not because our old one was broken, but we wondered if we could get better performance.  Occasionally our old one also a Linksys would cut out and we would have to turn it off and on.  Not enough to be annoying, but certainly more than it did when it was new.Getting the new one we were first surprised about it's size. It was 1.5X the size of the other and barely fit on the shelf we had the old one on. Also it had 4 antennas to our prior one's 2, so ideally it has a more omnidirectional reach.  Initial installation of the equipment and the SW went relatively seamless.  I had the initial case where you can't reach the internet and it told me to take a step to resolve this.  It did.  We thought we were off to fair skies.Prior to the installation we measured our internet speed on our old router and even directly from our modem, Essentially they were equal.  So we realized this new router could not offer more in speed and were hoping maybe reliability were to be gained.  Unfortunately our hopes were dashed early on.  First, we lost a connection a few times and used their fix in the SW.  Then we could not get the SW to work.  Finally we could not get the router to communicate with the modem at all.  We swapped back to our old router and all was good.  Over the course of a weekend, we changed the two routers out multiple times to no avail.Finally we opted to call customer service as several reviews had customer reps saying to do this.  To give the router a fair shake we did this.  First of all the number on the CD sleeve was utterly bogus and hooked us up to a direct sales site.  We ended up looking up a number on the internet and then successfully contacted Linksys.  After 2 hours talking to the service rep in the Philippines (a young woman with a very pleasant almost French accent, who spoke English very well), she concluded that the unit itself was faulty and though this is a Vine product (free), they would replace it, if we paid for the shipping.Jump forward a few weeks later, we dropped the new router in, where the old one was.  Installation since we wanted to use the same sign-in's took a bit of finagling on some devices, but was seamless on others, we now have a working router.  Given that the old one failed repeatedly the first night and it each subsequent use, this one has been working well in fact perfectly.4 or 5 days later...well, I thought it was working perfectly.  Unfortunately several days after I wrote that review, the new router, started acting like the prior one and no longer would work.  At this state, if it was not a "Vine" product, I would have returned it for my money back.  Ironically we returned to our older Linksys router that works perfectly.

Having read all the Sherlock Holmes books recently,  I approached this book with some trepidation. How could the author live up to the legend?  Well he does a passable job. While Athelney Jones and Frederick Chase are no Holmes and Watkins they make a great second string team.Some references to prior Sherlock Holmes capers are tucked in the book, in fact Athelney Jones was a police detective that botched prior investigations that Holmes solved.  However knowing the Holmes stories is not required to enjoy this book. When the references are made, they are for the most part explained.  This also helps if it has been awhile since you read the stories.One thing I do have to caution you, is that the first chapter is slow.  I was getting worried and then, it found its pace.  I think the author in trying to set up the book spent a bit too much time explaining. You were in the head of Frederick Chase as he pondered his next steps.  Finally when the two characters meet, the prose flows a bit better.  As with most Sherlock Holmes stories, the author has tucked in some unexplained issues and has created some significant twists.Overall a decent book.

Once I started this book, I had a hard time putting it down.  I opted for this book as I find people's personal stories compelling, especially if the have made a major life change.  The author having moved from the Soviet Union, as some of my colleagues had, I was wondering how acclimating went.  I got a few chapters in and had the strangest sense that the voice was familiar.  The author used the word: vranyo. (a sort of lying to others and oneself about the state of things).  I realized I had read the author's first book before she left the Soviet Union back in 2009 and was hoping she continued her story.  What struck me then and now, is her descriptions of things around her and assessment of people's motivations and understanding.  She has a sharp eye and a very descriptive tongue.  She also noted, that we here in the US have a bit of vranyo of our own.I cannot imagine how difficult her time with no guidance in Texas was.  It always amazes me when an immigrant as she; thinks not knowing something is a personal failure.  Lack of knowledge should never be apologized for, unless the person had the opportunity to get this information.  How would you know, the food, the clothing, or the paperwork without being exposed to it?Later her Mother joins her and any woman with a Mom knows, the acclimation to your Mother living with you after you have lived on your own, is the really hard part, all cultural differences aside. Her sister joins her sometime later and she wisely observes that she moved away not only from Russia, but from them as well and now here she was in the same position again.I cannot imagine picking up and leaving my country, nor could I imagine doing so for one that is so foreign, especially considering all the propaganda indicating the harshness of the situation. Furthermore due to the political situation, she was  under the impression she might never be able to go back to visit.  Thankfully she was wrong and has had the opportunity to see her family and friends again.This is a very well written and entertaining book giving a glimpse from a natives eyes into a country, that always pretended to be equal to the US, but was far from that.  Once you read this, I don't think you will take our country for granted any more.

Im sure some people might think, oh another Eat, Pray, Love. They might think so, but I think this book offers a unique perspective.  Each chapter has a lesson and they are quite interestingly handled.  It is also less about travel and finding oneself, and more about exploring the self, by letting go of our environmental issues such as culture, possessions and treating people and all life with reverence.  Less about choices and control and more about flow.I liked the chapter on breathing and story of the demon. As a person that struggles with meditating, that one really hits home. Never thought of following your breath as busywork before.Since the author has married a local man, it would seem to have furthered her insight.  Often when we see things our interpretation is from our world view and not what is intended.  I find the perspective interesting. She reveals her American ignorance and Western mindset on many occasions as I think many of us would.  Thats all we have to work with.Knowing nothing of Bhutan, it seems like it is a hard isolated life. Often that is found hand in hand with a very spiritual mindset. The author has captured the flavor of all this in her chapters:Calm downLose your baggageLearn to BreatheRusticateDrink TeaKindness will save usIts okay to be who you areLaugh in the face of DeathGenerosity is ContagiousWalk in Sacred PlacesParent YourselfYou are what you eatMore to the middle in all thingsThere are no accidentsLearn to be waterDont expect everything to always work outThink about death 5 times a daySimple is GeniusLook for MagicSee the world with your heartCheck your EgoWake up

This book grabs you and drags you into the world, of Raney, Bo and Charlotte.  The story skips back and forth between what is clearly an older time and current day, where the doctor Charlotte has a mysterious Jane Doe in her ICU.  No one knows this womans story and she is not reported as missing.  What could have possibly happened to this poor woman with such severe injuries? In the meantime the doctor; Charlotte, is in a relationship, that she feels has stalled.  Shes content where she is, as she is unsure of what she wants.  However she knows at some point in time, she has to critically decide what is next.  The clock is ticking.The other story, initially you dont know who it is about, but assume it is the Jane Doe and is of a childhood time where bonds are formed between children and circumstances influence choices. Two children Raney and Bo meet and grow closer over several shared summers.  It is clear Bo has a fractured family life and that is one of the reasons he is in Raneys town in the summer. However it is not evident what his role will be in her future.The story is told back and forth from the present to the past and evolves and reveals itself in slow motion. I like the way, the author has left it to the reader to make a few leaps before they reveal what is going on.  Makes you feel smart.  Always a good thing. She also alluded to things without going into too much detail, like a car crash in Mexico. It was a peripheral story, but led credence to the horror the character involved felt.I enjoyed the character development and personalities. Each persons voice was strong and consistent.  You could see their motivation and understood their decisions, even if they were not the best ones at the time.I highly recommend this book and I will look up the authors other books, as she has a nice way of telling a story.  I felt the medicine discussed was the right level for the book (after all the author is a doctor) and not overly dominating the story.

When they say comfortable chair....I'm in.  I can vouch that the chair is comfortable.ASSEMBLY:You get a relatively small box, for a chair and there are 5 main parts.  The chair pad, the 2 long legs the two short legs.  First you align the two sets of legs with their corresponding length legs and then you bolt both sets together, trust me, easier than I'm making it sound.  Flipping this over, you slide the chair pad onto these legs.  One person can do it, but two make it smoother.  Assembly from opening the box to sitting in the chair took about 15 minutes.  The longest part was unwrapping the plastic.  The second longest part was fastening the 8 screws.The only tool you need; the allen wrench, was provided.  Though the assembly went well, only 1 washer was extra.  Would have liked it if a spare screw was also provided.  You never know.USAGE:This chair is quite comfortable.
