The sling design, puts little pressure anywhere.  However the lack of arms may make it hard for some people to get in and out of.  My knees are my weak spot and this chair while comfortable is not the easiest to get up out of.  However I noted it is not lower than my other living room chairs, so it's height is not an issue.  Though it does not put any pressure on the back of my legs, I felt, it was a short chair.  Instead of supporting my legs nearly to my knee (I'm 5'9"), this fell short about 5-6".  For a living room chair that seems short.The slight back angle made this chair somewhat reclining, so this made me think I had to rest my arms down, but without armrests, they would be in my lap.  Also it made me want to put my feet up, versus leaving my feet on the floor.  Might be unique to me though.FABRIC;From the first moment after it was assembled, one of our cats decided it was his.  The smooth soft fabric attracted him over our leather cover chairs.  Considering the finish of the fabric, it should also be easy to clean. Thankful for that, as he is an orange cat and the fabric is sand.LEGS:The  chair legs are solid and do not easily bend.  They were well wrapped so the surfaces when they arrived are pristine.  Seem to be quite durable.OVERALL:Looking at the price relative to what you get, I thought this was pricey.  However it is well made and quite moveable, there the price is justified.

Having read Atul Gawandes books before, I opted for this one for more than just good reading.  I have a Mom in a nursing home and she has dementia. Thankfully she is not aware of the shear boredom I see around her.  Prior she was in an independent living environment full of activities and socialization around the dining room table. I mention this being fully aware that as a member of the baby boomer generation, we will become seniors in droves.  Some of us will live independently well into advanced age and pass away on our own terms but, a large group of us will end up in nursing homes or something similar, as our ailments increase with age.  This also pertains to those of us who have catastrophic accidents and illnesses that can no longer take care of themselves and neither can family. What sort of life will we have? The author brings up several examples where people have created homes for those who dont want to be warehoused and regimented and they were very successful.  Sadly though, they are very much the minority.The other perplexing dilemma is how ready is the medical establishment to help care for elders in fragile health or in an end stage of a disease, versus another person who has some likelihood of seeing the other side of this situation.  Do you cause harm and angst for 3 months only to have the person live out their already limited existence in considerable pain or recovery from surgery, that hampers their life. Or do you allow nature to progress and keep the person comfortable for the duration they have left and beyond and let death happen naturally.  Unfortunately doctors are not trained for this scenario.  Doctors often opt to treat when treatment obscures what is left of a persons life, so that more of this limited time is spent recovering, than living.  This is not only true for the elderly, but for people with a very limited or no chance of survival.  Unfortunately, not treating and letting nature take its course is seen as giving up and is so counter to our culture that it is perceived as a failure.The author discusses a very personal family situation where his father, was faced with some heavy choices, that due to his nature as a doctor, might be inclined to pursue aggressively, but instead considered of the potential outcome relative to his lifestyle and what was important to him.  In discussing this: He also pointed out there are 3 types of doctors, the authoritarian doctor of old, the informative doctor that just gives you the info and you choose and the cooperative doctor, that helps you consider the implications relative to what is important to you.  Unfortunately the cooperative doctor is hard to find and in the authors experience can seem this way, when actually being authoritarian.  Scary, as he and his father are both doctors and were swayed.  How is the average person going to first of all discern the difference or get the respect of the doctor to consider the patient well informed enough to make these choices?  In my own experience (a rather day to day one), after a minor injury to my wrist, during yoga, my own doctors solution was to stop doing yoga (permanently) as a treatment.  Considering the temporary nature of the injury and the long term advantage of doing yoga, these seems like a very short-sighted solution.  However this is not uncommon.  She neither asked the importance of this activity to me, nor seemed to care.  I badgered for physical therapy to strengthen my wrist (as she was not forthcoming) and this resolved the issue.  Frightening how little credence is given to what is important to us.Finally there is planning for the end and hard questions.  People just dont want to talk about it.I know I was taken aback when entering my Mom into  a nursing home, I was asked about funeral homes and plans upon death as well as DNR papers, but it would see we all want to think we will live forever, even when faced with a terminal situation.  The author pointed out that while doctors were thinking in terms of 3-6 month survival often their patients were imagining 10-20 years. It shows how way off we are and how insufficiently this is relayed.  If a doctor tells you to have surgery to give you 6 months more of life and you had only 2 months prior, you might spend 4 of those months recovering, with no quality of life and nearer to the end, what is left may not be worth living, that essentially he just took those 2 months away from you.  The patient acquiesces because they are imaging 6 months added to 1-2 years.This book is an eye opener on how to plan for your final days, what to consider and what to ask.  It will also help you understand what you may be faced with with an aging loved one.Most people wont plan for their less than independent years, so likely someone else will do that for you.  If nothing else, you need to make them aware what is important to you.  We also need to realize, that acceptance is harder than resistance in some cases as we may well be fighting the system as well.I hope this book gets the attention it deserves.

I've got a plethora of random drives around but this is probably the only one that specifically says it is water proof, shock proof, magnet proof, temp proof, and X-ray proof. It does not come with any sort of carry case or cover, but you could plug this into a laptop and probably forget it's there.

I received my SCCPVS600ECP-S Crock-Pot and initial impressions were that it is a nice stainless exterior, but the only item with any "heft" was the black interior pot. Both the external pot and controls feel very flimsy and do not extrude a feeling of substance. The lid lock anchors are also plastic, with the only metal bits being the actual wire hinges. Having said that, when the lid is locked down, it does feel very secure and you don't feel too worried about it coming undone, even when the crock is full of dinner.I guess I was lucky because out of the box, this crock worked just fine and I followed the basic Slow Cooker Revolution recipe for Beef Stew and it came out as expected.  The pot does seem to have a pretty central hot spot though - my old Crock-Pot brand crockpots seemed to dissipate heat better than this guy did, not sure if they've changed the interior pot within the last five years or so.  The control panel feels really flimsy though, and I'm not sure how long it'll last, especially compared to my old pot which just had the generic dials.All-in-all, it sure is a crockpot. I'm not really sure if the timer function of the pot is really worth the extra cost though - especially considering that you can sometimes pick up a non-digital version for $30 or less.

I received the Carhartt Force Vneck in Burnt Coral Heather.  I own quite a few other Carhartt Force shirts, mostly from their polo line. First impressions is that unlike most of the other Carhartts I own, this shirt actually feels smaller than I'd expect (I received a large and usually wear a medium/large). The large was actually already snug in the arms and the body.  Usually Carhartts are sized up compared to other brands - a L feeling more like a XL, but this wasn't the case here - I'd say that the L felt like a true L, maybe even a larger M. However the material is rather stretchy and I believe this shirt is made to feel like it's hugging the body, so if you're buying expecting a loose fitting Carhartt, this isn't the shirt for you.The second impression was that the material is pretty thin, again, especially for a Carhartt. This shirt feels much more like their fashion line rather than their work line. If you're doing a lot of rough and tumble work, I'd really worry about the longevity. My old Carhartt Women's Short-Sleeve Pocket T-shirts felt like they could be run over by a lawnmower several times a day and come out in one piece. This shirt doesn't make me feel confident about its longevity - but I'll update either way and since I don't have proof either way yet, this didn't affect my review here, other than for the feel of the fabric.Colorwise, the burnt coral heather is like a faded bubblegum pink, with a slight tinge of orange added. I'd almost call it a salmon mousse color. It's not bright enough that it'll draw a lot attention for being loud, but it's also rich enough that it looks very feminine.The v-neck isn't super deep so I'd say that this shirt is probably ok for most casual work environments. The side scoops plus stretchy material hug the body help make any female curves obvious. When sized, the shirt does not hug your "bad curves" too badly.  Broad-shouldered women might find the arm area a little tight though.One small annoyance - the material tag is along the left side of the shirt, near the waist. I'm not sure if I just got super unlucky, but mine was poking me every chance it got. The material tag is by far the stiffest material on this whole shirt.  Next time Carhartt, please go tagless!

I received the Acanthus Ruffle Floral Kitchen Apron in the Floral Taupe color, and build wise, everything seems pretty solid. The main body of the apron - the non-frilly areas, feel solid without feeling overly stiff or heavy.  The frilly areas are much softer, but still do not feel thin or fragile. The neck and waist straps are very adjustable and can accommodate many sizes of people.  For me, the frill area seems a little overly frilly - I much prefer my other apron, the DII 100% Cotton, Professional Bib Apron, but this one obviously has the feminine thing going for it.The central pocket is cut in two, but neither pocket is very useful in my opinion.  You could probably put one pack of 3" x 5" index cards in each pocket, but not much else. Measuring spoons, flatware, and small tongs would be fine, but anything larger like a full sized spatula would probably just fall out.

I received this apron in black and so far so good.  The material is a thick-ish 100% cotton weave.  Out of the box, the apron felt somewhat stiff and starched - the straps felt somewhat itchy when first put on.  After an initial wash, the cotton settled in nicely and the stiffness went away. It did leech some color into the wash though, so for the first few washes, I'd suggest washing with separated colors only.If there was any shrinkage, it wasn't noticeable.The neck strap is adjustable and the waist ones are very long. The single center pocket is wide, but not very deep.  You could hold measuring spoons or flatware, but probably not a full-sized spatula or anything along those lines.

The Everlast Nutrition Fuel is a nice on-the-go hydration option for those times you don't want to cart around a lot of sports drinks with you. As per the instructions, I put the powder into my water bottle and mixed. I generally hydrate while doing my workout so I don't really feel dehydrated, but it did seem like recover the next day was just slightly less stiff, slightly less sore. It wasn't night and day, but every little bit helps.The real gotcha is the taste. The citrus flavor is like an odd mix of Emergen-C, tang, and maybe even a watered down kool-aid without the sugar. The Fuel uses a stevia extract for a bit of sweetness though, so if you're like me and get that odd stevia bitter aftertaste, you'll probably dislike this stuff.  Instead of diving in head first and buying a full 14 count, I'd highly suggest trying a single packet if you can find it first. Drinking 14 of these isn't something I really want to do.

The La Roche-Posay Anthelios 50 AOX is a non comedogenic, silicone-based sunscreen and antioxidant serum which uses tocopherol (vit-E) as its antioxidant base.The serum spreads very well and a small amount will cover a large area - I could get a single pump to cover my entire face - albeit rather thinly. I'd guess that a 1 to 1.5 pumps is probably average. The serum goes on rather greasily and is not really pleasant feeling to apply. The greasy feel dissipated in a minute or so and left the skin feeling somewhat smoother (not as smooth as applying a moisturizer, but similar). With careful conservation, I'm guessing this single vial would probably last two or maybe even three months (assuming you are reapplying every two hours as directed while you're exposed to UV rays).There is no true scent associated to the serum other than a sort of faint and generic chemically smell when first applied. It didn't bother me much and seemed to go away within a few minutes.The serum also contains things like baicalensis root and cassia leaf extracts, both which are often used as antibac/antifungal and anti-inflammatory type medicines.The Anthelios 50 AOX is a decent sunscreen that goes on rather greasy, dries smoothly and does not have a noticeable scent afterwards. The non comedogenic aspects are great, especially since many sunscreens seem so heavy and clogging. However, there's quite a few chemicals included as well as being silicone based, which isn't exactly eco-friendly. If you have sensitive skin, this serum has quite a few glycols in the ingredients, so you may want to test it out before using all over your face.

The Menaji CAMO concealer is a good a general use concealer in a very convenient, easy to carry packaging. Having said that, the concealer is of a ticker mud-ish consistency which (depending on your skin tone) might require quite a bit of blending to not be obvious. While not specifically listed as non comedogenic, the concealer did not feel heavy or blocking when applied (although I wouldn't call it "light" either). If you have serious issues with breakouts due to pore blockage, you may want to find something specifically listed as non comedogenic instead of risking it. It is listed as hypoallergenic - I don't have sensitive skin, but I did not notice any reaction from use.I received the "Light" coloring and I would say that the description is pretty accurate. I generally have a light/medium skin tone and the concealer, once blended in, is a decent match. While not perfect, it's not painfully obvious that I'm wearing concealer either.  At the time of this review, this product was priced in the mid-twenties, making it a low-to-mid-ranged price for most concealers. When compared to similar brands, there are some really good names out there that - while not specifically marketed towards men - are awesome products. Personally I think I'd pick up a Nars, Make Up Forever, or Urban Decay instead. However this concealer performed decently well (but I'd still keep my Nars close at hand).

The Ammex APFN blue nitrile gloves are a good general use glove and their light color is one of my favorite ones to use for food prep. I found the Ammex gloves to be much sturdier than the generic gloves I pick up at the local drugstore. While I generally have to worry about punctures or rips with the generics, the Ammex gloves are very resilient and made it through some garage clean up with no issues.I generally wear a size M glove and these S I received were pretty tight on the hand. While the glove fit and I had no issue with functionality, the push on the fingertips quickly became an annoyance. I'd say these gloves run very true to size and would suggest buying a size up versus a smaller size should you be unsure of your best fit.

The Ammex GPNB GlovePlus nitrile gloves are a very nice and sturdy set of general use gloves.  Personally I do not like the darker colored gloves for food prep simply because you can't always tell if your gloves are clean or if you have some tagalongs - it's just much easier to tell with the lighter gloves. Personally I use these for general housecleaning or other functions along those lines.I generally wear a M or L in these style gloves so the XXL was very loose on my hand (as expected).  However the large fit made it so there were wrinkles in the glove, but it still stayed securely on my hand during use.

The recipe book that is Nuts is a good general look at various items you can do with nut meats - it covers all of your basics like roasting, boiling, making milk, butters, as well as general spice mixes, protein recipes, salad suggestions, as well as some desserts and even some cocktails. The book specifically covers your most easy to find nuts - Almond, Cashew, Chestnut, Hazelnut, Macadamia, Peanut, Pecan, Pine, Pistachio, and Walnuts (yes, it does cover the fact that peanuts are legumes).While the volume is a relatively short book - only 132 pages, it actually does cover quite a bit of ground. The recipes are easy to understand and well explained.  There's not a picture for every recipe (maybe closer to one in five or so), but the ones that are there are nicely presented.Since the volume does span from raw nuts to dessert and all courses in between, there's nothing that's specifically vegetarian or gluten free,  Having said that, the majority of the included recipes are quite healthy and many lean towards vegetarianism and gluten free options - you just have to avoid adding things like bacon to the salad, or skip the desserts with cake-ish subjects.  There's actually quite a bit to choose from for both specific requirements.All in all, I probably wouldn't suggest Nuts as a addition to small collector of cookbooks, simply because much of the subject matter is probably covered in general cookbooks, but if you're a cookbook collector like I am, it's not a bad volume to add.

The Braven Wireless Speaker is joining a large line up of bluetooth speakers and it performs relatively well when compared to others in the same price range.The speaker pairs easily and had a relatively loud volume, considering its size. It will be loud enough for a small outdoor gathering, but probably not for anything larger than five or more people in a small to medium sized backyard space. Like most bluetooth speakers, it paired easily with my phone (Note 3).The Balance has a 4000 MAh battery, and it doubles as a portable battery for any mobile devices, the USB output jack rated at 5V / 1A. For whatever reason, Braven decided not to allow USB charging for the speaker itself - you've got to drag along the AC adapter should you want to charge the speaker on the road. According to the manual, a single charge will provide you with 18hrs of music before requiring a recharge (less if you use the BOOST feature).  The Balance also has a discrete battery charge indicator in the back, so you can get an idea of how much power is left in the speaker - a nice little addition that's often left off of cordless devices nowadays.  The IPX7 waterproof rating suggests that the device is able to be put into 1 meter of water for up to 30 minutes and still function - however the manual specifically states that the device should not be exposed to liquids while charging.All in all this speaker is a decent addition to the line of up speakers posted at the $100-$150 range. Sound wise, as expected of a speaker with a shallow body, there's not much depth of sound or chest-thumping bass, but the highs and mids are decently defined. The inclusion of a waterproofing makes it much more outdoor-friendly than many of the other bluetooth options out there, however the AC adapter requirement for recharging is a minus.

Video game art books tend to stray towards a couple basic types. There are collaboration ones which take a shotgun approach by hitting several titles, and there are title specific books which give you both concept art and finished cinematic still frame type art. Game Art: Art from 40 Video Games and Interviews with Their Creators takes the first approach.For me, this really makes the book feel more like a collection of snapshots rather than any sort of in-depth view into video games or video game art. The interviews with the game developers is a nice touch, but even then, the amount of insight is small - each interview probably consisting of less than two full pages worth of text. While the book is filled with very beautiful glossy pictures of games, quite a few of the pieces are publicity photos. Final Fantasy is probably one of the more well-known franchises in this book, and quite a few of the images in the FF spread are directly from their promotional library. For instance, the giant splash page image of characters riding chocobos is lifted directly from the Final Fantasy XIV image catalog and very easily found online (search: final fantasy xiv chocobo).  Out of curiosity, I did a few Google searches on some of the smaller indie titles (Tengami, Child of Light, and Never Alone) and found that most of the art in this book could be found on the first page of image search results. Also worth mentioning was that most of the images Japanese games (specifically the JRPGs) other than Final Fantasy were not actual game art at all, but rather character or concept art. There are several pieces from the Atelier series but zero actual in-game photographs - only concept art.So to summarize, most of the images in this book are "public" photographs that you can easily find online by doing a simple image search for the relevant titles. The interviews with the creators and developers are a nice touch, but only surface interviews with very little substance - finding an interview with the creator done by a gaming site would probably give you more insight. The book itself is beautifully done. The colors and pictures are very sharp and the paper heavy and glossy. If you wanted a coffee table book about game art, or just a nice compact collection of general game art information, this is a good book to pick up.If you were hoping for a real "Game Art" book which lots of different images from games that can't be found anywhere else, this is not the book to grab. There have been a couple of books done about video game art and they tend to pale in comparison to title specific or studio specific books. If you were looking for a book on video game art, I'd suggest sticking with the more specific books for now, these shotgun approach titles just aren't up to par yet.Suggested titles to pick up instead:UDON's Art of Capcom: Complete EditionThe Art of The Last of Us and/or The Art of Naughty DogThe Legend of Zelda: Hyrule HistoriaAnd pretty much anything from a Japanese studio with the words "Works" or "Complete Works" in the title (example: Breath of Fire: Official Complete Works)

The Vichy DermaFinish in Nude is a good basic creamy concealer product. My current go-to product is the Bobbi Brown New Creamy concealer kit NATURAL, which I still prefer as my every day, but the Vichy is not a bad substitute when I don't want to do the full blending and foundation and powder regimen. The DermaFinish does feel a little heavy when applied, and while is listed for sensitive skin, does not specifically say it is non-comedogenic, so if you are prone to breakouts, this may not be the right choice for you.Tone-wise, I would say that the default "nude" color is a bit on the lighter side compared to other nude colors I've used. However it blends well and tends to act as a bit of a highlight, so it works well for under eye dark spots.

The Delta Compel faucet is a great looking faucet with very easy to follow instructions. Installation took a bit of time in my bathroom simply because of the sink configuration, but once installed the faucet worked perfectly. As long as you don't have a ton of irritating rusted nuts and bolts like I did, installation should probably take less than an hour.The finish and functionality of the faucet feel very solid and ready to work for years. The TouchO2 technology worked right out of the box with no issue.

The Classic Accessories round firepit cover did exactly what I wanted it to - keep the debris away from my firepit as much as possible. The cover itself feels heavy and substantial, and the beige color blends in very well with just about any decor. I found the cover to be easy to remove and install with my pit.

The Ammex AINPF Nitrile gloves fit well and had good grip that I did not find with the other Ammex gloves I have used so far, including the textured versions. While not powdered, I found that the nitrile material felt a little "dusty" when using, although there is no noticeable residue. I normally wear a medium size so the large felt a little loose on my hand but this did not impact the functionality or use of the gloves. The fingers fit well but they were very loose at the wrist.

The Ammex TLF series of latex gloves were a good set of general use latex gloves for those without latex allergies. I found that the latex gloves tended to snap a little bit quicker and feel a bit more durable than the non-latex versions. The large size sat a little large on my hand - I normally take a medium - but this did not impair the functionality or use. The glove sat loosely on my hands and very loosely at my wrist. I believe these gloves felt on par with the generic set I usually grab at the drugstore as far as durability goes.

The Ammex XNPF XTreme line of Blue Nitrile gloves are a good durable version of their nitrile gloves. I found the large size to sit on my hand relatively well (i usually take a medium), but the larger size did not cause any issues with use. These gloves feel quite a bit more durable than the generic transparent version I usually grab from the drugstore.

The Ammex AAMV gloves are a good set of general use gloves by Ammex.  I generally wear a medium size glove when I purchase them from the drugstore, so I found these large sizes to sit a bit loosely on the hands and very loosely at the wrist. This did not impair their functionality or their use, however. I found the AAMV style to be about on par with the other generic brand clear gloves I find at the drugstore as far as durability is concerned. The blue nitrile ones being more durable. However the tactile feel through these gloves felt a little more transparent than the thicker gloves.

I'm a sucker for knives of all shapes and sizes, and I love them all. However when the manufacturers claim one thing or another, I really want them to follow through. Sabatier's "Mother of Pearl 8 inch Chef Knife" claims a few things, and I'll tackle them one at a time.  At the time of this review, this knife was priced at nearly $140 which puts it into the premium knives category in my opinion, and I'll treat it as such.(Faux) Mother of Pearl -Lets talk about this one first since it'll be the easiest. When most people think of "Mother of Pearl," they think of nacre - that irridescent stuff that's usually on the inside of an oyster or clam shell. As the name implies, it's also the stuff that makes up the layers of pearls. What is on the Sabatier handle is *not* mother of pearl. It's "pearlized" - as in, it's sparkly. What is it actually made of?  Plexiglass. Or, by a more common name: acryllic. Some acryllic can handle even commercial dishwasher temperatures, however since Sabatier lists on the product page to handwash, I assume theirs is not one of these, which generally means their handle material is going to end up being less resillient. Not an issue if you're pretty delicate with your knives. If you're rough with them, expect some scratches and maybe even color clouding in time.(Not) High Carbon Steel -Do a search on X50CrMoV15 and you'll find that it has around 0.5% carbon content (and it's a German-based steel, not French) - which is less carbon content than your generic 440 stainless steel - the stuff that makes up some of the cheaper budget knives. To put this into perspective, this is the same steel that's in the best selling Victorinox Fibrox line - the ones that cost about a fifth of this knife. For knives that will see heavy use, the X50CrMoV15 is a relatively soft steel that will need frequent sharpening (2-3 months versus 6-8 for harder steels, very dependant on usage obviously). Honing is almost a requirement before every use. On the flip side, this knife will probably stay very shiny and be very scratch resistant. Toss your knife into the sink and leave it there after every use? This knife can take that sort of abuse.(Never trust a skinny) Chef Knife -I've uploaded a picture of this knife next to some of my other chef knives. What was immediately obvious upon opening the package was that the Sabatier was extremely thin as far as blade width was concerned. The only knife I owned that even came close to that thinness was my 6" Shun. I'd almost call this more of a large utility knife, or a non-flexible boning knife than a chef knife. The second thing that was immediately obvious was the lack of a rocking edge. The blade shape was almost as flat on the main edge as my santoku - the rounded tip being the main reason why I wouldn't call it a santoku. The flat blade shape makes this knife more suited to an up/down chopping motion than a slice. If you're a "rocker," you'll hate this knife.Here's the other kicker about the blade being so thin - there's hardly any knuckle clearance. I have what I'd consider normal sized hands - the Fibrox handles are on the edge of being too large to be comfortable. If you have giant gorilla hands, this knife will feel tiny, and you'll probably end up banging your knuckles constantly. I hated the feel of this blade in my hand and it took a while to figure out why - I was automatically adjusting my grip so that my two forward fingers were actually on the blade more than the handle in order to keep my knuckles from brushing the cutting board. When I purposefully tried to hold it normally - with a leader index finger, but the other three main fingers on the handle, the balance felt wrong, and my knuckles were hitting the board so often it felt like I was knocking on a door. Again, for gorila-handed people, the handle is very thin, similar in feel to that of a pairing knife. It felt pretty small even in my hands.Sabatier (What's in a name?) -Sabatier is a relatively generic French name which came into use before intellectual property and trademark laws existed. It used to mean high quality, fully-forged steel from Theirs, France. Now it's more of a generic term for "French knife maker", which can include anything from stamped knives or actual forged French knives. The fact that it was so hard to find the maker of these knives sent up warning bells as well. After some Googling, these particular Sabatier knives are made by the Rousselon brand (rousselon.fr), which has some really nice knives. However you'll notice that this "Mother of Pearl" line is not even mentioned on their website.Edge (Out of the box) -The edge out of the box was a good sharpness, able to cut through apples and tomatoes with little effort. The lack of weight behind the blade and lack of rocking edge made me feel that I needed to press on the head of the knife as well as the and handle in order to cut through the apple's core. The edge was fine enough that I was able to do paper-thin slices of the apple and tomato.Conclusion -Don't do it. This is a premium priced knife that has all the features of a budget knife. If you want a knife that looks nice sitting in a butcher block, but never gets used, a set of these would fit that bill nicely. However, for the price, there's so many better options out there. Many of which are probably cheaper.Recommended Knives (Note: All knives listed below were cheaper than the Sabatier at time of this review) -Victorinox Fibrox 8" Chef's KnifeZwilling J.A. Henckels Twin Four Star 8" Chef's KnifeGlobal G-2 8" Chef's KnifeVictorinox Rosewood 8" Chef's KnifeWusthof Grand Prix II 8" Chef's Knife

The OnHub Wireless Router is like a Fisher Price version of a router. I'd easily suggest setting this puppy up for those relatives who aren't really sure about technology. The device requires you link a Google account which is really the only oddball thing to me. I don't mind the requirement of passwording your network, I think everyone should do that by default - even for a guest network.If you like out of the box, ready to go type devices, this is a great router for you. However if you have an at home lab, specific subnet configs, or even band-specific networks, you'll have no luck with this device. As far as range goes, there's a reason why the newer high end routers all look like spiky porcupines, external antennas simply allow for stronger signal. I will say that for a unit with only internal antennas, the signal was surprisingly strong.I am curious if the Tomato folks will take on this router, it seems like it has a lot of potential. Or if the Google app will eventually keep evolving like the Amazon Echo and allow for advanced configuration options for "power users".

When it comes to Advil vs Tylenol, Tylenol was usually my go to for fevers and the like, but it really didn't do much for my headaches. I usually had to go to Advil for relief. These Goody's powders had a very similar result for me.I have mild shoulder pain from time to time which usually leads to a stiff neck and to a headache if I don't notice what's happening in time. Lucky for me, a package of Goody's headache powder just happened to land on my lap the last time this happened.Problem #1 - opening the packet. If you're name is Gregor Clegane and you are colloquially known as "The Mountain," you might be able to open these stupid packs by hand. Otherwise, you're going to search for scissors or other sharp instrument.The powder didn't really seem to dissolve completely - there were definitely chunks and little specs remaining in the glass after drinking, even after vigorous swishing. Taste-wise, it tasted better than I thought a crushed up aspirin would taste, but if you're like me and hate sweeteners, you won't like this stuff. It tasted like an artificial fruit juice drink - and that stupid sucralose taste felt like it coated my mouth and lingered forever. In Goody's favor, I seem to recall these tasting incredibly bitter as a child - there was zero bitterness in the Mixed Fruit Blast flavor and it was very easy to drink (if you can get past that fake-sugar flavor). The flavor reminded me of kid's medicine.Unfortunately as far as benefits go, for me it didn't work very well. It felt like someone just numbed my headache a bit, making it less annoying, but never fully getting rid of it like Advil usually does for me. My shoulder pain did calm down a bit, but was still there as well.  For me, I'm going to keep carrying around my Advil gel caps, but I was surprised at how how far Goody's had come (at least flavor-wise).
