I haven't been the best eater in the world and I know type 2 runs in my family, so I was always curious what my glucose readings would be. Yearly doctor visits clear me, but the little hypochondriac always likes to nag at me.I tested the BG5 with myself and my roommate - both on Android devices, the Note 3 and Note 5 (I had a Galaxy Tab 10, but the app was not compatible). If you go to iHealth's website, this looks like an Apple-only app. I was a bit stymied at first as there are zero iProducts in my home. And as far as I can tell, you cannot use this device without it first synching to some sort of supported device. So even if you turn on the reader, stick a strip in, put in a blood sample, the device just errors and tells you to connect to an app-enabled device first. For whatever reason, when I did a search on the Google Play store, the only hit I got was their MyVitals app (which will not work with this reader). I had to rind a random Youtube video which showed the person using an Android phone and figure out that the name of the app is the iHealth Gluco-Smart. Doing a search for that specific name brought it right up on the Play store (this was probably my fault, but hopefully it helps someone else out).It should be noted that the Gluco-Health app required a metric ton of permissions. The biggest "Why?" was that it has the ability to directly call phone numbers (not just read phone status). Most of the other permissions were pretty standard - take pictures/video, record audio, GPS location, modify SD card, prevent screen lock, WiFi access, Bluetooth access, reorder/retrieve running apps (another Why? one), run at startup (Why?), draw over other apps, allow Wifi Multicast, control flashlight/vibration, prevent from sleeping, change audio settings, modify system settings (Why?).Tethering the device was pretty simple for the first Android unit. It worked just as you'd expect - hit the pairing button, scan with your phone, and wait for the app to acknowledge the connection. Using the built in QR code scanner worked well, but it claimed that one of my vials of test strips was already expired (the date printed on the vials said it was good until 2016). Luckily my unit came with two vials of test strips and the other one read as good. The app also requires you to create an iHealth account before using.The lancet worked fine as expected, and the blood draw itself was very simple. It's always amazing how little blood these readers require nowadays. The reader said I had a glucose reading of 106 (I had eaten less than two hours ago). Looking online.t his seemed pretty normal. So I handed the device over to my roommate.Pairing with a second device was a little more questionable. By default, you're supposed to press the memory button for 3 seconds and wait for the bluetooth icon to blink - this should be pairing mode. When your phone connects, the bluetooth symbol is supposed to go solid to let you know the reader has successfully paired. This is how it worked with my phone. We had to try to pair the reader three times with the second phone before it took. The reader would show three dashes and the bluetooth symbol wouldn't stop blinking. The phone would claim that it has paired, but the app would stay stuck on "Please connect device". With some voodoo combination of restarting phones, unpairing from all existing phones, repairing with one phone, we finally got it working - unfortunately I can't tell you what the silver bullet was that made it start working correctly.My roommate, who had also eaten less than an hour ago, and had been drinking a rum-and-Coke style drink, tested at a glucose reading of 98. As far as I could tell from online sources, this was really low even for a fasting rate (he donates blood regularly and has not tested positive for high nor low blood sugar). This seemed like a really odd result, but didn't really have a good benchmark to compare it against nor another glucose reader to get a second opinion.I then saw all of the previous reviews of this device where the users had very drastic results from their other glucose readers and it made me question the validity of the results.  So I tried again in the morning, pre-breakfast - so after fasting 10hrs or so. First I put in the control solution - it registered at 116 (it was supposed to be around 100). So I did three tests in the morning, the first one read 25, so I'm assuming I managed to fudge that one up somehow. The second 85, the third 82.So for me, it's a bit of a crapshoot. I really wish I had another glucometer to test against to see if these readings are accurate.From a purely functional standpoint, the device is simple and easy to use. The app itself is a little on the clunky side with some questionable permissions. It's also a bit of a maze to find your individual readings (although it does do a neat graph chart). It's nice to have all that data directly on your phone, but a wider range of Android devices would be nice.  For diabetics, as long as you have a secondary unit which you trust to make sure that this reader is calibrated correctly, I can see this device being really handy. Test strip refills on the iHealth website seem cheap-to-average compared to what I can find for a similar count at local drugstores ($12.50 for 50 strips). They appear to be around $10 via Amazon Subscribe and Save right now.

So Fluxx is already a game of total chance - while you can make up possible strats in your head or even an idea for what cards you'll be playing your next turn, by the time your turn arrives, another player has probably blown that all out of the water. The Fluxx Dice doesn't really change that mechanic, all it really does is add the possibility that the number of cards played off the bat increases immediately. There's no real uniqueness though, all of the dice options already exist in all of the base games I've seen - the various Draw and Play X number of cards. It might have been a good addition if there were dice-specific actions, but there's not.These dice also are of questionable quality. Out of the box, there was obvious printer alignment issues as the text on my dice were a bit "skippy" and wavy. The black dice already had a few points where the paint chipped off parts of the text.  It makes me nervous that longevity might be an issue. Also since the Fluxx boxes are all relatively small, the dice will have to stay in the included box or a dice bag for storage purposes. If you're taking Fluxx to a friends, luckily they're a small package overall, but if you want to play with the Dice, you'll probably be taking two boxes (the base set and the dice).

My dogs have loved the Wellness Wellbars for years and i'm glad to see this hasn't changed. The Wellbars are a hard treat - so if you have dogs with sensitive or weak teeth, these may not be the best treat - the hardness reminds me of the Nature's Valley granola bars for humans. They're also a bit on the messy side as they will crumb-it-up when the dogs break them apart. My dogs lick up the crumbs, but it may be  best for a non-carpeted, non-rug floor (unless you plan on vacuuming afterwards).Ingredient-wise, I love most of Wellness' stuff because they've got a pretty simple list, and the top ingredients are usually identifiable.  For the yogurt, apple, and banana flavor, here's the list:Ground Barley, Cane Molasses, Ground Brown Rice, Canola Oil, Yogurt (Milk Ingredients, Lactic Acid, Citric Acid, Yogurt Cultures), Apples, Bananas, Oatmeal, Flaxseed, Ascorbic Acid (Vitamin C), Vitamin E Supplement, Mixed Tocopherols added to preserve freshness, Beta-Carotene.As you can see, the second ingredient is molasses and the apple and banana come later. This suggests that there's probably a pretty decent sized serving of sugar per bar (unfortunately they don't break down how much per serving like in human foods). So these are very much a treat food which should only be given now and then.The size is large enough that my Malamute feels like she has to chew them and break them up, but my Shiba can still handle them without issue. They're wide enough that I think even most larger dogs will still feel the need to break these down, but smaller dogs may have a tough time without breaking the bars in half first.All-in-all, I'm very happy with the Wellbars and so are my pups!

*Edit - According to AHAVA, triclosan is not in this product. It's always best to check your ingredient list if you're worried. It may be that I received a reformulation. Older tubes may still contain triclosan, so to be on the safe side, check before using.I have been using the AHAVA Dermud foot creme for a few days before I saw the Triclosan warning by another reviewer. Unfortunately the ingredients are not printed on the actual tube, but only on the original packaging box - which I had already thrown away at this point.When I checked on AHAVA's website for this product, Triclosan is *NOT* listed on the list of ingredients. I have sent their customer service an email inquiring if triclosan was recently removed, and if so, how to tell if the product I have was made in the batch with or without the chemical. I will update this review when I hear back from the company.Usewise, the creme was nice to use. The scent is a somewhat generic "moisturizer" smell, which no real heavy scent markers that really come to mind when I smell it. The feel of the lotion stays somewhat greasy for an extended time - upwards of five to ten minutes on a humid day - something I'm not really a fan of, but I understand is somewhat required in the heavily moisturizing products. I have rough patches on my heel and Achilles' tendon, and the product did help in those areas, but honestly I couldn't see a difference between this and something like CeraVe, which is my go-to moisturizer. Bang for the buck, I think I'll stick with my CeraVe, but the AHAVA did work well enough.

The Oceanique Tribal Chevron shower curtain is a nice external shower curtain. It is a fabric material so it will not block water - so you do need a shower liner for use with this curtain. The holes for the curtain hooks were only double-stitched rather than metal grommets, but they seem to be holding up well and I found no loose threads during installation.The curtain I received seem a lot more saturated for the Tribal Chevron pattern than shown on the Amazon page. The yellow really pops at you. The pattern is bold and bright but the colors (other than the yellow) are somewhat neutral. It'd probably look a little weird trying to mix in with a green or blue bathroom color scheme, but isn't bad overall.

The Phillips HD3095 Multicooker is an interesting device that's probably best suited for a smaller kitchen which don't have a lot of room for an array of gadgets. For basic purposes, the Multicooker can act as a slow cooker, a steamer, a (partial) skillet, and a small oven. The footprint is similar to a larger rice cooker, and in fact, if I didn't know better, I would have assumed that that is what this was. If I put it side-by-side with my Zojirushi 10 cup micom rice cooker, they'd take up around the same amount of space on the countertop.Performance-wise, it's not a great leap forward. Much like how slow cookers are convenient but don't seem to quite capture the true taste of a long roast in the oven, the Phillips Multi-cooker is the same. Having said that, I feel it does everything "well enough", especially for the sheer number of appliances the unit is attempting to emulate. Although my rice cooker has a steamer function, it doesn't do slow cooking well. My slow cooker doesn't steam well, and definitely doesn't do anything along the lines of baking. Neither rice nor slow cooker are very good at any high heat browning or sauteing. This multi-cooker can handle all the above tasks relatively well.

The AHAVA Time to Hydrate Active Moisture Gel Cream is an interesting product which doesn't feel quite as hydrating as the name suggests. The scent is both noticeable but not overpowering. Oddly enough, the product does not specifically say that it is non-comedogenic, so people who are prone to pore blockage may want to steer clear, or do some spot testing first."Gel cream" is a perfect description for the consistency of the product. It goes on wetter than a cream, but heavier than just a gel. Even with quite a bit of working, the moisturizer stays wet/tacky for a while, making me think it's not a great daytime match. There's also no built-in SPF protection, so you'd have to apply something else on top. For those with sensitive skin and allergies, while there are no parabens, the ingredient list includes a lot of acids, enzymes, and alcohols, as well as quite a few other chemicals. So test on a small area first.Personally I felt that my L'Occitane brand moisturizers blended better and made my skin smoother. I wouldn't say that the AHAVA didn't work, just that it didn't work as well comparatively.

The Proactive+ Redness Relief Serum works well for spot treating occasional redness and is a great addition to your overall skincare regimen, however the refrigeration requirement firmly places it in a "plan ahead" category of usage. You can't really store this in your purse/bag and bring it out to use on the fly. The serum feels nice and cooling (both due to refrigeration as well as formulation) when applied and since it is non-comedogenic, it doesn't feel heavy on the skin (and it would be weird for a product from ProActive to block pores). This is another time I wish I could give things half stars, as the product works well as intended, but also has quite a few drawbacks.The serum worked well enough on my random flare-ups and it is a nice product to have around, but I wouldn't call it a necessity for your regular day-to-day skincare maintenance. While per-use quantity is very small, the price point of this product is very high, although I expect this one tube to last me more than a year (I do not see myself using it extremely regularly - the tube also says to use a max of 3x's a week).For those with sensitive skin or allergies, this serum is chock full of glycols, glycerines, oxides, and ethanols. Make sure you won't be making your redness worse before using.

Currently I have been welding with an older Jackson auto darkening helmet. The helmet works perfectly fine, it was just starting to show its age. I was not expecting to see much of a difference in performance with the Jackson WH40 but I was pleasantly mistaken.The field of view on the WH40 is very nice, it has a slightly larger lens than my previous helmet but it makes quite the difference when the mask is only a few inches from your face. The clarity is superb, unlike most masks I have used where when not welding the lens is still quite dark and inhibits your eye sight in poorly lit environments, this mask is not nearly as dim (while not welding). I am able to keep the mask on in between welds while working in my garage at night with bad lighting. The helmet is very light and fits comfortably on my head.The controls on the helmet are pretty straight forward. Press a setting button, it shows you that setting's level on the display, press the button again and it increases the level by 1. There are adjustments for sensitivity, shade, delay and a toggle mode for welding or grinding. It took me about a min to get the helmet adjusted to my liking. Just make an adjustment, strike a quick ark, rinse and repeat if necessary or move on to the next setting.Overall I think this is a fantastic welding helmet. It definitely surpasses my expectations for a helmet in this price range, and I enjoy welding with it.

The Dr Infrared Heater 18 cuft system is a nice little compact system for roasting items you might have after taking a nice trip. My home is currently bedbug free and I'd like it to remain that way, so tossing not-easily-washable items is what this device is good for. While it's too small for your larger suitcases, it can fit most of your carry-on style bags (with some modification of the internal racks). The fan isn't whisper quiet, but it's also not jetliner loud, and it gets toasty pretty quickly, especially in the summer here in Texas where it's already warm out anyway.A nice little unit for peace of mind for small to medium sized items.

This Belkin CAT 5E cable works as expected. The flat form factor is nice for traveling as it winds up nicer than traditional round cables. While shielded to the 5E specifications, it's not very bulky or stiff (especially when compared to CAT6~ cables). If you still need a wired cable for travel, this isn't a bad one to pick. It's also a good option for permanent installations as the flat cable is less intrusive behind furniture or under items.

The Belkin Wired Tablet Keyboard with Stand is a very specific function keyboard. It's got a pretty large foot print which doesn't make it very portable. The stand portion does not fold down and stays poking, making storage a challenge as well - the angle is also static, so no adjusting. The keys are a cheap scissor switch style which do not feel that great (if you're a keyboard snob like me). They feel worse than the default keys on many laptops - very reminiscent of those $15 keyboards you'd find in a big box office store.So everything about this keyboard is very mediocre, nothing stands out. So the question becomes, would it be better to have a case with kickstand and a plain wired keyboard instead?The immediate win for this keyboard is the all-in-one factor. All you'd need is a tablet (or phablet) and this keyboard and you're ready to go. No worrying about a case and keyboard or if your device has enough juice to connect via Bluetooth at the moment.For my tablets, I've already invested in cases that do weird origami in order to sit in a couple of different viewing positions. I also much prefer the feel of my Poker 3 Keyboard and am willing to deal with the size differential there for the benefit of the better typing feel. However, when I don't want to use that space, I still think my SHARKK Aluminum Bluetooth Keyboard is still a better keyboard.Now, having said all that, if you need a static stand with a wired keyboard, this isn't a bad investment. It's just that the use scenarios are very specific. It might be good for a classroom lecture or for taking meeting notes for those instances when you don't have a laptop. This might also be an alternative for those non-technical family members who hate touchscreens and need a physical keyboard to write emails or even browse the internet on their tablets. For most people though, the case + keyboard combo will probably still remain more useful.

This Elmer's Freestyle glasses holder is an interesting little accessory which isn't quite up to the Command Adhesive level of usefulness yet. When you receive the product, the first thing you'll notice is that the adhesive backing is about three times the size of the actual glasses holder. It also requires a perfectly smooth surface to adhere well. My walls are textured drywall and the adhesive was not happy about it. Even after letting it sit for a couple of hours before even adding the tray, it'd slowly fall off after a day or so. Putting it on a smooth surface - like the side of my fridge - worked out much better (but I didn't really need it there). If you are planning on wall mounting this tray and have smooth walls with a gloss or semi-gloss latex paint, it should be fine.  Wallpaper, textured, or matte finishes probably won't work well. I'd pick a Command tray over this one in a heartbeat, but if you have the perfect surface, it works well enough.

The Dyson V6 Mattress is another offering in their barrage of handheld units released for 2015. I believe it is by far the cheapest offering in their current line up. For the price, the biggest thing you're losing is the extension tube, which in my eyes really removes the functionality of this little unit to possibly act as a vacuum replacement for smaller homes/apartments. Without the extension tube, this is more or less a pure handheld vacuum only (unless you plan on getting on your hands and knees to vacuum your floors). For the cost, unless you absolutely need the motorized mattress tool, I would say that the Dyson V6 Cordless Vacuum is a better all-around purchase as far as bang-for-your-buck is concerned.Cost analysis out of the way, this is a great handheld comparable to all of the other current Dyson handheld offerings. I used the V6 Mattress on my Steelcase Leap Chair and it picked up about half a sugar packet's worth of gray dust. Running it over a velvet-ish chair which my Shiba uses as his window lookout picked up all the hair and accumulated dust with ease. I even did a little spot cleaning on the carpet and it worked great. Moving on to the mattress, an item of note - if you have any loose fabric covering the mattress, such as sheets or a mattress protector, the motorized head will stall out. The tool needs to be on a taut surface to work - so heavy comforters or quilts will be fine, otherwise you'll have to remove them before using the vacuum. Since I use a mattress protector and Tempurpedics have a closed-cell architecture, the vacuum did not pull a lot of dust out. When I used it on the guest bed which also had a protector but was a box spring design, it did pull out a bit more, but nothing awe-inspiring. Lesson here - buy a dust proof mattress protector.For curiosity, I broke out my old Dyson Mattress Tool and stuck it on my full-sized Animal upright. Even though the mattress tool isn't motorized, the canister motor is nearly twice as powerful (100AW vs 180AW) so it worked just as well if not better than the handheld. So if you already have an full-sized canister vac, you're better off picking up a mattress tool attachment in my opinion. The canister is obviously bulkier, but you don't have to worry about power. Speaking of power, running with the MAX setting along with the motorized head, I'd say you get around 10 minutes of full power before the vacuum starts to get a bit laggy. If you were curious, you cannot run the vacuum while it is plugged in.In the box, you get your standard Dyson attachments of the mini soft dusting brush, the crevice tool, and the combo-accessory tool. This unit did not include a wall mount. As with most of the handhelds, there's no real storage option for the other accessories. They don't snap onto the handheld unit and there's no real storage rest included.If I were to rate this unit as a standalone and pretending none of the other Dyson units were out there, I'd say it was a fine machine with powerful suction for a handheld unit. The charge is mediocre and probably wouldn't last you through a single thorough cleaning of a large (queen+) mattress, much less multiple mattresses without recharging. It is a great tool for doing spot cleans of mattresses and fabric-based furniture though. Since the unit does not have any sort of flexible tubing, it does make getting into tighter spots a bit more challenging since you basically have to be able to fit the entire unit where you want to clean.Since this is not the only handheld unit Dyson offers, I'd say that losing the extension tube really relegates this model to a role as a spot cleaner - which is fine if that's what you're looking for. However, unless the motorized mattress tool is an absolute must-have, the other models in the handheld line are probably a better option for people thinking about using this as their only vacuum.

The Hello Kitty Trapper Keeper is your standard plastic style Trapper Keeper - basically a generic three ring binder with a closing flap. The rings use the generic snap enclosure, and there are pockets on each flap of the keeper, two in total. The pockets are made of the same thin plastic material that covers the inside of the binder. When I received the binder, it had been left outside in the Texas heat for a few hours already - the temps today reaching around 102 (it was probably 90ish in the shade when I picked up the package). Needless to say, the plastic was very malleable and the inside pocket was already slightly warped open. If you're planning on using this as a every day binder where it'll spend most of its time indoors in a locker, it should be ok, but I wouldn't consider it a good go-to for any hot weather (assuming you wanted to use the side pockets).The art is very cute and neatly printed, and the button enclosure snaps together nicely. However I can't see this justifying the exhortation price difference when compared to a simple generic 3-ring binder, or for the same price, I'd rather pick up a Five Star binder.

You know what you're getting yourself into when you get an Otterbox. It's almost like buying a Pelican case for your phone. It's big, it's clunky, but it's like putting a vault around your phone. These Defenders are the absolute archetypal examples of the big, clunky, phone case. In the case of the S6, it feels like you'r doubling - maybe getting close to tripling - the overall size of your phone. If you decide to use the belt holster, it's like being transported back to the 90's and having a two-way text pager on your belt.If I had a gripe about the Defender, it'd be how aggressively the holster holds on to the phone. I've actually ended up dropping my phone because of the pressure required to uncouple the phone from the holster. Needless to say, there wasn't a scratch on the phone thanks to the Defender, but it was still a pain. I tend to ignore the holster and just pop the phone with case in a pocket.The buttons work great, zero issues with the screen, and the case is a pain to put on for the first time, but after that, I have no qualms about performance. This thing is a tank and will protect your phone as well as you can probably ever expect a case to protect a phone.

I received this personal coin bank in exchange for a review. Its pretty simple really. Its a clear plastic container, with a plastic lid, that has a battery powered (two AAA not included) coin counter in it. You push the coins (any U.S coins) through the slot and it digitally counts so you know how much is in the jar. (You can manually change the amount by using the + and  buttons on top of the bank.)Its a nice little bank for my daughter, and if you have kids, it is a good way to get them to save and see how their money grows as they save.

I received this GoPro accessory kit from Vanwalk in exchange for an honest review. I find it to be a great set of accessories for a GoPro camera, especially for the price Vanwalk is selling the kit for. Some of the stuff I this kit you might not need or use, but a couple items stand out. The chest and head strap are two of the most useful items. I cant compare them with the chest and head straps from GoPro, but these work just fine.The little tripod is sturdier than I thought it would be and is handy. The extendable selfie stick isnt as solid as the larger black ones with the clips like a tripod when extending it. But for a very small light stick, it is okay. The suction cup works, but I like one I have that has two suction cups a bit better.The floating hand grip will be handy when at the river or lake, and all the other accessories are good to have on hand just in case. (extra mounts, screws, wrench, etc.) I havent used them all yet, and might not even use some, but this is still a great accessory kit for the price they are selling it for.If you have a GoPro or similar camera, this is a value pack of accessories that will help you get the most out of your camera.

My wife and I take CoQ10 supplements regularly and feel they are an important part of our supplements and diet. These softgel capsules are easy to take and provide a daily dose of CoQ10.The are a soft gel like many CoQ10 supplements, and contain 100mg coenzyme ubiquinone per 1 capsule. Each contains 5mg of BioPerine Black Pepper which is supposed to help with bioavailablitly and enhanced absorption.It is actually pretty difficult to evaluate many supplements as they don't really make you feel different, etc. However, they are helping you inside. And that is why we take CoQ10 supplements, and have no problem recommending this brand from Viva Labs.

I was provided this RFID blocking money belt in exchange for a review, and find it to be a well made money belt that will hold money, phone, passport, etc. Its made out of nylon, but has a RFID blocking lining. I have not tested it with something that reads RFID, so taking them on their word and description.There is a large compartment and two smaller compartments, as well as a couple of pockets on the inside that goes next to your body in the mesh. This easily holds my phone, passport, money and credit cards.I believe it is a good idea to keep your valuables tucked away and out of site. This money belt will help you do just that.

The Gaiam Performance Yoga Mat Bag works great to carry your yoga mat and yoga towel. The mat fits well in the main compartment, and then there is a separate compartment with breathable mesh for sweaty stuff, like your towel when done. There is also a small zippered pocked for your keys, phone, and such. The strap is adjustable.This is a pretty basic bag that is designed for a yoga mat, but could be used for other items. I like that it is black, as that is a bit more masculine than some of the mats you can get.It does exactly what it is supposed to do. Very good yoga mat bag.

Sadly, RFID blocking sleeves are needed. There are people out there who will use technology to rip you off, and with the new RFID (Radio-frequency identification) readers, they can steal your credit card number, information on your passport, etc. without you even knowing it.While you may have never heard of RFID before, chances are you are using them right now. RFID chips are found in passports, credit cards, pet finders, transportation payments or easy-passes, hospitals, retail stores and a number of other areas where information is needed to be scanned quickly easily for identification.This information on these cards can be easily read via a $50 credit card reader picked up on eBay by just about anyone. The readers store your credit card number, expiration date and CCV number with a quick pass of your pocket or wallet. Criminals are now using technology to up the strength to increase the distance in which they can scan your card to ensure they have good standoff from the scene of the crime. Some reports are showing your cards can be scanned from 20-30' away.The good news is that you can protect your information and credit card numbers by using something to block the radio-frequency. While there are different wallets and cases available, RFID blocking sleeves are often the easiest, and allow you to continue to use your favorite wallet or purse.I was provided a set of these RFID Blocking Sleeves by RFID SECURE and find them to be an excellent safeguard for your credit cards and passports. The set comes with 10 credit card sleeves and two passport sleeves. Using these will prevent your chip containing cards to be read without you knowing about it.Passport RFID blocking sleeves: I tried the sleeves with my credit cards and passports and all of them fit snugly, but well. I had no problems putting cards in at all. The sleeves are sturdy and not as flimsy as some I've seen. These should last quite a while with regular use.Since I teach people to be safe for a living, I recommend these or some other form of RFID blocking protection. These sleeves are just one more layer towards keeping you and your belongings more safe. Recommended for anyone traveling with a passport and/or credit cards.

I was provided this Double Suction Cup Mount for GoPro cameras from Smatree for review. I find it to be a very good mount. I've been impressed with Smatree's accessories for GoPro and other small cameras.I don't have a GoPro brand suction cup to compare this with, but I am quite pleased with the quality of this mount. The suction cups are strong, and the rest of the mount is solidly built. The key is to have a clean flat surface to fix this to. With that done, it will hold your GoPro camera, or other camera/cell phone that you might attach.Very good suction cup mount!

I was provided this Telescopic Pole for GoPro and other small cameras from Wareway for a review. I find it to be a great extension pole for my GoPro camera and my cell phone.It comes with the telescopic pole, wrist strap, a GoPro adapter to attach your GoPro to the pole (You will need a screw, a removable holder for the wireless control, a Bluetooth wireless control, a cell phone holder to attach your cell phone to the pole, and a small cloth bag to keep the smaller accessories in.I like these black extension poles with the clips to lock it at the desired length much better than the aluminum selfie sticks.  While those work fine for cell phones and small cameras, they just aren't as stable and sturdy as this type. This pole is lightweight, but also pretty sturdy. The end of this rotates and locks in place so you get just the angle you want.I like having a pole like this with me when I film the various videos for my websites. I use it more with my cell phone than GoPro. This pole by Wareway works great and is a quality made accessory. Recommended for anyone looking for an extension pole for their GoPro or other camera.

Spy Secrets That Can Save Your Life: A Former CIA Officer Reveals Safety and Survival Techniques to Keep You and Your Family Protected is a book by Jason Hanson, who has become more popular since appearing on ABC's Shark Tank and making a deal with Daymond John. Despite the CIA angle that is used for marketing, this book contains some solid advice on safety, security and survival.The book is written in a conversational style that is easy to understand and conveys information that most people really should know. I teach the same and similar information in my safety programs. The book is divided into these twelve chapters:One: Survival Intelligence. A good primer on being self-reliant and why you should know the information in this book. I really like that he points out that movement saves lives.Two: Situational Awareness. The cornerstone of staying safe, and Hanson bases his chapter on the classic color code of Col. Cooper. I liked that he also includes some pre-incident indicators and the concept of establishing a baseline.Three: Your Spy Escape And Evasion Kit. Good basic guide to gear to have on you, in your car, at your home, and ready to bug out.Four: Become An Escape Artist. This chapter teaches the basics to escape from rope, handcuffs, zip ties and duct tape. Also explains the basics of hot wiring a car, and how to break car windows. Very bare bones information on picking locks.Five: The Impenetrable Home. Strategies to criminal proof your home such as thinking like a criminal, delivery people, casing your own home, dogs, peepholes, doors, locks, alarms, lighting, windows, and so on.Six: Travel Safety. Tip to travel safe. These include when flying, taxis, hotels, and where you go.Seven: How To Run Countersurveillance Like a Pro. Most people are probably not being followed, but knowing how to tell if someone is following you and what to do it good to know. This chapter covers the basics regarding this topic.Eight: Social Engineering Secrets. I liked that he included this because it is important to understand to help keep yourself from being ripped off with scams, or being lured into something bad.Nine: How To Be A Human Lie Detector. This chapter examines some of the basic ways you can determine if someone is lying.Ten: How To Disappear Without A Trace. I like that Hanson points out that it is much more difficult to live off the grid and disappear than it used to be. With that said, he provides some tips for those that for some reason need to disappear.Eleven: The Art Of Survival Driving. Hanson teaches a survival driving course in Utah, and this chapter is an introduction to the topic with a few basics explained like the Reverse 180 and how to ram a car. Some good basic tips on being safe while driving also included.Twelve: Defending Yourself. Short chapter on what you can learn, with a plug for tactical pens which Hanson sells at his website. (I actually have a number of tactical pens, including the one Hanson sells, and it is a good pen for defensive purposes if needed.) Short chapter that gets you thinking about what you need to do in order to learn to defend yourself.Overall, I like the book because I am all for everything to help people live safer lives so they can enjoy the good stuff. It is a basic book, with resources out there that go more in depth on all the topics covered. However, it is nice to have all these basics in one volume, and then people can learn more on the topics they need to know more about for their lifestyle.It's a quick, easy read with some basic, practical information that will help people stay safe.

6:42 Mins The anti-theft travel rucksacks and luggage from Numinous Packs are excellent for the security minded traveler. Designed with anti-theft technology, these packs help keep your belongings safe while traveling.I was provided a 65L pack to review and find it to be an excellent pack back. It encompasses the Numinous layered security system that consists of the anti-slash material that has Kevlar in it, the TSA approved zipper locks on the main compartment and the laptop compartment, anti-puncture zippers, and a cable lock so you can secure your pack to a fixed object.The security features of this pack add a little weight, but not enough to matter a lot. The website lists it at 3.5 KG or about 7.7 pounds. I don't find it that heavy. Here are the main features of this pack:Large main compartment with compression straps inside and that opens full length. This is very handy for this larger back pack in that you don't have to search way down inside the pack or dump everything out. The compression straps help keep things in place and also help protect the pack from over packing.Padded laptop compartment. This compartment also has zippered mesh pockets inside to hold thin items.Anti-puncture zippers and TSA approved zipper locks on both compartments. These zippers are harder puncture with pens, etc. Makes it harder to get into this bag when using the TSA approved locks, which you can change the combination, and TSA can open with their keys.Covers for zippers to conceal and protect them.Anti-slash material that has Kevlar in it which is much stronger than regular nylon material.Carrying handles on top and side that are strong and make it easy to pick up the pack.Padded back pack straps and belt that hide away under flap. These are adjustable to ensure a good fit regardless your size.Mesh pockets inside and on side of pack. The outside pocket are great for water bottles or other items you need to access easily and quickly.Cable lock to secure pack to a fixed objectThis pack is extremely well made and durable with features specifically designed to help keep your belongings safe and secure. Highly recommended, especially for those who like to back pack around in different countries. I would have really liked this pack when I was back packing around Thailand and other Asian countries. Excellent pack for the security minded.

These ZIG Whey Protein Portable Shake packets are convenient, but not the best tasting protein powder I've used. With that said, I usually mix protein powders with milk at home, and with these I mixed with water when out and away from a refrigerator and milk.I didn't they tasted bad, but not as good as others. I should also point out that it mixes very well with water. There is a thing inside called a mixing mesh that is supposed to help, and I guess it does because it does mix well. This is just a protein drink that provides 20g of protein and has 140 calories. It is not a meal replacement and doesn't contain other vitamins and minerals, which I actually like. I like protein powders that are just protein.The worst thing about this product is that it is an awful lot of packaging for a small amount of protein powder. You have a box and the six plastic shaking containers. So you are paying for packaging and the convenience of being able to take a pack with you and mix with water wherever you happen to be. So if you need the one serving pouches that you can take with you, this is a good product if you don't mind paying extra for that convenience.

I've been using these gloves by Ring Side without wraps to workout with my 100 pound heavy bag, and like them just fine. They have a snug fit and protect my hands during workouts. I like the Velcro wrist strap that secures them, as these newer gloves with Velcro are so much easier than my old pairs with laces. These wrist straps tighten up well and stay secure when punching.The injected molded foam really does seem to allow more absorption of shock than the older style gloves. Since they are still fairly new, the shape and padding are still just right, but I expect them to be durable and good for many work outs.The leather striking surface, molded foam, and perforated palm to keep hands cool and dry (Sort of, if you are sweating a lot, this helps, but doesn't eliminate your hands being wet, and you still need to dry out and air out the gloves) all make these a great pair of gloves work heavy bag workouts.

The Sons of Anarchy board game Men of Mayhem is a cool game for fans of the show. In this day of video gaming, it's still nice to get with some friends to play a board game. The game is recommended for ages 13+ and you play with 3-4 players.Players take on the roles of different clubs: Mayans, One-Niners, Lin Syndicate and SAMCRO. As the subtitle states, the game is about money, guns, and violent consequences.  You want to occupy key locations and exploit profitable opportunities. Along the way you can bribe, threaten and bargain with rival clubs. If that fails, violence is always an option. Just do so without going to jail.At first you need to pay attention to the rules, but they aren't too hard or complicated to master. You just have to pay attention until you get the hang of it. There is enough variety and the way you play to keep future games different. And as you play, you learn strategies that will help you win.Fans of the show who enjoy board games will certainly like this game. Might fight over who gets to be witch club though. Those not familiar with the show may still enjoy it, but not quite the same as those who know the characters, clubs and such. Fun board game!

Legacy of the Bear: Book 1 of the Berserker's Saga by J.P. Ribner took me back to the science fiction and fantasy reading that I enjoyed when younger. I hadn't read a book in this genre for a long time, and I enjoyed this tale of coming to manhood in a land of warriors of Norse times. I'll get this out of the way up front, I don't like the cover. On the cover alone, I may not have read this book. So, don't let it cause you to pass this one by. While I don't like the cover, I did enjoy the read.The story is simple, but well told. It's the journey of a young warrior on his quest to become the warrior, or berserker, that his father was. He has to prove to others, but more importantly, prove to himself that he deserves the title of Berserker. To be worthy, he must face his inner demons as well as the external forces set to stop him. There are advisers to assist him, a love interest to temp him, and the villains to test him. All of which make it a good book.I found myself enjoying the story and caring about the characters. It was a fun and exciting read that was fast paced and kept me turning pages. Near the end, you are introduced to what lays ahead in the next books. And yes, while this adventure concluded, there is much more to come and you have to read the next book to see what happens next. (And Ribner does a good job of making you want to know what happens next.)Overall, if you are a fan of this genre, this is a quick read that you'll enjoy and want to continue to see where the story leads. Well done!

This is my first Epson printer, as I've owned HP and Cannon previously. I am happy with it and find it is a nice simple printer that does a very good job. One of the things I like the most is the double sided printing option. I print a lot of documents and I like being able to print on both sides to save some paper.While I primarily print documents and manuscripts, this is a nice printer to print photos to send to a few relatives that don't check pictures out on the computer that often. I've found the photo quality to be good. I just wish the price of ink wasn't what it is, but that isn't just Epson, all ink is expensive these days.The Epson XP-630 is also a pretty small printer, so good if you have limited space. It does mean you have to open up the trays, but again, it is nice if you have limited space.I haven't tried printing on a CD or DVD yet, but it is a cool added feature as well. The wireless feature that allows you to print from your phone or tablet is also a great addition compared to my older printers. You can also use this to scan, but since I have another scanner, I don't really use this feature on the printer.This is a very nice little printer for a home office.

It was getting where my laptop fan was running a lot, and it still seemed very hot on the right side. I was provided this cooling pad by LotFancy in exchange for a review, and it has helped a lot. I have been using it, and my laptop fan doesn't hardly come on at all anymore.It is a large pad, but still not quite as large as my laptop. (I have a 17 inch laptop) It is also pretty thick so the laptop sits up over an inch above the desk, table or whatever you are sitting it on.The cooling pad plugs into one of your USB ports, and that makes it convenient. There are two buttons on the back to turn on the larger fan and the small ones. There are also blue lights that come on. You can hear the fans, but they are not that noticeable. Not as noticeable as when my laptop fan turns on high.I am very happy with this laptop computer, and glad that my laptop fan is not working overtime like it was.

It's important to keep your money, credit cards, and passport safe while traveling. Not only are there pickpockets that will physically steal these items, the new thief can steal the information electronically. The Shacke RFID Pocket Vault Hybrid  Hidden Safety Travel Belt Wallet and Neck Stash helps you protect your items from both kinds of crooks.There are a number of these kinds of pouches available these days, but this one from Shacke is more thought out. I was provided one for free to provide and honest review, and I really like this design.First of all, it is made with an RFID blocking material to protect your passport and credit cards from being stolen from electronically. So that is a plus. You can still use an RFID blocking sleeve on your passport and credit cards if you wish, it would be overkill, but that isn't bad either.The wallet can be used with the neck strap hung under your shirt, or you can attack the belt loop on your belt and let it hang inside your pants. There are three compartments. This makes it easy to carry your most important items. Put your cash in the top font pocket, your credit cards in the bottom front pocket, and your passport and any larger item in the pocket that unzips down the side. (Note: The top front pocket goes all the way down the front of the wallet, so it is a deep pocket.) There are also two mesh pockets inside the larger compartment.There is also a driver's license pocket on the front with a clear plastic window and a fold down flap that secures with Velcro. This makes it easy to flip the flap up and show your picture ID if needed. The wallet even comes with an instruction card to make sure you get the most of your wallet, and contact information with an invitation to assist with any concerns.Bottom Line: The Shacke RFID Pocket Vault is a great traveling companion to store your money, credit cards, passport and other small valuables.

Steal the Show: From Speeches to Job Interviews to Deal-Closing Pitches How to Guarantee a Standing Ovation For All the Performances in Your Life by Michael Port is an excellent guide to not only public speaking, but as the title suggests, the book also provides information to help you connect with just one person at a time. This information can help you persuade, inform, and motivate others as you successfully attain and accomplish your goals.As an actor, author and speaker, Michael Port brings his unique experiences to show how anyone can make the most of any presentation, because as he explains, we are all performing all the time. The roles may be different, but the skills he teaches here will help everyone engage with those they are interacting with, regardless if in an office, boardroom, or from a stage in a large auditorium.Part one, the performer's mindset, includes chapters on finding your voice, playing the right role in every situation, and crushing your fears and silencing your critics. All of these lay an important foundation to prepare you to take the stage. (And anything can be your stage.)Part two, powerful performance principles includes chapters on having a clear objective, acting as if, raising the stakes, saying yes and, being in the moment, and choosing early and often. These topics make much more sense as Port describes them and illustrates them with real life stories.The third and final part, a master class in public speaking, includes chapters on how to craft captivating pitches, speeches and stories, how to create and tell stories that make em laugh or cry, how to rehearse and stage world-class performances, how to produce powerful openings, command closings, and amazingly interact with audiences, how to improvise into the hearts and minds of the toughest crowds, and how to get a standing ovation ever time. Again, Port provides excellent advice on these topics and illustrates each point with personal stories and examples.The world really is a stage, and we are all performing all the time. Michael Port has written an authoritative guide on how to Steal the Show. Practicing and implementing the strategies presented here will only help people succeed through better communication. Highly recommended.

This is an excellent set of yoga straps. They are six feet long and made of 100% cotton with a hard plastic buckle. They are very strong and well stitched.  I also like the color as they are a bit more masculine than some of the colored straps out there. There is a sewn on tag near the buckle that has the brand, HF Yoga on it.I've used them for different stretches and poses, and find them to work just like you want with no hint that they won't be strong enough. I'm sure they will last a long time too.I was provided a set of these in return for an honest review, and have no problem recommending them to anyone looking for a quality yoga strap.

This floating GoPro Grip Stick Pole Bobber is a nice lightweight accessory for your action camera. It is pretty simple, just a thick handle with a GoPro attachment on top to secure your camera. This attachment can be removed and you can attach any other camera or attachment (like those that hold cell phones) as the screw on top is standard size mount screw. There is also a standard size hole in the bottom. This isn't an extension pole, but rather a short grip to hold your camera. (It is easier to hold than holding the actual camera.)It comes with a wrist strap, but I don't know if I really like it attached to the top GoPro mount, and think it would be better to attach it to the bottom with a strap screw. I have those from other poles and like this a bit better.The handle is very smooth, and I was afraid it might be too slippery when wet, but even wet it was comfortable to hold onto and didn't slip like I thought. I still think I'd prefer a bit of texture or something. But as it is works fine and is comfortable to hold.The additional benefit of this handle is that it acts like a bobber and won't sink. If you were to drop your camera, this could definitely be a camera saver.I was provided one of these handles in return for an honest review and find it to be a very nice accessory for my GoPro cameras and would work for other cameras as well.

I was provided this set of canvas prints for an honest review, and I can honestly say that I really like them. The set of three canvas prints came in a large box undamaged and now look great hanging on our wall. It is a well made set and it is a very nice picture that makes the room brighten up.The mounting brackets are not attached when these arrive, so you do have to attach two to each print. This only takes a few minutes with a good screwdriver. Two screws for each bracket and two brackets for each print. There were three screws with each bracket, so you have a couple of extras.These are light enough that I just used one small nail per bracket to hang them. With a level and measuring tape, it wasn't that hard to hang them where they look good on the wall.I am very pleased with this set and recommend it highly to anyone else who also likes the picture.

I was sent a black jump rope to review and find it to be a decent rope for exercising. The rope is a rubber type material that you can really get spinning fast. (Don't hit yourself or anyone with it, as it will leave welts and hurt, but not quite as bad as a metal one.)The handles have a foam on them that is comfortable, but I wonder how long it will last. With a lot of use and sweat, I imagine this foam will wear out. The handle is hollow and you can take the end cap off to adjust the length of the rope. (There is a plastic thing on the rope inside the handle that you can adjust when you have the length you want.)Some people like heavier ropes, but for a light rope this one is a good piece of equipment for exercise.Recommended for those who jump rope in their exercise routines.

I was sent a pair of these yoga shorts to review and the first words that come to mind are Very Comfortable! These are right in line with other YogaAddict products I've reviewed, and that is high quality and comfort.The material has a little stretch to it, which is what helps make them very comfortable. There is a heavier waistband with a sturdy drawstring. This ties on the outside, as opposed to some that have the drawstring inside. There are no pockets, so if you need shorts with pockets, you should get something else.For an actual yoga workout, having something in your pocket could get in the way, so for the intended purpose, working out especially yoga workouts, these shorts without pockets are just right.Bottom line: These are a high quality pair of no pocket shorts for yoga and exercise, or just lounging. Oh, did I mention they are super comfortable?

Sadly, RFID blocking sleeves are needed. There are people out there who will use technology to rip you off, and with the new RFID (Radio-frequency identification) readers, they can steal your credit card number, information on your passport, etc. without you even knowing it.While you may have never heard of RFID before, chances are you are using them right now. RFID chips are found in passports, credit cards, pet finders, transportation payments or easy-passes, hospitals, retail stores and a number of other areas where information is needed to be scanned quickly easily for identification.This information on these cards can be easily read via a $50 credit card reader picked up on eBay by just about anyone. The readers store your credit card number, expiration date and CCV number with a quick pass of your pocket or wallet. Criminals are now using technology to up the strength to increase the distance in which they can scan your card to ensure they have good standoff from the scene of the crime. Some reports are showing your cards can be scanned from 20-30' away.The good news is that you can protect your information and credit card numbers by using something to block the radio-frequency. While there are different wallets and cases available, RFID blocking sleeves are often the easiest, and allow you to continue to use your favorite wallet or purse.I was provided a set of these RFID Blocking Sleeves by LINKYO to review and find them to be an excellent safeguard for your credit cards and passports. The set comes with 10 credit card sleeves and two passport sleeves. Using these will prevent your chip containing cards to be read without you knowing about it.I tried the sleeves with my credit cards and passports and all of them fit snugly, but well. I had no problems putting cards in at all. The sleeves are sturdy and not as flimsy as some I've seen. These should last quite a while with regular use.Since I teach people to be safe for a living, I recommend these or some other form of RFID blocking protection. These sleeves are just one more layer towards keeping you and your belongings more safe. Recommended for anyone traveling with a passport and/or credit cards.

I was provided a free mount from Ipow to review and find it to work fine, with a few things I didn't care for.It's a simple devise that holds your phone while driving. It works just fine, and I've driven around with it and I do like the placement of the phone and being able to easily use my phone with voice commands and on speaker.The few downsides are you have to attach a small metal panel (two came with it, one black and one metal mirror like) to the back of your phone case. There are a few of my cases I would not want to do this with. I selected one I didn't mind, and the provided metal panel stuck to it well. With this case, the phone attaches to the holder with no problem. I have an iPhone 6 plus, and the magnet holds it just fine.You have to clamp the other end of the holder into the air vent of your vehicle. This worked fine in my vehicles vent. However, it does take away from your air conditioning in the summer, and I'm not sure I want my phone in front of the vent when using the heater. It also moved side to side at times when cornering. It wasn't the holder that moved, but the way you can direct the air with the vent, that moved side to side.Except for the concern of using it while using the heater, the moving side to side was minimal and not that big of a deal.  I do like the phone in this position when driving, and will keep this mount and phone case together for when I want the phone mounted on the air vent.

I Want To Do Yoga Too by Carole P. Roman is a nice little book for any mom who wants her daughter to be introduced to yoga. (I don't think boys will be as interested in this book, but that might just be my gender bias.)The story is about a little girl, Hallie, who learns how to do some simple yoga poses. Cute story for a limited audience. I'm guess only moms who do yoga will want to read this book to their daughters.

We were provided this little mesh beach bag for review and find it to be a convenient little bag to take along to the river, beach, pool or any other similar place. I think the best thing about it is how it folds up into the small pouch that is attached so you never lose it. This makes is so convenient to take along and it is available to use when you need it.The mesh bag is big enough to hold quite a bit. Towels, wet clothes, toys, etc. There is a drawstring to cinch it shut and the carry handles work well and seem like they will last even when loading the bag up.When you are using the mesh bag you can put small things into the small carry pouch, so this serves another function.Overall, this is a nice bag for beach, river or pool outings.

There are people out there who will use technology to rip you off, and with the new RFID (Radio-frequency identification) readers, they can steal your credit card number, information on your passport, etc. without you even knowing it.While you may have never heard of RFID before, chances are you are using them right now. RFID chips are found in passports, credit cards, pet finders, transportation payments or easy-passes, hospitals, retail stores and a number of other areas where information is needed to be scanned quickly easily for identification.This information on these cards can be easily read via a $50 credit card reader picked up on eBay by just about anyone. While there are different wallets and cases available, RFID blocking sleeves are often the easiest, and allow you to continue to use your favorite wallet or purse.I was provided a set of these RFID Blocking Sleeves by Protectif and find them to be an excellent safeguard for your credit cards and passports. The set comes with 10 credit card sleeves and two passport sleeves.
