Technically, keeping legendary, emergency improviser Angus MacGyver in your glove box would be both inhumane and illegal but thankfully "DBPOWER" has developed a digital tire gage that performs many of the same functions including: glass-breaking hammer, seat-belt cutting blade, scissors and standard/Phillips screwdriver (all retractable swiss-army knife style) and last but not least a fairly respectable flashlight.  Oh ya, and it's also a digital tire gage (the reason most folks will buy I'm assuming) which includes 4 different measurement modes (PSI being one) with a contact that doesn't allow air to leak out in order to get an accurate reading and finally, there's a built in LED light just under said contact for taking a reading in poor lighting (e.g. at night or if perhaps you've been taken hostage by foreign spies and they're keeping you and your car in a dark warehouse and after making a daring escape you want to ensure there's enough air in the tires without tipping them off by turning on a light).Yes the "9-in1" gage is gimmicky but it also appears well-made and fairly durable and being roughly the size of a medium-sized flashlight, it can be easily stored both inconspicuously and within easy reach in your vehicle.  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review].  :o)

Ya know, I've seen some unbelievably cheesy films on MST3K over the years but I can't recall ever watching one so abysmally boring (either Joel or Mike era) as "Radar Secret Service".  I can imagine moviegoers of the 1950's standing in line after leaving the theater, paying to be beaten silly with nerf-bats after enduring this snore-fest about G-men using what was apparently technology that had captured the public imagination at the time (i.e. radar) to foil the absolutely unintelligible plans of some gangsters; all are dressed in full suits (with hats) almost indistinguishable from one another, all drive REALLY big cars (one with a radar on top) and spend scene after scene in said cars driving through fields and pastures (and occasionally a city street) chasing each other and talking about radar... lots and lots of talking about radar.Mike and the bots do their utmost to make an episode out of "Radar Secret Service" but it's such an utterly vacuous film to begin with that their best couldn't get more than a couple of chuckles out of me (although I did enjoy the short).  Please rent before buying.  :o)

I'm always wary when I rent a horror flick (suddenly popping up in the streaming world out of nowhere) with opening credits that seem to insist it's both outstanding and highly anticipated.[Not-so-spoiler-lite synopsis] Two American adventure seekers (one of whom is so cool that he wears his stocking cap tilted back cowboy style) are on holiday in Exmoor (abbreviated to Xmoor in the title for added edginess) in the southwest of England to capture footage of a mysterious creature and win a $40K prize (which would totally allow them to go film other stuff in other places cuz filming is what they do).  Five minutes into their expedition they narrowly escape a pair of pranksters who project a flaming car at their VW microbus, THEN they arrive at a ruined cottage where they meet a strung-out survivor (she's actually strung out on drugs not like, strung out on fear) of an attack by the creature only to have the McGuffin twins suddenly reappear, assaulting the female adventure seeker and subsequently being chased off at gunpoint by their animal-tracking expert guide named Fox (hey, at least they didn't name him Wolf).  The team finally arrives at the forest of the alleged sightings as night falls thus allowing them to stumble upon a cache of dead bodies (traumatizing them almost beyond their emotional endurance) and a horrific discovery of the true nature of "the beast" (which is actually less horrific than a non-metaphor based "beast" would've been).I thought the subgenre switcheroo was clever but I gotta mention I find it off-putting in an age of sexual equality, when a horror movie feels the need to have the guys go into risk-their-lives mode for the woman on the team knowing full well she's gonna be the only survivor anyway (oops did I spoil... naaaah).  I was also a little disappointed to discover that the stocking cap sporting boyfriend who looked an awful lot like Lance Hunter from Agents of SHIELD was one-in-the-same actor Nick Blood which is I suppose a testament to the actor's versatility in pulling off such a spineless douche.Unfortunately there isn't a likeable character for miles in this story that's so busy it ends up being a hot mess (I hate clichs but there it is), making "The Beast of Xmoor" a movie I wouldn't watch a second time... or even a first time had I known about its inherent hot-messness qualities in advance.  :o)

*giggles uncontrollably*  No but seriously, this is a very nice 5-piece set of measuring cups which include the standard sizes however I would mention that they are the stainless steel variety and therefore: EZPZ to clean, incredibly sturdy (in case you happen to leave them in the driveway), resistant to melting like a plastic set would if you left it on the stove next to a burner, etc.They very much remind me of another set I recently reviewed however the thing about the "Fresho" cups is that you can actually remove the rubber handles (for whatever insidious purpose) not to mention these guys give a lifetime warranty although I can't imagine needing to buy another set for a very long time.  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review].  :o)

This is a tale from the DC multi-verse centered on a Superman who is the son of general Zod, a Wonderwoman that is the granddaughter of Highfather and Batman as a vampire.On the plus side we get more of the wonderful animation we've come to expect from the Warner Bros. animation studios and a very engaging story including lots of great characters.  On the downside, I think it's a shame that DC Comics feels the need to pepper their animated films with gratuitous profanity and graphic violence, personally I don't think it fits the franchise as we don't see it in the comics (usually) or the live-action films.  Whether I'm watching anime or domestically produced animation "mature" content just feels more adolescent than adult in this medium and I really wish the studio would dial it back to PG.All that aside, I thought "Justice League: Gods and Monsters" was decidedly better than some of the other animated films the studio's been churning out lately (looking at you "War" and "Son of Batman") featuring slightly more thoughtful dialogue and again a pretty interesting story from start to finish.  :o)

"True Story" is a riveting mystery/drama about a man accused of a heinous crime that, through the strangest of circumstances, develops a relationship with a successful journalist from within prison.This film is guaranteed to keep the viewer completely engaged via a refreshingly unpredictable story that helps one to remain on the edge of their seat and in the dark till almost the final moments.  Is alleged murderer Christian Longo (James Franco) an innocent man trying desperately to cover for someone else or is he a cold-hearted psychopath?  Is journalist Michael Finkel (Johah Hill) simply an opportunist with a keyboard exploiting the misery of others to write a successful novel or is he himself being cleverly manipulated?  Franco plays the part of a mysterious prisoner haunted by his past par excellence while Hill portrays the keen journalist and confidante with credibility and their peculiar relationship unfolds, along with the events surrounding Longo's upcoming trial, through a series of remarkable scenes including a climactic and revealing confrontation between Franco and Finkel's wife, played by Felicity Jones.I was a little surprised when I saw Brad Pitt's name in the credits under associate producer however I suppose it just goes to show the talent behind such an excellent, modern thriller and I highly recommend you ignore the critics and give this one a rent (particularly if you're a Franco fan like myself).  :o)

WOW do these things ever block out light!  For me one of the most unlikable features of other sleep masks I've tried in the past is the fact that they smoosh my eyeballs, but not so with this little number from  "Drift to Sleep" as the area right above your eyes is cleverly raised which displaces any pressure and makes for a much more comfortable rest.  I think I mentioned that these things will make a day at the beach pitch black but let me also point out that they have a Velcro strap so as to preclude pulling it over your head (mussing up your hair) AND even comes with earplugs as an added perk in what I thought was a fairly stylish little case.  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review].  :o)

This combination coffee press/mug may seem a little intimidating at first but it's relatively simple: put the grounds in the cup, secure the top with plunger, pour some hot water through the flip-top and immediately enjoy your very own freshly brewed cup of java.  Grounds won't make it through the wire mesh and rubber edged plunger even when you increase the strength by moving it and holy cats does it ever keep warm for a remarkably long time.  Very slick innovation on what would be a nice, little coffee mug even without the press.  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review].  :o)

This is a sleepy little monster flick with elements of a disaster movie that maintains a fairly respectable creepy factor right out of the gate.Kevin Durand plays a grieving parent who is also tasked with being the sheriff of a small town plagued by recent encounters with a mysterious animal that does stuff like chase off the local wildlife, leave strange footprints all over town and occasionally engage in breaking and entering.  The police force, consisting of Durand and a deputy (played by Lukas Haas), spend the majority of the film investigating while the creature furtively harasses the townsfolk and brutally kills any animals that didn't have the sense to bail all the while building some legitimate suspense."Dark was the Night" features a remarkably good cast (kudos to the casting director) with special emphasis on Durand and Haas who are what I considered to be the film's greatest strength.  Unfortunately, the production team didn't seem to have had adequate funds for populating the small town with extras making it feel strangely deserted, and add to that a noticeable lack of scene-padding dialogue or ambient noise in general, other than scoring of the variety that Crow T. Robot once referred to as a "Yanni lick", all making this movie feel like it had taken a healthy dose of Ambien.In spite of moving at a snail's pace, it's a fairly engaging horror with some decent jump moments but I would point out that the creature itself is better left unseen as it turns out to be fully CGI and well... let's just say they must've hired the same FX studio that Syfy channel uses.  I would recommend it for a rental but please don't expect a non-stop action-packed thrill-ride and you shouldn't be disappointed. :o)

Ethan, Nick, Chris and Andrew are four, at large thrill-seekers with an obsession for practical jokes; in fact they have their very own successful web series called "Prankmasters".  Unfortunately, as is the case with so many habitual smart-asses, they have a hard time knowing when enough is enough and after the cool/handsome member of the group (i.e. Ethan) gets married the remaining three decide to use his honeymoon as an opportunity to play a cabin-in-the-woods/home-invasion ultimate prank.  Time spent with the guys however slowly begins to reveal they walk a fine line between being playfully juvenile and socially dysfunctional and when the elaborately staged joke fails miserably the situation becomes deadly.Employing a relatively unique theme for an indie horror, "The Jokesters" features top-notch production values and a likable cast who succeeded in conveying the profound awkwardness of the initial situation and had me invested in the story by the time it cleverly descended into terror.  Highly recommended for a rental.  :o)

Ok, I'll admit I never knew what the little, slotted hole on the base of my laptop was until I received an offer for the "Ruban Security Cable" in exchange for an honest review.Granted protecting one's PC is important, but so is not appearing to be a hyper-paranoid dork which is why it's an added perk that this particular theft deterrent is relatively stylish and inconspicuous in addition to functionality. I suspect you'd need bolt-cutters to "liberate" a laptop from the sturdy (and thankfully coated) cable and the combination lock couldn't be more intuitive.I think this would be a perfect little gift for that student heading off to college; it rolls up nice to fit in a backpack pocket or probably any computer bag for that matter.  :o)

The Q800 is a very impressive Bluetooth headset: with a 10hr battery life for music (I left mine on all night and the next morning I got a message saying "battery level high") and featuring a unique neck band that rests comfortablly and head movement doesn't jerk the earbuds, it's actually a clever innovation as you don't have the connecting cable just dangling free like other models.  The buttons (skip/play volume and phone) are large enough and distinct in shape so that you can feel them with your fingers (Braille style) and I prefer an actual power switch over a button (making it more difficult to leave on accidentally) with a blue LED light as a reminder.  The sound quality is excellent as long as the buds are fully inserted (comes with additional, different sized padded covers) and you can actually move a fair distance from your device (Kindle Fire in my case) before the signal cuts out.This is the third Bluetooth headset I've reviewed for Soundpeats and I continue to be impressed by not only the quality of their product but that everything you need is not only in the box but always well-packaged along with easy to understand and thorough instructions.  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review]  :o)

It seems as if Syfy has finally come to terms with their own identity; one which doesn't include qualities like originality, creativity or being on the cutting edge of anything in particular but rather one for sampling, splicing and b-grade production values in general which makes "Killjoys" refreshing in that it's unpretentious and without delusions of grandeur (looking at you Defiance).The first question that came to mind while watching the pilot episode (free btw... thanks amazon) was where the heck did they find their lead actress?  Aside from being slightly gorgeous, Hannah John-Kamen can act and then there's her sidekick played by Aaron Ashmore (twin brother of X-men's Shawn Ashmore) both of whom definitely sell their roles as space bounty hunters, unfortunately it's stuff like sets, props, the underwear model playing their third partner and not to mention the plot that are all just so frigg'n bleh.  Look, I get that this show prolly doesn't have a stellar budget but I mean come one... 80's era Doctor Who had more science fiction ambiance than Killjoys making the latter feel more like a slightly futuristic action/drama and not a particularly interesting one at that.I honestly can't imagine a snooze-fest like this ever seeing a 2nd season but then again I've been wrong before... either way here's hoping Syfy will use these two talented actors on other (better) future shows.  :o)

I must say "Seventh Son" is a visually remarkable film featuring some gorgeous cinematography which provides a sort of metaphor for the relatively simple yet nevertheless engaging plot that's unfortunately used like these scenic shots as mere backdrop for just another thoroughly uninspiring (and maybe even boring), young-adult romance. I don't think I'm going too far in saying that Jeff Bridges is playing the only really remarkable character and furthermore giving the only memorable performance (albeit difficult at times to understand) in what felt like an otherwise hastily put together and even more hastily concluded fantasy flick.  Not saying it's bad by any means but I would recommend renting before buying.  :o)

Rather than repeat specifications for this power bank, which are clearly displayed on this product page, let me say that right out of the box I charged the "Foxnovo 10400mah" to 100% within a matter of minutes and used it to charge my Kindle Fire and my blackberry (twice) and still had power left over.  Very impressed with how rapidly this bank charges both itself and other devices and not to mention it both feels and looks very durable (maybe even a little sci-fi) and I like that it comes with a single cable that can be used on multiple port configurations and last but not least its intuitive simplicity. [I received this product in exchange for an honest review]  :o)

The Vic Tsing (Gold-Plated) 1080P HDMI to VGA Adapter Video Converter is a handy patch if you have an older monitor with VGA only; basically the VGA to HDMI is one unit while the sound cable and USB power cord are included and although there were no instructions (the reason i'm subtracting a star) I suspect most folks who buy something like this have a pretty good idea what to do. I experimented with my Viewsonic VX2452mh monitor by swapping this cable for DVI and although I wouldn't recommend it for gaming it definitely does what it claims (i.e. analog/digital converter).  [I received this product in exchange for an honest review]  :o)

Let me start off by confessing that a little comedy goes a long way with me, however I am a Jim Gaffigan fan and so when I read that TV Land was producing a sitcom starring said comedian I just had to check it out.Episode 1 introduces the viewer to Gaffigan (as himself) his wife (Ashley Williams) and 5 kids along with a BFF (Adam Goldberg) as well as the parish priest (Tongayi Chirisa).  The "Super Great Daddy" is home from a tour and moderately enthused about getting involved in the daily household routine but it quickly becomes apparent that this isn't exactly his forte (putting it mildly).If you're familiar with Gaffigan then you know his standup is usually pretty PG but please be aware that this series might swing just a smidgen in the more mature category, albeit tastefully mature as he certainly doesn't specialize in raunchy in-your-face style humor. Although scripted (Gaffigan and wife are actually co-writers) it has a slightly improvisational feel (more "Curb your Enthusiasm" than "Big Bang Theory") in keeping with the slice-of-life theme and I'll be interested to see if they change the scene-transition music (or eliminate it altogether) because a busy episode means a fair amount of the only aspect of the show I didn't care for.Overall this felt very "lived-in" for a pilot, which certainly bodes well for the season and Gaffigan seems completely at ease in front of the television camera (not to mention he's frigg'n hilarious) and although his character is a comic portrayal of the not-so-ideal father he's definitely no Peter Griffin and consequently the humor centers more on the awkward than the absurd and I also found it refreshing that the family's religious beliefs figure prominently into their daily routine (OSV actually did an article on it) in a way that struck me as very natural (possibly even hip).Again, very entertaining pilot and if the season builds on the character of the original then I think TV Land is definitely making an improvement on the climate of television sitcoms.  :o)

Yes I received a free sample of "Naturalico anti-aging serum" in exchange for an honest review which doesn't affect my rating one, little bit as I am very pleased with the tightening/smoothing effects of this product (particularly around the eyes) and last but not least, it doesn't leave a residue as your skin absorbs it.  Also, I think the consumer is getting a pretty good deal with serum as opposed to cream anyway considering a single drop covers a relatively large area.  :o)

It's a familiar story... soldier returns from war to find his father's passed and the love of his life has moved on... oh, did I mention the conflict in question would be a little something we call the American Revolutionary War and this guy was on the losing side?Remember that super-hunky dwarf from Peter Jackson's recent Hobbit films (i.e. Kili played by Aidan Turner)?  Well now said actor has assumed the role of Ross Poldark, the war veteran mentioned above as well as the sole inheritor of an estate in ruin (including its debt) along with a generally ne'er-do-well reputation to live down.  What he does have going for him is a serious case of self-reliance, razor-sharp wit and enough determination to begin fixing up said inheritance (including a couple of abandoned mines) while taking time to lend a helping hand to a local urchin played by Eleanor Tomlinson ("Jack the Giant Slayer").Now if you've watched the season preview you learn the latter is a prospective love interest which I suspect will be the central theme drawing the majority of viewers (i.e. late 18th century romance) but for those not as excited about that aspect (myself included) I would point out that "Poldark" is a well-filmed, well-written (as it's based on a series of popular novels) period drama with an exceptional cast (emphasis on Turner and Tomlinson) and a revitalization story combined with a bit of liberation theme (in keeping with the protagonists view of the war) within a very class-bound setting, all of which works in creating what I thought was a very engaging first episode.TNT may claim to "know drama" but I think that Masterpiece Theater, in conjunction with the BBC, has a more distinguished and certainly longer history and "Poldark" is definitely another fine entry in that tradition. :o)

What an excellent innovation on a familiar theme... if only they worked.  I guess they work in the sense that you can use the solution to blow bubbles but as far as combing them, juggling, etc., didn't seem to work even with the glove (maybe we weren't holding our tongues right).  [I was given a free sample in exchange for an honest review].  :o)

I prefer functionality in a vehicle over appearance but let me just say I was a bit stoked when I received this steering wheel cover in exchange for an honest review cuz... it... looks.... faaaabulooous!Installation requires a bit of patience but it will make a snug fit and the end result is mega-comfy.  Regardless of where you place the patriotic air freshener I highly recommend you use it because there is a bit of odor associated with the cover.  My only complaint was that this only comes in one color but the company representative who sent me the sample assured me they will be releasing other colors in the future.  :o)

In the right hands the found footage method can yield some outstanding horror.  In the wrong hands we get a movie like "Day of the Mummy" which features lots of Egyptology sounding, made up stuff along with all the standard F.F. tropes of juvenile infighting, dialogue that relies on f**k for sentence structure, characters that could literally be dropped within just about any story setting and still lack credibility (Danny Glover in the standard Lance Henriksen role is embarrassingly bad and his acting is by far the best), etc., although I will grudgingly admit that the glasses/camera with a live feed was a cool innovation but not enough to give this stinker more than 1 star.I suggest you punch that nagging curiosity to rent "Day of the Mummy" squarely in the nose and wait for it to go Prime or Netflix.  :o)

In a horror movie world populated by mutants, aliens and werewolves we sometimes forget that the plain-old animals inhabiting our own national forests can be pretty, darn deadly.It's a relatively simple story; a couple from the city decides to take a weekend hiking trip at a nearby, national park... the guy gets in a little over his head trying to impress his girlfriend and they end up becoming lost.  This is a pretty decent drama based on nothing more than the interplay between the pair as they deal with a survival situation but I liked the added tension early on with the introduction of a territorial, tour guide providing a sort of clue to just how unprepared the male protagonist is at being the alpha.I honestly can't think of another film using bears as "monsters" other than 1966's "The Night of the Grizzly" or 1979's "Prophecy" (technically a mutant bear) and so first off I give writer/director Adam MacDonald props for originality as well as casting actors that give some very credible performances helping the viewer to really get in the moment of this relatively slow-building thriller.  Also, horror fans will recognize a nod to "You're Next" as the Meat Loaf-esque song from said film is playing on the radio during the trip to the park (which I sincerely hope is a coincidence rather than a potential convention indie producers will use for foreshadowing).  And just as a side note, please don't think this is some Syfy style of animal-gone-wild flick because the black bear is 100% real with zero CGI (that I could tell anyway) and so I also have to applaud this film for some excellent and extremely realistic choreography with a dang scary animal.At 92 minutes "Backcountry" features: cinematography easy on the eyes, a story that is relatively simple but well-executed, decent rewatchability factor, minimal gore and a remarkable under reliance on "adult" language (minus the occasional f-bomb) and is a great candidate for a movie-night rental.  :o)

"Something Wicked" is a sort of mindbender (possessing elements of horror) with a promising beginning including not only an allusion to Macbeth in the title but some fairly sophisticated Hitchockian opening credits followed by a quote from Aristotle, which all seem to indicate some fairly high-brow drama.Unfortunately, the suspenseful beginning and plot-twisted finale are like incoherent bookends of a slightly schizophrenic narrative whose sole purpose seems to be providing a vehicle for perving over Shantel van Santen ("Final Destination 4") best exemplified by a heavy dose of leer-cam, soft & squishy love interest (that keeps turning up in scenes unexpectedly), her brother (whose hobbies include window-peeking, philandery, watching his sister crack flossing with a lacy thong, etc.,), love interests' disturbed coworker (assisted by a creepy, mask-wearing sibling with a special power I call "dream giggling") and pretty much everyone else (almost looked like co-star Brittany Murphy was going down that road at one point as well).This one has decent production values and will certainly keep you engaged while trying to figure out exactly what the heck is going on but in the final analysis (and I mean that literally) I think the characters in this story (or possibly it was the actors portraying them) might be better suited to a film with either Scream in the title or bom-chicka-wow-wow in the background, because they felt really out of place in something trying to be a clever, psychological thriller (ironically resulting in the train wreck at the beginning becoming a sort of metaphor for what follows).  :o)

That was one of the many riffs on the gardener character (they dub Eric Clapton without pants) fairly early on that had me laughing for about 3 minutes.Where to begin, this episode was mega-funny beginning with a short starring no less than Gumbi featuring lots of hard and fast zingers that had me chuckling from the get-go (provides inspiration for a later skit) and portended great things to come.  The feature "The Screaming Skull" doesn't disappoint... at first that is, this one drags in the middle (due to some seriously uneventful scenes) which doesn't keep Mike and the bots from valiantly trudging through and helping this one to be fairly entertaining from start to finish.  Not quite a 5 star but easily a 4 and I could actually see myself adding this one to my permanent streaming collection of MST3K.  :o)

Musical tastes for both the area I live and the business where I work range from country/western to western/country and consequently when I listen to classical or jazz it's like scratching a chalkboard to my coworkers and so I've been thinking about buying a pair of Bluetooth earbuds and it just so happened along came an offer from Soundpeats audio for a pair of their "Q8 Wireless Sports Earphone" in exchange for an honest review.What's in the box (a very cool little box I might add): 2 earbuds (L & R clearly marked) with rubber ear cushions and hooks (extra set provided) so these puppies ain't falling out anytime soon, attached by a small but sturdy cable (21" when laid out flat) including a recharge port cleverly hidden in the right speaker and the controls (multi-function/sound+/-) are also part of the cable.  Additionally, I received the microphone complete with plastic ear attachment (for pairing with a cell-phone).Use is fairly intuitive and setup is simple in keeping with the simplicity of the device itself.  Place the left speaker in your ear (leaving the right one out to facilitate access to the controls) and press the multi-function button for approximately 5 seconds at which point a female, British voice announces "Power on" (accompanied by LED lights); approximately 2 seconds longer prompts the "pairing" mode (at which time you pair it with your device) and of course if you press the button again for 5 seconds it's "power off".  I'm writing this only from the perspective of listening to music via my Kindle Fire (I'm not interested in the calling options) and I thought the sound quality was excellent (approx. 50' range), volume control for the earbuds (used in conjunction with that on your device) conveniently provides a beep when you max either way.  I have found recharging is necessary with approximately 6 hrs. of continual use (there's also an audible reminder when the battery is low) and involves powering the buds down, plugging it in to the USB cable provided, at which point the LED lights red, blue indicates it's fully charged.Kudos to Soundpeats for such an excellently well-crafted, stylish and mega EZPZ to use Bluetooth headset that I absolutely love and have already recommended to several friends.  :o)

American soldiers stationed in the Middle East are fighting the ongoing war against extraterrestrial, squid-like Kaiju as well as local insurgents and the viewer is invited (rather forcefully I might add) to tag along.According to the movie summary at the top of this page (and IMDB) "Monsters: Dark Continent" is a sequel to the excellent 2010 "Monsters" although this one wasn't directed by Gareth Edwards and swings more towards action adventure than creature horror and includes a significantly higher density of "adult" content.  It sure would be cool if at some point one of these movies would give us at least one scientific character so we could get a little insight into what's going on (sequels are usually known for that) but instead we get a bunch of tools radiating testosterone and blowing up stuff (when they're not screaming or crying) all the while the camera is flailing chaotically to help the viewer "feel" the action... oh, and there's also some excellent CGI aliens usually off in the background which is prolly the only reason anyone would watch this in the first place."Dark Continent" obviously had a decent budget but unlike the first film, everyone in this one sucks... and by that I mean everyone, so that in the end I honestly didn't give a rats pajamas whether these "defenders of Earth" defeated any aliens and when the last 30 minutes introduced a sort of "Dances with Wolves" bonding-with-the-natives in an effort to engender sympathy, it was too little too late.  My advice is to watch the original again and skip this one.  :o)

Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region in Northwest China is a historical crossroads of cultures (having also been part of the Silk Road) and is currently experiencing, as part of the larger country's industrial revolution, the transition of a society on a course to modernity which inspired photojournalist Ryan Pyle to visually document this cultural time-capsule that will soon be gone.Beginning with a frenzied mix of urban marketplaces, the author shifts to the religious climate (predominantly Muslim) as the faithful in fur hats attend austere mosques leading into a contrast between archaic housing and the modern, earthquake resistant high-rises and office buildings (e.g. a child stands at the door of a very old house while new buildings line the opposite street on page 88-89) being constructed by workers looking as if they belong to a distant past.  The author then focuses on the culture's economic infrastructure beginning with pastoralism (pgs. 122-141) followed by artisans at work in traditional factories (featuring some of the more remarkable photography in my opinion) and then finally concluding the journey with pilgrimages though haunting desert landscapes.Kudos to author and photographer Ryan Pyle for this finely crafted, self-published title to which I give four stars for a fascinating tour of this unique culture as well as the inherent value of a visual record for future historians.  On the downside, considering that this is a completely visual look inside the culture, I didn't find the pictures for the most part particularly inspired... I mean yes, they're certainly better than what one would expect from tourists, but there was nothing that really captured the emotions of the changes taking place (apart from the happy little family on pages 86-87) nor stirred my own.I believe this book would be of value to those interested in this particular region of China as well as a contemporary study on the social effects of modernization, and I think it's a fine effort on the part of the author and I can honestly say I'm looking forward to future projects.  [I was given a copy of this book in exchange for an honest review]  :o)

Ok, I'm not saying that episode 9 "Pocket Listing" is one of the best I've ever seen... just that it had me laughing harder at the series than I have in a while not to mention that, due to the story complexity, it came awful close to feeling like an Archer mini-movie.  Love the larger role that Christian Slater is playing in the series (as he "plays" well against the other chars) and I thought this episode really showcased some of the exceptional animation that Floyd County Productions studio has been given us this season (special emphasis on Lana rock'n the maid outfit). Archer season 6 FTW!  :o)

The short "Body Care and Grooming" is a merciless, but hilarious look at a B&W educational film while the feature is a mega-lame, 50's-era, B-grade adventure flick titled "The Painted Hills", which is sort of like "Treasure of Sierra Madre" except with Lassie (playing the part of Shep... a dog).  This episode features some average riffing and occasional bursts of prolonged yucks with special emphasis on: working-the-gold-mine montage, the appearance of "Pile-on Pete" (who works as a "lawn-gnome in the summertime") and a post-attempted-murder of Lassie consolation of Tommy scene.I would mention the skits were fairly entertaining, especially when Dr. Forrester converts Frank's heart into a generator, but unfortunately I just didn't think this episode rated any higher than a 3 star so I'd recommend you rent before buying.  :o)

I was given a copy of "How Angels Die" (written by Guy Blews) in exchange for an honest review.This is a thought-provoking work about a very weighty subject focusing on one woman's struggle with MS eventually leading to her committing the very act that her boyfriend had so flippantly reserved for himself, ironically causing him to value life a bit more.  As the narrator, he moves from a sort of nihilistic philosophy of "I did not see the goodness in this world, I simply saw the pointless...  I know that life does not matter, but while I am here, I am determined it should be easy" to discovering a love he was reluctant to part with eventually leading to a sort of faith in human emotion: "Hope is the one thing that keeps humans alive, it is the intangible product of life that allows us to suffer interminably without giving up".The author possesses an engaging writing style that took me through the pages of a relatively depressing story and to his credit I felt like I really got to know these characters; but having gotten to know them I found I didn't particularly care for the contempt with which they tended to view those around them.  Also, I guess I was hoping for some redemptive quality or some moral to the story but instead it's tragedy without reprieve and although the narrator seems to have a change of heart regarding the value of a human life I suspect the author's intent was to teach a "lesson" to all those that think suicide is fundamentally wrong.I know this may sound a little clinical but it reflects the detachment I felt for the characters when I say that "How Angels Die" is a decent study in the motivations behind what drives one to commit suicide and the effects it can have on even the ultra-cynical.  :o)

For the record I'm not a fan of either the franchise mentioned in my title or writer/director Adam Green but I thought the preview for "Digging up the Marrow" looked pretty cool and I also noticed it had a actor in it I like (Ray Wise) so I figured I'd give it a shot.[spoiler-lite synopsis] A horror movie director (Green as himself) is contacted by an eccentric, retired detective (Wise) who claims to have tangible evidence that monsters actually exist and, in spite of the former's commitment to an upcoming, new television series, he simply can't resist the urge to grab his cameraman/partner and pay the guy a visit (recording it all in the FF style of course).  At first the duo suspect their new associate is completely delusional however he eventually takes them out monster hunting and after having a first-hand encounter, Green subsequently develops an insatiable desire for more, and more until...Aside from a central theme of the dangers inherent in chasing monsters, there's a mystery sub-plot (that's fairly transparent) adding some depth to the narrative which unfortunately doesn't help "Digging up the Marrow" avoid being mostly unsatisfying as horror in that the prevailing, lighthearted style seriously undermines any attempt at generating the necessary atmosphere.  Also, Green never shuts up (a fact which Wise actually comments on at one point) and considering he dominates screen-time, this movie almost felt like one, big selfie (with the occasional monster) and I can't help wondering what might've been if the writer (again... Green) had went more for creature/slasher/survival than pseudo-documentary.Although rocking some excellent creature FX, this movie ultimately left me flat and I personally couldn't see myself watching it again or really even remembering it two months from now.  My advice: wait for it on either Amazon Prime or Netflix but either way I wouldn't recommend paying the exorbitant rental fee being charged at the writing of this review.  :o)

It's amateur-grade horror (feels like a fan-film) featuring a strange amalgam of stock-characters and dialogue that puts the anal in banal, beginning at a cabin in the woods and eventually becoming a survival scenario with not-so-spooky American Indian tree-spirits.Sit in wide-eyed amazement as the foursome... talk about stuff, thrill as they... shuffle around the woods (and fall), marvel at the cinematography of leer-cam capturing cleavage in its natural environment,  be blown away by half-a** sound editing and FX that would totally wow a 5-year-old, scoot to the edge of your seat during a deadly game of Marco Polo resulting in a lone, female survivor (TOTALLY didn't see that coming) and an anticlimactic plot-twist followed by a second twist, and then a third.I wish I could figure out where the movie is that the people on this page are giving 5-stars to... all I could find was "Spectres" and it's only worth two.  :o)

Ok, if you can make it through the pervy opening credits (with its 80's synth music) you'll find a relatively clever b-grade (but not low-budget) slasher that is a sort of cautionary tale of a sleezy hobby gone horribly wrong.[spoiler-lite synopsis] The titular Girl House is a sort of Playboy Mansion for internet porn complete with plush accommodations, security guards and 24-hour surveillance, to provide the cyber audience with all the slice of life details they hunger for.  The viewer receives a whirlwind tour of the biz from the perspective of its newest girl (and central protagonist) Kylie, whose jaw-dropping debut is met with enthusiasm as she owns the mbps, including a devoted regular known as Loverboy.  Apparently, this particular fanboy spends so much cyber-time in the house that all the girls are a little affectionate towards him, however after seeing Kylie he falls in love and consequently makes the mistake of uploading his own rather disappointing pic to her pc, which another not-so-nice coworker spreads around thus makes LB a laughing stock.  This embarrassing event, along with being sexually bullied as a child and recently humiliated by a hot secretary for his workplace leering, causes a snap in his already tenuous mental stability and that's where the film (53 minutes in BTW) begins the descent into legit horror, and I mean big-time as LB (now sporting a creepy mask) breaks into G.H. and subsequently hacks and maims his way through its terrified residents."Girl House" gives us a killer both legitimately dangerous and pathetic who engages in some relatively creative (and moderately gory) kills and, as you can imagine, there's no shortage of T&A from a very attractive cast (all of whom can act) along with a bit of comedy relief provided by Kylie's love interest's BFF (who loves porn... if you can believe it) and "Gotham" fans will also recognize Camren Bicondova (Catgirl) as the bully from the killer's origin story.  So, probably not a good choice for a family night movie but hey... it is what it is... a fairly creative indie horror (with above average production values) that's definitely worth a rent.  :o)

[Horror movie screenwriter:] "I need to escape the pressures of London and reclaim my muse."[Mannish Realtor woman:] "This cottage is just the thing, oh and don't mind the elderly, blind woman that lives upstairs... who never leaves her room... and makes no noise... and doesn't require food."[Horror movie screenwriter:] "Hmmm... sounds reasonable, Sold!"[Too good to be true neighbor:] "Oh hey, I was picking berries in your yard, as opposed to going to a grocery store like normal people, and also using your tree-swing... hope ya don't mind."[Horror movie screenwriter:] "Hmmm... sounds reasonable, candlelit dinner?"- Later that evening...[Too good to be true neighbor:]  "I'm moderately attractive and so very lonely and I think I love you."[Horror movie screenwriter:] "Well I bathe infrequently and typically walk around in a hooded terrycloth  bathrobe and, what with my bald-spot and unkempt beard, possess all the raw sex appeal of a monk and it's totally reasonable that you would fall in love with me in just under two scenes heavy on padded dialogue and tedious pacing."[Blind woman upstairs:] *repeatedly plays records in the middle of the night from the 1920's even though that would make her like over 100*[Horror movie screenwriter:] "Somebody's playing records in the middle of the night and I bet this Ouija board will tell me why I'm having bad dreams"- Later during the climactic finale...[Mannish Realtor woman:] "Look at me, I'm Michael Myers"[Too good to be true neighbor:] "Look at me, I'm a corpse"[Horror movie screenwriter:] "Look at me, I'm hiding under the bed like a little girl"[Mannish Realtor woman:] "Look at me, I'm in a final scene that has zero continuity with the previous 10 minutes."- Fade to black. :o)

The peril of watching Nickelodeon with kids around Christmas time is that almost every commercial contains something they absolutely must have.  One of these perilous advertisements was for a cotton candy maker (with glow in the dark sticks) that we all agreed  looked mega-cool, but after doing a little research the consensus was to avoid that particular model.Further research eventually brought me to the Nostalgia Electrics Cotton Candy Maker and long story short, my nieces had a blast with it on Christmas Eve and several times since.  It's EZPZ to use (I do recommend adult supervision though) with the floss sugar, regular sugar or even jolly ranchers, peppermints etc.  Gotta be careful cuz it gets hot during use but is pretty simple to clean; also don't expect big, fluffy bouquets of cotton candy like you get at the fair, the payoff isn't huge, but for a small machine I think it's a pretty reasonable investment, not to mention it's rather stylish.  As of this review I'm giving it a 5-star but if it breaks down (as several reviews on this page warn) then I'll amend my rating accordingly.  :o)

Let's face it... the majority of zombie films that come out suck but every now and then the big studios produce something extraordinary and occasionally some independent studios do as well and such is the case with "Wyrmwood: Road of the Dead"[spoiler-lite synopsis]  The viewer is briefly introduced to a handful of characters in suburban Australia only to watch their world turned upside down by an extremely infectious, airborne virus and unless they're: wearing a mask, in an isolated area or immune (A- blood type)... they're dead (or more specifically undead) and although we're never told what actually happened (other than an anecdotal reference to Revelation 8:11) we do know that certain physical laws have been altered (e.g. gasoline is no longer flammable but zombie blood is).  These aren't zombies of the shambling variety but superhuman, extremely angry and very deadly but ironically the remaining government presence that's attempting to contain the situation is actually worse.  Said organization is travelling around in a mobile medical research unit led by a bizarre scientist who through some twist of fate actually manages to create a woman that can control the undead mentally (cool innovation).  Several of the survivors eventually unite into an armored death squad, one of whom is the brother of the chick that is for all intents a bona-fide necromancer and that's when they..."Wyrmwood" is heavy on exciting action and pretty dang gory but it also doesn't take itself overly serious (almost has an Evil Dead feel at times) and is one of THE most original zombie flicks I've seen in awhile and just one more example of all the good international horror on the scene these days.  :o)

Ok, so maybe "Frankenstein Vs. the Mummy" doesn't have the pageantry of a Hammer film or the entertainment value of a Universal monster flick but neither is it a stinky, low-budget cheese-festival.[mild-spoiler synopsis]  Victor Frankenstein is a professor (of medicine?) at an unnamed university and practices reanimation as a hobby; a fellow professor and close, personal friend is Dr. Naihla Khalil an Egyptologist who has recently been part of an expedition which discovered the mummified remains of a 3,000 year-old pharaoh.  Oh ya, did I mention that they're in love, cuz you're gonna spend a fair amount of time with these two talking, dining, shagging, etc., but it's all part of getting to know the two central characters; one with noble aspirations the other not so much.  After being forced to murder a gross body-snatcher (and steal his brain), Frankenstein completes his monster (yes... they managed to squeeze in "it's alive!") who is strangely reminiscent of Regan from the exorcist's head on a professional wrestlers body; the mummy just needs the heart of a nave undergrad and he's good to go.  Both are evil, both have superhuman strength and both (as with so many monster movies) are smitten with the pretty girl and when they collide (last 11 minutes BTW) it's a fairly cool monster brawl that unfortunately doesn't last long.Be aware "FVM" does rock some fairly convincing gore that occasionally had me cringing (this is coming from someone who watches tons of horror) but overall it's a cool premise for a modern B-grade monster flick and is it just me or does anyone else think these classic monsters would make great candidates for slasher movies?  :o)

So you know all those horror movies where they call in a priest to see if a place is haunted and he tells them something like "the church will need to investigate these claims to see if they're real"... well, this is a story about one of those teams actually engaged in fieldwork.[Mild-spoiler synopsis] Deacon (played by Gordon Kennedy from BBC's "Robin Hood") is a paranormal investigator for the Vatican and is joined by a snarky tech guy and a no-nonsense priest to look into a potential miracle at a small 13th century church that has been recently re-opened for the first time in over a century by one Father Crellick.  In spite of experiencing some strange phenomena during the investigation they decide to declare the situation a hoax until the resident priest commits suicide; an event which causes Deacon to question his own skepticism and provokes a decision to conduct another investigation.... at night.  After being literally scared out of the place (and this guy is no coward), Deacon decides to call in an expert on church history and the supernatural (one Father Calvino) and upon their return to the church things completely go to hell (and I don't mean that just figuratively).Technically "Final Prayer" is found footage as the entire narrative plays through a multitude of personal and strategically placed cameras however it defies the subgenre by first of all employing bona-fide grown up and professional actors and secondly by writing the characters being portrayed so that even in spite of clashing personalities they ultimately have to cooperate.  I found it to be a subtle but effectively spooky supernatural horror that is also a fairly clever mystery to boot and I would definitely recommend it for a rental.  Enjoy!  :o)

These are quite possibly the best noodles on the planet and seriously, 30 pkgs for what they're selling at... bar-gain!!!  But what I really love is that the hot spices are in a separate package (which is unusual for lots of Asian noodles) so you can toss those little heartburns-waiting-to-happen and still enjoy.  :o)

What started out in 2014 as an under-the-radar, summer series has apparently garnered enough popularity in the U.K. and abroad for BBC America to not only produce a second season but place it toe-to-toe with all the domestic heavy-hitters in the second half of Winter season 2014/2015.Although very entertaining, season one was at times balanced on a knife's edge of becoming a vehicle for action-stunts and clichd one-liners however the narrative seems to have moved past things like D'artagnan's adolescent desire to become a musketeer or over-the-top, fork dueling and looks as if the story arc is swinging more towards large-scale political intrigue.  Producers Adrian Hodges and Jessica Pope continue to cultivate a big-screen feel (special emphasis on episode 2 "An Ordinary Man"), while the writers are bringing a slightly more mature tenor (less the overreliance on "adult" content) and If anyone's wondering what happened to Peter Capaldi (a.k.a. Cardinal Richelieu) he's conveniently and mysteriously died between seasons as the BBC pulled him over to Doctor Who (helping to get the last few nails in that coffin).Following the events of episode 12 from the previous season, Milady de Winter (heavy on villain short on seductress) is back with a vengeance creating scheming subplots, there's also a welcome addition of Marc Warren as Comte de Rochefort (giving a slightly unhinged performance), King Louis (Ryan Gage) is moving from buffoonery to legitimate tyranny and although I said it when I reviewed the first season, I'll reemphasize that the four guys playing the musketeers have some real chemistry and it's just a pleasure to tag along on their adventures.I'm not the BBC fan I used to be, however I'm definitely along for the ride on Musketeers and I still say this show has the coolest opening credits of anything on TV.[Update 3/22/15]  An epic, exciting and at times bittersweet finale has rounded up this exceptional second season of The Musketeers and may I say I'm even more devoted to this series than I was when I posted my initial review.  There were some very remarkable scenes in episode 10 "Trial and Punishment" that reemphasize the thoughtful writing and creative energy invested in this show and I'm very glad to hear that BBC America will be renewing for a third season.  :o)

"Thriller" was a suspense-drama of the anthology variety that ran on NBC from 1960 to 1962 and was hosted by legendary horror actor Boris Karloff.  Ya, that's great and all but here's what you need to know; when the episodes focused on murder-mystery it was reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock Presents but when it focused on horror... Whoa!!Something about black & white raises the creepy factor anyway and the stories were typically inspired and  captivating ("Child's Play" being an exception) and although I would recommend the entire season  the following episodes are particularly remarkable:  "The Purple Room" which is a good haunted house, "The Watcher" a suspenseful slasher, "The Hungry Glass" a paranormal tale about a vengeful house, "The Devil's Ticket" fairly self-explanatory, "The Terror in Teakwood" a supernatural story of morbid obsession, "Dark Legacy" occult thriller, "Pigeons from Hell" one of the best haunted house shows you'll ever watch and finally "The Grim Reaper" which stars William Shatner in a dang good supernatural story about an evil painting.Be aware that this is NOT the entire series (there are 30 more episodes) and hopefully Amazon will eventually make season 2 available for streaming soon but in case you're eager for the complete set then check out Thriller: The Complete Series.  :o)

Camp - a style or mode of personal or creative expression that is absurdly exaggerated and often fuses elements of high and popular culture.Warning: this mid-60's, live-action superhero/adventure series must be viewed in light of the above definition to be completely enjoyed.The appeal of "Batman" isn't just for D.C. comics fans or those of nostalgia television in general or even this show's particularly influential if not monolithic status even in today's popular culture (Family Guy wouldn't be the same without Mayor West) but it's also downright fun with a capital F and suitable for all ages (kids are naturally drawn to it) and oh, by the way... see how voluptuous the colors are on the cover art at the top of this page?  Well, that's exactly how the show looks in HD; it's a delight for the eyes as it jumps off the screen and into your living room and oh my, did I mention the cavalcade of famous actors that guest-starred on this show on a regular basis (not to mention all the babes... giggity), and then there's the amount of episodes in a season for the price here on Amazon... "holy bargain-basements Batman!".I was born too late to have enjoyed the series when it originally aired but I do remember watching it in syndication as a kid and being in perpetual wide-eyed amazement that ABC used to produce shows of this caliber when the ones of my own childhood were so incredibly lame but thankfully "Batman's" knack for generating fond, viewing memories can be enjoyed by any generation and is FINALLY available for binge-streaming on Amazon.  Enjoy!  :o)

This is a mystery investigation show that distinguishes itself from so many others by engaging more in finding evidence than in endless speculation or bombarding our senses with historical recreations, shaky cameras in backwoods areas chasing "what was that... did you hear that", foreboding music, medieval art etc.Brothers Jim and Bill Vieira make no pretense at being anything more than amateur investigators (they're actually professional stone-masons) but what they lack in formal credentials they make up for in zeal and an uncanny ability to maintain focus on their primary goal which is to obtain tangible evidence of giant human remains in North America.  I find it refreshing how they constantly submit their findings to professional geologists, anthropologists, forensic professionals and a host of other giant-hunting enthusiasts and that they include the viewing audience in their research of historical documents rather than simply saying what they learned."Search for the Lost Giants" certainly stimulates the imagination as well as piques the adventurous spirit in us all and the payoff is that we actually get some results and even learn a bit about our nation's more obscure history.  Kudos History Channel on such an enjoyable new series!  :o)

It's 2033 A.D., just ten years after the USDF (United Space Defense Force) successfully repels an invasion from outer space leaving behind only a few pockets of alien resistance.  Unfortunately, more than a decade of peace has not only produced planet-wide memory loss, in that outposts which once provided defense are now largely abandoned, but once again Earth's resident population begins to turn on one another.IFC Midnight delivers a visually remarkable and fairly original indie sci-fi, combining a sort of war docudrama with space invasion that's told largely from a pair of embedded journalist's point of view.  Battle scenes are surprisingly realistic, aliens are large, heavily armored reptiles that look pretty darn cool, however the story itself is relatively unimpressive (more like an episode from a weekly television series).  Also, not much in the way of sympathetic characters or heroes to root for in "Alien Outpost"; basically war-weary, cynical and ill-tempered soldiers in a desperate, combat situation that kinda made me think "if this is humanity's last, best hope... think I'll join the aliens".  :o)

This is a fairly middling Joel Era episode where the majority of really good riffing escalates during like the last 20 minutes of the film along with Peter Breck's (Nick from The Big Valley) hammy over-acting; not a bad episode mind you... just a bit on the slow side.  As one might imagine there's more than a few Howl references, the fusion of opening theme to The Jetsons and the big-band score towards the end was hilarious, the timid little hotel manager almost doesn't need help from the bots and I think it's worth mentioning that Joel gets most of the laughs on this one (for a change) and Magic Voice is a pre-Pearl Mary Jo Pehl. :o)

Helen may have been the face that launched a thousand ships but she's plain as a paper bag next to the mega-hot Achilles played by Brad Pitt, who in this film (at age 40) is the definitive rock-star, radiating more sheer sex-appeal and charisma than a night at the Grammys and absolutely convincing as the deadliest warrior on the Mediterranean."Troy" may not be the most reliable source for gaining a deeper understanding of Homer's masterpiece; the battles don't possess a fraction of the Iliad's brilliance while most of the heroes are omitted (including my fav Diomedes) not to mention the Trojan horse is technically in the Odyssey etc., but make no mistake it IS a visually gorgeous, historical epic with just a dash of fantasy thrown in.  It is also the performance of a lifetime, featuring a gorgeous and talented movie-star in the prime of life which parallels (albeit on a smaller scale) the character being portrayed, thus lending legitimate hubris and helping "Troy" transcend what would've otherwise been a fairly mediocre production and maybe even pushes it towards a modern classic (although Leonard Maltin would prolly never say that).  :o)

I received 180 capsules of Garcinia Cambogia from Omega Soul in exchange for an honest review so (honestly) I'm not gonna say they're a wonder-pill (I have no idea if they actually stopped "fat being made") however I can confidently state that they succeed in suppressing hunger (which is great when you're at work and don't want to be constantly hassled by a growling stomach) and are best taken twice daily (morning and late afternoon for me) and considering the quantity (90 day supply if 2/day) I do think the price is a legitimate bargain.  :o)

Stylistically "The Town that Dreaded Sundown" (2014) is a sort of homage horror that combines 70's fashions (monochrome, polyester pant-suits and butterfly collars) in a 2013 setting, and includes some horror alumni's such as Veronica Cartwright ("Alien", "Invasion of the Bodysnatchers") and Danielle Harris ("Halloween IV", V, etc.,).More than just a slasher, this film adds legitimate suspense in the form of a high-profile murder investigation but where it really shines is in the acting (not a single b-movie performance to be found) with special emphasis on the main protagonist (Addison Timlin) who, in keeping with the general attempt at recreating a 70's feel, kinda reminded me of a young Margot Kidder.  The gore is more on the subtle side as opposed to shock-fest whereas the dialogue demonstrates a shocking dearth of profanity and although there's some shagging, the scenes are plot-driven rather than gratuitous given the killer typically likes to do his thing while folks are doing theirs.  Memorable Sundown scenes include: re-creation of a famous kill from the original 1976 film, woman with a compound fracture hunted down in a motel parking lot, love interest being stalked while walking through a series of motion-sensor lights and the final chase between the heroine and the killer (can I call him "sack-head"?).You don't need to be a fan of the original to enjoy this sequel; it's an excellent stand-alone movie and is also further evidence that 2014 was a dang good year for domestic horror.  :o)

In 2011 DC Comics initiated the "New 52" reboot of all their titles including Aquaman, a superhero that previously seemed like a fish out water (pun intended), and anyone who read that first issue had to pick their jaw up off the floor (I remember my fav comic store being constantly sold out) seeing this reinvigorated character leaping through the city streets (Incredible Hulk style) and basically looking and being awesome.  A prevalent theme for said comic has been the struggle for Atlantis which is also the driving force behind 2015's "Throne of Atlantis".This film is a sequel to "Justice League: War" however the two couldn't be further apart, a fact best demonstrated by the "rebooted" following themes: Shazaam is awesome again and his nose is no longer nestled between Cyborgs cheeks (not so much anyway), Lantern is voiced by Nathan Fillion (which all alone improves the overall quality of the character and the film in general), Superman and Wonderwoman actually engage in grown-up dialogue (not to mention a scene with Diana rock'n the hot bespectacled look) and I thought it was cool how they tried to recreate the magic of a now legendary kiss made famous by issue 12 of Justice League, the repartee between Lantern and Batman is entertaining as opposed to inane and we get the feeling that once again Earth is being protected by bona fide grown-ups as opposed to clich-spouting, not-particularly-intelligent pre-teens.Considering there are no less than 8 phenomenal superheroes (9 if you include Mera) in this film, not to mention all the Atlantean celebrities, I think that director Ethan Spaulding and screenwriter Heath Corson did an excellent job bringing a bit of depth, development and not to mention some legitimate wit across the board to these characters, which is especially impressive given the scope of the story and the 70 minute run-time.  I also appreciated how the forces of Atlantis were presented as being legitimately formidable and even capable of defeating the JL in a contest of brute force causing the latter to lean towards strategy.  I would actually put "TOA" on a par with "Flashpoint Paradox" when it comes to an engaging story and regarding visuals, basically it's the exceptional character rendering from "War" and the flawless animation sequences except this one was written for adults as opposed to... whoever "War" was written for (need to delete that one from my library) and I also wanna mention that composer Frederick Wiedmann gives us a pretty darn good score for a direct-to-video animated, action movie.I suspect you can tell that I thoroughly enjoyed "TOA" and again... all the more so considering its prequel was so incredibly bad, but the sequel is easily a stand-alone flick (particularly if you're a DC fan) and I just gotta say that it reaffirms my love, bordering on unhealthy obsession, for all things DC.  :o)

Great set of bowls!!  These are great for mixing, with an electric hand mixer, I don't have to worry about the mixer heads scratching off flecks of metal like I did with my previous set of mixing bowls.  They freeze and thaw soups and freeze ice cream.  The bowls are microwave safe and oven safe (without the lids) as well as dishwasher safe.  The only thing I would suggest is not going from having these in the freezer and then going straight into the microwave or oven, just to prevent them from cracking.  I'd try to let things thaw a little before.  Overall I'm very pleased with these bowls.*I took photos of the largest and smallest bowl. I wanted to take pictures of the middle two sizes but I used them immediately after opening them and just took photos of the largest and smallest before putting them away.  Hopefully it can just give a general idea as to how big they all age._______________Made by: PyrexSize: 8 piece setStyle Name: With LidProduct Packaging: Standard PackagingSold by: Amazon.com LLCShipped by: Amazon.com LLCDelivered: 4 days after order date

Nice case!  Works well - holds my Dragon Touch snuggly.  Although it's not the highest quality (I think it's actually pleather instead of real leather), but it gets the job done and it protects the tablet well.  I haven't had any problems with my Dragon Touch slipping around, nor is it difficult to press any of the buttons or access any of the plugs/outlets around the edges.  Overall, for the price, this is a good case.  It's not a $20 case or more, but it's a good for the price._________________Made by: TabSuitMade in: ChinaColor: BlackASIN: B00B2VMJ00Item model number: TS-CA-7a13Provided for review by: TabletExpressShipped by: TabletExpress

Very nice knee sleeve.  I tore my ACL snowboarding 5 years ago and from time to time need a little extra support and compression on my knee.  I like using this running/jogging - mostly in colder weather.  I'm 5'6'', 130 lbs and measure 13'' around the lower part of my thigh about 4'' above the center of my knee cap and I ordered a size Medium.  It fits well - although it does make the  lower part of my thigh look somewhat sausage-like or like a muffin top, but it's still comfortable and I feel it's the right size on me.The only thing I don't like about these are that it says "Hand wash only."  I'm hoping that my washer being a front-loading tumbling washer will be okay for washing this as I plan to put it in a delicate mesh garment washer bag.  I will update this review if washing them this way proves to be a mistake.  Until then, so far so good.  Overall this is a great, quality knee sleeve._____________Made by: BracooMade in: TaiwanSize: MediumColor: GrayASIN: B00NC6PAUEUPC: 819567010663Item model number: RK292Provided for review by: ComfytopiaShipped by: Amazon LLC

I was kindly supplied this item free of charge to test and evaluate. In exchange, I agreed to provide an honest review detailing my thoughts.  This is said review.These are nice headphones - but they aren't my favorite.  I can only compare them to the Bose QuietComfort 15 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones which I love.  These are okay, and for the price I'd say they are good, but they are definitely not noise cancelling.  Besides that, these headphones have a great quality of sound, very clear, crisp sound.  There are two things I don't like about these headphones, one being the ear cushions are completely flat -- they don't curve to the shape of your head at all.  And the second one is the +/-  volume button does not turn the volume up and down when these are plugged in to my computer.  I have to press either the up or down (+/-) volume buttons on the cord at least 5 or 6 times to get the volume to click once.  Not sure if this is a defective cord or what the issue is, but it is not nearly as responsive as I would expect since it does not turn the volume up or down with each time the + or - buttons on the cord are pressed.I do really like the style and the sleek look of these headphones and the case they come in.  But for the reasons listed above I don't think they will replace my Bose anytime soon._______________Made by: SenteyMade in: ChinaASIN: B014LMX5AYItem model number: LS-4430Sold by: SenteyShipped by: Amazon LLC

This TGM LED 4 watt light bulb gives off a nice warm glow. Although it is somewhat dim for a lamp with a darker or less translucent shade, it looks beautiful in any transparent globe or clear glass shade. It even looks nice just alone because it is not too bright.  I really like that it is LED because it doesn't ever flicker and I know it will last a long time.  Very pleased with this bulb.______________Made by: TGMSize: G14 4W=40W(1Pack)Color: Soft WhiteASIN: B00YCCV26IProvided for review by: TGM LEDShipped by: Amazon LLC

Great book!! Much better than Master The Boards. It has a lot of color, color pictures and color coded sections. It's great for individual clinical rotations. The subject content is only actually 311 pages and it's less than an inch thick.  Its subjects/sections are listed as the following:Cardiovascular DisordersPulmonary DisordersGastrointestinal DisordersGenitourinary DisordersEndocrine DisordersHematology and OncologySelected Topics in Emergency Medicine, Critical Care, and SurgeryNeurologic DisordersMusculoskeletal DisordersDermatologyGynecologic and Breast DisordersObstetricsPediatricsPsychiatric DisordersEpidemiology and EthicsOverall I'm very happy with this book and would definitely recommend it if you're going to do clinical rotations and/or take Step 2._____________________________________Copyright 2016 Wolters Kluwer, 4th EditionISBN-10: 149630974XISBN-13: 978-1496309747Sold by: Amazon.com LLCShipped by: Amazon LLC

These are awesome little lights.  They actually were able to blink right out of the box even though I hadn't put the solar panel in the sun yet -- although I turned them off and let them charge before testing the blinking settings.  These worked inside if the the solar panel is kept in a window that gets a decent amount of sunlight, or outside.  Not only is it solar powered but it only turns on when it's dark outside.  Well, technically it can be turned on while it's light inside or outside if the solar panel is covered so light isn't shining on it, but then you would have to make sure to uncover it so it can charge.  Just face the solar panel towards the sun or facing directly up and turn it on, it won't turn on or start blinking until the sun goes down and the solar panel "sees" that it's dark.  I just really like not having to hassle with timers to turn on outside lights on or using extension cords throughout the yard.____________________Made by: BESTECHNOMade in: ChinaColor: Cool WhiteASIN: B015FSYKZ2Item model number: 200LEDSample provided by: BESTECHNOShipped by: Amazon LLC

These are very comfortable compression socks.  I'm 5'6'', 130 lbs and wear a size 8.5 shoe.  I ordered a size Medium and they fit well.  They provide the most compression in the ankle and above but do not provide much compression in the toes or the arch.  I am actually that these aren't very tight in the toes because I already have trouble keeping my toes warm in the winter and in general.  These are a very nice quality compression sock  - -- they are thick and soft.  The thickness is great in that it can be worn in different types of shoes - it's not too thick in the ankle region to where it will make everyday shoes feel too tight.The only thing I don't like about these are that it says do not machine wash.  I don't hand wash my socks, and so I'm hoping that my washer being a front-loading tumbling washer will be okay for washing these as I plan to put them in a delicate mesh garment washer bag.  I will update this review if washing them this way proves to be a mistake.  But overall I am very pleased with these socks._____________Made by: FyttoMade in: TaiwanSize: MediumColor: BlackASIN: B00NTTI9YSUPC: 819567010755Item model number: PTI1080Product provided for review by: ComfytopiaShipped by: Amazon LLC

This is a nice earring/jewelry holder it gets the job done but it doesn't look like it's high quality.  I'm not sure if I will keep this in a cupboard or out in the open because it does looks somewhat cheap -- I think mostly because the entire thing is acrylic - including the hinges.  If the hinges were a metal then I think this would look nicer.  I think this would be great for a little girl or teenager to display her jewelry.  Overall I think it's just a matter of preference, but for the price I think it's a good holder.I took a picture with a pen just to give a size reference.  For some reason I thought it was going to be taller than it was, which I'm glad it's the size that it is - it's only 11'' tall, so it's not huge._________________Made by:  BeautifyMade in: ChinaItem model number: 10/043ASIN: B014UU46M8Product provided for review by: Designer HabitatShipped by: Amazon LLC

These are beautiful curtains!  They are very well made, the fabric is thick and soft, I absolutely love them.  They are thick and definitely don't let light through. I was kindly supplied this item free of charge to test and evaluate.  In exchange, I agreed to provide an honest review detailing my thoughts.  This is said review.Overall this is a nice tablet and it's a good price for what you get.  It works well and it's fast.  My only issue with it is that it wants to allow Google to track everything you do.  You have to have a Google account to download any apps or to even access the app/play store.  I had no problem connecting it to wireless internet or using the web browser.  I was surprised when it was charged and then I didn't use it for 4-5 days and when I picked it up the battery was dead.  Overall the graphics are nice, it's not a retina display but the graphics are good.  There are many options of images to use for the background image, some of which are moving background images you can choose.  The display flips from landscape to portrait and back very quickly and fluidly.  For the price this is a great little tablet.  I think it would be good for kids or maybe older individuals who may not use a tablet often or may not need a lot of memory.  This has 8GB of memory, whereas my phone has 16GB and I'm always running out of space so I'm sure this will quickly run out of space if I download apps or take a number of pictures.______________________Made by: Dragon TouchMade in: ChinaASIN: B015K35QBOSold by:  TabletExpressShipped by:  TabletExpress

Pick the size based on your WAIST measurement -- the hip and bust measurements given in the Product Description threw me off. These are very nice wireless headphones. The sound is good and they have a nice sleek design. On to the pros and cons...***PROS*** Good quality sound through the headphones themselves. My phone and laptop found the headphones very easily and paired with them in seconds -- It comes up in the bluetooth as "QY8". They charged in about 10-15 min. There is a red light that is on when they are charging and then it turns blue when they are done charging. Great for working out because you never have to worry about the cord and if you're using your phone you can have it across the room, you don't have to carry it or keep it on you the whole time. The volume buttons on these are conveniently on one of the ear pieces and the + is represented by two raised dots '..' and the minus volume button is one single raised dot. Unlike some of the other wireless headphones I've tried, the raised parts to quickly identify if you're pressing to increase or decrease the volume are prominent to the touch as to not mistake which part of the button you're pressing.***CONS*** There is a little plastic cap/plug that covers where you insert the micro USB to charge the headphones that is difficult to remove/open without a knife, small finger nails or pick of some sort -- it's just really small and there is no lip or area to grab or pull on to remove it to charge the headphones - (I may just end up cutting it off because it does not making charging these as easy as charging a phone). Unlike some of the other headphones I've tried, these started to hurt my ears after wearing them for a few hours. I kept taking one out and just rubbing the inside of my ear because it just felt sore, I'm not sure if this has to do with the fact that the hard plastic speaker part that is covered by the rubber ear plug is larger in diameter than some other of the other speakers themselves. Although I didn't have any issues with these falling out easily or becoming loose and having to push them back in compared to some other ear bud-style headphones.______________Made by: CakaMade in: ChinaColor: WhiteASIN: B00YPT5IA4Item model number: dgf34Product provided for review by: CakaShipped by: Amazon LLCDelivered: 3 days after order date
